BC-Rwanda-Genocide,0206
Report: Rwandan convicted of genocde attempts suicide
KIGALI, Rwanda (AP) _ A Rwandan who was convicted and sentenced to death for his role in thecountry's 1994 genocide has attempted suicide by seizing the steering wheel in a police car, a news agency reported. In the Monday incident, Geoffrey Gatera, a former surgeon, seriously injured three pedestrians, but escaped injury, the private Rwandan News Agency reported. Gatera was convicted Monday on charges of genocide and crimes against humanity. On the way to prison, he seizing the wheel from a police driver and tried to run the vehicle off the road. The driver was not injured, the news agency reported. Gatera became the 91st genocide convict sentenced to death since the Tutsi rebels seized power in July 1994 after the former Hutu government organized the slaughter of 500,000 people. Firing squads publicly executed the first 22 convicts on April 24. In total, 130,000 people are awaiting trial in overcrowded jails throughout Rwanda. Gatera was accused of taking part in the massacres of Tutsis at the Butare University hospital, 75 kilometers (45 miles) south of Kigali, where he was working at the time.

BC-Philippines-Deficit
IMF predicts large Philippine deficit unless taxes are raised
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ The International Monetary Fund fears the Philippines will suffer a large budget deficit this year unless steps are taken to improve tax collection, according to a finance official. An IMF team was in the Philippines late last month to review the economy's performance as part of conditions for a dlrs 1.37 billion standby loan arrangement. The finance official, who asked not to be named, said late Monday that the IMF believes that efforts to improve tax collection are not working and as a result the Philippines could end up in the red. The IMF has forecast that the deficit could reach 50 billion pesos (dlrs 1.3 billion) this year unless the government improves revenue collection by plugging loopholes and cracking down on tax evaders. The government of President Fidel Ramos passed a tax reform package last December, but officials close to President-elect Joseph Estrada say the reforms were not successful in sufficiently broadening the tax base. Tax rates are generally high, causing many people to evade or cheat on taxes. Estrada, currently vice president, takes office on June 30 after winning the presidential election on May 11. In April, the government raised 55.6 billion pesos (dlrs 1.4 billion) in tax revenues, 11.3 billion pesos (dlrs 290 million) short of what it expected. In the first quarter, the Philippines registered a budget deficit of 12.3 billion pesos (dlrs 315 million), with the government predicting a small budget surplus by the end of the year. The Philippines posted a budget surplus of 1.6 billion pesos (dlrs 41 million) in 1997 and 6.3 billion pesos (dlrs 161 million) in 1996.

BC-Sports-Baseball-NL Roundup,0679
Pirates halt Mets winning streak with 4-3 victory
PITTSBURGH (AP) _ Jason Schmidt, the NL's hottest pitcher, beat the league's hottest team as the Pittsburgh Pirates halted the New York Mets' nine-game winning streak with a 4-3 victory. The Mets' streak was the longest in the majors and covered Mike Piazza's first seven games in New York. Schmidt (8-1), the NL's first eight-game winner, had a shutout until Piazza homered with two outs in the eighth. Schmidt gave up six hits before leaving in the ninth following a leadoff single by Carlos Baerga and a double by Edgardo Alfonzo. After reliever Ricardo Rincon retired pinch-hitter Butch Huskey on a popup, Rey Ordonez hit a grounder to shortstop Kevin Polcovich, whose wild throw to first allowed Baerga to score. Jim Tatum then hit a sacrifice fly to make it 4-3 before Rincon got Brian McCrae on a forceout to earn his fourth save. Phillies 6, Expos 2 In Philadelphia, Gregg Jefferies homered and snapped an eighth-inning tie with an RBI single as the Phillies beat the Montreal Expos. Scott Rolen followed Jefferies' hit with a three-run homer off Mike Maddux (1-2) as the Phillies snapped a three-game losing streak. Desi Relaford singled with one out in the eighth, moved to second on a wild pitch and went to third on a groundout. After Doug Glanville walked, Jefferies singled to center, scoring Relaford. Rolen then hit an 0-1 pitch over the left field wall for his 11th home run. Wayne Gomes (4-1) allowed one hit in two innings of scoreless relief. Cubs 10, Marlins 2 In Chicago, Sammy Sosa, returning to the lineup after missing three games with a sprained thumb, continued his long-ball binge with two homers as the streaking Cubs beat the slumping Florida Marlins. Sosa hit a two-run shot in the first and a three-run homer in the eighth, his 14th and 15th this year. It was the third time in his last four games that Sosa has hit two homers. Henry Rodriguez hit a two-run homer in the first and an RBI double in the fifth as the Cubs won their fourth straight and handed the Marlins their sixth consecutive loss. Jeremi Gonzalez (4-5) ended a personal three-game losing streak, giving up two runs and five hits in 7 2-3 innings. Ryan Dempster (0-1) lasted 1 1-3 innings in his first major league start, giving up five runs, four hits and three walks. Braves 5, Brewers 2 In Milwaukee, Atlanta's Greg Maddux pitched a five-hitter and won his sixth straight game as the Braves beat the Brewers. Maddux (8-2) struck out a season-high 10, one short of his career best, and didn't walk a batter in helping snap the Braves' four-game skid and Milwaukee's five-game winning streak. Maddux came within one out of his 25th career shutout before Jeromy Burnitz hit a two-run homer. Maddux took a line drive off his left hip from Mark Loretta in the sixth, but third baseman Chipper Jones made a diving grab for the out and Maddux, unhurt, pumped his right fist in congratulations. Former Brewers pitcher Don Sutton, now a member of the Braves broadcast crew, threw out the ceremonial first pitch before the Braves played their first game in Milwaukee since bolting to Atlanta following the 1965 season. Diamondbacks 6, Rockies 4 In Denver, Andy Benes pitched a eight strong innings, Devon White drove in two runs and the Arizona Diamondbacks snapped a three-game losing streak. Kelly Stinnett added a solo homer for the expansion Diamondbacks, who gained some revenge for being swept by Colorado in their season-opening, three-game series in Phoenix. Benes (4-5), outpitched by Colorado's Darryl Kile in the Diamondbacks' franchise opener, prevailed over Kile in the rematch. After giving up a homer to Dante Bichette in the first, Benes settled down and at one point retired 13 straight batters. With Arizona leading 6-1 in the ninth, Benes gave up three hits, including a three-run homer by Vinny Castilla. Gregg Olson got the last two outs for his seventh save. MORE

BC-Australia-Queensland Election, 1st Ld-Writethru
Poll: Hanson splits conservatives, Labor Party to take Queensland
Eds: CORRECTS 4th graf to say `no parole' instead of `new parole'
BRISBANE, Australia (AP) _ A new poll released Tuesday predicted Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party will split the conservative vote in Queensland's June 13 election, lifting the opposition Labor Party to power. If Labor ousts conservative Premier Rob Borbidge's government, it will be a bad omen for the nationwide chances of Prime Minister John Howard and his conservatives in the federal election expected later this year. Whether or not Hanson's party, famous for its anti-gun control, anti-Asian immigration, and anti-Aboriginal welfare policies wins any seats itself, it would have made a major impact on Australia's political landscape. In an effort to win back potential One Nation voters, Borbidge has been talking tough on crime, unveiling new legislation to make sure violent criminals serve their entire sentence with no parole. Labor and Borbidge's conservatives currently hold 44 seats each in the state's 89-seat Parliament; Borbidge has governed only because a single conservative independent member of Parliament has voted with his side. The Newspoll survey in The Australian newspaper shows support for the governing conservative coalition in big-city Brisbane seats dropped from 42 percent to 25 percent while Labor had soared from 49 to 54 percent. The Newspoll showed support for Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party had tripled to 15 percent in the past six months statewide, and almost doubled to 7 percent nationally in the past two weeks. In Queensland rural areas, support for the governing conservatives had slumped from 54 percent to 41 percent. Borbidge told Australian Broadcasting Corp. radio Tuesday that it looked like his party was ``behind the eight ball.'' The poll was conducted last weekend by telephone to 1,007 Queensland households. Newspoll said the margin of error on various questions ranged from 3 to 4.4 percent, depending on the number of respondents. The poll suggests the Labor Party under Peter Beattie would gain enough seats to hold a comfortable majority even if One Nation Party wins several seats on its own, thus denying Hanson the balance of power.

BC-Australia-Funeral-Infection Threat
Commiseration kisses may have spread meningococcal infection
HOBART, Australia (AP) _ Hundreds of mourners may have been exposed to a potentially fatal disease at a funeral in Tasmania state, health authorities said Tuesday. Health officials are trying to locate up to 300 people who attended the funeral after a 76-year-old woman at the service was admitted to Launceston General Hospital on May 28 with meningococcal infection. It is believed the woman kissed most or all of the mourners at the service and a wake afterwards, possibly exposing them to the infection, which is usually spread through contact such as kissing or sharing food. Acting public health director Avner Misrachi said it was rare for the infection to become serious and that most affected people, while short-term carriers, would not feel ill. But it could cause meningitis or septicemia, possibly leading to serious long-term complications and death. Dr. Misrachi said risk of infection was usually small because of the intimate nature of the contact required for it's spread. He said officers had so far tracked down and treated with antibiotics about 150 people who attended the funeral. The infected woman is still in hospital, but has been moved from isolation to a general ward, he said.

BC-Australia-Navy
Minister: Australia's new frigates ``floating targets''
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ A junior government minister said Tuesday that Australia's eight new naval frigates will be ``floating targets'' because the previous Labor government did not plan to arm them properly. The Defense, Science, Industry and Personnel minister, Bronwyn Bishop, said the Labor government had not taken a strategic approach to the frigate project. ``Thus we have built some fine frigates, which because of the previous government's policies are floating targets,'' Bishop said. She said Australia's conservative government, elected in 1996, is tackling this problem by moving its spending from the ``blunt'' end of defense to the ``sharp end.'' ``It is this government which will turn them into capable platforms that can be used in the defense of Australia,'' Bishop said. She was speaking in Canberra at the launch of the government's new defense acquisition program. New Zealand has also ordered two of the ships, which are known as ANZAC frigates. Bishop also described two amphibious warfare ships, which the Labor government purchased second-hand from the U.S. Navy, as ``rustbuckets.'' They are presently being refitted for service in the Australian navy.

BC-Vietnam-Utility Loans
Loans from World Bank, ADB to help power-short Vietnam
HANOI, Vietnam (AP) _ The World Bank and the Asian Development Bank have pledged to provide dlrs 620 million in loans for projects to ease Vietnam's chronic power shortages, the Vietnam Economic Times reported Tuesday. The World Bank will provide dlrs 350 million for three projects, including dlrs 150 million for Dai Ninh, a 300-megawatt hydroelectric plant in the central highlands province of Lam Dong, and dlrs 100 million for improving efficiency of electricity delivery, the report said. ADB will provide dlrs 150 million for the Sesan 3 hydroelectric plant and dlrs 120 million for a northern power distribution network. The loans are for the 1998-2000 fiscal years. Vietnam has been running into regular power shortages each year, particularly during the dry season, as it increases industrial production. The problems have been underscored by the worst drought this century, which has hampered the hydroelectric plants that supply the bulk of the country's power. The drought has eased in recent weeks with the onset of the rainy season, and rotating power cuts that had been imposed nationwide are being dropped.

BC-Mexico-Banker Extradited,0251
Fugitive banker returned home to Mexico
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A fugitive Mexican banker was extradited from Spain to face fraud charges, four years after being accused of swindling banks out of dlrs 4 million. Angel Rodriguez Saez is the first major player in Mexico's 1994 banking and political scandals to be returned to his home country. Rodriguez Saez was escorted Monday to Mexico City by Mexican federal agents aboard an Iberia airlines flight. Rodriguez Saez, a flashy businessman known as ``El Divino'' _ The Divine One _ built a financial empire during Mexico's banking privatization in the early 1990s. He left Mexico in 1994 and regulatory authorities seized his bank, Banpais, the next year after discovering capital shortfalls and bookkeeping ``irregularities.'' He was charged with fiscal fraud and violation of banking laws. Spanish police arrested Rodriguez Saez in July 1996 after he dove off his yacht into the Mediterranean to try to elude authorities. Spanish judicial authorities agreed to his extradition in February and Rodriguez Saez dropped his objections to the ruling two months later. Spain's federal government approved the extradition on May 22. Mexican officials have failed to win extradition of former Assistant Attorney General Mario Ruiz Massieu from the United States, while financier Carlos Cabal Peniche _ the most important figure in the 1994 banking scandals _ is still at large.

BC-Mexico-Turtle Eggs,0138
Mexican police arrest two men caught with 14,000 turtle eggs
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Mexican police have arrested two men and seized 14,000 sea turtle eggs, which poachers have been known to sell as aphrodisiacs around the world. Jorge Garcia Avendano and Antonio Olmedo Garcia were caught transporting the turtle eggs in a truck along the highway between the Pacific resort of Acapulco and Oaxaca state, the federal Attorney General's office said in a statement Monday. Mexico's Pacific beaches are prime nesting grounds for sea turtles, which along with their eggs are protected by a 1990 law. Biologists have tried to persuade poor villagers from scavenging the eggs by giving them other means of support, such as pay for cleaning up beaches and gathering fire wood.

BC-Philippines-Markets
Philippine stocks suffer heavy losses, peso weakens
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ Philippine stocks plunged to a four-month low Tuesday as most Asian stock markets continued to reel from a selloff triggered by fears of a possible economic recession sweeping the region, traders said. The 30-share Philippine Stock Exchange Index fell 49.97 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,946.08, according to preliminary data. It was the index's lowest closing level since Jan. 29, when it registered 1,796.68. On Monday, it gave up 15.40 points. Tuesday was the eighth straight session of losses by the market, with the main index shedding 202.53 points, or 9.4 percent, during the period. Having broken its 1,950-support Tuesday, the index is expected to test its next support level of 1,900 points, traders said. Foremost among the danger signs which sidelined investors was the weak performance of the Japanese yen against the dollar in morning trading, dealers said. Investors feared the weak yen may spawn another round of devaluations of regional currencies. This is expected to further undermine the already fragile state of most Asian economies, many of which contracted in the first quarter, traders said. An exception was the Philippines, whose gross national product grew by 2.5 percent in the three-month period. Taking its cue from the weak yen, the peso averaged 39.414 to a dollar in morning trading, compared to Monday's 39.072 pesos. Dealers said heavier losses by the peso continued to be averted by weak corporate demand for dollars. The thin demand has helped buffer the peso as other regional currencies have fallen. Despite a fall in Treasury bill yields on Monday to their lowest level since the region's currency crisis erupted last July, the central bank elected to hold its key overnight borrowing and lending rates at 13.125 percent and 15.125 percent respectively. Some market watchers believe the recent fall in Treasury yields is bottoming out. Despite the Philippines' peaceful and credible national elections last month and economic growth in the first quarter, foreign investors aren't inclined to view the country positively given its regional context, said Mitzi de Dios, trader for ABN-AMRO Hoare Govett Securities Philippines Inc. De Dios said as long as Asia can't come up with a clean bill of economic health, the Philippines will be unable to capitalize on its inherent advantages. ``Foreign investors, across the board, are pulling out. The Philippines is still better off compared to its neighbors, but the negative sentiment in the region is pulling us down,'' she said.

BC-Indonesia-Starving Animals
Report: Animals at Indonesian zoo going hungry due to currency crisis
With BC-Indonesia
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ About 2,500 animals at an Indonesian zoo are on the brink of starvation because their keepers can no longer afford spiraling food costs, a result of the country's severe economic crisis, a news report said. Animals at the Safari Wildlife Park in Cisarua, West Java, have to go without food for as many as three days each week, zoo officials were quoted as saying in Tuesday's Jakarta Post newspaper. ``I hope that international animal welfare groups can temporarily help us fund our operations,'' Tony Sumampauw, one of the park's owners, told the Post. The paper ran a photo of an emaciated baby chimpanzee being fed milk from a bottle. The zoo is home to 225 species of animals from five continents and houses the largest collection of tigers in the world, including 27 of the endangered Sumatran tiger. Indonesia's currency, the rupiah, has lost 70 percent of its value against the dollar since last July when an economic crisis rolled across Asia. Much of the meat needed to feed the carnivores is imported, but even the cost of locally produced substitutes such as chicken have risen sharply. The zoo's daily operating costs, consisting mostly of food expenditures, have jumped from 7 million rupiah (dlrs 600) to 18 million rupiah (dlrs 1,525), while ticket sales have plunged to around 4 million rupiah (dlrs 340), the owners said. ``We have no idea what will happen to our animals if the situation worsens,'' Sumampauw said.

BC-Sports-Baseball-NL Roundup, 1st Add,0248
PITTSBURGH: seventh save. Padres 3, Cardinals 2
At San Diego, St. Louis lost Mark McGwire to back spasms in the first inning, then watched light-hitting Chris Gomez homer in consecutive at-bats to help the Padres beat the Cardinals. The Cardinals said McGwire's status was day-to-day. The slugger, who leads the major leagues with 27 homers, walked off under his own power after hitting a dribbler down the first-base line in the first inning off left-hander Sterling Hitchcock (3-0). McGwire, who set a big league record for the most home runs through the end of May, began the night with an NL-leading 68 RBIs and was on a pace to shatter Roger Maris' record of 61 home runs set in 1961. The first baseman has been plagued by injuries throughout his career. He was on the disabled list in 1989 and then every season from 1992-1996 because of problems with his foot, heel, back and ribs. Giants 16, Reds 3 In San Francisco, Jeff Kent and Charlie Hayes each tied career highs with five RBIs, and the Giants used an eight-run fifth inning to rout the Cincinnati Reds. Barry Bonds scored four runs for the Giants, and Mark Gardner (4-2) survived a shaky start to get the victory. He allowed three runs and six hits over seven innings. Kent went 2-for-2 with a sacrifice fly, three-run homer and bases-loaded walk. Hayes was 3-for-5 with an RBI single, a two-run double and a two-run single.

BC-FEA-Indonesia-Seeking Justice,0594
Clamor builds in Indonesia for justice in Suharto-era crimes
AP Photo JAK106 By CHRISTOPHER TORCHIA Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ One night in 1984, after days of anti-government sermons at mosques, soldiers opened fire on thousands of protesters in a poor Jakarta neighborhood. Numerous deaths were reported, but the military quickly closed the case. Now, with autocratic President Suharto out of power and his successor promising an era of political freedom and accountability, relatives see a chance for justice. They are not alone. For decades, Suharto's opponents were jailed or muzzled. Emboldened by the push for democratic reform, many Indonesians want government leaders to pay for alleged misdeeds during his 32-year rule. Calls for investigations come almost daily. On Monday, the attorney general announced a probe of government corruption under Suharto, but stopped short of targeting the former leader, whose wealth is estimated in the billions of dollars. There are fears that a clamor to put officials on trial could divide the fragile nation, caught up in the political and economic turmoil that forced Suharto to resign May 21. The powerful armed forces are likely to resist efforts to uncover abuses. ``Everybody's got their own case,'' said Salim Said, an expert on the Indonesian military. ``Our immediate problem is how to get the economy on its feet.'' Not for the family of Amir Biki, a businessman killed Sept. 12, 1984, in the Jakarta neighborhood of Tanjung Priok after criticizing the government in a speech at a mosque. Muslim preachers fueled a street protest with fiery sermons. Official records indicate 18 people died, but Biki's family alleges that soldiers killed more than 400 and dumped most of the corpses in unmarked graves. ``Where are those bodies now? We still don't know,'' said Boddi Biki, a 57-year-old caretaker of a mosque named after his brother, whose grave in a nearby garden is ringed by a wall of white tile. Two days after Suharto quit, the family demanded that the armed forces commander in charge at the time stand trial. In another prominent case, police are being urged to look again at the 1996 killing of a journalist whose articles on corruption angered local authorities, including a relative of Suharto, near the city of Yogyakarta. Human rights workers say police framed an innocent man in the death of Fuad Muhammad Syafruddin, a journalist for Bernas newspaper, who was attacked outside his home. The suspect was freed because of a lack of evidence; some police officers were demoted. Suharto's departure clears the way for serious pursuit of the killer or killers, said Parni Hadi, secretary general of the Indonesian Journalists' Association. ``The big barrier has fallen,'' Hadi said. ``People are getting more and more courageous.'' While the figurehead of the old era is gone, many people who loyally served Suharto remain in the government, including President B.J. Habibie, and could be exposed to legal action. Indonesia's new justice minister, Muladi, said Monday that he favored an investigation into the 1975 killings of five Australian journalists in the disputed territory of East Timor. An Australian inquiry found in 1996 that a force led by Indonesian military officers had attacked the journalists. The local special forces commander at the time, Yunus Yosfiah, has been named the information minister in Habibie's new Cabinet.

BC-Bahamas-Switzerland-Financier,0254
Swiss financier Rey extradited from Bahamas
By JESSICA ROBERTSON Associated Press Writer
NASSAU, Bahamas (AP) _ A former Swiss financier wanted on charges of embezzlement in his home country has been extradited after spending more than two years in a prison cell in the Bahamas. Werner Rey was extradited late Monday in the custody of Swiss officials on a charter jet. Looking haggard, Rey was escorted by four guards, two of them carrying submachine guns, across the tarmac and onto the plane. The Swiss government claims Rey defrauded European investors of more than dlrs 1 billion and left dlrs 2.8 billion in public and private debt when his business empire collapsed in 1991. Rey, who denies any wrongdoing, made his money in a takeover of Bally, a Swiss shoe manufacturer. He used heavily leveraged deals in the 1980s to build up his main company, Omni Holding AG. In 1992, the Swiss government charged Rey with fraudulent bankruptcy, business fraud, falsification of accounts and other felonies. He and his wife, Bernadette Gately, fled Switzerland for the Bahamas in 1991 and became a permanent residents of the country in 1992. He was arrested in March 1996 and had since been held in a cell at Her Majesty's Prison in Nassau while his lawyers fought to keep him in the Bahamas. In April, Rey lost his final appeal against extradition before the Privy Council of London, the supreme court for several former British colonies.

BC-Thailand-Helmet Gang
Police smash gang that mugged with motorcycle helmets
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Skull-smashing blows from motorcycle helmets wielded by robbery gangs as clubs have killed at least one victim and injured a score of others in a mugging spree across the Thai capital, police reported Tuesday. Police have broken two criminal gangs favoring the helmets _ an ubiquitous accessory in a grid-locked city where motorcycles are the only way to get anywhere on time _ to knock victims unconscious before robbing them. A third gang is still believed at large. The latest gang was broken Sunday when police nabbed one suspect, Decha Jonsuk, 19, as he was allegedly about to clout an unsuspecting pedestrian wearing a gold chain, one of the gang's preferred items to steal. Another was Rolex watches. ``He was a very strong, healthy person, with lots of muscles,'' Police Lt. Col. Varanthorn Chai-Aya said of Decha. ``When he smashed someone, they were really smashed.'' Police said the robbers cruised streets they knew well on a motorcycle, looking for victims. When they found one, the passenger would dismount, trail the victim, smash and rob him, then hop on the back of the motorcycle to flee. Just one blow was usually needed to knock the victim out. One man was killed Feb. 2 and his gold chain, Rolex and jade Buddha pendant were stolen. Decha was identified Monday by eight of his alleged victims. Several had suffered missing teeth and jaw fractures. Some said they had nervous problems and were unable to return to work. Also arrested were Decha's driver and a stolen goods dealer. The trio face charges including robbery causing death, punishable by a maximum of life imprisonment. They are believed to have acquired 2 million baht (dlrs 50,000) in stolen goods. At least 22 helmet-attack robberies have been committed since early this year, police said. Another such gang was broken a month ago. The robberies are part of an upsurge in crime accompanying the country's economic crisis.

BC-China-Nuclear
China reserves nuclear option, but pushing for halt to arms race
Eds: RECAPS previous cycle By RENEE SCHOOF Associated Press Writer
BEIJING (AP) _ China is reserving the option of resuming nuclear testing, given rising tensions in South Asia, but for now is seeking an international solution to halt an arms race. China will urge the world's powers to cool tensions between India and Pakistan when foreign ministers of the U.N. Security Council's permanent members meet Thursday in Geneva, a senior Foreign Ministry official told reporters late Monday. China conducted its 45th and last nuclear test in 1996, declared a moratorium and then signed a global treaty banning nuclear testing. But even the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty allows countries to resume testing if their ``supreme national security'' is threatened, said the official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I'm not saying China will do it. But we have to take into account this development. China is urging the world to do something,'' he said. China fears India's and Pakistan's tit-for-tat testing will ignite an arms race that would set back years of progress toward disarmament, said the official. China has no proposal for responding to the tests, the official said. ``That's why we're meeting. We have to work it out.'' Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan and U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, speaking by telephone, proposed the Geneva meeting, said Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao. Tang, Albright and the foreign ministers of Russia, France and Britain will attend the meeting. All five countries, in addition to being permanent Security Council members, were the world's only declared nuclear powers before India's tests last month. China believes that the advent of new nuclear powers could only destabilize the region, Zhu said. ``We should urge them with one voice and make them realize it's not in their interest,'' he said. Although China sees Pakistan as a close ally and is suspected of having aided Islamabad's nuclear program, Beijing has moved in recent years to improve relations with India. Zhu said China was ``infuriated'' when India tried to justify the tests by claiming nuclear-power China as its top threat. ``We are not their enemy,'' he said, adding the accusation was an insult. The senior official denied that China has helped Pakistan, its close ally, develop nuclear weapons. He confirmed that President Clinton spoke with President Jiang Zemin by telephone before Pakistan conducted its tests. But he denied reports Jiang called on Pakistan to forego testing at Clinton's urging. Jiang wrote to Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif ``on his own, absolutely 100 percent,'' he said.

BC-Australia-Economy, 1st Ld-Writethru
Asian crisis fuels current account deficit, Aussie dollar slumps by opposition, economists
Eds: UPDATES with election timing problems for government; comments
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ The Asian currency crisis fueled a massive U.S. dlrs 1.22 billion (2 billion Australian dollars) rise in Australia's current account deficit in the first three months of 1998, the government said Tuesday. While the figure was within the range of expectations, it is edging closer to 6 percent of gross domestic product, a level that, back in 1986, then-Treasurer Paul Keating said was indicative of a ``banana republic.'' It also puts Prime Minister John Howard in a dilemma. Now is hardly a good time to call an election that must be held before March 1999, but the longer he waits to call it, the more the Asian crisis could harm Australia's economy _ and his chances of re-election. Opposition Labor Party treasury spokesman Gareth Evans said the current account was at about 5.5 percent of gross domestic product. ``The `banana republic' was 6 percent plus; we're looking at 5 1/2 percent now, with the full effect of Asia still to bite. So we're getting close,'' he said. The overall economic problems also undermined the Australian dollar, which slumped to 61.15 U.S. cents, a 12-year low. The slump in Asian prices for Australian products pushed the current account deficit to a three-year high of U.S. dlrs 4.57 billion (7.5 billion Australian dollars), widening by 33 percent since the December quarter, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said. Economists had predicted the blowout, blaming the Asian currency crisis and struggling exports. Net foreign debt rose to U.S. dlrs 137 billion (225 billion Australian dollars), the Bureau said. The All Ordinaries stock index lost 45 points, 1.6 percent of its value, by midday Tuesday. The current account deterioration is ``a portent of things to come,'' said Craig James, chief economist at Colonial State Bank. ``The important point'' to take from the data is that ``the current account deficit will widen further'' over coming quarters, and likely will reach record levels over coming months, James said. John Peters, senior economist, financial markets at Westpac Banking Corp., agreed that while the deficit was close to expectations, ``We can expect continuing deterioration over 1998.'' The deterioration in the goods trade balance shows ``the full effect of the Asia crisis,'' James said.

BC-Asian Markets
Hong Kong falls, other markets weak on recession and yen fears
HONG KONG (AP) _ Markets fell sharply in Hong Kong and elsewhere in Asia on Tuesday because of the weakness of the Japanese yen and fears that the whole region was heading toward another long bout of bad economic news. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index, which has been on an extended losing streak since getting the word last week that the economy was heading toward recession, shed 156 points by midday. That came on top of other large losses in the past week _ 3.8 percent, or 322 points on Monday, and more than 5 percent last Wednesday. Manila also was sharply lower. Singapore fell after opening higher. In currency markets, the Thai baht reached an 11-week low of 42.20 to the U.S. dollar. Tokyo's main stock index rebounded from Monday's large loss, but analysts said there was not much steam in the rally. The yen continued its fall. After the government announced last Friday that Hong Kong's economy shrank 2 percent in the first quarter, institutional investors expect declines in the earnings of blue-chip companies, said Kenny Tang, research manager at Tung Tai Securities. He also cited skepticism in the market that a seven-point government program would have much of an effect. It includes plans to streamline residential mortgage programs, improve bank liquidity and boost tourism. Hong Kong's chief civil servant, Anson Chan, said the measures needed time to work. Speaking before leaving on a trip to Japan and the United States, she also reiterated that officials were ``very confident that our medium to long-term prospects are good.'' Nearly a year into Asia's economic problems, Hong Kong is just now beginning to feel strong effects. Unemployment is at a 14-year high, and in the all-important property market prices have fallen about 40 percent. Hong Kong's main air carrier, Cathay Pacific has also been affected. ``We are, indeed, facing the worst market situation in the history of the company, entering into a period of slower or negative growth and narrow or nonexistent profit margins on most routes,'' spokesman Willy Boulter said in the company's in-house newsletter. ``This situation is driven by weak market demand in our core Asian territories, from Japan in the north, to Australia in the south,'' he said. The bad news was not limited to Hong Kong. The fall in the Thai currency was tied to fears over Japan's economy. Japan is Thailand's largest creditor, and recession in Japan could slow recovery in Thailand. In Manila, the main index fell 2.5 percent to a four-month low on fears of a regional recession. Singapore's Straits Times index opened higher, but slumped 1.2 percent by its midday close. Taiwan's markets stabilized after a rough ride on Monday. Tokyo's Nikkei index rebounded after losing almost 350 points, or 2.2 percent, on Monday because of worries about the Japanese economy. It was up almost 100 points in early afternoon trading, but traders said there appeared to be few reasons for it to go much higher. The U.S. dollar was trading at 139.52 yen, up about 0.4 yen late Monday in Tokyo. Traders said the dollar could easily break above 140 yen, and perhaps to 142 in the near future.

BC-Asia-Air Pollution
End of El Nino may bring more rain, less haze to S.E. Asia
By JONATHAN DRAKE Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ The end of El Nino could bring relief to Southeast Asia, which is entering the dry season when haze from forest fires is expected to intensify, meteorological experts said Tuesday. As the disruptive weather phenomenon ends this month, Pacific Ocean temperatures could cool beyond their normal level, and ``that means excessive rainfall (for the) Australian and Indonesian area,'' Godwin Obasi, secretary-general of the World Meteorological Organization, told reporters. Such rain would dampen the fires that were expected to burn out of control on the Indonesian islands of Sumatra and Kalimantan during the June-August dry season, causing thick haze to shroud wide swathes of Southeast Asia. The intergovernmental organization is holding a regional workshop in Singapore on cross-border smoke and haze in Southeast Asia, attended by representatives of national weather services and other experts. ``The only chance that these fires can be put out is by rain, despite a lot of ground efforts,'' explained Woon Shih Lai, director of Singapore's Meteorological Service. ``Once this El Nino finishes, and it is predicted that this current one will end at the end of this month, then the Pacific Ocean becomes normal,'' Obasi said. ``How intense the normal situation will become, I cannot say at the present.'' Woon added that several factors will influence how intense the fires and resulting haze become, notably whether large-scale burning continues in Indonesia, and how strongly the weather patterns reverse as El Nino ends. ``If the prediction of El Nino going to end soon happens to turn out to be correct, then there is a greater chance that the situation will be much better than last year,'' Woon said. Both Obasi and Woon were wary of definite predictions, saying it was too early to tell exactly how the weather pattern will evolve, and what effects it will have on the haze. ``We cannot be sure that without El Nino, definitely there will be no haze,'' said Woon ``It's a bit difficult to tell now.'' The World Meteorological Organization will release its latest assessment of the evolving El Nino phenomenon, and its possible effects on world weather patterns Wednesday. Southeast Asia experienced its worst episode of haze last year, when an estimated 2 million hectares (5 million acres) of Indonesian forest were burned, according to a United Nations study. The fires and haze resulted in dlrs 4.4 billion in global damage, especially in Southeast Asia, according to a recent study by two major environmental groups.

BC-Asia-Pacific Economies, HFR
FOR RELEASE AT 1400 GMT, JUNE 2, TIME SET BY SOURCE PECC Study: Asia Pacific in recession year
By LAURINDA KEYS Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ This is a recession year for the Asia-Pacific region, with negative growth already projected for Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Russia and Thailand, the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council said in a report released Tuesday. The United States' economic growth this year will be a full percentage point less than in 1997, or 2.8 percent, mainly because the Asian financial crisis has slowed down the expansion rate of U.S. exports, said the annual study, released simultaneously in Washington, D.C. Average growth this year for 20 Pacific Rim nations should stabilize at about 2.6 percent, two percentage points below last year's level, but growth is expected to accelerate next year to 3.5 percent, said the council's Pacific Economic Outlook. Prepared by The Asia Foundation, a private organization that promotes U.S.-Asia relations, the report has a nine-year record of accuracy within a half percentage point on its forecasts for the 20 nations of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC). However, ``given the rapid unfolding of economic events in the region, any economic forecast is bound to be wrought with uncertainties,'' said P.C. Leung, a Hong Kong official who is the PECC director general. ``For 1998, we can use the term `recession year,''' he said. Banks and financial services companies are the hardest hit, but many other types of firms will also go bankrupt, he said, and the effects appear to be worsening as the year goes on. ``Consumption is falling with the drop in consumer confidence and declining investment,'' Leung said. Countries that have been less seriously affected by the Asian financial crisis _ Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore _ may lose three percentage points of growth that could otherwise have been expected, the report said. The PECC listed four risks to the predicted recovery in 1999: _ excessive monetary contraction in the seriously affected economies; _ political uncertainty in several economies, especially Indonesia, Australia, Colombia and the Philippines; _ the failure of Japan's fiscal stimulus to bring domestic recovery; _ a protectionist backlash by Asian countries that may try to get out of trouble by increasing their trade surpluses. Another risk, mentioned at a news conference presenting the report, is the chance of China reversing its promise not to devalue its currency, which would spark a new wave of financial turmoil in Asia. ``Reflecting the sentiment of the market, there is widespread expectation of a devaluation, notwithstanding the strong desire to take the (Chinese) premier at his word,'' said Chris J. Stephenson, a director at Arthur Andersen, which was involved in releasing the report. ``Domestic Chinese partners in state-owned enterprises are at this time resisting U.S. dollar financing of their projects,'' Stephenson said. ``They want renminbi (the Chinese currency) financing because they themselves are concerned about devaluation.'' A fall in the U.S. stock exchange would also seriously damage Asia's recovery chances, Stephenson added. ``This is a hazardous time for any forecaster. The situation changes from day to day,'' said Toh Mun Heng, the council's Singapore researcher. He predicted Singapore's growth will drop below 2 percent, further than government predictions. But because Singapore is such a small economy, he said the government has stimulus measures ready to keep it from falling into recession. The PECC, made up of academics, businessmen and government officials is the only official observer organization to the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. The forecasts were prepared by researchers in member countries before Japan's stimulation measures in January and Indonesia's change of government in May. An update is due in September. END EMBARGOED MATERIAL

BC-Indonesia
Indonesia's new government recognizes independent labor union
By GEOFF SPENCER Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Keeping up the pace of reform, the Indonesian government Tuesday formally recognized the legality of the country's largest independent labor union, suppressed before by ex-President Suharto's old regime. Manpower Minister Fahmi Idris told reporters the Indonesian Welfare Labor Union could now operate as a legal organization. The union is headed by dissident Muchtar Pakpahan, one of four political prisoners released by the government in recent days. ``According to the labor laws, it meets all criteria to exist,'' the minister said of the union after talks with new President B.J. Habibie. Habibie, formally Suharto's deputy, replaced the 76-year-old autocrat on May 21 after the nation of 202 million people was rocked by rioting and protests, sparked by the worst economic crisis in 30 years. In his brief time in office, Habibie has promised to make big economic and political changes, most notably a plan to liberalize the tightly controlled political system and to hold elections in 1999. During Suharto's era, human rights groups regularly criticized Indonesia for suppressing workers' rights and allowing bosses to pay unfair wages. Many employees were also forced to work in sweatshop conditions. Until his release last week, Pakpahan had been serving a three year sentence for allegedly organizing a workers' riot on the island of Sumatra in 1994. Since his release, other charges of subversion against him have been dropped. On Monday Indonesia's attorney general's office announced it had launched a broad inquiry into corruption under Suharto's rule. Among other things, it is expected to look at how Suharto's family amassed billions of dollars through business deals based on their position and power. Despite continuing announcements of reform measures, some student protesters, who played a key role in Suharto's ouster, remain dissatisfied. Less than 100 students staged a noisy but peaceful protest outside Parliament Tuesday calling for immediate elections. Others have demanded Habibie, a long time friend of Suharto's, step down immediately. About 50 protesters also gathered outside the U.S. Embassy for a second day to criticize tough reform demands being made by the International Monetary Fund. The Washington-based IMF is now considering whether to restart a dlrs 43 billion bailout package for Indonesia. The package was derailed last month when political turmoil hit the world's fourth most populous nation.

BC-Philippines-Marrying Priest
Catholic Church to defrock Philippine priest over wedding
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ A Catholic priest who got married in the southern Philippines while wearing his church robes will be asked to relinquish them, church officials said Tuesday. The Rev. Hector Canto, 36, exchanged wedding vows Sunday with Cynthia Diamante, a 24-year-old engineer he met in his parish, in a ceremony in the town of Lambunao in Iloilo province attended by about 600 people. Msgr. Pedro Quitorio, assistant secretary-general of the Catholic Bishops' Conference of the Philippines, said Canto will be asked to leave the priesthood because of his actions. He said a priest can ask permission to marry from his bishop, who in turn asks for dispensation from Pope John Paul II to recognize the wedding. The priest is then asked to leave the priesthood because of the end of his vow of celibacy, Quitorio said. ``There is no compromise. He is violating teachings of the Church,'' he said of Canto. ``The moment you commit yourself in marriage you cease becoming a priest.'' Quitorio said a special committee has been formed to determine sanctions for the Rev. Jesus Siva, who officiated the wedding. ``Apparently, his theology is also wrong,'' said Quitorio. ``He has to take several tests to determine what punishment he should receive.'' There are about 6,000 priests in the Philippines, serving about 60 million Filipino Catholics, Quitorio said. Very few Filipino priests ask permission to leave the priesthood to get married, he said. Canto is assistant parish priest of Dumangas, a town about 40 kilometers (25 miles) from Lambunao.

BC-China-Earthquakes
Aftershocks hit Chinese villages recovering from earlier quake
BEIJING (AP) _ Two mild earthquakes on Monday morning rattled villages near China's Great Wall that were still recovering from a devastating quake in January, government seismologists said. There were no reports of casualties but a seismologist in Hebei province's Zhangbei county said search teams were still investigating outlying villages. The first quake, of magnitude 4.6, occurred at 9:32 a.m. (0132 GMT) while the second, of magnitude 4.0, struck 75 minutes later, state-run media reported. The tremors toppled a few old houses already listing from the magnitude-6.2 quake that struck Jan. 10, said a seismologist with the State Seismological Bureau in Beijing. He refused to give his name. The powerful quake killed 50 and flattened villages along Zhangbei's border with Shangyi county. More than 44,000 people were left homeless and passed the bitterly cold winter living in tents put up by the military. Most of the homeless had moved into newly built houses by Tuesday's quakes, although a few had not, said the Zhangbei seismologist, who also refused to give his name. The tremors, which the seismologists termed aftershocks from the January quake, could be felt as far away as Beijing, 250 kilometers (150 miles) to the south, the Xinhua News Agency reported.

BC-Thailand-Hitler Potato Chips
Israel says apology over Hitler potato chip ads not enough
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Israeli diplomats held firm Tuesday that commercials using images of Hitler to sell potato chips should be pulled off Thai television and that an apology is not enough. Avi Nil, charge d'affaires of the Israeli Embassy in Bangkok, said Israel will keep demanding that an ad campaign it views as both offensive and morally unacceptable be halted. ``We as a government are going to do all we can with the means in our hands to stop this advertisement,'' Nil said. ``I think that this is a moral issue.'' Leo Burnett Bangkok, the Thai branch of the Chicago-based ad agency, has apologized for producing the ads for X potato chips, made by Food Processing Co. Ltd., a Thai company. Simone Wheeler, an agency spokeswoman, said consultations were still continuing with Food Processing over whether to pull the ads and that a solution was expected at any time. The commercials, which have aired only in Thailand, depict Hitler giving a Nazi salute and cut to a woman who casts a voodoo spell on him as he eats the chips, hoping to change his evil ways. A Nazi swastika turns into the product logo as the transformation is completed. The agency has said that the commercial, targeting Thai teen-agers, was meant to show that the world would be a better place if happiness prevailed. ``We appreciate that they see it's a mistake, but we want them to stop the campaign,'' Nil said. ``For us, the idea of Hitler and the Holocaust is not to be used at all to make money.'' Hitler unleashed World War II in Europe and systematically murdered millions of civilians, including 6 million Jews, that his Nazi regime considered subhuman, the worst genocide the world has ever seen. Consciousness about Hitler and his crimes is somewhat less in Asia, where his armies did not reach, than in the West. Nil said the controversy should have raised awareness about Hitler among Thais. Thailand has in the past expressed outrage over the use of people dressed as Buddhist monks in advertisements. Buddhism is the country's dominant religion and monks are generally revered.

BC-Indonesia-East Timor
Bishop wants troops out of East Timor; Habibie says they'll stay
DILI, Indonesia (AP) _ Nobel laureate Bishop Carlos Belo called for the Indonesian army to withdraw from East Timor on Tuesday, one day after Indonesia's new president said the government would retain control of the island. Belo, co-winner of the 1997 Nobel Peace Prize for his nonviolent campaign to free East Timor from Indonesia's grip, said he intended to travel to Jakarta and discuss troop withdrawals with new President B.J. Habibie and Armed Forces chief Gen. Wiranto. Habibie has said he has no intentions of changing the government's policy on East Timor, a former Portuguese colony Indonesia invaded in 1975 and annexed a year later. The United Nations has never recognized Indonesia's claim to the island, which was briefly an independent nation after the Portuguese pulled out. ``East Timor is an integral part of the republic. Nobody can deny this fact,'' Jakarta's ambassador-at-large to East Timor, F.X. Lopez da Cruz, said the president told him during a meeting on Monday. East Timorese resistance groups had held out hope that with the fall of then President Suharto last month after 32 years of autocratic rule, Indonesia's new government would change its policy or at least relax its harsh administration of the island. ``The are so many troops in East Timor, therefore, they have to be withdrawn,'' Belo told a news conference at his residence in the East Timor capital. He said the military presence was hampering efforts to resolve the island's status. Indonesia has six army battalions on the island. Human rights groups have also been demanding the release of East Timorese rebel leader Jose Alexandre Gusmao, also known as Xanana, from a Jakarta prison. ``His release would be able to expedite the settlement of the East Timor issue,'' Belo said. U.S. congressman Chris Smith, a New Jersey Republican who visited Gusmao in prison last week, has also called on the government to release him along with other political prisoners. Britain and several other countries have also asked for Gusmao's release and for new negotiations on the territory's future. Habibie has so far released four political prisoners jailed by Suharto's regime. Officials say many of another 200 are to be freed soon. However, Gusmao's release, along with other imprisoned East Timorese rebel fighters, seems far off. Indonesian Foreign Minister Ali Alatas was quoted by the Jakarta Post on Tuesday as saying Gusmao was arrested on criminal charges, including weapons possession, and so was not eligible for parole.

BC-Pakistan-Killings,0264
Police discover eight bodies in protracted factional feud
AP Photo KAR101
KARACHI, Pakistan (AP) _ Police discovered grisly remains Tuesday of eight men, their bodies stuffed into burlap sacks and thrown in garbage dumps in a central neighborhood of the ethnically troubled city of Karachi. Police officials were still investigating the deaths, but they said they feared it was related to an ongoing battle between rival factions of a minority ethnic group called the Mohajir Qami Movement. The death toll in fighting between the two factions in the past week soared to 19, following the discovery Tuesday of the eight tortured bodies, said police. The movement, which represents Muslims who settled in Pakistan after independence in 1947, split several years ago and routinely their members clash. The larger faction, led by the exiled leader Altaf Hussein, says eight of its activists were kidnapped over the weekend, but police has so far not identified the eight bodies they found in the central district. Police have stepped up security in the central district of Karachi, the scene of the latest gun battles. Most of the killings have either involved drive-by shootings or gangland style executions. Factional fighting by movement members in the past year has left hundreds of people dead in Karachi, Pakistan's largest city of 14 million people and its financial center. Many of the people killed have been caught in the crossfire. Paramilitary forces routinely patrol the city in armor-plated trucks.

BC-Thailand-Economy, 1st Ld-Writethru
Stocks, currency down; official says inflation will fall
Eds: UPDATES with stocks, currency falling, grafs 1-2
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Thai stocks and the currency were sliding again Tuesday, while a deputy prime minister tried to curb bad inflation news by predicting price increases would slow in the second half of the year. The baht weakened to 42.25 to the U.S. dollar, tumbling from 41.55 Monday. It was the lowest level plumbed by the currency in 11 weeks and was attributed by dealers to fears of a deeper recession. The Stock Exchange of Thailand index meanwhile sank 1.37 points in early trading to 311.67. Supachai Patichpakdi, who is also commerce minister, said in an interview late Monday on the ITV television station that declining inflation would allow high interest rates to fall as well. ``That will benefit the entire economic system,'' Supachai said, without projecting any estimated figures. High interest rates are crippling Thai businesses struggling to survive the current recession, which the government said last week will be far deeper and probably longer than previously expected. The International Monetary Fund has demanded that Thailand keep inflation at an average of 10.5 percent for the year as a condition of receiving a dlrs 17.2 billion economic bailout package. The economy has begun to stabilize under the administration of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, but new declines in the currency and stock market this week on fears of a deeper recession underscored how far the country still has to go. The Commerce Ministry released data Monday that showed Thai consumer prices rose 10.2 percent year-on-year in May, the worst inflation in more than three years. It was the fifth consecutive month this year that the index has kept rising. Inflation has worsened steadily since July 1997, when Thailand abandoned its fixed-exchange rate system under attacks by currency speculators and triggered a chain reaction of crises across Asia.

BC-Japan-Markets, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Dollar higher, stocks bounce back in Tokyo prices
Eds: UPDATES with closing stock, mid-afternoon bond, currency
TOKYO (AP) _ The U.S. dollar was higher in afternoon trading Tuesday amid continuing pessimism about Japan's economy, though it retreated from seven-year highs reached overnight in New York. Tokyo stocks rose. The dollar bought 139.48 yen at mid-afternoon, up 0.36 yen from late Monday in Tokyo. In New York overnight, the dollar settled at 139.70 yen, its highest level since June 24, 1991. The dollar has gained steadily in recent weeks against the yen as sluggish consumer spending and the write-off of some 76 trillion yen (dlrs 550 billion) in bad loans by the nation's banks cloud the outlook for Japan's economy. But the dollar ceded some of its gains in early Tokyo trading amid a rising chorus of concern for the weakening yen by Japanese finance officials. Finance Minister Hikaru Matsunaga told reporters Tuesday the yen is too weak and Japan will take decisive action to defend it. The same day, Haruhiko Kuroda, head of the ministry's international finance bureau, said the pace of the Japanese currency's decline is too fast. ``In any case, I have strong concern about an excessively weak yen, and we will take appropriate and decisive action against it,'' Matsunaga said at a regular news conference. On the stock market, the benchmark index regained much of the previous day's losses as sentiment improved after Monday's announcement that Nikko Securities Co., a major Japanese brokerage, and Travelers Group of the United States were planning an equity tie-up. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 233.42 points, or 1.52 percent, to close at 15,554.45. On Monday, the index had lost 349.75 points, or 2.23 percent. ``The market welcomed Nikko's alliance, as it will likely trigger more Japanese financial institutions' tie-ups with foreign institutions,'' said Masaru Arai, general manager of the stock division at Ryoko Securities Co. Deepening worries over the state of Japan's economy had triggered Monday's fall. The broader Tokyo Stock Price Index of all issues listed on the first section rose 16.27 points, or 1.36 percent, to 1,212.97. The TOPIX fell 24.79 points, or 2.03 percent on Monday. Meanwhile, the yield on the benchmark No. 182 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 1.120 percent from Monday's record low finish of 1.155 percent, driving its price up to 112.67 yen from 112.41 yen. BC-Hong Kong-Pillar of Shame
Homeless sculpture may head for container after Tiananmen anniversary
HONG KONG (AP) _ City officials on Tuesday turned down a request to display permanently a sculpture honoring those slain in China's 1989 Tiananmen crackdown in any public venue, saying it was too controversial. Counselors voted 19-18 against exhibiting the eight-meter (26-foot) bronze sculpture, named the ``Pillar of Shame'' by its Danish creator Jens Galshiot, in any city park or museum. Counselor Ip Kwok-chung of the pro-Beijing Democratic Alliance for the Betterment of Hong Kong, said it was too politically controversial. ``All displays should be non-controversial in nature because people should not be forced to see'' something they don't agree with, Ip said. But Wu Chi-wai, who sponsored the motion for permanent display, called the decision censorship. Wu is from the Democratic Party, which is critical of Beijing and is pushing for more democracy in Hong Kong. He said counselors like Ip ``don't want to see anything that carries a political message, especially ones that are anti-China.'' Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive after the handover to China last July 1, appointed nine members of the council, and all nine voted against displaying the sculpture. The sculpture depicts 50 badly twisted faces symbolizing the pain of the people, and carries a plaque saying ``How can old people kill the youth?'' in Chinese. It was shipped to Hong Kong last May for the annual candlelight vigil to commemorate the bloody June 4, 1989, military crackdown in Beijing. The sculpture has been on display at Victoria Park, which activists rented, since Sunday, when 2,700 people joined a three-hour commemorative rally. Activists also have planned a candlelight vigil on Thursday. Despite Hong Kong's handover to China, there has been no effort to halt the rallies. Szeto Wah, chairman of the Hong Kong Alliance for Patriotic Democratic Movement in China, said the group may be forced to put the sculpture in a cargo container after Thursday night. Szeto, who also is a Democratic counselor, said the group will apply for temporary display, as well. The sculpture has been on a tour of the territory's university campuses since last June. Outside City Hall on Tuesday, several protesters chanted ``Protect freedom of artistic expression. Against political censorship.''

BC-Lebanon-Obit-Shaaban
Sunni fundamentalist cleric dies of heart attack
AP Photo BEI-101
BEIRUT, Lebanon (AP) _ Sheik Saeed Shaaban, the firebrand Sunni Muslim cleric who led an armed militia during the civil war and advocated Islamic rule in Lebanon, died of a heart attack Monday night. He was 69. His Islamic Tawheed, or Unification Movement, said in a statement Monday night that Shaaban suffered a heart attack after returning home from evening prayers at a mosque in the northern port city of Tripoli. The white-bearded Shaaban, the ``emir'' of the Tawheed, dominated the life of Tripoli, Lebanon's second-largest city, in the early 80s when the country was fractured into sectarian mini-states. He wrested control of Tripoli's streets from its moderate traditional politicians and became a leading Sunni fundamentalist in this Muslim-Christian nation of 3.2 million people. In 1983, he sided with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat and his PLO guerrillas who made a last stand in Tripoli before evacuating by sea after a siege by Syrian-backed Lebanese leftist militias. Shaaban later denounced Arafat and mended fences with Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon. After the 1975-90 civil war, the white-turbaned cleric opposed the consensus Christian-Muslim governments that ruled Lebanon and continued to preach Islamic power. But his own power base began to diminish as the army disarmed militias and the state spread its authority over many parts of the country. In 1997, he was among the rare voices to criticize a visit to Lebanon by Pope John Paul II that year. He also defied a government order to close down his unlicensed radio and television stations. One supporter was killed and four were wounded in a clash in September with security forces who closed down the station by force. An activist in Muslim groups since the 1950s, Shaaban was one of the founders of the fundamentalist Lebanese Islamic Grouping in Lebanon in the 1980s. He went to a French-language missionary school in Tripoli for primary education and later studied religion at the Islamic Academy. He traveled to Egypt for Arabic language education at the Al-Azhar University. He worked as a teacher in Algeria and Iraq and helped convert Morocco's educational system from French to Arabic before returning to Lebanon. Shaaban is survived by his wife, Najah, five sons and two daughters. A funeral will be held Tuesday afternoon in Tripoli, where he will be buried. sfg-hd-sf

BC-Indonesia, 1st Ld-Writethru
Indonesia's new government recognizes independent labor union
Eds: ADDS estimates of Suharto worth, graf 11,12 By GEOFF SPENCER Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Keeping up the pace of reform, the Indonesian government Tuesday formally recognized the country's largest independent labor union, which had been suppressed under ex-President Suharto. Manpower Minister Fahmi Idris told reporters the Indonesian Welfare Labor Union could now operate as a legal organization. The union is headed by dissident Muchtar Pakpahan, one of four political prisoners released by the government in recent days. ``According to the labor laws, it meets all criteria to exist,'' the minister said after talks with President B.J. Habibie. Habibie, formally Suharto's deputy, replaced the 76-year-old autocrat on May 21 after the nation of 202 million people was rocked by rioting and protests, sparked by the worst economic crisis in 30 years. In his brief time in office, Habibie has promised to make big economic and political changes, most notably a plan to liberalize the tightly controlled political system and to hold elections in 1999. During the Suharto era, human rights groups regularly criticized Indonesia for suppressing workers' rights and allowing bosses to pay unfair wages. Many employees were also forced to work in sweatshop conditions. Until his release last week, Pakpahan had been serving a three-year sentence for allegedly organizing a workers' riot on the island of Sumatra in 1994. Since his release, other charges of subversion against him have been dropped. On Monday, Indonesia's attorney general's office announced it had launched a broad inquiry into corruption under Suharto's rule. Among other things, it is expected to look at how Suharto's family amassed billions of dollars through business deals based on their position and power. News reports said independent economist Christianto Wibisono had estimated Suharto family wealth at a minimum of dlrs 20 billion, based on the worth of companies and foundations controlled by them. Other estimates have ranged up to dlrs 40 billion. Critics have claimed that some of the fortune has been placed abroad and should be brought back to help bailout the ailing economy. Despite continuing announcements of reform measures, some students protesters, who played a key role in Suharto's ouster, remain dissatisfied. Less than 100 students staged a noisy but peaceful protest outside Parliament on Tuesday calling for immediate elections. Others have demanded Habibie, a long time friend of Suharto's, step down immediately. About 50 protesters also gathered outside the U.S. Embassy for a second day to criticize tough reform demands being made by the International Monetary Fund. The Washington-based IMF is now considering whether to restart a dlrs 43 billion bailout package for Indonesia. The package was derailed last month when political turmoil hit the world's fourth most populous nation.

BC-Cambodia-Elections
Cambodian leader says end of Khmer Rouge helps elections
By KER MUNTHIT Associated Press Writer
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia (AP) _ Cambodian leader Hun Sen says that upcoming elections will be more peaceful than polls in 1993 monitored by 20,000 U.N. peacekeepers, thanks largely to the collapse of the Khmer Rouge. In an interview seen Tuesday in his monthly Cambodia New Vision bulletin, Hun Sen said that security had greatly improved in the past five years despite tensions that led to a bloody power struggle with Prince Norodom Ranariddh last year. Hun Sen and Ranariddh emerged from the 1993 polls as co-prime ministers, but the prince was driven into exile by a Hun Sen-led coup last July. Ranariddh came home two months ago to contest elections called by Hun Sen to win his regime international aid and legitimacy. Hun Sen was quoted as saying that eligible voters were flocking to register for the July 26 polls, proving that ``our people prefer to choose a leadership by ballots rather than bullets.'' Critics say that the electoral process has been stacked in favor of Hun Sen, though intimidation and killings of opposition party workers appear to have calmed in the last month. Hun Sen said that the atmosphere is far better than five years ago, when U.N. peacekeepers were sent to Cambodia to help supervise polls that cost dlrs 2 billion to organize and were aimed at ending decades of civil war. The Khmer Rouge, who caused the deaths of as many as 2 million Cambodians when they ruled between 1975 and 1979, remained a potent guerrilla force in 1993 and boycotted the polls, threatening to kill Cambodians who voted. But turnout was massive and the rebel group has gradually collapsed. Thousands of war-weary guerrillas have made peace since 1996 while die-hards have been pressed into a few hilltop enclaves near the rugged border with Thailand. ``In 1993, Khmer Rouge occupied many places ...,'' Hun Sen said. ``Those areas have been reintegrated one after another into the royal government.'' Hun Sen said that the government will place 70,000 soldiers and civilians at the disposal of the National Electoral Commission, the body overseeing the polls, to ensure a stable election environment. ``There will be no tanks, no armored vehicles, trenches or safe havens as there were ... in 1993,'' Hun Sen said. Hun Sen welcomed the arrival of a handful of international observers, saying their presence helped ``create an atmosphere of confidence'' in efforts to organize the vote.

Netanyahu to visit Australia in August
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is likely to visit Australia later this year, probably in August, Prime Minister John Howard told Parliament on Tuesday. Howard confirmed a date around Aug. 14 was under consideration. However, it is believed a possible clash with an Australian federal election is preventing the date being finalized. Howard promised to use the visit to lobby Netanyahu to continue to seek a peace settlement with the Palestinians. ``Israel carries a special responsibility, along with the representatives of the Palestinian people, and I respect the rights and the aspirations of the Palestinian people, and I will use my opportunities and my authority to press that view on the prime minister of Israel,'' Howard told Parliament. ``I will certainly be pressing very strongly on the Israeli government the need for it to play its part,'' he said. But Howard said Australia's very strong view was that Israel had a right to exist behind secure and defensible boundaries.

BC-Taiwan-Submarine
Taiwan detects submarine, reports say it's from China
TAIPEI, Taiwan (AP) _ The Taiwanese military said Tuesday it detected what it believed was a foreign submarine off the Penghu island group last week, and reports identified the craft as Chinese. Defense Ministry spokesman Kung Fan-ding said the navy and air force detected two unidentified undersea objects on May 28. ``The first was judged extremely likely to be a submarine, and after it discovered we had targeted it and had it under surveillance, it departed when sea conditions were right,'' Kung told a news conference. The military determined the other object was a sunken ship, he said. The United Daily News reported the submarine was a diesel-powered Chinese submarine. The Penghu islands, also known as the Pescadores, lie 43 kilometers (26 miles) off Taiwan's west coast in the Taiwan Strait, about a half an air by air from Taipei. The Strait, which divides Taiwan from China, ranges between 220 kilometers (136 miles) and 130 kilometers (80 miles) wide. The official Central News Agency said a pair of navy support ships discovered the submarine, and anti-submarine warplanes were called in to pinpoint its location. It said Chinese submarines frequent the area to listen in on Taiwanese naval and air force target practice. The waters off of the Penghu islands are a major Taiwanese military training area. Anti-submarine warfare has become a major focus of Taiwan's naval upgrade, and was a theme of this year's annual war games. China threatens to use force to assert its claim of sovereignty over Taiwan. Its fleet of submarines, including advanced Kilo class subs purchased from Russia, would be key to enforcing a blockade of the island. Taiwan has just two modern submarines.

BC-Philippines-Banks
Report: Philippine banks set for further consolidation
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ The Philippine banking industry is heading for a further consolidation, creating a harsher business climate that could drive weaker, smaller institutions into failure, a report said Tuesday. Indosuez W.I. Carr Securities Inc., in a report titled ``Banking on the Brink,'' said the industry's major players should be able to weather the regional financial storm because of their solid capital base and established positions. But a number of smaller banks are expected to fall as pressure builds in the tougher operating environment, which will include higher minimum capitalization requirements, it said. The report said the Philippine banking system is solvent, unlike in some other countries in the region. Although the top 10 Philippine banks already account for some 60 percent of total assets in the banking system, the industry is heading for further consolidation, it said. This probably won't be achieved through mergers, but rather by the historical norm of takeovers and acquisitions. The report noted that in the first quarter of 1998, Orient Commercial Banking Corp. became the first Philippine bank to close since the regional financial crisis erupted in July 1997. Orient Bank, one of the smallest of the country's 56 commercial banks, shut down because of heavy withdrawals triggered by fears that its majority owner was in difficulties. The report said smaller commercial banks may have worsened their situation by earlier efforts to gain market share that left them with non-performing loans. Numerous small banks were established in the Philippines in recent years by inexperienced family corporations to ``service their own business needs and their egos,'' the report said. ``The current and expected operating environment should put pressure on these corporations to divest their banking foray as they will have to muster all their resources just to keep their main line of business standing,'' it said. The report says recent efforts by the Philippine Central Bank to strengthen bank oversight should also contribute to a further consolidation of the banking system. These include increasing the capitalization requirement of banks; additional loan-loss provisioning; and steps to more quickly spot bad loans. Of the top 48 banks, about 12 would have to increase their capital if the first round of capitalization increases were immediately implemented, the report said. In the first round, general-service banks must raise their minimum capital to 4.5 billion pesos (dlrs 115 million) from 2.5 billion pesos (dlrs 64 million) by the end of 1998 for non-listed banks and by June 1999 for listed ones. A second round of increases is planned for the end of 2000.

Pakistani executed in Emirates for murder
DUBAI, United Arab Emirates (AP) _ A Pakistani man was executed for robbing and then murdering a factory guard, a prison official said Tuesday. Ataullah Pir Mohammed, 31, convicted in the Dec. 1993 strangling murder and robbery of Kanduth Zubair Kaidal, was killed by a firing squad Monday, said the official, speaking on customary condition of anonymity. BC-SKorea-Chip Makers
South Korean computer chip makers plan to cut production
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ South Korea's computer memory chip makers said Tuesday they were considering cutting production to shore up falling global chip prices. ``Because of a global supply glut, we agree in principle that we must cut production,'' said Hong Kyong-tae, a spokesman of Samsung Electronics Co., the world's largest memory chip producer. The other two major chip makers _ Hyundai Electronics and LG Semicon _ also admitted that the plunge in memory chip prices has eroded their earnings, forcing them to consider measures to shore up the prices. On Tuesday, domestic news media reported that the three South Korean producers may idle some of their production lines for four days around South Korea's Memorial Day holiday Saturday, with further cutbacks planned in the months ahead. The three companies said they have yet to work out cutback plans. The three South Korean firms supply 40 percent of the world's computer memory chips, called Dynamic Random Access Memory (DRAM) chips. Japanese and U.S. chip makers have charged that South Korea's rapid expansion of facilities resulted in the drastic price cuts. South Korea put the blame on such new market entries as Taiwan. South Korea currently produces 57 million 16-megabit DRAM chips and 23 million 64-megabit DRAMs a year. Memory chips store operating instructions for electronic products such as personal computers. In the first quarter of this year, South Korea sold its 64-megabit chips for around dlrs 9 each. At the same time last year, it was getting dlrs 15 a chip. In 1997, South Korea exported dlrs 17.5 billion worth of semiconductors, or 12.8 percent of the country's total exports.

BC-Sri Lanka-War,0225
Sri Lanka troops kill 8 Tamil rebels
COLOMBO, Sri Lanka (AP) _ Sri Lankan troops killed eight Tamil rebels during an attack on a guerilla position in the northern war zone, the defense ministry said Tuesday. The fatalities occurred Monday when the troops attacked a rebel position on a strategic highway near the rebel-held town of Mankulam, said Colonel Ranjith Withana, the military spokesman. There was no independent confirmation of the report as the government bars journalists from visiting war zones. Tamil rebels are fighting for a separate homeland for the minority Tamils, saying they face discrimination in Sinhalese majority Sri Lanka. More than 52,000 people have died in the 15-year war. Government efforts to control the highway, which links the Tamil heartland of Jaffna with the rest of Sri Lanka, has been stalled near Mankulam for several months. Government troops have not been able to dislodge the rebels from the town which is on the highway. Mankulam is 250 kilometers (155 miles) north of Colombo. Jaffna, a former rebel stronghold, was captured by the army two years ago. Since then, Jaffna's 500,000 residents have had to rely on air and sea deliveries for food and other supplies because the rebels control the highway which is the only land route to the area.
