BC-China-US
U.S., China discuss upcoming summit
BEIJING (AP) _ U.S. President Bill Clinton's top national security aide held talks with Chinese leaders Tuesday on Clinton's planned Beijing summit with President Jiang Zemin late this month. Clinton plans to visit China despite growing criticisms in Congress that could hinder his ability to reach agreements with Chinese leaders. A Senate leader warned Monday that approval for renewing annual China's low-tariff trade terms was in doubt. U.S. Embassy officials said National Security Adviser Sandy Berger was here to prepare for the summit, but refused to discuss specifics. One diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said proposed agreements Clinton and Jiang or their aides might sign at the summit were all ``in flux.'' India's and Pakistan's nuclear testing added urgency to Berger's meetings and opened up another area for potential cooperation between Washington and Beijing, said the diplomat. U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan are to discuss ways to stem a South Asian nuclear arms race with the British, Russian and French foreign ministers in Geneva on Thursday. Berger met with Liu Huaqiu, the security issues expert for China's State Council, or Cabinet, Tuesday morning. He was to see President Jiang and Foreign Minister Tang among others before leaving Beijing late Tuesday, Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao said at a briefing. Zhu said the meetings also covered ``international issues of shared concern,'' but would not give details. U.S. and Chinese officials have been shuttling across the Pacific to arrange Clinton's China trip, the first by a U.S. president in nine years. Despite the high-level diplomacy, differences on substantive issues _ trade, Taiwan, human rights and Tibet _ remain to be bridged. Chinese leaders, who are keen to use summit pageantry to boost domestic support, also want Clinton to make a strong statement limiting U.S. support for Taiwan. U.S. officials say a deal on China's entry to the World Trade Organization is unlikely, barring last-minute market-opening concessions. The atmosphere for witnessing big money business contract signing may be spoiled by congressional inquiries questioning Clinton's dealings with China. The investigations are looking into alleged Chinese donations to Clinton's Democrats and whether U.S. satellite deals he approved helped China upgrade its ballistic missiles. Trent Lott, leader of the Senate's Republican majority, said Monday in Washington that the controversies put in jeopardy the annual extension of China's low-tariff trade status. Clinton spokesman Mike McCurry said the president will make a strong defense for continuing the most-favored-nation trade status by Wednesday's deadline. Zhu, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Washington's annual review of low-tariff trade terms for China was an ``outmoded practice'' that was ``not conducive to smooth trade relations.'' Beijing hopes Washington makes most-favored-nation trade status permanent as soon as possible, he said.

BC-Russia-Economy
Russian president to confer with businessmen over market drop
AP Photos planned By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Trying to halt the slide in Russia's financial markets, President Boris Yeltsin summoned the country's most powerful businessmen and law enforcement officials to the Kremlin on Tuesday. The government said the president's meeting with the 10 business leaders had been scheduled a month ago, but nonetheless Russia's deepening financial crisis would be the top item on the agenda. Investors continued to flee Russian markets on Monday, despite government efforts to entice them back, including interest rates as high as 150 percent. The main stock index dropped another 10 percent, down a total of 44 percent from the beginning of May. The ruble remained stable at around 6.18 to the dollar. But the Central Bank has spent down its reserves to bolster the price in recent weeks and it was not clear how long they would hold out. Yeltsin's meetings were apparently aimed at conferring with law enforcement officials about Russia's pitiful tax collection system, which is a major cause of the federal deficit. The businessmen invited to the Kremlin head Russia's increasingly powerful banking, business and media conglomerates. The ``oligarchs,'' as they are known, were expected to give the president their ideas for coordinated efforts to improve the situation, the Kremlin said. Investors' panic began last week, triggered by reverberations from the Asian financial crisis, a wave of workers' strikes, and a drop in world oil and gas prices. Russia is heavily dependent on oil and gas exports. The Russian stock market, whose performance was the world's best last year, has reversed its fortunes and so far is this year's worst-performing exchange. Speculation is growing that Russia will need a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund, similar to the ones arranged after Asia's financial crisis hit last year. But Russian officials have had trouble meeting the stiff conditions that accompany such aid. The IMF has held up recent installments of the loan to try and force Russian compliance with the terms, which include improved tax collection and limits on government spending. Moreover, the government doesn't want to worsen the appearance of crisis, and argues that Russia's underlying economic indicators remain steady: the economy grew a nominal 0.8 percent last year, and inflation is in the single digits. Mir running smoothly ahead of docking with U.S. shuttle
AP Photo planned By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia's Mir space station held steady in its orbit Tuesday after its crew fixed a computer failure which threatened to delay its planned docking with a U.S. shuttle. Space shuttle Discovery is scheduled to blast off Tuesday night and dock with the station Thursday to pick up astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on the Russian space outpost. NASA considered canceling the hookup after Mir's central computer broke down on Saturday, destabilizing its flight. After three tense days of repairs, Russian cosmonauts Talgat Musabayev and Nikolai Budarin managed to get the computer back on line late Monday and quickly reactivated the station's automatic steering system. ``Mir is now running smoothly and nothing prevents the planned docking with Discovery,'' said Russian Mission Control spokesman Valery Lyndin. He added, however, that the station is now maintaining its alignment using thrusters, which use precious fuel. It will take until late Tuesday to switch on all of Mir's 11 gyroscopes _ the station's preferred, fuel-free orientation system. ``The station can stay on thrusters for quite a while, so even if there is a problem with the gyroscopes the docking won't be jeopardized,'' Lyndin said. Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply dwindles since it can't rotate to keep its solar panels in full alignment with the sun. Luckily, when the latest trouble occurred, the station was on a so-called solar orbit, which puts it in direct sunlight round the clock. As a result, Mir's batteries remained fully charged, making it easier to reactivate the steering system. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a previous shuttle flight in January. That unit failed on Saturday after five months of trouble-free operation. The station's crew has replaced it with a back-up computer brought up by a Russian cargo ship but the new unit also failed on Sunday when the crew attempted to switch it on. Speaking in a radio hookup with ground controllers early Tuesday, Mir's commander Talgat Musabayev said that ``everything is now normal'' on Mir and reported that the crew was busy making final preparations for the docking. Musabayev also complained that media reports of the latest computer breakdown were blown out of proportion. Russia plans to bring down the 12-year-old Mir at the end of 1999 after the first parts of the international space station are in orbit. (vi/mr)

MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ The Philippine government received a record 91 billion pesos (dlrs 2.3 billion) from the sale of state-owned properties under President Fidel Ramos, officials said Tuesday. President-elect Joseph Estrada, who takes office June 30, plans to eclipse that record with privatization revenues of about 100 billion pesos (dlrs 2.6 billion) during his six-year term. Figures released Tuesday by the Department of Finance show privatization revenues during the Ramos administration accounted for most of the 114 billion pesos (dlrs 2.9 billion) received by successive governments since the country embarked on a privatization drive at the end of 1986. Estrada hopes to use privatization receipts to make up for shortfalls in tax revenues and also reduce costly subsidies to often inefficient state-controlled companies. These include Philippine National Bank, National Power Corp., Philippine Phosphate and Fertilizer Corp., and the Philippine Associated and Smelting Corp. Smaller privatizations include numerous media concerns. However, the International Monetary Fund has warned the government not to rely too heavily on privatization proceeds as a source of revenue. Since the privatization program began 12 years ago, some 452 state entities with combined assets of 184 billion pesos (dlrs 4.7 billion) have been sold off. Under Ramos, one of the biggest assets sold to the private sector was the former Fort Bonifacio military camp for 39.2 billion pesos (dlrs 1 billion). On the outskirts of Manila's financial center of Makati, Fort Bonifacio is being developed as a business and residential district. Other large privatizations included Petron Corp., the country biggest refiner, and National Steel Corp. Estrada is eager to see National Power Corp. and Philippine National Bank fully privatized this year.

Israeli defense minister meets Mubarak
By MARIAM SAMI Associated Press Writer
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai met with Egypt's president Tuesday about the Middle East peace process, which is stalemated by Israel's failure to accept a U.S. compromise on a West Bank withdrawal. Israeli radio reports said Mordechai was delivering news that Israel was close to deciding on the U.S. plan. But the Israeli daily Maariv said he hoped to convince President Hosni Mubarak to scuttle a planned Arab summit to discuss Mideast peace. Arab leaders have been discussing holding such a summit, but they are torn by their usual squabbles between those wanting a hard-line stance against Israel and others espousing a more moderate line. The hard-liners want to make good on a warning issued at a 1996 summit that Arab states would pull back from ties with Israel unless Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu kept to pledges made in peace pacts with Palestinians. Mordechai said nothing to reporters when he arrived at Cairo International Airport. He headed immediately to his talks with Mubarak at the president's Unity Palace. Reporters at the palace were told that the two were meeting without aides. The Israeli minister's trip comes a day after the Israeli Cabinet discussed the U.S. compromise but announced no decision. The compromise is an effort to restart Israeli-Palestinian talks stalled since mid-1997 when Israel began a Jewish settlement in traditionally Arab east Jerusalem. The American plan, never made public but widely leaked, calls for a phased withdrawal of Israeli troops from 13 percent more of West Bank land in exchange for Palestinians steps to increase security for Israelis. The Palestinians now have complete control over about 3 percent of the land _ the cities and large towns _ and share control with Israel over a further 23 percent. Under the U.S. plan they'd fully hold 16 percent, with shared area remaining 23 percent. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, who initially wanted a 30 percent withdrawal, has accepted the U.S. compromise. The Iraqi-born Mordechai is viewed as on the moderate side of Netanyahu's right-wing Cabinet. He has urged a ``double-digit'' withdrawal, seen as a vote for the U.S. proposal. Israel has argued pulling back from more than 9 percent of the land would endanger its security. Jewish settlers, who want to retain all the West Bank for Israel, have complained that a larger pullback would isolate some of their settlements. ms-ggl

China says India `solely responsible' for arms race
BEIJING (AP) _ China on Tuesday blamed India for the nuclear arms race in South Asia while muting criticism of staunch ally Pakistan. India was ``solely responsible'' because it tested nuclear bombs first, and Pakistan's tests were a reaction to the nuclear threat from India, Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao said at a briefing. India's five detonations in mid-May and a series of Pakistani explosions last week has stirred fears of a nuclear arms race in South Asia. Beijing originally condemned India for its tests but throughout the crisis has struck a more conciliatory line with Pakistan. Chinese statements have noted Pakistan's security concerns, while expressing ``regret'' over its nuclear response to India. Beijing was particularly upset that the Indian government tried to justify its tests by casting nuclear-power China as its main threat. Relations between the two countries had been improving in recent years despite a dispute over their border. Although Zhu blamed India on Tuesday for starting the arms race, he also urged both countries to heed growing worldwide support against nuclear testing and proliferation. ``We believe neither India's nuclear tests nor Pakistan's conforms to the historical trend,'' Zhu said. China calls on both countries to show ``maximum restraint'' and ``immediately abandon nuclear weapons development,'' Zhu said. Beijing also is urging them to sign the Non-proliferation Treaty and the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, he said. Zhu also repeated the government's denial of allegations that it has helped Pakistan develop nuclear weapons. China has always been against the spread of nuclear weapons and has not helped any country acquire them, he said.

TOKYO (AP) _ A lawyer for two U.S. Marines facing assault and conspiracy charges in Japan said Tuesday that a verdict is expected later this month in the case, which has drawn criticism from three U.S. congressmen. Pfc. William Costello of Farmingdale, New Jersey, and Pvt. Rocky Stubbs of Coshocton, Ohio, pleaded innocent at the opening of their trial Monday in southern Japan's Okinawan District Court, said lawyer Michael Griffith. While the pair have acknowledged joining in a March 7 brawl outside a bar in Okinawa frequented by U.S. military personnel, they argue it was a matter of self-defense, the lawyer said. The two Marines have already paid dlrs 4,600 in compensation to a disc jockey who suffered a broken jaw. The treatment of the Marines after their arrest, however, has prompted a letter of complaint to Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto from two U.S. senators and a House of Representatives member. ``While we understand that these Marines are subject to Japanese law, we are very concerned that their basic human rights and dignity have been severely violated,'' said the letter signed by Sen. Griffith said the Marines were interrogated without legal representation during an initial 23-day detention period, a provision allowed for in a U.S. military agreement with Japan. The lawyer, who called for a revision of the so-called Status of Forces Agreement with Japan, also said a bail application was turned down and that the two men have faced harsh treatment in a Japanese jail. The March 7 fight allegedly broke out after a ``verbal altercation over a cigarette,'' he said. Okinawa, the southernmost island of the Japanese archipelago, is home to about two-thirds of the 47,000 U.S. troops stationed in Japan. (cd)

Philippine stocks suffer heavy losses, peso weakens
Eds: UPDATES 2nd graf with peso closing lower.
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ Philippine stocks plunged to a four-month low Tuesday as most Asian stock markets continued to reel from a selloff triggered by fears of a possible economic recession sweeping the region, traders said. The peso, meanwhile, closed lower against the U.S. dollar but fared noticeably better than other regional currencies pressured by the weak Japanese yen. The 30-share Philippine Stock Exchange Index fell 49.97 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,946.08. It was the index's lowest closing level since Jan. 29, when it registered 1,796.68. On Monday, it gave up 15.40 points. Tuesday was the eighth straight session of losses by the market, with the main index shedding 202.53 points, or 9.4 percent, during the period. Having broken its 1,950-support Tuesday, the index is expected to test its next support level of 1,900 points, traders said. Foremost among the danger signs which sidelined investors was the weak performance of the Japanese yen against the dollar in morning trading, dealers said. Investors feared the weak yen may spawn another round of devaluations of regional currencies. This is expected to further undermine the already fragile state of most Asian economies, many of which contracted in the first quarter, traders said. An exception was the Philippines, whose gross national product grew by 2.5 percent in the three-month period. Taking its cue from the weak yen, the peso averaged 39.396 pesos to a dollar, compared to Monday's 39.072 pesos. Dealers said heavier losses by the peso continued to be averted by weak corporate demand for dollars. The thin demand has helped buffer the peso as other regional currencies have fallen. However, the weak yen, which drove the Thai baht to a three-month low in morning trading and pressured other regional currencies, could still undermine the relative stability in the peso-dollar rate, dealers said. Despite the Philippines' peaceful and credible national elections last month and economic growth in the first quarter, foreign investors aren't inclined to view the country positively given the regional situation, said Mitzi de Dios, trader for ABN-AMRO Hoare Govett Securities Philippines Inc. De Dios said as long as Asia cannot come up with a clean bill of economic health, the Philippines will be unable to capitalize on its inherent advantages. ``Foreign investors, across the board, are pulling out. The Philippines is still better off compared to its neighbors, but the negative sentiment in the region is pulling us down,'' she said.

China's railways to slash workforce, costs in bid to cut losses
By ELAINE KURTENBACH Associated Press Writer
BEIJING (AP) _ China's state-run railways will be reorganized and downsized to help reduce costs and trim losses that have climbed to 16 billion yuan (dlrs 1.9 billion) over the past four years, the Chinese railways minister said Tuesday. Railways are among many unprofitable state-owned industries that are shedding workers in broad reforms intended to make China's economy more competitive. Like many other businesses, the railways are also hoping to enlist more foreign investment and technology for what China estimates to amount to a dlrs 350 billion market, including upgrading of rail lines and purchases of locomotives and other equipment. Railways Minister Fu Zhihuan said that non-transport businesses would be spun off into separate enterprise groups, allowing the railways to focus on their core operations. Ambitious projects are under way that would help open much of the isolated inland areas in China's west and southwest. Meanwhile, speed and services will be improved along main routes such as the Beijing-Shanghai corridor, Fu said at a news conference to publicize the railways' strategy for future development. China has allocated dlrs 450 billion in the five years ending in 2000 to railways development, Fu said, adding that such projects would receive preferential tax and tariff treatment. Unable to keep pace with rapid growth in other industries, China's railways have been a key bottleneck of the economy. Meanwhile, government regulation of the strategically important transport sector has hamstrung efficiency-enhancing reforms. The railways, which employ a total 3.35 million workers in transport and other related industries, reported losses of 4 billion yuan (dlrs 484.26 million) in 1997, bringing cumulative losses to 16 billion yuan (dlrs 1.93 billion). It was the fourth straight year of losses, and Fu predicted that in 1998, the railways would remain in the red with losses of 1.2 billion yuan (dlrs 145.3 million). With other state industries cutting production as they restructure, demand for transport of coal _ which accounts for 43 percent of railroad revenues _ has plummeted. Asked how the railways could hope to regain profitability while industrial output slumps, Fu acknowledged that it could pose a problem. ``You are asking the question that has been troubling me day and night,'' he said. Fu said the railways hoped to compensate for that decline in business, however, by boosting revenues from other freight and passenger transport and by slashing costs. By 2000, the Railways Ministry expects to turn a profit, in keeping with Premier Zhu Rongji's vow to turn loss-making state firms around within three years. ``In the past, we operated rather inefficiently. There is plenty of potential for improvement in costs,'' he said. According to the Railways Ministry plan, of the 1.7 million workers employed in rail transport, 300,000 are due to lose their jobs by 2000. Overall, 1.1 million workers in related industries will be laid off.

Ruling Nationalists get electoral boost
TAIPEI, Taiwan (AP) _ Taiwan's embattled ruling Nationalist Party got another boost Tuesday ahead of year-end elections when the popular mayor of the country's second-largest city decided to run for re-election. Wu Den-yih's decision to enter the race in southern Kaohsiung followed former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou's surprising announcement last week that he will run for mayor of Taipei. ``It will be a very positive development,'' Nationalist Party Secretary General John Chang said of their decisions. For months, both Wu and Ma have rebuffed attempts to draft them as candidates. Their refusal was seen as a vote of no-confidence in their party, which has been mired in criticism of alleged corruption and suspected links with the Taiwanese underworld. The Nationalists lost in last year's local elections, allowing the Democratic Progressive Party, the main opposition, to govern 70 percent of Taiwan's population at the local level. Newspapers said Wu, like Ma, changed his mind after a last-minute appeal from colleagues who said he would ``go down in history as a villain'' because his refusal to run could help hand over power to the opposition. The high-profile mayoral elections could have an impact on results of legislative elections that will be held at the same time in December. The polls are seen as a test run for the presidential elections in 2000, when a successor will be chosen for President Lee Teng-hui. Lee plans to retire after 12 years in office. ``I've decided to enter this race to continue with the past efforts'' to improve Kaohsiung, Wu told a news conference. Wu, Kaohsiung mayor since 1990, has attacked government red tape and its failure to allocate resources to developing southern Taiwan. To win his consent to run, Premier Vincent Siew approved on Monday night requests Wu made several years ago for funds to rebuild a run-down village and the city's water system. Wu will face former DPP lawmaker Frank Hsieh. In Taipei, Ma will run against the powerful incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian. A survey conducted by the private firm Louis Harris International May 22-24 indicated the two races were even. Many Nationalist supporters fear a DPP victory could increase tension with China because of its history of advocating independence. Taiwan has been divided from China politically after the Chinese civil war ended in 1949. China claims Taiwan is a renegade province, and has threatened to use force against it if it declares independence.

PHNOM PENH, Cambodia (AP) _ Cambodian leader Hun Sen said Tuesday that Khmer Rouge guerrilla leaders should be tried for crimes against humanity, but only after their organization is completely destroyed. Drawing a parallel to the Nazi war criminals, he noted that ``following World War II, the Hitlerites ... could be brought to trial at Nuremberg only after their political and military organizations had been dismantled.'' When they held power in the late 1970s, the radical policies of the communist Khmer Rouge led to the deaths of as many as 2 million Cambodians through forced labor, disease and systematic executions. Hun Sen said appeals to hold an international tribunal for Khmer Rouge leaders were ``a trick aimed at preventing Cambodia from achieving real peace.'' The ploy ``cannot be accepted, for it would only help the Khmer Rouge to survive, while prolonging the sufferings of the Cambodian people,'' he was quoted as saying.

MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin denounced his staff Tuesday for failing to fulfill one of government's key tasks: collecting taxes. ``The tax situation has not improved, only worsened, especially in recent months,'' a gruff-sounding Yeltsin told law enforcement officials in a Kremlin meeting broadcast on national television. Russia's pitiful tax collection system is at the heart of the country's current financial crisis, which worsened Monday when the stock market dropped another 10 percent. Altogether, the market has fallen 44 percent in the past month. However, the market rebounded slightly by midday Tuesday, and was up 4 percent from Monday's close. Trying to halt the slide in Russia's financial markets, Yeltsin summoned government and business leaders to confer with him Tuesday. Chief among them were 10 heads of Russia's powerful banking, business and media conglomerates. The ``oligarchs,'' as they are known, were expected to give the president their ideas for coordinated efforts to ease the crisis. Yeltsin planned to have a ``sharp talk'' with them, the Interfax news agency quoted the president as saying. A top Central Bank official acknowledged Tuesday that the bank has spent nearly dlrs 1 billion in reserves over the past month to support the ruble, which remained steady at around 6.18 to the dollar. But Deputy Chairman Sergei Alexashenko said the bank still has dlrs 14.6 billion in reserves, up a low of dlrs 14 billion last week, and the bank has not had to intervene in recent days. Investors' panic began last week, triggered by reverberations from the Asian financial crisis, a wave of workers' strikes, and a drop in world oil and gas prices. Russia is heavily dependent on oil and gas exports. The Russian stock market, whose performance was the world's best last year, has reversed its fortunes and so far is this year's worst-performing exchange. After climbing 98 percent last year, the market has slid 55 percent since the beginning of the year. Speculation is growing that Russia will need a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund or other lenders, similar to those arranged after Asia's financial crisis hit last year. But Russian officials have had trouble meeting the stiff conditions that accompany such aid. The IMF has held up recent installments of the loan to try and force Russian compliance with the terms, which include improved tax collection and limits on government spending. Moreover, the government doesn't want to worsen the appearance of crisis, and argues that Russia's underlying economic indicators remain steady: the economy grew a nominal 0.8 percent last year, and inflation is in the single digits. As a result, the financial crisis has so far affected only investors and its effects have not yet reached ordinary Russians. (mr/ls)

Investigators say pilot error caused plane accident
MANILA, Philippines (AP) _ A pilot error involving the adjustment of engine thrust levers caused a Philippine Airlines jet to lose control and overshoot a runway in March, according to a government report obtained Tuesday. Three people on the ground were killed when the Airbus 320 skidded off the runway, crossed a river and plowed into a row of shanties before stopping atop a nightclub near a crowded commercial center in the Philippines city of Bacolod. A preliminary investigation report on the March 22 accident by the Philippines Air Transportation Office, which has been obtained by The Associated Press, said that during an attempted landing the plane's pilot misadjusted the position of two levers controlling the thrust of his aircraft's two engines. One lever, controlling the left engine, remained on flight mode while a second lever controlling the right engine was shifted to ``reverse thrust,'' the report said. It was not clear why the pilot shifted only one lever to reverse while the other remained on ``flight mode.'' A computer controlling the engines sensed the mismatch and interpreted that the right engine had malfunctioned and provided additional power to it, the report said. The mismatch in thrust caused the plane to veer rightward. The pilot tried to brake the plane but failed as he was also trying to keep the aircraft on the runway, the report said. The faulty lever positions were ascertained by investigators from the plane's flight data recorder. They were not able to question the plane's flight crew because they remain hospitalized under sedation, the report said. It said there was no indication that the accident was caused by weather conditions or problems with navigational or communications equipment. Air transportation chief Carlos Tanega said in March that the pilot missed the normal touchdown zone and landed ``beyond the first half'' of the runway. Airbus Industrie declined to comment on the investigation report. ``Until a public report is published, we have no comment on this accident or any other accident,'' said Sean Lee, a Singapore-based spokesman for Airbus. Philippines Airlines did not return repeated telephone requests for comment. PAL, the country's national carrier, is experiencing severe financial difficulties due in part to the Asian currency crisis. The Airbus 320 was one of four delivered to PAL last year. The airline has ordered 12 of the aircraft as part of a modernization program that began in 1996. The accident followed the crash on Feb. 2 of a Cebu Pacific Air DC-9 jet which flew into a mountain as it prepared to land in the southern Philippine city of Cagayan de Oro, killing all 104 people aboard.

EDS: UPDATES in grafs 8-10 with French coach saying strike AP Photos Planned By IAN PHILLIPS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Air France moved into the second day of a strike Tuesday, and the company president, due to hold talks later in the day with aggrieved pilots, called for a truce to allow the World Cup to go ahead smoothly. Air France president Jean-Cyril Spinetta agreed Monday to meet representatives of pilots' unions to discuss ending the strike which otherwise could continue for at least two weeks, disrupting the June 10-July 12 soccer tournament. The meeting, the first since last-ditch talks broke down Thursday, was scheduled for 3:30 p.m (1330 GMT). In an interview published Tuesday with the newspaper Le Parisien, Spinetta said ``there was still a lot of work to do'' to reach an agreement with the pilots, and suggested postponing talks until after the World Cup. ``Putting off the talks until the summer is absolutely conceivable,'' Spinetta was quoted as saying. He said the company was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike. The strike caused chaos for almost 100,000 passengers Monday, worries for fans and teams attending the month-long World Cup starting June 10 and embarrassment for all. The walkout disrupted training for the French national team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to report Tuesday to resume training. ``Yes, indeed a lot of players will arrive late because of the strike. It risks turning our whole day upside down,'' Jacquet said. Air France's main pilots' union called the 15-day action to protest against 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. Most of the 3,200 Air France pilots did not work Monday. Departure screens at airports around the nation flashed the bad news: ``annule'' and ``canceled'' next to list upon list of flights. Air France planes, many decorated with giant paintings of soccer players representing the 32 competing teams, sat idle. Air France said there would be a slight improvement in traffic Tuesday, with 16-18 percent of long-haul flights taking off, compared to 10 percent Monday, and 32 percent of short- and medium-haul flights scheduled. In total, 44 more flights were scheduled Tuesday, compared to Monday. Air France, the World Cup's official carrier, is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France. The company has said if the strike continues it will probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations. Air France, which almost went bankrupt in 1993, has given no indication it is ready to withdraw a controversial plan to cut pilots' salaries in exchange for shares in Air France. Pilots also want Air France to do away with salary cuts for starting pilots, a system in force for the past year. The strike has left passengers stranded across France at the end of a long holiday weekend. Lyon and Marseille, France's second and third-largest cities and World Cup venues, were particularly hit, as was Paris. BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Thai stocks rose Tuesday after five straight days of losses, while a deputy prime minister tried to curb bad inflation news by predicting price increases would slow in the second half of the year. The Thai currency earlier weakened to 42.25 to the U.S. dollar, tumbling from 41.55 Monday on fears of a deeper recession. It was the lowest level plumbed by the baht in 11 weeks. Supachai Patichpakdi, who is also commerce minister, said in an interview late Monday on the ITV television station that declining inflation would allow high interest rates to fall as well. ``That will benefit the entire economic system,'' Supachai said, without projecting any estimated figures. High interest rates are crippling Thai businesses struggling to survive the current recession, which the government said last week will be far deeper and probably longer than previously expected. The International Monetary Fund has demanded that Thailand keep inflation at an average of 10.5 percent for the year as a condition of receiving a dlrs 17.2 billion economic bailout package. The economy has begun to stabilize under the administration of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, but new declines in the currency and stock market this week on fears of a deeper recession underscored how far the country still has to go. The Commerce Ministry released data Monday that showed Thai consumer prices rose 10.2 percent year-on-year in May, the worst inflation in more than three years. It was the fifth consecutive month this year that the index has kept rising. Inflation has worsened steadily since July 1997, when Thailand abandoned its fixed-exchange rate system under attacks by currency speculators and triggered a chain reaction of crises across Asia.

China says no again to Tiananmen investigation
BEIJING (AP) _ Despite renewed pleas from dissidents and relatives of people killed in the military assault on Tiananmen Square demonstrators, China on Tuesday ruled out any investigation into the crackdown. With the ninth anniversary of the armed quelling coming up on Thursday, Chinese police have grown edgy about challenges to Communist Party rule. At least 20 dissidents have been detained nationwide to prevent public commemorations, by one monitoring group's count. Sporadic labor unrest and resentment among millions of laid-off urban workers nationwide has increased the volatility of what Beijing residents call the ``sensitive'' anniversary season. In central Xi'an city, 200 workers from a nearly bankrupt state construction firm staged a sit-in at a busy intersection Tuesday to protest layoffs, the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China reported. Plainclothes police watched Tiananmen Square in central Beijing in greater numbers Tuesday, despite a constant drizzle. Uniformed officers led away a man wearing a placard on his back decrying a housing dispute. After student-led demonstrators occupied the square for six weeks, military units fought their way into Beijing on June 4, 1989. Hundreds if not thousands were killed. Thousands more were arrested in the ensuing nationwide crackdown. Chinese leaders branded the movement an anti-government rebellion to justify the attack and have never provided an accounting of the dead. In the past week, groups of dissidents and 28 families of people killed in the crackdown have urged the government to investigate the military assault and divulge the death toll. Asked whether the government might agree to a reassessment, Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao said Tuesday that Chinese leaders already had reached the correct conclusion about the ``political disturbances'' and there was no need for a review. Amnesty International said Tuesday at least 250 people remain in jail from the crackdown. The London-based group called on the government to release all political prisoners, not just high-profile dissidents. A democracy campaigner and restaurant owner has been in prison since 1989 for providing free food to the demonstrators. The Hong Kong-based Information Center reported Tuesday that Chen Wei's family was appealing for his release on humanitarian grounds. Chen is serving a 12-year sentence for ``counter-revolutionary propaganda and incitement.'' He has never seen his daughter, born a half year after his arrest, and his wife, tired of raising the child alone, divorced Chen three years ago and returned to her parent's home, the group said.

Cambodian leader says end of Khmer Rouge helps elections registering to vote.
Eds: ADDS last graf with prominent opposition figure Sam Rainsy By KER MUNTHIT Associated Press Writer
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia (AP) _ Cambodian leader Hun Sen says that upcoming elections will be more peaceful than polls in 1993 monitored by the United Nations, thanks largely to the collapse of the Khmer Rouge. In an interview seen Tuesday in his monthly Cambodia New Vision bulletin, Hun Sen said that security had greatly improved in the past five years despite tensions that led to a bloody power struggle with Prince Norodom Ranariddh last year. Hun Sen and Ranariddh emerged from the 1993 polls as co-prime ministers, but the prince was driven into exile by a Hun Sen-led coup last July. Ranariddh came home two months ago to contest elections called by Hun Sen to win his regime international aid and legitimacy. Hun Sen was quoted as saying that eligible voters were flocking to register for the July 26 polls, proving that ``our people prefer to choose a leadership by ballots rather than bullets.'' Critics say that the electoral process has been stacked in favor of Hun Sen, though intimidation and killings of opposition party workers appear to have calmed in the last month. Hun Sen said that the atmosphere is far better than five years ago, when 20,000 U.N. peacekeepers were sent to Cambodia to help supervise polls that cost dlrs 2 billion to organize and were aimed at ending decades of civil war. The Khmer Rouge, who caused the deaths of as many as 2 million Cambodians when they ruled between 1975 and 1979, remained a potent guerrilla force in 1993 and boycotted the polls, threatening to kill Cambodians who voted. But turnout was massive and the rebel group has gradually collapsed. Thousands of war-weary guerrillas have made peace since 1996 while die-hards have been pressed into a few hilltop enclaves near the rugged border with Thailand. ``In 1993, Khmer Rouge occupied many places ...,'' Hun Sen said. ``Those areas have been reintegrated one after another into the royal government.'' Hun Sen said that the government will place 70,000 soldiers and civilians at the disposal of the National Electoral Commission, the body overseeing the polls, to ensure a stable election environment. ``There will be no tanks, no armored vehicles, trenches or safe havens as there were ... in 1993,'' Hun Sen said. Hun Sen welcomed the arrival of a handful of international observers, saying their presence helped ``create an atmosphere of confidence'' in efforts to organize the vote. Meanwhile, opposition figure Sam Rainsy registered to vote in Kompong Cham province. He joins Ranariddh in running as a candidate in Kompong Cham, traditionally viewed as a Hun Sen stronghold. The leader's brother, Hun Neng, is the provincial governor.

Eds: RECASTS throughout to add new details By GEOFF SPENCER Associated Press Writer
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Indonesia's new government pushed ahead with reform Tuesday, recognizing the legitimacy of a previously suppressed labor union and promising to observe basic workers' rights. Meanwhile a new estimate of the wealth of former President Suharto and his family has added pressure on the government to root out corruption that flourished under his 32-year rule. Suharto quit on May 21 following riots and protests amid the worst economic crisis in decades. Independent economist Christianto Wibisono has estimated the Suharto family wealth at about dlrs 20 billion, based on the worth of companies and foundations controlled by them. Other estimates have ranged up to dlrs 40 billion. Critics claim some of the fortune has been placed abroad and should be brought back to help bail out the ailing economy, as prices and unemployment soars, hurting most of Indonesia's 202 million people. Indonesia's attorney general's office launched a broad inquiry on Monday into corruption, including allegations that Suharto's family abused its position and power to build huge business empires. Human rights groups criticized Suharto for suppressing workers' rights and allowing bosses to pay low wages while maintaining sweatshop conditions. Only one state-sanctioned labor union was permitted to operate. Manpower Minister Fahmi Idris told reporters Monday that new President B.J. Habibie would soon ratify an International Labor Organization convention on workers rights. The government would also officially recognize the Indonesian Welfare Labor Union, headed by dissident Muchtar Pakpahan, one of four political prisoners released by the government in recent days, he said. Pakpahan's organization claims to be Indonesia's largest independent labor union, although the exact size of its present membership is unclear. ``According to the labor laws, it meets all criteria to exist,'' the minister said after talks with Habibie, who has promised sweeping reforms and elections by 1999. Until his release last week, Pakpahan had been serving a three-year sentence for allegedly organizing a workers' riot on the island of Sumatra in 1994. Since his release, other charges of subversion against him have been dropped. Despite continuing announcements of reform measures, some students protesters, who played a key role in Suharto's ouster, remain dissatisfied. About 100 students staged a noisy but peaceful protest outside Parliament Tuesday calling for immediate elections and the resignation of Habibie, a longtime friend of Suharto's. About 50 protesters also gathered outside the U.S. Embassy for a second day to criticize tough reform demands being made by the International Monetary Fund. They also accused the United States of meddling in Indonesian affairs through its calls for more reforms. The Washington-based IMF is now considering whether to restart a dlrs 43 billion bailout package for Indonesia. The package was derailed last month when political turmoil hit the world's fourth most populous nation. Hundreds of students in Padang on Sumatra and Ujung Pandang on Sulawesi island continued to occupy government buildings in protest against local official corruption. In disputed East Timor, 1996 Nobel Peace Prize winner Bishop Carlos Belo demanded the Indonesian army withdraw from the half-island territory, invaded by Suharto's troops in 1975 and annexed a year later. Belo said he intended to travel to Jakarta and discuss troop withdrawals with Habibie and Armed Forces chief Gen. Wiranto. Habibie has said he won't change the government's policy on East Timor, a former Portuguese colony. The United Nations has never recognized Indonesia's claim to the island, which was briefly an independent nation after the Portuguese pulled out.

LESIGNY, France (AP) _ Romario, Brazil's hero from the 1994 World Cup and half of the defending champion's ``Ro-Ro'' forward combination, was dropped from the side Tuesday, less than a day before the final rosters were to be submitted to FIFA for France '98. Midfielder Emerson of Bundesliga club Bayer Leverkusen has been called in to replace Romario, team officials announced Coach Mario Zagallo made a brief announcement at the team's training headquarters and then turned the press conference to Romario, who was choked with tears and could not speak. After breaking down again and covering his face with his hands, Romario said: ``I will now proabably learn how to value other things.'' He cried once more before being led away by Brazilian team press officer Nelson Borge as reporters broke out in applause. Romario, who was supposed to form the striking combination with two-time FIFA Player of the Year Ronaldo, will likely be replaced in the starting lineup by Edmundo, but Zagallo would not comment on the matter. Romario trained by himself Saturday while the team was traveling, and felt the injury to his right calf. An MRI on Sunday revealed swelling in the muscle, which could take up to a month to heal, team Dr. Lidio Toledo said Tuesday at the team's French training headquarters. A first MRI had revealed nothing serious, team officials said. Monday night, Brazil's technical committee, comprised of Zagallo, technical coordinator Zico and Toledo, met and decided to drop Romario. The decision to call in Emerson was based on the feeling that Brazil was sufficiently stocked in forwards, having six that could play the position, but that it could use help in backing up Dunga or Cesar Sampaio. PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ International aid organizations warned Tuesday of thousands fleeing the upsurge of violence in restive Kosovo, which has claimed dozens of lives in the past several days. All communications with western Kosovo, where Serb forces recently intensified their campaign to wipe out ethnic Albanian militants, remained cut off Tuesday, so no update on possible new casualties was available. Serb police said four policemen were wounded Monday, one seriously, by ethnic Albanian militants fighting for independence of Kosovo from Serbia. In Pristina, the ethnic Albanian human rights council demanded a humanitarian corridor be opened for western Kosovo, saying the people there face hunger. In total, 44 more flights were scheduled Tuesday, compared to Monday. Air France, the World Cup's official carrier, is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France. The company has said if the strike continues it will probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations. Air France, which almost went bankrupt in 1993, has given no indication it is ready to withdraw a controversial plan to cut pilots' salaries in exchange for shares in Air France. Pilots also want Air France to do away with salary cuts for starting pilots, a system in force for the past year. The strike has left passengers stranded across France at the end of a long holiday weekend. Lyon and Marseille, France's second and third-largest cities and World Cup venues, were particularly hit, as was Paris. The U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is sending the U.S. team on an American Airlines flight to Paris that connects to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses for all their travel plans in France. (ip-dgs)

BC-Sports-Basketball-NBA Finals,0602
As usual, Jazz taking low-key approach to dethroning Bulls AP Sports Writer
By BOB BAUM
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) _ The Utah Jazz are tired of waiting. The Chicago Bulls are just plain tired. Those are two reasons for the pervasive suspicion that the Jazz might be a good bet to bring an end to Michael Jordan's dynasty in the NBA Finals, which begin Wednesday at the Delta Center. With Jordan at full strength, the Bulls have won five championships in the last seven years. Only when he was away playing baseball, or just barely back from playing baseball, did the Bulls fail to win it all. Now Chicago is in the midst of its ``last dance'' _ one final run at a championship before the team is dismantled. Coach Phil Jackson seems gone for sure. Scottie Pippen expects to be playing elsewhere. And Jordan, pondering retirement, might not be playing at all. A farewell title would be a neat wrapup for a team and player who have dominated the game in the '90s. But the formidable Jazz stand in the way. ``In the back of all our minds, it's got to be _ This is the year,'' the Jazz's Greg Foster said. This time, Chicago must win on the road to take the title. Both teams were 62-20 in the regular season. But the Jazz have the home-court advantage because they won both meetings of the two teams. And while the Bulls sweated out a seven-game series against Indiana in the Eastern Conference finals, the Jazz swept the Los Angeles Lakers in four games. They are rested, and way past ready, for Wednesday's opener. By the Game 1 tipoff, the Jazz will have gone 10 days without playing anyone, the second-longest period between playoff games in NBA history. Utah's players know there is a fine line between being rested and being rusty. ``With 10 days off, which is an awful lot, we've got to get back to the type of basketball we were playing against the Lakers,'' Antoine Carr said. The equalizer for the Bulls might be the unmatched desire of Jordan. ``We may be a little tired,'' he said, ``but our heart isn't tired, and that's what's important.'' It was that heart that was on display the last time the Bulls played a playoff game in Utah, when Jordan, sweat pouring off his body as he fought off the flu, scored 38 points in Chicago's 90-88 victory at the Delta Center last year in Game 5. The win put the Bulls up 3-2, and they won Game 6, and the title, in Chicago. ``A motivated Michael Jordan is a scary thing _ obviously,'' Foster said. ``The guy is such a competitor. I don't know how he's still playing the game. He's got all the individual accolades and team accolades you could ever have. He's got all the money in the world. I don't know what drives him, honestly.'' The Jazz need a big series from their MVP, Karl Malone, who faltered in last year's finals. Malone said the important thing against Chicago is to play a physical defense that doesn't allow players to get to the positions they want in the Bulls' triangle offense. Utah spent most of its long layoff wondering whether it would play Chicago or Indiana. Monday was the first practice when the Jazz knew for sure. Utah's experience in its first finals ever last year makes the team more comfortable in its second appearance. ``We know that every ball counts for something _ every loose ball, every rebound,'' Carr said. ``You've got to get all the little things done. If you get all the little things done, everything else will take care of itself.''

Pacific nations working toward phone sales accord CORRECTS throughout that ministers, not officials, will be making decisions; EDITS throughout.
Eds: CLARIFIES in 3rd graf that tests are for importing country' standards; ADDS electronic commerce program details in 8th graf; AP Photo SIN101 By LAURINDA KEYS Associated Press Writer
SINGAPORE (AP) _ Pacific Rim nations plan to take concrete steps this week toward removing trade barriers in the telecommunications industry, the host of an Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum said Tuesday. Singapore's communications minister, Mah Bow Tan, said he hoped a Mutual Recognition Agreement would be reached this week to cut red tape and ease the selling of telephone equipment across the region's borders. The pact would allow products to be tested in the exporting country according to the importing country's standards. That would eliminate costly duplicated testing and certification, considered an informal trade barrier. ``We will be charting new directions for further developing the Asia Pacific Information Society and widening access to information technologies that will help us live better and work smarter,'' Mah said. Mah spoke at the opening of a trade fair ahead of a three-day gathering this week of telecommunications ministers and officials from around the Pacific Rim. The meeting ends on Friday. For the first time, Mah said, an APEC Cabinet ministers' meeting will hear from manufacturers, service providers and marketers from the telecommunications industry. Many industry officials are in Singapore to attend the communications trade exhibition. Although issues such as transparent rules and equal access to markets have already been settled between governments, ``the manufacturers will tell you there are many more pitfalls before the goods actually get into the market,'' Mah said. APEC ministers may also approve an action program for electronic commerce: to promote its use by businesses and consumers; to use it to for government services; to work toward harmonizing the region's policies; to promote development of infrastructure and new applications of the system. ``Both of these initiatives are important steps toward enhancing free and open trade in the APEC region by 2020,'' Mah said. The World Trade Organization estimates business volume conducted by electronic commerce will reach dlrs 200 billion by 2000, but issues such as contracts, legal signatures, payment guarantees and security need to be worked out. Discussions will also be held on creating an electronically linked, knowledge-based Asia-Pacific Information Society, Mah said. That task is only beginning because of the different levels of development, phone density, cable and satellite access available in the member states. ``It's obvious not every economy is going to be able to benefit equally from the process,'' Mah said. But no matter what sector of their economies governments are trying to build up, ``at the end of the day you need to have that strong telecommunications system.''

TEL AVIV, Israel (AP) _ The attorney for the chairman of the Maccabiah Games charged with negligence in the buckling of a foot bridge during Israel's Maccabiah Games questioned Tuesday why police were not held accountable for the collapse. ``The approvals (for the bridge) were signed by all the appropriate authorities, including the engineer, the fire service and the police, yet police accountability was never properly investigated,'' said Dov Weisglass, attorney for Yoram Eyal, chairman of the Maccabiah organizing committing. BC-Russia-START II, 1st Ld-Writethru
Russian parliament to hold closed hearings on START II
Eds: UPDATES thruout with Seleznyov comments.
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia's parliament announced Tuesday that it has decided to move up plans to hold closed-door hearings on the START II treaty, rescheduling the discussions for next week. However, Speaker Gennady Seleznyov warned that the hearings now set for June 9 would be shelved if President Clinton continues to put pressure on Russia to pass the treaty. The hearing had earlier been postponed until the fall, prompting criticism from Washington. Deputy Speaker Vladimir Ryzhkov announced the decision to hold the hearings without providing an explanation, the Interfax news agency said. But after recent nuclear tests carried out by India and Pakistan, some lawmakers have been urging Russia to show its commitment to disarmament by finally ratifying START II. Although the hearings have been scheduled, the State Duma, the lower house of parliament, has not set a date for ratification of the treaty, Seleznyov said at a news conference, according to Interfax. Clinton has said he doesn't want to come to Moscow for a summit with Yeltsin until after the treaty has been passed. That prompted an angry response from Seleznyov. ``Whenever I meet U.S. lawmakers, I ask them to politely tell their president not to articulate phrases that he will not go to Russia if START II is not ratified by the State Duma,'' Seleznyov said. ``If he says the phrase once more, he may count on a postponement of the discussion of the treaty for an indefinite period of time. As they say, Russians have their own pride, so when foreign presidents are trying to impose their dates and terms on us, we simply don't take it.'' Russia's parliament has shown little enthusiasm for the treaty, which would cut Russian and American nuclear arsenals to 3,500 warheads on each side. START II was ratified by the U.S. Senate in 1996, and Russian President Boris Yeltsin has been urging the State Duma to take quick action. But the Communists and nationalists who dominate the Duma have stalled, saying that reducing Russia's nuclear arsenal would further weaken the country's security at a time when conventional forces are weak. Russian military leaders support ratification. They say that by 2007 _ the treaty's deadline for destroying weapons _ Russia's intercontinental ballistic missiles with multiple warheads will be at the end of their service lifetime and will have to be discarded anyway. BC-Russia-Economy, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Russian president denounces poor tax collection, market rises boost investor confidence, market climbs higher, EDITS and TRIMS.
Eds: UPDATES throughout with Yeltsin urging business leaders to AP Photos planned By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin shook his finger at Russia's most powerful businessmen Tuesday and told them to do more to keep investors from pulling out of the country's wobbling financial markets. ``Foreign investors react very quickly,'' he told 10 of Russia's so-called ``oligarchs,'' the men who control the country's banking conglomerates. ``If you want foreign investors to keep their money here then you must tell your own investors not to pull out.'' Trying to halt the slide in Russia's financial markets, Yeltsin summoned government and business leaders to confer with him in the Kremlin Tuesday. Some of the government's responses appear to be working. After dropping another 10 percent Monday, the stock market rebounded by 5 percent in trading Tuesday morning. Russia's inept tax collection system is at the heart of the country's current financial crisis, and Yeltsin also summoned top law enforcement officials to his office to demand better efforts. ``The tax situation has not improved, only worsened, especially in recent months,'' a gruff-sounding Yeltsin said in footage broadcast on national television. Investors' panic began last week, triggered by reverberations from the Asian financial crisis, a wave of workers' strikes, and a drop in world oil and gas prices. Russia is heavily dependent on oil and gas exports. Altogether, the market has fallen 44 percent in the past month, and many analysts have feared the crisis could lead to a run on the fragile national currency, the ruble. A top Central Bank official acknowledged Tuesday that the bank has spent nearly dlrs 1 billion in reserves over the past month to support the ruble, which strengthened slightly early Tuesday to around 6.16 to the dollar. Deputy Chairman Sergei Alexashenko said the bank still has dlrs 14.6 billion in reserves, up a low of dlrs 14 billion last week, and the bank has not had to intervene in recent days. The Russian stock market, whose performance was the world's best last year, has reversed its fortunes and is this year's worst-performing exchange. After climbing 98 percent last year, the market has slid 55 percent since the beginning of the year. Speculation is growing that Russia will need a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund or other lenders, similar to those arranged after Asia's financial crisis hit last year. But Yeltsin spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky said Russia would prefer to lift itself up by its own financial bootstraps. ``The most important thing is to rely on our own resources and agree on joint responses by government and business and financial circles,'' he told a news briefing. In the past, Russia has had trouble meeting the stiff conditions imposed by foreign lenders. The IMF has delayed recent installments of a dlrs 10 billion loan to try and force Russian compliance with the terms, which include improved tax collection and limits on government spending. Moreover, the government doesn't want to worsen the appearance of crisis, and argues that Russia's underlying economic indicators remain steady: The economy grew a nominal 0.8 percent last year, and inflation is in the single digits. As a result, the financial crisis has so far affected only investors and its effects have not yet reached ordinary Russians. (mr/ml)

BC-Netherlands-Religious Hitch
Royal blooper at wedding wounds Catholic sensitivities
AMSTERDAM, Netherlands (AP) _ The joyous wedding of a Dutch prince and his commoner girlfriend has sparked a bitter row between the Roman Catholic Church and the country's Protestant royal family. Saturday's ecumenical church wedding between Prince Maurits, a Protestant, and his Catholic bride, Marilene van den Broek, was without fanfare until the Eucharist was given. At the invitation of one of the officiating clergymen, members of the royal family, who belong to the Dutch Reformed Church, participated in the ritual that is reserved for Catholics. The act ``violated the rule and faith of the Catholic Church,'' Jan-Willem Wits, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church, said Tuesday. Those who took the sacrament included ex-queen Juliana, her husband Prince Bernhard and her daughter Princess Margriet, who is also the mother of the groom. Queen Beatrix and her consort Prince Claus also attended the ceremony, but did not participate in the Communion. A spokesman for the royal family was not immediately available for comment Tuesday. The incident, which has become front-page news, was unusual for this religiously laid-back country. Ahead of the wedding, the fact that Van den Broek is Catholic and the royals are Protestants didn't make much of a stir, except among Calvinist lawmakers who refused to approve a traditional bill in parliament allowing the nuptials. Historically, hostility between Dutch Catholics and Protestants goes back four centuries when it was a cause for the Eighty Year War with Spain. Since William of Orange kicked Spain's Catholic occupiers out of the Netherlands in the 16th century, every Dutch ruler and regent has been Protestant. Maurits is the nephew of Queen Beatrix and fifth in line to the Dutch throne. (jc/bk)

BC-UN-Environment
U.N. seeks cost-saving rules for emission cuts
By TONY CZUCZKA Associated Press Writer
BONN, Germany (AP) _ A U.N. conference that agreed last year on global cuts in ``greenhouse gas'' pollution began debate Tuesday on cost-saving ways for countries to meet the targets. Officials from some 150 nations are working on rules for emission credits, under which industrialized countries can claim credit for helping other countries put in place cleaner technology _ an idea strongly backed by the United States. Some of these measures can save money by shifting the emission cuts from industrialized nations into lower-wage countries, said Michael Zammit Cutajar, the top United Nations official on climate change. The two-week meeting aims to advance last December's U.N. treaty on controlling heat-trapping greenhouse gases, which are blamed for global warming. The accord committed nations for the first time to roll back emissions _ of carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels and five other atmospheric gases _ to pre-1990 levels. New rules for emission credits are to be adopted at a Nov. 2-13 high-level meeting in Buenos Aires, Argentina. One area being discussed is crediting industrialized countries that finance clean technology projects in developing countries. Delegates also want to regulate ``trading'' of emission cuts between industrialized countries allowed under the treaty. Environmental groups and the 15-nation European Union favors a limit on pollution trading, but the Clinton administration, under pressure from U.S. industry, is reluctant. Developing countries have yet to agree on a common stand. Last year's accord in Kyoto, Japan, called for the United States to reduce greenhouse gases to 7 percent below what they were in 1990. The European Union would cut by 8 percent, Japan by 6 percent. The reductions would have to be attained between 2008 and 2012. No country has ratified the Kyoto treaty yet. (tc-cb)

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open, 1st ld-Writethru
Sanchez Vicario moves into semis
Eds: UPDATES with Sanchez Vicario victory; TRIMS. By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Former French Open champion Aranxta Sanchez Vicario moved into the semifinals Tuesday with a three-set win over Patty Schnyder of Switzerland. The fourth-seeded Spaniard lost a tiebreak in the second set but coasted through the third for a 6-2, 6-7 (5-7), 6-0 victory. Sanchez Vicario, who won a contentious match against American Serena Williams in the fourth round, was the first woman to move into the semis. She will face either defending champion Iva Majoli or Lindsay Davenport, who play later Tuesday. But the day's marquee match was between the world's top-seeded woman, Martina Hingis, and Serena's big sister _ Venus Williams. Williams is playing so well at this year's French Open that the match between the two young stars is being seen as worthy of the final. Could there be, finally, a rivalry to match Evert vs. Navratilova? That's what the tennis world hopes. But Hingis isn't ready to call Venus Williams a true rival. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she says. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam.'' ``I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth event on clay, responded diplomatically to Hingis' comments. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, including a 6-0, 6-4 win in the U.S. Open final last summer, their only previous Grand Slam encounter. They are 2-2 this year. But Hingis won their only career encounter on clay, the final of the Italian Open in May. ``It was a good victory for me there,'' Hingis said. ``I hope she will remember that, too.'' Statistically speaking, the two have had an almost identical run through the early rounds here. Hingis has lost just 14 games while averaging 56 minutes per victory. Williams has lost 13 games and averaged 58 minutes per match. But stylistically speaking, they are totally different. Hingis has a masterful touch, moving opponents around the court with precise groundstrokes. Williams is pure power. Marat Safin, an 18-year-old qualifier, used his power to carve his way through the first three rounds. His tournament ended on Monday, however, in five tough sets. The French fans chanted wildly for his opponent, Frenchman Cedric Pioline. ``Allez Cedric!'' they yelled. But as the match wore on, there were growing chants of ``Ma-RAT! Ma-RAT!'' It was in tribute to the remarkable run by the young Russian playing his first Grand Slam event. He began the tournament ranked 116th in the world, but won't be there much longer. ``I think I can beat good players now,'' he said after Pioline ended his run 7-5, 4-6, 6-7 (5-7), 6-4, 6-4. Safin's tournament started with three qualifying matches just to get into the main draw. Next up was Andre Agassi, the former world No. 1 who is in the midst of a strong comeback. Safin, however, had the answer to every problem Agassi presented, then ousted defending champion Gustavo Kuerten, ranked eighth in the world, in another five-setter. In the third round, Safin had a slightly easier time _ needing only four sets to beat Daniel Vacek of the Czech Republic. That set up the match with Pioline. The 28-year-old Frenchman is erratic, but brilliant on occasion. He has reached the finals of Wimbledon and the U.S. Open, both times losing to Pete Sampras. Pioline has a reputation for choking at the end of matches. Although he has reached 12 singles finals in his career, he has captured only two titles. Safin knew nothing of that. ``Nobody told me,'' he said. It didn't matter. This time it was Safin who unraveled. Pioline broke the Russian's serve three times, including once in the fifth set. That was enough. Safin said he wasn't thrown off his game by the 16,000 fans at Roland Garros shouting for Pioline. However, the presence of soccer star Ronaldo in the VIP box was another matter. Asked if he'd been distracted by the Brazilian, in town for the World Cup, Safin thought for a moment, then announced: ``Yes.'' ``I'd never seen Ronaldo so close up before,'' he explained. (jn)

SINGAPORE (AP) _ A decade of increasing prosperity has led to an older population in Singapore, where better health and education is tied to longer life and later parenthood, the government said Tuesday. Singaporeans' median age jumped from 28 to 33 from 1987 to 1997, while the population grew 2 percent, reaching 3,103,500 last year. Those over 60 increased from 8.5 percent of the population to 10 percent. The country's increasingly competitive society means more young men and women have postponed getting married and having babies until they get higher education degrees and good starts on their careers. JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ Indonesia's new government pushed ahead with reform Tuesday, recognizing the legitimacy of a previously suppressed labor union and promising to observe basic workers' rights. Meanwhile a new estimate of the wealth of former President Suharto and his family has added pressure on the government to root out corruption that flourished under his 32-year rule. Suharto quit on May 21 following riots and protests amid the worst economic crisis in decades. An independent economist Christianto Wibisono has estimated the Suharto family wealth at about dlrs 20 billion, based on the worth of companies and foundations controlled by them. Other estimates have ranged up to dlrs 40 billion. Critics claim some of the fortune has been placed abroad and hould be brought back to help bail out the ailing economy, as prices and unemployment soars, hurting the majority of Indonesia's 202 million people. Officials have predicted that the inflation could hit 85 percent in 1998. Central Bureau of Statistics chairman Sugito Suwito warned that the rate might surpass 100 percent if civil unrest breaks out again. Indonesia's attorney general's office launched a broad inquiry on Monday into corruption, including allegations that Suharto's family abused its position and power to build huge business empires. Human rights groups criticized Suharto for suppressing workers' rights and allowing bosses to pay low wages while maintaining sweatshop conditions. Only one state-sanctioned labor union was permitted to operate. Manpower Minister Fahmi Idris told reporters Monday that new President B.J. Habibie would soon ratify an International Labor Organization convention on workers rights. The government would also officially recognize the Indonesian Welfare Labor Union, headed by dissident Muchtar Pakpahan, one of four political prisoners released by the government in recent days, he said. Pakpahan's organization claims to be Indonesia's largest independent labor union, although the exact size of its present membership is unclear. ``According to the labor laws, it meets all criteria to exist,'' the minister said after talks with Habibie, who has promised sweeping reforms and elections by 1999. Until his release last week, Pakpahan had been serving a three-year sentence for allegedly organizing a workers' riot on the island of Sumatra in 1994. Since his release, other charges of subversion against him have been dropped. Despite continuing announcements of reform measures, some students protesters, who played a key role in Suharto's ouster, remain dissatisfied. About 100 students staged a noisy but peaceful protest outside Parliament Tuesday calling for immediate elections and the resignation of Habibie, a longtime friend of Suharto's. About 50 protesters also gathered outside the U.S. Embassy for a second day to criticize tough reform demands being made by the International Monetary Fund. They also accused the United States of meddling in Indonesian affairs through its calls for more reforms. The Washington-based IMF is now considering whether to restart a dlrs 43 billion bailout package for Indonesia. The package was derailed last month when political turmoil hit the world's fourth most populous nation. Hundreds of students in Padang on Sumatra and Ujung Pandang on Sulawesi island continued to occupy government buildings in protest against local official corruption. In disputed East Timor, 1996 Nobel Peace Prize winner Bishop Carlos Belo demanded the Indonesian army withdraw from the half-island territory, invaded by Suharto's troops in 1975 and annexed a year later. Belo said he intended to travel to Jakarta and discuss troop withdrawals with Habibie and Armed Forces chief Gen. Wiranto. Habibie has said he won't change the government's policy on East Timor, a former Portuguese colony. The United Nations has never recognized Indonesia's claim to the island, which was briefly an independent nation after the Portuguese pulled out.

AP Photos planned By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Eritrea has sent reinforcements to border areas disputed by Ethiopia, and Eritrean officers insist that neutral observers could verify that Ethiopian troops had occupied Eritrean territory, a photographer who visited the area said Tuesday. In Badme, 110 kilometers (68 miles) southwest of Asmara, Eritrean troops, tanks and artillery face Ethiopian positions on a ridge, the photographer, on assignment for The Associated Press, said. And an agricultural worker who returned Tuesday to Asmara from western Eritrea said Sudan had bombed several villages in another part of Eritrea near Tessenei, 230 kilometers (143 miles) west of Asmara. It was not immediately possible to confirm the report. Eritrea is hosting the rebel Sudanese National Democratic Alliance, and unconfirmed reports in the past have indicated the NDA has attacked Sudan from bases in western Eritrea. Eritrean officers in Badme, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Ethiopians were 16 kilometers (10 miles) inside Eritrea, according to the boundary drawn by Italian colonizers in the 19th century. One officer said Eritreans want a neutral party with colonial-era maps and a Global Positioning System to visit the border to determine who is where. The photographer said Eritrean reinforcements continued arriving in the area late Monday. Civilians abandoned Badme and surrounding villages in the Yirga triangle and moved north after Eritrean forces blocked an Ethiopian advance last week, the officers said. In Asmara, tarpaulin-covered trucks carrying what appeared to be artillery pieces headed toward Dekemhare, a military garrison town about 30 kilometers (19 miles) south of Asmara. Since its first public comment on the border dispute May 13, Ethiopia has repeatedly claimed that Eritreans have made incursions into Ethiopian territory. Eritrea denies the claims and has suggested international mediation. Ethiopia rejects direct negotiations until Eritrea withdraws and threatened to use force if it did not. Italy occupied what is now Eritrea from 1885 to 1941. Then it became a British-administered territory until 1962, when Ethiopia annexed it. After a 30-year war, Eritrea gained independence from Ethiopia in 1993, and according to standards established by the Organization of African Unity, the border agreed upon was the one drawn by the Italians. Ethiopia claims that Eritrea is illegally occupying the 400-sq. km. (160-sq.-mile) Yirga triangle in northwestern Ethiopia as well as other areas in the northeast. Eritrea has an estimated population of 3.67 million, compared to about 57 million in Ethiopia. An estimated 100,000 Ethiopians live in Eritrea. An official at the Ethiopian Embassy in Asmara said Tuesday few of them appeared to be returning to Ethiopia. President Isias Afwerki said in a nationwide television address Saturday that the border problem was one between governments and not peoples. (js/cm/sl)

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic remained conspicuously silent Tuesday over a major election triumph by his foes in Montenegro, who pledged to defy him and push for more democracy. Milosevic's reaction to the election victory of a coalition led by reform-minded Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic could determine whether Yugoslavia, now made up of Serbia and small Montenegro, breaks up or moves toward democratic changes. Milosevic's ally Momir Bulatovic, who lost the elections, was summoned to Belgrade for urgent consultations with the hard-lining Yugoslav president. There was no word from the meeting. Djukanovic and his aides are determined to stack Montenegro's bloc with their supporters, and hope to team up with the Serbian opposition to either unseat Milosevic or at least weaken his rule. No political analyst in Yugoslavia can imagine Milosevic going quietly. Since rising to power in Serbia in 1987, the wily Milosevic has used a powerfully effective mix of nationalism, tight media control and autocratic methods to cement his hold on power. But Djukanovic's presidential victory last October coupled with Sunday's parliamentary victory seriously weakened Milosevic's grip on the Yugoslav federation. Djukanovic said in an interview with the independent Belgrade Radio Index Tuesday that Milosevic ``will have to accept the new Montenegrin political reality.'' He accused Milosevic of destroying Yugoslavia with his ``arrogant obstinacy'' and said Milosevic ``will have to take the blame for the collapse of the country which he is running'' if he continues attempts to subjugate Montenego. Djukanovic first challenged the Yugoslav power-broker in the winter of 1996-1997, coming out against Milosevic during massive protests against his rule. Last fall, the Montenegrin then narrowly beat Bulatovic _ his former best friend _ for the republic's presidency. Strongly backed by Washington and western Europe, Djukanovic took office in January. The strength of his triumph in Sunday's elections will hand him a majority in the 78-seat Montenegrin parliament. Djukanovic said in the radio interview that he would insist on Bulatovic being replaced as federal premier. Milosevic maneuvered his protege into that office two weeks ago after the previous premier refused to crack down on Djukanovic's pro-Western reforms. Djukanovic's aides have suggested that he would seek holding a referendum in Montenegro on the republic's secession from Yugoslavia if Milosevic doesn't replace Bulatovic. (ds/rp)
