BC-Spain-Nazi Gold,0429
Spain rejects U.S. accusation that it trafficked in Nazi gold
By CIARAN GILES Associated Press Writer
MADRID, Spain (AP) (AP) _ Spain denied new allegations Tuesday from the U.S. State Department that the country under dictator Gen. Francisco Franco sold war material to Hitler in exchange for gold stolen from Jewish victims. ``Spain did not launder Nazi gold stolen or looted from the Jews,'' Foreign Minister Abel Matutes said in response to reports Tuesday of fresh allegations by historians and experts of the U.S. State Department that Spain under Franco played a ``crucial role' in laundering Nazi gold. Matutes said Spain stood by its investigation into the issue that confirmed the country acted correctly in its business dealings with Nazi Germany. The Eizenstat report says Spain was a leading exporter of wolfram metal to Germany, used in the making of canons and armored plating, and that it was frequently paid in gold. Matutes said Spain's exports of wolfram have never been a secret and the fact that the country sometimes was paid with gold did not constitute a charge against Spain. Spain's position regarding the investigation into the origin and destiny of Nazi gold has always been ``clear and honest,'' he said. Spain and four other technically neutral countries in World War II have been accused of handing back less than 20 percent of the looted Nazi gold estimated to be stashed in their banks. In April, a Spanish government commission presented a report in which it absolved Franco's regime of responsibility for the purchase of gold from Germany, saying it did so out of economic necessity in the aftermath of the devastating Spanish Civil War and that the transactions were ``judicially impeccable.'' It said Spain bought a total of 67 tons of gold, worth approximately dlrs 765 million today, from a variety of sources topped by Swiss banks. An earlier U.S. investigation estimated Spanish wartime gold purchases at some 123 tons, almost double the commission's figure, and said most of it originally belonged to Holocaust victims. According to the Spanish report, the U.S. figure was probably boosted by the inclusion of Portuguese gold purchases as well as those of German organizations in Spain. Although the Spanish report absolved Spain of moral or legal responsibility, it recommended that the government make an unspecified donation to the World Sephardi Organization as an expression of solidarity rather than in compensation for wrongdoing.

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, 1st Ld-Writethru
Large parts of Kosovo remain sealed off, four police wounded target Serb civilians
Eds: UPDATES with ethnic Albanian official urging militants not to By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ International aid organizations warned Tuesday of thousands fleeing the upsurge of violence in restive Kosovo, which has claimed dozens of lives in the past several days. All communications with western Kosovo, where Serb forces recently intensified their campaign to wipe out ethnic Albanian militants, remained cut off Tuesday, so no update on possible new casualties was available. Serb police said four policemen were wounded Monday, one seriously, by ethnic Albanian militants fighting for independence of Kosovo from Serbia. Serbs say their forces in western Kosovo are fighting guerrillas, who are fighting for Kosovo's independence from Serbia. But ethnic Albanians and international aid officials spoke of shelled villages and civilians fleeing. Some 2,000 people from Kosovo crossed into northern Albania on Sunday and Monday. Thousands more have been displaced in the province itself, Kris Janowski of the U.N. High Commission for Refugees said in Geneva. Virtually the entire Albanian population of the Kosovo border villages of Junik and Decane fled under attack, the spokesman said. The U.N. refugee agency doesn't know where they are but thinks they must be in surrounding hills. Refugees interviewed in Albania said they fled massive shelling by Serbian forces. They spoke of some 1,500 massed in the village of Junik. With 39 people reported killed over the weekend and fighting apparently continuing, the latest bloodshed is the worst since at least early March, when Serb police killed more than 80 people in a crackdown on independence-minded militants and their families. There were no reports on casualties from fighting Tuesday, but the Serbian pro-government information center reported four policemen wounded on Monday. In Pristina, the ethnic Albanian human rights council demanded a humanitarian corridor be opened for western Kosovo, saying the people there face hunger. Pajazit Nushi, head of the council and a member of ethnic Albanian negotiating team, said talks with the government scheduled for Friday could be canceled. ``I think talks cannot continue if the Serbian side does not withdraw military and police forces from Kosovo and doesn't stop the state terror against the Albanians,'' he said. Meanwhile, six political parties in Kosovo accused Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic of using the Serb-Albanian talks to commit crimes against civilians in Kosovo. ``Another Bosnia is happening in Kosovo,'' they warned, demanding NATO deployment in the province. Most ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo population, want independence from Serbia, which rules the province with a heavy hand. But the population is split on whether to use force to achieve it. Adem Demaqi, a prominent ethnic Albanian leader known as Kosovo's Mandela for the years he spent in Serbian prisons, appealed Tuesday to the Kosovo Liberation Army to refrain from targeting innocent Serb civilians in retaliation for police brutality. The statement by Demaci's Parliamentary Party of Kosovo is the first public message to the militants by any of the Albanian political parties in Kosovo, most of whom deny the existence of the organized militant movement. BC-Egypt-Israel, 1st Ld-Writethru
Israeli defense minister meets Mubarak, explains Israeli stance CHANGES headline.
Eds: UPDATES with comments from Mubarak, Mordechai, Mubarak aide; By MARIAM SAMI Associated Press Writer
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai met with Egypt's president Tuesday about the Middle East peace process, which is stalemated by Israel's failure to accept a U.S. compromise on a West Bank withdrawal. After the nearly three-hour session, President Hosni Mubarak's chief political adviser Osama el-Baz said Mordechai had sought to explain the Israelis' misgivings toward the American proposal. ``According to them, the 13 percent might not be the ideal percentage,'' el-Baz said. He added that for the Israel, ``the important thing is to start the final status negotiations after the withdrawal.'' Only one of three scheduled withdrawals outlined in Israel-Palestinian peace pacts has taken place, but Israel has pushed to move on to negotiations on a final peace agreement between the two sides. To break a more than year-long stalemate in the talks, the United States has proposed a phased withdrawal of Israeli troops from 13 percent more of West Bank land in exchange for Palestinians steps to increase security for Israelis. The Palestinians now have complete control over about 3 percent of the land _ the cities and large towns _ and share control with Israel over a further 23 percent. Under the U.S. plan they'd fully hold 16 percent, with shared area remaining 23 percent. El-Baz said the talks between Mubarak and Mordechai also ``touched upon'' Israel's nuclear capabilities and reporters' questions to the two concentrated on that issue following the recent Indian and Pakistani nuclear tests. Mubarak used the opportunity to expand on his proposal for a nuclear-free Middle East, telling reporters, ``Now I demand that there becomes a principle to eliminate all nuclear weapons in the world on a phase of several years.'' Mordechai, asked if Israel would sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, said only, ``We would like to sign a peace agreement.'' Reporters were told by officials at Mubarak's Unity palace that the Egyptian president and Mordechai began their meetings without aides present. Mubarak, a former pilot and air force general, said in reference to Mordechai's military career that ``the people who witnessed wars and killings are people who understand the true meaning of wars and death.'' The Israeli minister's trip comes a day after the Israeli Cabinet discussed the U.S. compromise but reached no decision. The American proposal is meant to restart peace talks stalled since March 1997 when Israel began a Jewish settlement in traditionally Arab east Jerusalem. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, who initially wanted a 30 percent withdrawal, has accepted the U.S. compromise. The Iraqi-born Mordechai is viewed as on the moderate side of Netanyahu's right-wing Cabinet. He has urged a ``double-digit'' withdrawal, seen as a vote for the U.S. proposal. Israel has argued pulling back from more than 9 percent of the land would endanger its security. Jewish settlers, who want to retain all the West Bank for Israel, have complained that a larger pullback would isolate some of their settlements. The Israeli daily Maariv had said that in Tuesday's talks Mordechai hoped to convince Mubarak to scuttle a planned Arab summit to discuss Mideast peace. But el-Baz made no mention of the summit coming up. Arab leaders have been discussing holding such a meeting, but they are torn by their usual squabbles between those wanting a hard-line stance against Israel and others espousing a more moderate line. ms-bm-ggl

BC-Disarmament-India-Pakistan, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Some 46 countries demand India, Pakistan end tests, join treaties adds byline.
Eds: UPDATES with more speeches, background, edits for transition, AP Photos GEV101-3 By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ Forty-six countries joined Tuesday in demanding that India and Pakistan immediately cease testing nuclear arms and join in the global move to eliminate the weapons. ``The testing of nuclear weapons by India and Pakistan is totally irreconcilable with claims by both countries that they are committed to nuclear disarmament,'' said a joint statement. Islamic countries and others, while expressing concern about the tests, also criticized the five nuclear powers _ Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States. They urged the five powers to drop their opposition to proposed negotiations for the scheduled elimination of their atomic arsenals. India said that, if the five powers had accepted its previous attempts to set up global nuclear disarmament, ``we need not have gone in for our current testing program.'' The five powers were among the countries that backed the joint statement before an emergency meeting of the 61-nation Conference on Disarmament. It said India's and Pakistan's tests ``blatantly undermine'' attempts to halt nuclear proliferation and threaten to undermine efforts to eliminate nuclear weapons. The statement, read by Clive Pearson, New Zealand's ambassador to the conference, said India's and Pakistan's explosions in May were ``provocative and dangerous acts.'' ``Indulging in competitive maneuvers ... belongs to a bygone age,'' said Pearson. He said, ``It is now crucial that India and Pakistan announce immediately a cessation to all further testing of these weapons, renounce their nuclear weapons programs and sign and ratify unconditionally the comprehensive test ban treaty.'' Also supporting the demand were Japan, South Korea, South Africa and European and Latin American nations, but conspicuously missing were Middle Eastern countries. Iran said it viewed the developments with ``deep concern,'' but also urged the declared nuclear powers ``to fulfill their commitment to nuclear disarmament in a time-bound framework.'' ``In the absence of an all-encompassing program for comprehensive nuclear disarmament the status and future of the NPT (Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty) will face great uncertainty,'' said Iranian Ambassador Bozorgmehr Ziaran. Despite Tehran's denials, Iran is widely believed to be pursuing its own nuclear-weapons program. On Monday Iran's foreign minister said on a visit to Islamabad that Muslims welcomed Pakistan's nuclear tests because it gives the Islamic world a bomb to counter Israel's widely suspected arsenal. Other nonnuclear nations joined in urging the five nuclear powers to commit themselves to nuclear disarmament. ``The South African government believes that these developments have made it even more imperative that the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva should now actively and with determination address the issue of nuclear disarmament,'' said Ambassador Jacob S. Selebi, head of the South African delegation. Australia, which joined with New Zealand in invoking the emergency session, urged other countries ``to pursue the objective of a nuclear-weapon-free world.'' (agh-gm)

BC-Netherlands-Religious Hitch, 1st Ld-Writethru
Royal blooper at wedding wounds Catholic sensitivities
Eds: UPDATES with comment from spokesman for royal family.
AMSTERDAM, Netherlands (AP) _ The joyous wedding of a Dutch prince and his commoner girlfriend has sparked a bitter row between the Roman Catholic Church and the country's Protestant royal family. Saturday's ecumenical church wedding between Prince Maurits, a Protestant, and his Catholic bride, Marilene van den Broek, was without fanfare until the Eucharist was celebrated. At the invitation of one of the officiating clergymen, members of the royal family, who belong to the Dutch Reformed Church, participated in the ritual that is reserved for Catholics. The act ``violated the rule and faith of the Catholic Church,'' Jan-Willem Wits, a spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church, said Tuesday. Those who took the sacrament included ex-queen Juliana, her husband Prince Bernhard and her daughter Princess Margriet, who is also the mother of the groom. Queen Beatrix and her consort Prince Claus also attended the ceremony, but did not participate in the Communion. A spokesman for the royal family, Eef Brouwers, said their religious beliefs were a private matter and decline to comment further. The affair, which has become front-page news, was unusual for this religiously laid-back country. Ahead of the wedding, the fact that Van den Broek is Catholic and the royals are Protestants didn't make much of a stir, except among Calvinist lawmakers who refused to approve a traditional bill in parliament allowing the nuptials. Historically, hostility between Dutch Catholics and Protestants goes back four centuries when it was a cause for the Eighty Year War with Spain. Since William of Orange kicked Spain's Catholic occupiers out of the Netherlands in the 16th century, every Dutch ruler and regent has been Protestant. Maurits is the nephew of Queen Beatrix and fifth in line to the Dutch throne. (jc/bk)

Policeman heckles Northern Ireland Secretary over prisoner releases
NEWCASTLE, Northern Ireland (AP) _ A police officer angered by plans to free paramilitary prisoners as part of a new peace deal heckled Britain's senior official in Northern Ireland Tuesday. As Northern Ireland Secretary Mo Mowlam stood to address the Northern Ireland Police Federation, Constable Gordon Taylor, whose colleague died in an IRA bomb attack, shouted, ``Three hundred police officers murdered. No prisoner releases.'' Taylor held up a newspaper listing some 300 police officers murdered in almost 30 years of ``troubles'' in the British-ruled province. Taylor, who is stationed in predominantly Catholic West Belfast, said later that most Royal Ulster Constabulary officers had voted against the agreement in the May 22 referendum because of the plan to release up to 400 paramilitary prisoners within two years. Seventy-one percent of voters approved the plan. Taylor said had been a police officer for just 11 days in 1989 when his colleague was killed in front of his wife and children by a bomb placed under his car. ``Police officers are only human,'' he said of his protest. ``This was a human reaction.'' Earlier, delegates applauded federation chairman Les Rodgers when he said members were ``dismayed and appalled'' at plans to release prisoners. ``I have to tell you that there are people in the Maze and Maghaberry prisons who, by any objective measurement, should not only not get out within the next two years, they should never get out,'' Rodgers said, speaking directly to Mowlam. ``In any other society, serial killers are kept behind lock and key for life. It is a pity that for political expediency we should be an exception.'' The federation represents most of the province's 13,000 police officers. Mowlam said she sympathized with Taylor, but the peace deal could not have been struck without the agreement to release prisoners. ``It is very difficult and I understand when Constable Taylor expresses that view,'' she said. ``No one wanted to do it willingly. But any other agreement that had taken place, accelerated releases is part of it.'' Half the 400 prisoners were due to be released within two years anyway, she said. Britain's Prime Minister Tony Blair said Tuesday that freed paramilitaries will not be allowed to join the Royal Ulster Constabulary, which is due to be reorganized. Some officers have expressed fears that they could end up serving alongside killers. Blair, who met in Belfast with leaders of the eight political parties who have signed up to the deal, said allowing paramilitaries to join ``would be quite wrong.'' Prince Charles was also in the province on Tuesday at the start of a two-day visit. The heir to the throne opened a center for peace and reconciliation at Ballycastle, 45 miles (70 kms) north of Belfast. (scl-rb)

BC-Singapore-Aging Population
Singapore prosperity leads to older population
Eds: CLARIFIES attribution in lead to `government statistics'; ADDS results are from annual statistics report in 2nd graf
SINGAPORE (AP) _ A decade of increasing prosperity has led to an older population in Singapore, where better health and education is tied to longer life and later parenthood, government statistics released Tuesday showed. Singaporeans' median age jumped from 28 to 33 from 1987 to 1997, while the population grew 2 percent, reaching 3,103,500 last year, according to the government's annual statistics report. Those over 60 increased from 8.5 percent of the population to 10 percent. The country's increasingly competitive society means more young men and women have postponed getting married and having babies until they get higher education degrees and good starts on their careers. As in many prosperous countries, these couples are having fewer children than their parents. Those aged 15 to 29 years declined from 30 percent to 22 percent of the population between 1987 and 1997. Meanwhile, the average years of schooling increased from 8.4 to 10.8. The government is concerned over the falling birth rate, especially among Singapore's more educated elite, and has encouraged marriage and more children with tax incentives, media campaigns and government-run matchmaking services.

LONDON (AP) _ Paul Gascoigne says he was drunk the night before he was cut from the England World Cup team. Gascoigne, the 31-year-old midfielder who was dropped Sunday by coach Glenn Hoddle for a lack of fitness, spoke about the incident in a front-page story in Tuesday's tabloid Sun newspaper. ``Yes, I was drunk. Gascoigne, who has been criticized for his reported hard-drinking and smoking 20 cigarettes a day, said he left the bar in La Manga, Spain, had sandwiches in his room with teammate David Seaman, and then ``crashed out.'' Gascoigne also said he had been drinking beer during a Sunday golf game just hours before he met with Hoddle. Given the bad news, the star of England's 1990 World Cup team admitted he exploded. ``He looked at me and said, `Paul, I'm sorry but you're not coming to France. I let my frustration go.'' ``I was crying and out of control. I didn't want to talk to anybody and I didn't want to listen to what Glenn had to say. There is nothing he could say.'' Gascoigne, ranked as one of England's best midfielders, has made more headlines recently for his play off the soccer field. In a highly publicized incident, he admitted beating his estranged wife Sheryl and late apologized for it. He's also been panned by British newspapers for his widely reported late-night capers with show business friends. Opinion polls have supported Hoddle's move. In a poll for GMTV, 62 percent of 8,000 caller supported Hoddle, and telephone poll by the Daily Mail showed 53 percent backing the coach. PRAGUE, Czech Republic (AP) _ President Vaclav Havel said he is ``fed up with everything'' from the media to his office staff, who do not work hard enough in his absence. ``I'm fed up with everything,'' Havel told a minister. ``With my ... office, which became lazy as I haven't been there for a long time already; with the political situation; with what the newspapers write.'' Havel suffered a ruptured colon and acute peritonitis while on vacation in Austria. BC-Sports-Soccer-Brazil-Romario, 2nd Ld Writethru,0733
Romario dropped from Brazilian roster; Emerson called as replacement, Bebeto likely starter
Eds: New throughout with details, quotes By PETER MUELLO Associated Press Writer
LESIGNY, France (AP) _ Romario, Brazil's hero from the 1994 World Cup and half of the defending champion's ``Ro-Ro'' forward combination, was dropped from the squad Tuesday, hours before final rosters were to be submitted to FIFA for France '98. Time ran out for Romario in his race to recover from an injury in his right calf, apparently incurred while he was playing ``foot-volleyball'' on a Rio de Janeiro beach last month. Coach Mario Zagallo waited till the last minute for his 32-year-old forward, who had a personalized training plan and even tried a spiritual healer. But on Sunday it became clear he couldn't recover in time for Brazil's opening game against Scotland on June 10. ``Things are happy for some, sadness for others. But now I think you're all sad as I am. I don't want to mean this is a farewell from soccer,'' he said. After breaking down again and covering his face with his hands, Romario said: ``I will now probably learn how to value other things. ``This won't be a goodbye from me. I'm sure it's not over,'' Romario said in a whisper, then broke down in tears and left the table to cheers and applause. His replacement on the 22-player roster is Emerson, a midfielder of Bundesliga club Bayer Leverkusen. Zagallo said the new starter alongside two-time FIFA Player of the Year Ronaldo will be Bebeto, Romario's co-star on the '94 team. The training camp was abuzz when Zagallo unexpectedly canceled morning practice and called a news conference outside the stately chateau that houses the team in this sleepy suburb of Paris. ``We have bad news,'' began Lidio Toledo, the team's doctor. Romario had reinjured his bad leg during training last Saturday, while the rest of the team was heading to Spain for an exhibition game. Although a first MRI test had showed nothing, a second test last Saturday revealed serious swelling in the muscle. ``He could reinjure it again any time,'' Toledo said. ``This kind of injury could take 10, 15, 20 days or even a month to heal.'' Former star Zico, now the team's coordinator, was one of the sole voices that had spoken out against taking an injured player to the Cup. He recalled his own experience in 1986, when he went injured and missed a penalty shot that led Brazil to elimination by France in the quarterfinals. ``We are very sad that Romario is leaving,'' said Zico. ``But we have the responsibility to continue on and win a fifth world title. For this we have the drive and the talent. There always will be somebody ready to replace anyone else.'' Zagallo, who had faced down charges that he was coddling Romario, said the team's high command had decided against calling another forward because of several midfielders also play forward. In addition to forwards Ronaldo, Bebeto and Edmundo, Rivaldo, Giovanni and Denilson also have played in the front line. Meanwhile, starting midfielders Dunga and Cesar Sampaio have been sidelined by injuries. Although they have recovered, Zagallo felt the team needed more depth at that position. ``This way we're covered,'' Zagallo said. ``Emerson has good technical qualities and plays on the right side. It was just good sense.'' With four World Cup titles to his credit as player, coach or team coordinator, Zagallo shrugged off the loss of Romario. In 1994, he recalled, Brazil lost its two starting fullbacks to injuries and was champion with reserves Marcio Santos and Aldair. The cut almost certainly ends Romario's career on the national team, where he scored 52 goals in 70 games. His greatest moment was at the '94 Cup, when he led Brazil with five goals and was voted the tournament's Most Valuable Player Although four years older and a step slower, Romario remains a team leader, highly popular and respected by the other players _ especially Ronaldo. His loss could be a psychological blow to Brazil. ``This is a very difficult moment for me,'' said Romario. ``But who knows? Maybe now I'll begin to appreciate the other things in life.'' (pm-rjm)

BC-Sports-Field Hockey-World Cup,0537
It's end of the road for penalty corner specialists
By MANDY MANN Associated Press Writer
UTRECHT, Netherlands (AP) _ Penalty corner executioners, those crack specialists who came off the bench to give it their best shot, are now a part of field hockey history. The World Cup that concluded Monday marked the end of the road for the latest dinosaurs in an evolving sport that's placing a new emphasis on free-flowing action to win more sponsors and TV viewers. Penalty corner specialists, who would step up from the bench to slam the ball into the boards or scoop it into the cage, lived a charmed existence for six years before the International Hockey Federation, or FIH, decided to veto the practice. In the future, teams wanting to employ crack penalty corner executioners will have to field them in the playing eleven. ``That's how it should be,'' said Ric Charlesworth, coach of the Australian women's team, which won its second World Cup on Sunday. ``We've always believed in making one of the players on the pitch take the penalty corner. The new rule will abolish stoppages caused by such changeovers,'' Charlesworth said. Crack penalty corner shooters used to figure in the playing eleven even if their main utility was to score with rasping penalty corner shots. But the introduction of the rolling substitution rule after the 1992 Barcelona Olympics brought into vogue specialists whose appearances during matches was restricted to half a minute for every penalty corner. The new rule will force several star players, such as crack Dutch shooter Bram Lomans, England's Calum Giles and Sohail Abbas of Pakistan, to reorient the course of their hockey careers. They'll have to find places on the playing teams to entertain hopes of further success in the sporting arena. The departure of the crack penalty shooter follows the abolition of the off-side rule after the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, a rule change that paid off in more goals at this World Cup. This was the first big tournament played under the no off-side rule. An average of five goals were scored in every game, and the number of field goals outnumbered those from penalty corners. Spurred by the positive response in boosting spectator support and commercial sponsorship, the FIH bosses are looking at changing more rules to make the game less technical and more enjoyable. ``The key is to find the right formula from both a hockey playing point of view and from a commercial point of view,'' said FIH President Juan Angel Calzado. Field hockey, once on the list of endangered Olympic disciplines, has gotten its act together. Getting International Olympic Committee President Juan Antonio Samaranch to back the sport during the World Cup was a major public relations coup. Now the FIH hopes to change the structure of its competitions to involve more hockey-playing nations in premier events. ``On the playing side, the FIH wants to encourage greater participation among lesser-developed countries to develop and strengthen our sport around the world,'' Calzado said.

Kiriyenko tells French newspaper Russia's crisis is psychological
PARIS (AP) _ Russian Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko said his country's problems were above all psychological and that a crisis of confidence was behind the country's deep financial troubles, a French newspaper reported Tuesday. Kiriyenko also said in a lengthy interview with the Le Figaro daily that Russia would not devalue the ruble and would take ``draconian'' measures to collect taxes. ``I am convinced the greatest problems in Russia are not economic but psychological,'' said Kiriyenko, who is set to begin a two-day visit to France on Wednesday. ``Russia is ill. To cure this illness, you can't just fight the symptoms. You have to attack the causes. Behind the financial crisis, there is a crisis of confidence,'' Kiriyenko said. Russia's parliament grudgingly confirmed Kiriyenko, 35, in April and the young prime minister has set redressing the country's economic woes as his main task. His visit to France will be his first overseas and aims to persuade French businessmen to invest in Russia. He is also expected to try to seek support from French political leaders in the event that Russia needs an IMF bailout. Russia's stock market has fallen 44 percent in the past month, and the belief is growing that Russia will need a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund or other lenders, similar to those arranged after Asia's financial crisis hit last year. Kiriyenko said, however, that the government had 14 billion dollars in reserves and would not need to ask for international aid. He also said that ``there will be no devaluation (of the ruble). We will maintain the rate of the ruble.'' Kiriyenko blamed the current crisis on the fact that the government for too long had been spending more than it was collecting in taxes, thus increasing the budget deficit. He said the government would try to hold down spending and planned to reduce family allocations by assisting only those people who were really in need. Millions of Russians have been hard hit by economic reforms that were started under former Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev and accelerated by Boris Yeltsin after the collapse of the Soviet Union. Kiriyenko defended Yeltsin in the interview, saying the Russian president was the country's ``principal support'' and that he was the ``guarantor of stability'' in Russia. (dgs-ae)

Conservatives announce plans for fall convention
PARIS (AP) _ Newly allied French conservatives announced plans Tuesday to hold their first convention in November to define a political program for the next elections. Modernizing the state, strengthening security and justice and lowering taxes were among the issues raised by Philippe Seguin, the provisional president of the Alliance. A new political formation created last month to salvage a right wing crippled by two humiliating electoral defeats and the rise of the far right National Front, the Alliance comprises the Rally for the Republic (RPR), the party of President Jacques Chirac, and the Union for French Democracy (UDF), a federation of center-right parties. If the alliance holds, the new movement could change the French political landscape which until now has been dominated by the RPR, the UDF and the Socialists and their allies on the left. But defeats in the 1997 legislative and in the 1998 regional elections, during which some mainstream conservatives accepted extreme-right votes in order to win, has plunged the right into a deep crisis. The formation of the Alliance appears to have been at least partially inspired by Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's so-called ``plural left,'' which brings socialists, communists and ecologists under its banner. Thai Cabinet approves special economic stimulus package UPDATES baht value with closing figure; EDITS to conform
Eds: RECASTS and UPDATES Cabinet approval of special expenditure;
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Thailand's Cabinet on Tuesday approved a special expenditure of 50 billion baht (dlrs 1.19 billion) as part of an effort to stimulate the economy, which went into a nosedive last year and has yet to recover. The Cabinet instructed government agencies to boost spending by a total of 40 billion baht (dlrs 952 million), and state enterprises by 10 billion baht (dlrs 238 million). That would increase the government's total expenditures in fiscal 1998 to 850 billion baht (20.24 billion), and swell the budget deficit by one percentage point to 3 percent of the gross domestic product. A report in the Bangkok Post newspaper said 40 billion baht (dlrs 952 million), would be drawn from the treasury's reserves of 245 billion baht (dlrs 5.83 billion), and the 10 billion baht (dlr 238 million) for state enterprises would come from borrowing. A large part of the 40 million baht (dlrs 952 million), would be used to pay overdue compensation to persons whose land had been expropriated for infrastructure projects, the Post reported. Some money would also go for occupational training for people who have lost their jobs in the current crisis. Overdue value-added tax refunds are also expected to be paid out of the money. The economy has begun to stabilize under the administration of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, but new declines in the currency and stock market this week on fears of a deeper recession underscored how far the country still has to go. Thai stocks rose Tuesday after five straight days of losses, while a deputy prime minister tried to curb bad inflation news by predicting price increases would slow in the second half of the year. The Stock Exchange of Thailand index gained 0.60 points to 313.64, which dealers attributed to selective buying of banking and finance company stocks that had fallen in recent days. The Thai currency closed at 42.05 to the U.S. dollar, tumbling from 41.55 Monday on fears of a deeper recession. It was the lowest level plumbed by the baht in 12 weeks. High interest rates are crippling Thai businesses struggling to survive the current recession, which the government said last week will be far deeper and probably longer than previously expected. The International Monetary Fund has demanded that Thailand keep inflation at an average of 10.5 percent for the year as a condition of receiving a dlrs 17.2 billion economic bailout package. The Commerce Ministry released data Monday that showed Thai consumer prices rose 10.2 percent year-on-year in May, the worst inflation in more than three years. It was the fifth consecutive month this year that the index has kept rising.

BC-Norway-Whale Revenge
Harpooned whale turns on whaling boat
OSLO, Norway (AP) _ A harpooned whale in a fight for its life rammed the boat that shot it, breaking the vessel's mast and dumping two crewmen into the icy waters. The whale escaped, but it was unclear if it survived its injuries, the Oslo newspaper Verdens Gang reported Tuesday. According to the paper, the Norwegian whaling boat Bolga was off Norway's northern tip Monday when it harpooned a minke whale, which can grow to be about nine meters (30 meters) in length. The whale then rammed the 53-foot (16-meter) wooden boat, and pulled with tremendous force on the rope used to attach the harpoon to the ship. The impact broke the boat's eight-meter (26-foot) mast, The two crewmen who had been spotting whales from a crows' next at the top of the mast plunged into the ocean, about 700 kilometers (425 miles) north of the Arctic Circle. ``I had made it about halfway down the mast when I felt a sudden jolt. The next thing I knew, I was in the water,'' crewman Benn Viggo Nilsen, 40, was quoted as telling the newspaper. Nilsen and the other crewman, Bjoern Johansen, were both rescued. Johansen suffered cracked ribs, while Nilsen was not injured. The whale escaped, although it was not clear whether it survived the injuries. The Bolga was so badly damaged that it had to withdraw from this year's hunt, the report said. Norway has endured frequent protests since resuming its commercial whaling hunts in 1993, despite a ban imposed by the International Whaling Commission in 1986. (dm-jh)

BC-Eritrea-Ethiopia,0525
Eritreans face Ethiopians at disputed border area; reports Sudan bombing Eritrean villages
By JULIA STEWART Associated Press Writer
ASMARA, Eritrea (AP) _ Eritrea has sent reinforcements to border areas disputed by Ethiopia, and Eritrean officers insist that neutral observers could verify that Ethiopian troops occupied Eritrean territory, a photographer who visited the area said Tuesday. In Badme, 110 kilometers (68 miles) southwest of Asmara, Eritrean troops, tanks and artillery face Ethiopian positions on a ridge, according to the photographer on assignment for The Associated Press. Since its first public comment on the border dispute May 13, Ethiopia has repeatedly claimed that Eritreans have made incursions into Ethiopian territory. Eritrea denies the claims and has suggested international mediation. Ethiopia rejects direct negotiations until Eritrea withdraws and threatened to use force if it did not. Ethiopia claims that Eritrea is illegally occupying the 400-sq. km. (160-sq.-mile) Yirga triangle in northwestern Ethiopia as well as other areas in the northeast. Also Tuesday, an agricultural worker who returned to Asmara from western Eritrea said Sudan bombed several villages in another part of Eritrea near Tessenei, 230 kilometers (143 miles) west of Asmara. It was not immediately possible to confirm the report. Eritrea is hosting the rebel Sudanese National Democratic Alliance. Unconfirmed reports in the past have indicated the NDA has attacked Sudan from bases in western Eritrea. Eritrean officers in Badme, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Ethiopians were 16 kilometers (10 miles) inside Eritrea, according to the boundary drawn by Italian colonizers in the 19th century. Italy occupied what is now Eritrea from 1885 to 1941. Then it became a British-administered territory until 1962, when Ethiopia annexed it. After a 30-year war, Eritrea gained independence from Ethiopia in 1993, and according to standards established by the Organization of African Unity, the border agreed upon was the one drawn by the Italians. One officer said Eritreans want a neutral party with colonial-era maps and a Global Positioning System to visit the border to determine who is where. The photographer said Eritrean reinforcements continued arriving in the area late Monday. Civilians abandoned Badme and surrounding villages in the Yirga triangle and moved north after Eritrean forces blocked an Ethiopian advance last week, the officers said. In Asmara, tarpaulin-covered trucks carrying what appeared to be artillery pieces headed toward Dekemhare, a military garrison town about 30 kilometers (19 miles) south of Asmara. Eritrea has an estimated population of 3.67 million, compared with about 57 million in Ethiopia. An estimated 100,000 Ethiopians live in Eritrea. An official at the Ethiopian Embassy in Asmara said Tuesday few of them appeared to be returning to Ethiopia. President Isias Afwerki said in a nationwide television address Saturday that the border problem was one between governments and not people.

Sanchez Vicario, Mantilla move into semis
Eds: UPDATES with Muster loss; TRIMS. By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Aranxta Sanchez Vicario became the first woman in the semifinals of the French Open Tuesday with a three-set victory over Patty Schnyder of Switzerland. The former champion, seeded fourth this year, lost a tiebreak in the second set but coasted through the third for a 6-2, 6-7 (5-7), 6-0 victory. But another former champion, Thomas Muster, continued a disappointing year with a quarterfinal loss to Felix Mantilla of Spain, the No. 15 seed, 6-4, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3. Muster has seen his ranking drop in the past year from ninth to 22nd. Sanchez Vicario, who won a contentious match against American Serena Williams in the fourth round, will face either defending champion Iva Majoli or Lindsay Davenport, who play later Tuesday. But the day's marquee match was between the world's top-seeded woman, Martina Hingis, and Serena's big sister _ Venus Williams. Williams is playing so well at this year's French Open that the match between the two young stars is being seen as worthy of the final. Could there be, finally, a rivalry to match Evert vs. Navratilova? That's what the tennis world hopes. But Hingis isn't ready to call Venus Williams a true rival. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she says. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam.'' ``I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth event on clay, responded diplomatically to Hingis' comments. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. Hingis holds a 5-2 record against Williams, including a 6-0, 6-4 win in the U.S. Open final last summer, their only previous Grand Slam encounter. They are 2-2 this year. But Hingis won their only career encounter on clay, the final of the Italian Open in May. ``It was a good victory for me there,'' Hingis said. ``I hope she will remember that, too.'' Statistically speaking, the two have had an almost identical run through the early rounds here. Hingis has lost just 14 games while averaging 56 minutes per victory. Williams has lost 13 games and averaged 58 minutes per match. But stylistically speaking, they are totally different. Hingis has a masterful touch, moving opponents around the court with precise groundstrokes. Williams is pure power. Marat Safin, an 18-year-old qualifier, used his power to carve his way through the first three rounds. His tournament ended on Monday, however, in five tough sets. The French fans chanted wildly for his opponent, Frenchman Cedric Pioline. ``Allez Cedric!'' they yelled. But as the match wore on, there were growing chants of ``Ma-RAT! Ma-RAT!'' It was in tribute to the remarkable run by the young Russian playing his first Grand Slam event. He began the tournament ranked 116th in the world, but won't be there much longer. ``I think I can beat good players now,'' he said after Pioline ended his run 7-5, 4-6, 6-7 (5-7), 6-4, 6-4. Safin's tournament started with three qualifying matches just to get into the main draw. Next up was Andre Agassi, in the midst of a strong comeback. Safin, however, had the answer to every problem Agassi presented. Then he ousted defending champion Gustavo Kuerten, ranked eighth in the world, in another five-setter. In the third round, Safin had a slightly easier time _ needing only four sets to beat Daniel Vacek of the Czech Republic. That set up the match with Pioline. The 28-year-old Frenchman is erratic, but brilliant on occasion. He has reached the finals of Wimbledon and the U.S. Open, both times losing to Pete Sampras. Pioline has a reputation for choking at the end of matches. Although he has reached 12 singles finals in his career, he has captured only two titles. Safin knew nothing of that. ``Nobody told me,'' he said. It didn't matter. This time it was Safin who unraveled. Pioline broke the Russian's serve three times, including once in the fifth set. That was enough. Safin said he wasn't thrown off his game by the 16,000 fans at Roland Garros shouting for Pioline. However, the presence of soccer star Ronaldo in the VIP box was another matter. ``I'd never seen Ronaldo so close up before,'' he explained. (jn)

U.S., China discuss upcoming summit
Eds: UPDATES with comment by President Jiang Zemin; EDITS to trim.
BEIJING (AP) _ U.S. President Bill Clinton's top national security aide held talks with Chinese leaders Tuesday on Clinton's planned Beijing summit with President Jiang Zemin late this month. Clinton plans to visit China despite growing criticisms in Congress that could hinder his ability to reach agreements with Chinese leaders. U.S. Embassy officials said National Security Adviser Sandy Berger was here to prepare for the summit, but refused to discuss specifics. Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao said the meetings covered Clinton's itinerary and international issues, but also declined to give details. Berger met with President Jiang, who said he was looking forward to meeting Clinton in Beijing, state news media reported. ``His visit to China will undoubtedly promote the bilateral relationship in a sound and stable direction,'' Jiang said, according to the Xinhua News Agency. Berger also met with Vice Premier Qian Qichen, Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan, and Liu Huaqiu, the security issues expert for China's State Council, or Cabinet. U.S. and Chinese officials have been shuttling across the Pacific to arrange Clinton's China trip, the first by a U.S. president in nine years. Despite the high-level diplomacy, differences on trade, Taiwan, human rights and Tibet remain to be bridged. Chinese leaders, who are keen to use summit pageantry to boost domestic support, also want Clinton to make a strong statement limiting U.S. support for Taiwan. U.S. officials say a deal on China's entry to the World Trade Organization is unlikely, barring last-minute market-opening concessions. The atmosphere for witnessing big money business contract signing may be spoiled by congressional inquiries questioning Clinton's dealings with China. The investigations are looking into alleged Chinese donations to Clinton's Democrats and whether U.S. satellite deals he approved helped China upgrade its ballistic missiles. Trent Lott, leader of the Senate's Republican majority, said Monday in Washington that the controversies put in jeopardy the annual extension of China's low-tariff trade status. Clinton spokesman Mike McCurry said the president will make a strong defense for continuing the most-favored-nation trade status by Wednesday's deadline. Zhu, China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Washington's annual review of low-tariff trade terms for China was an ``outmoded practice'' that was ``not conducive to smooth trade relations.'' Beijing hopes Washington makes most-favored-nation trade status permanent as soon as possible, he said.

BC-Sports-Soccer-WC98-Uniforms,0975
PREVIEWING THE WORLD CUP Simpler look returns due to fashion trends, FIFA order
By BRIAN TRUSDELL Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ If the uniforms of the teams at the World Cup seem a little simpler in France this time, it's not just by design _ it's by FIFA fiat. Weary of the mixtures of stripes and swirls, the blending of reds and greens and blues, FIFA has told the Gianni Versaces of the sporting goods industry: enough! ``We really cracked down on the shirts this time, and the shorts as well,'' FIFA spokesman Keith Cooper said. ``We made it clear we wanted one dominant color, unless there was a blue-and-white stripe like Argentina. ``We really tightened up on the manufacturers: what they could do with their (logo); the number on the back, that had become a part of the design element. We were in danger of the uniform losing its original function.'' With the way Adidas, Kappa, Nike, Diadora, Puma, Reebok, Umbro, Hummel and various smaller companies had been designing their shirts, FIFA and some traditionalists were bemoaning the ability to identify one team from another. Some companies used one standard kit design, and then filled it in with the team or country's colors. That was fine unless two countries with the same colors played against one another. The other option was to create a design unique to the particular country, that's where at times the shirts looked like they were put in a blender. Even the goalkeeper's uniforms had gotten into the act, with one, as Cooper described it, ``looked like he had gotten sick all down the front of it _ and the back, don't know how he quite managed that.'' But the simplification probably would've happened without FIFA's intervention anyway, the result of fashion trends _ just not as quickly. ``It has absolutely slowed down. Heavy graphics have been shunned,'' said Tom Kain director of marketing for Nike. ``It's back to building garments for the athletes. It's getting back to basics. ``That's a reflection of demand from the athletes and the consumers.'' FIFA wanted the shirts to be 80 percent of one color, Cooper said, but then relented somewhat realizing that it had no way to exactly determine between 79 and 80 percent. So it decided on a subjective judgment by FIFA staff. Other problems included the stylizing of the numbers on the jerseys and shorts, or stripes and other designs running through the numbers to make them unreadable. For example, on the recently retired U.S. jerseys, the broad stripes that ringed the shirt horizontally made it difficult to identify the numbers. On some jerseys, FIFA made the teams/manufacturers block out a place for the numbers, and made them meet the 30 centimeter (12-inch) size requirement ``I think you're beginning to see what you will see, a much cleaner, more respectful look,'' said Peter Moore, senior vice president of global soccer for Reebok. ``You're seeing a jersey worn more for the nation rather than the manufacturer. ``In most cases, the flag colors are in the jersey. So we're trying to pay homage while still doing some design work to give it distinction.'' But even with the new regulations, manufacturers will take some license. Considering the dlrs 200 million Nike reportedly paid for its deal with Brazil and the other dlrs 120 million it paid for its association with the U.S. Soccer Federation, it still has some say. The input is considerable when your realize that Adidas is anticipating dlrs 600 million in apparel sales from France '98, although not all in replica team jerseys. Yet, they know where they can play, and where they can't. ``Paraguay certainly has a well-known red-and-white stripes with blue shorts,'' Moore said. ``I'm not going to play with that. ``Where we will try to do something is we the away strip. And the third strip, which would gives you three options. That's where we take certain amount of license. Almost certainly, with the away kit, almost anything goes. ``For 30 years England played with red away. But they played in gray (Umbro officially called it indigo blue) in '94 and '96.'' The trick, according to Moore, is for a manufacturer to keep the basic elements of a team uniform the same, while at the same time identifying it with their brand. Working in Nike's ``swoosh'', Reebok's ``vector'', or Adidas' three stripes without being obnoxious is the new challenge. Working design elements with shadow striping, or the fabric's ``jacquard'', is one way. ABA Sport uses the method heavily in incorporating Aztec symbols in the Mexico jersey. Among them, five manufacturers will make the shirts for 23 of the 32 World Cup teams: Puma, Umbro, Reebok, Nike and Adidas, with the latter two accounting for 13 different teams. And they almost all are introducing their latest and greatest technical improvements, a fabric Nike calls ``Dri-Fit''; Umbro calls it ``Vapor-tech.'' Some manufacturers are easily identifiable by their standard design. Puma's shirts for Austria, Cameroon and Bulgaria are noticeable by the standard one color with side panels in a different color. Conversely Umbro, went out of its way to create distinct designs for its three teams: England, Scotland and Norway. For teams like the United States, Jamaica, South Africa or Bulgaria, sides without traditional looks, the urge to tinker will always be in the designer. But for others, there will always be the comfort of knowing Italy's Azzurri will always trot out in their familiar all blue, England in its white, or the Dutch in their orange. ``Some teams are very good about that,'' Cooper said.

BC-Palestinians-Arab Summit
Palestinians want Arab summit regardless of Israeli answer to U.S. proposal
By IMAD MUSA Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ The Palestinians will ask the Arab world to convene a summit whether or not Israel accepts the U.S. proposal for a West Bank redeployment, a top adviser to Yasser Arafat said Tuesday. Arafat has called for an Arab summit to form a unified Arab strategy to ``confront Israeli arrogance,'' which he blames for the deadlock in the Middle East peace process. The Americans have been pressing Israel to accept a proposal for a 13 percent withdrawal from the West Bank. The Palestinians have already accepted the U.S. proposal. Nabil Abourdeineh said Tuesday that he expects the U.S. ideas to be made public ``in the coming four or five days,'' and that a decision on whether to hold a summit would be made at the same time. The Palestinians have been trying to convene the summit since early this year, but the idea has gained momentum in the past two weeks. Despite a recent flurry of meetings in Arab capitals, however, no final decision has been reached. Syria insists the summit put the brakes on normalization of Arab ties with Israel, while Jordan, Israel's closest Arab ally, has apparently balked at that. Abourdeineh did not say why the summit would be needed if Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accepted the U.S. proposal, although there has been no indication he would do so. Negotiations between the Palestinians and Israelis have been frozen since March 1997, when Israel broke ground on a settlement project in the eastern part of Jerusalem, which Palestinians claim as their future capital. Israeli officials charged that the Palestinians' call for an Arab summit violated the peace agreements. im-hla

BC-Yugoslavia-Montenegro,0457
Milosevic silent over Montenegro elections
Eds: Stands for Podorica-dated story offered in AP news digest. By DUSAN STOJANOVIC Associated Press Writer
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic remained conspicuously silent Tuesday over a major parliamentary election triumph by his foes in Montenegro who pledged to defy him and push for more democracy. Milosevic's reaction to the election victory of a coalition led by reform-minded Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic could determine whether Yugoslavia, now made up of Serbia and small Montenegro, breaks up or moves toward democratic changes. Milosevic's ally Momir Bulatovic, who lost the elections, was summoned to Belgrade for urgent consultations with the hard-liner. There was no word from the meeting. Sunday's elections will hand Djukanovic a majority in the 78-seat Montenegrin parliament. Djukanovic and his aides are determined to stack Montenegro's bloc with their supporters, and hope to team up with the Serbian opposition to either unseat Milosevic or at least weaken his rule. No political analyst in Yugoslavia can imagine Milosevic going quietly. Since rising to power in Serbia in 1987, Milosevic has used an effective mix of nationalism, media control and autocratic methods to cement his hold on power. But Djukanovic's presidential victory last October, coupled with Sunday's parliamentary victory, seriously weakened Milosevic's grip on the Yugoslav federation. Djukanovic said in an interview with the independent Belgrade Radio Index Tuesday that Milosevic ``will have to accept the new Montenegrin political reality.'' He accused Milosevic of destroying Yugoslavia with his ``arrogant obstinacy'' and said Milosevic ``will have to take the blame for the collapse of the country which he is running'' if he continues attempts to subjugate Montenego. Djukanovic first challenged the Yugoslav power-broker in the winter of 1996-1997, coming out against Milosevic during massive protests against his rule. Last fall, the Montenegrin narrowly beat Bulatovic _ his former best friend _ for the republic's presidency. Strongly backed by Washington and western Europe, Djukanovic took office in January. Djukanovic said in the radio interview that he would insist on Bulatovic being replaced as federal premier. Milosevic maneuvered his protege into that office two weeks ago after the previous premier refused to crack down on Djukanovic's pro-Western reforms. Djukanovic's aides have suggested that he would seek holding a referendum in Montenegro on the republic's secession from Yugoslavia if Milosevic doesn't replace Bulatovic.

BC-Arabs-Summit, 2nd Ld-Writethru
Saudi prince holds more talks on summit, Jordan wants moderate outcome Precede CAIRO EDITS lower to remove later reference to Abdel-Meguid.
Eds: UPDATES with Abdel-Meguid saying full summit not expected; By JAMAL HALABY Associated Press Writer
AMMAN, Jordan (AP) _ Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Abdullah held further talks Tuesday on a proposed Arab summit as Jordan resisted any move that would have the meeting urge cutting off all ties with Israel. The meeting came as differences persisted over whether to hold the summit in Syria or Egypt and over how strong a message the summit should send to Israel about the breakdown of Middle East peace talks. In Lebanon, Arab League Secretary-General Esmat Abdel-Meguid told the leftist daily As-Safir that he did not expect a full Arab summit now. He said discussions now focused on a meeting of confrontation states _ those around Israel _ plus Saudi Arabia and Morocco. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat has urged a summit to clearly blame Israel for the negotiations stalemate. Israel-Palestinian talks have been stalled since March 1997 when Israel began building a Jewish housing project in traditionally Arab east Jerusalem. Abdullah met Tuesday with Prince Hassan, King Hussein's brother and heir, following overnight talks with the Jordanian monarch on the site and the agenda of the summit. Saudi Foreign Minister Saud al-Faisal met with Deputy Prime Minister Jawad Anani. After the 90-minute session, Anani said that Jordan prefers the summit be held in the headquarters of the 22-member Arab League in Cairo, Egypt. ``The context is the most important to us,'' he told reporters. Syria wants the summit held in its capital, Damascus, where the government of President Hafez Assad could exert more pressure for a strong stance against Israel. Underlining disagreements with Syria on the agenda of the meeting, Anani said more Arab consultations were needed before the convening of the summit. ``A summit is not something that falls out of a tree ... a summit must be well prepared,'' he said. ``We don't want to look to the rest of the world that we are just meeting there to disagree or meeting there just to exchange blames.'' Syria wants the proposed summit to put the brakes on Arabs' normalization of ties with Israel. At their last summit in 1966, the Arabs warned of such a step if Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu did not keep pledges made in peace talks with Palestinians. Jordan, the strongest advocate of peace with Israel, is worried that a hard-line stance could lead to Arab pressures and ultimately jeopardize close trade and political ties developed since the 1994 Jordan-Israel peace treaty. ``There is concern that Jordan and other countries at peace with Israel might be cornered at the summit,'' said a Jordanian official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He told The Associated Press that Jordan wants the summit to support the Palestinians and the peace process and ``focus on Israel's stubborn policy rather than giving Israel more excuses to distance itself from peace.'' Crown Prince Abdullah met with Assad in Damascus before coming to Jordan. He was scheduled to return home later Tuesday. Meanwhile, the visiting U.S. undersecretary of state for political affairs, Thomas Pickering, said after meeting Anani that the proposed summit should deal with the peace process with ``a great deal of care and sensitivity.'' jjh-str-ggl

The government has decided to increase the number of projects to be implemented by union parishads along with an increase in project money. The fund allocation to each UP chairman will be raised to Tk 2 lakh for eight projects a year from the present Tk 50,000 for five projects. This was announced by Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina yesterday. She warned that corruption in implementation of projects would not be tolerated. She was speaking as the chief guest at the conference of union parishad chairmen and members of Dhaka division at the Sher-e-Bangla Nagar Export Trade Fair ground. LGRD and Cooperatives Minister Zillur Rahman and State Minister for LGRD and Cooperatives Mofazzal Hossain Chowdhury Maya Bir Bikram were the special guests. Secretary of the Local Government Division AHM Abdul Hye presented the address of welcome. The Prime Minister said the government would amend the law to increase the sources of income of the union parishads from 7 to 15. She said the government would consider giving union parishad chairmen grants in phases. The government would also consider giving soft loans to the UP chairmen. Sheikh Hasina urged the chairmen and members of the union parishads to play a significant role in eliminating poverty, spreading education and ensuring health care to the rural people. Sheikh Hasina asked the UP chairmen and members to play an effective role in checking terrorism and curbing torture of women and children. She asked them to stop social vices strictly. She said the government had taken measures to train UP chairmen and members with the assistance of the UNDP for improving their leadership quality and efficiency. She said the overall development of villages and improvement of rural infrastructure was the aim of the government. The Prime Minister said the government had taken steps to provide special loans to the rural unemployed youths. The present paid-up capital of Tk 50 crore of the employment bank would be increased to Tk 300 crore in phases. The government had taken up the Tk 360 crore Ideal village project and set up a housing fund with Tk 50 crore capital. Sheikh Hasina said construction of more than 700 feeder roads was now being implemented. Link roads would be constructed in every union. The Prime Minister said the last union parishad election was the most peaceful in the last two decades. She mentioned that this time the women members were elected directly for the first time. She described this as a revolution in social life. She said social development was not possible ignoring the development of women. Sheikh Hasina said the government would provide welfare allowance to teachers and employees of registered primary schools. The government had granted Tk 31,4000,000 for the non-government primary school teachers this year. She said 27 projects for poverty alleviation at a cost of Tk 156 crore were being implemented in the present ADP. She said the government had taken steps to strengthen the local government following the recommendations of the local government commission formed by her government. The Prime Minister said the Upazila Parishad Act would be passed in the next session of the Jatiya Sangsad and Upazila Parishad elections would be held soon after that. Zillur Rahman said the process of strengthening the local government and decentralisation of power would continue. He said the power of the union parishads to lease hats had been raised to Tk one lakh from Tk 50,000 to make the union parishads self-reliant. Thousands of union parishad chairmen and members of Dhaka division, including a large number of women, gathered under the huge pandal at the conference venue at the sprawling Export Trade Fair Ground at Sher-e-Bangla Nagar. Chairman of Goran union parishad in Tangail district Mir Enayet Hossain Montu spoke on behalf of the UP chairmen and UP member Sajeda Begum of Ramdi UP in Kishoreganj district spoke on behalf of the women UP members. Chairman of Boalia UP in Rajbari district Begum Shahida Rahman presented the Prime minister with a crest. The office of the Civil surgeon of Dhaka arranged two medical aid camps at the conference venue. About 130 persons who were affected by the excessive heat were given treatment at the camps. About 30 persons were sent to different hospitals, according to camp sources.

BC-Russia-Trophy Art
Yeltsin reasserts his opposition to trophy art bill
MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin reiterated Tuesday his opposition to a bill that would prevent artwork looted by the Soviet army at the end of World War II from leaving Russia. Yeltsin vetoed the bill last year, but was overridden by both houses of parliament. He signed the bill in April, but immediately asked the country's highest court to determine its constitutionality. On Tuesday, he reasserted his opposition to the law at a meeting with Constitutional Court chairman Marat Baglai. Yeltsin says the law will backfire on Russia, making it more difficult to get its own stolen treasures back. ``They have taken more things out of Russia and we need to return them,'' Yeltsin said during the meeting, according to the ITAR-Tass news agency. At stake are an estimated 1 million books, 55,000 paintings, sculptures and other art works, and 175,000 coins and medals now in Russian state museums. Germany and other countries have long demanded the art back, and Yeltsin wants a free hand in negotiating their return. Russian lawmakers fiercely oppose returning any of the art _ a feeling shared by many Russians who see it as a rightful compensation for the huge human, material and cultural losses inflicted by the Nazis. Yeltsin argues that the trophy art law violates Russia's constitution and international obligations, and does not differentiate between art seized by the Soviet army and that seized by the Nazis. No date for a court hearing has been set. (vi/ls)

BC-Japan-Unemployment
Japanese Cabinet holds special meeting on jobless problem
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's prime minister ordered his Cabinet at a special meeting Tuesday to speed up government public works spending to cut the country's record high jobless rate, news reports said. The meeting of top policy makers came after the government announced Friday that the jobless rate hit 4.1 percent in April _ the highest level since the government started measuring it in 1953. Tuesday's was the first special Cabinet meeting on the economy in two years. Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto instructed Cabinet ministers to speed up disbursement of government spending in regions hit hardest by mounting unemployment levels, the reports said. The Cabinet agreed to hasten public works project expenditure in areas around Tokyo and Osaka, along with Japan's northernmost main island of Hokkaido and southernmost main island of Kyushu, Kyodo News reported. It also decided to expand public financing of jobs projects at businesses in these regions through government-linked financial institutions, national broadcaster NHK said. In April, the Cabinet adopted a public works-heavy 16.7 trillion yen (dlrs 119.9 billion) plan aimed at reviving the ailing Japanese economy. (cd)

BNP Secretary General Abdul Mannan Bhuiyan yesterday said that the state of Human Rights in the country would not be improved until the Awami League government was toppled. ``There are two ways to unseat the Awami League government; the first is to wait for three years for the next elections and the other is to overthrow the government through a mass upsurge,'' the BNP Secretary General said while addressing a seminar on ``The Current Status of Human Rights in Bangladesh'' at the Jatiya Press Club in the city yesterday. He said, ``The country is already in a vulnerable state, and if we have to wait for three years for next elections the country will be utterly ruined''. Organised by Human Rights Watch Bangladesh, the seminar was presided over by Chairman of the organisation, AM Badruzzaman Khasru and also addressed by former Vice Chancellor of Dhaka University, Professor Moniruzzaman Mia, Opposition MP, Amir Khasru Mahmood, President of the Rotary Club of Dhaka Cosmopolitan, Ameer Khashru Mahmud Chowdhury, Ruhul Kabir Rijvi, journalists Nurul Islam Bhuiyan and Amir Khashru, an Associate Professor of Political Science of Dhaka University Dr. Tasmim Siddiqui and Mahfuz Parvez. The BNP Secretary said that the government had even curtailed the inherent rights of the citizens of the country, especially of those who were critical of the government. He also said that the governments were the main violators of human rights different countries in the world for ages. Being critical about the neutrality of the Speaker, the BNP Secretary General said: ``Despite political affiliation, it is natural that the Speaker should be neutral. But unfortunately this Speaker is highly biased towards his political party''. Professor Moniruzzaman Mia said that though it was the constitutional rights to hold meetings and bring out procession, the Opposition was not allowed to do so under this Awami League government. ``The people are living with a fear that they will be sued whenever they will criticise the government,'' the former Vice Chancellor said. He alleged that the law and order situation had deteriorated since the people affiliated with the ruling party had been indulged to gain something out of their positions. ``It seems that they are very hungry for not being in power for the last 21 years,'' he said.

Government paper heralds councils' death, HONGKONG STANDARD xfdws GOVERNMENT-PAPER-HERALDS sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 HONGKONG STANDARD ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
THE government yesterday appeared to hammer a huge nail in the coffin of the Urban and Regional councils, proposing that they be stripped of important powers over food safety and environmental hygiene and listing restructuring options that could result in their abolition. A consultation paper on the future role of the two bodies and the district boards proposes that the government should take over responsibility for food safety and environmental hygiene, amid concern over recent health scares. It also proposes new finance arrangements for the councils' remaining functions of arts, culture, sport and recreation aimed at more public accountability and better value for money. But it further proposes four restructuring options for the thus-weakened councils including one _ which the government appears to favour _ that would dissolve the two bodies altogether. The options are: Merging the two councils but leaving the 18 district boards intact. Dissolving the two councils and transferring their functions to the government and statutory bodies. Merging the two councils and all district boards to form a small number of regional bodies, or Retaining the two councils and the 18 district boards but improving co-ordination of the municipal councils. Listing the pros and cons, the paper gives a positive assessment only of the second, saying it will enhance Legislative Council scrutiny of public spending and ensure greater accountability. The consultation paper says that amalgamating the two councils would not resolve the problem of discrepancies in polices and practices, co-ordination and fragmented responsibilities and the overlap between a combined council and the district boards. On a merger of the two councils and all district boards to form several regional bodies the paper says that some functions such as planning and management of major or territory-wide facilities could be discharged more cost-effectively at the central level by relevant departments or statutory bodies. To decentralise these functions might result in fragmented responsibilities and diminished efficiency. This option would be administratively complex and probably lead to wider diversity in implementation practices and difficulties in co-ordination. On retaining the status quo, the paper says that it is doubtful whether current problems could be satisfactorily resolved if the structure remained intact. ``It appears that unless changes are introduced, the problems cannot be resolved,'' the paper says. However, on the proposal to abolish the two councils the paper is upbeat on its advantages: inclusion of representatives from the arts and sports fields along with community leaders and experts in statutory bodies; public accountability on funding; legislature and district boards oversight; cost-effectiveness; additional resources for district boards along with enhanced role in provision of facilities at local level. However, Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Michael Suen Ming-yeung repeatedly stressed that the government had no preferences among these options. The consultation exercise will close next month and Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa is expected to announce the government's decision in his policy address in October. This would allow time for for next year's elections of the two municipal councils and district boards. However, Democratic Party member Fred Li Wah-ming who is on the Provisional Urban Council, said the government's intentions were obvious.

BC-Thailand-Economy, 4th Ld-Writethru
Thai Cabinet approves special economic stimulus package substituting for earlier newspaper report in grafs 5-7; DELETES old material about inflation
Eds: UPDATES with government explanation of where money will go,
BANGKOK, Thailand (AP) _ Thailand's Cabinet on Tuesday approved 50 billion baht (dlrs 1.19 billion) in special spending as part of a plan to stimulate the economy, which went into a nosedive last year and has yet to recover. The Cabinet instructed government agencies to boost spending by a total of 40 billion baht (dlrs 952 million), and state enterprises by 10 billion baht (dlrs 238 million). That would increase the government's total expenditures in fiscal 1998 to 850 billion baht (20.24 billion), and swell the budget deficit by one percentage point to 3 percent of the gross domestic product. A report in the Bangkok Post newspaper said 40 billion baht (dlrs 952 million), would be drawn from the treasury's reserves of 245 billion baht (dlrs 5.83 billion), and the 10 billion baht (dlrs 238 million) for state enterprises would come from borrowing. Of the 50 billion baht (dlrs 1.19 billion) spending increase, more than half will finance government programs aimed at creating jobs, the government announced. Government agencies will increase their investment budgets by 27 billion baht (dlrs 642.9 million) to pay for projects that create jobs by providing social services. The projects must be short-term because the Thai fiscal year ends Sept. 30. The government also will pump an additional 13 billion baht (dlrs 309.5 million) into the economy by making a big contribution to the country's Social Security Fund, helping to repay the debts of the Bangkok Mass Transit Authority and assisting government employees with their hospital bills. Thai Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda said the government would make a 4.75 billion baht (dlrs 113.1 million) contribution to the Social Security Fund on condition that the fund deposits the money with Thai commercial banks and finance companies. That move is aimed at shoring up the cash supply of Thai financial institutions, which have stopped making fresh loans because of a cash crunch. The economy has begun to stabilize under the administration of Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai, but new declines in the currency and stock market this week on fears of a deeper recession underscored how far the country still has to go. Thai stocks rose Tuesday after five straight days of losses, with the Stock Exchange of Thailand index gaining 0.60 points to 313.64. Dealers attributed the rise to selective buying of banking and finance company stocks that had fallen in recent days. The Thai currency closed at 42.05 to the U.S. dollar, tumbling from 41.55 Monday on fears of a deeper recession. It was the lowest level plumbed by the baht in 12 weeks.

The elections of the Dhaka University Central Students Union (DUCSU) have become uncertain as the leaders of the Awami League backed Bangladesh Chhatra League (BCL) and the Jatiyatabadi Chhatra Dal (JCD) leaders were at variance with each other over holding of fresh polls. The leaders of the BNP backed Jatiyatabadi Chhatra Dal (JCD) and the Bangladesh Chhatra Union have already demanded that a congenial atmosphere should be restored on the campus before to holding the DUCSU polls. The JCD leaders have also threatened to resist any attempt to hold polls unless the DU authorities arrest the armed BCL (S-P) members from the campus and rehabilitate the JCD members in their halls. The criteria for participating in the polls have also created mixed reaction among the leaders of different student organisations including the BCL (S-P). According to the Syndicate's decision, only the regular students of the university will be able to compete for the executive committee posts of the DUCSU. According to the university rule, students completing their honours courses within five academic year and Masters courses within three academic years will be treated as regular students. But those who take more academic years would not be treated as regular students. The Diploma students of the Institute of Education and Research (IER) and the Mphil and PhD students of the university would not be allowed to compete in the DUCSU polls, according to a DU rule regarding DUCSU polls. They can, however, cast their votes in favour of their candidates. BCL (S-P) leader Shujit Roy Nondi who is an Mphil student of the Marketing Department and willing to compete for a DUCSU post, said that the provision to restrict the Mphil students from competing in the polls was a discriminatory one. ``We shall stage a movement against this discriminatory rule,'' he added. The regular students and the emerging leaders of different student organisations were, however, much enthusiastic about the DUCSU polls, sources said. The leaders, who were the irregular students of the university, however, were not in favour of the DUCSU polls, sources said. Though they are willing to compete for DUCSU posts, the university regulations are barring them from doing it, according to sources. The Vice-Chancellor, Prof Abul Kalam Azad Chowdhury said that the DUCSU polls might be held in October or November this year. The DU authorities would call the leaders of different student organisations to fix up the schedules for the polls after the summer vacation, he added. ``We are trying to improve the situation in the university,'' said Prof Abul Kalam Azad Chowdhury when asked about JCD's demand for restoring congenial atmosphere prior to holding of the DUCSU polls. Earlier, the Dhaka University Syndicate in a meeting on Wednesday approved a new constitution for the DUCSU and dissolved it's eight years old committee which was elected in June, 1990. It may be recalled that the DU authorities had taken initiatives to hold DUCSU polls on four occasions after the 1990's polls. Those attempts were frustrated as a result of opposition from different student organisations. Earlier, initiatives were taken in 1991, 1993 and 1994 to hold the DUCSU polls. All those attempts ended in failure, following opposition from the BCL (S-P). Prof Abul Kalam Azad Chowdhury had also earlier taken initiatives to hold the DUCSU polls but his attempts failed due to opposition from the JCD. All the opposing student organisations demanded that congenial atmosphere should be restored on the DU campus prior to holding of the polls.
