Civil servants' pay rise likely to be the lowest in 12 years, HONGKONG STANDARD xfdws CIVIL-SERVANT'S-PAY-RISE sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 HONGKONG STANDARD ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
CIVIL servants are expected to get between 4 and 5 per cent in pay rises this year _ the lowest for 12 years. The Executive Council will discuss the pay rise during its regular meeting this morning before formally unveiling it to civil service union representatives in the afternoon. Almost two weeks ago, civil service unions proposed a 6 per cent across-the-board rise for all levels. It is believed that the Executive Council will only be considering an increase of between 4 and 5 per cent in civil servants' salary because of the economic downturn. ``The people should not expect too much because our economic performance is quite bad,'' the source said. ``We might even face negative growth for the whole year,'' he added. Financial Secretary Sir Donald Tsang Yam-kuen announced on Friday that the economy had shrunk by 2 per cent for the first time in 13 years. The government appears reluctant to grant a higher pay rise to the 190,000-strong civil service because of its effect on the budget. There had been scepticism over whether the government could meet the $10 billion surplus for the 1998-99 budget because of the economic downturn. Philip Kwok Chi-tak, the representative of the Senior Civil Service Council at the Pay Trend Survey Committee, said the unions would be very disappointed if the government granted only a 4 to 5 per cent pay rise. ``We will try to come up with a counter proposal if the government rejects our original demand of a 6 per cent pay rise,'' he said. Mr Kwok said the counter proposal would depend on the government's offer and also on the views of other unions. ``It has to be a collective decision, it is not only our association that will decide,'' he said. Vice-president of the Chinese Civil Servants' Association Peter Wong Hyo said the civil servants' proposal was very reasonable. ``I think civil servants have the right to ask for a pay rise that will help them with inflation,'' he said. ``That is not too much for us.'' Mr Wong said that his association would not consider staging industrial action, similar to that staged by government doctors_ even if they were disappointed with the pay rise. ``I will only support industrial action if the government makes drastic reductions in our pay scale and abolishes certain benefits,'' he said. A survey conducted by the Pay Trend Survey Committee recommended a 5.01 to 6.03 per cent increase in civil servants' salaries compared with 6.81 to 6.9 per cent last year.

BC-Australia-Papua New Guinea-Air Safety
Australians raise doubts about two Papua New Guinea airlines
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ Airline authorities said Tuesday they are prepared to prevent two regional airlines from flying into Australia unless they fix potential safety problems quickly. Transport Minister Mark Vaile said Papua New Guinea's national carrier Air Niugini and Milne Bay Airlines Pty. Ltd. have both already been warned of the possible ban. Vaile said a joint team of Australian and Papua New Guinea authorities had recently conducted a safety audit of both airlines. He said ``deficiencies'' had been identified and there had been an apparent lack of progress in addressing them. ``The Australian government views the issues raised as extremely serious,'' Vaile said. ``A number of deadlines for these airlines to remedy important safety issues have passed without any action from (Papua New Guinea's) Office of Civil Aviation,'' Vaile said. Vaile did not say what these safety issues are, and his spokesman, Peter Cassuben, said these would not be made public at this stage.

Hasina willing to visit Delhi, Islamabad to ease tension, THE INDEPENDENT xfdws HASINA-WILLING-TO-VISIT sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 THE INDEPENDENT ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina is willing to visit New Delhi and Islamabad at the earliest opportunity to meet her counterparts there to discuss the situation arising out of the nuclear tests. In separate letters to Indian Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee and Pakistan Prime Minister Newaz Sharif, the Bangladesh leader said ''personally I would be happy to visit your great country at an early date to discuss the situation arising out of nuclear tests and all issues of mutual concern.'' High Commissioners of India and Pakistan were separately called in the foreign office yesterday afternoon and handed over the letters. Sheikh Hasina was replying to the letters which had been addressed to her by the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan in which they explained their respective positions with regard to nuclear tests, sources at the foreign office said. Vajpayee's letter was received on May 16, while the letter of Sharif's was delivered on May 20. Sheikh Hasina in her ''more or less identical replies'' stressed that the imperative and priority for the countries of the region were development and cooperation among themselves so as to ensure a better quality of life and standard of living for the peoples of South Asia,'' sources added. The Bangladesh Prime Minister pointed out that an arms race involving nuclear weapons and missile technology would be detrimental to these objectives and also affect the atmosphere of cooperation and friendship, she said ''our main concern nationally, at this point of time, is to combat the pervasive problems of poverty, under development, disease, hunger and environmental degradation''. In this context, Sheikh Hasina referred to the successive SAARC meetings and in particular to the recent Bangladesh-India-Pakistan tripartite summit in Dhaka where there was clear expression of political will for greater cooperation and friendship for development in South Asia. While admitting that every country will decide its own security perceptions and take measures accordingly, the Prime Minister expressed her view that ''nuclear weapons did not enhance a country's security in the post-cold war and, indeed, could diminish it''. There was a great realisation the world over of the need for nuclear disarmament, the reply said. Sheikh Hasina expressed the confidence that all differences and problems could be resolved through dialogue and discussion.

BC-Australia-Iraq
Last Aussies to leave Kuwait soon
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ The government announced Tuesday that it will soon withdraw the last of the Australian forces still in Kuwait, sent in case a U.S.-led coalition decided to attack Iraq. Defense Minister Ian McLachlan, who made the announcement, said the decision follows the U.S. decision to reduce its forces in the gulf to roughly pre-crisis levels. Australia sent a contingent of 190 defense personnel to the gulf in February as part of coalition forces intended to persuade Iraq to allow U.N. weapons inspectors to do their work. But most of the Australian forces were withdrawn in May, leaving just one special air services troop of about 30 commandos. However, McLachlan said Australia is still concerned about the situation in Iraq. ``We are still concerned about Iraq's pursuit of chemical and biological weapons,'' he said. McLachlan said Australian forces would be able to return to the Gulf on short notice, if necessary. ``We must keep pressure on Iraq to destroy its weapons of mass destruction,'' he said.

THE plunge in property prices has wiped out an estimated $1.355 trillion in wealth held by private-flat owners. A report released yesterday by Hang Seng Bank warned the property crisis will have a more serious impact than the 1982-1984 crisis when prices tumbled about 40 per cent. ``The wealth effect on consumer spending, the severity of credit contraction and the reduction on property-related activities should be more substantial,'' the Hang Seng Economic Monthly said. The report said a swift recovery for the market ``remains difficult to envisage''. It said one major difference between the current downturn and the one in the early 1980s was the growing perception that there had been a fundamental change in the government's land and housing policies. The report views the government's desire to meet strong housing demand through various supply-side measures _ such as its target of building 85,000 flats a year _ as making it difficult for property prices to recover. The government has also introduced the Tenants Purchase Scheme, under which 25,000 rental-housing units would be offered for sale to tenants each year. ``The perception of a fundamental change in government policies towards land and housing is beginning to change the long-held belief that property prices can keep going up and up,'' the report said. ``There is expectation that residential property will have limited potential for capital appreciation and may not be so good a hedge against inflation as it once was,'' the report said. The bank said that property asset values, which have plunged 35 per cent from a peak in the third quarter of last year, make up about half the total deposits in the local banking system. At the peak of the market last year, the report said, the value of stock of residential flats amounted to about $3.871 trillion in total. ``A 35 per cent drop in prices would thus wipe out some $1.355 trillion from the value of the total stock of private-residential units,'' the bank's report said. The report went on to say it saw the property collapse cutting economic growth by at least two percentage points. ``Falling property prices have reduced the values of collateralised properties for bank loans and contributed to a contraction in credit,'' the report said. ``The significant negative wealth effect has cut deeply into consumer spending,'' the report added. Nevertheless, the bank said the plunge in property prices had largely improved the affordability of housing. The report pointed out that in view of the currency realignment in the region and the need to restore Hong Kong's competitiveness, the downward adjustment in property prices was both inevitable and necessary. However, the steep and abrupt fall in prices had started to undermine confidence in the economy, the report said. Measures to restore market stability would be welcomed, it added. Due to the significant role that the property sector plays in the local economy, the report predicts that the deflationary impact of the latest downturn is expected to be widespread and severe. Meanwhile, DBS Securities yesterday downgraded its forecast for Hong Kong's 1998 economic growth to negative 1.5 per cent of Gross Domestic Product, from its previous level of 1.5 per cent, saying the government's seven-point emergency economic package will not have any substantial impact in lifting the economy. DBS chief economist Chu Siu-wah said the emergency plan will only have a mild impact on both short-term and long-term economic growth. ``We are rather betting on a relatively stable external environment in the second half,'' he said. ``The economic condition will continue to worsen at least for the next six-to-nine months and unemployment will rise sharply to about four to 4.2 per cent for 1998,'' he said.

The President of Bangladesh Chamber of Industries (BCI), Sharif M Afzal Hossain has said the government should keep in the next budget, a 15 per cent difference on average between the import duties on industrial raw materials and finished goods to protect the local industries. ``The average import duty on finished goods should not come down under 30 per cent while that on industrial raw materials should not exceed 15 per cent,'' the BCI President said in an interview with The Independent. Eds: UPDATES with marchers' arrival at meeting. No pickup. CHANGES byline, ADDS photo numbers. AP Photos GEV104-106 By GEIR MOULSON Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ An exuberant group of children rescued from mines, sweatshops and servitude around the world descended Tuesday on Geneva to breathe new life into an old U.N. agency. ``Go, go, global march,'' shouted a group of 150 marchers as they were led into the U.N. European headquarters by 11-year-old Basudev Bhattarai, a former domestic servant from Nepal, and other children. Carrying colorful banners and chanting, they livened up the meeting of the 174-nation International Labor Organization, which is considering a new world convention aimed at abolishing the most extreme forms of child labor. ``We must wash this black spot from the face of humanity without hesitation or delay,'' march co-ordinator Kailash Satyarthi of India told delegates. The marchers' campaign, sponsored by the ILO, the U.N. Children's Fund, Scouts and other organizations, began last January in the Philippines and has included marches in 62 countries worldwide. On Saturday, more than 1,000 demonstrators brought downtown Geneva to a standstill as they marched through the streets. Child labor tops the agenda of the annual two-week ILO meeting, which brings together representatives of government, labor and management. The ILO draws up and monitors conventions on a wide range of labor issues. The campaign against child labor was a boost for the ILO, showing that the oldest U.N. agency stemming from the 1919 creation of the former League of Nations is still needed to stop labor abuses around the world. The ILO has been singled out by the United States in its campaign to reform the world organization. Some U.S. Republicans have accused it of being irrelevant. Other visitors expected at the meeting are newly freed Indonesian labor leader Muchtar Pakpahan, U.N. human rights chief Mary Robinson and Venezuelan President Rafael Caldera. The meeting will work on a declaration committing countries to work toward collective bargaining and the elimination of forced labor. The new child labor convention would call for criminal penalties, specify preventative measures and rehabilitation of child victims. The labor organization also has called for new international legal standards on child labor that would halt slavery and slavery-like practices, forced labor and debt bondage. The standards also would prevent children being used in prostitution and pornography or any activity likely to jeopardize their health or morals. ILO Director-General Michel Hansenne told a news conference that the convention would have to aim for realistic targets. Some campaigners, including Satyarthi, are calling for work that prevents children receiving education to be classed as an extreme form of child labor. Satyarthi regretted heavy spending on arms by developing countries, saying children should be their main priority. ILO surveys have found that a quarter of all children ages 5-14 are economically active, with many of them doing hazardous jobs. Every working child ``is working at the cost of an adult's job'' _ very often that of its parents _ Satyarthi said.

Chittagong Stock Exchange enters into automated trading system today, enlarging its business horizon beyond the port city, with hopes to regain investors' lost confidence. ``The automated system will create a lot of confidence in the Bangladesh capital market, not only among the locals but also the foreign investors,'' said CSE chief Amir Khosru Mahmud Chowdhury. Giving a demonstration of the screen-based trading system to a group of newsmen here on Monday, the CSE President said the system would ensure transparency in the security trade. He said the foreign investors in particular would feel encouraged to come back to Bangladesh, ``because they want to see and invest in transparent capital market''. After opening up of the country's capital market during the first half of 1990s, the foreign portfolio investors put a substantial amount in Bangladesh's emerging market. But they deserted the market after a share scam in late 1996 which, many feel, is a result of lack of transparency and accountability in market activities, coupled with other factors. The Asian Development Bank, approving an 80 million US dollar loan for the capital market development, called for immediate computerisation of stock trade to check any future catastrophe. ``Screen-based trading system will substantially increase the transparency in this situation,'' claimed Khosru setting forth CSE's road to automation. The CSE president will open the system in Dhaka's Ispat Bhaban at Karwan Bazar and CSE stockbrokers from Dhaka and Sylhet, apart from Chittagong, will be able to place sell or buy orders. The systems will be expanded to Bogra and Khulna in the next phase, Khosru told the newsmen. CSE, the country's second bourse, is the first to introduce computerised trading system in Bangladesh while the Dhaka Stock Exchange is due to have it later this month. A total of 30 stock exchanges in the subcontinent have got their own automated trading system. The CSE's technology is most advanced just after the Bombay-based National Stock Exchange of India. The Computer Maintenance Corporation (CMC) of India was engaged for installing the computer systems in the CSE while the American Bellcore International did the telecoms networking. Khosru said in the first phase that begins today, 113 securities would be put in the on-line trading, leaving 30 most active securities for trading on floor. ``The objective is to familiarise the investors with the new trading system.'' In the second phase, due to begin early July, the rest 30 securities, which account for 80 per cent volume in the bourse, will be put in the on-line trade, he said. ``The CSE is on way to fully abolish its floor trading,'' said Khosru, a leading business figure in the country who pioneered the bourse in the port city in 1995. Out of 128 members of CSE, 104 are based in Chittagong, 22 in Dhaka and the rest two in Sylhet, and all of them will have computerised systems to call the main server located in Chittagong. The CSE chief said the bourse would regionally settle all the transactions that will take place on the systems. ``With automation, the turnover in the market will also go up automatically,'' he added. The CSE boss, however, was dissatisfied with delays in introducing a central depository system (CDS) which, he said, is a key to further development of the capital market. ``The full benefit of automation can only be derived if a central depository system is established in our market,'' said Khosru, a member of Parliament from the opposition BNP. He said he had placed a private bill on CDS in parliament a few months back, but things were progressing very slowly. ``The CSE must create confidence. Also the foreign investors want portfolio managers in Bangladesh the foreign investors want portfolio managers in Bangladesh market, but it is very difficult without the CDS.'' CSE Chief Executive Officer AGM Shamsul Kamal told newsmen that they would face some problems with the new system because of the recently introduced one-day netting-settlement system. He called the new settlement system a ``real clumsy situation'' and said they would have to physically transfer hundreds of share certificates everyday between Chittagong, and Dhaka and Sylhet due to the new system. Khosru said they would go by the new settlement system, introduced by the securities and Exchange Commission, regardless for its detrimental effect on the stock market.

THE Special Administrative Region Government yesterday vowed to protect foreign investment in intellectual property as part of its battle against piracy in Hong Kong. Speaking at the opening of the World Intellectual Property Organisation Asian Regional Symposium, Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa also emphasised the importance foreign investors placed on the protection of intellectual property. ``Our population is densely packed and our society is strongly commerce-oriented,'' Mr Tung said. ``We are a world telecommunications centre and a leading centre for film and television production. ``The demand for cheap pirated optical discs is considerable and this provides the incentive for piracy or counterfeiting.'' Mr Tung said Hong Kong's laws on protection of patents, designs, trademarks and copyright works were ``the most complete and modern in the world'' and that the SAR Government was committed to protecting the creative talent of Hong Kong people and providing intellectual property protection for foreign investors. ``My government is determined to protect the creative talent of Hong Kong people, and to encourage investment here by providing proper protection for the intellectual property of our many foreign investors.'' Mr Tung said the Customs and Excise Department and other law enforcement agencies had seized more pirated optical discs in the first five months of this year than for the whole of 1997. Eds: UPDATES with Abdel-Meguid saying full summit not expected. By JAMAL HALABY Associated Press Writer
AMMAN, Jordan (AP) _ Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Abdullah held further talks Tuesday on a proposed Arab summit as Jordan resisted any move that would have the meeting urge cutting off all ties with Israel. The meeting came as differences persisted over whether to hold the summit in Syria or Egypt and over how strong a message the summit should send to Israel about the breakdown of Middle East peace talks. In Lebanon, Arab League Secretary-General Esmat Abdel-Meguid told the leftist daily As-Safir that he did not expect a full Arab summit now. He said discussions now focused on a meeting of confrontation states _ those around Israel _ plus Saudi Arabia and Morocco. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat has urged a summit to clearly blame Israel for the negotiations stalemate. Israel-Palestinian talks have been stalled since March 1997 when Israel began building a Jewish housing project in traditionally Arab east Jerusalem. Abdullah met Tuesday with Prince Hassan, King Hussein's brother and heir, following overnight talks with the Jordanian monarch on the site and the agenda of the summit. Saudi Foreign Minister Saud al-Faisal met with Deputy Prime Minister Jawad Anani. After the 90-minute session, Anani said Jordan prefers the summit be held in the headquarters of the 22-member Arab League in Cairo, Egypt. ``The context is the most important to us,'' he told reporters. Syria wants the summit held in its capital, Damascus, where the government of President Hafez Assad could exert more pressure for a strong stance against Israel. Underlining disagreements with Syria on the agenda of the meeting, Anani said more Arab consultations were needed before the convening of the summit. ``A summit is not something that falls out of a tree ... a summit must be well prepared,'' he said. ``We don't want to look to the rest of the world that we are just meeting there to disagree or meeting there just to exchange blames.'' Syria wants the proposed summit to put the brakes on Arabs' normalization of ties with Israel. At their last summit in 1966, the Arabs warned of such a step if Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu did not keep pledges made in peace talks with Palestinians. Jordan, the strongest advocate of peace with Israel, is worried that a hard-line stance could lead to Arab pressures and ultimately jeopardize close trade and political ties developed since the 1994 Jordan-Israel peace treaty. ``There is concern that Jordan and other countries at peace with Israel might be cornered at the summit,'' said a Jordanian official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He told The Associated Press that Jordan wants the summit to support the Palestinians and the peace process and ``focus on Israel's stubborn policy rather than giving Israel more excuses to distance itself from peace.'' Crown Prince Abdullah met with Assad in Damascus before coming to Jordan. He was scheduled to return home later Tuesday. Meanwhile, the visiting U.S. undersecretary of state for political affairs, Thomas Pickering, said after meeting Anani that the proposed summit should deal with the peace process with ``a great deal of care and sensitivity.''

But having held a number of key posts in South Korea's foreign ministry _ his last post was ambassador to Italy _ Mr Shin is too experienced a diplomat to let the present gloom get him down. ``The relationship between Hong Kong and South Korea has been very vigorous in the past. Unfortunately, recent financial difficulties have placed some understandable strains on that relationship _ the question is how to come out of that situation. Mr Shin recognises that Hong Kong is the business and financial centre in this region. The business relationship between Hong Kong and his country is very important. ``So my priority as consul-general is to build this commercial and financial connection. My role here is, in a broad sense an economic one,'' Mr Shin said. Commenting on Hong Kong property prices and rents, Mr Shin said they were abnormally high. ``If high prices continue there will be business migration from Hong Kong to cities that are less expensive'' he said. Mr Shin conceded that restructuring would necessarily lead to some job losses. Eds: UPDATES with speeches, background, EDITS throughout to AP Photos GEV101-3 By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ Forty-six countries joined Tuesday in demanding that rival neighbors India and Pakistan immediately cease testing nuclear arms and join in the global move to eliminate the weapons. ``The testing of nuclear weapons by India and Pakistan is totally irreconcilable with claims by both countries that they are committed to nuclear disarmament,'' said a joint statement. Islamic countries and others, while expressing concern about the tests, also criticized the five nuclear powers _ Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States _ and urged them to drop their opposition to proposed negotiations for the scheduled elimination of their atomic arsenals. India said if the five powers had accepted its previous attempts to set up global nuclear disarmament, ``we need not have gone in for our current testing program.'' The five were among the countries that backed the joint statement before an emergency meeting of the 61-nation Conference on Disarmament. It said India's and Pakistan's tests ``blatantly undermine'' attempts to halt nuclear proliferation and threaten to undermine efforts to eliminate nuclear weapons. The statement, read by Clive Pearson, New Zealand's ambassador to the conference, said India's and Pakistan's explosions in May were ``provocative and dangerous acts.'' ``Indulging in competitive maneuvers ... belongs to a bygone age,'' he said. ``It is now crucial that India and Pakistan announce immediately a cessation to all further testing of these weapons, renounce their nuclear weapons programs and sign and ratify unconditionally the comprehensive test ban treaty.'' Also supporting the demand were Japan, South Korea, South Africa and European and Latin American nations, but conspicuously missing were Middle Eastern countries. Iran said it viewed the developments with ``deep concern,'' but also urged the declared nuclear powers ``to fulfill their commitment to nuclear disarmament in a time-bound framework.'' ``In the absence of an all-encompassing program for comprehensive nuclear disarmament the status and future of the NPT (Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty) will face great uncertainty,'' said Iranian Ambassador Bozorgmehr Ziaran. Despite Tehran's denials, Iran is widely believed to be pursuing its own nuclear-weapons program. On Monday Iran's foreign minister said on a visit to Islamabad that Muslims welcomed Pakistan's nuclear tests because it gives the Islamic world a bomb to counter Israel's widely suspected arsenal. Other non-nuclear nations joined in urging the five main nuclear countries to commit themselves to nuclear disarmament. ``The South African government believes that these developments have made it even more imperative that the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva should now actively and with determination address the issue of nuclear disarmament,'' said Ambassador Jacob S. Selebi, head of the South African delegation. Australia, which joined with New Zealand in invoking the emergency session, urged other countries ``to pursue the objective of a nuclear-weapon-free world.''

Saudi authorities to reveal true story of bombing, says paper
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) - The Saudi government is expected to announce next month the results of its investigation into the 1996 bombing that killed 19 U.S. servicemen, a Saudi-owned newspaper reported Tuesday. The London-based Al-Hayat said the government has concluded the bombing was carried out by a Saudi Islamic group with help from Iranian-backed factions in Kuwait and Bahrain. The report comes amid conflicting statements by Saudi officials on who was behind the bombing of a military housing complex at al-Khobar in eastern Saudi Arabia that strained U.S.-Saudi relations. The Saudis have completed the investigation and ``what remains is only the announcement ... which could be made soon,'' Al-Hayat said. It added the results could be made public after the World Cup soccer tournament which ends in July. Saudi Arabia is participating in the games in France. Last month, Saudi Interior Minister Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz was quoted as saying Saudi citizens were to blame for the explosion in al-Khobar near the city of Dhahran and foreigners were not involved. The statement to a Kuwaiti newspaper was the first to rule out foreign participation in the attack, which also injured scores of U.S. soldiers. But a few days later, Saudi newspapers reported that the minister was misquoted and had only said that while Saudi citizens were the perpetrators, they received help from foreign groups. Earlier Saudi security sources suggested that several Shiite Muslims with links to Shiite Muslim Iran played a role in the bombing. Al-Hayat said investigators believe the explosion was carried out by ``an Islamic group that lives in the kingdom.'' It said some of the attackers were arrested in Kuwait and were handed over to Saudi Arabia later. That raised the speculation about their links with radical Shiite groups of Hezbollah parties in both Kuwait and Bahrain, it said. The charge has been dismissed by Shiite dissidents in Saudi Arabia who contend that the Saudi government is using the explosion as a pretext to target the disadvantaged minority, which has been agitating for better job opportunities and living conditions. The paper did not explain the discrepancy in the Saudi statements, but Saudi dissidents said the press leaks on the explosion reflect a power struggle inside the Saudi royal family and differences over issues such as relations with Iran. Crown Prince Abdullah is a known to be behind growing ties with Tehran, while some of the royal family members are believed to favor a slowdown. Top U.S. officials have publicly rebuked the Saudis for frustrating their efforts to find out who was responsible for the bombing. In Saudi Arabia, secrecy has shrouded the investigation, and Saudi officials have been reluctant to comment. sn-ggl

Lithuanian presidents strikes conciliatory tone with Russia
By JIM HEINTZ Associated Press Writer
STOCKHOLM, Sweden (AP) _ Facing renewed harsh Russian reaction to NATO's possible inclusion of former Soviet states, Lithuanian President Valdas Adamkus on Tuesday said aspiring alliance members must understand the Kremlin's anxiety. Adamkus statement came during a visit to the Swedish capital one day after Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov reiterated that NATO membership for former Soviet states such as Lithuania is ``unacceptable.'' ``This is no surprise,'' Adamkus told a news conference. ``I believe there is good reason for Russia to demand this kind of status'' _ that the Baltic states stay out of the alliance. ``The attitude toward NATO in Russia will change'' over time as the Kremlin learns the alliance has no designs on Russia, said Adamkus. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia all desire NATO membership. Russia, concerned that membership would give the Western alliance a strategically critical position along its Western borders, has been bitterly opposed. Russia last year offered the three countries security guarantees if they would abandon their efforts to join NATO, but all three coldly refused. The statement by Adamkus, who became president in February, was notably more conciliatory than much previous reaction from the Baltics. ``I hope that by continuous discussion, Lithuania has more to gain than by taking the rigid and confrontational position,'' he said. Adamkus, who fled Lithuania during World War II and became a top environmental official in the United States before returning to his native land last year, said his decades in America made him sensitive to another concern of Russia's _ the treatment of ethnic Russians inthe Baltic states. Hundreds of thousands of ethnic Russians in the Baltics became stateless after the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991. Russia has threatened Latvia _ with Baltics' largest ethnic Russian community _ with trade sanctions unless it improves their status. Adamkus promised Lithuania would establish ``absolutely equal rights for all.'' ``I enjoyed total freedom (in the United States) for 50 years,'' he said. ``All in Lithuania should have the same rights.'' By MARIAM SAMI Associated Press Writer
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Israeli Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai met with Egypt's president Tuesday about the Middle East peace process, which is stalemated by Israel's failure to accept a U.S. compromise on a West Bank withdrawal. After the nearly three-hour session, President Hosni Mubarak's chief political adviser Osama el-Baz said Mordechai sought to explain the Israeli misgivings toward the American proposal. ``According to them, the 13 percent might not be the ideal percentage,'' el-Baz said. He added that for the Israel, ``the important thing is to start the final status negotiations after the withdrawal.'' Only one of three scheduled withdrawals outlined in Israel-Palestinian peace pacts has taken place, but Israel has pushed to move on to negotiations on a final peace agreement between the two sides. To break a more than yearlong stalemate in the talks, the United States has proposed a phased withdrawal of Israeli troops from 13 percent more of West Bank land in exchange for Palestinians steps to increase security for Israelis. The Palestinians now have complete control over about 3 percent of the land _ the cities and large towns _ and share control with Israel over a further 23 percent. Under the U.S. plan, they'd fully hold 16 percent, with shared area remaining 23 percent. El-Baz said the talks between Mubarak and Mordechai also ``touched upon'' Israel's nuclear capabilities and reporters' questions to the two concentrated on that issue following the recent Indian and Pakistani nuclear tests. Mubarak used the opportunity to expand on his proposal for a nuclear-free Middle East, telling reporters, ``Now I demand that there becomes a principle to eliminate all nuclear weapons in the world on a phase of several years.'' Mordechai, asked if Israel would sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, said only, ``We would like to sign a peace agreement.'' Reporters were told by officials at Mubarak's Unity palace that the Egyptian president and Mordechai began their meetings without aides present. The Israeli minister's trip comes a day after the Israeli Cabinet discussed the U.S. compromise but reached no decision. The American proposal is meant to restart peace talks stalled since March 1997 when Israel began a Jewish settlement in traditionally Arab east Jerusalem. Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, who initially wanted a 30 percent withdrawal, has accepted the U.S. compromise. The Iraqi-born Mordechai, viewed as a moderate side, has urged a ``double-digit'' withdrawal, seen as a vote for the U.S. proposal. Israel has argued pulling back from more than 9 percent of the land would endanger its security. Jewish settlers, who want to retain all the West Bank for Israel, have complained that a larger pullback would isolate some of their settlements.

THE Basic Law should be amended to allow the government to stimulate the economy through a deficit budget during hard times, the Confederation of Trade Unions says. The confederation will submit a 10-point proposal to the government on the eve of the first meeting of its task force on employment led by Financial Secretary Sir Donald Tsang Kam-kuen tomorrow. Confederation chief executive Elizabeth Tang Yin-ngor, who is also a member of the task force, described the Basic Law's requirement for fiscal balances as inflexible when a higher level of public expenditures was needed. ``This deters the government from formulating a budget to correspond with the economic climate,'' Ms Tang said. The confederation proposes a $20 billion injection into the economy. It also suggests the speeding up of infrastructure projects, an unemployment fund, improved retraining programs, reduced rates and rent and the scrapping of the labour importation scheme. Ms Tang said the government should adjust its view that recovery would be led by the private sector. ``The government measures were focused on assisting the private sector. But in fact, the majority of firms, especially small and medium enterprises, are in difficulty. ``As the government is relatively rich in this sense, it should take the lead and introduce more active measures.'' But Ms Tang said she did not have high hopes for tomorrow's meeting. ``It seems that a set of policies has already been formulated, and the government just wants to hear our opinion,'' she said. The meeting is expected to discuss retraining programs, assistance for starter businesses and the review of Labour Department services.

Jane's: China planning to build aircraft carrier by 2020
LONDON (AP) _ China plans to build an aircraft carrier but it will not be fully operational until 2020, Jane's Defense Weekly reported Tuesday. Senior Chinese naval sources were quoted as saying that the carrier program was approved at last year's 15th Communist Party Congress in Beijing. But it appears to have been moved from China's 1996-2000 five-year plan to the 2001-2005 five-year plan, the military affairs magazine quoted naval sources as saying. The delivery of southeast Asia's first aircraft carrier to Thailand has increased the Chinese military's determination to acquire the necessary technology, Jane's said. The carrier program calls for a 24-month feasibility study to produce a design concept, the magazine said in its June 3 issue. ``The People's Liberation Army Navy expects it will take around 18 years to complete building, fitting out, sea trials and training before the first carrier is declared operationally ready,'' Jane's said. That means a carrier would not be fully operational until 2020, it said. A senior naval source quoted by the magazine said one of the leading Beijing defense studies institutes ``will be tasked with preparing a feasibility study'' from the year 2000. This will include a decision on what type of aircraft to use on the carrier, Jane's said. The magazine said unidentified diplomats believe that China's Central Military Commission is prepared to wait until 2000 to begin the study because it still has to secure funding for the carrier program. ``It is estimated that it could cost dlrs 500 million to complete the design at home and procure much-needed equipment overseas,'' the magazine said. Saudi authorities to reveal true story of bombing, says paper
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ The Saudi government is expected to announce next month the results of its investigation into the 1996 bombing that killed 19 U.S. servicemen, a Saudi-owned newspaper reported Tuesday. The London-based Al-Hayat said the government has concluded the bombing was carried out by a Saudi Islamic group with help from Iranian-backed factions in Kuwait and Bahrain. The report comes amid conflicting statements by Saudi officials. The Saudis have completed the investigation and ``what remains is only the announcement ... which could be made soon,'' Al-Hayat said. It added the results could be made public after the World Cup soccer tournament which ends in July. Saudi Arabia is participating in the games in France. Last month, Saudi Interior Minister Prince Nayef bin Abdel Aziz was quoted as saying Saudi citizens were to blame for the explosion in al-Khobar near the city of Dhahran and foreigners were not involved. The statement to a Kuwaiti newspaper was the first to rule out foreign participation in the attack, which also injured scores of U.S. soldiers. But a few days later, Saudi newspapers reported that the minister was misquoted and had only said that while Saudi citizens were the perpetrators, they received help from foreign groups. Earlier, Saudi security sources suggested several Shiite Muslims with links to Shiite Muslim Iran played a role in the bombing. Al-Hayat said investigators believe the explosion was carried out by ``an Islamic group that lives in the kingdom.'' It said some of the attackers were arrested in Kuwait and were handed over to Saudi Arabia later. That raised the speculation about their links with radical Shiite groups of Hezbollah parties in both Kuwait and Bahrain, it said. The charge has been dismissed by Shiite dissidents in Saudi Arabia who contend that the Saudi government is using the explosion as a pretext to target the disadvantaged minority, which has been agitating for better job opportunities and living conditions. The newspaper did not explain the discrepancy in the Saudi statements, but Saudi dissidents said the press leaks on the explosion reflect a power struggle inside the Saudi royal family and differences over issues such as relations with Iran. Crown Prince Abdullah is a known to be behind growing ties with Tehran, while some of the royal family members are believed to favor a slowdown. Top U.S. officials have publicly rebuked the Saudis for frustrating their efforts to find out who was responsible for the bombing. In Saudi Arabia, secrecy has shrouded the investigation, and Saudi officials have been reluctant to comment.

SATISFACTION with the present state of affairs in Hong Kong has fallen to a 15-year low, according to a government bi-monthly public opinion survey conducted last month. Only 44 per cent of respondents said they were satisfied with the present situation, significantly less than the 61 per cent in the previous survey. Meanwhile, only 52 per cent of respondents expected the situation to improve or remain the same in the coming 12 months. This also drastically falls short of the 67 per cent recorded in March. The spokesman for the Home Affairs Bureau, which interviewed 1,553 people by telephone on 11-15 May, said the number of people who expressed satisfaction with the situation was the lowest since the launch of the survey in January 1983. The spokesman said the issue playing on people's minds were foreign incidents, like the recent Indonesian crisis, and their impact on Hong Kong, and fears for the plunging local economy. He said that during the period of the survey, the Hang Seng Index at one point (on 13 May) dropped 3.78 per cent to close at 9,469.29 as political instability in Indonesia escalated, dragging down share prices and currencies in the region. He added that continuing layoffs by local firms might further increase people's concern over the Indonesian crisis. The survey also found that only 32 per cent of respondents expressed satisfaction with the overall performance of the SAR Government, compared with 48 per cent in the last survey, in March. Meanwhile, labour and employment were seen as the most important issues of the day, surpassing housing and the economy in March. About 54 per cent of people listed labour issues as their biggest concern, compared with 41 per cent in March. Among those concerned with labour-related problems, 96 per cent cited difficulties in finding jobs, and unemployment. In March the figure was 93 per cent. Housing, which used to be the number-one concern, dropped to third place, playing on the minds of only 30 per cent of people, a sharp drop from 46 per cent. Economic-related problems were mentioned by 48 per cent of the respondents, up from 44 per cent, making them the second-most mentioned maladies. Of those, 49 per cent singled out the economic depression and a weak economy as the source of their worries, up from 44 per cent. Among those who cited housing, 43 per cent considered the price of private housing to be too high, down from 47 per cent in March.

ECONOMISTS are tipping more hardship over the course of the year, as the economy continues to shrink. Associate Professor of business at Hong Kong University, Leung Wai-kin, said income would fall as more people joined the ranks of the jobless. He predicted the unemployment rate would reach 4.5 per cent. ``Negative growth is almost certain for both the second and third quarters of this year. We may start to see a turn-around in the fourth quarter,'' he said. Mr Leung said job insecurity would continue to undermine confidence in Hong Kong and people would consume less. This he said would further decrease gross domestic product (GDP), the total value of goods and services produced in the economy. The downturn would be particularly felt by small and medium-sized businesses, he said, which would be forced to lay off more staff. ``If you look around on the streets, many shops are closing, in particular those selling luxury goods.'' Returns from stock market and property investments would also fall, he said, adding to the overall drop in total income. However, Mr Leung said it was unlikely the government would increase the Comprehensive Social Security Assistance scheme to bring it in line with the rise in unemployed. The rate of increase in people applying for benefits has slowed despite the 14-year record unemployment rate. Mr Leung said people were more likely to rely on their savings and families, rather than apply for the dole. Professor Richard Ho Yan-ki, dean of business at City University, said many people would maintain a reasonable income because of investments overseas. He said the government could boost confidence by increasing tax rebates to stimulate demand.

Eds: UPDATES with ethnic Albanian official urging militants not to By ISMET HAJDARI Associated Press Writer
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Large sections of the southern province of Kosovo remained sealed off by Serb forces Tuesday after thousands of ethnic Albanians fled Serb mortar attacks on their villages. Also Tuesday, six political parties in Kosovo accused Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic of using Serb-Albanian talks as a distraction while he committed crimes against civilians in Kosovo. Ethnic Albanians outnumber Serbs 9-to-1 in the province but are a minority in what remains of Yugoslavia. ``Another Bosnia is happening in Kosovo,'' the parties warned, demanding NATO deployment in Kosovo. Serbs say their forces in western Kosovo are fighting guerrillas who want to make Kosovo independent from Serbia, the dominant republic in Yugoslavia. But ethnic Albanians and international aid officials spoke Tuesday of shelling that forced entire villages to hike through mountainous terrain to neighboring Albania. Dozens of people have been reported killed in the last few days as Serb forces intensified their campaign to wipe out the militants. The situation harked back to the ``ethnic cleansing'' _ the slaughter or forced departure of minority groups _ that ravaged Bosnia. With 39 people reported killed over the weekend and fighting apparently continuing, the latest bloodshed is the worst since a Serb crackdown in early March left more than 80 people dead. All communications with western Kosovo remained cut off Tuesday, so no update on Albanian casualties was available. However, Serbs on Tuesday reported four policemen were wounded Monday. About 2,000 people from Kosovo crossed into northern Albania on Sunday and Monday. Thousands more have been displaced in the province itself, according to Kris Janowski of the U.N. High Commission for Refugees. Virtually the entire Albanian population of the Kosovo border villages of Junik and Decane fled under attack, Janowski said. The U.N. refugee agency doesn't know where they are but thinks they must be in surrounding hills. Refugees interviewed in Albania said they fled shelling by Serb forces, with 1,500 troops massed in Junik alone. The refugees said one 3-year-old died on the way. In Pristina, the ethnic Albanian human rights council demanded Tuesday that a humanitarian corridor be opened for western Kosovo, saying that residents there face hunger. Pajazit Nushi, head of the council and a member of the ethnic Albanian negotiating team, said talks with the government scheduled for Friday could be canceled. ``I think talks cannot continue if the Serbian side does not withdraw military and police forces from Kosovo and doesn't stop the state terror against the Albanians,'' he said. Most ethnic Albanians want independence from Serbia, which rules the province with a heavy hand, but they are divided about whether to use force to do it. Adem Demaqi, an ethnic Albanian leader who spent years in Serb prisons, appealed Tuesday to the militant Kosovo Liberation Army to refrain from targeting innocent Serb civilians in retaliation for police brutality. The statement by Demaci's Parliamentary Party of Kosovo was the first public message to the militants by any Albanian political party.

Weather experts of Bangladesh would be able to make accurate forecasts of cyclones more confidently in the near future as they would have access to vertical imageries from the Indian meteorological satellite (Insat). Access to the Insat is expected to improve weather forecasts because the satellite is located almost directly above Bangladesh. So long, Bangladesh used to receive satellite imageries from the Geostationary Meteorological Satellite (GMS) of Japan which is positioned above the Pacific at 140 degrees longitude East. To make GMS imageries look like taken from above Bangladesh, a computer model had so long been in use. Imageries from the US polar orbiting satellite NOAA (National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) had also been available to Bangladeshi meteorologists. Insat is located at 80 degrees longitude East on the equator. The land area comprising Bangladesh lies between 88 and 93 degrees longitude East and between 20 degrees and 27 degrees latitude North. The arrangements for the installation of an antenna with a ground receiving station to get pictures from Insat have been finalised by Sazedur Rahman, Director, Bangladesh Meteorological Department during his recent visit to India. It would cost Bangladesh approximately Taka seven million (five million Indian Rupees) to install the receiving ground station. Necessary funds for this are expected to be earmarked in the budget for 1998-99. Sazedur Rahman said the Indian Meteorological Department had supplied all the technical details of utilising the services of the Insat that has been in the orbit for the last ten years. Bangladesh would receive imageries from the satellite once every three hours for which payment will have to be made. Access to the Insat would be most useful to track the movement of lows, depressions and cyclones over the Bay of Bengal, Sazedur Rahman said.

BC-South Africa-Botha Trial
Apartheid death squad leader likely to appear as witness in Botha trial
AP Photo GEO102 By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ One of the apartheid state's most feared assassins appeared headed Tuesday for a courtroom showdown with its last hardline president, P.W. Botha. Botha is on trial for refusing to appear before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, which is investigating apartheid-era human rights abuses. But the trial has become a probe into whether Botha's government sanctioned the murders of black activists. To establish why it wants to question Botha, the Truth Commission has produced documents suggesting that the State Security Council, which the former president headed, authorized the killings of black liberation fighters. Now, the prosecution wants Eugene de Kock, a former police colonel and death squad boss, to give evidence against Botha. Botha's lawyers oppose the move. De Kock, whose ruthlessness earned him the nickname Prime Evil, is serving two life sentences plus 212 years on six charges of murder and 83 other convictions. By appearing at Botha's trial, he would have a chance to pin some of the killings he committed on the former government. In his autobiography, published this year, de Kock called himself a ``sacrificial lamb'' for the apartheid-era state's human rights abuses and complained that ``the guiltiest of all ... the generals and the politicians, have got off scot-free.'' Aiding the case against Botha _ being heard in George, a southern coastal city near his retirement home _ could earn de Kock points in his own amnesty application with the Truth Commission. Evidence that Botha sanctioned attacks against black activists mounted Tuesday, when retired police commissioner General Johan van der Merwe testified at a Truth Commission hearing in Pretoria. Van der Merwe linked Botha to the 1988 bombing of the Johannesburg offices of the South African Council of Churches, which opposed apartheid. Repeating testimony made earlier, van der Merwe said former Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok told him that Botha wanted Khotso House, the building that housed the church offices, destroyed. De Kock has admitted planting the bombs. Van der Merwe also testified that Botha's government ordered security police to commit illegal acts to fight the African National Congress, which was waging a guerrilla campaign to end apartheid. Botha's successor, President F.W. de Klerk, negotiated with the ANC, culminating in the nation's first all-race elections in 1994, which marked the end of apartheid. Van der Merwe's testimony came during a hearing into the 1988 death of activist Stanza Bopape, who died under police torture. Van der Merwe, who headed the security police at the time, is seeking amnesty for covering up the death. Botha has insisted he has nothing to apologize for and has described the Truth Commission's work as a witch hunt against whites. (ph-aos)

THE Immigration Department is considering waiving visa requirements for Russian tourists who visit Hong Kong via the mainland. The proposal was originally made by the Hong Kong Tourist Association (HKTA) to attract tourists from Russia. Tapping the market of the former communist country is part of the package of measures intended to boost tourism which has been down by 24 per cent during the first four months of the year. A source said the department was quite willing to grant visa-free access to Russian travellers but approval of the policy might take some time. ``The situation in Russia has changed since the fall of the communist government and people now have more money to spend on luxury goods,'' the source said. ``And besides, Hong Kong is a free port and most countries have visa-free access.''. However, the department would have to devote a few months deliberating the issue before the policy was implemented, the source added. HKTA spokesman Peter Randall said at present, Russians were still required to get visas if they came directly to Hong Kong. ``But if they are already in the mainland, they should be able to come to Hong Kong without a visa _ after all Hong Kong is now part of the mainland,'' he said. HKTA research shows that about 800,000 Russians visited the mainland last year. ``This is a huge market which we can target,'' Mr Randall said. ``But we do not know how many of them will actually come to Hong Kong,'' he said. Last week, a group of more than 10 travel trade representatives from Beijing who organise tours for Russians visited Hong Kong for a five-day familiarisation program. Chief Secretary for Administration Anson Chan Fang On-sang is leaving for Tokyo today to lead a tourist promotion to Japan. Mrs Chan will be meeting 20 chief executives of Japanese travel agents to emphasise the importance of the Japanese market to Hong Kong. Mr Randall was optimistic the promotion will encourage Japanese tourists to return to Hong Kong. ``We will be telling them that Hong Kong is still a beautiful place to see and there are many new places which they can visit.'' The HKTA has launched ``Hong Kong Month'' for June with a series of events aimed at showcasing Hong Kong attractions. World-famous swimmer Brojen Das died of cancer yesterday at a clinic in Calcutta, India. He was 71, reports APB. Brojen was the first Asian to cross the English Channel in 1958. He crossed the chilly channel six times on different occasions. In 1986, the United Kingdom conferred upon the Bangladeshi swimmer ``King of Channel'', a special trophy. He left behind his wife, a daughter and a son. His body will be brought in Dhaka a couple of days after some religious rites in India, Bangladesh Swimming Federation sources told the news agency. Brojen Das, son of late Harendra Kumar Das, was born in Kuchimara of Sirajdikhan thana of Munsiganj district on December 9, 1927. From his teenage, he had attracted the attention of organisers and at his 25 in 1952 won the 100-metre freestyle in West Bengal. But his swimming career flourished in the following years when he won different events in the highest national events in the highest national level of competition. He took part in different national and international events during 1943-'61. Having a hobby in sports, Brojen, who dreamt to be the first Bengali swimmer to cross the English Channel, attained the feat in 1958. He also crossed the English Channel five more times, including in 1961 in a record time that earned him a place in the Guinness Book of Records. He obtained a number of laurels, including National Award in 1976, and Atish Dipanker, Kazi Mahbubullah and Jahanara Janakalyan Gold Medals. He earned Dhaka University Blue in 1956 and was lifelong member of the Channel Swimming Association of UK, and other international organisations. Brojen Das served Bangladesh Swimming Federation as General Secretary for three years beginning 1972. He was also member of various international bodies-vice-president of World Long Distance Swimming Association (Atlanta, USA), life member of Royal Life Saving Society (UK) and life member of Central Swimming Club (India). Condolence President Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed expressed deep shock and sorrow at the death of Brojen Das. In a message of condolence the President recalled the eventful life of Brojen Das. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has also expressed deep shock at the death of Brojen Das. She observed that the demise of Brojen Das is an irreparable loss in the sports arena in the country. Foreign Minister, Abdus Samad Azad and State Minister for Youth and Sports and Cultural Affairs, Obaidul Quader and different sports organisers condoled the death of Brojen Das. The others who condoled the death of the Swimmer are Deputy Minister for Shipping and president of Bangladesh Cricket Board Saber Hossain Chowdhury, president of Bangladesh Olympic Association Lt. General Mohammad Mahbubur Rahman, former president of Bangladesh Swimming Federation M Asaf-ud-Dowlah, General Secretary of Bangladesh Football Federation Harunur Rashid, MP. Sports Journalists' Association, Bangladesh Swimming Coaches' Association, Bangladesh Handball Federation, Bangladesh Volleyball Federation, former State Minister for Youth and Sports, Sadeq Hossain Khoka.

BC-Pakistan-Economy,0391
Analysts predict Pakistan may declare moratorium on debt repayment
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) _ Pakistan may have to declare a moratorium on repaying its debts as international sanctions bite into its reserves, say financial analysts. The government also may devalue the Pakistani currency by 3-to-5 percent to discourage imports that are further draining the economy, said a report by the Dutch ABN Amro Bank NV obtained Tuesday. The grim outlook from one of Pakistan's top independent analytical groups was a result of a drop in Pakistan's international credit rating following sanctions imposed after it exploded a series of nuclear tests last month. A government reaction to the report, dated June 1, was not immediately available. Pakistan declared a state of emergency May 28, blocking foreign currency withdrawals for fear of a run on bank deposits of dlrs 13 billion. It also froze the exchange rate at 46 rupees to the dollar. Until last week, Pakistan had one of the most liberal exchange policies in South Asia, having made its currency fully convertible. Government reserves were a paltry dlrs 1.3 dollars a week ago, just enough to cover three weeks worth of imports. Its foreign debt is dlrs 30 billion, of which it repays an estimated dlrs 4.7 billion per year. Standard and Poor, the international rating agency, downgraded Pakistan's long-term and short-term foreign currency issuer credit rating. That will make it tough for the treasury to borrow financing for its six-month oil import bill of dlrs 926 million, the report said. ``The possibility that Pakistan may have no option but to stop servicing some of its external debts becomes increasingly real,'' said the report. A debt moratorium, it said, would do ``irrevocable damage'' to Pakistan's standing in the capital markets and its ability to compete globally. After the U.S.-led sanctions were imposed, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif announced an austerity program, beginning with his own move from the newly opened 400-room government Secretariat, in a bid to cut non-development expenses. But the Amro report said the program was unlikely to help, since nearly half _ or 47.7 percent _ of Pakistan's non-development spending was earmarked to repay debts.

TWO Hong Kong long-distance calling card holders were landed with phone bills totalling thousands of dollars while they were in the United States in March and April. Leaked information on account numbers and Personal Identification Numbers (PINs) is believed to be behind the unauthorised calls. This has resulted in an alert issued by the Office of the Telecommunications Authority (Ofta) to card users to tighten security. Long distance calling card holders should be careful when using public pay phones, Ofta said. They should also make sure nobody is looking over their shoulder when they make the calls. Ofta gave the advice yesterday after two Hong Kong people complained each was charged thousands of dollars before they discovered more than 45 unauthorised calls had been made in different states in the US to different countries in one day in March and April. This happened despite the fact that neither had lost their cards and that they had used them in different US airports. They have complained to both the US and Hong Kong authorities. The two cases indicated that the access information of the calling card accounts has been intercepted, Ofta spokesman Danny Ng Kwan-cheong said. He said Ofta was unsure of how the information had been leaked. Although the office has received only two complaints, it has issued tips on tightening the security of calling cards, including changing the PIN on notification of new calling cards; changing the PIN from time to time; not revealing the PIN to anyone under any circumstances; and, in the case of company cards, assigning one card to one person only to ensure proper accounting by the user. Mr Ng also said that when making a call from any telephone, especially on a digital display phone and a public pay phone, ``always prevent others from seeing the calling card number and PIN and after terminating the call, clear the memory for redial from the same telephone by lifting the handset again and dialling a number at random''. If callers make an operator-assisted call using the calling card, they should make sure nobody overhears them when they give over their card and PIN numbers. Should callers discover unauthorised calls have been made from their calling card accounts during overseas trips, they should report to the calling card operator and local police immediately and report to the Hong Kong Police upon return.

TOP corporate decision makers are shying away from foreign direct investments (FDI) in the region, particularly in countries that have borne the brunt of the economic turmoil, and are now favouring China, Brazil and Poland. The survey by management consultants A T Kearney, highlights South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia among countries in which senior managers have the least confidence in their suitability for FDI. Hong Kong's allure has been eroded slightly, with 80 per cent of all respondents citing no change in their outlook for investment in Hong Kong compared with a year ago. ``South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia have suffered the worse reversals of fortune of all of the countries surveyed,'' said Paul Laudicina, an A T Kearney vice-president. ``Nevertheless, serious corporate investors, while shaken, appear ready to ride out the turmoil on the strength of Asia's long-term fundamentals.'' The survey among 150 executives from the world's largest companies, said market size, political stability and regulatory environment were the three most important factors senior executives consider before making direct investments. Mr Laudicina said that the survey was conducted prior to the civil and political unrest in Indonesia. However, senior managers still had a negative outlook for FDI in the region. ``Events that were taking place in the region were sufficiently worrysome to investors that 35 per cent of the executives interviewed said they had an overall downward shift of perception of the Indonesian market, followed by Thailand, Malaysia and South Korea,'' he said. China's enormous market and political stability continue to attract foreign investors. It ranks third in the overall index with 66 per cent of respondents expressing a medium to high likelihood of investing there in the next one to three years. However, Mr Laudicina said China would experience a 9 per cent decline in FDI this year over 1997. ``But we're still talking about US$40 billion (HK$312 billion) in FDI in 1997 over US$44 billion which was a record year in 1996.'' More than 30 per cent of all surveyed expressed a greater likelihood of investing in Brazil and Poland compared with a year ago.

Security Guard Emdadul Haque, arrested in connection with the murder of housewife Rubina Akter Ruby (25) on Friday, is reported to have admitted his involvement in the killing before the Metropolitan Magistrate on Monday. He was sent to jail after the confession. Earlier, another guard, Arif, and housemaid Sharifa were sent to jail after they gave their confessional statements to the Metropolitan Magistrate on Sunday. In his statement, Emdad confessed that Samad induced him by offering Tk 10,000 in cash to assist him in killing Rubina. He was on guard during the time of the incident when Arif and Samad entered the apartment of Rubina. Samad used the balcony and opened the main door through which Arif entered the apartment. They killed the housewife. Ruby (25) was murdered at her residence at Shantinagar in the city on Friday last. Maid Sharifa was arrested from her home at Shabazpur village in Sharail thana in Brahmanbaria district on Saturday while guards Arif and Emdad were arrested from Shantinagar on the day of the incident. Sharifa told the Magistrate that she abetted the main accused Samad in killing Ruby. She said that she had an affair with Samad since long and they had physical relation as well. Sharifa stated that she was sacked and driven out of the house by Rubina one and a half months ago when Samad proposed to her. This incident infuriated them and they decided to kill Rubina, Sharifa said. She added that she came to Dhaka to meet Samad two days before the murder and returned home the same day. A young garment employee was shot dead by unidentified assailants in the city's Tejkunipara area while an alleged mugger, who was severely beaten up by a mob, died at the Dhaka Medical College Hospital (DMCH) on Monday. They pressed him against the wall of the Saint Margareta Tutorial School at 73/3, Tejkunipara, about 50 yards from his residence, and shot him from a close range. He was the second son of late Syed Habibur Rahman of 73, Tejkunipara. Meanwhile, the alleged mugger Masum (20), who was under treatment at the DMCH, succumbed to his injuries at about 12:10 pm on Monday. Masum was caught by the people of Dania area while in the act of mugging a garment girl in front of the house of one Haji Kamar Ali at Dania Kabarkhana Road on Sunday night. The angry people beat him up leaving him unconscious on the spot. The police admitted the victim to the Dhaka Medical College Hospital. SEMI-TECH (Global) yesterday said the Stock Exchange of Hong Kong (SEHK) was to blame for the sudden halt in the company's bonus warrant issue. Semi-Tech proposed a bonus warrant issue of one new share for every 10 existing shares held, and a bonus issue of two 2001 warrants for every one existing 1998 warrant held. The company was verbally told the proposal of a bonus warrant issue was fine before the announcement dated 27 May, a source close to the company said. ``That's why the company went ahead with the announcement which was published in the press the day after,'' said the source. However, the exchange said it did not approve the proposal for the bonus warrant issue since it violated certain sections of the rules governing the listing of securities on the stock exchange. However, the spokesman did add that according to Chapter 15 of the listing rules, such warrants must expire not less than one _ and not more than five _ years from the date of issue or grant and must not be convertible into further rights to subscribe securities which expire less than one year or more than five years after the date of issue. ``The company feels very puzzled about the decision made by the exchange since it had said the proposal was fine on the one hand but did not approve it after the related announcement was published,'' said the source, adding that the issue will hurt Semi-Tech's image. The company has no immediate plans to put forward a substitute for the bonus warrant issue proposal, said the source.

Chairman Stanley Ho said the Asian financial turmoil and the depressed state of the Hong Kong economy had a direct impact on the restaurants' business. While the reduction in tourist groups visiting the floating restaurants represents a short to medium term change in the restaurants' customer mix, contribution from the two segments are now more or less the same. While the group has no intention of introducing price cuts to boost sales, profit margin is expected to be maintained at last year's level. Due to the business downturn, difficulties are expected to remain for some time this year according to Melco International director, Patrick Huen. JAKARTA (JP): Thousands of customers of Bank Central Asia (BCA) flocked to branches and automated teller machines (ATMs) throughout the city yesterday and queued for hours to withdraw their money. The run on BCA trailed several days of heavy withdrawals from the country's largest private bank, which is owned by the widely diversified Salim Group and children of former president Soeharto. Yesterday's run was also prompted by the government's announcement Thursday that the bank had been placed under the control of the Indonesian Bank Restructuring Agency (IBRA). The Jakarta Post observed BCA branches in Jatinegara, East Jakarta; Matraman, Slipi and Sudirman, Central Jakarta and Melawai in South Jakarta, which were all swamped by customers from 8 a.m. A woman who fainted at BCA Sudirman was assisted by security officers and allowed to rest in one of the offices. Some customers admitted queuing before 6 a.m. for a head start on the crowds. ``I came here (to BCA Matraman) about 5:40 a.m. It was still quiet. But a few minutes later people started coming and the security officers told us to stand in line,'' Rachmiaty. S., an employee of a private firm who skipped work yesterday, said. She said she would try to withdraw all her money and deposit it in one of the state banks. ``I work hard for my money. It's about Rp 4 million in total. Maybe it sounds small to other people but it's worth a lot for me.'' Randita Pramudya, a customer at BCA Slipi, said he was disappointed with the service. ``They closed the doors about 10 a.m.. We were forced to wait outside.'' Queues of people in front of BCA ATMs have become a daily scene here over the last few days after massive student protests, which resulted in former president Soeharto's resignation. There were people who came to terminate their accounts and there were also others who only wanted to withdraw money for basic expenses. ``I haven't paid my mobile phone bill, my credit cards ... and I don't have any money left,'' Gunawan, a resident of Tegalan, Matraman, said. ``If people keep on coming like this, I'm afraid BCA could collapse. I personally believe that the government would not abandon BCA customers. As you know, BCA is the largest bank here. ``But the lining up and the run has started to get on my nerves,'' the father of four said. Yustika Indriyani, a small vendor in Jatinegara, had a similar experience. ``I put money in the bank because I thought that it would be safe. But who would have thought about this ... Well I'd better just keep the money under the bed like I used to,'' she said, using a newspaper to shade her head. She said BCA customers were no longer high-class members of society. ``I saw all of my friends here ... they are all common people. There's Pak Trisuji, an ojek (motorcycle taxi) driver near my place,'' she said, waving. BCA claimed 122 of its offices were damaged during the massive rioting two weeks ago, including 17 of which where set on fire. Dozens of its ATM facilities were also attacked by angry mobs during the riots on May 14, dubbed Gray Thursday. In a move to bolster confidence in the bank, BCA president Abdullah Ali called a snap media conference Sunday to inform the public that BCA's shareholders were still committed to the bank, as was Bank Indonesia, the central bank. BCA is owned by the Salim Group, which retains a 70 percent majority stake and Soeharto's son Sigit Hardjojudanto and daughter Siti Hardijanti Rukmana, who hold the remaining 30 percent. ``The bank will operate normally since Bank Indonesia has guaranteed all deposits, including those at BCA,'' he said. But his words did little to calm people's fears. People are already too traumatized by the chaos and simply fear they will lose their money. ``We need to keep cash. This country is falling apart. What is left for little people like us?'' Yustika asked.

JAKARTA (JP): The National Police will review its cooperation agreement with a company belonging to Siti ``Tutut'' Hardijanti Rukmana whose dealings it claims are riddled with corruption and nepotism. The police signed the five-year accord in 1992 with PT Citra Permata Persada (PT CPP), which is owned by the eldest daughter of former president Soeharto, to administer applications for driver's licenses. National Police Commander Gen. Dibyo Widodo said Thursday the review was prompted by reports that the administrative fee for a license was excessively high and the company had raked in huge profits. A reliable police source said the company's official administrative fee was set at Rp 52,500 (US$5.20) for each driver's license but only Rp 4,500 went to the state coffers. ``But, as you know, in practice the fee is much higher.'' According to the source, there has never been a transparent breakdown of the fee and the accord is still effective although it expired a year ago. ``We will thoroughly review the cooperation as part of the burning spirit to wipe out nepotism, collusion and corruption within the police force,'' Dibyo said. The National Police signed the contract with PT CPP as part of its efforts to improve public services. Under the agreement, the company was to help the police provide better equipment and service in processing driver's licenses. But the promised facilities have never been supplied, the source said. ``All of the equipment was acquired by the police. They never spent a penny. This is crazy. Therefore we call for an open review and investigation into the matter.'' The source noted that Jakarta Police Headquarters issues between 2,500 and 3,000 driver's licenses every day. ``The police only get between Rp 11 million and Rp 14 million. The rest of the money goes into PT CPP's accounts in Bank International Indonesia (BII), which was appointed as the fee receiver,'' he said. BII is a subsidiary of the widely diversified Sinar Mas Group, owned by tycoon Eka Tjipta Widjaja. ``We suspect there is collusion between PT CPP and Sinar Mas Group because a relative of Eka Tjipta, Jimmy, is the managing director of PT CPP,'' the source said. When contacted by reporters, Sinar Mas Group spokeswoman Joyce A., said Wednesday that she was unaware of the situation. ``All I know is that BII has been assigned to keep the money from driver's license fees. But I have no idea where the money goes to. ``I only know that Pak Jimmy is a friend of Mbak Tutut. But I really don't know more than that.''

JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ A passenger train hit a minibus stuck on railroad tracks near the central Javanese town of Demak on Tuesday, killing at least 17 people, police said. The minibus became stuck on tracks on an unguarded crossing as the train approached, said a police officer in Demak. All of the victims were killed instantly. The bus was dragged some tens of meters (yards) away, said the officer, who identified himself only as Edy. The official Antara news agency, put the death toll at 18. The report said the bus was one of four vehicles carrying a group of villagers returning from a condolence visit to other village. Demak is about 400 kilometers (250 miles) east of the capital, Jakarta.
