BC-Greece-Immunity's Limits
Deputies question extent of immunity after lawmaker crash
ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ A high-speed car wreck leads to the death of a young woman. The police say the driver refuses a request for a legally mandated alcohol test. But instead of handcuffs clicking shut, the driver ties the hands of justice by claiming parliamentary immunity. Conservative deputy Constantinos Karaminas' alleged refusal to take a breathalyzer test after a fatal car crash early Monday has sparked a wider debate on the need to reform a law shielding legislators from prosecution. ``Politicians are equal to citizens before the law,'' left-wing deputy Stella Alfieri told the daily Ethnos on Tuesday. ``This theory of immunity has to stop sometime. Otherwise this is not a democracy.'' In Greece, like many countries, parliament members have protection from any type of prosecution in order to shield them against politically motivated charges. But following a rash of incidents, critics now say immunity is being abused. Karaminas, 50, suffered bruises after crashing into three parked cars after leaving a nightclub. Passenger Elli Pilidou, a 26-year-old teacher, was killed. Police said Karaminas, a member of the New Democracy opposition party, claimed immunity when he refused to the breath test. The deputy later told reporters he did not understand what the police officer was asking. Under Greek law, breath or blood tests to trace alcohol levels are obligatory for any driver involved in an accident resulting in injury or death. ``I will ask for my parliamentary immunity to be lifted,'' Karaminas told Athens' daily Ta Nea. ``I respect parliament and its institutions.'' But parliament very rarely lifts immunity. Ioannis Varvitsiotis, a New Democracy deputy who wants the law changed, predicted the 300-member parliament will close ranks around Karaminas and refuse to allow his prosecution. ``Immunity exists in all constitutions of the world, but other parliaments which respect themselves don't allow their deputies to hide behind it without reason,'' he said. Since the 1974 fall of the military dictatorship, parliament has dealt with more than 630 immunity cases. Only in three cases were deputies stripped of their immunity: on charges of bribery, fraud and aiding a drug dealer. ``There is one thing Karaminas could do,'' said deputy and former New Democracy leader Miltiades Evert. ``Resign immediately.'' eb-pq-bm

AMOCO Orient Petroleum Company, a unit of New York-listed Amoco Corp, seeks buyers for its 24.5 per cent working interest in the Liuhua oilfield, the largest modern oilfield discovered in the South China Sea. The oilfield is owned by a joint venture set up to own and manage the oilfield. The tie-up also includes the Chinese National Offshore Oil Co (CNOOC), which holds a 51 per cent stake, and a US oil company, Kerrmcgee, with a 24.5 per cent stake. The total investment cost for the Liuhua field is US$654 million (HK$5.1 billion). Liuhua is Amoco's only upstream oil and gas production asset in China. The move to sell the shares is due in part to an ongoing review of Amoco's worldwide exploration and production portfolio, said Don Barker, spokesman for the company. Amoco's operations on the mainland are focused principally on petrochemicals, including construction of a US$300 million petrochemical facility in Zhuhai. The Liuhua field, brought on stream in 1996, was the largest oilfield so far discovered in the South China Sea. It was developed using award-winning highly innovative technology. This includes the use of floating production and storage vessels and the use of advanced electrical submersible pump systems.

Walesa would consider presidential run in 2000 to oust Kwasniewski
WARSAW, Poland (AP) _ Solidarity founder and former president Lech Walesa said Tuesday he would considering running for president in 2000 if no one else appears capable of beating President Aleksander Kwasniewski. Kwasniewski, an ex-communist, defeated Walesa's 1995 bid for re-election. Walesa told The Associated Press in a phone interview that he was not announcing his candidacy. But he said he would run if he felt people were dissatisfied with the pace of reform and ``unanimously'' signaled that they wanted him to speed it up. Kwasniewski has had trouble sharing power with the new Solidarity-dominated parliament elected last September. Though the ex-communists and Solidarity politicians often both agree on reforms, ideological differences and years of history as foes has hampered cooperation between the political camps. Walesa has not run for office since failing to win a second term, although he helped campaign for the bloc of Solidarity parties in last year's parliamentary elections. Walesa founded the Solidarity pro-democracy movement that helped force the communist regime from power, and then led the successor political movement established under the democratic system until he was elected president in 1990. He founded a new political party, the Christian Democracy of Poland, after the last parliamentary elections. The party so far has not been a visible presence. (ms-im-cb)

BC-EU-US-Wheat Gluten
EU criticizes US quota on wheat gluten imports from Europe
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The European Commission on Tuesday denounced the U.S. decision to limit imports of EU wheat gluten over a three-year period and warned of retaliation. The quota, ``represents a major restriction on European exports,'' the EU executive Commission said in a statement. ``This action is all the more surprising coming from a government that only two weeks ago was calling on WTO members to further liberalize trade in agricultural products.'' The EU head office was considering ``appropriate responses'' but gave no immediate details. EU spokesman Gerard Kiely said the quota suggested Washington will defend free farm trade if that serves American farmers only. The EU has nabbed 30 percent of the American wheat gluten market. Kiely said that was because wheat prices in Europe are lower than corn prices, whereas the reverse is true in the United States. EU officials said high imports of EU wheat gluten into the United States had been predicted for years and said they were ``astonished this evidence was ignored'' for so long. They termed the U.S. quota unfair, especially since other exporters, such as Canada, have been exempted from it. On Monday, President Clinton signed off on a three-year quota on imported wheat gluten. He followed a recommended to that effect, issued in March, by the U.S. International Trade Commission. The quota will be 126 million pounds in the first year, rising by 6 percent annually. Each year the U.S. industry consumes 22 million bushels of wheat, worth about dlrs 100 million. Two billion tons of wheat flour yield 300 million pounds of gluten annually. Wheat gluten is the natural protein portion of the grain. It adds protein to breakfast cereals, pet food, livestock feed and helps whole-grain breads rise. The wheat gluten debate is yet another transatlantic trade dispute. Only last week, the two sides wrangled over a 30,000-ton shipment of subsidized Finnish barley that landed on U.S. soil. The United States announced it would start subsidizing barley exports. This year, the United States introduced poultry export subsidies after the EU imposed restrictions on US poultry imports. (as-dj-rw)

FUND manager Templeton has increased its weightings on Hong Kong stocks in recent weeks despite a sharp drop in the Hang Seng Index, emerging markets guru Mark Mobius said. The managing director of Templeton Asset Management Limited said he likes the local stocks. ``We are beginning to see value here after a downturn, we have increased our weightings in Hong Kong stocks,'' said Mr Mobius, who manages more than US$12 billion (HK$93.6 billion) in assets in emerging markets. Mr Mobius said that property and banking blue chips on the Hong Kong stockmarket could be picked up at bargain prices. ``We are obviously looking at banks and property stocks and in some cases smaller stocks of small manufacturers,'' he said. Templeton's Asian Growth Fund, which has a fund size of US$46.61 million, has 15 per cent of its portfolio in the Hong Kong stock market. Templeton has invested 3.6 per cent in HSBC Holdings, while it has 2.6 per cent in Hang Lung Development and 2.5 per cent in Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Holdings. Over the last three months the Asian Growth Fund has risen 7.99 per cent, but over the last year the fund has gone down almost 45.89 per cent. ``We have a long-term view on the Hong Kong market and now even more so compared to other markets,'' Mr Mobius said. He added that the Hong Kong market would remain sluggish for some time yet. ``Usually when you have bulls and bears fighting, as you have seen here, people are not panicked to the extent that they want to dump their shares and then there are people coming in the market who want to pay lower prices because the market is down, so this kind of a stand-off can last for a while, which can make markets move in either direction,'' Mr Mobius said. The Hong Kong market could slide further, he said and added, ``I see the index at 8,500 by the end of the year''. Mr Mobius said among all the regional markets, Thailand offered the best value. ``Thailand of course is the most interesting, they are pulling out (of recession) faster than other markets,'' he said.

Protesting Roma sets himself ablaze in Bulgaria
SOFIA, Bulgaria (AP) _ A member of the Roma minority in northern Bulgaria set himself on fire Tuesday after two weeks on a hunger strike protesting poverty and unpaid social benefits. The 37-year-old man from the town of Lom, 200 kilometers (125 miles) north of the capital Sofia, suffered only slight injuries, as a fire brigade instantly put out the flames. The man is among 17 gypsies, or Roma, who have been on a hunger strike for two weeks in a tent camp in front of town hall, demanding that the municipality repay leva 400 million (dlrs 224,000) of outstanding social assistance to local Roma, state radio said. Public Administration Minister Mario Tagarinski arrived for talks with the protesters after they threatened that each hour one of them would set himself on fire to attract government attention. While talks went on, some 200 Roma crowded in front of the town hall chanting: ``We want bread.'' The protesters have complained that local companies refuse to employ Roma, who comprise a third of Lom's population of 36,000. Roma number about 300,000 in Bulgaria's population of 8.5 million. Unemployment is above 50 percent among the Roma, who also have the highest crime rate among social groups. (vz/dc)

German chancellor quashes speculation about presidency
BONN, Germany (AP) _ Chancellor Helmut Kohl said Tuesday he wants to keep speculation about who will be Germany's next president out of this year's election campaign. Incumbent Roman Herzog is retiring from the largely ceremonial post in May after a five-year term, and newspapers reported last weekend that the Christian Democrats would nominate prominent eastern German politician Kurt Biedenkopf to replace him. Kohl's party views the move as a way to woo eastern voters for the Sept. 27 federal election, the reports said. But Kohl denied the accounts about Biedenkopf, the popular governor of Lower Saxony state, as ``freely fabricated.'' ``The current debate about the office of the president is unacceptable,'' he said in a statement. Nominally above politics, the German president is often considered the nation's conscience. He is elected by a session of both houses of parliament. Kohl accused the opposition Social Democrats of triggering an ``unseemly spectacle'' by talking up a possible candidate of their own, Johannes Rau. Rau governed North-Rhine Westphalia, the nation's most populous state, for two decades until making way for a younger successor last month. Kohl asserted Rau stepped down only after the Social Democrats promised to nominate him for president. (tc-cb)

BANKS yesterday showed keen interest in the new Hong Kong dollar repurchase mechanism designed to increase liquidity in the banking system. Standard Chartered Bank regional treasurer Stanley Y F Wong said the bank was getting lots of inquiries about the new repurchase facility since it was announced as one of seven measures to boost the economy. From yesterday, the banks acting as market-markers for the repurchase facility agreed to offer quotations for one-month, two-month, three-month, and six-month debt papers for a minimum $20 million and a maximum $200 million. This means that corporate borrowers holding debt paper eligible for the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) _ the rediscount window managed by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority _ can offer the debt papers to the market-making banks as collateral for loans from $20 million to $200 million with one-month, two-month, three-month, and six-month maturities. Before the introduction of the new repurchase facility, only Exchange Fund bills were allowed to be used as collateral through the repurchase facility. With the LAF paper as collateral, borrowers can get the cash from the market-making banks including: HongkongBank, Standard Chartered Bank, Bank of China, Hang Seng Bank, Dao Heng Bank, and Bank of East Asia. When the loan matures, the borrower pays the creditor bank the cash it borrowed plus interest and gets back it's LAF debt paper.

Successive Governments have always praised the tourism industry because of the benefits that the country can derive through promotion and development of tourism and they promised enhanced allocation for the sector. But the Fifth Five Year Plan (1997-2002) which has been announced already indicates that allocation for tourism development has been curtailed.The fifth five year plan has an allocation of Taka 312 crore for tourism development. Out of this allocation Taka 12 crore will be provided by the government for implementation of plans in the public sector and the remaining Taka 300 crore have been allocated for the private sector. Compared to this, the public sector allocation for tourism in the 4th Plan was Taka 25 crore and the private sector allocation stood at Taka 200 crore. The public sector allocation during the 3rd Five Year Plan was Taka 12 crore. In other words, the public sector allocation, after 2 Plan periods, stands at the same scale, despite the fact that the value of Taka has gone down by 33 per cent during the period. It is to be noted here that the public sector allocation for tourism development in the country is used for plans implemented by the Bangladesh Parjatan Corporation. The private sector allocation is not a direct expenditure from the government fund. It is a kind of indirect support for encouraging the private sector through tax incentive, bank loans, land allotment, etc. During the 4th Plan, Taka 200 crore were earmarked for the private sector. But neither the Ministry of Civil Aviation Tourism nor the Parjatan Corporation has any idea as to how much of this allocation has been used by the private sector in the form of tax incentive, bank loan and land allotment. Due to heavy taxes, such as VAT, surcharge and service charge, a resident in any respectable hotel in Bangladesh has to pay nearly 32 per cent of his total bill as taxes and duties. This is highest tax collected by any country in the SAARC region. This acts as an disincentive to the growth of tourism in Bangladesh and its hotel industry. As during the 4th Plan no tax incentive to tourism industry was provided, nobody really knows what will happen to the private sector allocation of Taka 300 crore during the 5th Plan period. It is common knowledge now that the 5th Plan was finalised in a hot haste without proper consultation, survey and research. Even the Ministry of Finance did not have the opportunity to have a thorough look at the draft 5th Plan, according to reliable source. Some insiders say that the tourism allocation for the 5th Plan was done arbitrarily without consulting the executing agency. In the meantime, the Land Ministry, which allocates land for hotels and motels, has revised its policy in May this year. In this revised policy the Civil Aviation and Tourism Ministry is just a recommending body which is not the case in some of the neighbouring countries where the authority for final allocation of land for tourist establishment in declared tourist areas lies with the Tourist Board or with the Ministry of Tourism.However, in the above scenario, the 5th Plan aims at achieving the following goals for tourism development: Tourism sites will be developed in collaboration with other sectors such as transport and communication, hotels, motels and catering establishment, etc. Tourism facilities will be created in the Chittagong Hill Tracts, coastal areas, border districts, etc. More 4 and 5 Star hotels will be set up in Dhaka and Chittagong. Private sector/NGOs will be encouraged to develop and run tourism sites and other facilities; Low cost tourism facilities will be developed for the domestic tourists; Special facilities will be created for expatriates working in the Export Processing Zone; One or two coastal islands will be leased to private enterprises for development as tourists resorts; The Tourism Training Institute will be expanded.

NEW Aspiration Party has begun beating its war drum much sooner than expected -- even before the House passed three organic laws that will set the stage for a general election under a new system, as required by the new Constitution. NAP has named 12 chieftains for electoral regions, with the northeast, its electoral power base, designated a top priority for victory. The party, whose political wounds have yet to heal, is gunning for another triumph and a return to government. NAP leader Gen Chavalit Yongchaiyudh sounds more confident these days as cracks have begun to appear in the popularity of the Democrats, whose struggle to effect an economic rescue has received less-than-thunderous applause. It might be too soon, however, for NAP to expect an election victory over the Democrats, whose fate could depend on economic events that will unfold over the next three months. So far, the present trend is not very encouraging at all. There is a new political equation. Thaksin Shinawatra has decided to form his own political party. The telecom tycoon has a huge war chest to match his ambitions, but whether he is willing to invest in a place on the stage out of his own pocket remains to be seen. Yet, Thaksin represents greener pastures for many young NAP politicians, who believe that the ex-leader of Palang Dharma Party has stronger selling points than Chavalit, whose stature was badly shaken during his 11-month premiership -- so much so that his name has become synonymous with the current economic turmoil. Chavalit's political wounds are deep and hard to heal. His failures have been hashed over time and again during House debates, yet the former army chief believes the people who will decide his fate are the northeasterners, and their support for his party is as strong as ever. NAP is fragmenting due to factional rivalries. Its MPs, hoping to preserve their good names, might want to jump ship and Thaksin's party will provide a tempting alternative, no matter how much hype the big-time businessman kicks up. The Thaksin factor could also affect Chat Pattana and other parties finding it difficult to exist under the new electoral system. Chalerm Yoobamrung has dissolved his Muan Chon Party to become a big fish in NAP's big pond. NAP heavyweights and key lieutenants also believe that the next three months could change the mood of the voters if Prime Minister Chuan and his team fail to perform up to the public's expectations. That could mean a good opportunity for NAP to work out a new alliance and deal a blow to the Democrats. Yet, NAP does not seem to want a general election now. Major players in other parties have said on record that Chuan can choose an appropriate time for voters to go to the polling booths. Everybody is afraid to be in government right now. The underlying belief is: ''If the Democrats can't do it, who can?'' Some MPs even suggested that if Chuan feels that it is too much for his team to carry on he should resign and let somebody else succeed him instead of dissolving the House and calling a snap election. Some NAP young guns and foot soldiers raised a feeble cry for Chuan to let the people decide the country's fate through a new election, but they weren't backed by party chieftains, who would rather wait for the Democrats to lose their shine, as well as their sting. Fortunately for voters, more time is need for the government to lay the groundwork for the new electoral system. It's a big change for politicians as MPs will no longer be able to become Cabinet members, making House seats less attractive than before. Those who believe they have sufficient clout and fame want to be on a party list so they can take ministerial portfolios. NAP's best strategy at the moment is to seize on any missteps the Chuan Cabinet makes and let the public know all about them. Chavalit and his lieutenants are aware that even if they can form a coalition, the question of broad-based public acceptance cannot be dealt with easily, not to mention acceptance by the international community, which has influence on the country's economic direction. Being in government could mean a march towards another downfall, particularly as there are indications that a second economic meltdown is lurking around the corner, this time involving giants like Japan and China. NAP's war drum has not struck a resonating beat. Chat Pattana has yet to decide who will replace the late Gen Chatichai Choonhavan -- a subject which will also dictate the party's future. The immediate effect is a muffling of the drum by the hype of Thaksin, who is sounding out many well-known figures to join his camp. To a certain extent it could cause uncertainty for those looking to defect from NAP, whose own war chest remains impressive. The plain message is that there is plenty of meat left on the bone for all who decide to stay. Calls for a new election will continue to come from public-pressure groups, which have been saying that the crusade to rescue the economy should not provide an excuse for the Chuan government to delay polling. Chuan must not call an election merely on the basis that he wants the people to decide a new government. That's too easy an excuse to escape the pressing responsibilities. There is only choice left for him -- he has to succeed in the present economic rescue attempts. Anything else is insignificant. There is no urgency to change horses in mid-stream. As the public sees it, those floating around are either dead or wounded led by an old campaigner who himself looks half dead -- if not actually dead --politically.

Williams, Majoli out at French Open
Eds: UPDATES with Williams losing, Davenport victory By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Venus Williams, who powered her way through the first four rounds of the French Open, met her match Tuesday in top-seeded Martina Hingis, losing 6-3, 6-4 in the quarterfinals. But Williams' compatriot, No. 2 seed Lindsay Davenport, moved into the semis with a 6-1, 5-7, 6-3 victory over defending champion Iva Majoli. Hingis used her deft touch and clever court sense to run Williams down. She almost always seemed in control, never looking off balance or rushed. Hingis raced to a 3-0 lead, but Williams broke her in the fifth game for 3-2 as Hingis twice double-faulted. Hingis then broke right back for 4-2, and held on to win the set. In the second set, Williams had a chance to break Hingis for 2-0, racking up three break points. But Hingis won five straight points to take the game. In the crucial game of the set, Hingis broke Williams for 4-3 _ again on two double faults, this time by Williams. Also reaching the semifinals was Aranxta Sanchez Vicario, the No. 4 seed, who advanced with a three-set win over Patty Schnyder of Switzerland. The two-time champion lost a tiebreak in the second set but coasted through the third for a 6-2, 6-7 (5-7), 6-0 victory. But another former champion, Thomas Muster, continued a disappointing year with a quarterfinal loss to Felix Mantilla of Spain, the No. 15 seed, 6-4, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3. Muster has seen his ranking drop in the past year from ninth to 22nd. Williams was playing so well at this year's French Open that the match between her and Hingis had been seen as worthy of the final. But Hingis wasn't ready to call Williams a true rival. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she says. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam.'' ``I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth event on clay, responded diplomatically to Hingis' comments. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. Statistically speaking, the two have had an almost identical run through the early rounds here. Hingis has lost just 14 games while averaging 56 minutes per victory. Williams has lost 13 games and averaged 58 minutes per match. But stylistically speaking, they are totally different. Hingis has a masterful touch, moving opponents around the court with precise groundstrokes. Williams is pure power. Marat Safin, an 18-year-old qualifier, used his power to carve his way through the first three rounds. His tournament ended on Monday, however, in five tough sets. The French fans chanted wildly for his opponent, Frenchman Cedric Pioline. ``Allez Cedric!'' they yelled. But as the match wore on, there were growing chants of ``Ma-RAT! Ma-RAT!'' It was in tribute to the remarkable run by the young Russian playing his first Grand Slam event. He began the tournament ranked 116th in the world, but won't be there much longer. ``I think I can beat good players now,'' he said after Pioline ended his run 7-5, 4-6, 6-7 (5-7), 6-4, 6-4. Safin's tournament started with three qualifying matches just to get into the main draw. Next up was Andre Agassi, in the midst of a strong comeback. Safin, however, had the answer to every problem Agassi presented. Then he ousted defending champion Gustavo Kuerten, ranked eighth in the world, in another five-setter. In the third round, Safin had a slightly easier time _ needing only four sets to beat Daniel Vacek of the Czech Republic. That set up the match with Pioline. The 28-year-old Frenchman is erratic, but brilliant on occasion. He has reached the finals of Wimbledon and the U.S. Open, both times losing to Pete Sampras. Pioline has a reputation for choking at the end of matches. Although he has reached 12 singles finals in his career, he has captured only two titles. Safin knew nothing of that. ``Nobody told me,'' he said. It didn't matter. This time it was Safin who unraveled. Pioline broke the Russian's serve three times, including once in the fifth set. That was enough. (jn)

Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina formally launched the government's old-age allowance programme on Sunday last. The programme, initiated by the government to redeem the ruling party's commitment, aims at paying a monthly allowance of Taka 100 to over four lakh people all over the country. It is indeed a significant development, since no such move had ever been made in the past to provide pecuniary help to the poor old men and women. The beginning, modest though, reflects the realisation on the part of the decision makers that the old and infirm need to be taken care of with whatever resources we have. For many, life turns out to be an unbearable proposition owing to grinding poverty and poor physical conditions. But they are the same humans who once worked hard for their families and undertook nation-building activities. So there is a debt that society owes to them, and it should be paid back when they are too old to support themselves. Unfortunately, though elderly people have traditionally been treated with sympathy and respect in our society, many of them are now left without any source of income. So the task on our hands is to push the scheme towards its logical conclusion--- supporting as many old people as possible. The programme can be further expanded and the monthly allowance enhanced in future provided it is taken up in all seriousness. It can be meaningful only when we realise that helping the old is more than a matter of moral obligation-- it is a sacred responsibility that we have to shoulder with a sense of gratitude to the senior citizens. A lot more should to be done to ensure that they do not slip into a wretched existence in the last few years of their lives. For example, the number of homes for the old is still hopelessly inadequate. So an elaborate plan has to be formulated to change the lot of the old and ignored people. The old-age allowance programme should provide us with a sense of direction.

An earthquake struck northern Afghanistan on Saturday. More than 5,000 people are feared dead, probably buried under landslides and the ruins of their village homes. Figures of the injured exceed 1,000 and it is feared the toll may rise further. Last February an earthquake in this area left 2,300 dead and thousands homeless. Aid workers and relief agencies who were working in this region on that occasion should be able to utilise their experience in providing relief to this inaccessible mountainous place. The nearest airport at Faisalabad, already in use for relief to the war-ravaged country, can be the jumping-off base for the internationally sponsored effort to give succour to the quake-affected region. Though planes have provided preliminary supplies, the weather is not favourable because of overcast conditions and falling rain. Perhaps planes without landing can drop relief goods, medicine, tents, plastic sheeting and other disaster fighting materials since the need of the distressed cannot wait for any tomorrow.The earthquake region is in anti-Taliban alliance territory. On humanitarian grounds, there should be a truce declared in unequivocal terms among all the warring factions so that they may be able to pool their resources and help the quake victims right away. The local authorities have appealed for help on an urgent basis. They are asking the survivors of the more than eight villages which have been wiped out totally to leave the quake-prone area for its being too dangerous. People are always reluctant to leave one's home, however. But it is clear that if the villagers wish to re-build their homes, they should do so with quake-proof building material appropriate to their mountain homes. Most important, they will probably have to set up abodes elsewhere so that landslides do not bury their homes as before. Afghans it seems have been the prey to their own kind and nature, suffering the ravages of internecine war, freezing icy winters and earthquakes in remote regions where the populace perhaps felt safe from the guns. Peace is positively a required step, otherwise life will have little meaning to the quake-rehabilitated victims as well as their fellow citizens.

BC-Japan-Budget Deficit
Report: Japan expected to incur fiscal deficit for 1997
TOKYO (AP) _ Japan's state revenues for the 1997 fiscal year are expected fall short of government spending for the period because of the flagging economy, a news report said Tuesday. Final statistics for the year will be available only after the Finance Ministry compiles more recent tax revenue statistics, Kyodo News reported, citing ministry sources speaking on condition of anonymity. But tax revenues for the first 11 months of fiscal 1997, at 45.7 trillion yen (dlrs 328.8 billion), accounted for only 81.3 percent of the government's tax revenue projection, the report said. That means state revenues for the entire fiscal year are certain to fall short of budgeted government spending, Kyodo reported. Japan is going through its worst economic stagnation in decades, and the downturn has dented corporate earnings and income taxes, worsening the government's already troubled finances. The government had projected tax revenues would increase 8 percent over the previous year, but revenues in the first 11 months of the 1997 fiscal year _ which ended March 31 _ were only up 2.8 percent. BANGLADESH
Pakistan's nuclear blast: Completing South Asia's nuclear cycle!, THE INDEPENDENT xfdws PAKISTAN'S-NUCLEAR-BLAST sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 THE INDEPENDENT ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. KarimPakistan exploded five nuclear devices on the 28th May and became a nuclear power, the 7th and the latest in the world. It took no one by surprise, as people had apprehended its inevitability after India's nuclear explosions two weeks earlier. The issue was not whether but when Pakistan would detonate a bomb, as was explained by Pakistan's Foreign Minister Gouhar Ayub. Pakistan had already acquired the capability of exploding a nuclear device for some years, but India had actually detonated one as early as in 1974. The whole world condemned the tests of the two countries, in varying degrees, though both witnessed a maddening jubilation by their respective people following the events. Over and above this, Pakistan made another blast on the 30th May, in a bid to score a point higher than India in the nuclear race. Why did Pakistan act in the teeth of heavy opposition throughout the world, especially the big powers? The major powers, both nuclear and non-nuclear, sought to dissuade Pakistan from undertaking the action, but in vain. Their policy of carrot and stick failed to work in this case. The United States, Japan, UK, Germany and such other countries' offer of material rewards to Pakistan could not deter the latter from treading the path it had chosen. Nor the fear of the severe consequences of imposition of sanctions by those countries could set Pakistan off its track.The official explanation given by Pakistan related to one of security perception, signifying a threat from across its eastern borders. The purpose was purely defensive, stated by the Pakistanis with as much emphasis as the Indians had stated to justify their own. India's action left Pakistan with no alternative but to take a similar and possibly, a matching reaction. Any amount of protective assurances from big powers could not convince Pakistan of the efficacy of a nuclear umbrella, if it were at all possible. Besides, the pressure on Nawaz Sharif's government with a popular demand for Pakistan to go unclear following India's latest tests was mounting heavily. Many believed that no government in Pakistan could withstand such a heavy pressure indefinitely. Furthermore, the need for security was supplemented by a sense of vindication of national pride of the Pakistani people. And also, the fear of being stung by biting sanctions of aid donors was to be mitigated by the apparent readiness of the Pakistani people to undergo severe austerity for this purpose. Declaration of a state of emergency only testifies to that determination. Again, Pakistanis were also disappointed by what they regarded as inadequacy of condemnation of Indian tests and imposition of ineffectual sanctions on recalcitrant India by nations and world bodies. Finally, the Pakistan bomb may act as an effective deterrent to the Indian bomb, as the nuclear stalemate between the East and the West has, according to many, forestalled the world from plunging into a Third World War. If these could be advanced as points in favour of Pakistan's initial action, detonation of a sixth device could hardly be added to it as any measure of justification.India's initial reaction to Pakistan tests was mild. Indian leaders appeared to have viewed Pakistan's reaction almost as a foregone conclusion. They stated they would put a moratorium on further nuclear tests, agreed to negotiate about signing of the CTBT which action they had so long abhorred as discriminatory, and offered to discuss the issue with Pakistan. Pakistani Prime Minister also stated his readiness to talk to the Indians about this. This overture from both sides would be most welcome and is, perhaps, one of the most significant positive developments that has taken place in this murky episode. On the other hand, Pakistan Foreign Minister's apprehension about the possibility of Indian troops to go across the borders or the ceasefire line in Kashmir in ``hot pursuit,'' casts a gloomy pall of shadow in the minds of many.The nuclear tests of India, no doubt, upset the delicate balance of power that had precariously existed between India and Pakistan since their very inception as sovereign independent states. The balance tipped in favour of India and caused ecstasy in most quarters in that country, her leaders knowing fully well that Pakistan, which had already developed nuclear technology, would follow suit almost immediately. Why then would the government of India choose to bask in this transitory glory at the risk of introducing the horror of nuclear peril in the sub-continent? The so-called danger from the North or from the West is neither imminent nor real, taking into account positive overtures from the North and absence of extra-ordinary rattling from the West. It is hard to justify India's action. But, it is harder still for her people to face some good measure of political isolation and economic hardship which could better be avoided for the benefit of all concerned.India and, for that matter, Pakistan both had attained nuclear capability since many years, but the successive governments of both countries desisted from developing bombs in order to avoid a dangerous and resource gorging escalation of nuclear arms race which the poor people of the two counties can ill-afford. People wonder, whether it is the oft-repeated declaration of BJP leaders to glorify India with a nuclear status or a bid to consolidate unity of a fragile coalition of the government? May be both, may be some other additional considerations. Whatever may these have been, it bore ill tidings for the people of this region and even beyond.Another factor may be discerned from an analysis of these events in South Asia. It may entail the dangerous possibility of encouraging actions to promote similar nuclear programmes in other parts of the globe. The greatest concern of the West in this connection is not anywhere but in the Middle East. The near nuclear technology attained by Iran, for example, may be further developed into full nuclear capability in no time, and this would add to the worries or those who have undertaken the responsibility of safeguarding peace in that region. To restrain or punish Iran in the event it decides to go nuclear would not be as easy as it was for neighbouring Iraq. It may also be interesting for some to claim Pakistan's bomb as the Islamic bomb, since Pakistan itself is an Islamic Republic. But it is not regarded as such, since Pakistan's missile delivery system is not yet braced to reach the Western part of West Asia. But, it has the potential. Pakistan has categorically stated that it would continue with its nuclear programme and fix warheads to the missiles already developed and to those being developed. India had already announced her intention to induct the bomb on her missiles. The South Asian nuclear cycle is now complete. The escalation has commenced. It can be arrested only by the wisdom, initiative and efforts of the leaders of both India and Pakistan so as how to face the complex and dangerous situation that has now evolved. Given sincerity of purpose, only through dialogue between the parties concerned can the situation be somehow redeemed and this would help restore the sense of stability and peace that prevailed in the region and what all peace-loving people aspire for.

BC-Hungary-Politics
Outgoing premier also stepping down as Socialist Party leader
BUDAPEST, Hungary (AP) _ Outgoing Prime Minister Gyula Horn also plans to step down as the leader of his Socialist Party, a party vice president said Tuesday. The announcement was made by Magda Kosa Kovacs, after the party's executive committee met and decided to call a congress in late August or early September. Horn will not run for re-election as Socialist Party head then, she said, but will, however, continue to sit in Parliament as a Socialist deputy. Horn, 65, has led the Socialist-party since 1989, after it split from the old-line communists, and led them to victory in the 1994 elections. In elections last month, the Socialists were defeated by the center-right Young Democrats-Civic Party, which won 148 seats, to the Socialists 134. Young Democrats leader Viktor Orban on Tuesday met President Arpad Goencz, who indirectly told him he would be asked to form the next government as head of the party with the most seats. Orban told reporters afterward that he was urged to proceed with coalition talks. ``We agreed with the president that the interests of the country dictate that the next government be set up as soon as possible,'' Orban said. Orban has yet to meet with the head of the Independent Smallholders, Jozsef Torgyan. Torgyan's party won 48 seats and without his support Orban cannot form the next government. Negotiations, expected to start later in the week, promise to be tough. Orban last week assured German Chancellor Helmut Kohl that Hungary remains keenly interested in attracting western investments. The agrarian-based right-wing Smallholders, however, view foreign capital with suspicion. (ab/gj)

THAILAND
POLITICAL VIEW: Who actually are the 'still' rich?, NATION xfdws WHO-ARE-STILL-RICH sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 NATION ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
The battle between the ''rich'' and the ''poor'' has become keener, with northeastern MPs in the opposition camp styling themselves guardians of the poor and joining in the fray. These politicians hope to gain votes by portraying their adversaries in government as mean people who only open their hearts to the rich. The debate has become socially divisive and explosive as the national economy remains in deep crisis. This is a bad time indeed for most people. It is also the first time in our modern history when free lunches have been offered daily to the jobless, the poor and the destitute under the philanthropic programme initiated by Her Majesty the Queen. It is similar to the soup line provided for the homeless in the West, especially during the Great Depression. Politicians of the New Aspiration Party, who are mainly from the poverty-stricken northeast, are making the most out of it. As they champion the rural poor, they finger the urban rich -- now the formerly rich -- as the group which benefits most from the present government-rescue measures. Unscrupulous politicians have no qualms in driving a wedge between the sensitive layers of society for their own benefit. They may gain a few additional votes, but in the end these may not be worth the ensuing conflicts. The outcry over the disparity between the ''rich'' and the ''poor'' by NAP MPs is frequently heard during House debates. They like it most when the sessions are telecast live, making it sound as if the northeastern poor would be better off if they were back in government. However, these MPs are typical pork-barrel politicians who skim the cream off the budgets allocated for rural projects. Many of them have set up dummy or front companies to bid for contracts for public projects owing to their close connections with local officials and rural community leaders. MPs once enjoyed a Bt20-million slush fund each every fiscal year for development projects in their constituencies. Nobody ever questioned them in a serious manner as to how they spent such money. The fund was really a perk clothed in a nice term so that the spenders did not have to feel overly embarrassed. While a full accounting of the money used has yet to be completed to determine the extent of the projects' true benefits, it would be no surprise to learn that the poor rural souls never received what had been meant for them. What is seriously wrong is that the rural folks have never got the right people as their representatives. If their MPs were as efficient and caring as they have claimed, the rural poor would not have to seasonally march to Bangkok, set up camp in front of Government House and endure all the terrible environment and suffering of the city. Maybe it is an appropriate time to ask those self-styled crusaders for the rural poor: who are the formerly rich and the still rich? Corporate crooks in the finance and banking sector who have managed to siphon off money for the good life before their firms collapsed are still rich. They are trying their best to keep themselves safe from the relatively feeble arm of our law. Families with old wealth which thrive on interest income are not affected. They stand to be wealthier provided that the institutions which hold their deposits do not go under. Businessmen who cannot cope with the harsh conditions of tight liquidity, high interest rates and failed transactions may be in either the rich or poor category, depending on what kind of financial lifebuoys they have prepared for themselves. Salaried people, wage-earners and the self-employed are affected through reduced income and pay packages. Those already laid off by their employees to join the swelling unemployment are hardest hit if they do not have enough savings. Many have to part with homes and cars through foreclosures and repossession. Most sectors in society have complained about the deteriorating economic situation, but by profession politicians are blessed with opportunities to become ever richer. So far there has been just a token cut in their pay, which is already high by national standards compared with the number of days they attend House sessions. Remember the notorious northeastern spin doctor whose bank account showed over Bt3 million but who claimed that Bt1 million had been borrowed from a friend? The manure-throwing downtrodden at the rally would never have a chance to lay their hands on that kind of money in their lifetimes. MPs with ministerial experience stand to be even richer. None has died a pauper so far except for those long known for their modest living and lifelong honesty. Parliament, when in session, resembles a motor show where MPs unabashedly display their wealth. Expensive wines and attire among well-monied MPs are mind-boggling for the little people they vow to serve. By professional and House rules, the MPs wear suits, a far cry from the well-worn and unwashed attire of the poor souls who rally in front of Government House. These MPs have yet to explain to the public what category they would be in were their own financial standings made public. Many northeastern MPs who shed tears for the poor are actually more affluent than the average millionaire. Indeed, these campaigners for the poor, by and large, are still very rich and unaffected by the economic hardships. They are spoiling for the days when they can exercise the power of their wealth to lure the gullible to elect them back to the House, no doubt for further self-enrichment. When poor politicians don't have their own campaign funds to buy votes, they borrow money from patrons to fake their wealth and mislead the voters into thinking that they are financially sound enough to fulfil their campaign promises if elected. See? They are even rich in lies.

THAILAND
EDITORIAL: Need to hire foreign consultants prudently, NATION xfdws FOREIGN-CONSULTANTS sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 NATION ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
Like vultures, international consultancy firms have flocked to crisis-hit Thailand which is under pressure from foreign creditors to reform its institutions, policies and management. Yes, the much-heralded solutions such as good governance, transparency and accountability cannot simply occur like magic: they need advisory input. But policy-makers should rethink their consultancy-hiring policies. They may discover that Thai consultants can do a better job, and at more competitive fees, than their foreign counterparts. Where Thailand needs foreign know-how is not in terms of ideas but in actual management such as implementers, managers, enforcers, trainers and supervisors. Spearheading much of the consultancy work is the World Bank, Asian Development Bank, International Monetary Fund and the Thai government itself. Foreign consultants are now flooding various ministries. Go to the Finance Ministry on any day and one will find long queues of foreign consultants, investment bankers and creditors, all waiting to see the minister, his deputy or department heads, offering work from consultancy on privatisation, recapitalisation and reorganisation, international bond issue and bureaucratic reform to system efficiency management. Many well-known international consultancy firms have set up offices in Bangkok: McKenzie Co, Arthur Andersen, Coopers and Lybrand, Price Waterhouse, Ernst and Young, Booz Allen and so on. Despite that the government is broke, these firms expect to earn hefty fees from the restructuring loans extended by the World Bank and others to the Thai government. The deals are not just being done out of Bangkok but from the headquarters of these international organisations. Such organisations have inside information on what consultancy work may be up for bidding. For instance, the World Bank has cut its permanent staff in recent years and is now relying on outside consultancy -- turning it into a global business. If there are merits in using international consultants to help provide know-how, and to provide systematic planning and implementation to tackle Thailand's weaknesses as well as upgrading policy-making and systems to international standards, that is fine. But in many instances, it's not the case. There is also a growing chorus within Thailand that foreign consultancies are taking many Thai agencies, and therefore taxpayers, for a ride by overcharging, taking advantage of local consultants and submitting work which makes Thailand dependent on them. Such a view should be taken seriously by Thai policy-makers, the World Bank, and especially the Finance Ministry which is dishing out the money. Indeed, many local firms could do the main consultancy work better because of their greater understanding of local culture and ways of working. Of course, they would need additional input from foreign partners. However, at present the main consultancy contracts are often won by the foreign consulting firms who then sub-contract minor parts to local firms. There are instances where expensive privatisation studies done by foreign consultancies are gathering dust on the shelves. While this could partly be due to internal resistance to change, some recommendations provided by the foreign consultants are not practical under the working culture of the Thai bureaucracy. In many cases these recommendations cannot be immediately implemented because more studies are required, and thus they create a dependency. The World Bank et al and the Thai government should rethink the way consultancy work is handed out. They should also carefully examine how the work between foreign and local consultants is divided before awarding contracts. If they do that, they will find they might save a lot of money and get more things done. And they will also find that local consultants can do much of the work now given to foreign consultants. Where foreign input is needed most is not in advice but in management. How about awarding advisory contracts to Thai consultants and hiring foreigners to help with the actual implementation, training and managing and supervising of governance, transparency and accountability? Then it would be a win-win situation for everyone.

Ex-Fiat head takes over Italian Publisher
MILAN, Italy (AP) - Cesare Romiti, the outgoing chairman of industrial giant Fiat, on Tuesday was named chairman of the company controlling Italy's largest newspaper, Corriere della Sera. Italian newspapers over the weekend reported that Romiti was likely to be appointed to head RCS Editori, the publishing arm of Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali SpA. Romiti's son, Maurizio Romiti, is the chief executive officer of Holding. Traders have said Romiti's appointment could herald a restructuring within the group and a focus on either its fashion or publishing businesses. Romiti will replace Alberto Ronchey. Fiat has a controlling interest in the publishing company, and also owns the Turin daily La Stampa. Romiti turns 75 in June, when he has said he will leave Fiat. (dj/djw)

BANGLADESH
Stop this madness, THE INDEPENDENT xfdws STOP-THE-MADNESS sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 THE INDEPENDENT ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. AND WORLD TIMES, INC. NO PORTION OF THE MATERIALS CONTAINED HEREIN MAY BE USED IN ANY MEDIA WITHOUT ATTRIBUTION TO WORLDSOURCES, INC.
HussainPakistan has done it again. If India stunned the world by detonating five nuclear devices in two days, Pakistan sprang a surprise by storming into the nuclear club by conducting five tests in one day and following it up with another blast on Saturday. Hawks in both countries seem to have carried the day in flagrant disregard of international opinion.India's decision to flex its nuclear muscle and Pakistan's tit-for-tat response have dumbfounded the world. There is no gainsaying the fact that it was India that started the deadly nuclear race in the sub-continent. The BJP leadership with its penchant for populist measures and Maciavellian tactics was looking for a device that could save its floundering coalition government. And what better way could there be than the atomic device and claim credit for making India a nuclear power state? But the credit for making India attain nuclear power status should go to the Nehru dynasty. It was India's first Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru who established the Atomic Energy Commission in the 50s with the avowed purpose of using nuclear energy for peaceful purposes. Indira Gandhi carried forward this work a step further and enabled India to join the nuclear club with a bang in 1974. It should be said to India's credit that it imposed a moratorium on further tests. It is a matter of great regret that the BJP-led government has disregarded this self-imposed moratorium and embarked upon a policy which could bring bigger nuclear holocaust in the sub-continent. If the claim made by Pakistan's Foreign Minister Gohar Ayub Khan that India is planning to conduct more tests this month in Orissa (the earlier tests were conducted in Rajasthan) is correct, then the portents are ominous. The only silverlining in the cloud is that in India itself the initial euphoria over the successful nuclear tests has evaporated and the Vajpayee government is in the dock for starting this mad, mad race.If the economic sanctions slapped on India and Pakistan by the industrialised countries are strictly enforced, then the masses in both the countries are bound to suffer immensely. After the liberalisation of the economy during Narasimha Rao's Prime Ministership, the Indian economy had made rapid strides. It has now received a big jolt with share prices plummeting and the rupee tumbling to an all-time low of 41-70 against the American dollar. The sanctions are likely to hit Pakistan harder as its economy is heavily dependant on foreign aid. Pakistan may be looking to the oil-rich Gulf States to bail it out of impending economic disaster. Will they come to Pakistan's aid in this hour of crisis? This is a moot question.The world has justifiably reacted with shock and anger to the uncalled-for nuclear explosions by New Delhi and Islamabad. The hope that the latter would desist from conducting further tests after matching India's five underground tests has been shattered. It is high time that the two countries listened to the voice of sanity and called a halt to the deadly arms race. The unspeakable hours of Nagasaki and Hiroshima are still green in our memory. If they ignore the call of the international community to exercise restraint and desist from making Islamic bomb' and Hindu bomb,' it will be tantamount to committing hara-kiri, for in a nuclear war there won't be any victor. There will be only losers and destruction and devastation that will remind us of Dooms Day. Will there be light at the end of the tunnel?

THAI TALK: A new political party, anyone?, NATION xfdws POLITICAL-PARTY sked Emerging Markets Datafile June 02, 1998 NATION ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC. A very good friend of mine called the other day to announce that he was setting up a new political party. He said he was financially well-endowed. He wanted to serve the country. The only trouble was he didn't have a platform that could make him a serious contender. The other problem, equally if not more serious for him, was that he had yet to think of a name for the party. I congratulated him on his show of patriotism. The country is in trouble. We need new political leaders with convictions. A new party will offer an alternative and much-needed vision. He will show the electorate around the country that the existing major parties simply don't have workable solutions to the country's economic crisis. I was excited. Finally, here's someone providing the country with some fresh, bold and innovative platform. But an ambitious political aspirant could be very humble indeed. He confessed that it wasn't out of any serious convictions that he had decided to form a political party.He is more pragmatic than that. ''No, I prefer not to talk about platform. You see, I want to set up a party for people who think the Democrats are too liberal and the New Aspiration Party too conservative,'' he declared. ''In other words, those rejected by the two major parties,'' I suggested, not quite sure what he was getting at. ''No, we will be somewhere in the middle. People want a third choice. I am the third choice. I have money. I have connections. I have social status,'' he declared. I was almost convinced, but my reporter's instinct dictated that I had to pose some naive questions. ''So you are the grey party, somewhere between black and white?'' I proposed. ''No, we are white, the new white. The Democrats have turned grey and the New Aspiration people remain black. The Thai people, you must realise, are short on patience. They are easily bored with politicians, however good they may be. They will jump at anything that looks new and exciting. That's why, applying my business marketing strategy, I will be announcing a relaunch of the same product, only this time it will be much more attractive with a new packaging technique.'' I was overwhelmed by that eloquent explanation. The crucial question, though, still had to be asked. ''But that doesn't hide the fact that you still don't have a platform. People don't know what you represent,'' I said, sincerely concerned about his devil-may-care approach. He remained nonchalant. ''Don't be stupid. Politicians in this country do not win elections through platform. Who cares? If I must say something about platform, it's very simple. All I have to say is that this government doesn't care about the poor and the current opposition is too poor to do anything about the poor. They all know I am super rich. So they will believe me when I say I am the new champion of the poor.'' I was almost convinced. ''That may be true, but don't you have to tell the public just how you will go about fulfilling your promise?'' I asked, almost apologetically. ''That's irrelevant. They kicked out Chavalit because they got fed up with his underlings. Now they are beginning to get frustrated with Chuan. It's six months, and the honeymoon is over. They want a new face who can make new promises. And that's where I fit in. Running this country has nothing to do with platform. It has to do with pleasing a few outspoken academics, cajoling some newspaper columnists and, most important of all, stroking the ego of a handful members of the elite. The secret is: never ever stop talking the poor whether you have done anything for them or not.'' So, in a curious way perhaps, he does have a platform. Wrapped under a new, stunningly colourful packaging, ready for the big relaunch.

BC-Zimbabwe-University Closed
University closed after anti-Mugabe demonstrations
HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) _ Officials closed the University of Zimbabwe Tuesday because of anti-government demonstrations and heavily armed riot police evicted students from residence halls. Protesting students lit a giant bonfire as police moved from one hall to another on the tense campus to evict students. Fleets of taxis ferried the students away from police barricades set up at every campus entrance. Students' actions had ``made it impossible to continue operating normally,'' the university's principal and Vice Chancellor Graham Hill told state radio. ``The closure has been necessitated by the criminal damage to University of Zimbabwe by a group of students.'' Hill's boss is Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe, who is the university chancellor and controls the university senate under a 1994 law. The university campus houses about 3,000 students and another 2,000 students live elsewhere around the city. Mugabe was the target of thousands of student demonstrators last week who blocked the streets leading to Parliament and demanded Mugabe's resignation. Chants and signs compared allegations of government corruption under Mugabe with that of Indonesia's deposed President Suharto. Eds: INCORPORATES India-Economy. Trims. No pickup AP Photo GEV101-103 By KRISHNAN GURUSWAMY Associated Press Writer
NEW DELHI, India (AP) _ Bucking international criticism, Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee suggested Tuesday that the five traditional declared nuclear powers get rid of their own arsenals rather than preach to India. ``Let us see if they heed our call,'' Vajpayee told 300 supporters who came to his house in New Delhi to congratulate him for India's five underground nuclear tests last month. Those underground tests prompted neighboring Pakistan to retaliate with six announced nuclear tests of its own, igniting a nuclear arms race on the volatile subcontinent. In Geneva, 46 countries jointly demanded in a statement Tuesday that India and Pakistan immediately cease testing nuclear arms and join the global move to eliminate the weapons. ``The testing of nuclear weapons by India and Pakistan is totally irreconciliable with the claims by both countries that they are committed to nuclear disarmament,'' said the statement. Among the countries that backed the statement before an emergency meeting of the 61-nation Conference on Disarmament were the traditional declared nuclear powers of United States, Britain, China, France and Russia. Also supporting the ban on further testing were Japan, South Korea, South Africa and European and Latin American nations, but conspicuously missing were Middle Eastern countries. The statement said India's and Pakistan's explosions in May were ``provocative and dangerous acts.'' In his speech Tuesday, Vajpayee noted that U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan had said there is need to rethink disarmament issues. ``I want to add that the time has come not just to think but to act as well,'' Vajpayee said to applause. ``There have been endless meetings, discussions and seminars on disarmament, but no steps have been taken to get rid of nuclear weapons.'' Vajpayee reiterated that he had asked India's scientists to test only as many devices as needed to safeguard India's security and then ordered a moratorium on further tests. Jane's Defense Weekly reported Tuesday that India pulled back at the last minute from carrying out a sixth nuclear test. The London-based weekly, quoting unidentified defense sources, said even though two other small devices were tested May 13, the third test was abandoned that day partly due to a minor technical hitch but largely for political reasons. The government was apparently hesitant after being hit with U.S. sanctions for three tests May 11. ``The unexploded device has reportedly been recovered from the site and put into ``safekeeping'','' Jane's said. Also Tuesday, Atomic Energy Commission chief R. Chidambaram denied a local report that he told fellow scientists Monday that more small nuclear tests might be carried out for research purposes. He said there would be no further testing. The United States, Australia, Japan and other countries have cut off loans and all but humanitarian aid to punish India and Pakistan. Montek Singh Ahluwalia, India's top Finance Ministry official, said Tuesday that state-owned Indian corporations can still borrow from U.S. banks. Only direct investment to the government in the form of treasury bills and government bonds is affected, he said. India's latest budget, presented Monday, contains a 14 percent increase in defense expenditures and a hefty 68 percent hike in spending on atomic energy.

OSLO, Norway (AP) _ A harpooned whale rammed the Norwegian boat that shot it, breaking the vessel's mast and dumping two crewmen into the icy waters, an Oslo newspaper reported Tuesday. The whale escaped, but it was unclear if it survived its injuries, according to Verdens Gang. One crewman was injured from the fall. The incident occurred Monday off Norway's northern tip, about 700 kilometers (425 miles) north of the Arctic Circle, where the Bolga harpooned a minke whale, the newspaper said. The whale then rammed the 53-foot (16-meter) wooden boat, and pulled with tremendous force on the rope attached to the harpoon, it said. The impact broke the boat's 8-meter (26-foot) mast, throwing two crewmen spotting whales from atop the mast into the water. ``I had made it about halfway down the mast when I felt a sudden jolt. The next thing I knew, I was in the water,'' crewman Benn Viggo Nilsen, 40, was quoted as telling the newspaper. Nilsen and Bjoern Johansen were rescued. Johansen suffered cracked ribs, while Nilsen was uninjured. The Bolga was so badly damaged that it had to withdraw from this year's hunt, the report said. The minke whale can grow up to 9 meters (30 meters) long. Norway has endured frequent protests since resuming its commercial whaling hunts in 1993, despite a ban imposed by the International Whaling Commission in 1986.

IF statistics unveiled recently by the Malaysian Motor Traders Association (MMTA) painted an unflattering picture of the automotive industry, it was also not entirely unexpected. Rumblings of a market shakedown were already felt months before the end of last year. Yet robust performance for the earlier part of 1997 enabled the industry to record a modest growth of 11% for the year. For the last six months, however, the combined effect of the 1998 Budget, weakening of the ringgit, the depressed stockmarket and the credit squeeze has begun to exact a heavy toll on the market. Sales of new cars have reportedly fallen by more than 60%. Used car value has declined by more than 30%. MMTA expects a sharp market decline for all sub-sectors. Total industry volume is predicted to fall by about 60%. While sales of 4X4 and commercial vehicles may be the worst hit, the market for passenger cars is foreseen to decline just as badly. From more than 300,000 units sold last year, total sales for 1998 is expected to be in the region of 130,000 cars. With its control of some 80% of the domestic passenger car sub-sector, manufacturer of the national car, DRB-Hicom, could be in for an especially rough ride ahead. Proton, the main operating subsidiary of the group, is already on a major cost-cutting drive with substantial production cuts on the cards. The group's Perodua plant in Rawang is reported to have scaled down production to 2,800 units this year from 10,000 units the year before. The situation is apparently just as pressing, is not worse, at facilities of non-national car assemblies. Depressing sales at Cycle Carriage Bintang, assembler and distributor of Mercedes Benz and Mazda cars, has led to temporary closure of its production facility for three months since April 1. Workers have been asked to go on long leave with a 25% pay cut. The question is what will happen after that. Few expect the industry to turn around in such a short time. What will happen to the 50,000 workers employed by the sector? How long can car companies stay in the black? What options do they have? Quite naturally, because of its commanding position in the market, all eyes will be on the DRB-Hicom Group. Its offer of substantially cheaper lower range models - Kancil and Iswara - has created some excitement in the market. So is its foray into overseas markets. However, whatever benefits these may bring, they are unlikely to be able to return sales to anywhere near last year's level anytime soon. What remains is for the group, indeed the entire industry, to dig in and persevere. They should be prepared for a tough long haul. It would be unrealistic to expect a shortcut out of the present situation. - Editor

Miners' protests continue in Ukraine despite government appeal
By SERGEI SHARGORODSKY Associated Press Writer
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) - Despite an appeal by the Ukrainian government, dozens of miners rallied Tuesday in front of parliament headquarters, demanding the payment of back wages. The workers were backed by left-wing opposition activists, who long have sought to capitalize on their protests so as to achieve political goals. Dozens of Ukrainian mines have been idled by scattered strikes since last month, with workers demanding the payment of wage arrears, salary hikes and more state support for the struggling coal industry. Last week, the government and two miners' unions, including the largest, the Coal Industry Workers' Union, signed a protocol in which the authorities pledged to meet some of the workers' demands. In particular, the government promised to spend a total of 800 million hryvna (dlrs 400 million) to support the industry. But the Independent Miners' Union refused to accept the document, pointing out that the government only promised to allocate 500 million hryvna (dlrs 250 million) to cover wage arrears. The union estimates the total sum owed to the miners at 2.2 billion hryvna (dlrs 1.1 billion), the Interfax news agency reported. In a statement late Monday, the government said it could only fulfill the independent union's demands at the expense of other miners. It called on the striking miners to show ``wisdom'' in a joint search for a solution and also blamed some coal industry leaders for failing to ensure prompt wage payments to the miners, Interfax said. ``The current crisis in the coal industry has deep and structural roots. It is practically impossible to quickly resolve the miners' problems, which have piled up for years,'' the statement said. Speaking at a government meeting, Prime Minister Valery Pustovoitenko also blamed the wage crisis on coal industry managers' irresponsibility, and insisted that the government was fulfilling its financial commitment to the industry, Interfax said. Besides financial problems, Ukraine's coal industry is plagued by poor work discipline that, together with outdated equipment, has claimed the lives of about 170 miners this year. On Tuesday, rescue workers found the body of a miner who died in a May 28 rock collapse at a mine in eastern Ukraine, the Emergency Situations Ministry said. In an accident Monday, the main ventilation system stopped working at the Matrosskaya mine in the eastern Luhansk region, the ministry said. Some 53 workers who were inside the mine at the time were safely lifted to the surface, it said. (sms/ml)

THAILAND could become a major international supplier of amphetamine as Thai drug cartels have struck up an alliance with their Lao and Burmese counterparts to produce the illicit stimulant in neighbouring countries, according to a drug expert. Dr Vichai Poshyachinda, a drug expert and member of the Narcotics Control Board, said the shift in production base was aimed mainly to circumvent tougher control on chemical precursors, such as ephedrine, which is classified as a restrictively controlled substance in Thailand. ''It becomes as clear as jigsaw pieces falling into place that Thai drug cartels are on their way to becoming major suppliers of amphetamine in the international market,'' said Vichai. The supply of amphetamine in Thailand was believed to be from foreign sources outside the Southeast Asian region until the first clandestine laboratory was found in a Bangkok suburb in 1986. Supplies of amphetamine have increased dramatically along with demand for the stimulant in recent years. He cited Laos' recent anti-drug report which indicated that most of the cases of production of amphetamine in Laos involved importing substances for the purpose of immediate re-export either to circumvent import tax in the target countries or to divert the substances for illicit purposes. In one of the major drug busts in recent years, Lao drug-enforcement officials in a northwestern province raided a clandestine amphetamine laboratory, arresting 25 suspects, including seven Thais and 10 Burmese, and seized more than 20 tonnes of material and equipment, the report said. Among the substances seized in the raid were various chemical precursors imported from a neighbouring country. Lao law-enforcement officials also seized 6.7 tonnes of chemical precursors near the Mekong River not far from the laboratory. The report was submitted to an international seminar on drug-abuse problems in Bangkok recently. Another report made by the Burmese government said that although stimulant and hallucinogen abuse were not popular in Burma, law-enforcement officials had reported an increasing number of people arrested in connection with production and trafficking of amphetamine. In 1996 law-enforcement officials made arrests in 13 cases of amphetamine production and trafficking, seizing 5.9 million tablets. Last year there were nine offences, with a seizure of more than 1.1 million tablets. It was also known that ephedrine was being moved from China to Thailand through Burma's Shan State. Vichai said the Golden Triangle, the major production area of opiates that straddles the Thai, Burmese and Lao borders, has now expanded its output to include large supplies of methamphetamine. ''The involvement of a multinational network extending over the whole Far East in the illicit trade is also evident,'' Vichai said. Although the manufacture of illicit stimulants in the Asean countries is evidently confined to methamphetamine, abuse of illicit stimulants includes the Ecstasy group of amphetamine derivatives and cocaine, he said. ''It is clear that the abuse of stimulants is fostered simultaneously by intra- and extra-regional supplies,'' Vichai said.

EU criticizes U.S. quota on wheat gluten imports from Europe
BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) - The European Commission on Tuesday denounced the U.S. decision to limit imports of EU wheat gluten over a three-year period and warned of retaliation. The quota, ``represents a major restriction on European exports,'' the EU executive Commission said in a statement. ``This action is all the more surprising coming from a government that only two weeks ago was calling on WTO members to further liberalize trade in agricultural products.'' The EU head office was considering ``appropriate responses'' but gave no immediate details. EU spokesman Gerard Kiely said the quota suggested Washington will defend free farm trade if that serves American farmers only. The EU has nabbed 30 percent of the American wheat gluten market. Kiely said that was because wheat prices in Europe are lower than corn prices, whereas the reverse is true in the United States. EU officials said high imports of EU wheat gluten into the United States had been predicted for years and said they were ``astonished this evidence was ignored'' for so long. They termed the U.S. quota unfair, especially since other exporters, such as Canada, have been exempted from it. On Monday, President Clinton signed off on a three-year quota on imported wheat gluten. He followed a recommended to that effect, issued in March, by the U.S. International Trade Commission. The quota will be 126 million pounds (57,000 metric tons) in the first year, rising by 6 percent annually. Each year the U.S. industry consumes 22 million bushels of wheat, worth about dlrs 100 million. Two billion tons of wheat flour yield 300 million pounds of gluten annually. Wheat gluten is the natural protein portion of the grain. It adds protein to breakfast cereals, pet food, livestock feed and helps whole-grain breads rise. The wheat gluten debate is yet another transatlantic trade dispute. Only last week, the two sides wrangled over a 30,000-ton shipment of subsidized Finnish barley that landed on U.S. soil. The United States announced it would start subsidizing barley exports. This year, the United States introduced poultry export subsidies after the EU imposed restrictions on US poultry imports.
