THE Prachakorn Thai Party, Monday, moved a step closer to expelling its 12 rebel MPs by firing all the executives on the party's board. However, the rebel MPs, who were among the 17 executives fired, argued that the resolution violated regulations and threatened to appeal to the Constitution Court. Earlier, four executives on the rebels' side had resigned from the board thereby quitting the party. Prachakorn Thai leader Samak Sundaravej had the board appoint 21 new executives immediately, which would give him monopoly over the board, as a final step in expelling the 12 rebels. Samak has yet to schedule the next meeting of the board which will concentrate on expelling the 12 members. To get rid of them, Samak would need votes from at least 49 of 65 party executives before he expels the renegade MPs. The appointment of the new executives had been approved in a party assembly, which followed the board's meeting. Somboon Vessunthorn, a party executive close to Samak, said the party has yet to submit Monday's resolution, to appoint new executives, to the political parties' registrar for acknowledgment before the new board can convene. Somboon said he expected the 12 MPs to be expelled within two months. Most of the rebel MPs attended Monday's board meeting, except Deputy Interior Minister Vatana Assavahame and PM's Office Minister Somboon Rahong. After being fired from the board, Deputy Government spokesman Pan Phuengsujarit said the resolution had violated Article 45 of the party's regulations. Pan said that even though Samak had set up a committee to investigate the 12 MPs, the panel had never asked them to testify or allowed them to defend themselves against allegations. ''We will appeal to the Civil and Constitution courts for a ruling on whether the resolution to expel us from the board was justified or not,'' Pan said. However, Samak argued that Article 45 could only be applied when a party member is expelled from the party, not from the board. Earlier, Samak had replaced 11 executives loyal to the rebel MPs with his own men. The rebels had appealed with the Election Commission that resolution violated the party's regulations but the commission had ruled in Samak's favour. The MPs then sought a ruling, yet to be made, from the Constitution Court.

SCORE (Sistem Pelaksanaan dan Penyaluran Pesanan Berkomputer): The acronym for ``System on Computerised Order Routing and Execution'' - the trading system of the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange. Under SCORE, orders are keyed in at the stockbrokers' offices. These are then routed to the KLSE's central computer system for matching. Once an order is matched, the trades will be displayed on the Exchange's realtime dissemination system, Winstock. SCRIP ISSUE (Terbitan Saham): The issue of shares, free of charge, by a company to its shareholders in proportion to their existing holdings. Such an issue is also called a bonus issue. SECONDARY MARKET (Pasaran Sekunder): The market for existing securities which have been issued. It is distinguished from the primary market in which securities are issued for the first time. SECURITIES (Sekuriti): A generic term for any financial instrument. Examples include ordinary shares, warrants, fixed interest debt investments, etc. SELL ORDER (Pesanan Jualan): An order given by a customer to a broker/remisier to dispose of a security on the market. SELL OUT (Jualan Paksa): When the buyer fails to pay for the shares he has contracted for, the stockbroker sells the shares at the best obtainable price in the open market and any loss on the transaction is borne by the buyer. SETTLEMENT (Penyelesaian): The completion of a transaction whereby securities and corresponding funds are delivered and credited to the appropriate accounts. SHARE (Saham): A security which represents a portion of the owner's capital in a business. Shares may be of different types, conferring varying rights on their holders; such different types include ordinary shares, preference shares, redeemable preference shares, etc. The most common type of share is ordinary share. SHARE CERTIFICATE (Sijil Saham): A document indicating the registered owner, the security and the number of shares owned. SHARE SPLIT (Pecahan Saham): The subdivision of shares into a larger number of shares with a smaller face value (or par value). Sometimes splits are made to increase the marketability of a security. SHARE SWAP (Tukarganti Saham): The issue of shares by a company in exchange for equity interest of another company. SHAREHOLDERS' EQUITY (Ekuiti Pemegang Saham): The liabilities of a company represented by its issued capital and reserves. The issued capital is the amount which has been subscribed by the shareholders. Reserves include accumulated profits or capital gains retained in the business. It is also known as shareholders' funds. SHORT SALE/SELLING (Jualan Singkat): The action of a person selling shares which he does not own at the time of selling. The short seller believes that the price will decline and that he will be able to buy the shares back at a lower price. At the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange, only regulated short selling is permitted in respect of approved securities. Trading in RSS is temporarily suspended at the KLSE. SINKING FUND (Dana Terikat): Money set aside on a regular basis by a borrower in order to redeem outstanding loans. Normally such a fund is set up in accordance with a debenture deed as added security for the lenders. SPECIAL ISSUE (Terbitan Khas): The issue of shares to a special group of individuals or organisations. SPECULATION (Spekulasi): Investment on a short-term basis hoping for quick profits. STOCK EXCHANGE (Bursa Saham): An organised marketplace for the buying and selling of securities. STOCKBROKER (Syarikat Broker Saham): An agent who buys and sells shares on behalf of his clients and is paid brokerage or commission for his services. SUBSIDIARY (Anak Syarikat): A company in which more than 50% of the voting shares are owned by another company. SUBSTANTIAL SHAREHOLDER (Pemegang Saham Utama): A person or organisation holding at least 5% of a company's issued capital. SUSPEND TRADING (Penggantungan Dagangan): A halt in the trading of a counter on the exchange. The suspension may be at the request of the company or imposed by the exchange.

THE Rolls-Royce of all cars is here in Malaysia. It is, not surprisingly, a Rolls-Royce! The Silver Seraph, to be exact. Indeed, the Silver Seraph is the first new Rolls-Royce for nearly two decades - an eternity in modern motoring terms for a new model to be introduced. But then, the Rolls-Royce is not your everyday anonymous utility runabout rolling off some highly mechanised mass production line. Such is the premium attached to individual craftsmanship and attention to detail as Rolls-Royce owners come from the monied ranks drawn from royalty, business tycoons, more royalty and more business tycoons. In fact, at least one member of royalty and one tycoon (apparently unaffected by economic problems like most others) was spotted at a reception held by Next Car Sdn Bhd - the distributor of Rolls-Royce and Bentley cars in Malaysia - a few Saturdays ago to introduce the Silver Seraph to the Malaysian public. Need one add that they had come chauffeur-driven - in their Rolls-Royces of course! So, if you are one of eight people (Malaysia's quota for this year's production) in the land with RM3.4 million in loose change (after the pernicious 300% import duty and a further 10% sales tax), hurry along and grab one. Even before BMW began wooing Rolls-Royce Motor Cars to form an auto alliance, the German automaker already had a foot in the door. The Silver Seraph's all-aluminium 5.4 litre, V12 engine beats with a Teutonic heart. In fact it was back in 1994 that both companies started engineering collaboration to develop and test the specific power and torque characteristics required for the new Rolls-Royce Silver Seraph. The result is a linear torque characteristic providing smooth delivery of power from low engine revs, allowing the car to accelerate through to 100 kmph in under seven seconds. But all that is secondary to the Rolls-Royce inimitable regal looks. Seraph points to a celestial being of the highest order associated especially with light, ardour and purity. The new name, Silver Seraph is spelt out in the graceful exterior styling which is a contemporary treatment of classic Rolls-Royce themes. Its defining feature is the shouldered waistline which sweeps unbroken from nose to tail with both the cabin and boot inset from it. Viewed from the side, the waistline reaches a plateau just forward of the front door handles, then gradually falls along the length of the car in one continuous line. Allowing the boot to rise independently of this falling waistline not only links the Seraph to previous Rolls-Royce styles but offers improved aerodynamic efficiency and a significant increase in luggage space. The re-proportioned radiator grille has been integrated into the overall front end design via a featured step in the front bumper and a softened, sloping header tank. The Silver Seraph's headlamps are separate from and adjacent to the radiator shell, retaining design links with the marque's lineage but incorporating complex refractor lighting. Front wing crowns are raised to be visible to the driver, aiding placement and manoeuvrability. The corner lamps are designed to reinforce the visual strength of the wings without interrupting the continuous flowing surfaces. Chrome details are employed to help the eye pass around the car in one continuous appraisal. The overall effect is a vehicle that looks compact and tailored whilst having great presence and sweeping lines. Step inside the Seraph and be transported into a world of sculptured waistrails, crowned fascia and console and softened, rounded seat silhouettes. The highly appointed, hand-crafted interior combines Connolly hide and Wilton carpets, smooth chrome switches, detailed stitching and the finest veneered woodwork. Advanced technology has been employed in creating a new seat design. Apart from improving front seat headroom and legroom, variable density seat foam provides anatomically correct levels of support to the shoulders, back, base of spine and thighs. The Silver Seraph may have taken a long time in coming. But the wait has not been in vain for the rich and richer-still who will no doubt credit Rolls-Royce for coming up with the Rolls-Royce of Rolls-Royces - that is until Rolls-Royce produces another Rolls-Royce! In another 20 years' time, perhaps? ANKARA, Turkey (AP) _ Parliament on Tuesday condemned a French legislative motion recognizing the 1915 killings of ethnic Armenians in Turkey as a genocide. ``It is extremely sad that such an unjust step that deliberately distorts historical facts and targets the Turkish nation has been taken,'' said a decree. Last week, France's National Assembly unanimously adopted a one-sentence motion stating: ``France publicly recognizes the Armenian genocide of 1915.'' The motion must go before the French Senate for approval. The decree said that if upheld by the Senate, the decision would harm Turkish-French relations. Turkey denies that the deaths of some 1.5 million Armenians between 1915 and 1923 constituted genocide, insisting that losses occurred on both sides as the result of a civil war. Turkey has protested the measure and threatened economic retaliation. (sf/djw)

Russian president denounces poor tax collection, market rises
Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with closing figures, TRIMS pvs. AP Photos planned By MAURA REYNOLDS Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ President Boris Yeltsin shook his finger at Russia's most powerful businessmen Tuesday and told them to do more to keep investors from pulling out of the country's wobbling financial markets. ``Foreign investors react very quickly,'' he told 10 of Russia's so-called ``oligarchs,'' the men who control the country's banking conglomerates. ``If you want foreign investors to keep their money here then you must tell your own investors not to pull out.'' Trying to halt the slide in Russia's financial markets, Yeltsin summoned government and business leaders to the Kremlin on Tuesday. Some of the government's responses appear to be working. After dropping 10 percent Monday, the stock market rebounded to close 12.2 percent higher Tuesday. Russia's inept tax collection system is at the heart of the country's current financial crisis, and Yeltsin also summoned top law enforcement officials to his office to demand better efforts. ``The tax situation has not improved, only worsened, especially in recent months,'' a gruff-sounding Yeltsin said in footage broadcast on national television. Investors' panic began last week, triggered by reverberations from the Asian financial crisis, a wave of workers' strikes, and a drop in world oil and gas prices. Russia is heavily dependent on oil and gas exports. The market has fallen 44 percent in the past month, and many analysts have feared the crisis could lead to a run on the fragile national currency, the ruble. However, the financial crisis has so far affected only investors and its effects have not yet reached ordinary Russians. A top Central Bank official acknowledged Tuesday that the bank has spent nearly dlrs 1 billion in reserves over the past month to support the ruble. Deputy Chairman Sergei Alexashenko said the bank still has dlrs 14.6 billion in reserves _ less than the market believes _ and has not had to intervene in recent days. The Russian stock market, whose performance was the world's best last year, is this year's worst-performing exchange. After climbing 98 percent last year, the market has slid 55 percent since the beginning of the year. Speculation is growing that Russia will need a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund or other lenders, similar to those arranged after Asia's financial crisis. But Yeltsin spokesman Sergei Yastrzhembsky said Russia would prefer to solve its own problems. ``The most important thing is to rely on our own resources and agree on joint responses by government and business and financial circles,'' he told a news briefing. In the past, Russia has had trouble meeting the stiff conditions imposed by foreign lenders. The IMF has delayed recent installments of a dlrs 10 billion loan to try to force Russian compliance with the terms, which include improved tax collection and limits on government spending. Moreover, the government doesn't want to worsen the appearance of crisis, and argues that Russia's underlying economic indicators remain steady: The economy grew a nominal 0.8 percent last year, and inflation is in the single digits. BC-Air France-Strike, 4th Ld-Writethru
Talks underway in Air France pilots' strike
EDS: LEADS with talks starting, ADDS color on World Cup in grafs 10-11, ADDS quote from Michel Platini in final graf AP Photos Planned By IAN PHILLIPS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Air France officials met with pilots' unions Tuesday in a bid to reach a truce over a wage dispute which has grounded planes for two days, and threatens to disrupt the World Cup. Seven members of Air France sat down with 26 union officials at the company's headquarters at Charles de Gaulle airport north of Paris. The talks, the first in five days, began at 4 p.m. (1400 GMT.) In an interview published Tuesday with the newspaper Le Parisien, Air France president Jean-Cyril Spinetta said ``there was still a lot of work to do'' to reach an agreement with the pilots, and suggested postponing talks until after the World Cup. ``Putting off the talks until the summer is absolutely conceivable,'' Spinetta was quoted as saying. He said the company was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike. The strike caused chaos for almost 100,000 passengers Monday, worries for fans and teams attending the June 10-July 12 World Cup and embarrassment for all. The walkout disrupted training for the French national team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. ``Yes, indeed a lot of players will arrive late because of the strike. It risks turning our whole day upside down,'' Jacquet said. At Charles de Gaulle airport, a shop employee sat alone Tuesday in an empty store stocked with World Cup insignia. Opposite was a newspaper stall where headlines read: ``World Cup held hostage,'' and ``World Cup in peril.'' Air France's main pilots' union called the 15-day action to protest against 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. Most of the 3,200 Air France pilots did not work Monday. Departure screens at airports around the nation flashed the list of canceled flights. Air France planes, many decorated with giant paintings of soccer players representing the 32 competing teams, sat idle. After walking 70 kilometers (43 miles) from Paris to Chartres over the weekend with 10,000 other youths on a pilgrimage, Ellen Kerry was trying to get to New York on an Air France flight. ``We only found out when we got in the taxi that there was a strike. We could have saved the money and walked,'' said Kerry, whose home is in Virginia. Sharon Borrege said she was trying to get to San Francisco following a trip to Paris she took after winning Air France tickets in a raffle at the San Francisco film festival. ``I'm angry. I was told the flight was canceled and to stand in line,'' said Borrege. ``I love France, but I now I see what they mean about France's reputation for strikes.'' Air France said there would be a slight improvement in traffic Tuesday, with 16-18 percent of long-haul flights taking off, compared to 10 percent Monday, and 32 percent of short- and medium-haul flights scheduled. In total, 44 more flights were scheduled Tuesday, compared to Monday. Air France, the World Cup's official carrier, is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France. The company has said if the strike continues it will probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations. Air France, which almost went bankrupt in 1993, has given no indication it is ready to withdraw a controversial plan to cut pilots' salaries in exchange for company shares. Pilots also want Air France to do away with salary cuts for starting pilots. The strike has left passengers stranded across France. The U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is sending the U.S. team on an American Airlines flight to Paris that connects to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses for all their travel plans in France. Former French player Michel Platini, co-president of the World Cup organizing committee, accused the pilots Tuesday of ``taking the country hostage.'' ``During a World Cup, there has to be solidarity,'' he said. ``Because this is the image of France at stake, not necessarily that of an airline.'' Nuclear politics: new twist in Israel-Palestinian quarrel
By LAURA KING Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ In the cavernous carpeted interior of Jerusalem's Al-Aqsa Mosque, the tone of the sermon was angry. Muslims are humiliated by the West, the mosque preacher told the faithful _ but that could change. ``The Pakistani nuclear bomb is the beginning of the resurgence of Islamic power,'' Sheik Hayyan Idrisi told the thousands of worshippers, who broke into a rhythmic chant of ``Allahu Akbar!'' _ God is great. The scene last week at Al-Aqsa, the holiest Islamic shrine in Jerusalem, illustrates how the nuclear rivalry of India and Pakistan has become a troubling new factor in the already volatile Israeli-Palestinian equation. Among Palestinians, the popular response to Pakistan's nuclear tests has been a sense of pan-Islamic pride _ and renewed resentment over Israel's undeclared but widely assumed possession of a large nuclear arsenal. Yasser Arafat's Palestinian Authority has refrained from either praising or criticizing Pakistan, the first Muslim nation openly to go nuclear. But senior Palestinian Cabinet minister Hanan Ashrawi said it was unfair for Pakistan to face international sanctions over its nuclear tests while Israel goes unscathed. ``Israel is the one rogue country in our part of the world that is above accountability ... when it comes to its own nuclear weapons,'' Ashrawi, the minister of higher education, said over the weekend. ``There is a very clear double standard.'' Israel has expressed concern about the accelerating arms race on the nearby Indian subcontinent, saying nuclear proliferation anywhere heightens the ability of states such as Iran and Iraq to develop nuclear weapons. Israel has friendly political and military dealings with India _ but no relations with Muslim Pakistan. Even so, Israel has carefully avoided publicly characterizing Pakistan's nuclear tests as any more worrisome than those of India, which set off the nuclear muscle-flexing. ``The point is not whether or not the nuclear power is in Islamic hands,'' said David Bar-Illan, a top aide to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, pointing to Israel's ties with Muslim countries like Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. But Pakistan apparently feared the worst from Israel. Israeli media reported Monday that Pakistan anxiously sought last-minute assurances from the United States that Israel did not intend to bomb its nuclear installations to prevent it from carrying out its test detonations. Bar-Illan denied the existence of any such Israeli plan, saying there was ``no intention whatsoever'' by Israel for an air strike against Pakistan. ``I am amazed that the government of Pakistan has yet to blame us for the earthquake in Afghanistan,'' he added acidly in an interview with Army radio. Israel, however, has not hesitated to use pre-emptive measures in the past. In June 1981, it bombed Iraq's French-built reactor outside Baghdad, saying Saddam Hussein was using it to produce weapons-grade material. If Arafat has withheld praise for Pakistan and its nuclear ambitions, there are no such constraints on his rival, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of the radical Islamic group Hamas. Yassin, who has been on an extended regional tour to raise money and drum up support for Hamas, was quoted by the Sudanese newspaper Al-Rai Al-Aam as calling Pakistan's nuclear status ``an asset to Arab and Muslim nations.'' That made banner headlines in Israel. Like Arafat, Arab governments have avoided any overt encouragement of Pakistan. The Muslim world's main group, the 55-nation Organization of the Islamic Conference, said Monday the world must urge India and Pakistan to quickly sign a non-aggression treaty to prevent regional instability. But as in the Palestinian lands, there is widespread Arab distaste for what is viewed as Western hypocrisy on the nuclear issue. Countries including Saudia Arabia, Lebanon and the United Arab Emirates have accused the United States of fueling the arms race by ignoring Israel's nuclear arsenal. Pakistan's bomb does help feed a sense of Muslim solidarity at a time of eroding faith in the United States as a Mideast mediator. Both Arafat and Yassin have been trying _ though with very different agendas _ to promote the notion of Arab solutions to the Palestinian question. Israel, though, bluntly warned Palestinians against assuming that anxieties about the changing nuclear picture will pressure it into making territorial concessions in exchange for peace. ``Whoever suggests an argument that means withdrawal from (the West Bank) because of the `nuclear threat' _ what they are suggesting is that we cut off our arms and legs because of a headache,'' said Cabinet secretary Dan Naveh. ``Any peace in our region will be one that will deter threats from both near and far.''

THE securities Commission (SC) has acquired new powers to fight insider and market manipulation following amendments to two securities industry laws - the Securities Industry Act 1983 (SIA) and the Securities Industry (Central Depository) Act 1991 (SICDA). SC's chairman Datuk Dr Mohd Munir Majid said the amendments address key regulatory principles of investor protection and market integrity. The SIA's definition of `insider' has been widened and the range of sanctions, including civil ones, against insider trading and market manipulation, expanded. Under the amendments any person who possesses inside information is not only prohibited from trading in relevant securities, but also from communicating that information. Further, insiders are no longer just defined as persons with fiduciary duties such as CEOs and directors. They now include all parties who possess information not generally available, for instance family members of a director, a body corporate who is associated with that director, or a substantial shareholder. The new sections of the SIA also allow the investing public the chance to wield the stick on an insider trader for losses or damages incurred. Under subsection 90A(1) of the SIA, a person who traded opposite an insider and suffered losses and damages would be able to institute civil action. Previously only the SC could take criminal action against insiders. A case may be brought against the offender even if he has not been charged, or proven guilty of any charge, under the criminal law. Munir stresses that the new provisions are aimed at enhancing transparency and corporate governance in line with the move towards disclosure-based regulation.

------ KINSHASA, Congo (AP) _ President Laurent Kabila has banned politicians who served under the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko from standing in future elections. Aides of Etienne Tshisekedi, Congo's foremost opposition leader, said the two men met on Saturday in the southern town of Lubumbashi after Kabila sent a plane to carry Tshisekedi to and from his home village in Congo's Eastern Kasai province. Tshisekedi told aides the two spoke about Congo's transition to democracy. It was not clear whether they would meet again. Tshisekedi's aides did not know if his detention had been discussed. Tshisekedi was arrested and banished in February and ordered to carry out work in the farm fields and organize food cultivation programs. ------ HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) _ Kariba Lake might reach its highest level since 1982 after years of poor inflows from the Zambezi River and heavy water diversion to meet the hydro-electric power needs of Zambia and Zimbabwe, says a spokesman for Kariba town publicity association. Once the largest man-made lake in the world, Kariba is one of the major tourist attractions for landlocked Zambia and Zimbabwe, and supports a sardine-fishing industry that provides cheap protein. ------ HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) _ A two-week campaign to inoculate 6 million Zimbabwean children against measles is in full swing despite resistance from traditional African religious groups who reject Western medication. The numerous ``Vapostori'' sect, whose white-robed followers gather at open spaces to sing and pray every weekend, warn adherents they face the wrath of spirits if they send their children to school or seek treatment from doctors schooled in European medicine. Despite chronic shortage of funds due to Zimbabwe's continuing economic crisis, the Ministry of Health and Child Welfare has allocated 2.7 million Zimbabwe dollars (U.S. dlrs 150,000) to a campaign aimed at eliminating measles, which often proves fatal to children who are malnourished. Children under age 14 are being inoculated as health workers visit schools and clinics. Officials are considering making it a punishable offense for parents to refuse their children inoculation. In remote areas, measles-infected children are still sometimes blinded when traditional healers tell parents to have them lie on their backs and stare into the midday sun to be cured. ------ KIGALI, Rwanda (AP) _ Zambian President Frederick Chiluba discussed bilateral and regional issues with his Rwandan counterpart, Pasteur Bizimungu, a presidential spokesman said. Spokesman Joseph Bideri said without elaborating that Chiluba and Bizimungu talked for three hours on Monday in Kigali. Relations between Kabila's government and neighboring countries that aided his rise to power _ including Rwanda and Uganda _ have since been strained because they are unhappy with his rule. Zambia also is among the countries enforcing an embargo against Burundi to pressure Pierre Buyoya, who took power over the central African country in a coup in July 1996, to negotiate with the majority Hutu opposition. Both Zambia and Rwanda have expressed doubt about the effectiveness of the sanctions. ------ CAPE TOWN, South Africa (AP) _ A trade imbalance between South Africa and Malawi is hurting the growth of relations between the two countries, President Nelson Mandela said Tuesday. Environmentalists demand Germany's retreat from nuclear energy
BONN, Germany (AP) _ The environment minister conceded Tuesday that Germany's nuclear energy industry is in a ``crisis of trust'' due to a safety scandal, but said Germany wouldn't heed environmentalists' calls to abandon nuclear energy. The disclosure that radiation in excess of allowed limits had been measured seeping from nuclear waste containers sent to processing plants in France and Britain has renewed debate about the industry's safety. Environmentalists who have long opposed the shipments renewed their calls for the nation to abandon nuclear energy. But Environment minister Angela Merkel said nuclear power remains a workable source until solar energy and other alternative sources become more viable. The ``crisis of trust must be overcome through openness,'' Merkel was quoted by the mass-circulation Bild newspaper as saying. Officials said the radiation has posed no threat to people, but the issue sparked an election-year scandal for Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government and finger-pointing about who was to blame. The government suspended waste shipments abroad last month after French and British authorities informed it that higher-than-permitted radiation had been measured from containers arriving at treatment plants from Germany. Merkel later said the industry had known of the problem for years but hadn't properly informed the ministry. The lapse has ``severely damaged the security culture that we've built up together in Germany,'' Merkel was quoted as saying. Merkel said that the radiation problem must be solved, better communication between France and Germany be arranged and all future lapses be properly reported. Greens and other opposition politicians claim Merkel has been too cozy with the industry and have called for her resignation. (im-cb)

On his seventh presidential tour of this northeastern state, Zedillo said the nation's ports are the vanguard of Mexico's economic recovery following the December 1994 crash, according to Notimex. In related news, the Navy added a new type of gunner to its Armada and launched it into the Gulf of Mexico as part of the Navy Day celebrations, which were headed by President Ernesto Zedillo and Navy Secretary Jose Ramon Lorenzo Franco. The 907-ton, 75-meter long gunner is the first of a program known as ``Holzinger 2000,'' and part of the nation's overall strategy for improving its Coast Guard service. THAILAND plans to extradite a member of the notorious Burmese drug warlord Khun Sa's gang to the United States following the Appeals Court's decision Monday to uphold an earlier verdict by a lower court. The Appeals Court ruled in favour of extraditing Chukiat Nimitphakphum, 71, also known as Na Chaikhui, for trafficking 1,000 to 2,000 kilogrammes of heroin to the US between 1987 to 1989. Thai police arrested Chukiat on Nov 27, 1995, in his home town of Mae Sai in Chiang Rai province. However, the accused has vehemently denied the US charges claiming he has never been to America or Mexico. Chukiat also denied being a chemist and an expert in heroin processing. Pol Gen Phiphop Biewkhaimuk testified in court against Chukiat saying he is an expert chemist who processed and distributed heroin in foreign countries. The police officer said he knew the man because he had arrested him once at the end of 1989 for possession of opium but the accused had escaped after being granted bail. Phiphop said besides the sale of drugs, Chukiat also dealt in war weapons and manufacturing of heroin for Khun Sa's army in Burma's Shan State.

Women may be called to arms for first time
ATHENS, Greece (AP) _ Fearing its declining birth rate will put it at a military disadvantage over rivals such as Turkey, Greece has for the first time decided to train its women in the arts of war. Under legislation submitted to Parliament late Monday, the Socialist government has proposed that women from 18 to 60 train and serve in civil defense units for four days a year. Taking more than a decade to draft, the ``Universal Defense Plan'' hopes to increase reserve forces by nearly 20 percent. It could also serve as a litmus test for a bigger female presence in the military, currently reserved for professional women soldiers. ``I do not disagree (with this new law)... I am under 60 years old, I will go... It is about equality,'' said Maria Anousaki said, a Socialist deputy. All men from 18 to 60 have to serve about two years in one of the three military branches. After completing their term, many men serve in the reserves. Greece currently has 168,000 men and women under arms, compared to 639,000 for Turkey. With a population of 10.2 million, Greece has a birth rate of zero, compared to a 1.7 increase for Turkey's more than 60 million people. The new law hopes to better organize reserve and national guard forces and enlist people who have not served into civil defense units. It also calls for women to participate in the communal protection of the country in peace and war, and during natural disasters or other catastrophes. lo-pq

BC-Sports-Cycling-Tour of Italy
Guerini wins grueling 17th stage, Pantani takes pink jersey
Eds: will be UPDATED
SELVA DI VAL GARDENA, Italy (AP) _ Marco Pantani, the best ``Giro'' climber, beat Alex Zuelle by more than four minutes in Tuesday's grueling 17th stage of the Tour of Italy ending in the Dolomite mountains and snatched the pink jersey of overall leader from his Swiss rival. Pantani placed second to fellow-Italian Giuseppe Guerini at the finish line in this resort of the Gardena valley and achieved his goal to wear the pink jersey for the first time in his career. The stage victory was the first ever by Guerini at Giro D'Italia. Pantani and Guerini broke away as the road climbed to the Fedaia pass _ the next to last in a stage including four passes - and Zuelle quickly slid behind. The leading duo widened a three-minute lead on the last mountain before the finish _ the Giro highest point at the 2,214-meter high Sella Pass - and Guerini won the two-way sprint at ease. Zuelle, an against-the-clock specialist who had beaten Pantani by more than three minutes in Sunday's time test at Trieste, finished 4:37 minutes behind Tuesday and fell to fourth overall, 1:01 minutes behind the new leader. Guerini completed the stage in six hours, 16 minutes, 58 seconds. Pantani, who trailed Zuelle by 3:48 at the start of the 17th stage, vaulted to first place in the standings 30 seconds ahead of Russian Pavel Tonkov, who finished fourth in the stage. Guerini moved to third, only one second behind Tonkov, a Giro winner in 1996. Pantani, 28, of the Marcatone Uno team, has the chance to strengthen his lead in the next two stages, including mountainous passes and uphill finishes. The bald-headed Italian was a champion of bad luck in 1995 when he suffered two consecutive bad spills and a broken leg. He was sidelined for the entire 1996 cycling season. Wednesday's stage of 115 kilometers (71.3 miles) ends at Alpe di Pampeago at 1,760 meters of altitude. (pv)

UNDER attack for doing little to help the poor, Prime Minister Chuan Leekpai has chosen to announce his government's performance on tackling the problems of the poor before announcing its achievement on economic missions. PM's Office Minister Supatra Masdit and PM's Deputy Secretary-General Amnuay Patise said Monday that Chuan might go on television on June 8 to announce the government's progress in solving the problems of the poor as well as answering critics' questions on social issues. Supatra said Chuan has yet to select Cabinet members to accompany him during the meet-the-public session. She said the government would schedule an announcement on its economic and political achievements later to mark the sixth month of the Chuan administration's term in office. The opposition, political action groups and some academics have attacked the Chuan government for devoting its efforts to solving only the problems of the rich. Amnuay, who chairs the government's coordination committee on the people's plight, said Chuan had asked him to compile a report on the progress of the government's efforts to solve the problems of the poor which had been carried out since Dec 30. Amnuay said he had submitted the report on May 22 and the report would be the basis for Chuan to explain to the public what the government has done. Supatra said government spokesman Akhapol Sorasuchart had proposed that Chuan go public to talk about the government's achievements in tackling the farmers' problems. According to Amnuay's report, the government has set up 21 national-level committees to deal with the farmers' problems. The report said a total of 444 cases of problems of farmers from 36 provinces had been put forward to the government. The problems were divided into four groups -- debt problems, forest encroachment, encroachment on public and Royal Household Bureau land and land expropriation for construction of dams. The report said the government has solved 75 cases or 16.89 per cent of all the problems. On the debt problems, the government has set up the national farmers' debt restructuring committee, headed by Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panitchpakdi. On the land rights problems of villagers accused of encroaching on forests, the national-level committees have assigned provincial-level committees to prove the rights. On the problem of villagers accused of encroaching on public and Royal Household Bureau land, the committees are in the process of proving the villagers' rights. On the problems of villagers affected by dam construction, the committees have set up clear-cut guidelines for paying compensation to the villagers.

Former Mexican banker Angel Isidoro Rodriguez Saez, alias ``El Divino,'' flew into Mexico City from Spain Monday following an extradition order for his role in bank fraud, the Federal Attorney General's Office (PGR) reported. Spanish authorities handed over Rodriguez Saez, whose alias means ``The Divine One,'' to their Mexican counterparts upon their arrival to the Benito Juarez International Airport. In accordance with Mexican law, Rodriguez Saez was reviewed by representatives from the National Human Rights Commission (CNDH) and medical examiners. According to various passengers on the flight, Rodriguez Saez was allowed liberty on the flight and was given no restrictions. And although there are four arrest warrants against him, Mexican authorities are not allowed to detain him because of injunctions that protect him from arrest and imprisonment. Former bank president Rodriguez Saez is accused of defrauding his bank, Banpais, out of millions of dollars. He is also charged with violating Mexico's law of credit institutions and with violations to the law of market values, which, officials say, gravely damaged the reputations of Mexican financial institutions and the federal treasury. At the helm of Grupo Financiero Banpais-Asemex, Rodriguez Saez carried out various fraudulent financial operations, authorities say, which included loaning himself money, making out loans to nonexistent companies and writing unguaranteed loans to his own front men. On May 22, 1998, Spain agreed to extradite Rodriguez Saez to Mexico in connection with his role in fraudulent money exchanges at Banpais-Asemex, which he headed until being found out by authorities and fleeing the country in 1995. At Mexico's behest, Spain detained Rodriguez Saez on July 29, 1996, beginning a 22-month extradition process. On April 20, 1998, Rodriguez Saez accepted Spanish authorities' decision to extradite and annulled all judicial resources that had prevented Spain from handing him over legally to Mexico.

Hingis beats Williams, Davenport beats Majoli at French Open
Eds: UPDATES with Williams, Davenport quotes By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Playing like the champion she is, Martina Hingis ousted Venus Williams from the French Open Tuesday, ending the American teenager's impressive run in Paris. Williams, who powered her way through the first four rounds, met her match in the world's No. 1 player and lost 6-3, 6-4 in the quarterfinals. ``I didn't play as well as I should have,'' Williams said later. ``I made too many errors. These things, I assure you, will be corrected.'' Of Hingis, she said, ``She's raising her game. Everyone else has to raise theirs, too.'' Also eliminated was defending champion Iva Majoli, who was beaten by No. 2 seed Lindsay Davenport, 6-1, 5-7, 6-3. Davenport joked later that she might be the most overlooked semifinalist. ``If I was a betting person or a journalist, I would overlook myself also,'' she said. ``I don't have a tag. I'm just an ordinary girl playing tennis and having success. That's a boring story.'' In a showdown billed worthy of a final, Hingis used her deft touch and court sense to wear down Williams. She almost always seemed in control, never looking off balance or rushed. Hingis raced to a 3-0 lead, but Williams broke in the fifth game for 3-2 as Hingis twice double-faulted. Hingis then broke right back for 4-2, and held on to win the set. In the second set, Williams had a chance to break Hingis for 2-0, racking up three break points. But Hingis won five straight points to take the game. In the crucial game of the set, Hingis broke Williams for 4-3 _ again on two double faults, this time by Williams. Also reaching the semifinals was Aranxta Sanchez Vicario, the No. 4 seed. The two-time champion from Spain lost a tiebreak in the second set but recovered to beat Patty Schnyder of Switzerland 6-2, 6-7 (5-7), 6-0. But another former champion, Thomas Muster, continued a disappointing year with a quarterfinal loss to No. 15 Felix Mantilla of Spain, 6-4, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3. The Austrian's ranking has dropped this past year from ninth to 22nd. Leading to the headline match, Hingis wasn't ready to call Williams a true rival. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she said. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam. ... I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth event on clay, responded diplomatically. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. Marat Safin, an 18-year-old qualifier, used his power to carve his way through the first three rounds. His tournament ended on Monday, however, in five tough sets. The French fans chanted wildly for his opponent, Frenchman Cedric Pioline. ``Allez Cedric!'' they yelled. But as the match wore on, there were growing chants of ``Ma-RAT! Ma-RAT!'' It was in tribute to the remarkable run by the young Russian playing his first Grand Slam event. He began the tournament ranked 116th in the world, but won't be there much longer. ``I think I can beat good players now,'' he said after Pioline won 7-5, 4-6, 6-7 (5-7), 6-4, 6-4. Safin's tournament started with three qualifying matches just to get into the main draw. Next up was Andre Agassi, in the midst of a strong comeback. Safin, however, had the answer to every problem Agassi presented. Then he ousted defending champion Gustavo Kuerten, ranked eighth in the world, in another five-setter. In the third round, Safin had a slightly easier time, needing only four sets to beat Daniel Vacek of the Czech Republic. That set up the match with Pioline. The 28-year-old Frenchman is erratic, but brilliant on occasion. He has reached the finals of Wimbledon and the U.S. Open, both times losing to Pete Sampras. Pioline has a reputation for choking. Although he has reached 12 singles finals in his career, he has captured only two titles. Safin, however, knew nothing of that. ``Nobody told me,'' he said. It didn't matter. This time it was Safin who unraveled. Pioline broke the Russian's serve three times, including once in the fifth set. That was enough.

LESIGNY, France _ Romario was dropped Tuesday from Brazil's World Cup team. Brazil's hero of the 1994 World Cup-winning team, Romario was not included because of an injury to his right calf muscle. Midfielder Emerson of Bundesliga club Bayer Leverkusen has was called in to replace Romario. Coach Mario Zagallo made a brief announcement at the team's training headquarters and then turned the press conference over to Romario, who was choked with tears and had trouble speaking. ``Things are happy for some, sadness for others. But now I think you're all sad as I am. I don't want to mean this is a farewell from soccer,'' he said. After breaking down again and covering his face with his hands, Romario said: ``I will now probably learn how to value other things.'' ___ LONDON (AP) _ Paul Gascoigne says he was drunk the night before he was cut from the England World Cup team and that he went berserk when coach Glenn Hoddle gave him the news. The 31-year-old midfielder, who was dropped Sunday by Hoddle for a lack of fitness, spoke about the incident in a story in Tuesday's Sun newspaper. Gascoigne, who has been criticized for his reported hard-drinking and smoking 20 cigarettes a day, said he left the bar in La Manga, Spain, had sandwiches in his room with teammate David Seaman, and then ``crashed out.'' Gascoigne also said he had been drinking beer during a Sunday golf game just hours before he met with Hoddle. Given the bad news, the star of England's 1990 World Cup team admitted he exploded. ``I completely lost it. I went mad, berserk. I lost my rag big time. I was shouting and swearing. I couldn't believe the injustice of it.'' ___ TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ Iran dropped two veteran strikers but added two rookies to its 22-man World Cup squad announced Tuesday. Coach Jalal Talebi sacked veteran strikers Alireza Emamifar and Alireza Akbarpour to make way for newcomers, 22-year-old striker Ali Latifi and 24-year-old midfielder Sattar Hamedani. Both rookies play for local club Bahman. Iran's three Bundesliga players, Ali Daei, Karim Bagheri and Khodadad Azizi, were included in the roster as was top goalkeeper Ahmadreza Abedzadeh. The team is in Croatia and will play a warmup against the country's national team Wednesday before leaving for France. ___ PARIS (AP) _ Saudi Arabia's Saeid Al Owairan, who scored the most spectacular goal of the last World Cup, will be frightening defenders at this one too. Especially now that he looks like Ronaldo. Al Owairan, whose weaving run through the Belgian defense earned the Saudis a 1-0 victory in Washington, now has the Ronaldo shaven-headed look. ``I shaved all my hair off myself a couple of days ago because it kept getting in my eyes,'' said the forward. The Saudis are in action on the third day of the World Cup June 12, when they face Denmark in Lens. ___ PARIS (AP) _ FIFA president Joao Havelange and World Cup co-organizer Michel Platini are used to having the media chasing them. This time it was Havelange and Platini who went to the media when they formally opened the World Cup press center Friday. ``It's a symbolic inauguration because it's the first of the 11 sites to open its doors officially,'' said World Cup co-president Platini. ``It is also the first symbol of five years work by the organizing committee.'' Havelange said his thoughts were with the other co-president, Fernand Sastre, who missed the ceremony because of ill health. ``I have known Fernand Sastre for 50 years,'' he said. ``As president of the French soccer federation he was responsible for organizing the European Championship in 1984 and that was the first move towards bringing the World Cup to France.'' ___ SEOUL, South Korea (AP) _ South Korea has opted for a mixture age and youth for its World Cup team, naming teenage rookie Lee Dong-hook alongside veteran striker Hwang Sun-hong on its 22-man roster. Hwang, 29, South Korea's most famous player, returned to the national team in April after a two-year break due to knee injury. He has since scored three goals in seven World Cup warmup matches. Forward Lee Dong-kook was the surprise selection. At 19, Lee became the youngest South Korean ever to join the national soccer team. Coach Cha Bum-keun said he was taking the rookie to France to train him as South Korea's next-generation star. ___ YAOUNDE, Cameroon (AP) _ Cameroon announced Tuesday its final World Cup squad, including some veterans, a new generation of attackers _ and few surprises. An expected omission from the team is Marc Vivien Foe, a standout midfielder with French champion Lens, who broke his leg in training in late May during the buildup to the World Cup. Unexplained in his absence, however, was Tockene Bertin, a defender expected to be a starter for the Indomitable Lions. Veteran goalkeeper Jacques Songo'o, who plays for Deportivo La Coruna in Spain, will anchor the team along with striker Francois Omam-Biyick of Sampdoria in Italy. Key young faces include attackers Alphonse Tchami of Hertha Berlin in Germany and Salomon Olembe of Nantes in France. ___ TOKYO (AP) _ One of the biggest names in Japanese soccer was dropped from the World Cup team Tuesday. Coach Takeshi Okada said Kazuyoshi Miura, 31, would have no chance to play, considering the team's ``pillar striker'' is 22-year-old Shoji Jo. The announcement at the team's training camp in Switzerland is a severe blow to Miura, the only Japanese to have ever played in Italy's Serie A. Ever since he was a teenager who went to Brazil to study soccer, Miura had his heart set on taking Japan to the World Cup. He was one of the key members of the Japanese team that failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup. He scored a spectacular 14 goals in qualifiers for this year's World Cup _ Japan's first. ___ MILAN, Italy (AP) _ Oliver Bierhoff, 1st Graf (scw)

AFTER several years in overdrive, the Malaysian motor industry has swerved into the slow lane since the third quarter of 1997. Reason: last year the industry received several blows which bridled the horsepower of the sector. `A series of new government guidelines limiting credit availability to car buyers and an increase of duties on foreign luxury cars coupled with a sluggish economy have caused the industry to suffer a significant drop in sales,' says Wong Si Si, analyst at Kuala Lumpur City Securities Sdn Bhd (KLCS). Analysts say car sales have dropped some 60% to 70% since November last year. The Malaysian Motor Traders Association forecasts sales for 1998 to be a paltry 160,000 cars compared with 1997's 404,800. Investors dumped their motor stocks on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE) which by the end of 1997 were trading at 70% to 85% below their January prices. Prices fell even more early this year, and analysts expect further price weakening. The main culprit, analysts say, was the difficulty in obtaining end-financing. In the 1998 Budget, the credit ceiling for hire purchase of passenger cars was reduced to 70% with repayment limited to five years. (Previously the credit limit was capped at 75% of the vehicle cost, with a maximum of eight years to repay the loan.) But in reality, the credit squeeze is much worse. As an analyst with a foreign research house points out, `The actual scenario is that many finance companies are only offering financing for up to 60% the cost of vehicles. Credit shortage will be a major obstacle to any sales increase.' Last month the government stepped in to help, by upping the credit limit to 85% for cars priced at RM40,000 and below. One reason for this measure, analysts say, is to cushion the national car industry and keep it from collapsing. `The main beneficiaries of this move are Perusahaan Otomobil Nasional Bhd (Proton) and its distributor Edaran Otomobil Nasional Bhd (EON) as well as Perusahaan Otomobil Kedua Sdn Bhd (Perodua) whose models are mostly priced within that range,' says the analyst. The result: EON's sales jumped 62.3% to 3,782 units in March this year from 2,330 units in February, helped along by a small discount on car prices. But this may only be a temporary reprieve. Wong of KLCS says the ruling will not change banks' prudence in approving loans. In March 1997 Bank Negara had directed all financial institutions to limit their lending to non-productive sectors of the economy, which includes the motor industry. Taking heed, banks and finance companies have adopted more stringent lending policies, resulting in lesser loans being given out for the purchase of cars. Foreign car sales are in a worse state: the 1998 Budget increased the already heavy duties they were under. Import duty on CBU (Completely Built Up) cars were raised from between 140% and 200% to between 140% and 300%, while duty on CKD (Completely Knocked Down) cars grew from 42% to a maximum of 80%. An analyst notes that on a year-to-year basis for March, car sales for Nissan has dropped 75%, Toyota by 79.5% and Mercedes Benz by 79.8%, as compared to sales of Proton and Perodua which have declined 73% and 52.4% respectively. A rising interest rate environment has also made it more expensive to buy cars. Hire purchase rates were raised on several occasions in 1997. From the initial 7% (as at August 1995), rates climbed to 8% in October 1997 and to 8.5% a month later. The last change took effect on Dec 1, when hire purchase rates were hiked up to 10%. The move, while needed to mop up excess liquidity in the financial system, would naturally affect car sales. `Despite the current and expected discounts on the national cars, this is partly offset by the buyer having to pay more interest,' says an analyst. Another variable in the motor industry is the Ringgit's value vis-a-vis the Japanese Yen, to which car manufacturers have a fairly large exposure. Although the Ringgit's depreciation of some 18% against the Yen since the beginning of the year should mean rising costs for car makers, assemblers and importers in Malaysia, the effects are not immediate as most motor companies have reasonably large stockpiles. `They have locked in their supply of raw materials when the Ringgit was stronger,' says one. Case in point: Tan Chong Motor Holdings Bhd (Tan Chong) has RM528 million in assembled motor vehicles, which analysts say would cover supply for the next six months. But should sales remain bleak, motor stocks on the KLSE will remain underweight. `The price earnings (PE) of the sector is undemanding at 5.9 times for financial year 1998 and reflects the earnings risk,' says the analyst. `Going by past trends the current drop (in sales) should bottom out by the end of 1998. In the last recession, car sales fell by 20%, but this time around it has fallen by 60%. Going by this, earnings of motor companies are expected to fall by 60-70% in financial year 1998.' Deteriorating profit margins have already begun to show up in financial year 1997 balance sheets. For instance, Tan Chong registered only a 2% increase in pre-tax profit - and this surpassed analysts' forecast. UMW Holdings' pre-tax profit rose only 4.6% while EON recorded a pre-tax drop of 4.9% in 1997 despite the increased sales of Proton cars. One company which bucked the trend was Cycle Carriage which reported a 24% rise in pre-tax profit for financial year 1997, but this came mainly from an increased contribution from its associate companies. Keeping costs low is now crucial for the survival of motor companies. `Companies will now have to sharpen their competitiveness. As players fight for a shrinking market share, innovative marketing strategies will aid in drawing buyers,' says Wong. As for stock-to-stock analysis, Proton is expected to do better than the rest because of its dominant role in the market. Proton has the cash -close to RM1.4 billion - but it also has short- and long-term liabilities. In addition, Proton plans to introduce a new model to replace the Iswara which will involve a capital expenditure of RM500 million. `The current cash pile has its uses, but much of it has been earmarked for other purposes, which means Proton may feel the heat of the current downturn,' says the analyst. For the current financial year, its factories are running at more than 50% under capacity. The Proton facility in Shah Alam alone is designed to produce 230,000 units a year. DRB-Hicom has another plant in Pekan, which produces Proton variants like the Satria and Wira Aeroback. For the current financial year, the group is looking at a combined production of 110,000 units. In the case of EON, analysts believe that it has the ability to withstand the huge drop in earnings. Explains Wong, `Unlike other automotive counters, EON solely handles the distribution and the sales of Proton cars, and does not dabble in vehicle assembly. This means that overheads may be easier to control, and it is not a victim of the vagaries of currency fluctuations.' The company is also diversified but most of its operations are bleeding due to the downturn. EON is exposed to the delicate financial sector - through subsidiary EON Bank and 30% associate, Leong and Co - which analysts say will slow down its profits. EON's other interests are in Mobikom and Singapore-based CCL Group, both of which, say analysts, are not doing well. As these are testing times for the luxury car market, Cycle Carriage is expected to be the worst hit. Even though CC has low gearing -its net debt-to-equity ratio is minimal at 0.5% for financial year 1996 -it has only RM2 million in cash and equivalents at the end of financial year 1996. `Its relatively weak cash position as compared to other motor stocks makes it an unattractive investment as sales have dropped by more than 50%,' says the analyst. `In comparison, Tan Chong has a cash hoard of RM310.5 million as at the end of financial year 1996, Oriental Holdings, RM793 million, and UMW, RM267.8 million.' Help from an associate company, the CCI Group Properties, is also not expected to be much. While CCI was the main profit contributor to CC's bottom line in financial year 1997, analysts say its core activities - property development in Singapore and property investment in Malaysia - are not doing well because of a slump in property prices. `The property market in Singapore has softened, with condominium prices having fallen by more than 20%. In fact we expect progress billing to be delayed and interest income to fall in the face of slower sales and tough operating environment,' adds the analyst. CC recently shut down its plant for three months beginning in April and analysts wonder what's in store. `Will CC have to retrench?' asks one. Tan Chong is more favoured by analysts. `Tan Chong's cash reserves of over RM300 million coupled with its low net debt-to-equity ratio, which stood at 1.1% in 1996, makes the company cash rich,' explains Wong. `It will therefore be able to withstand the slowdown in motor sales.' The company, he adds, emerged unscathed from the last recession and `with its experienced management team, we believe that Tan Chong will do the same this time around.' Another plus point for the company is the postponement of its listing. `This will conserve its cash pile as Tan Chong will not need to make the cash repayment of RM0.70 per share which will total RM470.4 million on the demerger,' says Wong. But with the debut of the country's national truck this year, Hicom-MTB will give Nissan's commercial vehicles a run for its money. Says Wong, `As these vehicles will be sold at RM7,000 to RM9,000 less than other non-national commercial trucks, we anticipate that Hicom-MTB will manage to gain top spot for the commercial vehicle segment, taking over Nissan's position which it has held for two years running.' As for UMW Holdings Bhd, analysts believe that its exposure to the national car segment through Perodua may insulate it from a severe drop in sales of higher-end vehicles. UMW has a 38% interest in Perodua and for financial year 1997, Perodua contributed 30.5% to UMW's pre-tax profit. Toyota's commercial vehicle segment would face greater challenges in regaining its number one spot from Nissan in 1998, with the emergence of the national truck. `It is likely that UMW Toyota will sell only an average of 200 units of commercial vehicles a month, translating into a fall of 76.7% on a year-to-year basis,' says an analyst. Analysts note that UMW has learnt from the 1986 recession when it almost folded. `This time around they are relying less on debt and can draw on the strength of an experienced management team,' says an analyst. `UMW had a gearing ratio of 56.3% as at the end of financial year 1996, while its cash and cash equivalents stood at RM267.8 million. We believe UMW may emerge from the slump in sales better than the last recession.'

NOBODY knows for sure when the next general election will be called. But some politicians have begun actively campaigning, especially in the Northeast. A few weeks after ex-premier Chavalit Yongchaiyudh's visit to northeastern provinces, his wife Khunying Phankrua Yongchaiyudh donated Bt200,000 from the New Aspiration Party pocket to the Lunch for the Poor Fund. ENVIRONMENTALLY-FRIENDLY Bangkok Governor Bhichit Rattakul continues to launch new projects to make the city a better place to live. DATUK Adzmi Abdul Wahab, 56, managing director of Edaran Otomobil Malaysia (EON), would have been equally at home in the civil service as he is in the automobile industry. Back in 1967, this unassuming man joined the Malaysian Administrative and Diplomatic Service and worked in various capacities in the Ministry of Finance, Pahang Tenggara Development Authority and the Prime Minister's Department. Fifteen years later, he left to become HICOM's manager of corporate planning. In 1985, he joined Proton where he was head of the administrative and finance division, before going on to EON. In February 1992, Adzmi, who has a BA (Hons) degree from Universiti Malaya and an MBA from the University of Southern California, was appointed to the board of EON. He was appointed as managing director in November that year. In a recent interview with Investors Digest, Adzmi discusses EON's plans and strategies in meeting the challenges of today and the future. Excerpts: On the position of EON in the 21st Century when the WTO liberalisation regulations come into effect We are taking measures to ensure that EON will be in a good position to compete, come 2003, by improving efficiency and cutting cost. This year, we plan to cut costs by 30% and improve productivity. Our average sales growth since 1985 has been at the rate of 18.5%, higher than the national average for the same period. Besides, we are in a position to compete as we have the largest network of sales and after-sales service in the country. The car market in the 21st Century would depend a lot on the economic conditions. The current situation is temporary. Some say recovery is expected within the next two years. How fast we recover depends on how the entire economy responds and what policies are adopted by the Government. Malaysia will emerge stronger after this economic slowdown. Companies will be more lean. So we expect the demand of cars to continue rising over the long term. We will innovate and go for strong AP (advertising and promotions) to continue to strengthen our sales and after-sales services to ensure success. On the reasons for not combining EON and USPD service centres We have these two outfits separated because this will foster competition. And this will keep us on our toes as well. USPD concentrates on sporty cars while we do more sedans. There is no possibility of a merger right now. But of course, anything is possible in the future. On the training and development of its sales personnel We are conducting courses in salesmanship and customer relations. We are placing more emphasis now on customer satisfaction. But we have experienced tough times in 1985, 1986 and 1987 when we had to go from house to house to look for customers. Now we just have to retrain our people and go to the customers more aggressively. On Motoria (EON's reconditioned and used car outfit) Motoria's concept of autofair has been a success. In the Klang Valley, we have organised fairs in Subang. We have also held similar fairs in Penang and Alor Star. The idea is to introduce branded used cars stressing on quality. Most cars we refurbish are given a one-year warranty. However, we are not totally concentrating on used cars because that market is still dominated by the Japanese makes, which are cheaper. On the correlation between new and used car markets There is difficulty in acquiring financing for used cars. We have proposed to the Government to relax financing for used cars as well since the used car mart correlates with the brand new market. About 60% of the people who buy new cars trade in their old ones. If people can't get good prices, then they may be reluctant to sell their cars and this will make it difficult for us to market new cars.

A REDUCTION of petrol prices in the world market and a stronger baht have led to a cut in domestic diesel and petrol prices by Bt0.70 and Bt0.30 a litre respectively, effective from Tuesday. This is the first time that private oil companies, led by Esso (Thailand), have brought down the price instead of the Petroleum Authority of Thailand. The retail petrol price will be Bt12.31 per litre for octane 95 petrol; Bt11.67 a litre for octane 91 petrol; Bt11.25 a litre for octane 87 petrol; and Bt8.70 a litre for diesel. Metta Bunteungsuk, deputy secretary-general of the National Energy Policy Office (Nepo), said the petrol price reduction was a result of a weakening of worldwide petrol prices by US$3 per barrel to $18.50 and a reduction in the price of diesel by $3.50 a barrel to $18.50 a barrel. Also, the baht's value in May strengthened by around Bt1 per US dollar. Therefore, the total cost of petrol and diesel has been reduced by Bt0.80 a litre and Bt0.95 a litre, respectively. Metta said the big drop in petrol prices is due to fierce competition in the wholesale petrol market. An executive vice president of Mobil Oil Co, Lance E Johnson, said Monday the current world crude oil overhang, which has increased as a result of the Asian economic crisis, will likely persist through to 2000. ''The likely situation is some deferrals of capacity expansions and moderate Opec control resulting in a continuation of the status quo, at least in the near term, with prices remaining in the $14 to $16 per barrel range,'' Johnson said. Although Mobil still expects Asian oil demand to grow at almost twice the rate of the rest of the world, it has lowered its estimate of annual demand growth in Asia over the next five years from 4 per cent to 2.7 per cent, or 1.4 million barrels per day in 2002 less than it forecast eight months ago, he said. Mobil currently estimates Asian oil demand will grow to 22.3 million b/d in 2002, from 19.5 million b/d in 1997. Even noting that the recent Asian economic downturn is just a temporary pause in long term demand growth, Johnson insisted price weakness will likely continue unless significantly more production comes off the market.

Forgotten bombing returns to haunt Botha
With BC-South Africa-Botha Trial By PAUL HARRIS Associated Press Writer
GEORGE, South Africa (AP) _ On Tuesday, the Aug. 31, 1988, bombing of the South African Council of Churches came back to haunt former President P.W. Botha. Standing a few feet away from Botha, 82, ex-security guard Welcome Ntumba described the night the bomb tore through the foyer of the building. ``I heard something, a very big noise like lightning,'' he said, speaking in Zulu through an interpretor. ``I just saw the walls collapsing and the electricity went off.'' A former national police chief has told the Truth and Reconciliation Commission that Botha authorized the bombing of Khotso House, where the church's offices were located. The blast sent Ntumba plummeting into the basement. He escaped almost unharmed. No one was killed and only a handful of people were injured in the blast. Botha, wearing a dark suit, shifted in his seat to look directly at Ntumba as the small, stocky black man told how he was pulled from the rubble by passersby and taken to a hospital. The Rev. Peter Storey, a former head of South Africa's Methodist Church, arrived at Khotso House after the blast and described to the court a scene of fallen masonry, shattered glass and smoldering fires. ``We were met by a scene out of hell,'' he recalled. Botha has denied he authorized the bombing. Botha is on trial for refusing to appear before the Truth Commission, which is investigating apartheid-era human rights abuses. (ph-aos)

Putting pragmatism behind the wheel, INVESTOR DIGEST xfdws PUTTING-PRAGMATISM sked Emerging Markets Datafile May 16, 1998 INVESTOR DIGEST ENGLISH COPYRIGHT 1998 BY WORLDSOURCES, INC., A JOINT VENTURE OF FDCH, INC.
