TIMES have certainly altered the clear and distinct path Malaysia's automobile industry used to cruise on. The days when the industry's sales per month effortlessly touched five figures is a far cry from its present predicament, where monthly sales have dwindled to below 10,000 units. Certainly the spell when buyers of certain marques and models had to wait for more than six months to take delivery of their cars, is past. Nowadays, car salesmen will be grateful if they can sell just one car a month, with virtually all promising instant delivery of the vehicles. Apparently, the regional currency and economic woes have affected the motor industry. Credit tightening measures on the hire purchase financing of cars have put a further damper on sales. The industry, which had an average growth rate of 14.5% from 1985 onwards, gazes at gloomy prospects in 1998. Total industry volume, including passenger cars, commercial and 4X4 vehicles, stood at 404,837 units in 1997. However, official statistics released by the Malaysian Motor Traders Association (MMTA) indicate that only 160,000 units will be sold in 1998. This means that 60% of motor vehicle sales are going to be wiped out of the market this year. The used-car market, which faces even more stringent conditions like tighter financing terms, has also suffered a blow, shedding more than 30% of its value since July 1997. Therefore, the industry's powers-that-be have been scurrying around to maintain, if not increase, their market presence. Adoption of savvy marketing strategies have become more critical than ever to push sales in adverse economic conditions. Edaran Otomobil Nasional (EON), which markets and distributes Proton Iswara, Wira (sedan) and the Perdana range, was one of the first to embark on an advertising and promotions (AP) blitz. `We have taken various measures to stimulate demand. We have gone through aggressive advertising, including dropping the Wira on the North Pole during the North Pole Expedition recently. This is part of our strategy to show how strong our cars are. The car could start after it reached the ground even in that freezing temperature,' says the managing director of EON, Datuk Adzmi Abdul Wahab. But more importantly, the company came up with a bold pricing strategy for the Iswara 1.3S Aeroback. Commencing April 1, 1998, the model was offered for sale at RM29,683 without accessories, but inclusive of excise duty, sales tax and air-conditioner. `This scheme is aimed at making it more affordable for customers to buy the Iswara. In an economic slowdown, people have less money. So, we decided to go with the no-frills version by attaching a RM29,000 price tag. In the past they had to take the six standard accessories, but now they have a choice,' says Adzmi. The strategy seems to have paid off handsomely. `Within a month, we managed to increase the sales of Iswara Aeroback,' says Adzmi. `It exceeded 3,000 units in April, which is 192% more than the previous month.' He finds that rather ironic. When the industry was on the roll, EON was selling more of the Wira range, which was of a higher price. `But now, due to the downturn, we can see a more pronounced demand for the lower range models. We expect to sell more Iswaras this year.' He believes the overwhelming response to the new scheme is no fluke and expects the brisk sales to continue. `Now is the best time for buyers to purchase cars because I don't see car prices staying low for long,' says Adzmi. `This is because of the pressure on cost generated by the weakening of the Ringgit. The duration of our current offer depends on the manufacturer, DRB-Hicom. As long as it continues to give the cars at that price, we will continue with the scheme. But the cost pressure is there - with the fluctuating Ringgit and rising prices of auto components. Although Proton is still maintaining its current prices, we don't know how long this will last.' The no-frills scheme has another objective. Adzmi points out that the slashed prices for Iswara will bring more customers to the showrooms, and he hopes that some of the visitors will also be tempted to buy the other Proton cars, perhaps the more expensive ones. Another national car has adopted the same strategy as well. Perusahaan Otomobil Kedua Sdn Bhd (Perodua), which manufactures the Kancil range, knocked down the price of the EXB model to below RM20,000, to bolster sales. The 659 cc, four-speed, manual model is sold at RM19,980. The limited edition model, however, comes without an air-conditioner, and accessories like alarm, central lock, radio and cassette player, glove box, dashboard tray, body side protector strap and wheel-caps. Does EON view this as a threat? `I don't think so because they are in a different segment at the range of RM20,000. Ours, on the other hand, is at the price range of RM29,000 and above, with higher cylinders. And at that price, there's good value for money,' says Adzmi. The non-national carmakers, however, do not have the luxury of slashing prices. Says an executive from a non-national car franchise-holder, `We can't do that. We can't simply cut prices because our costs, in the form of duties, are high. Besides, banks are charging very high interest rates on loans. A lot has been given to the national cars, but nothing much for us.' He estimates that most car companies at present would have at least 10 months' stockpile of unsold cars. `And that's January's estimate. Unsold stocks would have increased to a higher level by now. In fact before the crisis set in, the whole non-national passenger car segment could sell almost 20,000 to 30,000 units per month, but now we can chalk up maybe 6,000 units.' So, what can the non-national car franchisees do in the wake of this slowdown? `Well, we are doing our best,' says a non-national car company executive who requested anonymity. `The worst of the lot are companies selling luxury cars. At the moment, they are implementing some cost- cutting measures. In terms of layoffs, we are sending back only the foreigners. But we are not retrenching locals because if we do that, it is going to be very difficult to get them back when the good times return. That's why what Cycle Carriage did is laudable.' Cycle Carriage Bintang Bhd, which is Malaysia's sole distributor of the upmarket Mercedes Benz, adopted an innovative scheme to reduce the burden on the company as well as its workers when it temporarily shut down its production plant due to the slowdown. Instead of retrenching its 435 production workers, the company requested them to go on three months' paid leave from April 1 at 75% of their basic salary, and a RM50 monthly attendance allowance. The workers on leave are permitted to seek non- permanent employment during this period to supplement their income. The scheme earned kudos from various quarters, including Human Resources Minister Datuk Lim Ah Lek. Average sales in the passenger car industry for the last five years were 218,400 units. There has been a steady increase in sales since 1987, after the mid-80s economic crisis, peaking at 307,907 units last year. The gloomy forecast for 1998 can be attributed to the loss of consumer confidence and uncertainty caused by some macroeconomic factors, namely the weakening of the Ringgit, which shed 43% against the US dollar and 36% against the Yen, compared to July 1997. The fall of the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE) and the downward revision of the 1998 gross domestic product (GDP) from 7% to 2-3% also played a part. Besides, funds for end-financing has been reduced because of the squeeze on credit growth from 25% in 1997 to 15% in 1998. The higher hire-purchase interest rates, from 6.5% in July 1997 to more than 10% at present, has also hit the market badly. Meanwhile, the substantially steeper duties for bigger capacity passenger cars, especially for completely-built-up (CBU) models, have further dampened enthusiasm. Sales figures for the first three months of this year weren't encouraging. Total passenger car sales for January, February and March were 9,775 units, 5,641 units and 7,350 units respectively. The February figures were probably the lowest monthly sales recorded in recent years. If a ballpark estimation were to be made from the average of the first three months - 7,589 units - the volume of sales is insufficient to reach the 1998 forecast of 130,000 units. `To revive the car market, we believe in focusing on and talking about the positive aspects to stimulate sminimum downpayment was increased to 30%. However, following recommendations from the National Economic Council (NEAC), prospective buyers are now allowed to secure up to 85% credit from finance companies when purchasing new cars below RM40,000. Besides that, EON announced on April 23 that all loans for all new Proton cars taken from its panel of finance companies will enjoy an interest rate of 9.5%, compared with the 10% previously. However, these measures have caused concern among certain quarters in the industry. Many feared that the moves would attract unscrupulous syndicates due to the easy access to loans. These syndicates, according to industry observers, could purchase a substantial number of cars, and then take them apart to illegally sell their components. In the final stage, the advocates of the scam will report the car missing or damaged, and make claims from their insurance companies. At the end of the day, the finance and insurance companies as well as genuine prospective buyers, will lose out. But Adzmi argues that the screening process carried out by finance companies is tighter now. `Not every Tom, Dick and Harry can get car loans so easily, especially these days,' he says. `Anyhow, there may be one or two cases - it is not rampant.' The benefits of increased loans will not trickle down to the non- national car segment. `The increase in hire-purchase financing to up to 85% for cars below RM40,000 will be a boon for the national cars. But for the non-national segment, virtually none of them are at that price. The Government should consider the plight of this segment as well because they are also hit by the economic slowdown,' says an analyst. In terms of passenger car market share, the national car segment continues to hold the fort (see table). The Proton range of cars, distributed by EON continues to be the leader, accounting for half the market share in 1996, dropping to 45.8% in 1997. In fact, Proton's slice of the automotive cake has been dropping since it peaked at 74.1% in 1993. This is because part of the market since then is shared with Kancil and the Proton range of cars distributed by EON's sister company, Usahasama Proton-DRB (USPD). USPD, which distributes the Wira Aeroback, the Satria, the Putra and the Tiara, commanded 18.1% and 13.8% of the market in 1997 and 1996, respectively, while the Kancil conquered 18.9% and 17% of the market in 1997 and 1996, respectively. In the non-national segment, Honda leads the pack, dominating 6.4% and 6.6% of the car market in 1997 and 1996. Toyota comes in second, claiming 3% and 3.8% of the pie in 1997 and 1996. Nissan held 2.7% and 2.5% of the market share in 1997 and 1996. In the Continental car segment, Mercedes Benz has apparently quashed traditional rival BMW, holding 1.4% and 1.6% of the respective segments in 1997 and 1996. BMW managed to maintain 0.9% for both years. While waiting for the local market to recover, the national carmakers are trying to spread their wings overseas. Perodua is currently awaiting the results of a feasibility study for the setting up of left-hand drive assembly operations in Egypt, its biggest market in West Asia. The Kancil is already exported to Brunei, Malta, Mauritius, Cyprus, Fiji, Sri Lanka, the United Kingdom, Comoros Island and Egypt and has been signed up for distribution in Lebanon and Jordan. The DRB-Hicom group, manufacturers of the Proton range, is expecting to export at least 52,000 units in the fiscal year ending March 31, 1999. The United Kingdom, Germany and Australia will continue to be the group's main export markets.

The beginning is nigh: host players bid farewell to family
By RAF CASERT Associated Press Writer
CLAIREFONTAINE, France (AP) _ One thing is clear when even the host players bid farewell to their wives and kids and promise to stay away as long as possible _ the World Cup is upon us. Coming off three final days with family and friends, the French players gathered at their castle-training camp in the lush Rambouillet woods outside Paris Tuesday, hopefully to stay together until the July 12 final. ``Now the family can sleep, eat, and not have any worries,'' said French star Zinedine Zidane, who spent the long Pentecost weekend going for walks with his wife and child. Some of the 22 players were expected to arrive late because of the Air France strike, but that was only a small worry at Clairfontaine castle. Right from the start Tuesday the place was buzzing with rumors how coach Aime Jacquet might reshuffle his team ahead of the June 12 match against South Africa in Marseille. Denmark and Saudi Arabia complete Group C. ``I know the starting 11, but it is not impossible to change,'' he said, highlighting how two preparation games in Morocco had raised as many questions as solved them. France is a favorite to make at least the tournament's final four and Jacquet has been working hard on physical preparations over the past week to get everyone in top shape. WITHOUT an e-mail address, you will lose your friends and without a website you will lose your business, Cisco Systems stated emphatically at a seminar held last week in Bangkok, which drew more than 800 participants. Even though the Internet has gained popularity in Thailand some companies and organisations are still unaware of what it means to their business. San Francisco-based Cisco, the world's largest Internet network maker, has decided to educate the market, in anticipation that more people would use the system and thereby boost sales. The company made its intentions clear at the beginning of the seminar. ''Many people have asked me what Cisco will get from holding this free seminar. We are not selling anything to you. We want you to use the Internet and we can sell to ISPs (Internet Service Providers),'' Gene Deutsche, a Cisco lecturer on the Internet and networking systems, said. Internet webpages could become an important commercial tool by helping to sell products and services. However, many entrepreneurs and business executives are still hesitant to do business in cyberspace. A survey held last year by Forrester Research on why companies use the Internet for commerce, found that 67 per cent said they wanted to be technology leaders. About 27 per cent said they used the Internet because their buyers were on-line, while 13 per cent said they wanted to keep up with the competition. Sixty-three companies interviewed. In 1997, the average organisation generated 18 per cent of its revenue through the Internet while the rest came from phone and fax. However, by the year 2000, the Internet can expect to be generating about 42 per cent of the total income. ''More and more people are realising the need to get into the Internet,'' Deutsche said. The media is making an impact on all businesses. As more is learned about globalisation, Thai firms cannot help but join the Internet trend. ''Think of it this way: now, people have e-mail addresses on their business cards. What happens if you do not have one? Companies want to know your products, the first place they will check is the website, if you do not have one, you will lose business,'' Deutsche said. Even other communications firms, like telephone companies, have not been able to avoid the impact of the Internet. Their way of surviving is to be a part of the Internet, said Vorawat Pattrayanond, managing director of Cisco Thailand. ''More data will go through networks that once only served voice communication. That's why telephone companies want to become an Internet Service Provider,'' Vorawat said. He cited the success of Amazon.com, the world's largest bookstore with more than two million titles, as a reflection of globalisation. ''Our Duangkamol bookstores or any bookstores in Thailand are facing competitors like Amazon.com who is doing business from abroad through the Internet,'' Vorawat said. He said Thai companies will have to look at expenditure on information technology in a different way. ''In the 1980s, expenditure on information technology facilities was considered a waste. However, in the 1990s, it is regarded as a productivity tool and from the year 2000 it will be a tool for competitive advantage,'' Vorawat said.

NO doubt these are uncertain times, but anyone in the market for new cars can hardly have it better: 1998 is shaping up to be a bumper year for the introduction of new models in Malaysia. Featured here are some of the more significant models headed our way - barring hitches such as runaway home market demand resulting in late production starts for Asian specifications, pricing negotiations falling through between agents and their principals, or changed market conditions taking a toll on launch intentions. Others are models newly introduced in the country. Certainly, those with Ringgit to spare this year will be spoilt for choice. ROLLS-ROYCE: The ultimate dream car NEXT Car Sdn Bhd, the Rolls-Royce and Bentley distributor, hopes to sell six to eight units of the Rolls Royce Silver Seraph(1), the latest model of Rolls-Royce in 18 years, and only the ninth in the marque's 90-year history. Replacing the Spur, the Silver Seraph was launched at the Geneva Motor Show in March. It costs about RM3.4 million on the road in Malaysia. AUDI has class to spare AUDI variants in Malaysia, such as the A4 and A6 models, take on both Mercedes and BMW in the medium-sized executive market. The A6 2.6E V6(2), especially, has all the right stuff. Select a smart colour combination and you'll have a car that looks as classy as its more expensive rivals. Following Audi's engineering tradition, the A6 2.6E V6 is mounted longitudinally and drives the front wheels through a tiptronic automatic transmission. Its engine is smooth and sophisticated although, when compared to its rivals' powerplants, is slightly rough-edged and hesitant in producing its power. Ssangyong(3) has come to your rescue by skilfully repackaging the old Mercedes Benz W124 E-class platform and mechanicals and turning it into their flagship model, the Chairman, with overt styling cues that copy the German marque's large S-class. Already a runaway success in South Korea, the Chairman could be a winner here too if prices are kept in check. Expect it around year-end, if domestic demand reach satisfactory levels by then. THE regal Range Rover BILLED as a `powerful off-road vehicle with regal presence on or off the pavement,' the Range Rover(4) shares its `Best of the Best' distinction with other accoutrements of high living, such as Cartier jewellery and Rolex watches. `When you specialise in four-wheel drives for 50 years as only Land Rover has, winning honours year after year takes on added significance,' says the president of Land Rover. `They reinforce a process of steady refinement in the breed that keeps us at the front of the pack.' Although staying ahead has been getting harder for Range Rover with the arrival of rivals like the Mercedes-Benz ML430 and Lexus LX 470, the Solihull flagship remains a strong seller in the luxury SUV (support utilities vehicle) sector. BMW mirrors perfection IF the economy recovers, BMW(5) lovers will get to see the new 3 series in four-door format towards the last quarter of the year. Larger, roomier and more refined than the current model, the new sedan is expected to preserve the 3's nimble handling in spite of its size. In the meantime, BMW distributor Auto Bavaria Sdn Bhd is busy promoting the latest in the 5 series, which many regard as the most complete and well-sorted sport-luxury sedan range in the world. Be it the entry-level 150bhp 5201 or the upcoming 400bhp 4.8 litre V8 M5 flagship, every 5 Series car feels like perfection, with driveability, quality and desirability in equal portions. THE Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) will allow foreign investors to invest in the Joint Development Area (JDA) gas pipeline project worth more than US$1.2 billion in a bid to reduce the huge investment burden. Piti Yimprasert, president of PTT Gas, said PTT plans to seek foreign partners for joint investment in the JDA gas pipeline project, including JDA-Songkhla, JDA-Erawan II and the Rayong-Bang Pakong pipeline installation. Since the investment is so large, PTT needs support from strategic partners to proceed with the project. Due to the budget deficit, the government has allowed state enterprises to conduct construction under a build-own-transfer system to reduce the investment from public sector. PTT in late April signed a purchasing agreement for 640 million cubic feet per day (MMscf/d) of natural gas from JDA operators to be delivered to Thailand in late 2001-2002. However, PTT will negotiate with Malaysian authorities to postpone the natural gas delivery date from 2002 to a few years later to keep the project in line with the economic situation, he added. ''We prefer to postpone gas delivery date by around two years to wait for economic recovery. Besides, once the gas pipeline from Burma to the country is installed, Burma will be able to supply additional natural gas to Thailand.'' Conducting a joint investment project worth more than Bt5 billion between private and public sector requires approval by a special committee of representatives from ten ministries based on State Enterprises Act. A public hearing is also required. The joint investment approval procedure takes around two years. According to Piti, PTT will wholly invest in the Ratchaburi-Wang Noi gas pipeline project, worth Bt12 billion, although PTT has been suffering from a budget shortage. The contractor bidding is expected to be completed by the end of this year to be in line with gas supplied from the Yetagun gasfield in the year 2000. ''The Ratchaburi-Wang Noi project is necessary so that the country can secure an energy supply system since most of gas pipelines are located in the Gulf of Thailand area.'' To proceed with the project, PTT will cut the budget of some projects that do not urgently need investment capital. Some portion of the budget will be allocated from the sale of PTT Exploration Production Plc's shares and the investment budget of fiscal 1999, he added. The Cabinet recently granted investment worth approximately Bt1.5 billion to lay the pipeline of the Pailin and Benchamas gas field projects to prepare for gas delivery in 1999. According to studies by several oil companies on the natural gas business, the natural gas sector has had the least impact from the regional economic crisis. Although gas consumption in the industrial sector this year has dropped by around 10 per cent, the slack has been taken up by new customers in the power generation business. The number of clients is expected to reach 137, as against last year's 117. Anon Sirisaengtaksin, senior vice president of PTT's natural gas marketing transmission, said natural gas demand is expected to jump to 2,200 MMscf/d in 1999-2000, compared to 1,600 MMscf/d at present. The rise will come from several power generation projects. In addition, government policy to use natural gas in the South Bangkok Power Plant and Bangpakong Power Plant, which have a combined capacity of more than 3,000 megawatts, will help increase gas consumption.

AFTER firming to a high of RM2209/MT due to the Ringgit weakening to 3.8000 level, the market resumed a wary stance as players awaited Indonesia's next step on its palm export ban. A few Indonesian-linked companies then made a pre-emptive move by selling the forward products market in anticipation of the lifting of the export ban, causing the KLCE to correct downwards to a low of RM2135/MT. However, prices quickly recovered, as the supply situation in Malaysia remained tight with South Physical Crude against KLCE widening to RM50. Despite a stronger Ringgit at about 3.6500, prices rallied to above RM2200/MT. Even with confirmation of Indonesia lifting the export ban by April 22 and imposing a 40% and 35% export duty on CPO and RBD Olein, respectively, prices corrected only slightly. A relatively bearish end-March 98 Porla release with production at 598,612MT (-0.44%, slightly above the trade estimate of -3%) and stocks at 623,989MT (-15.42%, above the trade estimate of 600,000MT), failed to dampen sentiment. With producers reluctant to sell on one hand and refineries desperate for crude on the other, prices rallied further to the mid-RM2300/MT levels. Near month's end, the bullish sentiment faltered as Indonesia actually shipped out some palm cargo and prices dipped to RM2260/MT levels. However, the market proved resilient and charged back as crude sellers remained scarce and as the Ringgit weakened to 3.7000 levels on further corporate failures. At month's end, news of frequent riots in Indonesia diminished hopes of a steady palm supply from that country, prompting massive trade and speculative buying to test the RM2400/MT mark. It appears that the fuse in Indonesia is lit again, as public discontent about hyperinflation flares into widespread riots. The primary assumption is that palm supply from Indonesia will be unreliable and that supply from Malaysia will still be more secure. Besides, although palm stocks in Indonesia is said to be quite high, estimated conservatively at 400,000MT and 700,000MT on the high end, much of this supply is to fill previous deferred shipments. Therefore, bearishness of the ban lifting appears to be discounted. The secondary reaction is that the Indonesian socio-political unrest will again pressure the regional currency units. This will translate into higher Ringgit denominated crude prices. As such, the palm scenario continues to be supportive. Production in Malaysia appears to be stabilising, estimated to be unchanged to 2% higher at 600,000MT. Initial reports of heavy declines early in the month has been tempered by better output in the second half of the month. Output will likely improve significantly from now onwards, but the long dry spell has certainly `stressed the trees'. We will assume that peak production in September/November will likely be curtailed and that the last quarter output will decline very quickly. A similar model applies to the Indonesian production pattern. Comments from Oil World implies that the global edible oils situation this year is pressing with contractions in palm oil output in Malaysia and Indonesia and in the summer oilseeds crop in India. Therefore, weather is paramount in the second half of the year as India and the United States enter the oilseeds planting window. Sentiment will certainly be edgy as a crop failure will be catastrophic. Palm demand appears to be stable with April 98 disappearance estimated at 680,000MT. A few refineries experienced cargo readiness problems in light of scarce crude supply resulting in some shipments deferred into May. India has been the most impressive buyer with 110,000MT of palm products in bulk. Pakistan has maintained consumption at about 60,000MT while China, having bought substantially in March, has reduced offtake at about 50,000MT. Due to the shortfall in India's summer crop, it will continue to be a large buyer until the winter oilseeds harvest in November. From the above data, end-April stocks will be reduced to about 550,000MT. This tight situation will persist into June, as production will barely meet demand in the next few months. Traders maintain a buy approach towards the market especially if the Ringgit strengthens back to about 3.6000 as they are not particularly friendly towards the unit based on Chart Analysis. Loh Kin Kien is the manager of Sri Comm Options and Futures Sdn Bhd

THE Council of Economic Ministers Monday approved a measure to help boost the income of farmers and alleviate the suffering of the agricultural industry which has been hit by the baht depreciation. With the measure's approval, the government has assigned the Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives to provide loans to farmers at the start of the harvest season to improve their bargaining power. The government will also strengthen the purchasing power of local merchants and provide a mechanism for them to bargain with exporters for better prices. In addition, the Internal Trade Department must set up an efficient information system for agricultural exporters, local traders and farmers to reduce unfair conditions in the market mechanism. The Commerce Ministry, Agriculture and Cooperatives Ministry and the Bank of Thailand will prepare clear, basic information on production, quantity, export prices and foreign exchange rates. Government spokesman Somchai Sahachairungruang said the measures proposed by the Commerce Ministry were based on important export factors including production costs, exchange rates, interest rates, world market prices and export prices, domestic prices, liquidity and transportation, to provide a picture of market trends and the country's competitiveness. Somchai said demand for agricultural goods is lower than last year as a result of the overall economic recession. Asia's financial crisis is reducing purchasing power in the region, where important export markets are located. Prices are also declining due to lower demand. Export rice prices, for example, have dropped by 16 per cent, and tapioca prices plunged by 24 per cent compared to the same period last year. However, Thai agriculture exports are growing with high demand from countries that faced droughts caused by the El Nino phenomenon. Rice exports are expected to reach 6 million tonnes this year. Before July 2, agricultural prices depended on market demand and supply. Afterwards, the market was most concerned about other factors, such as exchange rates, which have an important impact on market margins in the form of high risk-high returns. The stabilisation of the baht from April to May will help return trading and producing to the right direction as they were before the flotation. ''The baht hit its lowest at Bt56-57 against the US dollar in January. Farmers gained higher export value but also faced higher production costs and interest rates,'' Somchai said, adding that losses have caused another important problem, forcing farmers out of the market and reducing the country's output this year.

RIOTS and street demonstrations in Indonesia have spooked the Singapore stockmarket, encouraging selling, keeping potential buyers away, and dashing hopes of a quick rally. The market, which collapsed in January as the Asian currency crisis sent shockwaves through financial markets, had made a comeback in March, with the benchmark Straits Times Industrial Index (STII) peaking at 1,700 points. It was driven by a sense of relief that the worst could be over for Southeast Asia, along with a more stable regional currency situation and lower interest rates. Cash-laden mutual funds, which had bailed out of the region's stockmarkets on fears that the economic and political instability in Indonesia could lead to a regional financial catastrophe, started rebuilding their positions in Singapore when the worst-case scenario did not materialise. But the deteriorating situation in Indonesia appears to have dimmed hopes of a sustained recovery and could sink the market, possibly to the January level when the STII fell to 1,031 points. Currently, hedge funds are selling while confidence remains fragile. The market shows no sign of reversing the falls any time soon; instead, a one- way bet is providing further incentive to sell, with occasional bargain- hunting in selective stocks. On May 7, the 30-share unweighted STII fell more than 3% to a low of 1,399.61 in the wake of riots and police shootings that wounded two demonstrators in Medan, a key commodities trading centre of two million people. The city lies just a few hundred kilometres northwest of Singapore. The Indonesian unrest followed sharp rises in domestic fuel and transport prices, which were part of the conditions for a US$40 billion economic rescue package by the International Monetary Fund. In the short-term, the STII is expected to slide further as investors fear the Indonesian riots could spread political uncertainty to the rest of Southeast Asia and affect the confidence in the region. As Indonesia's an important trading partner, accounting for nearly 11% of exports, Singapore is vulnerable to this contagion. Further, the problems plaguing the Japanese economy are also expected to undermine investors' confidence in the Singapore market in the coming months. The Japanese economy, which has been threatening to plunge headlong into a recession, could drag the Yen even lower and send Southeast Asian currencies, the Singapore dollar included, into another downward spiral. On the domestic front, there are worries that the island is starting to lose its reputation as a fortress against the regional economic uncertainty and a haven for investors, following an expected abrupt halt to its years of strong economic growth. For the first three months of this year, Singapore's real gross domestic growth (GDP) was an impressive 5.6%, while last year, the economy grew by 7.8%, compared to the previous year. But with the full impact of the regional financial turmoil yet to be felt and the social and economic meltdown in Indonesia yet to settle down, the economy is likely to slow down considerably in 1998 - possibly even below the government's forecast of between 2.5% and 4.5%. In addition, the Singapore dollar has lost considerable ground to the US currency, while interbank rates have crept up to a two-month high of 6.5% in early May, fuelling fears that local banks might raise their prime rates from the current average of 7%. There are also concerns over the Singapore banking sector, with banking groups expected to make provisions similar to last year's for their regional exposure to non-performing loans. Companies' earnings growth is also expected to be flat this year, making a mild recovery. Most Singapore companies are likely to experience a prolonged period of economic malaise as the business environment deteriorates. In the short-term, the STII is likely to test the 1,200-point level and could go down to 1,100 points before recovering as the market consolidates and responds to the severe, long-term economic effects of the region's financial crisis. Volume, meanwhile, is expected to continue to be depressed as many investors refrain from buying until there are definite signs that the region is turning the corner, and this could exaggerate any price movement.

AFTER closing above the 700 level at the end of the first quarter of this year, both the KLSE CI Futures and the underlying KLSE CI fell 13.3% and 12.8% respectively on April 1, 1998. A deep discount of between 20 to 27 points separated the April Futures and the KLSE CI on aggressive selling of KLSE CI Futures by large foreign institutions. April Futures converged on April 30 1998 with the KLSE CI at the settlement price of 622.30, passing the deep discount to May Futures with May-April rolls traded to as wide as -24 points spread (although the fair value was +5 points.) In general, like the other regional bourses, the KLSE CI and the futures reacted to the changes in local currencies. In April, Nikkei fell 621.78 points to 15,641.26 while Hang Seng was not much stronger, shedding off 10% to 10,383.68. Therefore, KLSE CI's 12.8% fall was in tandem with the weakness of the entire region. Several negative developments in April worsened the situation. The suspension of Maybank (the third largest market capitalisation stock in the KLSE) on April 1, 1998 caused the spot month contract to plunge from the month's high of 717.90 through the 700 psychological level to close near KLSE CI's April low of 616.04. Maybank, which have a beta of 1.28 against the KLSE CI, lost RM3 in April, finishing near lows of RM11. Meanwhile, the largest market capitalisation stock in KLSE, Telekom, slided from RM12.50 to RM11 on concerns of a possible bailout of Time Telekom. The downtrend was aggravated by the suspension of Ekran and Wembley at the beginning of the month and growing fears of more public listed companies succumbing to the pressure of receiverships. Heavy selloffs by foreign fund managers, rumoured to be from the US, pushed the futures to continue trading at deeper discounts of 20 to 27 points to the KLSE CI. With the KLSE probing into the affairs of local brokerage houses, the bearish sentiments persisted throughout the month. Futures seemed to be the only sensible mean of trading the market. Rating agency Standard Poor's downgrading of the Ringgit and its estimate of a 20% default of Malaysian bank loans compounded the negative sentiments, pushing the futures and index down further. The relisting of RHB and RHBCap did not help the weakened market as RHB fell RM1.10 on the first day of relisting to RM4.10. All in all, out of the 21 trading days in April, 14 days were marked with black candles (close lower than when the market opens) on the chart. For next month, the general indicators seem to point towards the Mayfutures trading at a discount of around 20 points on continued bearish sentiments.On a daily chart for the KLSE CI, the 3 day and 7 day moving averages seem to have converged, signaling a breakout. However, with sellers converging around the 635 level, the first resistance seems strong. All this is in line with the weak Ringgit which had trapped itself in a triangular formation. The focus should therefore very much be on the frail Yen and the Yen-German Mark crossplay. With expectations of rising interest rates in Germany and the Deutschemark emerging as the leading currency in the Europe forex market, the general sentiment is to long the Deutschemark against other currencies especially the US Dollar, Pound Sterling and Yen. Regional currencies here will watch the play and react accordingly. Like the Yen, which is held strong by the Bank of Japan between 134.73 and 128.60, the Ringgit will also range between 3.79 and 3.64 with market rumours of Bank Negara intervening at 3.80 level. Like in April, the foreign investors will be watching the Ringgit and other regional currrencies for May's direction. The downtrend seems set to continue. Any retracement may be minor as fresh waves of selling will take place. The aggressiveness in the short rolls (short May after closing long April positions) is indicative of this. As at the beginning of the month, the fair values for May and June are 1.3 and 5.8 respectively. This is because large index linked stocks like Telekom, are paying heavy dividends. Telekom is paying a 12 sen dividend with the ex date being 7 May. Given the above, technical rebounds are likely to be shortlived and should be considered as opportunities to short the futures, at least in the early part of the month. However, should a base be formed once the Jan-Feb gap is covered, then some retracements in the middle of the year seems likely. Jacinta Chan is with CIMB Futures Sdn Bhd.

Porsche recalls 9,500 Boxter models
EDS: UPDATES with recall worldwide, details
STUTTGART, Germany (AP) _ The luxury automaker Porsche on Tuesday recalled more than 9,500 Boxters worldwide for possible defective casings around the ignition starter switches. Porsche said most of the cars affected were 1997 models. The two-seat roadster, introduced last year, was Porsche's first new model in 19 years. The defect could cause electrical components, such as the windshield wipers, to malfunction. The automaker said the problem is present in cars that will not return to position one, ignition on, from position two, starter motor runs. Porsche said it also will change the bearing bushings idler levers in the tiptronic transmission of 2,692 of the recalled cars. Porsche said owners were being informed in writing. (dj-cb)

SHOULD you launch your new product on television? If you run a small business nowadays, that's an easy decision. You don't. You can't. Instead of a straightforward assault on the consumer market with a major campaign, you're better off deploying an ambush: use promotion instead. Promote by gimmick. Sell by giving things away. Big companies have nationwide reach if they give something away; you don't. But you have an advantage on them: you don't have a staid image to protect, so you can be more wildly imaginative. The essence of promotion is taking people unawares to get past their natural scepticism, appealing directly to their emotions. You can inspire people to yearn for your product if you believe you were put on this planet to sell it - and only if you don't take yourself too seriously. 1) Give away lots of samples. But besides being liberal with them, be strategic: use celebrities. Track them down at the restaurants they haunt (you can find this out easily in the celebrity press). Be persistent. If Brooke Shields gets photographed for a magazine playing with your toy, you're all set. Be nervy. If you're marketing a rubber axe for Halloween, find Jack Nicholson and make him a present of it. Be imaginative. A friend of mine invented a `No Smoking' kit, and wanted to get a picture of it in the hands of C. Everett Koop, the US Surgeon General. He heard that a local school was auctioning off lunch with Dr Koop as part of a fund-raising event. My friend bought the lunch. 2) Give live demonstrations in public places. Choose carefully. Try public plazas and tourist attractions where large crowds gather. (Why not try for press coverage too?) 3) Create a zany spokesman for your product. If you've got a new sneaker, try a talking track shoe with eyes that light up. Or turn something into your spokesman. I was impressed by a stunt I saw in New York: a shoe company put shoes on the statue of Atlas in Rockefeller Centre. It took six hours for security guards to get around to removing them. 4) Make trade shows fun - most of them are so boring. Hire the Dallas Cowboy Cheerleaders to work your booth. A paper-shredder manufacturer might convince Fawn Hall to demonstrate his wares; if not, a good lookalike will do. If you don't want to use showbiz glitz, there's still no need to have someone just standing by your booth with an order pad saying, `Hi, it's nice to meet you.' Have him standing on his head. And don't make the mistake of having a good buffet. All too often, people just come for the food and forget what you're about. 5) When you're sending samples to important people, never keep them waiting. Use Express or a messenger; if your sample is to go to another city, consider flying it there yourself. Make your package fun, not just for the person you're trying to impress, but for the whole office: have something in there for the receptionist, the assistant, the secretary. Get them on your side. When the big guy returns from lunch, your stunt will already have worked. He'll find the receptionist and secretary playing with your product, calling out to him, `Look what we got!' What should be in your kit? Nothing the `big guy' has to assemble or inflate. You inflate it and put in the batteries, and maybe he'll turn on the switch. Better yet, send the product already running inside the box. A groaning, scratching package will pique a little curiosity. Remember, the point is to get lots of your product in people's hands. Richard Knerr and `Spud' Melvin, the inventors of the Hula-Hoop, went around the San Fernando valley just giving Hoops away. Debbi Fields ran up and down the streets giving out her cookies. By giving something away, you will be getting something you couldn't create with all the TV commercials in the world: people's surprise and spontaneous enjoyment of your product. There is no better advertising. -UPS

YOU wouldn't consider making an important sales call in a dirty shirt and a pair of worn-out shoes. So why approach an investor with a balance sheet that doesn't portray your company in the best light? A balance sheet is your best sales pitch for your business. There's no document so thoroughly scrutinised by a financier or so critical to his decision to lend you money. You'll have an easier time convincing him if you present a compelling story. A balance sheet is a snapshot of your company's financial health at a particular time. The prettier the picture, the more you'll reassure lenders you can repay them. Your goal in structuring your balance sheet is to increase assets and reduce liabilities. Every extra dollar in assets you present without an offsetting liability drops to the bottom line as owner's equity. That's an important source of collateral: each bottom-line dollar can translate into US$5 to US$7 worth of credit. To look your financial best, pay attention to how you list information. Start by identifying assets: everything the business owns or leases that has exchange or market value. List assets in order of their nearness to cash, or the ease with which they can be liquidated. Cash: It's king. When preparing for a round of money raising, postpone as many spending decisions as possible. Account Receivable: This is money owed to your business for goods or services already delivered. But if an unpaid invoice is more than 90 days old, write off or get the customer to sign a promissory note, to convert the account to a ``note receivable.'' Notes Receivable: Document all of these IOUs to the business, even informal loans to employees and family. One way to build this category of assets and reduce operating expenses is to take a big chunk of your salary out of the company as a note receivable. The strategy may also save you income tax. Inventory: It represents the value of your company's raw materials, work in progress, and finished goods on hand. Check with your CPA about the best methods of valuation. Fixed Assets: These include all tangible properties such as furniture, fixtures, office equipment, and machinery. If you must buy fixed assets before shopping around for new capital, always go for quality stuff so that it retains as much book value as possible. Deposits: Prepaid Expenses. Among these are real estate, equipment, or vehicles that you personally own and lease to the company. You can use them to create additional assets. If the company pays you US$2,000 a month in rent, consider taking half that and increasing the security deposit; at the end of a year, you'll have a US$12,000 cash asset for the business that you can use tax-free until you declare the deposit forfeit. Other Assets: These include patents, trademarks, copyrights, and royalty agreements, which should be reported if you're legally entitled to them. Don't neglect the debit half of the ledger. You job is to minimise liabilities, which are claims on assets, or, at least, to push the due dates as far away as possible. Current Liabilities: These are debts, such as notes payable to banks, coming due within a year or less. Try to convert them to long-term liabilities to free up working capital. Long-Term Liabilities: It pays to restructure long-term debt (due more than a year away) either to take advantage of reduced interest payments or to lengthen the payback period because it improves your cash flow. Other ways to get long-term debt off the books: assuming personal responsibility for it, especially if you're already guaranteeing it; reporting parts of your salary or bonus as equity in the company. Check with your CPA to make sure all changes are in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. Since you're using the balance sheet to sell yourself and your company to the financial community, be certain the statement conforms to what you really are, while accentuating your good points. Get started now. Your capital needs may be six months or a year away, but it's never too early to restructure your balance sheet. - UPS

AS at Dec 31, 1997 the Securities Commission (SC) recorded a surplus of RM178.4 million. Total Income for the year - RM252.85 million -comprised levies RM190.89 million, interest on deposits RM40.19 million, fees and charges RM19.94 million, and other income RM1.83 million. Set against this was Expenditure of RM74.48 million, which included the following items: personnel RM29.18 million, administration RM14.08 million, premises RM5.41 million, depreciation RM6.83 million and grants RM19 million. The SC's three-phased plan to move from merit-based regulation to a disclosure-based system spans more than five years. The second phase that was to have started this year is now expected in 1999. During financial year 1997, the SC promulgated several policies and amended certain Guidelines. The major ones include Guidelines for the Public Offering of Securities of Foreign-based Companies with Listing and Quotations on the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE), which was issued in April 1997. Revisions to Guidelines on Unit Trust Funds was issued in May. Updates and revisions to the Policies and Guidelines on Issue/Offer of Securities were issued in July. September saw the issue of Two New Practice Notes - Practice 16 and 17, and Guidelines Governing Purchase of Own Shares by Listed Companies. Procedures for applying for exemption from making a mandatory general offer, were announced in December. The number of corporate proposals submitted for approval by the SC increased in 1997. A total of 379 submissions were received from public companies, a 14.8% increase over 1996, of which 318 were considered and 267 approved. The 318 proposals included 149 flotation submissions, of which 106 were approved. Twenty-six were approved for listing on the Main Board and 80 on the Second Board. There was a 24% decline in the number of proposals relating to bonus, rights and special issues submitted to the SC, from 38 in 1995 to 29 last year. Debt securities submissions increased by 44%, from 27 in 1996 to 39% in 1997. There were no submissions for call warrants during the year. For 1997, a total of 210 issues was expected to raise about RM50.3 billion (in 1996, 173 issues raised RM16.8 billion). Component issues approved to be undertaken by listed and unlisted companies in 1997 included 106 Initial Public Offerings raising RM15.8 billion; 40 Rights Issues raising RM14.6 billion; 17 Special Issues raising RM2.2 billion; four ICULS raising RM968.6 million and 43 Debt Securities raising RM16.7 billion. In 1997, the SC also received 153 applications pertaining to various requirements of the Take-Overs Code (in 1996, there were 154 applications). The number of applications involving the making of general offers decreased from 89 the previous year to 66 in 1997. There was a significant increase of 33.8% in the number of applications not involving the making of general offers, from 65 in 1996 to 87 in 1997. As for supervision of the market, the SC conducted a full scope examination of one stockbroker and a limited scope examination of another for call warrants. Four others were examined by the KLSE subject to supervision and full review by the SC. The SC invoked Section 52(1) of the Securities Industry Act 1983 by appointing Independent Auditors to perform full scope audits on three stockbrokers due to adverse liquidity and financial positions. In 1997, the SC and market institutions continued to work together to ensure compliance in the market. Audit reports of exchanges among their members were submitted to the SC and reviewed. The KLSE conducted management audits of 40 stockbrokers and updated the status of the 20 stockbrokers examined in 1996, in compliance with the government's broad policy on active Bumiputera participation in the stockbroking industry. Apart from this special audit, the SC also received 38 audit reports from KLSE for review. There were 11 audit reports from KLOFFE, eight from MME, seven from KLCE and 13 from the MDCH submitted for SC review. A total of 69 cases were investigated under various sections of the Act. While the majority of investigations involved short-selling (51 cases), the SC also conducted investigations on, among others, insider trading, market manipulation and false or misleading statements. Some 119 new complaints were lodged with the SC in 1997; the SC also had to deal with 40 complaints brought forward from 1996. The SC managed to close the file on about 19% of the cases. The SC's market supervision function was enhanced with the signing of memoranda of understanding (MoU) with the China Securities Regulatory Commission, Capital Markets Authority of Kenya, Financial Services Board of South Africa, Securities and Futures Commission of Taiwan, and Comissao de Valores Mobiliarios of Brazil. The MoUs provide a framework for mutual assistance and information sharing. Efforts in this direction were facilitated by Section 438 of the Securities Commission Act, which allows the SC to provide assistance to any foreign securities supervisory authority.

MOODY's Investors Services downgrading of Japan's sovereign debt outlook to negative earlier last month incurred the wrath of Japanese economists. This was because this rating essentially implied that Japan is faced with a high risk of default in its debt repayments. They argued that this was ironic, considering the country's hefty trade surplus and strong foreign reserves. The gloomy report rocked the country's markets, dragging down the Yen to a record seven-year low against the US Dollar. In fact, one analyst went to the extent of saying that comparatively, it is the United States which should receive a negative rating, based on the February figures. It recorded the biggest deficit in six years - the goods and services deficit increased 4.2% to US$12.1 billion (RM46 billion) from a revised US$11.6 billion in January. This threatens to offset the favourable effects brought upon by the super power's contracting budget deficit. The downrating also baffled economists because Japan's ability to repay its external debt is strong due to its high reserves holdings, especially in the form of US Treasury bonds. This episode added insult to injury at a time when rating agencies the world over were rigorously trying to redeem themselves from the massive criticisms received for failing to predict the Asian currency turmoil and subsequent economic downturn. And this was despite the presence of strong signals like high asset inflation, burgeoning current account deficits and poor management of the banking and financial system in some of these countries. The failure of rating agencies to detect these weaknesses to accurately forecast the health of Asian economies and companies has become the butt of jokes. In fact, at the height of the Asian currency meltdown last year, some industry observers had even jokingly implied that an independent watchdog needed to be set up to start rating these agencies! Jokes and implied inefficency aside, their influence has hardly waned, if Moody's forecast for Japan is anything to go by. In fact, the Far Eastern Economic Review's weekly Asian Executive Poll recently showed 69% of top company executives interviewed said they trusted international rating agencies more than Asian ones. At the same time, approximately 58% of the business leaders polled said international rating agencies like Moody's and Standard Poor's have not been too harsh on Asian countries and companies. However, in Malaysia, 53.3% of business executives interviewed said these agencies were too harsh in their ratings, while only 17.2% said they would rather trust Asian rating agencies than Moody's or SP. Moody's recent downgrading of Japan's debt outlook has prompted some people - the Japanese at least - to seriously consider evaluating rating agencies. The Japan Centre of International Finance, a group backed by private financial firms, will assess rating validity and credibility of eight agencies, including Moody's and SP. This is because a downgrading by either one of world's two most influential rating agencies - the US-based Moody's and SP - can seriously affect a company's and even country's ability to raise funds. However, rating agencies contend that they are not the bad hats they have been made out to be. As Suresh Menon, general manager of Rating Agency of Malaysia (RAM), puts it, `The criticism that rating agencies have been slow in responding to the Asian financial crisis is correct but it was not due to their negligence.' He said rating agencies based their forecasts on information received. `Rating agencies are no magicians. We can't gaze into the crystal ball and predict what is going to happen. `You also cannot fault a rating for a surefire yes or no. If a bad rating is given, we are simply saying that the company has a high tendency to default. However, it does not necessarily mean it will default. Timeliness and the quality of the information available are important elements to foresee what is going on.' Menon's views echoed those of his superior, Datuk C Rajandram, chief executive officer (CEO) of RAM and Vincent J Truglia, managing director of Moody's. The right information is indeed vital to credit raters. They both agree that transparency and full public disclosure is the key to accurate forecasts. Truglia said in a recent report that although a rating may be accurate, it might yield different results due to the different methodologies used. Therefore, he added, `the facts themselves must be known as well.' Comparing ratings between various agencies are like comparing apples and oranges. However, as long as investors understand the distinction between the various rating methods utilised by different agencies, Truglia believes no real harm is done. Rajandram believed rating agencies are doing their best to disseminate vital and timely information to the public but the delay in receiving the much needed information leads to a setback in disclosing their opinions. `So, we need to re-examine the transparency requirements so that we will be better informed,' he said recently. Menon thinks the lack of transparency and information lags on aggregate private sector debts caused rating agencies to ignore signals of a potential downturn. Referring to the current economic slowdown, he says, `Nobody, not even international agencies like the World Bank or the International Monetary Fund (IMF), which possess greater and more timely access to such information, had anticipated the cumulative effects of the situation until the bubble burst.' This is because compared with the Mexican and Latin American crises which were associated with government excesses, the Asian problems stem largely from the private sector and were therefore more difficult to detect. `Getting information from governments for the Asian kind of problem is very difficult for rating agencies. So, our opinions are derived from the information given by various ministry officials,' Menon explained. On hindsight, it took until late December last year for Moody's, SP and Fitch-IBCA to tell that South Korea was in danger of default. By that time, the Won had lost 55% of its value against the US Dollar and yields on its Eurobonds had risen by at least 5% points. These agencies have also said that their delayed forecast was due to them not receiving information as fast as they needed it. So, investors will have to rely on past rating reports and conduct their own research. In the case of Malaysia, why did local rating agencies let impending problems go undetected despite signals like the widening current account deficit and the rapid credit growth compared with the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth? Menon says, `We don't do sovereign risk analysis. Our analysis is more on micro-level, that is on a company by company basis. Still we have warned about the asset inflation for the property market. Our reports from the very beginning show that there has been asset inflation and there has been an oversupply in the hotel sector. We have highlighted the dangers of overlending in the stock broking sector. We have been incorporating these warnings in our ratings.' Nevertheless, he admits that the local rating agencies did not anticipate a swift downturn. `We were expecting more of a soft landing. I must admit we did not foresee the degree of the current downturn, although we have been factoring these potential dangers in the ratings.' In the final analysis, rating agencies can learn some lessons from this entire episode. For one, contagion effects due to the increasingly integrated regional and global economy are becoming an important source of financial market instability and risks. The severity of these effects varies from country to country. Therefore, rating agencies must develop the ability to differentiate individual countries' strengths and weaknesses. `It shows you the importance of having analysts on the ground to get a real feel of the respective country. That is something foreign rating agencies should take note of. One way of doing this is for international rating agencies to tie up with local ones,' Menon points out. RAM's partner, Duff Phelps, besides tying up with RAM, has recently forged an alliance with a Korean rating agency. `So, they will now feel the pulse of the Korean economy more profoundly since their local Korean partners know the market and economy there.' Menon said this was especially important in the era of shrinking borders where it was vital to have people who really understood what was going on in each country. This was because each country had its own characteristics. In micro-economic term, especially in Malaysian domestic-oriented debts, the mismatch of funding tenure and requirements of companies will lead them to fall into the trap more quickly. `Companies that use predominantly short term debt to finance long term projects are the ones who are more likely to be in trouble. It is a classic case of a mismatch of funding requirements but this has been happening because of the liquidity available. But in the current times of tight liquidity, companies relying on that kind of funding will be the first ones to be likely hit in a rising interest rates scenario,' says Menon. Another valuable lesson is for credit rating analysts in Malaysia to realign their thinking because a crisis like this provides the best avenue to learn. `Our analysts in RAM are basically a young group. Besides the few of us, nobody else has gone through a recession since our inception in 1991. Now they are faced with a situation of liquidity crunch, interest rates hikes and an exchange rate depreciation, things they have not experienced before,' he states. This is the best time to learn and take stock of the situation to rectify their thinking for the future, he concludes.

THE Securities and Exchange Commission's Board of Directors Monday agreed to stir investment in the Thai Trust Fund scheme by offering more investment channels to investors. Additional channels would help motivate foreigners to buy more shares of the listed company through the Thai Trust Fund, the SEC said. After its fourth meeting this year, the SEC's board allowed more alternatives over Thai Trust Fund via the purchase of listed company's capital increase shares in the primary market. Investors can now buy capital increase shares of listed companies offered via private placement or public offering. Moreover, in case of investment in the secondary market, the SEC allows the orders for big lots of shares and the lots can be swapped to other kinds of securities. Earlier, the SEC allowed the purchase of big lots only for transaction of similar investment units. According to Krongkaew Piemduoytham, managing director of the Thai Trust Fund, currently only four listed companies have joined the Thai Trust Fund programme. And among the four companies, Alucon Plc is the only company which has been quite active. However, with the new investment criteria, more property companies were likely to join the programme because it would allow capital increase shares to be traded in the primary market. The SEC also agreed in principle on the issuance of the share offer under the greenshoe option in which the transaction would now be allowed to be more than 15 per cent of the total new shares. The SEC agreed to adjust the calculation of the over-allotment shares from not more than 15 per cent of total new issuance shares to more than 15 per cent of the total shares offering. Concerning the closed finance companies which were the members of the Bangkok Securities Dealing Centre (BSDC), the SEC said the companies would not be allowed to vote for the BSDC's directors. They would also not be allowed to vote for the extraordinary meeting of the Centre or join the Centre's membership meeting, or receive any services which is provided by the BSDC. The SEC added that any of their rights or responsibilities would no longer be effective, although this would be with the approval of the BSDC's directors as well as that of the SEC.

IN the burgeoning local unit trust industry with more than 80 approved funds at present, product innovations have become imperative for survival and growth. In this respect Commerce-BT Lifetime Trust stands out from the crowd. The reason: Commerce BT is the first unit trust company in Malaysia to gain approval to launch three funds simultaneously, under one umbrella trust deed and one prospectus. `Three funds for three different life stages,' enthuses Jason Yetton, chief executive officer of Commerce-BT Unit Trust Management, the company offering this innovative package. The three funds - Future Goals Fund, Balanced Returns Fund and Income Plus Fund - are specifically designed to meet investors' differing needs for risk and return, and income, as versus capital growth. Each fund has a maximum size of 500 million units, being offered at RM0.50 apiece. Commerce-BT combines the local expertise of one of Malaysia's premier banking groups - the Commerce Asset-Holding Group - with the international know-how of one of the world's largest fund management companies - Bankers Trust Group. Bankers Trust has a network spanning over 50 countries with more than RM1 trillion in total funds under its management, as at end December 1997. It is also the largest international investor in Asia and in 1997, ranked as the best performing fund manager in the world. Lifetime Trust, says Yetton, took 12 months to develop. `When Commerce Asset and Bankers Trust decided to extend our successful partnership to the unit trust industry, it was clear that we needed to do something different if Commerce-BT was going to be successful,' he contends. `After all there are more than 80 unit trust funds available in Malaysia.' Its novelty lies in the flexibility it provides investors to switch among the three funds up to twice in any year to suit their investment goals. Says Yetton, `Some investors would want to change due to investment objectives or market conditions and we oblige, free of charge.' Each fund has a different asset exposure. The Future Goals Fund is targeted at maximising capital growth over the long-term through investment in Malaysian shares. `It is suitable for aggressive investors seeking potentially high investment returns. Of course this also involves high risk and, therefore, investors must be able to accept that investment returns will fluctuate significantly over the short term,' says Yetton. The Balanced Returns Fund aims to grow the value of your investment over the long term through investment in a diversified portfolio of Malaysian shares and fixed interest securities. `It can invest up to a maximum 70% in the stock market and will pay an income distribution to investors each year in January.' The Income Plus Fund, for its part, is tailored to the more conservative investor. It will provide an income distribution every six months along with some capital growth over the medium term to offset the effects of inflation. `The Income Plus Fund will predominantly invest in fixed interest securities with a maximum 40% invested in shares at any one time.' Yetton says the Lifetime Trust is mainly targeted at retail investors. The minimum investment in each fund is RM2,000. Alternatively investors can start with as little as RM1,000 and then invest RM100 or more each month using the easy Investment Plan. Corporations have shown keen interest in this investment. `We are talking to a few corporates but so far we have not concluded any deals,' says Yetton. `We hope to achieve the RM500 million maximum within three to five years. But I think if we can achieve a size of RM200 million across all three funds within the first year, that will be good enough in this economic environment.' Was the launch timely? The stock market is riding low and the majority of unit trusts have lost half their value. Yetton believes the current gloom provides seasoned investors with a once-in-a-decade opportunity to invest selectively in fine undervalued stocks. `We are launching at a time when many companies are trading at valuations below their net asset values and which are the lowest in the past five to seven years.' This makes it the best time for investment provided investors are prepared to take a three-to five-year view. `Historically, markets often rebound quite strongly after a severe downturn and we believe that there is a significant up-side for people who are prepared to take a three- to five- year view to investment.' Lifetime Trust is managed by Commerce Asset Fund Managers Sdn Bhd (CAFM) - another joint venture between Commerce Asset-Holding and Bankers Trust - which has earned an enviable reputation over the last seven years. As at December 31 1997, it was handling more than RM303 million in funds. In the recent Watson Wyatt 1997 Annual Report of asset managers in Malaysia, CAFM was ranked top for 1996 and 1997. CAFM's investment strategy combines a top down macroeconomic analysis with bottom up on-the ground stock research. Currently, Yetton says, the approach is cautious towards the stock market as banks' non-performing loans have been rising and the property sector has yet to hit rock-bottom. `The thrust is stock-picking. We are looking at individual stocks that have potential to be winners.'

DESPITE improved sentiments in the country's economy, alleviation of the debt problem remains a key factor in true economic recovery, SG Asian Research's quarterly economic review said. ''Thailand is still in the critical zone but is moving out of it. It is too early to say if it has already left the danger zone,'' the research institute's report said. The report added that the government should help lower the private sector's debts to stop the economy from collapsing even further. Ideally, it should be done without the use of public money and the state should act as a facilitator in the process of bringing the creditors and debtors together. The strategy would encourage foreign banks to roll over short-term debts and to reach individual settlements with debtors. However, there are signs that this process could have problems. According to the report, the roll-over rate of 85 per cent is actually dropping. With an estimated US$4 billion due each month, a 15-per cent maturity rate puts tremendous pressure on the balance of payments. The maturity structure for roll-overs is very short, only extended from one to three months, because head offices are keen to keep their options open. Moreover, Japanese banks, by far the largest single creditor group, are facing a difficult situation at home with widening premiums reducing roll-overs. The report added that the policy of encouraging debt roll-overs was just a short-term palliative and did nothing to solve the long-term problem. However, there still seems to be a reluctance in providing any official support for debt restructuring along the lines of Indonesia and Korea, as they fear it would confirm how bad the situation really is. This also highlights the need for the framework to be supported by the international community. The report said the key would be to promote a market-based solution when practical, without worrying about ethical issues, because of the urgency of the situation. Both creditor banks and shareholders would have to bear the losses. The longer uncoordinated debt-restructuring talks between creditors and debtors drag on, the longer it will take for normal international financing flows to resume, the research institution said. ''Our fear is that until this happens, the baht will not stabilise and the corporate sector will continue to face this overhang,'' the report said. The worst outcome would be an unmanaged debt moratorium, which would have negative implications for long-term financing -- a major problem in Thailand given the high dependency of the corporate sector on bank financing. The odds on this are still uncomfortably high and must offset the positives outlined above. Until this type of framework is put in place, the baht will remain vulnerable to negative sentiment, and SG Asi keeps its year-end forecast of Bt45/US dollar, given that sentiment is still fragile and could turn negative if debt restructuring progress is not forthcoming, the report said. According to SG Asia, the other big concern is that the strong support for the present policies may lead to some policy slippages, as the pressure to reform is lessened. Examples include backsliding on the liberalisation of real estate restrictions placed on foreigners. The Chavalit administration had proposed some important reforms to allow greater access but these appear to have been dropped. This is a major concern because it means that the massive property oversupply situation will take much longer to resolve as only foreigners have the ready funds available to buy property. The consequence is that the banking system problems (which are related to overvalued property prices) will be more difficult to resolve. Moreover, reforming the Alien Business Law appears to have been put on hold. There are difficulties in the details as to how exactly the Asset Management Corporation (AMC) and the Financial Sector Restructuring Authority process works and grey areas in the prevention of abuses. Although the AMC is being recapitalised to Bt10 billion from Bt1 billion, this is unlikely to be enough to buy the bad assets of the closed finance companies. Also, funding for the Financial Institutions Development Fund's large losses, which represent a large monetary and, thus, inflationary overhang, is still unresolved as the proposed international bond issues are small in relation to the bail-out sums involved which amount to almost $30 billion.

THREE influent private organisations Monday agreed to conduct a joint study on the new labour law, coming into effect on Aug 19, 1998, in an attempt to suggest changes to the amended law to Premier Chuan Leekpai this week. The new law has become a problem for both employers and workers. Earlier, the Federation of Thai Industries (FTI) said the government should allow a grace period after the implementation of the new law, given the country's economic crisis. Khemadhat Sukondhasingha, FTI secretary-general, said that the government should revise the law to make it more practical as the private sector is not able to meet the new conditions. Thavatchai Yongkittikul, secretary-general of Thai Bankers' Assocition (TBA), will head the working group responsible for drafting the proposal for consideration by the government. However, any solution must be acceptable to both employers and workers. Small and medium-sized industries have been struggling to stay afloat and rushing to lay-off workers before the law becomes effective. The move has contributed to a further rise in unemployment. Khemadhat said several conditions in the law could deter investments, such as the compulsory measure that a company must take responsibility for its subcontractor's workers in the event of a collapse or closure and that workers should not be forced to work for more than eight hours with the exception of certain professions. Moreover, the new law will narrow chances for female workers as employers are expected to avoid hiring women due to tougher conditions such as the prohibition of a pregnant employee working up to 10 pm. ''The FTI, TBA and Board of Trade of Thailand do not object strongly to the new law, they simply think that it is inappropriate under the present circumstances,'' said Khemadhat. In addition, the private sector consultative committee will hold a seminar on private debt restructuring between May 8 and 10. The conclusion of the seminar will be proposed to the central bank as input for setting the official criteria. An announcement on the issue is scheduled for June 15. The committee also urged the government to waive corporate tax on private company revenues generated through debt restructuring, such as purchasing assets for debt payment. Deputy Finance Minister Pisit Lee-artham previously agreed in principle with the private sector's request and ordered the Revenue Department to make the necessary revisions.
