CAR sales in the region are plummeting as disposable income shrinks, and once obliging banks and finance companies have stopped offering easy money for that prestige marque. Those who already own a vehicle are holding on to it - that is, if it has not already been repossessed because of payment defaults. But it is not just individual dreams of automotive luxury that are being shattered, as currencies crash throughout the region and economies sink with them. The auto industry has also stalled, while growth through exports - the key to development for many of the region's industries -seems questionable at best, even with devalued currencies to help sales abroad. Hardest hit has been Thailand which became a regional auto hub for both parts production and car assembly in the booming 1980s and early 1990s as manufacturers from Japan, Europe and the United States realised the potential of Asia's markets. Tens of thousands of auto workers are now jobless in an industry once seen as vital to industrial growth. The manufacturers - mainly Japanese -which once targeted the middle-class Thai market have turned their focus to exports and introducing smaller, cheaper vehicles, prompted by the crumbling purchasing power, the baht devaluation and Thailand's banking crisis. As a result, exports soared 201.06% last year with 42,218 units shipped, while value jumped by 281.9% to 16.2 billion baht (RM1.14 billion). Other numbers, however, are grim. Production dropped 35.6% to 360,303 units in 1997 from 559,428 units a year earlier, while domestic car sales slumped 38.4% in 1997 to 363,156 units, from 589,126 units the previous year. The future looks `hopeless', says an analyst, who points out that since the middle of last year, banks, finance houses and leasing companies have imposed more stringent requirements for car loans. These include down payments of as much as 50%, compared with 10% previously; double-digit interest rates; and reduced payment terms, generally from five years to three. The desperation encountered in Thailand is also felt in Malaysia and Indonesia, the other two main car producing nations in the region. The future holds little promise for Indonesia, where the deal between Bimantara, which is controlled by one of President Suharto's sons, and South Korea's Hyundai to build cars in Indonesia has been suspended. The deal between Kia, the South Korean brand rescued by its government last October, and Indonesia's Timor, which is controlled by another presidential son, looks even less secure. Kia had undertaken to supply cars and technology to Timor, Indonesia's national car company, which was to have enjoyed massive tax and tariff advantages over rival marques. But following Jakarta's agreement with the International Monetary Fund, those privileges have been rescinded. The Timor car, priced at only Rp18 million (slightly less than RM7,000), went on sale last October and to date, only 20,000 units have moved - many of them forced on government agencies and private operations. Another 23,000 are languishing in a compound near the Jakarta docks awaiting owners willing to drive them away. At present, 36,000 workers or about 60% of the industry's workforce, have been sent home on indefinite leave, while prices of mostly imported spare parts have risen in rupiah terms by 90-100% since the beginning of last year. Car sales are expected to drop by half this year, from more than 380,000 units sold last year, as a result of rising prices, estimated at 30%, and a credit squeeze. Astra International, Indonesia's largest vehicle assembler that once boasted of not being able to make enough to meet demand, is finding it difficult to score with its top-selling Toyota Kijang, despite a larger engine and a more streamlined look. Malaysia's carmakers, likewise, have not found the going easy. Domestic demand has collapsed with sales dropping to 70% in the first quarter, compared to a year ago. Proton, the largest of the national brands, and Perodua, its more recent counterpart, have scaled back in the face of the depressed home market, and the lack of extensive export markets. The financial turmoil sweeping through the region is also causing massive pain to car manufacturers in Japan, Asia's biggest carmaker, that has enjoyed strong returns from the region since the early 1960s. Coming just months after a drop in domestic sales because of higher local sales tax, it caused heavy losses as investments in the region crumbled. Of the big carmakers, only top-ranking Toyota, and Honda have bucked the trend, earning record profits. The others - Mitsubishi Motors, Nissan and Mazda - are on their knees. Nissan, say analysts, may have scraped a profit, but it has been in trouble for years. Both Mazda and Mitsubishi incurred heavy losses and are now burdened with huge debts. New vehicle registrations in Japan fell 3.8% to 4.49 million units last year, while for this year, analysts expect a further 1.5% drop to 4.43 million units. There is also likely to be a decline in royalty payments and revenues for technology transfers from the new carmakers that the Japanese have nurtured in the region, such as Malaysia's Proton that has grown because of Mitsubishi. Massive retrenchment has taken place as car markers were forced to curb production and investment in anticipation of leaner times ahead. Toyota, Nissan and Honda have also budgeted for lower direct exports to Southeast Asia and reduced sales by the joint ventures they dominate in the region. Car exports from Japan to the region during the first quarter crashed by 43.7% with exports to Indonesia and Thailand, the two worst hit countries, plunging 95% to 254 units and 92.5% to 600 units respectively.

BC-Germany-Saliva Testing
German police-record error hindered child murder investigation
By ANNE THOMPSON Associated Press Writer
FRANKFURT, Germany (AP) _ Police admitted Tuesday to record-keeping mistakes that allowed a convicted rapist to avoid detection early in the investigation into the rape and murder of an 11-year-old girl. The killing of Christina Nytsch gained international publicity after police resorted to the extraordinary measure of taking saliva samples from 16,400 men for DNA testing _ the largest mass genetic test to date. Weeks of lab tests produced a suspect: Ronny Rieken, saliva sample No. 3,889, was arrested Friday and confessed to raping and killing Christina after his DNA linked him to the crime scene. The 30-year-old mechanic had been imprisoned for three years until 1993 for rape. But Rieken's record was not in Lower Saxony state files that could have aided police in the investigation and made the saliva test unnecessary. ``There is absolutely no information in his files of his previous conviction,'' Detlef Ehrike, police spokesman for the northeastern state told NDR 1 Radio Niedersachsen on Tuesday. Ehrike blamed police in Oldenburg for faulty record keeping. They arrested Rieken for rape in 1989, but files mentioned only his convictions for theft and house-breaking. Oldenburg police were investigating how the error happened, a local official, Herma Heyten, said Tuesday. A series of highly publicized sex crimes against children in recent years has galvanized efforts to improve crime records and to make it easier for police to cooperate. Christina's murder _ and the saliva testing that nabbed a suspect _ intensified a push by Interior Minister Manfred Kanther to start a national database of DNA from convicted sex criminals. The lower house of parliament is expected to pass a law approving it before summer break. Database information could be compared to biological evidence found at crime scenes, such as saliva, semen, blood, or tissue. Police in Germany's 16 states could cross-reference data, a tactic already used in Austria, Britain, the Netherlands and the United States. The interior minister said Monday that Christina's killing proved the need for a database as a tool for solving and preventing crimes. If a database had existed, he suggested, the confessed killer's DNA would have been on record because of his previous crime, making it easier to catch him and discouraging him from striking again. Christina disappeared March 16. Her body was found five days later in woods near her home in Struecklingen, a village of about 3,500 people near the Dutch border. Soon after, police in the nearby city of Cloppenburg asked the 18,000 men ages 18-30 in the region to have their saliva tested. Voluntary DNA testing has worked in small communities where peer pressure drove everyone to participate _ including the killer. Despite the large size of this test sample _ 16,400 men volunteered _ the technique apparently worked. Rieken confessed not only to Christina's murder but also to the unsolved 1996 rape of another 11-year-old girl. He has been charged with murder and sexual abuse. (aet-cb)

THE Bank of Thailand has exercised its legal power ordering commercial banks to re-adjust their lending plans in the second half of this year in an apparent effort to stimulate loans to the cash-strapped business sector. A letter, endorsed by deputy governor Tanya Sirivedhin, was dispatched to all banks, requiring them to submit their plans by June 11. The order came right after the central bank acknowledged a 2.9 per cent decline in combined credit growth during the first quarter of 1998. The figure was compared with the same period last year. The letter said that banks' lending plans should be re-adjusted, given the continued stability of the baht as well as a rising number of deposits. ''Liquidity problems in banks should be eased to a certain degree, so that lending activities can continue [to boost the economy],'' it added. So far, banks have refrained from providing loans to local companies as risks were relatively high in the midst of the country's worst-ever economic era. The central bank's economic data showed a continued drop in credit growth. Commercial bank credits in November last year fell 17.6 per cent year on year. The decline continued in February. The March preliminary figures also showed a drop. The central bank also estimated that commercial bank credits will fall further in April. As a consequence of the dry liquidity, lending interest rates were also hiked. Meanwhile, the BOT is reconsidering its stand on the financial institutions' non-performing loans (NPLs) after the International Monetary Fund said the Thai economy this year is projected to stay in the negative territory of 4 to 5.5 per cent from the previous forecast of 3 to 3.5 per cent. Governor MR Chatu Mongol Sonakul noted that such reconsideration will help the BOT estimate how much the banks needed for recapitalisations to better cope with the rising NPLs. However, he believed that large banks, whose recapitalisation plans have been fully completed, should have adequate amount of capital to clear the NPLs. Bangkok Bank's NPLs are expected to stay at 30-35 per cent this year. ''We will call for a meeting with financial institutions next month,'' Chatu Mongol said. He said that despite the shortened period of stop-accrued interest from six to three months, loan restructuring is now under way and that it will help reduce the NPLs of a number of banks. As a result, banks are not needed to set their loan-loss provisions higher, paving the way for them to continue lending to the real sector in order to help cash-strapped companies out of trouble. Thailand has come under tight liquidity which threatens to increase bankruptcies. Domestic problems discouraged banks from lending fear their provisioning burden will exceed their ability. Most foreign creditors have also shunned lending to Thai companies amid rising risks. Agence France-Presse reported from Sydney that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia Ltd on Sunday became the latest of the country's big four banks to reduce loan exposure to Asia, cutting it back by 8 per cent. Its total loans to the region now stand at A$6.24 billion (US$4 billion), down from $6.74 billion in December. ''We are not going through a dramatic pullback -- we felt we had a modest exposure to start with,'' said Michael Ullmer, head of risk management. Most of the pullback was from Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea and achieved by not renewing loan facilities when they matured. The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd, whose share price has suffered from the Asian economic crisis, said on Sunday that its policy about doing business in Asia would become more conservative. ANZ has the largest exposure to Asia of the major Australian banks. Earlier this year, its rating outlook was downgraded from stable to negative by ratings agencies Standard and Poor's and Moody's Investors Service as a direct result of its exposure to higher risk markets in the region. It has reduced overall exposure to Asia by 38 per cent from $16 billion to $11 billion during the first half of the current financial year. ''I would never anticipate our aggregate exposure levels to increase from the current levels,'' chief executive John McFarlane told Channel Nine television. Exposure would drift down ''naturally'' from where it is. Westpac Banking Corp last week said it had reduced its exposure by 23 per cent during the past six months to $7.96 billion, although National Australia Bank Ltd has indicated it is happy with its $16.5 billion Asian exposure.

FOREIGN capital inflows, worth more than Bt300 billion, are now in the pipeline, but the debts of some companies, owned by the 56 defunct finance firms, have not been restructured due to the Financial Sector Restructuring Authority's legal process. Bank of Thailand Governor MR Chatu Mongol Sonakul said the new money is expected to flow into the country during the next couple of months. The expected capital will be in the form of joint-venture firms such as steel or property loan management companies. However, loans of these firms belong to the 56 troubled companies whose debts are now under the management of the FRA. According to the law, such debts must be auctioned and are forbidden to be restructured. Chatu Mongol noted that the central bank will negotiate with the FRA to let these debts go under the hammer much sooner, so that it will help keep the debt restructuring process going. ''If we can restructure these debts, the expected amount of foreign capital will flow into the country,'' he added. Furthermore, the central bank is now undertaking a study on debt restructuring to meet international standards in accordance with the Office of the Currency Controller (OCC), a supervisory department of the US Federal Reserves overlooking financial institutions. According to the fourth letter of intent submitted to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the BOT is required to go ahead with the debt restructuring and re-estimation of collateral before mid-June. Hoping that the FRA's legal block will be resolved, Chatu Mongol noted that such inflows will help strengthen the baht and inflationary pressure would also be eased to a certain degree. ''We are now trying hard to reduce illiquidity in pursuit of a possible cut in interest rates, but inflation as well as the baht's stability must be closely watched,'' he explained. Meanwhile, the director-general of the Fiscal Policy Office Sommai Phasee told Reuters the government is planning to issue bonds of Bt500 billion in the local market within the next one or two months. He told the news agency that new money raised from the bonds will help restructure debts of financial institutions. ''Such money will help compensate short-term debts of the Financial Institutions Development Fund (FIDF),'' Sommai added. Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda was earlier quoted as saying that the plan for a global bond issue worth US$1 billion to U$2 billion may be delayed, given the regional market volatility. The bonds were expected to be issued in July. Sommai said the government is hoping to issue the bonds prior to the end of the 1998 fiscal year, but the plan would be postponed if the market condition is unfavourable. Nevertheless, Deputy Prime Minister Supachai Panichpakdi said after the economic meeting Monday that global bonds will be issued on schedule in spite of the regional economic battering. But the Finance Ministry will be cautious about issuing the bonds. The market situation and appropriate timing will also be taken into account. ''Thailand should make a speedy move to boost the economy and restore foreign investor confidence,'' Supachai noted. He also assigned the central bank to study the impact of the economic slowdown.

BC-Sports-Cycling-Tour of Italy 1st Ld-Writethru
Guerini wins grueling 17th stage, Pantani takes pink jersey
Eds: UPDATES with detail, quotes
SELVA DI VAL GARDENA, Italy (AP) _ Marco Pantani, the best ``Giro'' climber, beat Alex Zuelle by more than four minutes in Tuesday's grueling 17th stage of the Tour of Italy ending in the Dolomite mountains and snatched the pink jersey of overall leader from his Swiss rival. The bald-headed ace of the Mercatone Uno team placed second to fellow-Italian Giuseppe Guerini at the finish line in this resort of the Gardena valley and achieved his goal to wear the pink jersey for the first time in his career. With the two next stages including mountainous passes and uphill finishes, Pantani has the chance to strengthen his lead and win the 1998 Tour of Italy which ends in Milan Sunday. The stage victory was the first ever by Guerini at the Giro. Pantani and Guerini broke away as the road climbed to the Fedaia pass _ the next to last in a stage including four passes - and Zuelle quickly slid three minutes behind. The leading duo widened the advantage on the last mountain before the finish _ the Giro highest point at the 2,214-meter high Sella Pass - and Guerini won the two-way sprint at ease. Zuelle, an against-the-clock specialist who had beaten Pantani by more than three minutes in Sunday's individual time test at Trieste, finished 4:37 minutes behind on Tuesday and fell to fourth overall, 1:01 minutes behind the new leader. Guerini completed the 217-kilometer (134.5-mile) stage from Asiago to Selva di Val Gardena in six hours, 16 minutes, 58 seconds. Pantani, who trailed Zuelle by 3:48 at the start of the 17th stage, vaulted from fourth to first place in the standings 30 seconds ahead of Russian runnerup Pavel Tonkov, who finished fourth at Selva di Val Gardena. Guerini moved to third overall, only one second behind Tonkov, a Giro winner in 1996. ``When I attacked, along with Guerini, I just wanted to reduce my gap from Zuelle,'' Pantani explained at the finish line, after spraying cheering fans with champagne from the podium. Thousands of enthusiastic people lined along the roads taking to the Dolomite passes and to the finish line of the toughest Giro stage so far. ``I did not believe that Zuelle could lose so much. After the bad beating suffered in the time trial (Sunday) I was dreaming of revenge, of a day like today,'' Pantani said. Pantani, 28, was a champion of bad luck in 1995 when he suffered two consecutive bad spills and a broken leg. He was sidelined for the entire 1996 cycling season. Colombian Chepe Gonzales, who placed third 2:04 minutes behind the winner, was one of the day heroes as he led on the road climbing to the Fedaia pass and surrendered to Pantani and Guerini only on the last tough uphill section of Sella, named Cima Coppi after the late Italian ``Campionissimo'' Fausto Coppi. Zuelle, who already lost and recaptured the pink jersey twice in the current Giro, will have an opportunity to fight back in the next-to-last stage Saturday, an individual time trial of 34 kilometers (21 miles) in the Swiss lake resort of Lugano. Defending Giro champion Ivan Gotti, suffering from back pains and with a gap of 12:42 minutes overall, did not start Tuesday. Those who retired during the stage included Italian top sprinter Mario Cipollini, winner of four stages this year. Wednesday's leg of 115 kilometers (71.3 miles) ends at 1,760 meters of altitude of Alpe di Pampeago. (pv)

THAI Prasit Insurance Plc has acquired ownership of its headquarters building and expects to buy another building once Bangkok Bank of Commerce and a debtor-client reach an agreement on the status of ownership, a top executive said. A case being investigated by police which involves the two buildings and allegations of embezzlement was being sorted out, Thai Prasit chief executive Sukhatep Chansrichawla said. ''We are prepared to clarify everything. It is not a case of embezzlement as claimed,'' he said. Sukhatep's comments came as Commerce Minister Supachai Panichpakdi said he has been receiving reports regularly on the insurance firm's move to solve any problem related to outstanding debts by clients. Supachai urged the media to check both sides of any insurance news before publishing to avoid unwarranted panic by the public. Sukhatep denied any fund misappropriation and said that of the Bt800 million collateralised loan for the office buildings, the Bt500-million headquarters building has already been transferred to it, and the Bangkok Bank of Commerce and its customer will shortly settle ownership of the Bt300-million ICE Tower. ''The clients used the land title as collateral. There was no damage to the company,'' he said. Meanwhile, he said that of the loans totalling Bt300 million to three customers, Bt200 million was repaid. The remainder is due on June 26. The case is also under police investigation, but Sukhatep is confident of clearing everything up. He said an employee of a property and land appraisal company -- which is not related to the insurance company -- had falsified a document. The case was investigated by the Insurance Office. The person who faked the document was later found to have committed suicide. ''We did not have any knowledge of it but are willing to clarify everything to the police.''

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo, UPDATE
Romania and Macedonia ask for U.S. troops in Kosovo
BUCHAREST, Romania (AP) _ The foreign ministers of Romania and Macedonia urged the United States Tuesday to send troops to the troubled Kosovo region. ``Their presence would help to stop an extension of the crisis in southeastern Europe,'' Romanian Foreign Minister Andrei Plesu said after a meeting with his Macedonian counterpart Blagoj Handziski. The two did not specify whether they sought U.S. troops in Kosovo proper or in countries the Serbian province borders, like Macedonia or Albania. American troops are already in Macedonia, as part of an 800-strong U.N. peacekeeping mission originally established to contain a possible spill-over from the Bosnian war. The two ministers said their governments would support the autonomy of Kosovo inside Yugoslavia. (ma/gj)

THE Siam Commercial Bank Monday clarified that it intends to sell a total of 3.045 billion new shares to local and foreign investors in a major recapitalisation for Bt40 billion fresh funds to cover its position over the next two to three years. Jada Wattanasiritham, executive vice president of the bank, said the plan will increase SCB's capital from the current paid-up Bt5.8 billion to Bt40 billion via issuance of 3,400 million new shares, of which 20 million shares, 146 million shares and 200 million shares will be reserved for euro-convertible debentures, warrants and new convertible debentures, respectively. SCB intends to sell 45 per cent of the new offering of 3,045 million shares to Thai investors and the rest 55 per cent to foreign investors to maintain majority Thai ownership of 51 per cent. Currently, Thai ownership is 66 to 67 per cent, while foreign ownership is 33 to 34 per cent. Based on Monday's closing price of SCB at Bt17.75 per share, the bank would have to sell 2,253.5 million shares to get a total of Bt40 billion earmarked for recapitalisation. At this stage, it is not known at what price SCB will get for its offering and how many shares will have to be sold to get a total of Bt40 billion. Jada said SCB will offer new shares to 17 types of investors, including the Crown Property Bureau, which currently holds 28 per cent of the bank, and foreign insurance firms, among others. Earlier, American International Group (AIG) was reported to be interested in acquiring 10 per cent of SCB's equity. Jada said SCB will have a capital adequacy of 18 per cent under Bank of International Settlement (BIS) rule if its recapitalisation of Bt40 billion is successful, up significantly from the current 10.6 per cent. At 18 per cent, SCB's capital adequacy will be close to that of Thai Farmers Bank and Bangkok Bank, which raised Bt33 billion and Bt40 billion, respectively, in March and April this year. Jada claimed that the timing for the SCB's recapitalisation was right, even though some market analysts have contended that SCB would have fewer prospects of attracting foreign money after TFB and BBL recently got a combined amount of more than Bt70 billion from recapitalisation. ''It is neither too late or too early [given that SCB would have to compete with TFB and BBL if it were to recapitalise earlier],'' she said, adding that SCB will move swiftly to complete the recapitalisation because there will also be competition for funds from Korean and Malaysian, among other regional banks, for new funds.

ELECTION Commission (EC) member Yuwarat Kamolvej Monday voiced concern about achieving a high turn-out for absentee balloting among Thai workers abroad. The EC, tasked with organising national polls for MPs and senators, has drafted a new regulation for absentee voting for overseas Thais, as mandated by the new charter for the first time. Yuwarat disclosed that the EC would hold further consultations with Thai diplomats on the designation of polling stations and the balloting procedures in order to facilitate voters' convenience. The EC is particularly keen to encourage voters living abroad to exercise their voting rights, specially in countries which have a large settlement of Thais, he said. There are about 2 million Thai voters living in various countries around the world, with the largest concentration in the United States. Thailand to summon envoys THE Foreign Ministry will summon the Bangkok-based ambassadors of India and Pakistan to express its deep concern on their series of nuclear tests which have badly affected security in South Asia, a senior Foreign Ministry official said Monday. Foreign Minister Surin Pitsuwan has ordered that the ministry convey Thailand's deep concern to both ambassadors on the nuclear testings which have drawn outrage from the international community, ministry spokesman Kobsak Chutikul said. Kobsak said that the ambassadors, who will meet together with a senior Foreign Ministry official, would be informed that the testings will have affect on an economic pact which comprises Bangladesh, India, Burma, Sri Lanka and Thailand. Fume checking resumes ALMOST half the vehicles tested by authorities at 15 checkpoints throughout the city Monday emit fumes exceeding legal limits. Municipal police, traffic police and Pollution Control Department officials Monday resumed operations at the checkpoints after they were temporarily shut down since April following allegations of police extortion. Out of 678 vehicles tested Monday, 316, comprising 47 cars and 269 buses and trucks, did not pass the test. The checkpoints by the three bodies which started operating in October last year had collected over Bt8.9 million in fines. Under the Land Transport Act, motorists whose vehicles emit excessive fume limits have to pay a fine of up to Bt5,000. Tanayong project deadline THE scheduled commencement of service on the Tanayong elevated train project in early 2000 may be brought forward before Dec 5, 1999, to mark the 72th birthday of His Majesty the King, City Clerk Prasert Samalapa said Monday. ''The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration thinks that the service should be available before the auspicious time, and has therefore urged that the project be completed earlier,'' he said. Reporting the project's progress, Prasert said conditions of traffic lanes at the main project sites on major city roads would completely return to normal on August 31. Rice mill owners given relief Rice mill owners have been temporarily allowed to hire foreign workers until authorities help recruit Thai workers to replace them by next month. At a meeting Monday of a committee to solve problems concerning foreign workers, the Immigration Bureau told the mill owners that they could hire until July 10. The meeting resolved that a panel be set up, to be led by Labour Ministry permanent secretary Niphon Bunyamani, to help recruit Thai workers to work in the mills by next month. More than 200 rice mills nationwide have reportedly been forced to shut down since the government started repatriating foreign workers in May. About a hundred mill owners gathered last week to ask the government to recruit Thai workers for them.

TO provide the physically challenged with equal education opportunities, the Non-Formal Education Department (NFED) and various non-governmental organisations have joined handed to hold special non-formal courses for the handicapped. This activity is in response to the increasing number of handicapped individuals who wish to benefit from a solid education so that they are able to improve their prospects in life. The courses are equivalent to formal and vocational training under the present education system, and aim to prepare participants for undergraduate courses and/or the employment market. The organisers are also offering fundamental Braille reading for the visually impaired, and lessons in sign language for the deaf. Any non-governmental organisations interested in joining the project and running classes with the NFED for the disabled are requested to contact the NFED. For more information, call 280 2942. The hotline service is being implemented at all government-run hospitals in Bangkok and neighbouring provinces. The hotline service is intended to minimise emotional stress and help residents overcome shyness or embarrassment of going to see a psychiatrist. Use of pesticides and quality control advice KASETSART University Press is pleased to announce the launching of two new publications: -Technology Karn Chai Sarn Kamjad Sattroo Phuet (The Technology of Pesticide Application) by Dr Uap Sarnthoy of the Department of Entomology, Kasetsart University. - Sareera Witthaya Lae Technology Lak Karn Kep Kiew Phak Lae Pholamai (Agronomy and Techniques of Harvesting Vegetables and Fruits) by Dr Jingtae Siriphanit of the Faculty of Agriculture's Horticultural Department. BC-Italy-Friar Sentenced
Italian friar sentenced for the murder of an African woman
BERGAMO, Italy (AP) _ An Italian Capuchin friar who admitted killing an immigrant woman was sentenced to eight years and eight months in jail Tuesday, the ANSA news agency reported. Fabrizio Moretti, 32, strangled the 22-year-old woman from Sierra Leone in her apartment in this northern city last September. Moretti was suspended from his priestly duties after the incident. When police came to the scene, he admitted killing the woman, Aminata Harding. He later said Ms. Harding had invited him to dinner and asked for help in renewing her residence permit. Moretti claimed he lost his head and strangled her when she threatened to report the dinner to his superiors if he didn't help her stay in Italy. The prosecution had sought a 15-year jail term. The Ms. Harding had two children, who were awarded 100 million lire (around dlrs 57,000) each in damages, ANSA said. (ar/djw)

HARARE, Zimbabwe (AP) _ A former aide testified Tuesday that he watched pornographic videos at State House with ex-President Canaan Banana who is charged with homosexual offenses. ``At times, he would ask me to commit what we were watching,'' Jefta Dube, 36, said on the second day of the trial. Banana, 62, an ordained Methodist minister and figurehead president from 1980 to 1988, has pleaded not guilty to two counts of sodomy, three of attempted sodomy, and six of indecent assault. Eleven people allege Banana made unwanted sexual advances toward them. Banana's attorney Chris Andersen intends to challenge the legality of Zimbabwe's ban on sodomy and to cite gender equality and privacy guarantees under the constitution, legal sources said. The law allows consensual sex between women. Andersen, who was justice minister under white-ruled Rhodesia, said Monday that any sexual intimacy with Banana took place with consent. The case is being closely watched by Zimbabwe's gay and lesbian communities who have been told by President Robert Mugabe that they are ``lower than pigs or dogs'' and have ``no rights at all''. Dube, a former police inspector, is serving a 10-year jail term for murder. Dube made the first allegations about Banana's homosexual advances during his trial last year. Psychiatrists testified Dube was only partly responsible for killing a constable he alleged had taunted him for being Banana's ``wife''. The prosecution claims top political figures and military commanders covered up Banana's homosexual indiscretions. Vice President Simon Muzenda and Justice Minister Emmerson Mnangagwa are expected to testify. Dube claimed that he reported Banana's assaults to Muzenda, who failed to take legal steps but transferred Dube to another post. Andersen said Dube's alleged dates of the offenses did not square with the official calendar of events.

Government presents package to cool Danish economy
COPENHAGEN, Denmark (AP) _ Fearing that Denmark's good times are on the verge of getting too good, the government on Tuesday proposed a package of measures to cool the economy. The Central Bank and private economists have been calling for more fiscal restraint since last year, warning that the economy could overheat. The package, which must be approved by the parliament, calls for measures including reducing the tax deduction for interest paid on mortgages. It also wants to make permanent the mandatory payment of 1 percent of income into pension funds _ a measure that was enacted on a one-year basis this year. The government also wants to raise gasoline and heating oil taxes by 50 oerer (3.4 cents) per liter (13 cents per gallon). (jo-jh)

IN the March 1998 edition of leading fashion magazine, Vanity Fair , Michael Shnayerson writes: ''With the looks of a matinee idol, the determination of a Panzer commander and the pop-culture antennae of a teenager, Tom Ford [Gucci's creative director] has turned a tired Italian leather-goods firm into a US$1 million international fashion force. Right now, Gucci is cooler than cool.'' The reigning doyenne of fashion critics, Suzy Menkes, of the International Herald Tribune agrees. ''He has a real sense for of what modern marketing is about.'' It is that sense of marketing that has made Ford's recent launch of Gucci first fragrance all the more successful. The world famous designer has been behind Gucci Envy for Men every step of the way and now Thai men too can revel in the sexy parfum . ''Envy'' is a rich blend of secret ingredients that are combined to reflect a sexy, cutting-edge modernity. The overall effect is a complex manly fragrance tamed with a luxurious elegance and the essence of desire. In an exclusive chat with The Nation , Ford reveals how he has used his past experiences and memories to produce such an impressive fragrance for the modern man. To him, it's much more than an ordinary male perfume. What is your best memory of being seduced by the power of fragrance? ''My grandmother. I used to go and visit her when I was a little boy and she would pick me up and she always smelt the same. Even two or three years ago when I bought the house that had been hers -- it's in New Mexico -- I walked in and I could smell her -- she hadn't lived in that house for 20 years. I always associated that smell with fun. Did you find creating Envy challenging? I found it really fun -- I love fragrance, I love smell, I love packing, I love bottles, I wear fragrance a lot, probably too much, it was a lot of fun. How do you feel when you wear Envy? Again, there's that old word 'sexy'. But fragrance to me, and I said this in the video [advertising the new product] is very sexy. You need to want to bite the person wearing it. Fragrance to me is a very oral thing. Even though it's not necessarily oral, things that smell good usually make you want to put them in your mouth. A great fragrance for me -- you do not want necessarily want to eat it -- but you want to get really close to it so you can smell it some more. How did you approach the task of transcending the previous image of Gucci fragrance? Luckily I don't even think about the previous image of Gucci perfumes and I don't think most other people do either. I don't think the customer even knows it exists. It was the same thing we were faced with when we wanted to relaunch Gucci accessories and -- luckily or unluckily -- most of our customers had died. What was the inspiration behind the name ''Envy''? Envy is one of those words that can be both positive and negative. It has a slightly negative connotation because you are taught that you should not feel envy and you shouldn't be envious. But really it's just another name for desire, another name for wanting something. When you want something someone else has, when you want something you do not have, when you want something that you used to have and you don't have anymore -- it's desire in a sense. Yet, I like that double meaning -- of it being a positive and a negative thing. Russia won't revoke arms sales to India over nuclear tests
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russia will not cancel a lucrative arms deal with India in response to its nuclear tests, and appealed Tuesday to both India and Pakistan to sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. ``Moscow is interested in preventing the escalation of tension between Delhi and Islamabad, in neutralizing the dangerous consequences of the nuclear tests carried out by these countries,'' Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman Valery Nesterushkin said. He urged both India and Pakistan to sing the non-proliferation and Comprehensive Test Ban treaties, the Interfax news agency said. Belarus also joined the protests against the nuclear tests Wednesday, saying they ``have sharpened our worry about a possible chain reaction of nuclear proliferation not only in South Asia but also beyond it.'' Belarus gave up the nuclear weapons it inherited from the former Soviet Union. ``Belarus, which several years ago has made a historic choice in favor of discarding the nuclear potential it possessed, and which is a party in a number of major agreements on nuclear disarmament, cannot but feel a special responsibility and concern in connection with such turn of events,'' a Belarusian Foreign Ministry statement said. The nuclear tests in India and Pakistan will be discussed Wednesday, when Russia plays host to a meeting of top diplomats from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, ITAR-Tass reported. Foreign ministers of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council _ including Russia _ plan similar talks Thursday in Geneva, and discussions on whether to impose sanctions, as favored by the United States. Russia has no plans to cancel its contracts for the sale of Su-30 fighters to India, representatives of the Sukhoi aircraft company said Tuesday, according to Interfax. India already has received eight Su-30 fighters under a dlrs 1.8 billion deal to buy 40 advanced aircraft from Russia, concluded in 1996. The rest are expected to be delivered by 2000. India is among the most lucrative customers for Russia's weapons industry, and Moscow is eager to protect the much-needed market. (ad/ls)

Two killed, two injured in Tehran explosion opposition group claims responsibility, CHANGES overline.
Eds: UPDATES with television reporting two killed, two injured;
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ An explosion in a government building Tuesday killed two people and injured two others in the capital Tehran, Iranian television said. An Iranian opposition group in exile claimed responsibility in a statement faxed to The Associated Press in Cairo, Egypt. But Iranian news reports indicated it was an accident. The opposition Mujahedeen Khalq said its military units detonated a bomb at the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office, killing ``scores of torturers and interrogators.'' It said the building was demolished. The prosecutor's office apprehends and tries Iranians violently opposed to the 1979 Islamic revolution that installed the rule of clergy in Iran. The Khalq, the largest Iranian opposition, is committed to overthrowing Iran's Islamic government by force. There was no immediate response by the Iranian government to the allegations by the Khalq, which is based in Baghdad, Iraq and whose members have also been targeted by the Prosecutor's Office. Iranian television gave no details except to say two people were killed and two injured in the midmorning blast in eastern Tehran. However, the official Islamic Republic News Agency said the blast was caused by explosives, and indicated that the material was being brought to the court as evidence in a case under investigation when it went off accidentally. The different reports could not be immediately reconciled. IRNA quoted an official source as saying that the blast was the result of ``negligence in transporting the explosives related to one of the cases under investigation at the court.'' In an earlier report, IRNA had said the blast was caused by a briefcase bomb and that it injured three people. But subsequent IRNA reports made no mention of the briefcase bomb. The Mujahedeen Khalq said it carried out the bombing in retaliation for the slaying of eight Khalq members on Nov. 2, 1997 by agents of the Intelligence Ministry and the Prosecutor's Office. In its statement, the Khalq said ambulance sirens could be heard in the area for several hours after the explosions. Later, security forces sealed off nearby streets and began searching vehicles, it said. But the guerrillas who planted the bomb escaped, the statement said. The explosion comes as Iran is gripped by an intensifying power struggle between the moderate faction of President Mohammad Khatami and hard-line opponents who oppose his social and political reforms. Their rivalry has led to large public demonstrations in Tehran and other cities in recent weeks that have sometimes turned violent. pvs-ti/vj

The farang lady who was telephoning me didn't give her name. As she spoke, she sounded amused, though, as if she was inviting me to join in a joke. I couldn't quite place her voice for a moment until she said, ''So, Laurie. I understand you had lunch with my husband today.'' And then I knew. Well, a home-wrecker I'm not. The hours a reporter keeps are not conducive to setting up as ''the other woman''. Besides, what man looking for a home away from home would snuggle up to five cats, 25 fish and 10 turtles? But I understand a farang wife's fears. Marriages break up all the time in all countries, but whether the marriage is 10, 20 or even 30 years along, there's something about Thailand that tests a relationship. The give-and-take nurtured over years, the shared memories and experiences of other times in other countries can turn into an insubstantial dream of another life. What does a farang wife face when she finds out her husband is involved with another woman, when her husband tells her (if she's lucky) that the marriage is over? Apart from potential financial problems, she is lonely, her self-confidence devastated, whether or not she's been happy in her marriage. It doesn't matter if the other woman is a bar girl, a secretary or a business associate. The wife is left in limbo as the social circle she belonged to with her husband disintegrates. I know a number of wives whose lives have suddenly been halved, more or less. You can call the other women homewreckers if you wish, but somewhere at the core is one unhappy man. As far as possible, I think I understand the men who leave. Living in Thailand has opened up new worlds for them. They have a sense of freedom away from the constraints of society in their home countries. Everyone here knows foreigners who do what they would never consider doing in their own country. You can joke about male menopause all you wish, but it's there. Also there is the jolt the man gets as he notices other people -- and himself. He's getting older. The hair is going, the body too. He looks at his wife, his family, his life, and one day (or night), the thought comes to him unbidden: ''Is this all there is? Is this all I can expect from my life?'' It isn't the wife's fault. She may be thinking the same thing about her life, for all we know. But when he opts for the other woman, she knows he's being self-centred, valuing a relationship so little that he can toss it out without remorse. He, on the other hand, doesn't think he's being selfish. It's his last chance in this life for something more. She says (more or less), ''Get real. This is all there is.'' He says (more or less), ''Get real. This is not all there is.'' And what of friends? Well, whether or not they agree with the man's decision to end the marriage, they still see him socially. The wife is dropped. Splat. Or they transform her from a weekend friend to a lonely woman they invite for dinner on Tuesday nights. They still enjoy gossiping, though. Well-meaning friends are sometimes the first to inform the wife of the husband's outside interests, as I was learning from that telephone call. As soon as the lady made that comment, I knew who she was -- the wife of a farang managing director of a major company here. Yes, I had had lunch with her husband that day, along with two other reporters from The Nation , as well as the man's secretary and his public relations manager. Somewhere in that restaurant lurked a ''friend'' who recognised the husband, ignored the accompanying contingent and decided to tell the wife about the strange farang woman sitting at the same table. We finished our meal at 2 pm. By 2.30, the wife had been informed. Except that the wife knew immediately who I was. We're friends, not close friends, just two people who enjoy each other's company when we do meet. So when the friend presented the melancholy news of her husband's philandering, the wife burst into laughter. ''Oh, that was just Laurie,'' she said. ''She must have been interviewing my husband.'' I've often wondered about that ''just''. On the other hand, I'm grateful for having been allowed the chance to participate in crushing a nasty sort of friend. Questions about living in Bangkok? BC-Air France-Strike, 5th Ld-Writethru
Talks under way in Air France pilots' strike
EDS: UPDATES with French comment, details on strike talks AP Photos PAR106,109 By IAN PHILLIPS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Top brass at Air France sat down with striking pilots' unions Tuesday in an attempt to keep the World Cup from becoming a no-show event for thousands of fans. The walkout at the World Cup's official airline, in its second day, was already causing scheduling nightmares for teams preparing for the soccer championship that begins June 10. The president of the state-owned airline, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, was among officials who opened talks at 4 p.m. (1400 GMT) with the unions representing 3,200 pilots, at the company's headquarters at Charles de Gaulle airport north of Paris. In an interview published Tuesday, Spinetta said there was ``still a lot of work to do'' to settle the salary dispute with the pilots and suggested postponing talks until after the World Cup ends July 12. ``Putting off the talks until the summer is absolutely conceivable,'' Spinetta told the daily Le Parisien. He said the company was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike, which was forcing tens of thousands of people worldwide to look for other ways to travel. Air France's main pilots' union called the 15-day action to protest 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. The walkout disrupted training for the French national team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. ``Yes, indeed a lot of players will arrive late because of the strike. It risks turning our whole day upside down,'' Jacquet said. At Charles de Gaulle airport, a shop employee sat alone Tuesday in an empty store stocked with World Cup insignia. Opposite was a newspaper stall where headlines read: ``World Cup held hostage,'' and ``World Cup in peril.'' After walking 70 kilometers (43 miles) from Paris to Chartres over the weekend with 10,000 other youths on a pilgrimage, Ellen Kerry was trying to get to New York on an Air France flight. ``We only found out when we got in the taxi that there was a strike. We could have saved the money and walked,'' said Kerry, whose home is in Virginia. At Marseille's Marignane Airport, passenger Pierre-Antoine Graziani was getting fed up waiting to get on a waiting list to fly to Paris. ``I'm told something different from one hour to another,'' he said. ``I might take my chances with the TGV,'' the high-speed French train. Air France said there would be a slight improvement in traffic Tuesday, with 16-18 percent of long-haul flights taking off, compared to 10 percent Monday, and 32 percent of short- and medium-haul flights scheduled. In total, 44 more flights were scheduled Tuesday, compared to Monday. Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France and would probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations if necessary. But the U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is flying its team to Paris on American Airlines, connecting to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses in France. Former French player Michel Platini, co-president of the World Cup organizing committee, accused the pilots Tuesday of ``taking the country hostage. ... This is the image of France at stake, not necessarily that of an airline.'' (ip-cb)

BC-Pakistan-Economy, 1st Ld-Writethru,0535
Analysts predict Pakistan may declare moratorium on debt repayment
EDs: UPDATES with comment from state bank government, Cabinet meeting; CORRECTS to dlrs 1.3 billion in 11th graf. ADDs byline By ARTHUR MAX Associated Press Writer
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) _ Pakistan may have to declare a moratorium on repaying its debts as international sanctions bite into its reserves, say financial analysts. The government also may devalue the Pakistani currency by 3-to-5 percent to discourage imports that are further draining the economy, said a report by the Dutch ABN Amro Bank NV obtained Tuesday. The grim outlook from one of Pakistan's top independent analytical groups was a result of a drop in Pakistan's international credit rating following sanctions imposed after it exploded a series of nuclear tests last month. The governor of the State Bank of Pakistan, Mohammed Yaqub, said the government had no intention of defaulting on its debts. ``There is no consideration of a moratorium on any debt. We have never defaulted on a single penny or a single day,'' he told Dow Jones Newswires in Karachi, Pakistan's financial hub. Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif cabinet met for six hours Tuesday to discuss new austerity measures, deciding to trim the number of public holidays from 20 to 11. To symbolize the a tightening of belts, Sharif dispensed with the cabinet's usual meat-snack lunch and ordered a simple meal of lentils, rice and green tea, said the state-run news agency Associated Press of Pakistan. Pakistan declared a state of emergency May 28, blocking foreign currency withdrawals for fear of a run on bank deposits of dlrs 13 billion. It also froze the exchange rate at 46 rupees to the dollar. Yaqub said such measures were temporary. Until last week, Pakistan had one of the most liberal exchange policies in South Asia, having made its currency fully convertible. Government reserves were a paltry dlrs 1.3 billion a week ago, just enough to cover three weeks worth of imports. Its foreign debt is dlrs 30 billion, of which it repays an estimated dlrs 4.7 billion per year. Standard and Poors, the international rating agency, downgraded Pakistan's long-term and short-term foreign currency issuer credit rating. That will make it tough for the treasury to borrow financing for its six-month oil import bill of dlrs 926 million, the report said. ``The possibility that Pakistan may have no option but to stop servicing some of its external debts becomes increasingly real,'' said the report. A debt moratorium, it said, would do ``irrevocable damage'' to Pakistan's standing in the capital markets and its ability to compete globally. After the U.S.-led sanctions were imposed, Prime Minister Sharif announced an austerity program, beginning with his own move from the newly opened 400-room government Secretariat, in a bid to cut non-development expenses. But the Amro report said the program was unlikely to help, since nearly half _ or 47.7 percent _ of Pakistan's non-development spending was earmarked to repay debts.

The gunman who pumped seven bullets into local legislative leader Marti Batres' car Friday really was aiming at two other people, with whom he had quarreled since school days, Judicial Police Director Mauricio Tornero Salinas said at a news conference. ``(Both persons) declared that the shots were fired at them because they had had arguments since they were students in secondary school,'' Tornero said Monday. It did not seem the shooting was politically motivated and Tornero suggested Batres' car simply was the mistaken target. Tornero added the eyewitnesses and assailant had known each other since scholastic days at secondary school No. 51, located in Ninos Heros de Chapultepec, the same neighborhood where Batres' car was riddled with bullets late Friday evening. Batres was unharmed, while his car was parked in front of the house of fellow local assemblywoman, Angeles Correa de Lucio, on Santa Maria Nativitas street between Castilla and Bolivar. His personal assistant, Jose Luis Santos, had to duck to escape injury. Police say they know who and where the assailant is, although they did not name him at the news conference held at Judicial Police headquarters. Tornero said the two people who came forward have given investigators a workable description of the shooter. ``(The persons) declared before public prosecutors that they recognize and fully identify the subject that shot'' at the car, Tornero said. Police said eyewitnesses told them the assailant didn't dismount his orange sport-type motorcycle when he fired in the direction of Batres' car. Both Batres and Correa de Lucio are members of the Party of the Democratic Revolution (PRD), the left-leaning party that controls the capital's city hall, as well as the local assembly, known as the ALDF. The apparent assault on Batres and Correa de Lucio would mark the 12th threat or attack of a PRD assembly member or official since Jan. 22 of this year.

BC-Germany-Bathtub Corpse
Probe ended into former German governor's death 10 years ago
LUEBECK, Germany (AP) _ Prosecutors closed a three-year investigation into the 1987 death of a state governor Tuesday, leaving still unsolved one of Germany's biggest postwar mysteries. Uwe Barschel was found dead in the bathroom of a Geneva hotel room 16 days after he resigned as governor of Schleswig-Holstein state because of his involvement in a smear campaign against a political rival. Swiss authorities originally ruled the death a probably suicide. But German prosecutors reopened the case on the basis of a toxicologist's conclusion that it was unlikely Barschel was capable of voluntarily taking a fatal dose of cyclobarbital since he had already ingested three other sedatives. New leads at the time pointed to possible links with the East German secret police, North Korean agents or arms shipments to Iran. After closing the case, prosecutors said it was likely that at least one other person entered the bathroom where the governor's drugged body was found. But there was not enough evidence to determine exactly the circumstances of his death. Luebeck prosecutor Heinrich Wille said investigators pursuing various arms deal theories even interviewed former Iranian President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr. But neither an arms deal, nor involvement with East Germany's Stasi or with North Korean agents could be substantiated, prosecutors said. And toxicologists remain in dispute about which drug killed Barschel and when, making it impossible to confirm that someone other than Barschel administered the fatal dose, Wille said. A lawyer representing Barschel's family, which has maintained the death was foul play, said he would review the decision to close the case. (im-cb)

BC-Iran-Bomb, 1st Ld-Writethru,0440
Two killed, two others injured in Tehran explosion opposition group claims responsibility, CHANGES overline.
Eds: UPDATES with television reporting two killed, two injured;
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ A bomb exploded Tuesday afternoon inside the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office in eastern Tehran, killing two people and injuring two others, Iranian television said. An Iranian opposition group in exile claimed responsibility in a statement faxed to The Associated Press in Cairo, Egypt. However, the official Islamic Republic News Agency said the blast was caused by explosives, and indicated the material was being brought to court as evidence in a case under investigation when it went off accidentally. The different reports could not be immediately reconciled. The opposition Mujahedeen Khalq said its military units detonated a bomb in the prosecutor's office, killing ``scores of torturers and interrogators.'' It said the building was demolished. The prosecutor's office apprehends and tries Iranians violently opposed to the 1979 Islamic revolution that installed the rule of clergy in Iran. The Khalq, the largest Iranian opposition, is committed to overthrowing Iran's Islamic government by force. There was no immediate response by the Iranian government to the allegations by the Khalq, which is based in Baghdad, Iraq, and whose members have also been targeted by the prosecutor's office. IRNA quoted an official source as saying that the blast was the result of ``negligence in transporting the explosives related to one of the cases under investigation at the court.'' In an earlier report, IRNA said the bomb was in a briefcase and that it injured three people. But subsequent IRNA reports made no mention of the briefcase bomb. The Mujahedeen Khalq said it carried out the bombing in retaliation for the slaying of eight Khalq members on Nov. 2, 1997, by agents of the Intelligence Ministry and the prosecutor's office. In its statement, the Khalq said ambulance sirens could be heard in the area for several hours after the explosions. Later, security forces sealed off nearby streets and began searching vehicles, it said. But the guerrillas who planted the bomb escaped, the statement said. The explosion comes as Iran is gripped by an intensifying power struggle between the moderate faction of President Mohammad Khatami and hard-liners who oppose his social and political reforms. Their rivalry has led to large public demonstrations in Tehran and other cities in recent weeks that have sometimes turned violent.

BC-Portugal-Nazi Gold
Portugal says it trusts its own investigators into Nazi gold
LISBON, Portugal (AP) _ Prime Minister Antonio Guterres said Tuesday that Portugal had nothing to hide about its wartime dealings with Nazi Germany and was keen to uncover any evidence about flows of gold allegedly looted from Holocaust victims. ``The Americans can say what they want. We are just interested in the truth,'' Guterres told reporters in reaction to Tuesday's publication in Washington of a U.S. government report detailing neutral nations, including Portugal, with Nazi Germany. Guterres said that Portugal had always treated the issue of Nazi gold with total openness. He stressed that two commissions, currently combing Portuguese wartime records, are due to publish reports by the end of the year detailing the extent of Portugal's dealings with Nazi Germany. According to the U.S. report, Portugal provided Germany's war machine with tungsten and other materials used to produce weapon-grade steel. The report said the Third Reich paid for much of this trade with gold looted from the banks of occupied countries and the melted-down valuables of Holocaust victims. The deputy governor of the Bank of Portugal said that earlier investigations had already revealed that Portugal sold essential raw materials to Nazi Germany during the war. ``The wolfram trade was known during the war and was monitored by the Allies, especially the British who we had informed about it from the start,'' Luis Campos e Cunha said in a telephone interview. Documents discovered last year in the U.S. National Archive showed that 79 truckloads of Nazi gold were sent to Portugal between January 1942 and May 1944. Portugal returned almost four tons of Nazi gold at the end of the war following a detailed investigation of the Bank of Portugal's gold reserves by Allied officials, Campos e Cunha said. (bh/jt)

Albright: Economic progress in LatAm, but major problems persist
CARACAS, Venezuela (AP) _ Democracy and free-market economic reforms have helped reduce rural poverty and improve the lives of women in Latin America, but major problems persist, U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said Tuesday. ``Despite the progress, huge challenges of underdevelopment remain,'' Albright told the Organization of American States. The benefits of open societies and open markets must be delivered to ``not just some, but all of our people.'' Addressing foreign ministers from 34 countries, Albright said children are staying in school longer, women are gaining more access to education and health care, and 1 million people are to receive loans for micro-enterprises in the next few years. Still, overall poverty in the region has gone up since 1980, with a record 210 million people now below the poverty line, according to the OAS. Latin America suffers the greatest gap between poor and rich in the world; in some countries, 10 percent of the population controls 50 percent or more of the wealth, the OAS says. Albright's one-day visit to Caracas was to end Tuesday when she departs for Washington and then Geneva for talks on nuclear testing in India and Pakistan. She urged OAS delegates to strongly condemn the testing. The three-day OAS meeting, which ends Wednesday, is to address subjects including corruption, drug trafficking, poverty and consolidating democracy.

BC-Russia-Economy, 4th Ld-Writethru
Russian markets bounce back slightly as Yeltsin lectures `oligarchs' comments, taxpayers' meeting. CHANGES byline.
Eds: AMs. RECASTS and UPDATES throughout with fresh quotes, analyst AP Photos planned By MITCHELL LANDSBERG Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ Russian markets bounced back Tuesday as President Boris Yeltsin convened an extraordinary meeting of the country's most powerful business tycoons to map out a strategy of economic recovery. Shaking his finger at 10 of the ``oligarchs'' who control the country's banking conglomerates, Yeltsin urged them to do more to keep investors from pulling their money out of the Russian economy. ``Our meetings are rare,'' Yeltsin said. ``Only when it's too much to bear, when the government is in trouble, when the economy begins to crack, when foreign investors begin to flee, and when our own investors won't keep their money here.'' Russia's financial markets, which have performed miserably this year, plummeted in a near freefall last week. Economists blamed a convergence of factors, including fallout from the Asian economic crisis, a drop in world oil and gas prices, and a coal miners' strike that called attention to the government's failure to ensure that workers are paid. Russian stocks rose 12 percent in thin trading Tuesday and the ruble strengthened. But some analysts cautioned that the rebound might be temporary. ``It's a little dead-cat bounce,'' said Fred Berliner, head of trading at the Troika Dialog brokerage in Moscow. ``Whether it will last, I don't know. But my feeling is that it won't last for long.'' Russia's inept tax collection system is at the heart of the country's current financial crisis, and Yeltsin also summoned top law enforcement officials to his office to demand better efforts. ``The tax situation has not improved, only worsened,'' Yeltsin said gruffly in footage broadcast on national television. Russia has no taxpaying tradition and many individuals and companies can't afford its steep new taxes. Last year, only 5 million of the nation's 147 million citizens paid taxes. Tax chief Boris Fyodorov agreed that the system was not working and called for lower taxes to encourage compliance. ``So far, the government was pretending to collect taxes and the people were pretending to pay them, so we have to change this strange habit,'' he said at the inaugural meeting of the Union of Russian Taxpayers. ``But I firmly believe that unless you cut taxes, in a country which didn't have a tax system for a long time, it's very difficult to make people pay very high taxes. So you lower taxes and then you hit hard. Carrot and stick. That's the only way I think can be efficient.'' Before Tuesday, the Russian stock market had fallen 44 percent in the past month, and many analysts feared the crisis could lead to a run on the ruble. A top Central Bank official said the bank has spent nearly dlrs 1 billion in reserves over the past month to support the ruble, which strengthened slightly Tuesday to around 6.16 to the dollar. Deputy Chairman Sergei Alexashenko said the bank still has dlrs 14.6 billion in reserves, higher than some traders have assumed. He said the bank has not had to intervene in recent days. Speculation is growing that Russia will need a rescue package from the International Monetary Fund or someone else. But Deputy Prime Minister Viktor Khristenko said Russia is working within the bounds of earlier agreements rather than considering emergency measures, Interfax reported. (ml/ls)

BC-Sports-Baseball-Cuba-US,0457
Cuban agency says Cuban players could play in U.S. _ but as a team
By LUIS R. VARELA Associated Press Writer
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) _ Cuba on Tuesday opened the door to the possibility that its baseball players could play in the U.S. Major Leagues _ but only if they play as a Cuban team. The idea, according to the Cuban government's Prensa Latina news agency, could ease political friction generated by the defections of top Cuban athletes who end up in the United States. ``Instead of the instigation of talent scouts against (Cuban) players, it would be more logical to enter negotiations to ... reach a solution favorable to all parties,'' Prensa Latina said. Tuesday's dispatch, which cited Cuban government sports officials, was the first time in recent years that the possibility of allowing Cubans to play Major League Baseball was so candidly discussed. Cuba's amateur sports establishment has seen a wave of defections by athletes hoping to compete as professionals abroad. Cuban officials condemned the defections as a strategy by Cuba's enemies to undermine its communist system. Professional sports are banned in Cuba. While top athletes receive favored treatment, salaries run about dlrs 10 a month and living standards pale beside those of millionaire athletes abroad. Prensa Latina said Tuesday that one obstacle to Cubans playing in the United States was the U.S. embargo against Cuba, which it said would prevent players who didn't want to defect from sending their earnings home. It cited the example of the late Cuban chess grandmaster Guillermo Garcia, who in 1988 wasn't allowed to take home dlrs 10,000 he won in a New York tournament. Prensa Latina said various Major League teams have shown interest in establishing training camps in Cuba but were barred from doing so under U.S. law. ``Wouldn't it be better to reach an agreement with the Cubans?'' it said. Cuba has permitted some players to join professional leagues in Japan, Europe or Latin America after retiring from Cuban sports, but it said recently that it was ending that practice. In March, four Cuban baseball players and a coach reached the Bahamas on a raft. One player was allowed to go to Japan because he has a Japanese wife, but the rest were repatriated to Cuba on May 18. In December, Orlando ``El Duque'' Hernandez defected by raft. He was allowed into Costa Rica and signed a dlrs 6.6 million, four-year contract with the New York Yankees. Other defector players have included Hernandez's half-brother, Livan, of the Florida Marlins and major leaguers Rene Arocha, Osvaldo Fernandez, Rey Ordonez, Ariel Prieto and Rolando Arrojo.

THE international community is of the opinion that Pakistan and India should hold talks to ease the tension following their tit-for-tat nuclear tests. After causing dissapointment across the globe - with Asian countries being as vocal in opposing the tests - leaders of both governments must recognise the fact that prolonged conflict will have disasterous results. The last thing anybody wants is another war breaking out in the Indian sub-continent. All outstanding issues which had prompted such tests must be resolved amicably. Let's not forget that nobody has ever emerged a true winner in a military confrontation. The First and Second World Wars proved this. There were signs over the weekend that Pakistan was willing to apply a ``coolant'' to its relations with India. Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said on Sunday that his Government's policy to solve the outstanding issues with India remained and his commitment towards a stable South Asia must be respected by all parties. But Sharif's noncommittal stance as to whether Pakistan was ready to join the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT) and sign the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty is seen by analysts as a stumbling block for the intended meeting with New Delhi. At the same time, news that Pakistan is developing a new long-range missile to carry nuclear warheads is rather alarming. India's five nuclear tests on May 11 and May 13 followed by Pakistan's six blasts two weeks later have fuelled widespread international concern of a dangerous arms race between the two countries. The tests were met with worldwide condemnation and punitive sanctions on both countries by the US, Japan and several other countries. Pakistan's decision - despite the threat of sanctions - to match the nuclear tests of its arch-rival, India, and the euphoria that has gripped the country in the last few days can be understood only in terms of the blood feud that has preoccupied Pakistan for half a century. Successive governments in Pakistan have been obsessed with nuclear weaponry ever since India conducted its first test in 1974. As reports spread, over the years, of Pakistan's nuclear progress, the military and political leadership came to view the nuclear threat as a deterrent to India's overwhelming military power. This belief was strengthened by two events. In 1984, the Indian army conducted a major exercise that massed troops some eight miles from the border. Pakistani officials warned that this could mean war and intimated that nuclear weapons might be used. The Indian Prime Minister at the time, Rajiv Ghandi, said he had not been informed of the exercise and withdrew the troops. In 1990 as unrest mounted in Kashmir, India, believing that weapons were pouring in from Pakistan, again moved troops near the border. The US Director of Central Intelligence, Robert Gates, flew out in an emergency mission and defused the crisis. India, too, is plagued by its own domestic problems. There is Kashmir, the war being waged by militant Sikhs fighting for an independent Khalistan state, conflict in Assam and the Tamil separatist movement in the south. However, both countries never seemed to realise that the on- going confrontation, which has so far claimed thousands of lives, will be very difficult to contain should they each cling to national pride. The politics of arrogance have proven fatal to the spirit of neighbourliness. The time has come for Pakistan and India to address their differences with regard to regional stability and peace. As the world moves towards a total ban on nuclear weapons, the two neighbouring countries must take into account the great devastation caused by their last three bitter wars and imagine the possible damage nuclear bombs could inflict, should they lose their balance in making decisions. No doubt, Kashmir is still an outstanding issue but somehow or rather, a solution must be reached. Instead of playing on sentiment, they must focus on mutual development and respect as well as on bilateral cooperation for the benefit of both their peoples. Wasn't this the agreement reached by Mahatma Gandhi when the two countries' separated half a century ago?

THE Asean Insurance Training Fund will be providing 75 scholarships to qualified insurance personnel in Asean to attend training at the Malaysian Insurance Institute (MII) over the next five years. In addition, the fund will also be sponsoring short technical courses ranging from underwriting and claims to actuarial and takaful insurance, said Bank Negara governor Tan Sri Ahmad Mohamed Don when launching the fund in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. ``These short courses are expected to attract not less than 300 participants from Asean over a five-year period,'' he said. The fund is an idea initiated by the Malaysian Government at the first Asean Finance Ministers' Meeting in Phuket last March and is aimed at facilitating the creation of a pool of qualified insurance personnel in the region. ``The fund is provided by the Malaysian insurance industry with a ringgit-for-ringgit matching grant by the Malaysian Government,'' he said adding that the fund can be one of the platforms through which Asean members will build expertise in insurance and at the same time foster closer relationship among the players. Currently, the Government has contributed a total of RM3 million while the industry has contributed another RM3 million, making the total sum currently available RM6 million. ``The fund will be sponsoring one candidate from each Asean member country to pursue the Diploma in Insurance and Risk Management course at MII,'' he said. Each scholarship is valued at RM13,500 and is intended to cover the tuition fees for the diploma and associateship courses. The fund will be managed by MII which will also provide the facilities to conduct the two courses, the Diploma in Insurance and Diploma in Risk Management as well as the MII Associateship technical training programmes. MII has already sent applications for the scholarships to all respective insurance bodies in the Asean countries comprising Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Myanmar, Indonesia, Vietnam, Brunei and the Philippines. After the launch Ahmad Don officiated the MII Annual Public Lecture 1998 on ``Moving into the New Millenium - An Appraisal and Rating of Insurance Industry''. He added that with increasing globalisation and liberalisation, it is imperative for insurers to re-examine their operations and capability to meet the new challenges.

BC-Bosnia-War Crimes
Bosnian Serb suspect pleads innocent to war crimes charges
AP Photo planned By JENIFER CHAO Associated Press Writer
THE HAGUE, Netherlands (AP) _ An alleged Bosnian Serb prison chief indicted for atrocities against Muslims and Croats at an infamous camp pleaded innocent to war crimes charges Tuesday. At his arraignment before the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal, Milojica Kos entered a plea of innocence to 11 counts of war crimes and crimes against humanity for atrocities allegedly committed at the notorious Omarska prison camp in northwestern Bosnia. Kos, 35, faces a maximum sentence of life imprisonment if convicted. The U.N. court did not immediately set a trial date. Asked by judges if he had anything to tell them, Kos responded: ``I have faith in justice and God, nothing more.'' A police officer, Kos's indictment alleges he was a shift commander at Omarska who commanded camp guards who ``regularly and openly killed, raped, tortured and beat'' prisoners. Kos and other leaders at Omarska ``knew or had reason to know'' that their underlings were about to commit these crimes and failed to stop them or punish the perpetrators, according to the indictment, which was issued in February 1995. Omarska was a makeshift prison camp established after Serb forces took control of the Prijedor district of northwestern Bosnia in May 1992. About 3,000 Muslims and Croats from the area were rounded up and taken to the camp. Three other suspects linked to atrocities at Omarska _ Miroslav Kvocka, Mladen Radic and Zoran Zigic _ are already in tribunal custody in The Hague and awaiting trial. Kos was arrested by NATO-led forces last week in the northwestern Bosnian town of Banja Luka and transferred to The Hague. He is the 27th suspect in custody out of 74 publicly indicted by the court, set up in 1993 by the U.N. Security Council to bring to justice those responsible for atrocities in the wars that raged in the former Yugoslavia after its split. The tribunal's two most-wanted suspects, former Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic and his wartime military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, remain free. (jc/bk)

BC-Italy-Reform, 1st Ld-Writethru
PRECEDE Milan, Italy Italian reform effort seems dead
ROME (AP) _ Constitutional reform in Italy was on its deathbed Tuesday, but political leaders said they were putting the funeral off until next week. A vote had been scheduled on an article reshaping the role of the president. But a squabble over presidential powers scrapped the vote, and after a meeting of party whips, legislators said they the would take up the matter June 10. ``On Wednesday, June 10, the Chamber will meet and it will acknowledge that the conditions to continue the reforms no longer exist,'' Gustavo Selva, deputy whip for the right-wing National Alliance, told The Associated Press. He said the chairman of the parliamentary committee that has been working on the reforms for nearly 18 months, Democratic Left leader Massimo D'Alema, still may try to convene committee leaders for a last-ditch effort. ``We would need a miracle'' for the reforms to continue, D'Alema said in a speech to the chamber. ``Let's hope it happens.'' Premier Romano Prodi insisted earlier Tuesday that his government's stability doesn't depend on the fight over constitutional reforms. Prodi had said he wants the reforms approved by a large majority as a sign of wide support for constitutional change. But new objections from the center-right opposition apparently caused the breakdown. Opposition leader Silvio Berlusconi wants the president to have the power to dissolve Parliament any time, rather than only when the government resigns. The center-left traditionally opposes a strong president, a reaction against the 20-year dictatorship of Fascist leader Benito Mussolini. Political commentators and leaders were groping in the dark over what the next step would be if the reform plans break down. They also envision reshaping the legislature and judicial system. Possibilities include the forming of a constituent assembly to rewrite the constitution, changing the constitution by popular referendum or chipping away at reform through ordinary laws.
