By DIRK BEVERIDGE
LONDON (AP) _ The parent company of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars on Tuesday called a 430 million pound (dlrs 700 million) bid from Volkswagen a good, solid offer _ and said any last-minute approaches would face big obstacles. Plans to sell Rolls-Royce to the Germans were thrown somewhat into question Monday, when a group of Rolls-Royce enthusiasts said they were planning a higher bid with the intent of keeping the company British. Vickers PLC has called a special meeting Friday for shareholders to vote on Volkswagen's offer. The company has not yet received any kind of bid from the British group, which calls itself Crewe Motors and is run by a lawyer, Michael Shrimpton, who previously led a failed effort to bid for Rolls-Royce. Vickers has acknowledged any that last-minute bid, if credible, could force it to delay its plans. Shrimpton told a reporter Tuesday he was still hoping to deliver a bid by late Wednesday. But Tuesday, Vickers sought to defend its current deal with Volkswagen, saying in a statement that it had ``the achievement of good and reliable value for shareholders uppermost in its mind,'' and that it didn't want to lightly unravel a solid deal for selling Rolls-Royce. Vickers noted ``press speculation that it may shortly receive a proposal from a private consortium,'' and warned that if the deal with Volkswagen is not approved Friday, the ``current timetable will be lost,'' which could pose risks for shareholders not getting as much money in the long run. Vickers also said Volkswagen would probably have to pay between 460 million pounds (dlrs 750 million) and 470 million pounds (dlrs 766 million) to close the deal. Volkswagen agreed in its bid to repay Vickers for any investment that it makes in Rolls-Royce in the interim _ mirroring terms of an earlier deal Vickers had reached with BMW. BMW had bid just 340 million pounds (dlrs 554 million) and was outgunned by Volkswagen. A BMW spokesman affirmed Tuesday that BMW has no plans to change its bid. (db-kg)

Portugal says it trusts its own investigators into Nazi gold
LISBON, Portugal (AP) _ Prime Minister Antonio Guterres said Tuesday that Portugal had nothing to hide about its wartime dealings with Nazi Germany and was keen to uncover any evidence about flows of gold allegedly looted from Holocaust victims. ``The Americans can say what they want. We are just interested in the truth,'' Guterres said in response to a publication in Washington of a U.S. government report about the dealings of neutral nations, including Portugal, with Nazi Germany. Guterres said Portugal always treated the issue of Nazi gold with total openness. He stressed that two commissions, currently combing Portuguese wartime records, are due to publish reports by the end of the year detailing the extent of Portugal's involvement with Nazi Germany. According to the U.S. report, Portugal provided Germany's war machine with tungsten and other materials used to produce weapon-grade steel. The report said the Third Reich paid for much of this trade with gold looted from the banks of occupied countries and the melted-down valuables of Holocaust victims. The deputy governor of the Bank of Portugal said earlier investigations revealed Portugal sold essential raw materials to Nazi Germany during World War II. ``The wolfram trade was known during the war and was monitored by the Allies, especially the British who we had informed about it from the start,'' Luis Campos e Cunha said in a telephone interview. Documents discovered last year in the U.S. National Archive showed 79 truckloads of Nazi gold were sent to Portugal between January 1942 and May 1944. Portugal returned almost 4 tons of Nazi gold at the end of the war following a detailed investigation of the Bank of Portugal's gold reserves by Allied officials, Campos e Cunha said.

THE Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange (KLSE) extended its slide yesterday when the key barometer tumbled on news of contracting gross domestic product (GDP) in the first quarter of this year. The benchmark KLSE Composite Index (KLCI) fell 20.24 points or 3.76 per cent to 518.00, its lowest level since January 15 this year. Last Saturday, Bank Negara Malaysia announced negative 1.8 per cent growth in GDP, the country's first negative quarterly economic growth in over a decade. Analysts said blue-chips retreated on forced selling of certain finance stocks and the market's fall was in tandem with the decline of other regional bourses. Turnover stood at 119.998 million shares worth RM236.095 million from 127.625 million shares worth RM277.763 million last Friday. Losses outpaced advances 511 to 95 with 126 unchanged. Asia-Pacific bourses fell across the board on concerns of the weakening yen and shrinking economic growth in the countries of the region. Jakarta stocks shed 1.5 per cent, Bangkok 3.9 per cent, Manila 0.8 per cent, Singapore 1.6 per cent, Tokyo 2.2 per cent, Hong Kong 3.6 per cent and Taiwan 3.8 per cent. However, Seoul managed to buck the downtrend when it posted a marginal 1.4 per cent rise on news of a May trade surplus.

BC-Ukraine-Overdue Wages
Ukrainian government fails to pay wages, pensions
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) _ Workers and pensioners in many regions of Ukraine are owed more than 2-1/2 months' wages and pensions, Finance Minister Ihor Mytyukov said Tuesday. Mytyukov also told parliament that nearly all the 800 million hryvna (dlrs 400 million) the government collected in revenue in May was used to pay wages and pensions. Still, the government was able to meet only 86.2 percent of its obligations, he said, according to the Interfax news agency. However, teachers, medical workers, police and the army were paid in full, he said. The head of parliament's accounting chamber, Valentyn Symonenko, said Tuesday that Ukraine was experiencing ``a total lack of money.'' He cast doubt on the government figures for wage and pension arrears, and said National Bank figures show a much larger debt. Parliament passed a resolution Tuesday instructing the Cabinet to report on the situation by June 9. Mytyukov acknowledged that enterprises owe the state Pension Fund nearly 3 billion hryvna (dlrs 1.5 billion), which will worsen the situation. More than one-third of deputies in the 450-member Verkhovna Rada also signed an opposition proposal to debate a motion of no-confidence in the government, opposition lawmakers said. Faction leaders were to discuss the proposal later in the week. (sms/ls/ml)

BC-Georgia-Abkhazia
Georgian armed forces not combat-ready, president says
TBILISI, Georgia (AP) _ Georgia's armed forces stayed out of recent fighting in the separatist Abkhazia region in part because they are not prepared to fight, President Eduard Shevardnadze said Tuesday. Shevardnadze blamed Russia for failing to meet a commitment to supply Georgia with arms, and said it had left the Georgian military unfit for combat. Speaking to reporters, Shevardnadze also gave new, higher figures for casualties in the clash between Abkhazian armed units and Georgian guerrillas. According to the president, more than 300 Abkhazians and 16 Georgians died in the fighting between May 19-25. In addition, six police officers and employees of the Abkhazian Security Service died Tuesday when their car struck a mine in the Ghali region, where the latest fighting took place, the ITAR-Tass news agency said. Abkhazia, a Black Sea province in northwest Georgia, declared independence in 1992. Separatists drove out Georgian troops and ethnic Georgian civilians in a 13-month war. Since then, fighting has frequently erupted in and around the region. Boris Berezovsky, the Russian tycoon who is executive secretary of the Commonwealth of Independent States, the loose federation of former Soviet republics, is expected to go to Georgia on Wednesday for talks aimed at settling the conflict, ITAR-Tass said. In his remarks Tuesday, Shevardnadze called again for an international peacekeeping force in Abkhazia, which Russia opposes, and said Russian peacekeepers have failed to stop the fighting. ``Now is not the time for political ambitions,'' he said. ``We must understand precisely that there is no alternative to reconciliation for Georgians and Abkhazians. ... The only alternative is a war, blood and victims.'' (str/ml/ls)

EFFECTIVE July 1, all bills issued to importers and consignees must be accompanied by an acknowledgement slip to avoid wrongful billings by Socotec (M) Sdn Bhd. Socotec (M) Sdn Bhd is the collecting agent appointed by shipping conferences to collect detention charges for full container loads on their behalf. It has been acting as a representative for shipping lines since February 1 1996. The new billing system, described as ``more transparent'' by the Association of Forwarding Agents Port Klang (AFAPK), was reached following numerous meetings among the association, Socotec, the Federation of Malaysian Manufacturers (FMM) and shipping conference representatives. AFAPK chairman of port operations committee Yee Poh Tak said it was at the April 29 meeting, chaired by Klang Port Authority (KPA) free zone manager Paul Seo, that the agreement on the billing was reached. Business Times had last August highlighted the problem on the billing system which had resulted in some importers being blacklisted for not paying the detention charges as a result thereof causing their cargo of not being cleared on time at the port. The importer in question then had to pay the fees required to have his name taken off from the blacklist so that his cargo could be cleared at the port. Explaining the new billing system to Business Times yesterday, Yee said when the haulier pulls the empty containers back to the designated depot, he has to prepare the acknowledgement slip for the depot to verify that the container has been received. ``With this method, there will be no more cases of wrong billing,'' he said, adding that the hauliers have agreed to bear the cost of late charges if it is of their fault. ``The importer will pay first, before claiming back from the haulier later.'' Yee said AFAPK members will advise their clients to maintain accurate record of the receipt and return of containers at their premises. ``If the detention charges are correct, and are according to the importers record, then our members will advise their clients to settle the charges within the specified period,'' he added. However, he said, if the importer's record shows that the container has been returned within the free detention period, the importer should dispute the said charges by showing proof, that is, the importer's container receive/return record. ``The importer should file the dispute report immediately upon receipt of Socotec's bill. This means it is imperative for the importer to maintain good record showing when the hauliers have been informed to pull the box and when the same has been pulled.'' Empty containers must be returned to the depot within seven days of leaving the depot. If it is returned after seven days, detention fees are charged to importers. Problems arise after the importer clears or unstuffs the containers and the hauliers do not collect the empty containers on time, or they send them back to the wrong depot, by which time several days have passed already. ``We are very grateful to all the parties concerned for coming up with a solution. We are trying to make Port Klang a user-friendly port so as to encourage more shipping lines to use it,'' he said. ``We believe in consultation and cooperation. We do not want any one party to lose out or suffer. This way, everyone benefits, from the freight forwarder to the consignee and the shipping lines.'' Yee said freight forwarders previously had to do a lot of running around on behalf of their clients to check with both the hauliers and the depots as to when the containers were actually returned. ``All this is done in our own time and at our own cost.''

KUALA LUMPUR, Mon. - The Works Ministry will be submitting three working papers to the Cabinet soon on solutions to the water shortage in Selangor and the Federal Territory. The working papers would be covering specific solutions such as speeding up the construction of a supply pipe from the Sungai Selangor Phase II water treatment plant to the Kuala Lumpur area as well as long-term solutions such as replacing all old water mains with new ones. Minister Datuk Seri S. Samy Vellu said the working papers were being prepared by ministry officials to be submitted to the Cabinet in the next eight days. ``We are now in the process of gathering comments from various agencies such as the Economic Planning Unit of the Prime Minister's Department and also the Finance Ministry.'' Speaking to reporters after a meeting with Selangor Waterworks Department, Selangor State Government and ministry officials, he said the working paper would also provide an update on the current situation. One of the proposals would be for allocations to subsidise the speedy contruction by Puncak Niaga (M) Sdn Bhd of a supply pipe linking part of the Sungai Selangor Phase II water treatment plant and the Kuala Lumpur area. ``The pipe-laying works are currently under way but Puncak Niaga has informed me that it would take about six months. I have asked them to study the possibility of completing it in about two months.'' He said Puncak Niaga had been asked to study the proposal immediately and present a report to him tomorrow. ``The reason for me asking Puncak Niaga to complete the project earlier is that I have been made to understand that the water situation is expected to worsen after December.'' The supply pipe stretching about 40km will supply about 22 million gallons a day to several areas in the Kuala Lumpur area when completed. Samy Vellu said more water would be supplied as the capacity of the treatment plant at Batang Berjuntai increased. The Sungai Selangor Phase II water treatment plant is expected to supply about 210 million gallons per day when completed in 2002. He said the plant would produce about 105 million gallons for the Klang Valley area when part of the plant operated. ``This is expected to be in December, but we are asking Puncak Niaga to start producing that amount much earlier.'' The Sungai Selangor Phase I and II project is expected to reach maximum capacity by the year 2007 and water supply from other States would be needed. Samy Vellu said another working paper to the Cabinet would be on the construction of a supply pipe linking Selangor and water sources in Pahang which could supply up to 400 million gallons of water a day. ``It would cost about RM5 billion and the consultant enginneer said that it would take about five years to construct,'' he said. Another proposal, according to Samy Vellu, is to change all water pipes in the Kuala Lumpur area from asbestos to steel within the next 10 years. He said the the changes, covering about 5,000km of pipes, were important to reduce the amount of non-revenue water loss. ``The ministry would ask the Cabinet to provide an allocation of at least RM75 million annually to undertake the changes.'' On the situation at the Semenyih and Langat dams, Samy Vellu said there were problems with supply to households which receive water from these dams since supply from the catchment areas had been reduced. He said water supply to industries will be maintained at 100 per cent, unless they were in housing areas involved in the rationing exercise. Samy Vellu also said ministry officials were looking into an area near Fraser's Hill in Pahang to build a new dam.

BC-Taiwan-US-Military, 1st Ld-Writethru,0291
U.S. agrees to sell navigation, targeting equipment: report actual selling
Eds: CLARIFIES throughout that US willing to allow sale, not doing
TAIPEI, Taiwan (AP) _ The United States will allow the sale of advanced night navigation and targeting equipment to Taiwan to enhance the capabilities of U.S.-built F-16 fighters, a local media report said Tuesday. Taiwan's official Central News Agency said the U.S. Defense Department was prepared to approve the sale of 28 Pathfinder-Sharpshooter infrared devices, along with training and support, for U.S. dlrs 160 million. Taiwan's Defense Ministry would not confirm the sale, but spokesman Kung Fan-ding said the military ``looked forward,'' to such purchases. Taiwan has been worried about heavy pressure on Washington from China not to sell Taiwan more weapons. China claims Taiwan as a breakaway province, which is subject to forcible reintegration, if necessary. Taiwan bought 120 single-seat F-16As and 30 twin-seater F-16Bs in 1992 for U.S. dlrs 6 billion. Eighty of the planes have arrived so far. The new devices would vastly increase night flight safety, especially at low altitudes, CNA said. Taiwan lost an F-16B and two pilots over the Taiwan Strait during a training flight in March. The plane has not been found, and no cause of the accident has been announced. Taiwan has virtually remade its air defenses through the purchase of the F-16s, 60 French Mirage 2000-5 fighters, and continuous deployment of 130 homemade IDF jets. The upgrade has allowed it to retire planes such as 1950s-era F-104 Starfighters to meet the challenge from China's Su-27 jets purchased from Russia.

KOTA BARU, Mon. - Kelantan Religious and Malay Customs Council (MAIK) deputy president Datuk Ashaari Azmi Abdullah told the Syariah High Court today he lodged a police report against the copies of text of a Hari Raya sermon distributed by the State Government's information secretariat to safeguard the council's credibility. ``It was also to prevent any untoward incident from happening since the text of the sermon was being circulated two or three days before Hari Raya,'' he added. He said the report was lodged on Feb 7 last year at the Kota Baru police station, a day after he was given the text. ``The text was written by the State Pas Dewan Ulama,'' he said, adding that the action was not allowed under Section 5 (1) of the MAIK Enactment on the establishment and incorporation of the council. To a question from Takiyuddin, Ashaari Azmi said there was no relation between the report he lodged with the police on Feb 2 and that of the case filed by MAIK against Mohd Amar. ``I don't know him (Mohd Amar) nor was I informed of the case. Croatian, Bosnian Serb prime ministers discuss refugee issue
ZAGREB, Croatia (AP) _ The premiers of Croatia and of the Serb republic within Bosnia agreed on Tuesday that refugees should be free to choose whether to return home or sell their old property and settle where they chose to. Zlatko Matesa of Croatia and Milorad Dodik of the Bosnian Serb republic met against a background of fierce international pressure on Croatia to stop foot-dragging on permitting Serb returns. Tens of thousands of Serbs fled in 1995, when Croatian government troops retook areas Serb rebels seized in 1991. An estimated 50,000 found shelter in the Serb-controlled half of Bosnia. Many of them live in houses of Muslims and Croats expelled from the region during the Bosnian war. On the flip side of the coin, Bosnian Croats driven out of Bosnia now live in homes Serbs abandoned in Croatia. The Croatian government argues that the Bosnian Croats should be allowed to return home too, but only a few of the approximately 70,000 who fled have been able to come back because of resistance to them in former home areas now controlled by other ethnic groups. Talking about a refugee agreement for the region to be signed later this month, Matesa said it was based on the ``right of each person to chose where one wants to live.'' Dodik said the Dayton peace agreement, which ended Bosnian war, ``envisages that every person has equal right to return, sell or exchange his property.'' ``We want to offer people the opportunity to decide on one of these three options,'' the state news agency HINA quoted him as saying. BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open, 7th Ld-Writethru
Hingis eclipses Venus at French Open, men's favorite Rios ousted
Eds: UPDATES with Moya beating Rios, Seles winning By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Playing like the champion she is, Martina Hingis ousted Venus Williams from the French Open Tuesday, ending the American teenager's run in Paris. But there will be two Americans in the semifinals. Monica Seles, playing her first tournament since the death of her father, and Lindsay Davenport both advanced with three-set wins. And Pete Sampras, though thousands of miles away, can rest easy: Marcelo Rios lost a chance to take the world's No. 1 ranking when Carlos Moya defeated him in four sets. Rios, the No. 3 seed, had been a favorite to take the title after the early exits of Sampras and No. 2 Petr Korda. Williams, who powered her way through the first four rounds, met her match in the world's No. 1 player and lost 6-3, 6-4 in the quarterfinals. ``I didn't play as well as I should have,'' Williams said. ``I made too many errors. These things, I assure you, will be corrected.'' Hingis last year won every Grand Slam event except the French Open. Now she is two victories from capturing the lone major to elude her. ``She's raising her game,'' Williams said. ``Everyone else has to raise theirs, too.'' Seles looked like her old winning self during her victory over Jana Novotna, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3. Even the grunts were back. Seles pounded her fist in the air in triumph after breaking Novotna in the final game. Defending champion Iva Majoli went down to No. 2 seed Lindsay Davenport, 6-1, 5-7, 6-3. Davenport joked that she might be the most overlooked semifinalist. ``If I was a betting person or a journalist, I would overlook myself also,'' she said. ``I don't have a tag. I'm just an ordinary girl playing tennis and having success. That's a boring story.'' Moya, a talented Spaniard, was at the top of his all-court game in his 6-1, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4 victory over Rios. With Moya serving, the Chilean saved three match points in the final game, including a lucky net cord. That delighted the vocal Chilean fans, who waved a big flag whenever he won a point. But Moya fired an ace to set up the fourth match point, and Rios netted his final shot. In a showdown billed worthy of a final, Hingis used her deft touch and court sense to wear down Williams. She almost always seemed in control, never looking off-balance or rushed. Hingis raced to a 3-0 lead, but Williams broke in the fifth game for 3-2 as the Swiss star twice double-faulted. Hingis then broke right back for 4-2, and held on to win the set. In the second set, Williams had a chance to break Hingis for 2-0, racking up three break points. But Hingis won five straight points to take the game. In the crucial game of the set, Hingis broke Williams for 4-3 _ again on two double faults, this time by Williams. Also reaching the semifinals was No. 4 Aranxta Sanchez Vicario. The two-time champion from Spain lost a tiebreak in the second set but recovered to beat Patty Schnyder of Switzerland 6-2, 6-7 (5-7), 6-0. But another former champion, Thomas Muster, continued a disappointing year with a quarterfinal loss to No. 15 Felix Mantilla of Spain, 6-4, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3. The Austrian's ranking has dropped this past year from ninth to 22nd. Leading to the headline match, Hingis wasn't ready to call Williams a true rival. ``Everybody else is trying to make rivalries against me,'' she said. ``Venus, she won Key Biscayne, but that's not a Grand Slam. ... I'm No. 1, I've won four Grand Slams. I have the self-confidence.'' Williams, seeded eighth at Roland Garros in just her fourth event on clay, responded diplomatically. ``I think that she's playing good tennis, and she has every right to say what she wants to,'' Williams said. TOKYO, Mon: Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad, who arrived here for a five-day working visit today, expressed hope that the regional economic problems will have minimal impact on Japanese foreign direct investment to Malaysia. ``I think it will be affected to a certain extent. There is no running away from that, but I hope it will be minimal,'' he said. Speaking to reporters upon his arrival, Dr Mahathir said large Japanese companies are still interested to invest in Malaysia and are continuing to do so. He said at the same time, Malaysia is also getting a lot of investments now from the US, particularly in the petrochemical and chemical industries. Of Japnese projects worth RM4.6 billion that were approved by the Malaysian Industrial Development Authority last year, 70 per cent was for new projects and the rest re-investments or expansions to existing facilities. Asked if Malaysia is now opening up these sectors to American investors, Dr Mahathir said: ``We welcome anybody, but the Americans seem very keen on the chemicals sector, with large investments.'' During his visit here, the Prime Minister is scheduled to have several private meetings with Japanese businessmen. He is also scheduled to speak at a Symposium on ``Revitalisation of the Japanese Economy and the Future of Asia'' tomorrow. Reggiani Martinelli's lawyers said in opening arguments that she hated Gucci and often said she'd like to see him dead. But they said a 1992 brain tumor operation had rendered incapable of conceiving and carrying out the murder scheme. BC-Kenya-London Club
London Club, Kenya Sign Pact On dlrs 70M Debt Rescheduling
PARIS (AP) _ The London Club of commercial creditors and Kenya signed an agreement on a dlrs 70 million debt rescheduling, Banque Nationale de Paris (BNP) said Tuesday. The signature formalizes a preliminary agreement reached Feb. 13, 1998, which was left unchanged. In February, BNP, which led the negotiations, said that of the dlrs 70 million total, dlrs 31.2 million was in past-due interest from January 1992. Under the plan signed Tuesday, Kenya's principal debt will be restructured into 10-year bonds, with a three-year grace period. That new bond will pay fixed interest of 3.5 percent, for the first four and one-half years and will pay the London interbank offered rate (Libor) plus 13/16 percent thereafter. Two-thirds of the overdue interest will be forgiven and of the remaining portion, 60 percent will be capitalized, or lumped into the principal. The rescheduled credits are all in dollars. (dj/sl)

BC-Egypt-Press
Egypt bans printing English-language newspaper for second time
CAIRO, EGYPT (AP) _ The government has banned the publication of an English-language newspaper a week after revoking a ban that prevented its printing in Egypt, the publisher said Tuesday. Hisham Qassim, publisher of the Cairo Times, said the owner of the printing plant that puts out the fortnightly informed him that he received orders from the Information Ministry not print the paper. However, an official reached at the ministry said the decision was not made there, speaking under usual conditions of anonymity. It was not clear if some other government office might be involved. In April the state-run Investment Authority, which supervises the duty-free areas, imposed a ban on all publications in the zones where some 40 magazines and newspapers had been printed. The move came amid a government crackdown on what officials call ``sensationalist reporting'' that hurt Egypt's image. Egypt also has tightened libel laws and jailed three journalists on libel charges. Critics said the ban on printing in the duty-free zones would damage Egypt's image as a rising free-market economy. Most of the publications involved printed in English and other foreign languages and were taking advantage of high quality and low prices in the free zones. On May 20 the government rescinded the ban but said that only specialized publication could use the free zones and would still need licenses. The government statement caused confusion, but since then Qassim had put out the Cairo Times at least once in the free zone. He said the government provided no reason for the latest ban on the newspaper's publication. After the initial ban, some publishers in the zones moved their printing to Cyprus and Lebanon, while continuing to distribute in Egypt. Under the law, all publications licensed abroad have to pass censorship. sn-ggl

BC-Vatican-Swiss Guards, 2nd Ld-Writethru
New commander of Swiss guards appointed
Eds: AMs; RECASTS, ADDS comment from new commander
VATICAN CITY (AP) _ Acting quickly to replace his slain Swiss Guard commander, Pope John Paul II named a Swiss army colonel on Tuesday to head the tiny force. The pope appointed Pius Segmueller, 46, just a month after predecessor Alois Estermann was fatally shot on May 4 along with his wife by a disgruntled young guardsman. It took the Vatican seven months to announce Estermann's appointment. Hours after the announcement, he was shot dead. The young guardsman killed himself, the Vatican said. ``I'm taking on the post with confidence and hope also to gain people's confidence in me,'' Segmueller said. He said he had been approached for the job three days after the killings. He called it a particular honor to be called on at such a critical time. The pontiff named Lt. Elmar Maeder, an attorney and army veteran, as second-in-command. Estermann's death, the first murder in the Vatican in 150 years, grabbed headlines around the world and shook the staid Swiss Guards to its foundations. In a statement Tuesday, interim commander Roland Buchs thanked the pope for his ``unwavering trust'' in the corps. The Vatican said Segmueller is a native of Lucerne with degrees from the University of Zurich, the Zurich Military Academy and the General Staff's academy. Maeder, who served in the Swiss Army and is now a lawyer, is from St. Gallen in the eastern part of Switzerland. Both are members of the majority German-speaking community. For five centuries, popes have drawn on Swiss Catholic men to serve in the 100-member papal army, protecting the pope and, in modern times, performing ceremonial duties at the Vatican. Segmueller and his wife Therese have a 9-year-old son and 8-year-old daughter. (cph/djw/vls)

BC-Sports-RugbyU-Bateman
Wales embroiled in club versus country rugby fight
CARDIFF, Wales (AP) _ Wales and British Lions center Allan Bateman is the latest casualty in a conflict of rugby loyalties. Bateman Tuesday became the 19th player to withdraw from Wales' six-match tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe, leaving the Welsh in a similar predicament as the English squad currently touring Australia. Wales accused English premier division club Richmond of pressuring Bateman into withdrawing from the tour so he could have an operation on his nose, meaning he won't miss a game next season. The Welsh Rugby Union said Bateman was fit enough to travel and could have had surgery following the Test against South Africa on June 27. Announcing his withdrawal Tuesday, Bateman said his priority was being fit and prepared for next year's World Cup. ``Matters came to a head between the club and the WRU and, in the end, I decided I just wasn't prepared for the trip and there was no way I could go. ``The whole business has been a distraction.'' Bateman's absence means Wales will travel with only three of the eight Lions who helped win a Test series against the Springboks last summer. (jp/scw)

BC-Palestinian-Jerusalem
Official: Palestinians must be ready to `confront' for Jerusalem
By SAMAR ASSAD Associated Press Writer
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Palestinians must be willing to take to the streets to block Israeli settlement activity in east Jerusalem, a senior Palestinian official said. Faisal Husseini, the senior Palestinian official in Jerusalem, said last week's clashes between Palestinians and Israeli police after a Jewish settler group put up seven tin sheds in the Muslim Quarter of Jerusalem's Old City showed ``a Palestinian readiness to confront.'' ``This is something we must feed,'' Husseini told The Associated Press in an interview this week. ``We must continue this process ... Political and diplomatic responses do not get the job done if there is no movement on the Palestinian street.'' On Tuesday, however, Husseini used the diplomatic approach, taking eight European consul-generals to the site of last week's scuffles, just inside the Old City's Herod's Gate. Walking through the narrow alleyways of the walled Old City, diplomats from Britain, France, Belgium, Turkey, Sweden, Germany and Greece shook sand from their well-polished shoes as they looked at the site. City workers demolished the unauthorized sheds, but the settler group, Ateret Cohanim, won the right to maintain a presence on the plot, which is surrounded by Arab homes. ``This area is in the heart of the Islamic neighborhood and planting another settlement here only complicates negotiations,'' Husseini told the diplomats. On Tuesday, Israel demolished five Palestinian homes and a marble factory built without permits in and around Jerusalem. Hanan Ashrawi, the Palestinian minister of higher education, said Israel's policy of demolishing homes and confiscating land will lead to violence not only with Palestinians, but with the Arab, Muslim and Christian world. ``Israel is busy destroying any possible of peace or coexistence,'' she said. The dispute over Jerusalem is the most explosive issue of the Israel-Palestinian peace process. Palestinians want east Jerusalem, which Israel captured in 1967 and later annexed, as a capital for their future state. Israel insists the entire city must remain under Israeli sovereignty. Husseini said Palestinian committees are studying ways to make Jerusalem a capital of two states. He said the Palestinian position is that east Jerusalem is occupied territory and not up for negotiation. Any negotiations on Jerusalem should be over Arab property in the western sector of the city, he said. sa-hla

Annan envoy sees opportunities for rebuilding Sierra Leone
By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Despite continued fighting in Sierra Leone, a senior U.N. envoy said Tuesday enough stability has returned to justify a major international effort to rehabilitate west African country. But Olara Otunnu, who returned this week from a four-day visit to Sierra Leone, said if the international community waits until there is ``perfect peace... there's a real danger that the restored democracy ... will be seriously jeopardized.'' Otunnu said one of the major advantages Sierra Leone enjoys over other countries emerging from civil conflict is the widespread support enjoyed by its newly restored government, headed by President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah. Otunnu said Kabbah's political legitimacy would make it easier for the United Nations to mount an effective humanitarian rehabilitation program in partnership with the local authorities. He said the government was committed to foreswear recruiting youngsters into the ranks of the Kamajors, the paramilitary force allied with Kabbah. Otunnu said the Kamajors had also agreed to begin discharging ``child soldiers'' already in their ranks. In addition, he said the government had agreed to protect ``child soldiers'' of the deposed junta and its allies in the Revolutionary United Front, still holding out in rural areas. Last month, the United States and the European Union accused rebel forces in Sierra Leone of engaging in ``horrific'' violence that has killed or maimed several thousand people in recent months. They said hundreds of people are being treated in hospitals after rebels chopped off their arms, legs and ears with machetes. Many women and children have been systemtically raped, U.S. and EU officials have alleged. Otunnu said he visited one hospital in the capital Freetown which had received more than 300 people who had lost limbs and hands. ``I will never forget the words of a young boy, must have been about 5 years old, who told me after severing his hands, the RUF soldiers then told him `go tell President Kabbah we are still here,''' Otunnu said.

LUSAKA, Zambia (AP) _ Former President Kenneth Kaunda comforted himself during five months of detention with poetry, Christian hymns and thoughts of the late Princess Diana. ``I am very moved when people do good things for fellow man,'' said Kaunda of the princess' charity work. ``I've been trying to write something on Diana.'' BOGOTA, Colombia (AP) _ President Ernesto Samper says he's got a thick dossier of threats against his life _ from drug traffickers, leftist rebels, paramilitary groups and political foes _ and will have to leave the country for a few months when his term ends in August. ``I understand perfectly that when I leave office, I will be one of the most threatened people in Colombia,'' Samper, 47, said in an interview with The Associated Press at the presidential palace. He was arrested in March 1996 and had since been held in a Nassau prison cell while his lawyers fought to keep him in the Bahamas. Rey could face a jail sentence of up to 15 years if found guilty. Now she is two victories from capturing the lone major to elude her. ``She's raising her game,'' Williams said. ``Everyone else has to raise theirs, too.'' Seles looked like her old winning self during her victory over Jana Novotna, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3. Even the grunts were back. Seles pounded her fist in the air in triumph after breaking Novotna in the final game. ``I think about my dad every day,'' she said. ``But for me it's a tennis match, it's a tennis tournament. Davenport joked that she might be the most overlooked semifinalist. ``If I was a betting person or a journalist, I would overlook myself also,'' she said. ``I don't have a tag. She almost always seemed in control, never looking off-balance or rushed. Hingis raced to a 3-0 lead, but Williams broke in the fifth game for 3-2 as the Swiss star twice double-faulted. Hingis then broke right back for 4-2, and held on to win the set. In the second set, Williams had a chance to break Hingis for 2-0, racking up three break points. But Hingis won five straight points to take the game. In the crucial game of the set, Hingis broke Williams for 4-3 _ again on two double faults, this time by Williams. Also reaching the semifinals was No. 4 Aranxta Sanchez Vicario. TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ A briefcase bomb exploded inside a government building in eastern Tehran Tuesday, police said. At least two people were killed and two others were injured, Iranian media reported. An Iranian opposition group in exile claimed responsibility in a statement faxed from Iraq to The Associated Press in Cairo, Egypt. But Iranian news reports indicated it was an accident. The different reports could not be immediately reconciled. The midmorning blast caused no visible structural damage to the four-story white marble building housing the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office and related courts. The office is responsible for catching and trying Iranians violently opposed to the 1979 Islamic revolution that installed the clergy's rule. Pictures taken by the official Islamic Republic News Agency showed one room with a wall caved in and piles of plaster dust. A police official at the scene, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the explosion was caused by a bomb placed in a briefcase. He did not elaborate. The bombing is a surprise in a city where security is tightly controlled. The last reported bombing in Tehran was four years ago when two devices went off in a commercial district but caused no fatalities. The attack remains a mystery. Iran's state-run television and radio only reported an explosion at the Prosecutor's Office without specifying if it was a bomb. The reports said two people were killed and two were injured. IRNA, the official news agency, said the blast was caused by explosives, and indicated that the material was being brought to the court as evidence in a case under investigation when it went off accidentally. But in its statement from Iraq, the opposition Mujahedeen Khalq said its military units detonated the bomb, killing ``scores of torturers and interrogators.'' However, the scene outside the building _ relaxing firemen and little activity among the police _ appeared to contradict that claim. The government did not immediately respond. The Mujahedeen also said the building was demolished, which proved to be untrue. The group has often made exaggerated claims in the past. It is the largest Iranian opposition group and is committed to overthrowing Iran's Islamic government by force. It is based in Baghdad, Iraq and its members in Iran have often been targeted by the Prosecutor's Office. The explosion comes as Iran is gripped by an intensifying power struggle between the moderate faction of President Mohammad Khatami and hard-line opponents who oppose his social and political reforms. Their rivalry has led to large public demonstrations in Tehran and other cities in recent weeks that have sometimes turned violent. pvs-ti/vj

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Backers of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic on Tuesday challenged his foes in Montenegro to make good on promises of the good life for voters, giving them 100 days to do so. The moderate reaction to the election victory led by reformist Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic indicated that for now Milosevic and his Montenegrin proxies would not directly challenge the poll results. SEVILLE, Spain (AP) _ Primo Nebiolo is still bitter about the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. The powerful Italian leader of track and field's world governing body launched a scathing attack Tuesday on the organizers of the Centennial Games. Nebiolo called the organization ``disastrous,'' described the dismantling of the Olympic Stadium as ``shameful'' and complained that Atlanta officials refused to pay a cent to promote a pre-games track meet. The president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation has criticized Atlanta organizers before. But he went further than ever when speaking with reporters during a meeting of national and international Olympic officials in Seville. Addressing the problems faced by track and field in the United States, Nebiolo recalled that the IAAF organized a Grand Prix meet in Atlanta a few months before the games. ``We did not find any help,'' he said. ``The meeting cost dlrs 2 million and we paid all of it. Nebiolo said he was especially angry that, after the games, the Olympic stadium was retrofitted into a baseball park for the Atlanta Braves. ``After the games, they spent $260 million from the Olympic revenues when we (the IAAF) received practically nothing. They have destroyed the stadium and built a new stadium in the name of Ted Turner. It is shameful. ``They also promised us to maintain a good stadium for 25,000 spectators. This disappeared also. This is shameful. It is not possible to spend money coming from the Olympic revenues in this manner.'' Nebiolo said he wasn't blaming any person in particular, only pointing out ``a disaster in the organization and a strange use of the money.'' Citing the transportation problems which marred the games, Nebiolo recounted his own experience of taking a bus from the stadium after the opening ceremony. ``The bus left for the hotel one hour after the ceremony,'' he said. ``After 1 kilometer, the bus stopped and the engine was burning. Nebiolo noted that President Clinton's daughter, Chelsea, is attending Stanford and that the president himself ``is expressing a certain sympathy for the idea.'' On other issues, Nebiolo: _ expressed satisfaction with preparations for the 1999 World Championships in Seville and said construction of the new stadium should be completed in April or May of next year. _ said the Golden League, a series of six elite European meets being launched this summer, could be expanded to eight meets next year, with Paris, Stockholm or a British city added. BC-Spain-Death Squad Trial
Former top official incriminates old bosses in kidnapping trial
By JOHANNA TUCKMAN Associated Press Writer
MADRID, Spain (AP) _ A former top interior ministry official testified Tuesday that he was within the inner government circle that created a shadowy paramilitary unit to combat Basque separatists in southern France. Julian Sancristobal is among 12 defendants _ including ex-Interior Minister Jose Barrionuevo and his number two Rafael Vera _ on trial for the 1983 kidnapping of a French businessman who was mistaken for a hitman from the Basque separatist group ETA. The abduction of Segundo Marey was the first action claimed by the so-called Anti-terrorist Liberation Groups, or GAL, that went on to kill 27 suspected members and sympathizers of ETA in southern France between 1983 and 1987. During four hours of questioning, Sancristobal told the Supreme Court that Vera gave him a suitcase containing one million French francs (worth approximately dlrs 130,000 at the time) to cover the cost of kidnapping Marey _ including hiring mercenaries to carry it out. He insisted that the whole operation was authorized by Barrionuevo. Sancristobal's testimony bodes ill for his two former bosses and fellow defendants in the Supreme Court trial. Both Barrionuevo and Vera are expected to deny involvement in the kidnapping, as well as the GAL, when they take the stand on Wednesday at the end of the second week of the trial that is expected to last over one month. The other accused have already testified on previous days that the responsibility for the kidnapping belongs to the upper echelons of the interior ministry, but Sancristobal's version includes a first hand account that the decisions were made within the government. Allegations that former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez's government set up and ran the GAL were instrumental in the defeat of his Socialist Party in 1996, after nearly 14 years in office. On Monday a former Socialist Party deputy from the Basque region, Ricardo Damborenea, said the green light for the GAL was given directly by Gonzalez. Gonzalez, who is not accused but is to testify, has insisted that his government never acted illegally in its fight against ETA _ an acronym for Basque Homeland and Freedom _ that began its violent campaign for an independent Basque state in 1968. The former premier has also claimed that the trial is a political conspiracy that is highly damaging to the national interest. Prosecutors are seeking 23-year jail sentences for Barrionuevo and Vera, 22 for Sancristobal, 16 for Damborenea and a total of 104 years shared out between the remaining eight defendants. (jt)

BC-Germany-Slave Labor
German court awards damages to inmate forced to work by Nazis
BREMEN, German (AP) _ A court awarded reparations Tuesday to a Jewish concentration camp inmate forced by the Nazis to work as a city laborer and who was unable to apply for postwar government compensation. The court rejected back-wage claims of two other Jewish inmates of the Auschwitz camp, saying they already have been receiving government pensions aimed at compensating them for their imprisonment and health damage. The first plaintiff, referred to in court only as Mrs. Rosenberg, lived behind the Iron Curtain after World War II and was unable to receive any compensation from then-West Germany. She can therefore claim compensation now, the Bremen state court ruled. She was awarded a lump sum of 15,000 marks (dlrs 8,300), two-thirds of it for her time spent as slave laborer for the city of Bremen and one third for health damage. The verdict was similar to a Bonn court ruling in October for Auschwitz inmates who were forced to work at a munitions factory. That court denied back-wage claims of 21 Jewish women who had already received postwar government compensation. But it awarded 15,000 marks to a Jewish woman who had lived in Poland after the war. Israeli legislature votes to dismantle shrine at gunman's grave
JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel's legislature voted Wednesday to dismantle the makeshift shrine that has sprung up at the grave of an Israeli gunman who massacred 29 Muslim worshipers. In the attack four years ago in the West Bank town of Hebron, Brooklyn-born Baruch Goldstein opened fire with an automatic rifle on Muslim worshippers kneeling in prayer in the Tomb of the Patriarchs, a site sacred to Muslims as well as Jews. The makeshift shrine that has sprung up around Goldstein's well-tended grave in the Jewish settlement of Kiryat Arba, just outside Hebron, has become a point of pilgrimage for Jewish extremists. ``What we have today is a memorial and not just a grave,'' said Ran Cohen, the opposition lawmaker who introduced the bill to take down the shrine. Objects to be removed include a cabinet containing a Torah, a case of religious books, and benches and lamps. The grave itself will not be moved. Cohen said that if the grave continues to be a focus of pilgrimage, he will introduce a new bill calling for the removal of the grave itself. dk-hla

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open Notebook
Racketless, coachless in Paris
By MARILYN AUGUST Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ When the strings popped in the middle of his junior match, Russia's Artem Derepasko found himself on court with only one other racket. Since the rules do not allow players to leave court, except for bathroom breaks, the chair umpire told Derepasko to ask his coach to bring a few more rackets to court. But Derepasko said he doesn't have a coach. ``I travel alone, I don't have a coach and my only friend here is Marat Safin,'' he told the umpire. Safin _ the upstart Russian who ousted defending champion Gustavo Kuerten _ was otherwise engaged, battling Cedric Pioline on center court for a berth in the quarterfinals. A ball boy bailed out the young Derepasko with a freshly-strung racket, and he went on to win the match. ___ PRIDE OF BELGIUM: The only player in the men's draw to reach the quarterfinals at the French Open without losing a single set almost pulled out of the tournament with a sore back before swinging a racket. Belgium's Filip Dewulf _ who made the semifinals here last year _ hurt his lower back on the eve of his first-round match against Sweden's Magnus Larsson. Dewulf's strong play here has been all the more surprising given his record this year of 10 wins and 11 losses. He's won five tiebreakers on his route to the quarters, beating Spain's Francisco Clavet, Marzio Martelli of Italy and Thomas Enqvist and Larsson of Sweden. Dewulf, 26, came to Paris with another monkey on his back: pressure from his national media to pull off a repeat performance here. He has sparked greater interest in tennis in Belgium, and led a team that beat France in a playoff match to reach the main group in Davis Cup play. Since then, Belgium has beaten a powerful Dutch squad and will now face the United States in a Davis Cup quarterfinal in July. --- CHANG'S POLITESSE: Michael Chang never fails to amaze the personnel at Roland Garros. This year it's his manners. Following his loss to Spain's Franciso Clavet, Chang waited for the ball girls and boys to finish collecting the balls, and then thanked each one individually for working his match. ``He's the only player who ever thanked us for every ball and every bottle of water,'' said Caroline, a head ball girl on center court. --- HOMETOWN HERO: Hometown hero Cedric Pioline may lack the charisma of former French Open champion Yannick Noah, but a record 9 million TV viewers in France tuned in Monday for his match point against Russia's Marat Safin. Pioline, who's reached the quarterfinals, is the nation's best shot for the title, which Noah won in 1983. Noah was the last Frenchman to do so since Marcel Bernard won in 1947.

Police chase and beat students protesting new law
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Club-wielding policemen on Tuesday beat Belgrade students protesting a law that gives the government full control of Serbian universities, media reported. After rallying in front of the rector's office for the 14th consecutive day, the students decided to march downtown to the government building but were stopped by a police cordon in the main pedestrian mall. A smaller group of some 50 students bypassed police, finding its way into a park area close to the government building, when about 20 policemen rushed them and beat them with clubs, Studio B television reported. Serbian parliament last week passed a law giving the government full administrative control over the universities, including appointments of rectors, deans, teaching and administrative staff. The new law triggered the resignation of the Belgrade university dean and the department of philosophy declared a general strike, while students vowed to hold daily protests in front of the rector's office. YEARS of hard work and perseverance finally paid off for 350 students of the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants when they received their scrolls at a graduation ceremony held recently at a hotel in Seri Kembangan, Selangor. The students, their parents and relatives arrived early at the Palace of the Golden Horses in the Mines Resort City on the graduation day. The graduates have successfully completed either all 14 papers (or less for those who got exemptions) offered by the international accountancy body. Their eagerness and excitement were clearly visible. Some were hysterical and ecstatic while others were either nervous about stepping up on stage to receive the recognition or simply too touched by the whole affair. The parents and relatives too were equally emotional. Proud mothers were seen hugging and kissing their children. Other students also exchanged hugs and congratulations with their friends and lecturers. It was indeed a moment the graduates and their families would cherish especially for those who had performed really well in their examinations. Even for those who just managed to pass the ACCA papers with sufficient credits, the ceremony was still an event to remember. Several Malaysians did the nation proud when they emerged tops at the international level and won several awards. They are Yong Chee Keong who is the ACCA subject world winner (paper four), Leong Chee Ming who is the subject world winner (paper nine), Goh Cheoh Weng who is the first world winner for the certified diploma in accounting and finance, and Goh Siew Ai who is the certified diploma in accounting and finance subject world winner (paper one). Others were ACCA Malaysian place winners Lee Wei Ying, Janice Chin Sue Vei and Chandra Mohan Selappan who were ranked first, second and third respectively. Goh Cheoh Weng, 33, holds an applied science bachelor's degree from University Kebangsaan Malaysia and an economic masters degree from Cambridge University. He opted for the certified diploma in accounting and finance post-graduate diploma course as it provides the essential practical management skills which are important sential to him as a senior executive in a multinational firm. His ingredients for success are not extraordinary. He said one needed discipline, diligence, time management and perseverance to succeed. Even though, the past one year has been a difficult time especially when he had to think about work, studies and family all at the same time, it never occurred to him to quit. ``I spare the weekends and holidays for the family as during weekdays, apart from attending classes and doing revisions after work, I needed to focus on my office work as it needed a lot of after-office attention,'' he said. In his case, although Cheoh Weng only had classes two days in a week, he took the effort to study and revise for at least an hour every day. ``I need to keep my mind running. Our brains are like machines which if we leave it unused for too long, it will rust and would take some time to be reconditioned,'' he said. On graduation day, he was accompanied by his wife Foong Leng, who seemed even more excited than Cheoh Weng about the whole affair. Foong Leng, a housewife, strongly encouraged her husband's pursuit and provided the moral support while Cheoh Weng was pursuing his studies. ``I made sure that everything was comfortable for him while he was concentrating on his studies or revisions,'' she said. She felt that under the circumstances, showing understanding and tolerance were important. Chandra Mohan Selappan has been working for some months since the results came out at a consultant company as a finance and administration executive. He acknowledged that although the working world was not exactly the same as classroom work and such, the ACCA had provided him with the necessary knowledge for him to be competitive with others who were more senior. Chandra Mohan took a bold step forward when he decided to decline an offer to study accountancy in a local university to pursue the professional qualification. ``People told me I am crazy to take such risk as I would have to sit for all the papers again even if I failed only one paper,'' he said. However, he had no doubt he had made the right choice and his perseverance and consistency had proven right. ACCA Malaysia president William Arul said the examination was among the most demanding written assessment in the world and it required determination, discipline and perseverance from the students. ``They choose ACCA because it is a high quality qualification which has worldwide recognition and offers a high degree of career mobility,'' he said. ``Completion of the ACCA course has equipped them with the skills and knowledge to excel in their careers. ``However, an accountant can no longer focus only on skills within the organisation that he works in. Rather, the person needs to be adaptive to changes in the global environment.'' William Arul added that the new generation of accountants should be more than technically oriented. They need to be effective communicators, persistent motivators and logical strategists working towards becoming successful leaders. The presentation of certificates was made by Ministry of Finance Parliament Secretary Datuk Seri Shafie Mohd Salleh. ACCA is an international professional accountancy body. Established in Britain in 1904, it currently has more than 60,000 members and 130,000 students worldwide in more than 130 countries. In Malaysia, there are 13,000 students, 1,500 graduates and more than 3,500 registered members. Over the years, its has produced many successful professionals to serve as chief executives, senior partners, finance directors, entrepreneurs and high ranking civil servants.

BC-Switzerland-Bhutto,0516
Pakistan official says Swiss charged three close to Bhutto
AP Photo GEV107 By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ Pakistan's anti-corruption investigator said Tuesday that a Geneva magistrate indicted three Swiss citizens linked to former Pakistan Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto and was close to indicting her and her husband. Senator Saif-ur Rehman said he was present Tuesday when Judge Daniel Devaud announced the indictments on money laundering charges. ``Judge Devaud has confirmed his intention of proceeding with the indictment of Mr. Asif Ali Zardari (Ms. Bhutto's husband),'' Rehman said at a news conference. Bhutto was dismissed in November 1996 on charges of corruption and misrule, which she claims are concocted by political opponents. Zardari, widely blamed for his wife's downfall, has been jailed since her dismissal. Devaud also intends to indict Ms. Bhutto if he determines she cannot receive immunity, Rehman said. Devaud expects to know within a week, he said. Repeated attempts to reach Devaud by telephone were unsuccessful. Indicted Tuesday was Hans J. Fischer, former senior executive vice-president at Geneva-based Societe Generale de Surveillance SA, where he was responsible for the company's government contracts division. The other two indicted were Robert Massey, managing director for SGS former subsidiary, Cotecna Inspection SA; and Jens Schlegelmilch, whom Rehman described as a Geneva lawyer who served as Ms. Bhutto's and her husband's agent in handling financial transactions. Elisabeth Salina Amorini, chairman of SGS's board, said Fischer stepped down last year to aid the investigation. Schlegelmich declined to comment. Recorded messages left for Massey and Fischer were not immediately answered. Rehman said the Swiss conducted the investigation at the request of the Pakistani government. Rehman showed reporters documents he gave Devaud, saying they indicated kickbacks flowed to Ms. Bhutto and Zardari through companies based in the British Virgin Islands from Pakistani government contracts with SGS and Cotecna. SGS, parent of the world's largest inspection services group, and Cotecna lost their contracts to inspect imports and exports from Pakistan after Ms. Bhutto was ousted from government. Rehman said he does not know the full scope of Devaud's case, but he believes more than dlrs 250 million are in Bhutto family accounts in Swiss banks, which the Swiss government has blocked at Pakistan's request. Swiss authorities said last October that they had found about 20 million Swiss francs (dlrs 13.8 million) in accounts frozen in seven Geneva banks. Rehman said he expects to find another dlrs 250 million in banks in Britain and the United States. Pakistan also is working with authorities in France, the Netherlands and Spain in the Bhutto case, he said. Rehman also said Swiss authorities were proceeding with a second case against the Bhutto family involving drug trafficking. He did not elaborate.

LACK of interest among the younger generations of the Victoria Institution ex-students in becoming members of the Old Boys' Association was the main issue brought up during its recent annual meeting recently. The association formed 76 years ago is currently made up of mostly ``not- so-young'' members. Association president Datuk Mustafa Mohd Ali when responding to this issue said three years ago he had distributed about 250 application forms to school leavers to enable them to join the association as honorary members but sadly, none of the forms came back. The association, he said, had many times sent circulars to the prospective school leavers and only five per cent applied to be members. Mustafa, however, understood why there was such a poor response. ``Most of the school leavers will be too occupied with establishing themselves with careers or settling down in the first 10 years after leaving school as in my case,'' he said. ``However, I believe that the problem of lack of membership from the younger generations of ex-scholars can slowly be solved with networking.'' With networking, Mustafa meant a member-get-member system. ``If a member knows of any ex-scholars who are non-members, he should try to get them to join the association,'' he suggested. If an ex-scholar wants to join the alumni, he is advised to apply as a life member and not just an ordinary member. An ordinary member has to pay RM24 a year for membership while a life member only need to pay RM300 for life-long membership. ``It will be easier for the alumni to keep track of life members as we will be sending them from time to time the association's bulletin and they can always contact us if they change addresses,'' he said. Since a life member is required to pay the subscripiton in one lump sum, Mustafa said this would encourage them to be more active in the association's activities. A bigger membership means more income for the association which means more activities can be planned and carried out. For the association, this means more money can be channelled to its alma mater and the existing students through the VIOBA Foundation. Other than efforts by the association to attract members, member Chung Chee Min has also on his own been compiling names of ex-scholars of VI since two months ago. He said this compilation, which will be made into a book, would not be just an ordinary alumni directory as he had so far interviewed some prominent ex-students such as Jimmy Talalla of the Talalla brothers, both of whom had fought in the World War II, former Bank Negara Governor Tun Ismail Ali, Tun Omar Ong and New Straits Times cartoonist Ahmad Fauzi Zainal Abidin. ``The interview with them will be compiled in the book and it would be an exciting read for students as well as ex-students,'' he said. He added that there was a homepage, started by a few Old Boys, consisting of interesting stories on VI, the teachers and the old boys. The Internet site is frequently updated. KUALA LUMPUR, Sat. - Bank Negara Governor Tan Sri Ahmad Mohd Don said there was still a lot of confidence in the economy, with the current account deficit, which used to be around five per cent of Gross National Product, now ``close to balance''. He was confident the current account would show a significant improvement in the second half of the year. On the Islamic banking system, he said the Syariah Council had decided to allow financial institutions offering interest-free products and instruments to shift towards free-float money market instruments instead of a fixed peg. This shift, to be done within two months, would enable Islamic banking institutions to compete with conventional banks. On factors that would affect Malaysia's economic recovery, Ahmad said it hinged on export growth, financial institutions being able to lend within their credit plan, a commitment to implement macro-economic adjustment package, stable exchange rates and a growth in investments. ``One favourable factor is that world demand is there. Output is forecast to grow at 3.1 per cent while trade will go up 6.7 per cent. Malaysian firms are still competitive and long-term investments are still positive,'' he said. ``The central bank will ensure there is sufficient liquidity within the system to finance the economy. Measures have been taken to ensure banks focus on lending. The latest step is the establishment of the Asset Management Company. ``Recovery also hinges on economic and financial measures being implemented as announced,'' he added, adding that the ringgit had been relatively stable although it was still vulnerable. He admitted that the tight monetary policy resulted in some banks having problems in funding economic activities but overall there were more repayments than disbursements in the first quarter. Loans growth will pick up in the second half with the various funds and Government-inspired schemes coming onstream. On non-performing loans, Ahmad said its ratio to total loans was 7.6 per cent for commercial banks, 13.5 per cent for finance companies and 7.9 per cent for merchant banks. On a net basis, meaning without including interest-in-suspense and specific provisions, the ratio dropped to 5.8 per cent for commercial banks, 10.5 per cent for finance companies and 5.2 per cent for merchant banks. Ahmad said that this was the result of the latest ``stress test'' the central bank put on financial institutions. Interestingly, Ahmad volunteered the information that if the non-performing loans ratio of two commercial banks were excluded, it would improve the overall ratio of commercial banks to 4.8 per cent. As expected, he declined to name the two banks, adding that the Press was ``perceptive'' enough to know which two. Ahmad was also asked to comment on a warning by Economic Adviser to the Government Tun Daim Zainuddin that a high-interest regime coupled with tight lending guidelines would send the economy into a tailspin and put it in danger of a stagflation. He said Daim's advice would be noted by all the implementing agencies of the Government as he was also executive director of the National Economic Action Council. ``We receive all comments and criticism with an open mind as we all work towards stability in the economy and a speedy recovery,'' he said. ``We have no hang-ups that if something is negative, we will put it away ...,'' he quipped.

BC-Disarmament-India-Pakistan, 3rd Ld-Writethru
Some 46 countries demand India, Pakistan end tests, join treaties
Eds: RECASTS for AMs with new material. AP Photos GEV101-3 By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ From the United States to Malta, 46 countries Tuesday demanded India and Pakistan immediately stop testing nuclear arms and join efforts to eliminate the weapons. Islamic countries and some nonnuclear countries expressed concern about the tests, but they blamed the five nuclear powers _ Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States _ for failing to heed the concerns of India and Pakistan. In an all-day emergency session of the 61-nation Conference on Disarmament, the nonnuclear countries urged the five powers to drop their opposition to proposed negotiations to eliminate their atomic arsenals. India and Pakistan maintain that such talks according to a ``time-bound framework'' would be the only way to address the security needs of all countries. If the five powers had accepted India's attempts to set up global nuclear disarmament, ``we need not have gone in for our current testing program,'' said Indian Ambassador Savitri Kunadi. The nuclear powers maintain that they are eliminating their arsenals but have to do it among themselves and cannot subject the complicated topic to global bargaining. The conference, the world's main forum for negotiating disarmament agreements, wrote the test ban treaty flouted by the Indian and Pakistani tests. Pakistani Ambassador Munir Akram welcomed the debate, which said ``widely acknowledged'' that Pakistan was only reacting to ``the nuclear threat emanating from India.'' The five nuclear powers were among the countries that joined in the joint statement spearheaded by Australia and New Zealand. ``The testing of nuclear weapons by India and Pakistan is totally irreconcilable with claims by both countries that they are committed to nuclear disarmament,'' the statement said. India's and Pakistan's tests last month ``blatantly undermine'' attempts to halt nuclear proliferation and threaten to undermine efforts to eliminate nuclear weapons, and belong ``to a bygone age,'' it said. The statement said it was ``crucial that India and Pakistan announce immediately a cessation to all further testing of these weapons, renounce their nuclear weapons programs and sign and ratify unconditionally the comprehensive test ban treaty.'' Also supporting the demand were Japan, South Korea, South Africa and European and Latin American nations, but conspicuously missing were Middle Eastern countries. Iran said it viewed the developments with ``deep concern,'' but said what is needed is ``an all-encompassing program for comprehensive nuclear disarmament.'' Despite Tehran's denials, Iran is widely believed to be pursuing its own nuclear-weapons program. On Monday Iran's foreign minister said on a visit to Islamabad that Muslims welcomed Pakistan's nuclear tests because it gives the Islamic world a bomb to counter Israel's widely suspected arsenal. South African Ambassador Jacob S. Selebi said it was ``imperative'' that the conference tackle nuclear disarmament. (agh-gm)

BC-Russia-Mir, 1st Ld-Writethru
Mir running smoothly ahead of docking with U.S. shuttle
Eds: AMs; RECASTS to UPDATE with Mir's gyroscopes working again. AP Photo planned By VLADIMIR ISACHENKOV Associated Press Writer
MOSCOW (AP) _ The gyroscopes that keep Mir's solar panels facing the sun were working again Tuesday, the last repair necessary after a three-day computer failure that threatened to delay a planned docking with a U.S. shuttle. Mir's main computer was repaired Monday, and the automatic steering system needed to steady the space station for the docking with space shuttle Discovery was reactivated soon afterward. On Tuesday, ground controllers switched on Mir's 11 gyroscopes, the station's preferred, fuel-free orientation system. NASA considered postponing the hookup with Discovery after Mir's computer broke down Saturday, but the blast off is set for Tuesday night as planned. It will pick up astronaut Andrew Thomas, the seventh and last American to live on the Russian space outpost. ``Mir is now running smoothly and nothing prevents the planned docking with Discovery,'' said Russian Mission Control spokesman Valery Lyndin. Mir commander Talgat Musabayev agreed: ``With the gyroscopes, everything seems to be OK, touch wood.'' Mir's main computer operates the station's motion control system, and when it fails, the station's energy supply dwindles since it can't rotate to keep its solar panels in full alignment with the sun. When the latest trouble occurred, the station was on a so-called solar orbit, which puts it in direct sunlight around the clock. As a result, Mir's batteries remained fully charged, making it easier to reactivate the steering system. Mir's computer repeatedly failed last year, prompting Russian space officials to send up a replacement on a previous shuttle flight in January. That unit failed on Saturday after five months of trouble-free operation. The station's crew has replaced it with a back-up computer brought up by a Russian cargo ship but the new unit also failed Sunday when the crew attempted to switch it on. Russia plans to bring down the 12-year-old Mir at the end of 1999 after the first parts of the international space station are in orbit. (vi/ls)

Wine association wants tough punishment against cheating producer
Eds: UPDATES with comment from wine expert, producers' spokesman; MODIFIES translation in 2nd graf By CHRISTOPHE HUTTEAU Associated Press Writer
BORDEAUX, France (AP) _ Bordeaux wineries aiming to defend their reputation _ and their lofty prices _ urged authorities Tuesday to come down hard on two colleagues accused of committing the trade's ultimate crime: adding water, among other things. The wineries' association, ``concerned with protection of consumers and the reputation of all Bordeaux wine producers,'' said it wanted authorities to ``take all necessary action'' after its investigation. The statement came a day after judicial sources confirmed finding water, sugar and inferior wines in Chateau-Giscours. The Margaux is one of the most noted ``grand cru'' wines of the Medoc region. The wine council, called the CIVB, said in the statement that it will ``follow this affair very closely and take all the measures it feels necessary to accomplish its mission.'' It did not elaborate. Placed under investigation for illicit practices _ one step short of being charged _ are Chateau-Giscours wine expert Regis Froitefond and the winery's former director Jean-Marie Ferrandez, the judicial sources said on condition of anonymity. Dutch billionaire businessman Eric Albada-Jeigersma, who has bought part of the domain, was questioned in the investigation, Le Monde reported. The Bordeaux prosecutor's office opened its investigation in 1995 after complaints by a government office that oversees competition and fraud complained. Acting on information from a former employee, the office discovered a mixture of vintages and inferior wines, the judicial sources said. Water and sugar were also allegedly added to some vats, the sources said. The newspaper Le Monde reported that milk and certain acids were likewise detected. None of the additives makes the wine dangerous for the consumer, the sources said, but they could ruin the chateau, disparage the Margaux wines and there was speculation it could even shake up the rising Bordeaux wine prices. One French wine expert, Michel Bettane, suggested government checks on wineries ``are still insufficient. In particular, on adding tartaric acid. ``It's evident that that fraud is widely practiced all over France,'' he told LCI television. But Bettane urged the law be revised, ``because it was made to avoid artificial wine.'' Hubert Bouteiller, a spokesman for the CIVB, told LCI that Bordeaux producers ``are serious people by a very very large majority. ``You see it in their selections, in how much of the harvest they reject, to make remarkable wines justifying their price.'' Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with police saying it was a By AFSHIN VALINEJAD Associated Press Writer
TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ A briefcase bomb exploded inside a government building in Tehran on Tuesday, police said. At least two people were killed and two others were injured, Iranian media reported. An Iranian opposition group in exile claimed responsibility in a statement faxed from Iraq to The Associated Press in Cairo, Egypt. But Iranian news reports called it an accident. The different reports could not immediately be reconciled. The midmorning blast caused no visible structural damage to the four-story white marble building housing the Revolutionary Prosecutor's office and related courts. The office is responsible for catching and trying Iranians violently opposed to the 1979 Islamic revolution that installed the clergy's rule. Pictures taken by the official Islamic Republic News Agency showed one room with a wall caved in and piles of plaster dust. The bombing is a surprise in a city where security is tight. The last reported bombing in Tehran was four years ago, when two devices went off in a commercial district but caused no fatalities. The attack remains unclaimed. A police official at the scene, speaking on customary condition of anonymity, said the explosion was caused by a bomb in a briefcase. He did not elaborate. Iran's state-run television and radio only reported an explosion at the Prosecutor's Office without saying it was a bomb. The reports said two people were killed and two were injured. IRNA, the official news agency, said the blast was caused by explosives, and indicated that the material was being brought to court as evidence in a case under investigation when it went off accidentally. But in its statement from Iraq, the opposition Mujahedeen Khalq said its military units detonated the bomb, killing ``scores of torturers and interrogators.'' However, the scene outside the building _ relaxing firemen and little activity among the police _ appeared to contradict that claim. The government did not immediately respond. The Mujahedeen also said the building was demolished, which proved to be untrue. The group has often made exaggerated claims in the past. It is the largest Iranian opposition group and is committed to overthrowing Iran's Islamic government by force. It is based in Baghdad, Iraq and its members in Iran have often been targeted by the Prosecutor's Office. The explosion comes as Iran is gripped by an intensifying power struggle between the moderate faction of President Mohammad Khatami and hard-line opponents who oppose his social and political reforms. Their rivalry has led to large public demonstrations in Tehran and other cities in recent weeks that have sometimes turned violent.
