BC-Sports-Olympics-Nebiolo's Attack
Retransmits to fix typo in slug Primo Nebiolo rips `disgrace' of Atlanta Olympics AP Sports Writer
By STEPHEN WILSON
SEVILLE, Spain (AP) _ Primo Nebiolo is still bitter about the 1996 Atlanta Olympics. The powerful Italian leader of track and field's world governing body launched a scathing attack Tuesday on the organizers of the Centennial Games. Nebiolo called the organization ``disastrous,'' described the dismantling of the Olympic Stadium as ``shameful'' and complained that Atlanta officials refused to pay a cent to promote a pre-games track meet. The president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation has criticized Atlanta organizers before. But he went further than ever when speaking with reporters during a meeting of national and international Olympic officials in Seville. Addressing the problems faced by track and field in the United States, Nebiolo recalled that the IAAF organized a Grand Prix meet in Atlanta a few months before the games. ``We did not find any help,'' he said. ``The meeting cost dlrs 2 million and we paid all of it. The organizers of the Olympic Games of Atlanta did not do anything to offer a coffee, an apperitif (cocktail), a little reception, a sandwich. How is this possible?'' Nebiolo said he was especially angry that, after the games, the Olympic stadium was retrofitted into a baseball park for the Atlanta Braves. ``After the games, they spent $260 million from the Olympic revenues when we (the IAAF) received practically nothing. They have destroyed the stadium and built a new stadium in the name of Ted Turner. It is shameful. ``They also promised us to maintain a good stadium for 25,000 spectators. This disappeared also. This is shameful. It is not possible to spend money coming from the Olympic revenues in this manner.'' Nebiolo said he wasn't blaming any person in particular, only pointing out ``a disaster in the organization and a strange use of the money.'' Citing the transportation problems which marred the games, Nebiolo recounted his own experience of taking a bus from the stadium after the opening ceremony. ``The bus left for the hotel one hour after the ceremony,'' he said. ``After 1 kilometer, the bus stopped and the engine was burning. We were 20-25 people on the bus and we said to the driver, `What do we do? Do we have to push?' The driver said, `I don't know. You can push, but I don't know which way to go. I am from New York.''' Meanwhile, Nebiolo reiterated that the IAAF is offering to help build up track and field in the United States, where the sport has suffered from lack of promotion and public interest, and he encouraged Stanford's bid to stage the 2001 World Championships. ``Personally I would like to have the World Championships in the United States once in my lifetime,'' he said. ``I believe the U.S. deserves to have the championships for all that it has offered to track and field.'' ``It is a good bid from Stanford,'' Nebiolo said. ``We are trying to help them.'' Nebiolo noted that President Clinton's daughter, Chelsea, is attending Stanford and that the president himself ``is expressing a certain sympathy for the idea.'' On other issues, Nebiolo: _ expressed satisfaction with preparations for the 1999 World Championships in Seville and said construction of the new stadium should be completed in April or May of next year. _ said the Golden League, a series of six elite European meets being launched this summer, could be expanded to eight meets next year, with Paris, Stockholm or a British city added. Aid agencies appeal for helicopters to evacuate wounded
Eds: ADDS color, quotes. No pickup. Changes byline. AP Photos ISL103, 107-108, FDB101-105 By JUDITH INGRAM Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan _ Aid agencies ferried the critically wounded from quake-devastated villages in northern Afghanistan on Tuesday and appealed for more aircraft and fuel to rescue survivors of the earthquake that killed anywhere from 2,000 to 5,000 people. In the village of Kol, hundreds of people swarmed a United Nations helicopter that touched down three days after Saturday's earthquake struck a remote mountainous area rocked three months earlier by another massive quake that claimed some 2,300 victims. On Monday and Tuesday, U.N. helicopters evacuated 50 of the most seriously injured to emergency medical centers. Rescuers have reached only 29 villages, or about half of those believed to have been seriously damaged by the 6.9-magnitude quake. Of those, 12 were 80 percent to 100 percent destroyed, said Rupert Colville, a U.N. spokesman. ``It's now clear that the destruction is very wide spread,'' Colville said. Survivors carried the injured on stretchers of sticks and old clothes through winding hillside streets and past crumbled packed-mud houses to reach the helicopters. The villages' remoteness and lack of transportation were hampering the aid effort. The United Nations, the Red Cross and other agencies have three borrowed helicopters to deliver medical aid. The lack of aircraft ``is undercutting everything we are doing now,'' Colville said. The agencies need at least one more cargo plane to deliver supplies, he said. Rescuers worked from the dirt airstrip of the nearby provincial capital of Faisabad, still littered with the rusting junk of old Soviet tanks and artillery from Afghanistan's decades-long civil war. Aid workers said it would take several weeks to get a clear picture of how many people were killed. Red Cross helicopters have delivered 2 tons of high protein biscuits, flour and oil to victims in Shari Basurkh, near the quake's epicenter, some 45 kilometers (27 miles) from Faisabad Mohammed Karim was in Faisabad when the quake hit his village on the outskirts of Shari Basurkh. Hitching a ride in a car, he and four friends raced for home, walking the last few hundred meters (yards). They found the village virtually gone. ``We started digging. When we brought the people out they were already dead,'' said Karim. ``We brought the bodies from under the destruction and buried them without an Islamic prayer. We didn't have time.'' . Most of the injured were women, children and the elderly who had stayed inside their homes while men worked the fields. Most of the injuries are broken limbs, internal and head wounds, said Svante Yngrot, a medical coordinator with the Red Cross. Many of the survivors were still in shock, made worse by a series of aftershocks. ``That frightened everybody. Sixty thousand people from the whole district will be spending the night outside.'' Colville said. ``The most traumatized were those who survived the February quake, when they saw friends and relatives killed before their eyes. Now they're going through it again.''

CLEARLY, a new approach is required ... the current global environmental crisis is a result of dominant value systems, driven by human greed and excessive materialism, and the mistaken belief that science and technology hold the key to the solution of all our problems. Seoul Declaration, World Environment Day 1997. THE birth of the National Water Council has been a difficult one. For more than 10 years, State Governments remained ambivalent about it. It was first proposed in the 1982 National Water Resources Study and then again in 1991 following the Malacca water crisis; but there was not enough political will to get it started. Not any more. Current water shortages, felt most acutely by the people of Selangor, Negri Sembilan, Penang, Johor, Sabah and northern Sarawak have provided the much-needed catalyst to the setting up of the council, soon to be holding its first meeting. Although information remains sketchy - who are the key players, for example, other than the fact Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad will head the council - this is still a landmark event. ``It is timely, although it is unfortunate it had to take another water crisis for the council to materialise,'' says World Wide Fund for Nature Malaysia conservation director Dr Isabelle Louis. The fact that the PM will chair the NWC - unlike the National Forestry and Land Councils, headed by his deputy - shows that water resources such as rivers, groundwater and lakes have finally and rightfully taken their place on the national agenda. While cynics may dismiss the move as too little, too late, the creation of the NWC should be welcomed. Better late than never, says Consumers Association of Penang legal adviser Meenakshi Raman, who - like other informed hydrologists, engineers, environmental scientists and conservationists - has for years valiantly pushed for such a set-up. ``There must be a mechanism of checks and balances in the council,'' she stresses. The idea of the council is to coordinate and integrate the management of land, forests and water resources, while ensuring uniformity in practices and laws, explains another advocate, Drainage and Irrigation Department director-general Kheizrul Abdullah. There are, for instance, over 30 related laws on water. The time has come for politicians and the power-wielding business community to acknowledge that land, forests and water are mutually dependent for economic and environmental sustainability. Historically and constitutionally, however, these natural resources have been managed as separate entities, resulting in cross-purposes among Federal and State agencies and the widespread scourge of passing the buck. Further, the mentality of build-first-remedy-later has shaped the way in which forests are cleared and land is developed. Instead of determining land uses according to the availability of water, development projects have been allowed to take place without considering their impact on river quality and quantity - in particular, the river's capacity to handle the pollution loads and the amount of water extracted. The emphasis has always been on increasing supply rather than conserving water and protecting rivers and groundwater against pollution. While it is understandable that each State Government guards its natural resources jealously, as these are their main sources of revenue, guaranteed under the Constitution, nature does not recognise man-made boundaries. After all, how does one prevent pollution flowing from one State to another? Is it fair for one State to bear the burden of another's pollution? The issue of inter-State resources management can no longer be sidelined. The NWC provides the appropriate platform from which to resolve it. So, how to make the NWC a force to be reckoned with? Engineer Kheizrul says it is crucial that Chief Ministers and Menteris Besar are represented in the NWC, as they are in the National Forestry and Land Councils. After all, land and water are inseparable, and both are State functions. ``Politically,'' he argues, ``it is unlikely the Federal Government will be allowed to take over the management of land and water.'' For better or worse, ultimately, the onus is on State governments. It is vital that agencies with the requisite technical know-how preside at the NWC, to give valuable advice. Equally pertinent is the presence of the Economic Planning Unit (of the Prime Minister's Department), as water is also a social and economic resource. Although Works Minister Datuk Seri S. Samy Vellu failed to include the public when he announced the set up of the NWC, it will mollify discerning Malaysians if the council gives them an avenue through which to voice their views and participate in decision-making. While the structure of the NWC has yet to be defined, there is no argument that it must first draw up a National Water Policy to provide general guidelines, which in turn must become the principles for planning and managing the country's 150 river basins. There should be a policy regarding a grace period in which to inform the public of the line of action when there is impending drought or flood. Much groundwork must be done if the Government is serious about preventing another water crisis. First, conflicting land uses must end. To do this, Kheizrul says, ``we must think globally, act locally'' and proposes the following to the council: Determine the amount of water in the respective river basins; assess present land uses to determine the demand for water and demand impact on rivers and groundwater; and ascertain the chain of command when river basins cover more than one State. Kheizrul also proposes that, where demand exceeds supply, the council should explore the option of tapping excess water from neighbouring river basins. He is confident that it can be done, provided there is proper planning and integration. The excess water can be extracted, he stresses, only after taking into account requirements for the survival of aquatic species, navigation, and industrial and household needs. There are 150 river systems nationwide. There should be a master plan, says Kheizrul, for each river basin, guided by NWC policy. Who is to see this through? There must be respective river basin authorities represented by experts from diverse fields. The maxim is, one authority, one river basin, with the respective State Economic Planning Units as focal point. Why State EPUs? The choice is obvious, explains Kheizrul. They have a direct impact on water resources as they make economic decisions on land use. Each river basin authority must be vested with the power to make day-to- day decisions, insists Centre for Environmental Technologies executive director Goh Kiam Seng. In each master plan, says the former director-general of the Department of Environment, there must be standard provisions for the following: Water quality monitoring; water resource development; flood mitigation; pollution minimisation; silt control; landuse planning; drainage and irrigation improvement; mangrove preservation (to act as buffer against coastal erosion); fishing ground protection; river rehabilitation; wetland restoration; water pricing policies; and the beautification of rivers for recreation. This, however, requires technical experts and policy-makers, in order for the river basin authority to be effective. Goh believes it should be chaired by no less than the Menteri Besar, with the participation of Federal Ministers and State Exco members in charge of the environment, science and technology, forestry, agriculture, housing and local authorities. Capitalising on existing Government machinery, multi-disciplinary experts from various Federal and State agencies should be placed together with scientists under a technical committee, he says. On the other hand, the public, non-governmental organisations, professional bodies and research institutes can play a role on the advisory panel. Still, one critical point has not figured prominently in the debate on the current water crisis: The role of the private sector, in view of State governments' increasing dependence on it to treat and supply water. How does the private sector fit into the scheme of things with the NWC and river basin authorities in the making? Meenakshi of CAP has doubts that the private sector can get the nation out of its mess. ``Water is too important a public resource,'' she argues, ``to be left in the hands of the private sector.'' As profit is the driving force of private companies, she fears that further privatisation of water treatment and supply will widen the gap between rich and poor. She dreads the day that water will be sold to the highest bidder, leaving the poor behind. Unequal access to water, as history has shown, spells trouble. ``The Government should reconsider privatising water supply; current events in Selangor show it hasn't worked well,'' she urges, referring to the case of Puncak Niaga Sdn Bhd's repeated shutdowns of its water treatment plants at the Langat and Cheras rivers. While there are pros and cons to privatisation, one thing is clear: Consumers are fed up with water rationing. They do not want to hear any more excuses. With the NWC and the river basin authorities taking shape, we certainly hope things will improve.

KUALA LUMPUR, Sat. - MCA president Datuk Seri Dr Ling Liong Sik said today globalisation is transforming economies to be increasingly borderless and its related issues have become far more complex than ever before. ``What takes place in one country or region impacts directly upon neighbouring ones.'' As an example, he said, the local stock market reacted to price movements in exchanges in Tokyo, Hong Kong, New York and London. Dr Ling said these were facilitated by modern communications systems such as Internet, fax and satellite transmit information. ``Such instantaneous information can create immediate repercussions with multiplied effects of sometimes devastating proportions,'' he said in his presidential address at the party's 45th annual general assembly in Dewan San Choon at Wisma MCA. He said huge sums of capital moved swiftly and easily from one region to another, adding that nations had also become more exposed to international hedge funds and currency traders. Dr Ling, who is also the Transport Minister, said before long the country might have to cope with international economic expectations for greater free trade and liberalisation of markets. Praising the leadership of Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad in tackling the economic problems, he said: ``Dr Mahathir has taken firm and urgent steps in response to such economic challenges. ``Measures are being adopted to overcome present difficulties, while bold and innovative policies have been introduced to build a more robust economy. Many of the steps taken are beginning to yield encouraging and positive results.'' He said despite the turmoil, the country's economic fundamentals remained sound and this had been acknowledged by overseas financial institutions. Dr Ling also pledged the party support for Dr Mahathir's call for international regulation and supervision of the world financial system and the latter's appeal for a strengthening of co-operation among nations to have greater transparency in financial and capital markets. ``Without this, the economy of nations including Malaysia are vulnerable to currency traders, and much of what have been achieved through the hard work and sacrifice of millions are lost by the acts of a few,'' he said. The MCA would mobilise whatever capabilities and resources it has, Dr Ling said, to assist the Prime Minister in dealing with the economic challenges. In reiterating the party's support for Dr Mahathir, he reminded members of the mid-80s when the country had gone through a major recession. Under Dr Mahathir's decisive leadership, urgent and pragmatic measures were then implemented to address key problems in the economy. ``He was tireless in seeking foreign investments and in restructuring the economy to be more diversified and less dependent on primary commodities. ``The country steadily recovered, and subsequently enjoyed more than a full decade of strong economic growth,'' Dr Ling added. He said the party was certain that Dr Mahathir's policies and approach, intended for the overall good of the nation, would once again guide us through the present financial crisis. He also reminded Malaysians that the strength and greatness of a nation is not reflected in its wealth or military power. It is to be found, Dr Ling said, in the resourcefulness and discipline of its citizens. ``It is a great nation, if its people can rally together in troubled times and lift high their spirits, hopes and their confidence. And through all these such a nation retains a sense of calmness, tolerance, moderation and fairness,'' Dr Ling added. ``Malaysia under the leadership of Dr Mahathir, who is also the head of the Barisan Nasional, has this character and quality.'' MCA would work with undiminished zeal, he said, to ensure that the Prime Minister's vision of the country in the year 2020 would be fulfilled. He further reminded the people that there were only 580 days to the start of the millennium and that the character as Malaysians would be tested as we progress towards the year 2000. ``We are mindful that the task before us will not be easy. But we, as a community, share with other Malaysians a quality of resilience and toughness so that situations of adversity will be turned into occasions of opportunities.'' Thus, it was with hope and confidence, Dr Ling said, that we prepared our community for the new era. ``As the new century approaches, we will be a community that remains loyal and patriotic. ``Our members, through enterprise and application of skills, will continue to help develop the economy towards fully developed status.'' The community looks forward with confidence to the new millennium, Dr Ling said, because it has faith in the leaders and in their vision.

Ukrainian national banker optimistic about IMF conditions
KIEV, Ukraine (AP) _ Ukraine met the International Monetary Fund's conditions for securing a loan in May, and now hopes the dlrs 2.5 billion loan will be granted, the country's top banker said Tuesday. National Bank chief Viktor Yushchenko said the conditions related to the bank's foreign currency reserves and Ukraine's budget deficit. The government took measures last week to reduce the expected budget deficit to 2.3 percent of gross domestic from 3.3 percent, although the plan still needs to be approved by parliament. The IMF refused to approve a loan to Ukraine last year because of the country's stalled economic reforms. An IMF delegation is scheduled to return to Ukraine in mid-June, followed by the fund's head Michel Camdessus on June 20, to assess progress toward implementing the loan conditions. ``Summing up the month of May with the broad view of the program in mind, we can say that we would have a good basis for the next round of talks with the IMF mission,'' Yushchenko said in comments carried by the Interfax news agency. Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Milosevic camp giving By DUSAN STOJANOVIC Associated Press Writer
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia (AP) _ Backers of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic challenged his foes in Montenegro on Tuesday to make good on promises of the good life for voters, giving them 100 days to do so. The moderate reaction to the election victory led by reformist Montenegrin President Milo Djukanovic indicated that for now Milosevic and his Montenegrin proxies would not directly challenge the poll results. With Djukanovic expected to use his victory to try to unseat Milosevic, there had been fears that the Yugoslav strongman would declare the election invalid and send troops into Montenegro, the smaller of the two republics making up what is left of Yugoslavia. The new government of Djukanovic supporters ``will be given 100 days to prove it can fulfill promises ... of a better life for all,'' said Predrag Bulatovic, deputy chairman of Montenegro's Socialist People's Party. His statement, carried by Tanjug, Yugoslavia's state news agency, did not say what would happen after 100 days. Bulatovic spoke after Milosevic ally Momir Bulatovic _ whose supporters lost the elections _ was summoned to Belgrade for urgent consultations with the Yugoslav president. The two Bulatovics are not related. With both Montenegro and larger Serbia holding the same number of seats in Yugoslavia's federal parliament, Djukanovic is believed to be planning to stack the Yugoslav parliament with his supporters. They could then team up with the Serbian opposition to unseat Milosevic or at least weaken his rule. No political analyst in Yugoslavia can imagine Milosevic going quietly. Since rising to power in Serbia in 1987, the wily Milosevic has used a powerfully effective mix of nationalism, tight media control and autocratic methods to cement his hold on power. But Djukanovic's presidential victory in October, coupled with Sunday's parliamentary win by his supporters, seriously weakened Milosevic's grip. Djukanovic said in an interview with the independent Belgrade Radio Index on Tuesday that Milosevic ``will have to accept the new Montenegrin political reality.'' He accused Milosevic of destroying Yugoslavia with his ``arrogant obstinacy'' and said Milosevic ``will have to take the blame for the collapse of the country which he is running'' if he continues attempts to subjugate Montenegro. Djukanovic first challenged the Yugoslav power-broker in the winter of 1996-1997, coming out against Milosevic during massive protests against his rule. Then last fall, the Montenegrin narrowly beat Momir Bulatovic _ his former best friend _ for the republic's presidency. Strongly backed by Washington and Western Europe, Djukanovic took office in January. His triumph in Sunday's elections will hand him a majority in the 78-seat Montenegrin parliament, and has a large say in who gets sent to Yugoslavia's federal parliament. Djukanovic said in the radio interview that he would insist on Momir Bulatovic being replaced as federal premier. Milosevic maneuvered his protege into that office two weeks ago after the previous premier refused to crack down on Djukanovic's pro-Western reforms. Djukanovic's aides have suggested that he might seek a referendum in Montenegro on the republic's secession from Yugoslavia if Milosevic doesn't replace Bulatovic.

MALAYSIA has relied on a broad spectrum of measures, including interest rates, to promote macroeconomic stability and economic recovery, Bank Negara said in a statement late yesterday. ``At the current interest rate level, the real rate of return on deposits (after taking into account the expected rate of inflation) is being maintained at levels prevailing before the crisis.'' ``This has allowed savings in Malaysia to be efficiently mobilised through the banking system. Bank Negara said its statement was aimed at clarifying the ``current monetary policy stance''. Bank Negara also announced yesterday that the three-month interbank weighted average base lending rate for May was 11.03 per cent per annum. Baxter suspends European blood-substitute test,0385
AP Business Writer
By CLIFF EDWARDS
CHICAGO (AP) _ Baxter International announced Tuesday it had suspended European tests of its HemAssist product in trauma victims after early results found no statistical benefits, in a further sign that its oxygen-carrying blood substitute has run into trouble. The move comes less than two months after Baxter suspended testing in U.S. emergency rooms after more patients who used HemAssist died than did those in the control group. The Deerfield, Illinois-based pharmaceutical giant found that 46.2 percent of the people given HemAssist died, more than the projected 42.6 percent mortality rate and well above the 17.4 percent in the control group. Baxter is continuing U.S. trials on the blood substitute on elective surgery patients, but the delays in emergency room testing mean the company now will not receive marketing approval here or abroad until at least 2001 and again throws open the race for an effective blood substitute. Northfield Laboratories Inc., Biopure Corp. and Alliance Pharmaceutical Corp. also are working to develop a viable blood substitute. The race to find a blood substitute has been intense because artificial blood could ease the effects of whole-blood shortages, lasts longer than conventional blood, eliminates the time-consuming need to match blood types and wipes out the risk of contamination with such viruses as HIV and hepatitis. The market represents instant billion-dollar potential because it can be used on battlefields and at accidents, as well as in poor countries that have weak blood bank networks. Also, members of some religious groups refuse to accept transfusions of human blood. Baxter said it had enrolled 117 patients in the European trauma test and, after consulting on the initial data of 79 of those patients with European regulators, decided to stop the test to further analyze the data. ``We are not seeing a statistically significant clinical benefit'' of using HemAssist, said spokeswoman Mary Thomas. ``It's very early, but we decided it's best to analyze all the data so we can appropriately determine the direction we should take,'' she said.

Eds: RECASTS with new material. No pickup AP Photos GEV101-3 By ALEXANDER G. HIGGINS Associated Press Writer
GENEVA (AP) _ From the United States to Malta, 46 countries on Tuesday demanded that rival neighbors India and Pakistan immediately stop testing nuclear arms and join efforts to eliminate the weapons. Islamic countries and some non-nuclear countries expressed concern about the recent tests, but they blamed the five traditional nuclear powers _ Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States _ for failing to heed the concerns of India and Pakistan. In an all-day emergency session of the 61-nation Conference on Disarmament, the non-nuclear countries urged the five powers to drop their opposition to proposed negotiations to eliminate their atomic arsenals. India and Pakistan maintain that such talks according to a ``time-bound framework'' would be the only way to address the security needs of all countries. Indian Ambassador Savitri Kunadi said if the five traditional nuclear powers had accepted India's attempts to set up global nuclear disarmament, ``we need not have gone in for our current testing program.'' Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States insist they are eliminating their arsenals, but the matter cannot be subjected to global bargaining. The conference, the world's main forum for negotiating disarmament agreements, said in a joint statement that the recent Indian and Pakistani tests flouted the test ban treaty. The five nuclear powers were among the countries that signed the joint statement spearheaded by Australia and New Zealand. ``The testing of nuclear weapons by India and Pakistan is totally irreconcilable with claims by both countries that they are committed to nuclear disarmament,'' it said. Pakistani Ambassador Munir Akram welcomed the debate, which said ``widely acknowledged'' that Pakistan was only reacting to ``the nuclear threat emanating from India.'' India's and Pakistan's tests last month ``blatantly undermine'' attempts to halt nuclear proliferation and threaten to undermine efforts to eliminate nuclear weapons, and belong ``to a bygone age,'' the conference statement said. The statement said it was ``crucial that India and Pakistan announce immediately a cessation to all further testing of these weapons, renounce their nuclear weapons programs and sign and ratify unconditionally the comprehensive test ban treaty.'' Also supporting the demand were Japan, South Korea, South Africa and European and Latin American nations, but conspicuously missing were Middle Eastern countries. Iran said it viewed the developments with ``deep concern,'' but said what is needed is ``an all-encompassing program for comprehensive nuclear disarmament.'' Despite Tehran's denials, Iran is widely believed to be pursuing its own nuclear-weapons program. On Monday Iran's foreign minister said on a visit to Islamabad that Muslims welcomed Pakistan's nuclear tests because it gives the Islamic world a bomb to counter Israel's widely suspected arsenal. South African Ambassador Jacob S. Selebi said it was ``imperative'' that the conference tackle nuclear disarmament.

ON May 20, Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim made an epochal pronouncement: a special agency, to be called the Asset Management Company, would be established to manage non-performing loans of financial institutions. The rationale for creating an asset management corporation is simple. If we flip back a page or two of history we would realise that many banks and financial institutions had been enervated by imprudent loans to unproductive sectors over the past several years. Lending to unproductive sectors are loans to speculators in the stock as well as the property markets. This profligate dispensation of credit resulted in a high percentage of non-performing loans. Readers of the financial pages of the daily papers will understand what are NPLs. But for those who don't, NPLs are loans that are not serviced. Phrased in language that all would understand, the borrowers did not pay even the interest due on the loans they had taken over a period of time. In good times, the period to designate loans as NPLs was six months. But late last year, the central bank changed this to three months as was the international norm. This was a factor but not the sole factor that perforced financial institutions to record in their accounts a high incidence of NPLs. In some cases, the proportion of NPLs against total loans disbursed was as high as 14 per cent. This was the primary reason why one bank, Sime Bank, suffered losses of RM1.5 billion and had to be taken over by RHB in a complex restructuring exercise that necessitated an injection of RM1.8 billion in fresh funds. Following the intervention of the central bank which issued guidelines to curb lending, the percentage of NPLs has been reduced to 9.3 as at the end of March. But the actual numbers are big and warrant grave concern. Bank Negara's statistics place the amount of NPLs at 9.3 per cent of all outstanding loans which totalled about RM500 billion at the end of March. This works out to RM46.5 billion. The figure is a mere statistic, signifying little to many readers. To understand the burden financial institutions have to endure, let us examine an example of a bank that has RM1 billion in deposits in savings accounts and in fixed deposits. The former requires the bank to grant six per cent in annual interest while the latter would warrant 10 per cent, at current rates. Averaged, it works out to about eight per cent on deposits or RM80 million. To service these deposits, the bank dispenses loans at an annual interest rate of at least 14 per cent, netting, if it uses all the cash at its disposal, more than RM140 million. It might even be as high as RM160 million. So when the profit and loss account is declared, the bank will have gained RM80 million. This is hunky-dory. But the rub is, many, if not most, financial institutions, have loans in their books that are not serviced by borrowers. In other words, NPLs. The bank had given out RM1 billion in loans. If 9.3 per cent of the loans is not serviced after the first three months, the loss the bank would have to bear would be a nominal RM93 million. Such a figure could easily erase the profit of the bank. True, loans disbursed are based on a percentage of the value of the collateral borrowers tender. Given the market norm, disbursement of loans would only be between 60 and 70 per cent of the value of assets. But a lender would not be overly preoccupied with the value of the collateral he has. His prime concern would be: The amount of money he has to provide in interest on the deposits he has collected; and The amount of money he receives in interest on the loans he had disbursed. If the two match, he is solvent; if his loan portfolio yields more than he has to dispense on deposits, he would be happy. The problem, however, is that his non-performing loans would eat up his profits. Simplified, NPLs accounting for slightly more than nine per cent of total loans would easily erase the nine per cent profit of any bank. And that in sum, is a basic fact that the authorities have acknowledged. Acknowledging NPLs is one thing, but coming up with an answer to at least manage that problem is another. This is where the Asset Management Company comes in. First readers must realise there are many asset managing companies. By genre, these are companies that invite and attract cash which are then invested in various instruments, like equities, fixed deposits, the money market and in bonds and goverment issued bills. Their main objective is to generate good returns on the funds they receive. But the AMC envisaged by the Government is of a slightly different pedigree. Its primary objective is to buy the NPLs from the financial institutions at a discount and later rehabilitate the loans or sell them to interested companies. Conversely, the purchase by AMC of the NPLs would relieve financial institutions of a burden, resulting in at least three ramifications. First, the sale of NPLs would provide the financial institutions with fresh funds to give new loans. Second, the institutions would be freed from the debilitating costs of servicing deposits that fund the NPLs. Third, the institutions would no longer carry in their accounts, suspended interest on the NPLs. In sum, the financial institutions would be placed on a solid plank to continue with their everyday business of accepting deposits and lending money. The logical question that follows is: how will the AMC be funded, if it is to be entrusted with buying NPLs totalling RM46.5 billion even at a 10 or 20 per cent discount? The amount adds up to a hefty figure. That question cannot be answered now since details will only be made available this week. But sources conversant with the concept of the AMC say the funds will come from, one, ``sovereign loans'' which are loans provided by the Government; two, foreign investors who might be willing to take up equity in the AMC; and, three, local investors. The next question is: how will the AMC undertake its task? Again, we have to wait for details that the Government will spell out this week. In the meantime, however, we can look at one precedent in the United States. Which brings us to the Resolute Trust Corporation, one of the models that the AMC is said to be ``loosely'' framed upon. Why was the RTC created? In the US, thousands of small banks, commonly known as Savings and Loans companies flourished in the 1970s and early 1980s. They basically invited deposits and gave loans to buyers of houses. Peter Lynch, in his book, Beating The Street, says many of the SLs became greedy. Entrepreneurs took over these small companies and began to disburse loans to dubious development projects in the early 80s. For a while, the loan portfolios and high interest rates made these SLs attractive investment vehicles. But recession set in and there were few takers of houses, apartments and shopping malls that the SLs bankrolled. The result was a financial fiasco the US had never encountered before. Beginning in the late 80s as many as 2,900 SLs were in financial trouble, forcing the George Bush administration to enact various laws, one of which established the RTC. This agency was entrusted with managing and disposing of the assets and liabilities of the failed SL companies. According to Lynch, the RTC had to bail out the SLs at a cost of about US$500 billion (about RM1.9 trillion) that is still being paid by American taxpayers. Now why would we want to frame a company on the American model that was established to bail out troubled banks. The answer is not simple. AMC is not a replica of RTC. Its character is different. The difference will be manifest in an article next week.

YOU used to have to be a teenager before you got to be part of the in crowd, but not any more. These days, even a six-year-old is at ease with ``cool'' language and other contemporary flavours like the Spice Girls. Education and exposure to instant communications have turned today's under-18s into a generally confident and articulate lot, with a mind of their own and a will to match. This, however, can be double-edged. In a consumption-oriented generation, merchandise marketing is aimed with deadly accuracy at a teenage segment that wants to be trendy at all costs. The tobacco industry knows it and pours millions annually into capturing this lucrative market through advertising, new flavoured and smokeless products, and brand-name merchandise. This is the battlefront on which activists consistently have to face off the industry, to reach the hearts and minds of youngsters first so that they make an informed and sustained choice of health over tobacco use. The World Health Organisation has dedicated the coming year to efforts that will help the young grow up without tobacco, a reference to both direct products and merchandise sold under the same brand-names. It recommends campaigns based on research and planning, to be pursued in ``tireless, strategic and aggressive'' fashion as a national agenda. But Malaysians are only too familiar with the static domestic setting in which tobacco production, cigarette manufacture, subsidiary businesses of tobacco companies and indirect brand-name promotions exist side by side. Without comprehensive laws, the Health Ministry relies on regulations to control tobacco use in public places including schools and university campuses. Enforcement, however sporadic, should not be the only solution. The ministry's second (and latest) national health and morbidity survey in 1996 found that 16.7 per cent (539,000) of adolescents smoke; more of them are boys; and that prevalence is higher in rural areas. In the first survey 10 years ago, adolescent smoking stood at nine per cent. With rare candour, the report concedes ``the public health sector lags 10 to 20 years behind transnational tobacco companies ... failure to act aggressively from the 1970s has made action in the 1990s more difficult''. Over the years, tobacco activists have protested the absence of a national action plan that addresses the special needs of youth smokers and discourages the creation of new generations of young nicotine addicts. Their concern could only have been amplified earlier this week when Deputy Education Minister Datuk Khalid Yunus glibly denounced ``truancy and smoking'' as twin terrors of the school population. Teachers and parents were told to deal with it although they are no closer to being given the resources, support services or specialised training to handle prevention, counselling and smoking cessation work. Recent developments in industrialised countries, where smoking trends are on the decline due to tough laws and increasing social disapproval, require a parallel and immediate review of the Malaysian response. For instance, US tobacco companies have found that strong policies on youth tobacco use, litigation and community activism at home are impeding business expansion, and are therefore building up markets abroad. National Centre for Tobacco-Free Kids (TFK) William Novelli warned of this last May when he called on Americans to take responsibility for public health affected by the external activities of ``US Tobacco''. It has since begun a global initiative that has caught the interest of tobacco activists in India, Turkey, Poland, Vietnam, Cambodia, Mongolia, Nicaragua and Zambia to date. The centre hopes to align US trade policies with health policies, provide technical support and funding to the no-tobacco lobby in other countries, and co-ordinate worldwide strategies. Over the past year, too, internal documents of tobacco companies have revealed that the youth market has always been a prime target to replenish a customer-base of adult smokers who die or who quit smoking. National Poison Centre (NPC) director and no-tobacco campaigner Professor Dzulkifli Abdul Razak says the Government must be alert to industry spin-doctors moving in on children with purportedly positive sponsorship. He cites the example of a shopping complex in Penang which has cigarette advertisements ``plastered all over'' an area where World Cup '98 is being promoted, pulling in the football fans among shoppers. ``Despite the norms of the International Olympic Committee and WHO against associating sports with tobacco products, this still goes on,'' he says. ``We should not have flip-flop policies where ministries obviously don't agree with one another because it confuses the public. Are we then justified in blaming teenagers for smoking?'' The Health Ministry attempts co-ordination of relevant ministries, non- governmental organisations and universities through a no-tobacco committee set up last year. ``It now disseminates information on the hazards of smoking. Next, it will encourage non-smokers to exercise their rights to a smoke-free environment,'' says principal assistant director Dr Sallehuddin Abu Bakar. Smoking cessation programmes are being designed to supplement clinics run by various bodies while government doctors and health education officers are to be trained to counsel patients who want to stop smoking. Under the next phase, NGO personnel will receive similar training to expand outreach and take no-smoking assistance into communities. The ministry has also designed a self-help booklet to help people quit smoking. However, every target group - patients with smoking-related illnesses, pregnant women, ``quitters'' and youths - requires different handling that takes into account individual needs in prevention and rehabilitation. Malaysian Cancer Council (Makna) project manager Farahida Mohamed Farid says youth-oriented no-tobacco work only skims the surface of the problem. ``Children are not stupid, but they should not be getting mixed messages. NGOs could help out more if the Education Ministry allows free contact between no-tobacco advocates and schools,'' she says. ``There are groups that would like to help schools set up an Action on Smoking or Health (ASH) Club, for instance. Information and activity kits could be provided to help members organise and monitor projects.'' Even looking at youths alone will be an intensive and extensive exercise, as the experience of the US-based Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids has shown (see accompanying story). Operating under the auspices of the National Centre for TFK, the campaign is into its third year and has achieved a key objective - to capture the imagination and excitement of the American public including youngsters. ``It may make you angry that tobacco hurts children and that tobacco companies make their money by addicting children to nicotine. Does it make you angry enough to want to do something about it?'' it asks children. There is reason for concern. Each day, 3,000 American youngsters become regular smokers and US youth smoking rates were at a 17-year high last year. Asked if the initiative could be replicated in Malaysia, the NPC's Dzulkifli says a coalition of NGOs could do this if they can put aside ``territorialism'' to work out details. Although the fragmentation of interests could get in the way, he sees this as a source of strength to extend youth-related information and activities from different perspectives, towards a holistic strategy. Farahida, who suggests priority for youth smoking-cessation programmes and training of school counsellors, adds it will be crucial to get working committees going and to ensure continuity of work. Up to now, children themselves have not been asked to find solutions to tobacco use, but have only been told they are a problem. This leads to a ``then what?'' question that has never been adequately answered by adults. The Campaign for TFK creates fun projects without losing sight of serious messages. It tracks and provides current news on the tobacco industry, legislation and projects on its website (www.tobaccofreekids.org). Tobacco control is promoted through Kick Butts Day, a nationwide event to encourage leadership among youngsters. Activists are recognised as Youth Advocates of the Year, while young actors serve as Youth Ambassadors. This dovetails with the WHO's suggestion to let young people ``take on the tobacco industry'' and demand actions like tobacco-advertising bans, through letters to officials in government and industry and to the media. For, as Novelli of the National Centre for TFK says: ``We don't have time or money to be timid or patient. Tinkering at the margins of the tobacco problem will not work.''

ASIAN students in Britain whose funding has been affected by the economic crisis in the region have been offered a helpline through an emergency scholarship fund set up by the British authorities. The STG6.6 million (RM37.44 million) fund, managed by the British Council, will be made available to students from Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea. ASIAN students in Britain whose funding has been affected by the economic crisis in the region have been offered a helpline through an emergency scholarship fund set up by the British authorities. The STG6.6 million (RM37.44 million) fund, managed by the British Council, will be made available to students from Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea. The fund is supported by the British Council, the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, British universities and British companies through the Department of Trade and Industry. British Council Press officer Ruth Brander said it was open to all students from the five countries already studying in British institutions of higher education or those joining in the coming academic year which begins in September. ``They are required to write to their respective British universities with reference to the scheme. The university will then decide on the deserving students and forward the application to the British Council.'' The scholarships would be awarded on merit and applicants should not be on any other scholarship, either local or foreign. This scheme is a one-off offer and only covers the 1998/99 academic year. Successful applicants will be get a STG1,600 for first degree courses while post-graduate students may get up to STG2,000. The scholarship scheme will come as a blessing for several British universities whose income is expected to drop substantially because of the lower enrolment of Asian students. British universities earn about STG300 million a year from Southeast Asian students. Of the estimated 23,000 Southeast Asian students in the UK, 18,105 are from Malaysia. It was reported that applications from Malaysian students this year had dropped by 36 per cent.

Dr RAHIMAH A. KADIR: Are you taking Wrigley's chewing gums, Chiclets or bubble gum? All three are actually modern versions of the original tasteless chewing gum (CG) or chictli made up of milk sap of the Mexican jungle tree - the sapodilla. It was a favourite of Latin Americans and was introduced into the United States by an exiled Mexican general - Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna. However, it was photographer cum inventor Thomas Adams who actually turned it into a commercial investment in 1871. Of the many types of CGs, Wrigley's peppermint gums appeared to be the most popular for many decades. The action of chewing gum is said to exercise the jaw muscles and helps to relieve facial tension which, in turn, can impart a general feeling of bodily relaxation. In modern dentistry, under the supervision of a dentist, tasteless chewing gum is often recommended for medically compromised patients who have problems with saliva production. Misuse or excessive use of chewing gums can, however, pose a number of oral health problems thus defeating the beneficiary purpose. For instance, today's gums are mostly prepared with sugar or artificial sugar. Sugar-flavoured chewing gums can be detrimental to your teeth if used excessively as it can react with bacterial plaque and turn your mouth into an acidic environment. The excessive chewing of gum will not allow enough time for the acidity to be leveled off into a neutral pH. Instead, the oral environment will be kept at a low acidic pH continuously. This can also give out a sourish smell and non-stop chewing of CG can also cause wear and tear of your jaw muscles. I suggest you try and wean off from the habit gradually. You'll be surprised at how much more attractive you look by keeping that constant chewing motion at bay. In the meantime you might want to consider substituting the sweet chewing gums to one that is sugarless. The latter contains artificial sugar which has been proven to counter or delay acid production.

THERE has been a refreshing change of cool air blowing in one corner of the commercial square of SS2 in Petaling Jaya. Two huge `fans' distributing a light mist of `dew' helps customers at the PJ Sidewalk Cafe keep their cool in these days of record hot afternoons. But more than just this, this section of Petaling Jaya is quite starved of an outlet that offers more than Asian and local cuisine. And no, we refuse to mention the greasy offerings from fast-food outlets. The month-old PJ Sidewalk Cafe nicely fills in this gap between Chinese cuisine, curry fish-head, Thai cooking and hawker fare. Billed as alfresco dining as well as indoor bistro and cafe and fun pub, it offers a fusion of flavours of both East and West. Running the show is the team of project manager Sammy Lee, operations manager Desmond Lun and executive chef Johnny Choo. The restaurant is located at the perimeter of the noisy business centre, with its open air dining area facing residential houses. A huge cream-coloured canopy keeps the sun and rain out while slabs of clear perspex tones down the buzz of traffic while maintaining the atmosphere of outdoor dining. Open daily from 10.30 in the morning till 12 midnight, the main attractions right now are the food and drinks served with yuppie attitude. Chew and Sharon sip on glasses of ice chocolate with chocolate ice-cream and chocolate syrup (RM8.50) while I slurp on ice mocha (RM9). This is really refreshing after the hot drive from the office. Just remember to stir in the scoop of ice-cream as otherwise the drink is unsugared. Carbonated drinks, fruit juices, hot drinks and tea are also available. Main meals are available for lunch and dinner with daily specials chalked up on the board both inside and outside. But in between, sandwiches come with a choice of white, grain pita or foccacia bread and fillings of roast chicken, beef, cheese, vegetarian, crabmeat and otak- otak as well as tuna, salami, pastrami, smoked salmon with roasted peppers, onion, mushroom, sundried tomato, capsicum, olives, capers and even artichoke. Tapas make a good in-between snack as well with items like seared mussels, eggplant canneloni, deepfried squid, rissoles and popiah from RM4.80. We had the escargot roll (RM6.80) with a filling of chopped escargots wrapped in popiah skin and fried to a golden crisp. It is served on a bed of lettuce and sambal garlic sauce. I like this much better than the seared scallops (RM6.80) tossed with harisa sauce and deepfried capers. There is an overwhelming smell of spices which really does nothing to improve the fresh scallops. A shame really. I feel fresh scallops need nothing more than just two minutes of panfrying on both sides to bring out the sweetness in them. Right now, Sammy says, there are at least 100 items in the menu. ``From customer feedback, we will reassess every three months, changing certain items and keeping the popular ones,'' says chef Johnny. As with most late afternoons in the Klang valley, it is pouring cats and dogs by 6 pm and we are so thankful for the thick canopy over our heads. The temperature drops and the air takes on a cool note. We are now ready for the selection of pasta. From the nine items on the menu, we pick spaghetti soto (RM11.80) and seafood capellini (RM13.80). The latter is fine angel hair pasta in a spicy prawn stock with plenty of fish, prawns and squid. The sauce is heavily flavoured with tomato, saffron and other spices. Johnny uses prawn shell as well as flower crab, simmering these in fish stock to get the shellfish aroma. Initially, I much prefered this to the spaghetti soto which is milder in flavour. But somehow, this local touch to an Italian basic endears by the mouthful. It comes with shredded chicken, chopped tomato, celery and a liberal dose of chopped chili padi. Watch out for these lethal bites unless like I, you are a chili padi fan. Crispy skin salmon (RM18.80) is unusual in that the crispy skin is reminiscent of salt fish, especially with the far too salty soy-based sauce that comes with it. It comes with a variety of salad leaves but is not particularly inspiring. But whatever is lacking in the salmon, Johnny more than makes up for in his mango chicken (RM14.50). This is an excellent example of fusion advantage. The well-marinated deboned chicken is panfried and served on a bed of lettuce and papadum. The sweet, yet mildly tangy mango sauce poured over provides an excellent foil for both the chicken and salad and softens the papadum. But no harm done here. If your tastebuds insist on local, nasi rames (RM16.90) is a complete meal. Just like nasi lemak, a mound of white rice comes escorted by a bevy of condiments. There's curry chicken, rendang, egg with sambal, pickled vegetables, tofu and keropok. Otherwise there's peranakan items like belacan fish, opor ayam, udang asam goreng and Dutch curry chicken as well as Japanese choices which we didn't get to try as the chef was out. The Dutch curry chicken is supposedly made from a traditional recipe and is served with white rice. It is very lemak and the fragrance of spices, especially serai, hits you before you even taste it. At the end of the meal, we ask for a cup of short white (RM4.50), a robust brew which comes with a frothy head. It is creamy with the full-blown chocolately bouquet of freshly-brewed coffee - perfect cheering up on a wet evening.

WHEN children watch us calmly discussing a problem, reasoning things out, and weighing alternative solutions, they naturally begin to value and imitate this behaviour. On the other hand, if we become irritable, argumentative, depressed, or overwhelmed by our problems or if we pretend that the problems will just go away or take care of themselves, what can we expect our children to learn? For a variety of psychological reasons, some parents may not exercise problem-solving skills in the home although they are capable problem-solvers at work or in the community. Take the case of Daud, a father of three, a pharmacist at a chain superstore. He works nine- and sometimes 10-hour days. He also takes courses toward a professional qualification in the hope that he might one day land a research position with a pharmaceutical company. Daud is proud of his ability to handle anything that comes his way at work. He considers himself cool-headed and rational, the man to call when a problem arises. But at home, he feels that he should have time away from problems. He tells his wife that he wants his home to be a sanctuary, a place for resting and recharging his spirit. Thus when he arrives home from work at 6.30pm only to be told that dinner will be late, he's mad. ``Late! Late again?'' he exclaims. ``Can't I get my dinner on time once a month?'' At dinner, his oldest daughter announces that she got a `C' on a spelling test. ``Well, if you studied like I told you to,'' he growls, ``you would have gotten an `A', wouldn't you? Nobody wants to do their job around here. Everybody takes the easy way. I've got a headache.'' He storms away from the table. It is a great mystery why we often treat casual acquaintances and even strangers better than those we love. And yet with effort, this does not have to be. When parents take responsibility for their roles as leaders in the family, they provide excellent models for their children. To them, you are a person with tremendous power - even more than the prime minister! There are some leadership qualities that parents need to exhibit in order to maintain happiness and individual esteem in the family. The following are some of them: You must have vision, direction, and goals. You must communicate your leadership effectively. You must keep your family focused on the goals. You must consider the needs of others. You must support progress. You must expect success and get it. Do you demonstrate to your child how to solve problems through your day to day words and actions? Think of a recent problem you had that affected your family. Were you late paying the bills? Did you have an illness that kept you from some of your normal activities? Did one of your children misbehave? Now, using the chart provided, check off the statements that best describe how you solved the problem. Did you check off more than half of the list? If not, make sure you read this column next week and we will discuss some practical tips on how you can implement the above points in problem-solving situations for your children to learn from.

Sweden defeats Italy 1-0 in warmup
AP Photos Available
GOTEBORG, Sweden (AP) _ Sweden defeated Italy 1-0 Tuesday after a last minute goal by striker Kennet Andersson. Andersson, one of the better players on the Swedish side, headed a left-wing cross from Andreas Andersson past Italian keeper Gianluca Pagliuca. Italy's coach Cesare Maldini started veteran strikers Roberto Baggio and Fabrizio Ravanelli. The duo had several chances, but failed to beat Coventry goalie Magnus Hedman. ``We played fairly well, but were somewhat weak in attack. I have nothing to regret except the defensive lapse in the final minute which cost the goal,'' Maldini said. ``Andersson, as usual, proved he's very good in the air. It was a warmup game, a good chance before the World Cup to experiment.'' Ravanelli had Italy's best scoring chance in the 66th minute of the game, but his shot hit Hedman's left post. Sweden had two good chances in the 55th and the 69th, but Inter's Pagliuca, who will substitute injured Angelo Perruzzi as starting keeper, made two easy saves. At times, Milan's defender Paolo Maldini had difficulties averting Swedish attacks. The first half was lack-luster and slow-paced. Players on both teams showed signs of hard training and the Italians arrived fresh from a 10-day-training period at Coverciano near Florence. Lazio's Alessandra Nesta was yellow-carded in the 26th minute after roughing Bologna striker Kennet Andersson. After the game, Andersson revealed that he had extended his contract with Bologna. The Swedish striker scored his 30th goal on the national side. Andersson was yellow-carded in the 57th. The warmup at Ullevi Stadium attracted 25,553 spectators. BC-Egypt-Building Collapse
Court acquits owner of collapsed Cairo building
CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ A Cairo court Tuesday acquitted on technicality a landlord convicted of manslaughter in the 1996 collapse of his 12-story building that killed 64 residents. The Court of Cassation rejected a High Security court ruling last year, which found Raouf Wissa Ibrahim, 60, guilty of illegally adding four floors atop an eight-story building. Prosecutors said the additional weight caused the building to buckle under. Ibrahim was sentenced to seven years in jail, but wasn't imprisoned pending his appeal. Egypt's Middle East News Agency said the Cassation Court ruled that Ibrahim was not liable since he had already been tried for adding the extra floors in 1977 when he was fined and given a suspended jail sentence. It was not known if the Cassation Court put the blame on authorities for not demolishing the four floors. The Court also reversed a ruling against two engineers and ordered their retrial in another court. The engineers were also sentenced by the High Security court to three years imprisonment, and fined 325,396 Egyptian pounds (dlrs 95,000) for negligence. They were accused of removing columns and supporting walls on the ground floor to make room for a bank. The building collapse in the upscale Heliopolis district in Cairo sparked calls for tougher construction laws and stricter punishments for shoddy building practices, which became rampant in the 1970s because of rising real estate prices. my/vj

Talks under way in Air France pilots' strike
EDS: UPDATES with Wednesday flights, talks could last overnight AP Photos PAR106,109 By IAN PHILLIPS Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Top brass at Air France sat down with striking pilots' unions Tuesday in an attempt to keep the World Cup from becoming a no-show event for thousands of fans. The walkout at the World Cup's official airline, in its second day, was already causing scheduling nightmares for teams preparing for the soccer championship that begins June 10. The president of the state-owned airline, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, was among officials who opened talks at 4 p.m. (1400 GMT) with the unions representing 3,200 pilots, at the company's headquarters at Charles de Gaulle airport north of Paris. More than 4 1/2 hours later, talks were still under way, with officials on both sides saying privately the meeting could last well into the night and resume Wednesday. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. An Air France source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the airline would stand firm on 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual salary cuts, but that it could eventually drop its two-tier scale paying a lower salary to new pilots. In an interview published Tuesday, Spinetta said there was ``still a lot of work to do'' to settle the salary dispute with the pilots and suggested postponing talks until after the World Cup ends July 12. ``Putting off the talks until the summer is absolutely conceivable,'' Spinetta told the daily Le Parisien. He said the company was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike, which was forcing tens of thousands of people worldwide to look for other ways to travel. Air France's main pilots' union called the 15-day action to protest 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. The walkout disrupted training for the French national team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. ``Yes, indeed a lot of players will arrive late because of the strike. It risks turning our whole day upside down,'' Jacquet said. At Charles de Gaulle airport, a shop employee sat alone Tuesday in an empty store stocked with World Cup insignia. Opposite was a newspaper stall where headlines read: ``World Cup held hostage,'' and ``World Cup in peril.'' After walking 70 kilometers (43 miles) from Paris to Chartres over the weekend with 10,000 other youths on a pilgrimage, Ellen Kerry was trying to get to New York on an Air France flight. ``We only found out when we got in the taxi that there was a strike. We could have saved the money and walked,'' said Kerry, whose home is in Virginia. At Marseille's Marignane Airport, passenger Pierre-Antoine Graziani was getting fed up waiting to get on a waiting list to fly to Paris. ``I'm told something different from one hour to another,'' he said. ``I might take my chances with the TGV,'' the high-speed French train. Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France and would probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations if necessary. But the U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is flying its team to Paris on American Airlines, connecting to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses in France. Former French player Michel Platini, co-president of the World Cup organizing committee, accused the pilots Tuesday of ``taking the country hostage. ... This is the image of France at stake, not necessarily that of an airline.'' (ip-cb)

HE has been a police sergeant and a tapioca farmer, among other occupations. He has also worked in the British Royal Air Force in Singapore, wrote background music for the film industry in India, a band leader in Sabah and is now an accomplished pianist out to woo listeners to his special blend of music - a mix of western percussion and the native sounds of ethnic groups in Sabah. Hailed as the `Father of Sabah Music', Peter Pragas' love affair with the piano began during his childhood days in Penang. At the age of seven, his father, Anthony Pragasam initiated his first attempt on the piano keys. Together with eight other siblings, Pragas grew up with music in the house. But he was the only one who has pursued it with a passion born of a natural bent, and a keen ear for music. A chance meeting with two renowned musicians - Professor Hoffman from Germany and Professor Arulde from India - when he was 12 years old led to professional coaching for Pragas in the art of piano and violin. In later years, he completed his Grade Eight in the external course of the Trinity College of Music. Pragas recalls playing the organ in church, on the days that his father could not make it, as his first introduction to a public audience. ``My dad was the organist in our church. But being an editor with a local daily, there were times he worked night shifts, and couldn't play in church, so I would replace him,'' the 72-year old recollects. The Japanese Occupation of Malaya saw him taking up arms in the police force as sergeant, a role he eventually relinquished to opt instead for planting tapioca in Nibong Tebal. When the war over, he went back to school, completed his Senior Cambridge, and left for Singapore to join the Royal Air Force in the administrative department. But he was restless, needing an outlet for his creative side. Finally, Pragas went to India (to quote him) ``with star dust in his eyes'' to seek his destiny. He was in his 20s, enthusiastic and eager to assimilate experiences in the music industry. India proved to be the turning point in his quest for further knowledge in Eastern/Carnatic (classical) music. For the next four years, he worked as a freelance assistant music director at Gemini Studios and in Bombay theatres. ``It wasn't easy. I had to learn the notations of Eastern music. Dad had taught me to read music notes of the gregorian chants, which means latin church music. But this is different from modern music notes, and in India, I learned different notes again,'' he says. After India, he came back to Kuala Lumpur, because he ``had learned enough''. He joined Film Unit (now known as Filem Negara) as director of music. In 1957, during a visit to Borneo, he fell in love with Jesselton, now known as Kota Kinabalu. A year later, he joined RTM Sabah, and set up a band called the ``Se-renaders''. ``There was no proper band at that time to promote local music. We entertained people in the interior, the suburban and the urban areas of Sabah,'' he reminisces. The intriguing sounds of Sabah enticed him to stay, and in 1959 he married Helen Chung, who is of Chinese Kadazandusun descent. The couple settled in Kota Kinabalu. Three fully grown offsprings later - namely Adrian, Sandra and Jeanette - Pragas is still inspired by Sabah. ``I'm still learning about the music of the place, and the intriguing sounds that you get when you blend piano and local traditional instruments together,'' he enthuses. He recalls the pride he felt when EMI launched his album entitled Land Below The Wind in 1979. In 1981, Pragas was asked by the Sabah government to produce a set of cultural albums in conjunction with the state's Centennial Celebration. The collection, entitled Sabah Centennial Celebration, comprises one album of recorded native traditional music and an album of popular songs favoured by the people of Sabah at that point in time. This momento is being exhibited at the state museum in Kota Kinabalu. For his contributions to Sabah, Pragas was confered the Ahli Setia Darjah Kinabalu Award in 1993. After retiring from public service, Pragas concentrated on his music, releasing Mystical Malaysia in 1987, and Kyrie Elesion in 1989. Another project is Memories from Sabah, which incorporates compositions in Kadazan, Bahasa Malaysia, Chinese and English. In this collection, Pragas has blended piano melodies with the sounds of traditional instruments like the sompoton (a number of flutes joined together), the turali (nose flute) and the bungkau which resembles a Jews harp made of bamboo. His most recent project, released last month, is Greetings from Sabah which incorporates the sounds of piano, sompoton, bungkau, turali, ukelele, accordion and tambourine. Today, Pragas still plays at the Shangri-La and Hyatt hotels in Sabah, as well as at the beach resort in Kinarut. He likens his love for the piano to a love for orchestra, because as he says, one can produce full harmony and orchestral sounds on a piano, unlike some instruments which can only produce melodies. ``I modify slightly the sompoton to suit western scales, but the bungkau needs no modification,'' he explains when asked about the way to blend the music. Of his three children, only Jeanette has followed in his footsteps. She teaches music in Sabah. Adrian is a civil engineer based in Brunei while Sandra is an educationist in Kuala Lumpur. ``Music is a good legacy to leave behind, not just to one's children but to future generations. I cannot get bored with music. There are so many things to learn about the music industry, or for that matter, any industry. There's just no end to learning,'' he concludes.

IT'S happened, and much sooner than I had expected, too. Despite endless parental pleading to take it easy and personal vows never to sink so low, I've become the typical Malaysian driver of reckless renown. I motored hesitantly onto the roads for the first time less than six months ago and spent the initial period minding my road p's and q's, anxious not to provoke anybody into muscling my tiny Kancil into the longkang. The priorities then were clear - let people cut in front if they want. Let them toddle in front at a Sunday-drive-like 30km/hr. Let them shower you with abusive language. Just get to wherever you want to go in one piece without getting lost. But the constant frustration of being bullied, sideswiped and honked at was simply too much. Gandhi himself would have eventually abandoned his non-violence stance and lost his temper. Which I meant I did exactly that almost immediately. My speedometre has been breaking new ground lately, which I first noticed the day I spotted my mother's white-knuckled grip on her seat. I've also stopped rolling over and playing dead the minute a bigger car challenges me. It happens often, probably because with the ``P'' sticker on my windshield and the Lillputian size of the car, I might as well be carrying a ``Kick Me'' neon sign around. It's funny how bigger, luxury car drivers act all outraged if a smaller car dares to put up any resistance. They glare with a ``How dare you?!'' glint in their eye as you niftily move your way past. One guy nearly had a apoplectic fit when I refused to let him cut in front me, and promptly tried to barrel into my lane the minute we hit the highway. Godzilla may now be in the theatres preaching ``Size does matter!'' but a pinch of foolhardy stubbornness can level the playing field for smaller cars. The exceptions to the rule are the truly huge vehicles - buses, construction trucks - that often clog our roads. Going head to head with any of these mammoths isn't asserting your right, it's being stupid. Luxury car drivers, however, are a different class. Their driving often suggests that they believe the money they plonked down for their pricey imports entitles them to a bigger share of the road. They don't seem to fully realise that it's only earned them a migraine- inducing payment plan, which is why I've been thinking about having a car bumper sticker made up: ``I'm making my car payments just fine, how about you?'' Now, being Asian, I'm getting the sneaking suspicion that all this bragging of on-the-road bravado is going to tempt the fates to screw up my karma, or whatever you want to call it, and land me into trouble. So let me explain this: I'm a responsible driver. Most of us Kancil drivers are actually, because we're mindful of our size. But we're also defensive about it and won't take any strong-arm tactics without biting back. Yes we're small, but we're also nimble. And you know what? In a city where public parking is as rare as a Yeti sighting, guess who'll be able to squeeze into the tiny spaces?

Four survivors of Antarctic crash need medicine, outside help
MOSCOW (AP) _ Four Russians seriously injured in a helicopter crash in Antarctica are being treated on a Russian ship that has only one day's supply of medicine, a news agency said Tuesday. The injured need to be taken to the nearest port, Cape Town, South Africa, for more sophisticated medical care, but that is a 10-day voyage, ITAR-Tass said. A MI-8 helicopter with nine people on board crashed Monday, 15 minutes after taking off from the research vessel Academician Fyodorov and shortly before reaching its destination, the Russian Antarctic station Novolazarevskaya. ITAR-Tass said officials on the Academician Fyodorov were trying to get more medicine from the Russian and Indian polar stations. (ls)

Quake survivor reaches village too late to help With Afghanistan-Quake
By ZAHEERUDDIN ABDULLAH Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ By the time Mohammad Karim reached his village, nearly everyone was dead. All that was left was to pull bodies from the earthquake debris and bury them quickly, without even a prayer. Karim, a rugged-looking farmer in his mid-30s, was 50 kilometers (30 miles) away in Faisabad when the earth heaved in a violent jolt that devastated scores of villages like Chawgani, where he lived. With four friends, Karim hitched a ride, then walked to Chawgani. They found little left standing. ``We started digging. When we brought the people out they were already dead. One of them was my cousin who was married two months ago. He was lying next to his wife,'' said Karim. All the members of two families related to Karim were wiped out in the quake, he said _ more than a dozen people. Few in the village of about 200 survived. ``We brought the bodies from under the destruction and buried them without an Islamic prayer. We didn't have time,'' he said. Survivors, most of them suffering broken bones, face shortages of food, clean water and medicine. Karim said most of the people in Faisabad, the provincial capital of Badakhshan province, lost relatives in the quake. Look around, he advised a reporter. ``You cannot find a smile on any face.''
