FOR many, ``transparency'' refers to the clear sheet of plastic used for presentations with overhead projectors. That however, is not the ``transparency'' we will be addressing. For the last few months you would have noticed that transparency has been hotly discussed. Notwithstanding this, people are still unsure about it, or more importantly what good it is to them. We will look at what transparency is, followed by the global and domestic implications. We will end it off with the crucial aspects of how transparency affects the everyday investor and how it can benefit you in investment decisions. One definition of ``transparent'' is ``something that is easily seen through or easily understood''. An alternative might be ``a thing or service is transparent when you know what is in it, or how it really works''. In other words you are not in the dark. The concept stands for putting everything on the table for everyone to see. Other than trade secrets such as the special recipe for Kentucky Fried Chicken, the consumer has a right to know. Global THERE is a definite trend towards greater transparency on a global level as the number of businesses operating in more than one country continues to grow. Typically developed nations operate with a relatively high degree of transparency and expect the same when doing business in other parts of the world. In order for businesses to interact and operate across borders, they have to be able to understand each other. In Penang there is a high-technology centre manufacturing a variety of goods, not to mention personal computers. Factories there actually import some of the parts to manufacture the computers. When a computer maker imports, it wants to know every detail about the goods that it is getting, down to the finest points. If the part can affect the finished product, it wants to know. If the supplier of the goods were to say ``just take the product and don't ask so many questions'', chances are the computer maker would go to another supplier. Domestic THERE have been many calls for increased transparency in Malaysia especially in the financial sector. As is the case anywhere in the world, an economy does not become transparent overnight; it is part of the development process. From a global standpoint increasing transparency will make Malaysia more attractive to foreign investors over the long-term. With the current regional economic crisis, the demand for information is greater than ever. It is ironic that it takes a downturn to increase the need for information. In the boom times people are more liberal, and they do not want to know quite as much. In fact, the drive for information should be strong all the time, not just during a downturn. The most recent example of the need for a high level of transparency is the newly-formed Asset Management Company. The authorities and analysts have already said the AMC must be exceptionally transparent to be a successful venture. Man On The Street MOST of us are not manufacturing personal computers or selling non- performing loans, so does transparency really mean anything to the average investor? Actually, it means a lot! Now, more than ever, you need to know exactly what is involved in any potential investment. You will find that for the same investment some companies provide substantially more information than others. The more information you can get about a potential investment, the better. If you are not able to get all the information you want, you had better be asking yourself why. If there is nothing to hide why not be completely transparent? The trend towards greater transparency is definitely in favour of the individual investor. In essence, it allows the individual to see the situation in a better light. When it comes to investments there are some basics that you should look out for on transparency. It makes good sense to know all the fees or costs associated with the investment. If they seem hidden or in ``extra'' small print you should be asking yourself why they aren't made easy to understand. Next, you want to check what protection you will have. For instance, are there investment restrictions so that your interests are safeguarded and you will know where your money is going? Lastly, look for the investment to very clearly spell out any potential risks associated with it. Nothing comes free and the companies should tell the investors up front what it is going to cost, in all respects. But the investor also has a role to play in the development. The investor has to be very demanding in two respects. First, you have to demand more information from companies that you are investing in or considering. It is as a result of this demand that the companies will start to supply the information the investing public wants. Second, if you are not getting the necessary information do not invest in the product. With the lack of demand for the product the company will get the hint very quickly that it has to meet potential investors' needs. If investors continue to give business to companies which do not have transparent policies there is no reason for them to change. At the end of the day, transparency benefits everyone, except those who have something to hide. As an investor, it will definitely benefit you in the short- and long-term.

Sweden defeats Italy 1-0 in warmup
AP Photos
GOTEBORG, Sweden (AP) _ Sweden defeated Italy 1-0 Tuesday after a last minute goal by striker Kennet Andersson. Andersson, one of the better players on the Swedish side, headed a left-wing cross from Andreas Andersson past Italian keeper Gianluca Pagliuca. Italy's coach Cesare Maldini started veteran strikers Roberto Baggio and Fabrizio Ravanelli. The duo had several chances, but failed to beat Coventry goalie Magnus Hedman. ``We played fairly well, but were somewhat weak in attack. I have nothing to regret except the defensive lapse in the final minute which cost the goal,'' Maldini said. ``Andersson, as usual, proved he's very good in the air. It was a warmup game, a good chance before the World Cup to experiment.'' Ravanelli had Italy's best scoring chance in the 66th minute of the game, but his shot hit Hedman's left post. Sweden had two good chances in the 55th and the 69th, but Inter's Pagliuca, who will substitute injured Angelo Perruzzi as starting keeper, made two easy saves. At times, Milan's defender Paolo Maldini had difficulties averting Swedish attacks. The first half was lack-luster and slow-paced. Players on both teams showed signs of hard training and the Italians arrived fresh from a 10-day-training period at Coverciano near Florence. Lazio's Alessandra Nesta was yellow-carded in the 26th minute after roughing Bologna striker Kennet Andersson. After the game, Andersson revealed that he had extended his contract with Bologna. The Swedish striker scored his 30th goal on the national side. Andersson was yellow-carded in the 57th. The warmup at Ullevi Stadium attracted 25,553 spectators. ALL eyes of the international eco-tourism fraternity are trained on Pulau Kukup, a mangrove island one kilometre off the south-western tip of Johor. Pulau Kukup, reputed to be the world's largest mangrove island, will soon be on the world eco-tourism map as the country's second permanent wetlands site. Tasik Bera in Pahang is the first. The Johor Government has engaged Wetlands International Asia-Pacific to undertake a detailed study to support its application for permanent wetland status for the island. Pulau Kukup is unique for its extensive open mudflat area. Mudflats serve as an important stopover and feeding ground for migratory birds, due to the presence of mollusc species such as crabs, snails, shrimps and worms. These represent a food source for many birds. About 450 kinds of birds, including five shorebird species, have been identified on the island. The island is also a breeding ground for the Lesser Adjutant Stork (Leptotilus Javanicus) which is listed as vulnerable in the Red List of Threatened Animals. Reptilian, amphibian and mammalian species also live in the island's mangrove forest. A huge population of wild pigs, monkeys, snakes and fish, including a variety of the mud skipper which measures more than 50 centimetres in length, abound. Johor Environment and Consumer Affairs Committee chairman Dr Chua Soi Lek said the 1,298-hectare island, including 650ha of mudflats, was now under the Johor National Parks Corporation. Dr Chua is the technical chairman of the corporation which has the distinction of managing Johor's national parks, unlike other States where national park areas are run by the Federal authority. He said the island which was gazetted as a national park in 1996 had been divided into four zones - the mudflats, coastal mangrove area, slightly elevated ground in the interior where the Rhizophora apiculata mangrove trees grow, reaching heights of up to 25 metres, and the central region of mixed vegetation including nipah and undergrowth. The coastal area can be broken into three distinct mangrove areas: the north-eastern and south-eastern zones where the 10-metre Rhizophora apiculata mangrove trees grow, the north-west with its 20-metre Sonneratia alba trees, and the south-east with a mixture of Avicennia intermedia, Avicennia alba and Rhizophora apiculata. There are two stretches of coast comprising eroded banks of about a metre high which are backed by the Rhizophora apiculata and Bruguiera gymnorhiza mangrove species. He said other species found on the island are the Rhizophora mucronata and Bruguiera cylindrica. Studies have shown that clear-felling of mangrove trees on Pulau Kukup when it was managed by the State Forestry Department before being gazetted as a national park, had changed its natural mangrove composition. The State Government's decision to gazette the island as a national park is a positive effort towards protecting and enhancing the mangrove habitat, which is threatened by development, pollution and reclamation activities. Pulau Kukup has suffered from unplanned reclamation and development of the Kukup waterfront villages by fishermen. The villages with about 200 illegal houses built on reclaimed mangrove swamp land, are not within the Pontian District Council's jurisdiction. Thus, it's without a proper waste disposal system and residents dump their garbage into the sea, causing serious pollution. Another source of pollution is the 70 fish farms cradled in the sheltered waters between the Kukup shoreline and Pulau Kukup. The island is also hit by ships dumping sludge and numerous oil slicks. Yet Pulau Kukup retains much of its natural charm. During high tide, it is submerged except for 40 per cent of the forest canopy, causing the trees to appear to be ``floating'' in the sea. During low tide, the mudflats surrounding the island are totally exposed. Dr Chua said in its quest for permanent wetland status, the island enjoys the advantage of a strategic location along the path of migratory birds. ``A variety of large and small birds including the Chinese Harrot and Green Harrot fly about 5,000km from China and Siberia to the island. ``Bird enthusiasts can view these birds nesting on the island between September and April.'' Dr Chua said in anticipation of an eco-tourist influx, the State Government will spend RM1.3 million to build infrastructure such as a jetty, walkway, bird watching tower and fishing facilities. He said existing chalets run by Kukup fishermen would be upgraded. Facilities are also being planned for visitors on educational or scientific research trips. Though necessary, it's hoped that such development will not diminish the island's natural charms.

FREETOWN, Sierra Leone (AP) _ The head of the U.N. refugee agency began talks Tuesday in Sierra Leone on repatriating a half-million refugees to this battle-scarred West African country. UNHCR director Soren Jessen-Petersen flew into Sierra Leone's capital of Freetown late Monday for meetings with President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah and other government officials before leaving on Wednesday. Discussions focused on the problem of repatriating 530,000 Sierra Leoneans who have fled the country since 1991, UNHCR officials said. Most of the emigrees have sought refuge in neighboring Guinea, Liberia and the Gambia. Jessen-Petersen said UNHCR had launched an urgent appeal for dlrs 7.3 million to give emergency assistance to thousands of refugees who fled Sierra Leone since January this year. ``We are talking about life and death and the need for refugees to survive,'' Jessen-Petersen said, estimating that possibly thousands were in need of food aid. So far, the United States had pledge dlrs one million to the problem, he added. A 1991-96 rebel war in Sierra Leone triggered an exodus of some 380,000 refugees from the country. A further 150,000 are believed to have fled since May last year when Kabbah's government was ousted by troops loyal to Lt. Col. Johnny Paul Koroma. After spending months in exile, Kabbah was restored to power by a Nigerian-led West African intervention force in March. (crm-gam)

ANALYSTS concur that the steps taken by Malaysian Airline System Bhd (MAS) to sell, lease and defer delivery of aircraft are positive for the long term. However, even with the deferment, analysts expressed concerns over funding costs when delivery of new aircraft eventually begins in the year 2000. One analyst pointed out that the overall load factor of MAS is currently 60 per cent. This means that only 60 per cent of the company's aircraft is being used. ``With the extra capacity, the national carrier should focus on saving costs,'' said the analyst. She said that sluggish demand for air travel in Asia at present has forced other Asian airlines to slash airfares. With such competition, MAS will have to be more efficient, the analyst added. The sale and leaseback arrangements for some of MAS' aircraft are timely, another analyst said. This should be done in order for the group to repay some of its debts. Net borrowings for MAS currently stand at some RM11 billion, the analyst said. ``A huge problem for the group is that over 90 per cent of the loans was secured with floating interest rates and these rates are now in double digits,'' the analyst commented. The analyst agreed that the delay in aircraft delivery will ease some cost pressures on MAS. However, he said the group should have obtained a longer time extension. Analysts contacted by Business Times gave mixed opinions on factors which had adversely affected the national carrier. Most of them, however, agreed that exposure to foreign debts is a large concern. ``Unlike Singapore Airlines which uses cash to purchase aircraft, MAS borrows since there is a limited amount of disposable income that it can lure,'' one analyst said. Another analyst mentioned that fuel costs are expected to be higher with the fall in the ringgit. Even though fuel prices dropped by 15 per cent, total fuel cost incurred by MAS was RM215 million for the year ended March 31 1998, which was attributed largely to the weak currency. However, one analyst contended that weak regional demand for air travel will be the bane for MAS in the current financial year. ``With depressed currencies and less disposable income, Asians are not likely to travel more,'' the analyst said. However, the analyst added, the currency depreciation is also a blessing for MAS as more foreign tourists are enticed to visit Malaysia as they get more value for their money.

LESS than a year ago, when the economic slowdown started, three entrepreneurs joined forces to embark on an uncharted course. To track down advertisements, monitor them and offer the compilations to clients to keep them in touch with what was going on in the marketplace. Today, MediaBanc has a staff of six and business is growing. I asked General Manager Alan Lim the story. S: What are MediaBanc's core activities? L: They fall into two areas. One is our Advertisement Library of all television, radio and print advertisements which we have monitored. These are categorised by brands, industry, language, duration and the month the ad was launched plus a title or file name for each entry. For example, you can make a request for two chosen brands of toothpaste ads which appeared in the last six months and if you require the commercials in English only. The second area we are active in is news monitoring. Based on standing instructions or on an ad-hoc request basis, we can monitor your news, your competitors' news or even your industry news when it appears over television, on radio and in the newspapers. This service also covers monitoring the TV and Radio programme which you sponsored to make sure that it appeared as promised or just to keep a copy of the programme for future reference. Additionally, we do media schedule monitoring where the ad agency or client will provide us a copy of the booked media schedule and we'll make sure they appear as scheduled. The requirements of every client are always different. Our ads are digitised or scanned into the computer and categorised across many spectrums. And this can best be done using a computer system with a good database. S: Are you planning to build an archive of Malaysians ads for future generations of Malaysians and students to refer to? L: Yes. We hope libraries, advertising schools, advertising associations and the like will be able to feature our advertisement library in the near future when we are ready with a substantial archive. S: Who are your main clients and how do you serve them? L: Our big clients are ad agencies, public relations companies and those involved in the field of advertising. And second, on an ad-hoc basis where they will contract us to monitor the news/programme or do a compilation of a certain category of ads. As for the name MediaBanc, Media means we do all types of media monitoring work and Banc suggests our customers can withdraw what they need as and when they need to. S: How many advertisements do you have in your library so far? What categories do you cover? L: We have all TV commercials from the past eights years (about 5,000) in our library and they cover all categories. ASSET securitisation should be made available in the Islamic capital market as it can provide enormous flexibility to the Islamic Debt Securities (IDS), said an analyst at the Rating Agency Malaysia (RAM). Zameema Ariff, the analyst at RAM's Islamic desk said this concept could be the key answer to one of the many issues of the Islamic Finance industry - recourse to liquidity. ``A factor that could be considered so as to raise our Islamic capital market to a new dimension is the concept of securitisation - specifically asset-backed securitisation,'' said Zameema. ``Some of the benefits of asset securitisation such as the concept of tranching the cash flow from the financial assets are just as applicable in Islamic asset securitisation,'' said added. This concept, she said, can provide enormous flexibility as each instrument can be formulated and designed to meet the investment objectives of different classes of investors. Zameema believed that by broadening and deepening the Islamic capital market, it would not only provide greater options to the existing pool of capital providers but would also draw the attention of the international investment community especially those from the West Asia. In an article dated June 1 1998, she said although Islamic financing is one of the fastest growing capital pools nowadays, the Islamic capital market still lacks the attractiveness. She noted that the Islamic capital market would need to be attractive from all angles and in all aspects which include pricing, innovations, universality of acceptance, practicality and flexibility. The selection of a financing option is primarily based on merit, she said and not based on religious considerations or moral suasion. She said the broadening of the investor base would also bring Malaysia one step closer to realising its vision to become the regional financial centre. In 1997, some RM10 billion was raised from Islamic Debt Securities (IDS) which constitutes 21 per cent of the country's total private debt securities. This figures show that the Malaysian IDS market has successfully grown out of its infancy phase, said Zameema. ``The viability of Islamic finance is no longer an issue as the success of the domestic IDS market within a short period is a testimony of the widespread acceptance of Islamic finance principles in the country,'' she said. WHILE fare payment on urban transit in Malaysia continues to operate in isolation from each other, many countries have moved towards the ``one ticket from origin to destination'' concept of travel. One has to understand that integrated ticketing is not a system but a concept. There are various ways to implement it. It can mean literally just one ticket from origin to destination. Some systems also require passengers to buy ``transfer tickets'' while others work on the common stored-value card or electronic smartcard which can be used on various modes of transport. One of the simplest examples is Melbourne, where public transport is served by three modes, namely bus, commuter trains and trams. Although the trains and trams are operated by The Met (the trading name of the Public Transportation Corporation) many bus services, especially in the outer suburban areas, are run by private operators. Nevertheless, tickets commonly known as ``Met tickets'' can be used on all services within the authority's three zones. The beauty of the system is that a commuter can use all three modes of transport with just one ticket, which can come in the form of a two-hour, daily, weekly, monthly or yearly ticket, bought according to the zones in which one needs to travel. Besides single-zone tickets, multiple-zone tickets are also available. If a commuter has a two-hour Zone One and Two ticket, he can travel on a feeder bus from his home in Zone Two, transfer to a commuter train which brings him into the city in Zone One, and then transfer onto a tram when he gets off the train. His ticket will be valid for two hours from his first journey and can be used for as many trips on any mode within the two zones as long as they are completed within the two hours. Working on a different concept is the system in Singapore, where the common ticket is actually a stored value card, called the Farecard, issued by a common clearing house Transitlink Pte Ltd. The card can be used on the two bus companies which cover the entire republic (Singapore Bus Service and Trans-Island Bus Service), and the rail-based Mass Rapid Transit. For buses, commuters will have to feed the Farecard into a validator which is installed on all buses. The commuter presses a button to indicate the fare, which will be deducted from the card. A ticket is then issued to prove payment. To ride on the MRT, a commuter merely has to feed the card into the turnstile machine upon entering or leaving the system. The correct fare will be deducted automatically. Strictly speaking, the card itself is not a ticket, and the passenger still pays separate fares for each mode of travel. However, the fact that the card is accepted by all modes and allows for cashless travel makes it as convenient as a common ticket. One further peculiarity the card has afforded is the transfer rebate system, making travel involving transfers from one mode to another cheaper than the total amount of full fares for each trip added up. According to the guidebook issued by Transitlink, the subsequent fare will be 25 cents less for adults and 10 cents less for children if a commuter transfers from the MRT to a bus within 30 minutes of leaving the MRT exit turnstile. Similarly, the same rebate will be given to a commuter who transfers from a bus to MRT, or from one bus to another. In these cases, the time given for the transfer depends on the fare paid on the bus used before the transfer is made. The Transitlink card does not replace the individual fare collecting systems of the bus companies or MRT, where commuters can still pay cash to buy tickets. A letter from SBS Bus Services Pte Lte corporate communications manager Loo Ing Heng said his company was also participating in a trial conducted by the Singapore Land Transport Authority for the use of contactless smartcards, similar to Rangkaian Segar Sdn Bhd's Touch n' Go card. One place where the smartcard has been successful is Hong Kong, where the Octopus Card allows a commuter to travel on the underground Mass Transit Railway, Tuen Mun-Yuen Long light rail transit, Kowloon-Canton (commuter) railway, Citybus, Kowloon Motor Bus and by ferry to the outer islands. All these systems, including the MTR, have the smartcard readers at the entrance and exits, where passengers have to ``touch'' their cards upon entry and exit, and the relevant fares will be deducted automatically. And just like Singapore, the Octopus Card system merely supplements the individual ticketing systems of each mode. Passengers can still purchase tickets for each form of transport.

SHAH ALAM, Mon. - Police have so far identified two companies involved in the theft of water in Selangor and both the cases have been referred to the Deputy Public Prosecutor for action, said Inspector-General of Police Tan Sri Rahim Noor today. Without naming the companies, he said the police were awaiting the DPP's instructions. ``We believe there are many more industries involved in the theft of water. We will be working closely with the State Government, Waterworks Department and other relevant authorities to nab the culprits.'' Ever since the water rationing exercise, Rahim said the police in Selangor and Kuala Lumpur had had their hands full responding to complaints related to water woes including theft, vandalism of water pipes and hydrants and fights between residents when water tankers visited the housing estates. ``Problems related to water supply are also highlighted in the media practically every day,'' he added. Speaking to reporters after paying a courtesy call on Selangor Menteri Besar Datuk Abu Hassan Omar at his office today, Rahim felt that public should voice their grouses and problems to the State Government, State Exco and the relevant departments. ``We understand the problems the people face in the dry spell. ``People should understand and be patient. From his discussion with the Menteri Besar, Rahim said he came to understand that all possible short and long-term measures were being taken to resolve the water problem. He said he also discussed with Abu Hassan matters pertaining to crime and social problems in the State. ``We are very concerned about the increase in crime, especially that related to property in Selangor and Federal Territory, over the past four months. ``Property crime has shot up by 40 per cent the last few months as compared with the same corresponding period last year.'' He said Kuala Lumpur and Selangor topped the list in terms of the crime index and police were taking a serious view of the matter as most of the crimes were committed in the Klang Valley. ``These are all preventable crimes. With the co-operation of the public, property crime can be reduced,'' he said, adding that the State Government had also sought the co-operation of the police in reducing social problems involving youths. Abu Hassan confirmed that Rahim discussed the theft of water, among other topics, and that the State Government had deployed enforcement officers to nab culprits and errant companies. ``Vandalising pipes to get water is becoming a serious problem in Selangor and we need the co-operation of the police. If people start vandalising, then the problem of water will worsen,'' he added. As to the burning of two suraus, Abu Hassan said investigations had been stepped up by the police and the Islamic Religious Department. AFTER more than a year of silence, the almost-dead story of common ticketing for public transport in the Klang Valley was given a fresh breath of life with a plea early this month for its implementation during the Commonwealth Games. Although the call was for a watered-down version of the original and covers only two bus companies (Intrakota and Cityliner) and Sistem Transit Aliran Ringan Sdn Bhd's light rail service, the plea by Kuala Lumpur Datuk Bandar Tan Sri Kamaruzzaman Shariff nevertheless shows how far we are from adopting such a concept. Kamaruzzaman admitted it was impossible for the original plan, involving seven operators, to be implemented in time for the Games, even though the call came more than a year ago. This setback seems to fit in perfectly with all the others that have dogged the public transport sector. Although the seven commuter rail, light rail and bus operators in the Klang Valley signed a memorandum of understanding in February last year to come up with a common ticket, nothing has emerged even until now. The seven are KTM Bhd, Park May Bhd, Intrakota Consolidated Sdn Bhd, Sistem Transit Aliran Ringan Sdn Bhd, Projek Usahasama Transit Ringan Automatik Sdn Bhd, Express Rail Link Sdn Bhd and Kuala Lumpur People Rapid Transit Sdn Bhd. But last October Kamaruzzaman said it was up to the individual operators to decide whether they wanted the system, and that a new one would be chosen if the cost of implementing it was too high. He however backed down from that statement and said the move towards integrated ticketing would be completed by this year. According to Universiti Malaya expert on transport economics, Associate Professor G. Naidu, the foot dragging has more to do with attitude rather than technological barriers. ``The operators basically do not see the benefit of sharing the profits which come with sharing a common system,'' he says. The situation, he says, was a perfect illustration of a mismatch between the interests of the private and that of the public sector. Besides the reluctance to allow a common clearing house to handle their fares and paying it for that service, operators are also not happy investing in another ticketing system on top of what they have already put in for their present system. ``When the Government sealed the concession agreements with these operators, ticketing was left to the operators to implement according to their own specifications. ``The Government did not tell them they had to talk to each other about ticketing,'' says Sabariah Jemali, coordinator of the Malaysian Centre for Transportation Studies of Institut Teknologi Mara. In other words, the current situation owes much to lack of foresight at the very beginning of the ``modernisation'' of Klang Valley's public transport system. The economic slowdown will certainly not help the situation. Indeed, it will only create more resistance to the large investments required to modify their individual systems. However, other than economic reasons, there is very little else which can be used to justify the operators' reluctance to have a common ticket. Fare evasion can easily be sorted out by advanced technology and increased inspection. At the same time, the popular argument that the complex formula for revenue distribution together with a clearing house is not feasible will not hold water. ``Integrated ticketing is such a common thing in the world now. It is obvious that the supposed complications can be easily sorted out,'' says UM's Naidu. The fact may have been missed by many but integrated ticketing is actually already here in Malaysia, although the use of the common card is not restricted to public transport but can also be utilised for toll payments. The Touch n' Go smartcards, distributed by Rangkaian Segar Sdn Bhd, can be used not only for fare payment on Park May Bhd buses but also for paying toll on the Federal Highway, Jalan Pahang, Jalan Cheras and the East-West Link in Kuala Lumpur, the Penang Bridge and the Malaysia- Singapore Second Crossing and Second Link Expressway in Johor. As for its use on public transport, Hisham Othman, Rangkaian Segar's chief operating officer, says it will also be used on the second LRT service run by Projek Usahasama Transit Ringan Automatik Sdn Bhd when it becomes operational. It is believed that KTM Komuter will also use the prepaid card in the near future. Although essentially catering for companies within the Renong Group, its increasing involvement in the transport industry could mean that the Touch n' Go card will be the common ticket for public transportation in the Klang Valley. While the Renong connection has made it easy for the Touch n' Go to be implemented with the present companies, Hisham explained that Rangkaian Segar still played the role of a clearing house and stuck to revenue remitting procedures to these companies strictly as if the companies were not at all connected. ``We have no problem knowing exactly how much each company earns as it is recorded each time a person uses the card. Revenue is cleared to each company within 24 hours,'' he says. Rangkaian Segar collects a commission from these companies for its services as a clearing house. On the possibility of people evading fares, especially on buses, Hisham says the technological abilities of the smartcard had managed to overcome the problem. ``On the bus, if a passenger fails to `touch' the reader when he leaves the bus, the maximum fare for the journey will be deducted from his card automatically,'' Hisham says. The problem does not arise in closed ticketing systems or toll gates as turnstiles or the boom gate will not allow people who have not paid to go through. Hisham also says the Touch n' Go system does not replace a company's existing ticketing system, but is merely an addition to it. ``At the toll gates, the normal cash payment can still be done, but card users will get dedicated lines,'' he says. Besides eliminating the need for cash, Hisham says the greatest plus point the Touch n' Go card possesses is the ease and speed in which it can be used. ``If the card needs to be swiped, you might as well pay cash,'' he says. Speed is of course central to the argument for a common ticket, which in turn is fundamental in the issue of integrating the separate transport operations. System integration itself has been high on the public transport agenda worldwide as the reality in most cities is that the commuter has to use more than one mode of transport to get to his or her destination. Moves to reduce duplication of routes and the adoption of rail-based mass transit which require feeder services will only increase the incidence of passengers needing to hop from one form of transport to another. ``To make public transport successful means making it as convenient as possible for passengers. That includes making it easy to switch from mode to mode,'' says A. Rahman Paul Barter, coordinator of Sustainable Transport Action Network for Asia and the Pacific, or Sustran. Besides convenience, a simple fact is that the common ticket can cut down transfer time and therefore reduce door-to-door travel time. And that is crucial in making public transport attractive. ``Universally, the talk is about a `seamless flow' where passengers move from one mode to another in such a way that it almost feels as if it is just one continuous trip,'' says UM's Naidu. This seamless flow could even bring in economic benefits as the overall number of commuters could actually go up with the increased convenience, a phenomenon Sustran's Barter calls the ``network effect.'' Nevertheless, Naidu does not envision integrated ticketing taking off without the long overdue push by the authorities. ``It basically boils down to the lack of political will to implement integrated ticketing.'' Meanwhile, commuters will just have to endure the hassles of juggling with pocketfuls of coins and endless queues for tickets when setting out on a journey across town.

It is understood that Binariang is holding discussions with several parties, including Singapore Telecom Ltd and Cable and Wireless of the UK, following moves by the Government to allow a 61 per cent foreign ownership in telecommunication companies. Jamaludin declined to give the breakdown in investment for the respective sectors, but he said about 80 per cent of the investment for the mobile sector will be utilised to improve its existing network services with new cells sites and micro cells. ``We will be enhancing additional capacity to strengthen the network and network for the existing 400,000 customers rather than going for new area coverage,'' he said. Former police commissioner admits he helped cover up death of activist
PRETORIA, South Africa (AP) _ The country's top police commander during apartheid said Tuesday that he helped cover up the death of an anti-apartheid activist to avoid mass demonstrations and keep up police morale. Testifying before the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, Johan van der Merwe said he knew the body of Stanza Bopape was thrown into a crocodile-infested river to hide the evidence. Bopape died while being tortured by police in 1988. ``The security branch was the most important shield ... between order and anarchy in the country,'' van der Merwe said. Van der Merwe, who was chief of the Security Branch at the time of the coverup and later became the national police commissioner, is seeking amnesty from the panel that is investigating politically motivated abuses of human rights during the system of white rule. His lawyer has disputed that he ordered Bopape's killing. But Van der Merwe said Tuesday that he lied to his superiors, including former Law and Order minister Adriaan Vlok, about Bopape's death, keeping up the charade for years that the activist had escaped from police custody. The reconciliation process has enabled many families to discover the truth about what happened to loved ones who disappeared without a trace. Victims often were buried in unmarked graves. Van der Merwe said he feared that anti-apartheid activists would hear of Bopape's death in police custody after he was tortured by electrical shock, and whip up emotions and riots. Five of the amnesty applicants in the case have admitted to torturing Bopape.

Q: I HAVE been married for a year. I had a miscarriage in February last year. Since then, I have been having irregular cycles and no conception. During my last cycle the flow was very scanty, lasting only three days. I am also overweight. My doctor says I have low progesterone levels on day 21 of my cycle. Please advise. A: WHEN progesterone is low one week after ovulation should have been expected to take place, it usually indicates that there has been no egg released. Failure to ovulate can be due to many reasons, but being overweight can certainly contribute. If you eat whole natural foods and cut out sugars and saturated fats, the weight should start to come off regardless of how much you eat. If you chart your body-at-rest temperature you will also be able to see two other important things. Firstly, if you are ovulating, the temperature will rise at mid-cycle, as progesterone increases body heat. Secondly, if the temperatures are consistently off the bottom of the graph, you may have a hypo-thyroid problem, which could also effect reproductive health and weight gain. MANY people who think of wetlands as swampy areas are surprised to find that even coral reef flats are classified wetland habitats. It is indeed an eye opener for them to realise that wetlands also consist of habitats of such colour and beauty. Coral reef flats are considered the most aesthetically beautiful underwater community known. Today, this habitat is being depleted at an alarming rate. According to researchers, damage to coral reefs in Kenya, Madagascar, Malaysia, Mauritius, Seychelles, Thailand, Indonesia, United Republic of Tanzania and other countries has been irreparable. Studies also show that more than half of the reefs in South East Asia are in advanced stages of destruction, with about 25 per cent of live coral cover in good condition and a mere five per cent in excellent condition. Coral reefs occupy only about 0.1 per cent of the surface of the planet and yet it is estimated that they produce almost 10 per cent of the world fish landings. In Malaysia, almost 50 per cent of our seafood come from the reefs. The primary productivity of coral reefs equals or surpasses all other natural eco-systems, even rain forests and one reef may support as many as 3,000 species. Coral reefs are a valuable source for the tourism industry. The multi-coloured corals, fish, shells, tubeworms and other organisms as well as shallow calm lagoons and clean beaches associated with many coral reefs attract numerous visitors. This wetland habitat is also regarded as importantbreeding and nursery grounds for many marine organisms including fishes, lobsters, cephalopods and a variety of molluscs. In many places, coral reefs take the full impact of the waves and dissipate its energy, thereby preventing erosion. They also block ocean currents which could otherwise erode coastal areas. The science of marine pharmacology is in its infancy and coral reef organisms might further provide valuable sources for medicinally useful compounds which are yet to be discovered. Reefs are sensitive and easily destroyed because they require specific conditions to form and survive. Conditions favouring the development of reefs include water temperatures above 18o Celsius, water depth shallower than 50 metres, constant salinity greater than 30 but less than 30 parts per thousand, low sedimentation rates, sufficient circulation of pollution-free water and pre-existing hard substrate. As the population of the world increases, so does the threat to coral reefs. The most important single cause of reef degradation is sedimentation resulting from human activities on land. These include unsound agricultural and forestry practices, mismanagement of watersheds, exploitation of mangroves, earth-moving for construction and the dumping of terrestrial and marine mine tailings and effluents. Increased turbidity reduces the penetration of sunlight, thus inhibiting photosynthesis in primary producers such as the symbiotic algae of coral polyps. This in turn decreases the coral growth. Coral communities in deeper waters are at the margins of light penetration and may be the most vulnerable. Sedimentation also smothers living coral, and silt hinders the settling of coral larvae. Destructive fishing methods common in the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand such as blasting, dragging nets over reefs, use of cyanide and traditional spearing are also threats to this beautiful eco-system. Apart from threats by man, coral reefs also have a natural enemy. The crown-of-thorns starfish is one of the natural predators that destroy coral reefs. This starfish eats stony corals and devastates large areas of reef during an outbreak. In Malaysia, the Pulau Redang Marine Park corals are in danger of being completely destroyed by these voracious predators. However, steps are being taken to reduce the rate of coral reef depletion throughout the world. Last year was officially designated the International Year of the Reef by the United Nations to conserve and sustainably manage this wetland habitat. Corporate sectors, government agencies and NGOs have been involved in the conservation of coral reefs. In Malaysia, HongkongBank became involved with the Government's conservation effort through the Department of Fisheries, by sponsoring and participating in expeditions to remove crown-of-thorns starfish from the Pulau Redang Marine Park. The Government is also helping conservation work by establishing marine parks. Marine parks are areas of the sea zoned as sanctuaries for the coral reef community. Numerous NGOs and institutions of higher learning are conducting extensive research and creating awareness to conserve coral reefs throughout the globe. It is sad that one of the most productive and beautiful eco-systems in the world is being destroyed through human ignorance. We should be considerate and conserve these eco-systems so that our future generations may see and enjoy them as we have.

BC-Swiss Banks-Nazis,0333
Swiss hope report will lead to `more objective discussion' With US-Nazi Gold
BERN, Switzerland (AP) _ Switzerland on Tuesday welcomed a U.S. government report concluding that neutral nations supplied Nazi Germany with hundreds of millions of dollars of trade, and stressed that its own efforts to reappraise its past continue. ``In regard to Switzerland, the American report contains no essentially new findings,'' the ruling Federal Council said in a statement. A U.S. report last year accused Switzerland of providing financing to Nazi Germany that prolonged World War II. The coalition cabinet said it hopes the report ``will contribute to more objective discussion, particularly in the United States, on Switzerland's role during World War II.'' ``It says in effect that it is wrong to oversimplify and apportion historic blame on the basis of isolated facts,'' the statement added. Swiss commercial banks, Jewish organizations and lawyers for class-action claimants are negotiating a global settlement of claims by Holocaust victims. Class-action suits for dlrs 23 billion have been filed in the United States against Swiss banks and insurance companies on behalf of Holocaust victims and their heirs. Jewish organizations have accused the banks of delays in allowing Holocaust victims' heirs access to dormant assets. The Swiss cabinet said the publication last week by an independent panel of historians of a study on Switzerland's gold dealings with Germany ``proves that Switzerland takes the reappraisal of its history seriously.'' The government ``welcomes the fact that the U.S. government is also taking this course,'' the statement added. The U.S. ambassador in Bern, Madeleine May Kunin, paid tribute in a statement to Switzerland's efforts to address its past. ``Switzerland stands at the forefront of this international effort to address one of the darkest chapters in history,'' she said.

IT'S amazing how far a simple idea can stretch. For inventor Robest Yong, every simple idea that pops into his head has stretched all the way to the bank. No wonder he's a picture of cheerfulness as he perches on one edge of the sofa while I sink into my corner. His lightweight frame remains perched as we talk, and the image of a bird ready to take flight comes to mind. He exudes energy and a quiet determination to grasp at ideas that will bring financial rewards. The year 1994 will surely be etched in his memory as the year he really came into his own. Pitted against candidates of intellectual standing, he was ecstatic to be selected as the National Inventor of the Year by the Ministry of Science, Technology and the Environment. He stood tall as he received the RM20,000 award. ``I felt good, no doubt about it. The other shortlisted candidates had doctorates to their names. I was the small fry and stood out like a sore thumb,'' he recalls, smiling at the eventual turn of events. Today, Yong's favourite response when asked about his amazing inventiveness is that one does not need a Ph.D to become an inventor. ``What is far more important is an open mind and keen observation. No doubt a high IQ gives you an edge but your intelligence will not bring results if you have a one-track mind,'' the 38-year-old offers. Ever since the national recognition as an inventor of high calibre, Yong has gone on to win international acclaim. Participating yearly at the International Exhibition of Inventions in Geneva, Switzerland, Yong has bagged awards that now grace the wall in his home. In 1994, he won the Gold award for his Polyclone Instant Rubber Stamp Machine which now forms the core of his business transactions; in 1995 he won the Silver medal for his Kamikaze Mosquito Glue; in 1996 he was awarded the Bronze medal for his Carver Up Car Mat Cover, and in 1997 he bagged the Bronze award for his Automatic Brake Lock. Last year also saw a double win for him as he walked away with the RM5,000 prize in the category for Creative Innovations in conjunction with the National Youth Day celebrations in Malaysia. So how does it feel to be a winner all the way? The Penangite grins. Suddenly the years are taken off his face and I'm left sitting with the charming youth that he really is. ``Great, though I must say my ambition is not to be the greatest inventor in Malaysia but the richest!'' He seems set on the path, if the Ford TX3 Lynx in his driveway is anything to go by. The inside of his house may not be as glamorous as his car, but it bespeaks him all right. Boxes of plastic handles for rubber stamps are stacked against one wall from end to end, and a computer sits on a table laden with shelves of paraphernalia of invention at the opposite end. The sitting room wall is lined with framed awards and plaques of recognition sit on side tables, together with a disarray of stuff. He walks towards the computer and beckons me to follow. Switching it on, he asks for my photo and prepares to design a rubber stamp for me with my face on it. Gosh, what a sure-fire way to make my presence felt! Just stamp my face all over! But alas, my photo doesn't turn out well because it's in colour. A black-and-white would be perfect. So he creates an address stamp for me instead. Satisfied with his input, he gets a computer printout and proceeds to place a blue-coloured negative on top of it, after which he laminates it on a machine so that the image is printed onto the negative. He then places on top of the negative what looks like a thick piece of plastic to me but what he calls a polyclone stamp plate. The card goes into the rubber stamp machine that he invented. We wait a minute-and-a-half and the card is ready to be washed in a basin of tap water. Yong dries it with a hair dryer and placing the card back into his machine, switches on the dryer light and waits for another few minutes. This process, he explains, is to harden the card. He then uses double-sided tape to stick the card onto the stamp holder, clamps the handle into place, and hey presto, the job's done in 10 minutes. ``That'll be RM8 please,'' he jokes, referring to the standard rate for a rubber stamp these days. But, he's quick to point out, that price is based on collection of card after 24 hours. For urgent needs, like in 10 minutes flat, rubber stamp-makers charge up to RM25. It's easy to understand why his invention is garnering good sales. Given a good location and a regular clientele, Yong claims the initial cost of RM3,800 to buy his machine can be recouped within months. Of course, other costs like a computer system, a laminating machine and stamp handles which cost 50 sen each, have to be taken into consideration. There are advantages in using Yong's invention. Hassles like time-consuming letter composition, messy plaster moulds and chemicals are done away with. There is also the advantage of a one-man operation in a small working space. And, according to him, rubber stamps of any shape, size, language, font- type or design can be done in 10 minutes. Electricity costs, he maintains, are minimal because the four exposure lamps in the machine equal a 40-watt fluorescent lamp. SINCE he invented the Polyclone Instant Rubber Stamp Machine, Yong has continued to ride its waves of success, going from strength to strength. He set up a factory in Sungai Way, Kuala Lumpur, to manufacture the machine which he sells not only in Malaysia but also in countries like America, Russia, United Kingdom, Australia, the Fiji Islands, Australia, Japan and Thailand. ``We have agents all over the world,'' he says. The `we' refers to his wife Teng Yu-Mein who helps him in the business, acting as secretary-of-sorts. Apart from Thailand, where sales have decreased by almost 50 per cent because of the current economic slowdown, worldwide sales for his machine have not been affected. In Malaysia, orders continue to come in, even from small towns like Kuala Lipis. It had taken a bit of dogged persistence, especially during the early days of uncertainty, before Yong's folks gave him the thumbs up. After all, many people are likely to be sceptical about the likelihood of carving a living out of an invention. ``But my family started to believe in the possibilities after my inventions proved successful,'' Yong says. His parents live in Nibong Tebal and his siblings, numbering eight boys and two girls are scattered all over the country. ``Life was very competitive as a child,'' he recalls. The sixth child in the family, he had to share things and use hand-me-downs. Consequently, he developed the habit of making his own toys. He also fiddled with things, like bicycles, taking them apart because he was curious about their components. Obviously his spirit of invention was set in motion during childhood. After his secondary schooling in Nibong Tebal, Yong went to Japan to take up a course in machineries. In the two years he was there, he learned the technology of printing and later, back in Malaysia, applied his knowledge in a company dealing with printing machines. Ten years later, he decided to freelance as a technician for printing machines. In 1993, while freelancing, he hit upon the idea of the rubber stamp machine. In 1994 he was ready to submit his invention for Mindex, the Malaysian Invention and Design Exhibition organised by Minds, the Malaysian Invention and Design Society. He walked away with the first prize. Minds then submitted his design for the international competition in Switzerland. The rest, as they say, is history. Despite the success of his rubber stamp machine, Yong is not one to rest on his laurels. He has kept himself busy inventing other things which have not gone unrecognised. A mosquito attraction is one of his inventions. Calling it the Kamikaze Mosquito Glue, he has designed it such that the scent attracts mosquitoes and the glue kills them. Then there is his car mat cover which has pocket vents that allow the dirt to gather on the mat but is not seen on top. Like sweeping the dust under the carpet? I tease, and he nods smilingly. Another invention is the automatic brake lock which he says works when the brake is stepped on fully, and the car is stationery. The brake is then automatically locked. It can be unlocked by stepping on the accelerator. Yong is also working on a synchronised locking system for toilets which are linked to two rooms. His latest invention features a basin and a tap built onto the cover of the water tank. Clean water for hand washing automatically flows from the tap as soon as the toilet is flushed. The ``used'' water then flows back into the water tank to be used for the next flush. ``I got the idea after I saw the frequent breakage of the top covers in petrol stations toilets. People would lift off the covers to wash their hands in the water, and usually break them. So I thought about how to solve this problem and at the same time recycle the water,'' he says. The result is Flush `n' Wash Water Closet, which, if present negotiations with a company go well, will soon be available in the market. All the consumer has to do is replace the top cover of his toilet bowl with the cover that Yong has invented. No installation required, and the cost of replacing the cover would be minimal, according to him. It seems that all his ideas turn out to be lucrative for him. I guess mere inventiveness is not enough. One must have a business head as well. Yong agrees. ``Ideas must be creative and at the same time be practical. I can't sell my inventions if they don't make good products. ``Some inventors are sentimental and have romantic ideas which are not practical, so they lose money. ``Of course we can't compete with big corporate bodies which have money for RD, like in the case of electronics. But we can focus on simple ideas and turn them into useful products,'' he advises. He gets his ideas by thinking all the time, he says. Sometimes they come by chance, sometimes through exposure to problems. Whatever the case, once an idea forms in his head, Yong delves into the intricacies of developing the technology. In areas where he can't manufacture the products, he sells the concept and patent right. Yong has come a long way since he worked as a technician. Self-employment now gives him the flexibility and freedom to develop his concepts, and with a mind ever brimming with ideas, he is fully occupied translating them into workable solutions for all the problems his keen eye perceives.

THE medical definition of menopause refers to the cessation of the adult female menstrual cycle. This occurs because the ovaries gradually become less responsive to gonadotrophin (hormone) stimulation causing low levels of estadiol (oestrogen), while increasing the levels of FSH and LH -follicle stimulating and leutinising hormones. About three to five years before the last period, a woman's ovaries begin producing less of two female hormones, oestrogen and progesterone. This phase is called the climacteric, or perimenopausal period. The hormonal levels may not decreases in a uniform manner, so she may experience irregular menstrual cycles and heavy bleeding before her period end altogether. Up to about 15 per cent of women have no problems when their periods cease, whilst about 70 per cent experience symptoms that include menstrual irregularities, hot flushes, mood swing, insomnia, vaginal dryness, urinary urgency and weight gain. A hot flush is a sudden perception of intense heat over the upper part, or the entire body and face - caused by dilated blood vessels, which in turn is related to a decrease in the estrogen level. Sometimes the face and neck become red, and blotches appear on the chest, arms and back. These can range from being mildly uncomfortable, to debilitating. `Night' hot flushes is another dreaded occurrence. Generally, these flushes can last anything from a few minutes to half an hour. Left untreated, they usually subside within a couple of years from the onset of menopause. Statistically, Asians record less incidence of hot flushes as compared to their caucasian counterparts. In Japan, there have been reports of this being attributed to a higher consumption of soya bean, which in turn apparently increases the hormones oestrogen. Interestingly, certain `trigger factors' have been identified that contribute to higher occurrence of these flushes. They include spicy food, alcohol, tobacco, hot tubs and sauna, stress and anger (especially when unexpressed). Thinner women have also been associated with having higher incidences of hot flushes as compared with their more `rounded' cousins. This is because fat cells help in converting more of the adrenal hormones into the hormone oestrogen. Maybe, one of the biggest concerns associated with menopause is a condition called osteoporosis. Here, the bone density is reduced due to the reduction of calcium in the bone matrix, causing it to become thinner and more brittle. This leads to increased risks of fractures (especially involving the spinal vertebrae, hip joint and the upper limbs). Family members should pay special heed to elder women when they complain of aches and pains, resulting from a fall. Sometimes these symptoms can be subtle, and patients have been known to walk into clinics and emergency units, only to have an X-ray diagnosis of a fracture of the femur or hip joint. Menopausal women also have a higher risk of developing cardio-vascular diseases, primarily due to changes in their lipid (fat) profile. This is attributed to an increase in the total cholesterol and LDL (low-density lipoprotein - bad cholesterol) levels and a decrease in the HDL (high- density lipoprotein - good cholesterol) level. Another significant change noted by women during their menopause involves their genito-urinary system and their sex life. Due to the lack of oestrogen support of the lower genital tract, they experience vaginal dryness and dyspaurenia (painful intercourse), urinary urgency, frequency and stress incontinence (uncontrolled leaking or dribbling of urine when stressed or while straining). So what are the treatment options? Hormonal replacement therapy has been the mainstream consensus and the standard treatment for many years. This primarily involves the hormone oestrogen (in small divided doses), and in some cases progestins. Oestrogen helps prevent further bone loss in osteoporosis, reduces the risk of cardiovascular diseases, and slows down atherosclerosis. The dosages vary, and one of the known side effects of hormonal therapy, is withdrawal or irregular bleeding after the first few doses or episodes. Hormonal therapy s not without it's share of adverse effects, and one of the most dreaded ones is the increased risk of developing endometrial (uterus) and breast cancer - particularly those who are oestrogen dependent. As such, regular mammograms and breast examinations should be carried out at least while you are on treatment. Consult your family doctor or gyneacologist for further advice on this. Of late, the treatment options have widened considerably. There have been reports of women claiming alleviation of their symptoms by consuming herbal medicine (ginseng and don quai herbal tea). Wild yam root extract (rich in a chemical called diosgenen, which is converted into progesterone), and even Vitamin E (doses ranging from 600-800gm) and C and evening primrose oil have been advocated. Others claim that acupuncture, yoga and even meditation play a significant role in `menopause therapy'. Your doctor or pharmacist could further enlighten you on the therapeutic ranges that are available these days. Today, menopause is seen more as the gateway to a second adulthood. If 50 is the old age of youth, then it is also the youth of this second adulthood. A famous philanthropist in describing menopause, once said: ``The heyday of a woman's life is in the shady side of 50, when her thoughts and forces, once garnered in the corners of her mind, flow out in broader channel - revealing a mature, wise lady with every aspect of her femininity still absolutely intact.'' Menopause is certainly NOT a disorder, but like puberty, is a period of physical and emotional change that affects some women far more than others.

Aid agencies appeal for helicopters to evacuate wounded helicopters.
Eds: LEADS with nine grafs with more details of need for AP Photos ISL103, 107-108, FDB101-105 By JUDITH INGRAM Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ Aid agencies ferried the critically wounded from quake-devastated villages in northern Afghanistan on Tuesday and appealed for more aircraft and fuel to rescue survivors of the earthquake that killed anywhere from 2,000 to 5,000 people. In the village of Kol, hundreds of people swarmed a United Nations helicopter that touched down three days after Saturday's earthquake struck a remote mountainous area rocked three months earlier by another massive quake that claimed some 2,300 victims. On Monday and Tuesday, U.N. helicopters evacuated 50 of the most seriously injured to emergency medical centers. Rescuers have reached only 29 villages, or about half of those believed to have been seriously damaged by the 6.9-magnitude quake. Of those, 12 were 80 percent to 100 percent destroyed, said Rupert Colville, a U.N. spokesman. ``It's now clear that the destruction is very wide spread,'' Colville said. Survivors carried the injured on stretchers of sticks and old clothes through winding hillside streets and past crumbled packed-mud houses to reach the helicopters. The villages' remoteness and lack of transportation were hampering the aid effort. The United Nations, the Red Cross and other agencies have three borrowed helicopters to deliver medical aid. The helicopters came from neighboring Tajikistan, and Colville said he hoped other neighboring countries would contribute as well. Russia, which has loaned helicopters in previous disasters, said it would consider sending aid. The lack of aircraft ``is undercutting everything we are doing now,'' Colville said. The agencies need at least one more cargo plane to deliver supplies, he said. He said the agencies needed at least one more cargo plane to deliver supplies that had already been brought into the region after the February disaster. Rescuers worked, 8th graf pvs

Dr RAHIMAH A. KADIR: Dental plaque will always exist. Nature works in such a way that a membrane called acquired pellicle is formed on the tooth surface within seconds after it is cleaned. This acts as a net that will catch debris so new plaque is developed all the time. If it is not removed, it becomes `aged' with toxins and virulent bacteria. You can help reduce plaque accumulation and virulency in your oral cavity by maintaining effective toothbrushing procedures and checking your diet. You are doing fine with the normal routine of brushing twice daily. But make sure that you have been systematic in your technique. Be sure to place the toothbrush bristles in the right place (at the neck of the tooth with one part on the gums and the other on the tooth surface) when you brush. I suggest you check with your dentist for any other adjunct oral hygiene devices that can help to alleviate the problem. As for bad breath, it is not unusual, especially upon waking up in the morning. Most of us miss some parts when brushing at night so there is bound to be a little debris left over to be devoured by bacterial plaque. In addition, when we are sleeping our self-cleansing mechanism - the saliva production and the tongue movement - is reduced. At the same time, if you have been eating a lot of sugared foods, some of these will be stored in the form of glycogen. Thus, in a state of `fasting', like during sleep, glycogen will release its sugar spares for bacterial plaque to act on. The degree of morning breath can, to a certain extent, tell you how clean your mouth was the night before. The positive side is that bad breath due to the above do go away after you have rinsed or brush your teeth.

CHINA has assured Malaysia that it will put in place soon a mechanism to make it easy for Malaysian joint-venture refineries (JVCs) in the republic in getting their respective palm oil quota. Primary Industries Minister Datuk Seri Dr Lim Keng Yaik said the assurance was given to him by the relevant authorities of the republic during his visit to China last week. At present, local palm oil companies operating in China are given palm oil quotas by the Chinese authorities to facilitate their operations. The delay in the issuance of new quotas has been a problem for these companies in the smooth running their business in the republic. ``I impressed upon the authorities in China that in the interest of ensuring the viability of the JVCs, they (JVCs) should be given a quota for palm oil that is at least 50 per cent of their capacity,'' he said in a statement released in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. As a step to further bolster bilateral trade, Dr Lim said Malaysia and China have agreed that they pursue the possibility of using counter trade. In this regard, the prospect of exporting palm oil, timber, rubber and cocoa products in exchange for corn, rice and beef need to be explored by the private sector of both countries. He noted that there are already indications that barter trade between palm oil and corn may be possible between Malaysia and China. On investment, Dr Lim said China had expressed the hope that the establishment of a joint-venture pulp and paper mill in Sabah, agreed to by both countries, will be expedited. ``As China needs substantial amounts of pulp and paper, I suggested that we explore the possibility of establishing a pulp and paper mill with oil palm biomass raw material,'' he added. Dr Lim said such a project could tap on the 30 million tonnes of oil palm biomass available annually in Malaysia without taking large tracks of land for tree planting purposes. He noted that another possible joint-venture that can be mutually beneficial to China and Malaysia is the establishment of rubberwood plantations as China is a large market for furniture. Another area where Malaysian and its Chinese counterparts could collaborate is in tripartite investment ventures for the cultivation of oil palm. Dr Lim said Malaysia would provide the management and technical expertise, China provides the capital and market, while a third country concerned could provide the land and labour. He noted that his discussion with China's companies during his visit indicated that there are interests on the part of China to be involved in these areas of investments.

BC-Bosnia-Politics
Ruling Bosnian Croat party splits in two
By SRECKO LATAL Associated Press Writer
SARAJEVO, Bosnia-Herzegovina (AP) _ In a blow against nationalist hard-liners, the Bosnian Croat member of the country's joint presidency announced Tuesday that he is forming a new party. The move comes after three months before general elections in Bosnia and months of power struggle in the Bosnian Croat leadership. It effectively splits the ruling Croat Democratic Union, ending its years-long monopoly on votes of most Bosnian Croats. There were no details about the future program and orientation of the new party founded by Kresimir Zubak. But sources said most of its members _ several prominent Bosnian Croats, including Zubak and a few federal ministers _ are considered moderates, supporting the Dayton peace accord and unified Bosnia. Without additional details, foreign diplomats refused substantive comment. ``Time will tell,'' said Simon Haselock, a spokesman for Bosnia's top international mediator, Carlos Westendorp. He said western powers support ``anything that encourages pluralism, anything that encourages greater compliance with the Dayton (peace accord).'' But the move clearly pleased outside powers involved in Bosnia because it weakened the Croat Democratic Union, a traditionally hard-line party that has turned even more rigid in the past few months. Nationalists leading the party oppose returns of Serb or Muslim refugees and other aspects of the Dayton accord. A similar split in the Bosnian Serb leadership last year marked one of the biggest breakthroughs in Bosnia since the 1995 end of the war. Western powers used that chance to support Serb moderates and sideline the old hard-line leadership. The dominant Muslim SDA party also has had to deal with much stronger opposition from two Social-democrat parties in the Muslim-Croat federation. Bosnian Croat sources said the new party will try to run in the September elections despite the fact that the registration period for the parties has ended. The international organization charged with the elections will discuss this issue and try to register the new party in the next few days, said a western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. SYARIKAT Lian Ping Enterprise Sdn Bhd, an interior design company, has filed an action to wind up construction based Cygal Bhd over non-payment of RM3.2 million. Syarikat Lian Ping had claimed in its petition that Cygal Bhd owes it RM3,135,451.31 for interior decorations done in a hotel under construction in Johor Baru. Apart from the principal sum, Syarikat Lian Ping is also seeking from Cygal Bhd financing charges of RM74,907.22 and legal costs of RM5,000. The company's application, filed on Jan 27, will be heard at the Kuala Lumpur High Court on June 9. Syarikat Lian Ping said it entered into a contract with Cygal Bhd, listed on the Second Board of the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange, on April 12, 1996, to do interior fitting-out for suites and corridors at Grand Bluewave Hotel in Johor Baru for RM8.3 million. The company said that upon the completion of its work, the architect of the hotel, MNA Architect, had duly certified payment to Cygal Bhd. Syarikat Lian Ping said MNA Architect had not recommended to Cygal Bhd any deductions against the sum due. There were no circumstances justifying any deduction or set-off. ``Due to the company's (Cygal Bhd) failure to pay (the RM3.1 million), Syarikat Lian Ping has to bear financing charges for loss of use of the funds.'' The company said that Cygal Bhd had failed and neglected to settle despite requests and demands. Syarikat Lian Ping said that Cygal Bhd had neglected to pay the amount or any part of it despite being served a demand notice on Dec 30, 1997. The company said that Cygal Bhd was insolvent and unable to pay its debts and is claiming that it be wound up with an Official Receiver appointed by the court. Syarikat Lian Ping said in its petition that Cygal Bhd's authorised capital was RM100 million divided into 100 million shares of RM1 each, adding that the amount of capital paid-up or credited as paid up was RM47,778,000.

I HAVE to undergo a major jaw reconstructive surgery because it was seriously destroyed by a dental tumour (ameloblastoma). Besides the reconstructive work, all the teeth on the left jaw will be removed and my jaw will be wired up for two to three weeks to facilitate the maturing of bone graft. With the removal of the teeth, my doctor suggests tooth implants or a `bridge'. I wish to know more about these methods and the cost. As my jaw will be wired up for a long time, I will not be able to do any oral cleaning. How could I maintain oral hygiene to avoid infection? Will salt water help? Currently, there is a wound inside my mouth following the biopsy. Normally, I clean it with salt water, followed by brushing. Will there be any harmful chemical reaction between the toothpaste and salt? If I were to do the brushing before the salt water, is it advisable to leave the salt over-night inside my mouth? - Tsen Kieu Tyng, Luyang, Sabah Dr RAHIMAH A. KADIR: It is important to know your age for purposes of treatment prognosis. However, based on your description, it is clear that you will need either an implant or bridge mainly for functional, and to a certain extent, cosmetic purposes after surgery. A bridge is a prosthesis that fills up space between two `posts' or teeth. The two end teeth will undergo special preparation so that they act as supports. The space between the two `posts' will then be filled with a specially constructed artificial tooth that `locks' itself on the two `posts'. Since all your six back teeth on the left side will have to be sacrificed, implant work will be a better option. The technique requires surgical procedures whereby screw-like metals are embedded into your remaining jaw bone. A teeth denture will then be prepared to fit the space. This denture `clicks' itself onto the screws based on the same principle of the stud buttons our tailors use on blouses, shirts or jeans. An implant will cost more because the procedure is more complex, requires surgery and non-allergic materials are used. The actual cost of the implant (minus the surgery) will also vary, based on the type of metal screw or screw system (that is, the Branemark or the Ankylos system etc) used and the service rendered. Conservatively, if you need six teeth replaced, the cost of materials alone can run from RM40,000 upwards. Discuss the cost with your dentist to avoid any misunderstanding. A word of advice, though. Be sure that you get the job done by qualified professionals. The Faculty of Dentistry, Universiti Malaya, has an implant unit manned by a team of specialists. For further information or to fix an appointment, you can call 03-7594881 or write to the: Professor B.C. Ling Coordinator, Implant Unit, Faculty of Dentistry, Universiti of Malaya 50603 Kuala Lumpur. You can also e-mail him at bcling um.edu.my. To answer your other question, there is no harm in using a mouthwash of warm salt water to help early wound healing. However, you should not keep salt in the mouth overnight. Given your condition, it is wise for you to be rigorous in maintaining oral hygiene as you do not want plaque to accumulate. Use a soft toothbrush and toothpaste with fluoride. You should also floss the remaining teeth. If you can afford it, buy a portable `irrigator' called a water-pik. It produces jet sprays and clears food debris from the teeth.

THE National Centre for Tobacco-Free Kids in the US is the largest private initiative ever launched to protect children from tobacco addiction, with funding from American foundations, organisations and individuals. Its partners are the American Cancer Society, American Heart Association, American Medical Association, the National PTA and more than 100 other health, civic, corporate, youth and religious organisations of all sizes. The centre aims to protect children from tobacco addiction and exposure to environmental tobacco smoke (ETS) by: creating a social, political, legal, economic and ethical environment conducive to reducing tobacco use by children and exposure among young ones; developing and achieving related public and private policies; and, exposing and counteracting the tobacco and allied industries' strategies and tactics. Three years ago, it set up the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids with an ambition to be aggressive, work in partnership and think big. The network of professional and non-governmental organisations protects children: by raising awareness that tobacco use is a paediatric disease; changing public policies to limit the marketing and sales of tobacco to children; altering the environment in which tobacco use and policy decisions are made; and, countering the tobacco industry and its special interests. To combat industry's marketing budget, it serves as a resource and partner for more than 130 groups dedicated to reducing tobacco use among American youths. It operates a toll-free number of how to get involved. It disseminates information and implements media campaigns and events; assists State and community-level programmes; undertakes research and analysis; co-ordinates with federal, State and local governments; and engages in advocacy to promote supportive public policies. Its latest project, Unfiltered Facts, was launched on Sept 15 last year. Packaged in a cigarette-style fliptop box, this comprises information flash-cards detailing the lethal consequences of smoking among youths. The cards explain problems such as the number of children who will die from tobacco-related disease, how many use smokeless tobacco, and the number of cigarette packs sold illegally to minors. Special cards tell of admissions by tobacco companies in their internal documents, about marketing to children and on industry contributions to US political campaign funds. In five years, the organisers hope to produce another set of cards -this time with a story of reduced numbers of youth smokers and cigarette buyers, and of fewer lives being lost to tobacco addiction. The cards have been distributed to members of Congress and their staff, public health advocates, and State political leaders and attorneys-general. This is to remind them that, without action at both State and national level, children will continue to become addicted at record rates. Another project, Counter-Ads, fights back against tobacco advertising. Each month, more than 20 advertisements are placed in national newspapers and magazines, and on television and radio. It lets Congressmen, State legislators and policy-makers at all levels know that ``Americans are sick of tobacco companies manipulating their children'' into an addictive and lethal habit.
