ACF Holdings Bhd has proposed to revise its profit guarantee for the year ended Dec 31, 1997, and also give a full discharge of the profit guarantee for each of the financial years ending Dec 31, 1998 and 1999. The profit guarantee arose from the proposed disposal of a 33.6 per cent stake in ACF Holdings to Affin Holdings Bhd for RM92.99 million. Pursuant to the profit guarantee agreement signed on Oct 18, last year, the guarantors and major shareholders of ACF Holdings had agreed to provide a guarantee of RM63.31 million for the group's pre-tax profit ending Dec 31, 1997. The guarantors and major shareholders - Trillionvest Sdn Bhd, Amsteel Corporation Bhd and Lion Corporation Bhd - had also agreed to provide guarantees of RM46.96 million each for the years ending Dec 31, 1998 and 1999. ACF Holdings said it had proposed to revise the initial guarantee in view of the changes in Bank Negara's guidelines on general provisions from 1.1 per cent to 1.5 per cent and also in interest suspension. ACF Holdings said the profit guarantee of RM63.31 million was made on the assumption that the general provision was 1.1 per cent. The classification of loans as non-performing loans when they were three months overdue had also effectively increased the interest suspension, it added. Affin Holdings's proposed acquisition of the 33.6 per cent stake in ACF Holdings (62 million ordinary shares) will result in the former emerging as the latter's controlling shareholder. It is also expected to take over the management of ACF Holdings. It was reported that upon completion of the entire exercise, there were plans to merge Affin Finance Bhd with Asia Commercial Finance (M) Bhd. Affin Finance is the financial arm of Affin Holdings while Asia Commercial Finance is a subsidiary of ACF Holdings. Affin will be required to make a mandatory general offer for the remaining 122.51 million shares in ACF Holdings which it does not already own. Both Amsteel and Lion Corporation are expected to accept the proposed offer, subject to approval from their respective shareholders, where applicable.

KUALA LUMPUR, Sat. - A couple of hours after Bank Negara announced a negative growth of 1.8 per cent for the first quarter of this year, Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad said the Government was working to find ways to reduce interest rates. The Prime Minister said the interest rates, presently 15 to 16 per cent, were very high. Commenting on calls to lower the rates, Dr Mahathir said the actual lending rate was dependent on the cost of money, inter-bank borrowings and the margins that banks imposed on borrowers. ``We are under pressure because the so-called market forces want us to raise interest rates,'' he told reporters after opening the 45th general assembly of the MCA at Wisma MCA. The Government is of the view that when companies get into difficulties which may lead to bankruptcy as a result of high interest rates, the Government's finances too would be affected. At a Press conference earlier, Bank Negara governor Tan Sri Ahmad Mohd Don announced that Malaysia recorded a negative growth of 1.8 per cent in the first quarter of this year but chalked up a commendable trade surplus of RM8.808 billion on the back of surging exports and declining imports. Ahmad, however, expressed confidence that the targeted gross domestic product expansion of 2.5 per cent for this year was achievable but he would not say if the second quarter would see positive growth. Commenting on this, Dr Mahathir said ``we have to accept that the economy is facing a lot of problems''. Dr Mahathir was also asked to comment on the observation by Economic Adviser to the Government and executive director of the National Economic Action Council Tun Daim Zainuddin that stagflation - a state of high inflation without the corresponding increase in demand and employment -would be imminent if credit growth remained at a standstill. The Prime Minister said the Government wanted credit growth. However, when banks were not confident of future performance, they were normally reluctant to give out loans. Against this, the banks would have to be ``prodded'' to give out more loans, he said. Dr Mahathir said a whole spectrum of measures were being taken to help overcome the economic problems. He said Malaysia had to conserve its earnings of foreign exchange and at the same time minimise spending. ``There is a need to reduce imports, increase exports and trade in the currencies of the countries concerned.'' In this context, Japan has agreed to trade in yen. ``Before this, 70 per cent of our trade was conducted in the US dollar although actual trade with the United States was only at 18 per cent. ``When the US dollar strengthened, we have problems buying goods from abroad. When the yen depreciated, we did not get the benefit because the contract is in the US dollar.''

SOUTH Korea, Malaysia's fifth largest trading partner, is confident of selling more machinery and industrial equipment to the local manufacturing sector this year despite the economic slowdown. South Korea exported about RM8.24 billion worth of machinery and equipment to Malaysia last year. This is more than 70 per cent of its 1997's total exports of RM11.27 billion to Malaysia. In turn, South Korea imported some RM7.1 billion or about 3.2 per cent of Malaysia's total exports. Korean Trade Centre (KOTRA) trade commissioner and director-general Im Sungbin said the positive trend and performance of the Malaysian manufacturing sector in the past three years were the key factors of the strong demand for higher technology and equipment. Kuala Lumpur-based Im said among the export-oriented industries which will continue to buy machinery are the electrical and electronic, textile, rubber products, wood and related products, transport equipment and non-metallic mineral products. Im said that 25 Korean companies would showcase their range of hi-tech machinery and equipment and other industrial products at the 12th Industry Tradefair Malaysia (ITM '98). The five-day exhibition beginning Wednesday will be held at the Mines Exhibition Centre in Sungei Besi, Kuala Lumpur.

KUALA LUMPUR, Sat. - The 2,800 SPM and SPMV holders who failed to obtain places in local universities will know the outcome of their appeals by June 15. Another 1,000 students who were ``left out'' despite obtaining good results because of computer errors or mistakes in their applications, will have their forms checked by Unit Pusat Universiti against the database of results from the Examinations Syndicate. Education Ministry's director of higher education Professor Hassan Said said this at a Press conference today. ``Students (who appealed) who do not receive notification by June 15 will have to consider their appeals unsuccessful. This also applies to the `left out' students. ``The notifications will be sent out from June 2. Students in Kuala Lumpur may receive theirs by Wednesday, while those in Sabah and Sarawak may have to wait for six to seven days.'' Hassan said today was the last day for accepting appeals. ``We must be fair to the universities as the academic sessions have started. It will not serve any purpose to continue to entertain appeals as they will never end.'' Hassan also advised students not to go to the UPU, but to wait for the letter. The majority of Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia and Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia Vokasional holders involved had applied for matriculation courses, while the rest had applied for degree courses at Universiti Teknologi Malaysia and Institut Tun Hussein Onn, as well as diploma courses. Hassan said there were fewer appeals from STPM holders and these would be handled by the universities. He was unable to provide statistics on the latest number of successful appeals nor the number of seats available for appeal cases, saying that: ``As the process of vetting the appeals is ongoing, it is impossible to give accurate figures. Everything will be finalised on Monday when representatives from the universities meet to furnish us with the number of places available.'' Hassan advised those whose appeals had failed to consider other options such as Form Six. He said most of the 2,800 appellants were students who failed to meet the qualifying criteria, but were allowed to appeal ``to be fair to them''. In contrast, there was a good chance that the ``left out'' students with good results would be accepted.

TONGKAH Holdings Bhd is disposing its entire 51 per cent interest or 3.57 million shares in Tongkah Medivest Sdn Bhd to Hospital Pantai Bhd for RM35.7 million cash. The proposed disposal would give Tongkah about RM30.38 million in capital gain, RHB Sakura Merchant Bankers Bhd said in a statement on behalf of Tongkah. RHB Sakura said assuming that the proposed disposal was completed on June 30, Tongkah's group earnings would be further increased by about RM2.26 million for the financial year ending June 30, 1999. KUALA LUMPUR, Sat. - The 1.8 per cent negative growth recorded in the first quarter of this year was the first for a quarter since the mid-1980s, Bank Negara governor Tan Sri Ahmad Mohd Don said today. If the current quarter also ended with a negative growth, it would meet the accepted definition of a recession - contraction of the economy in consecutive quarters, he said. At a Press conference this morning, the central bank reported a real GDP growth of -1.8 per cent for the first quarter ended March 31 of this year compared to 6.9 per cent in the previous quarter and 8.5 per cent in the first quarter of last year. Asked if the current quarter would also be negative, Ahmad said a recovery was expected but he would not say for sure if growth would be positive. For now, he said, the whole-year forecast remained at 2.5 per cent. As usual, Bank Negara would conduct a mid-year review of all estimates and forecasts in July, he said. On balance of payments, Ahmad said Malaysia achieved a trade surplus of RM8.808 billion, up from RM1.674 billion in the previous quarter, and RM2.022 billion in the first quarter of last year. This was on the back of higher exports of RM69.773 billion against lower imports of RM60.965 billion (see graphics on Page 2). The central bank has succeeded in reducing credit expansion to its targeted 15 per cent with April's figure showing 14.7 per cent. Ahmad gave an assurance the banking system still had sufficient liquidity to meet the financing needs of the economy. Elaborating on the loans growth cap of 15 per cent, Ahmad explained that there would still be RM60 billion for the eight months to December within the banking system. ``For the first four months, we experienced a marginal credit decline but if we allow loans of RM7.5 billion a month, then we would achieve our 15 per cent (target). ``We give allowance for variations from month to month but there is ample room for credit lending. We will stick firmly to this (cap of 15 per cent). ``There is RM60 billion for the next eight months and it is up to them (borrowers) to justify and ensure (their projects are) viable,'' Ahmad commented in apparent pressure recently from industry to relax lending guidelines. On interest rates, he said viable economic activities had access to funds at reasonable rates with the various funds and schemes which have recently been boosted, like for small and medium-scale industries, export credit refinancing and Fund For Food.

ASIAN oil companies, which are mostly Government-owned, will need to re- examine their relevance in the rapidly changing business environment, Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim said yesterday. In doing so, the industry will need to re-visit several fundamental concepts and question some basic assumptions in the philosophy underlying the industry's orientation. ``Some challenges are clear. Asian oil companies will have to improve their efficiency and the management of risk because one misstep can be fatal. ``In such a dynamic environment, the degree of risk is no longer limited to commercial considerations, but often also subject to socio-political realities. ``As the oil and gas industry becomes more global, the issues that need to be resolved would be increasingly complex, thereby escalating the potential risks,'' Anwar said in his keynote address at the launching of the 3rd Asia Oil and Gas Conference in Kuala Lumpur. He said that in order to manage risk effectively, there will be greater demands for transparency. ``Mergers and alliances, as well as sharing of assets and resources, are one way to optimise operations as well as share and spread the risks, given the right partners. ``For industry players from outside the region's energy sector, you have the choice of becoming an investor or a bystander in the game,'' Anwar said. He added that in the long term, Asia will continue to remain as a huge engine of growth of global energy demand, although at a slower pace in the face of the current economic crisis. Anwar quoted the World Bank as saying that the Asia Pacific region's energy demand is likely to exceed one third of the global total by the year 2010. ``Hence, the biggest challenge facing the energy industry in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in the oil and gas industry, lies in meeting Asia's seemingly insatiable appetite for energy. ``Those who choose to stay away do so at the risk of being left behind by others who seize the opportunities thrown by the crisis. Because East Asia will bounce back,'' he said. Anwar in his address also said there is no reason to doubt that East Asia can rise again in the future provided that ``we seize the moment to institute long-delayed reforms that would rid our economic and political systems of excesses and abuses. Anwar added that it is imperative that countries of the region work together in revitalising regional economies. ``We must be aware of evolving trends and new challenges, as well as be quick to anticipate and recognise threats and opportunities that may dramatically alter the economic and business landscape,'' he said.

GOTEBORG, Sweden (AP) _ Talented Alessandro Del Piero, healed from a right thigh strain which had put at risk his presence at France '98, on Tuesday was included in Italy's final list of 22 players for the upcoming World Cup. Del Piero inclusion meant the automatic exclusion of Parma's striker Enrico Chiesa, who had been put on alert as a possible substitute of the 23-year-old star of Juventus. Del Piero, who was injured during the Champions Cup final against Real Madrid, will resume full-time training with the teammates later this week. Del Piero is a considered a key to Italy's fortunes in the World Cup. ``Indications of the team doctors (about Del Piero's recovery) are positive,'' coach Cesare Maldini said Tuesday night. The list also included Fiorentina's keeper Francesco Toldo, a last-minute substitute for injured No.1 goalie Angelo Peruzzi. Peruzzi, of league champion Juventus, pulled a muscle in training at Coverciano Sunday. (pv)

New biathlon events added; two more women's hockey teams approved
SEVILLE, Spain (AP) _ The International Olympic Committee executive board on Tuesday approved new biathlon events and the addition of two more women's ice hockey teams for the 2002 Winter Games in Salt Lake City. The inclusion of men's and women's pursuit in biathlon, proposed by the international biathlon federation, was endorsed by the board on the first day of its four-day meeting in Seville. In addition, women's ice hockey will have eight teams in Salt Lake City. There were six teams in Nagano, where women's ice hockey made its Olympic debut. Salt Lake City organizers will make a presentation Wednesday to the executive board on their state of preparations. On Thursday, they will report to the assembly of national Olympic committees. IOC director general Francois Carrard said discussions were continuing on the possibility of adding the sport of skeleton _ a head-first version of luge _ as well as women's events in bobsledding and ski jumping for 2002.

IN another example of the susceptibility of the forex market to rumours, the ringgit yesterday fell to close at 3.9250/350 to the US dollar on market talk that Bank Negara governor Tan Sri Ahmad Mohd Don was quitting. The rumour, which surfaced in the early afternoon, was swiftly refuted by Adlin Zabri, Press secretary of Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim. The ringgit, however, failed to recover lost ground against the greenback which has been firming gradually against all other regional currencies as well. As it ebbed towards the psychological barrier of 4.0000 to the greenback, the ringgit succumbed to a short flurry of covering activities by those short on the greenback immediately after the rumours surfaced, dealers said. The local unit opened the day at 3.8600/800 but held firm at 3.8560/800 after morning trading. It fell to the 3.9200/3.9300 level after the rumour surfaced. The forex dealers said the rumour was not the main cause of the ringgit's slide yesterday. It was a factor which showed market sentiments could be swayed by such rumours. At least, it struck a cord with institutional and corporate players short on the greenback. In an already jittery forex market lacking fresh leads and on a day when the greenback further strengthened against the yen, the local currency could not hold up to any negative rumours, a dealer said. However, he said, the flurry of ringgit selling to the greenback was immediate and short-lived with characteristic thin volume. It later stabilised as the London and Singapore markets recovered from its reactions to the rumour. ``Of course, there was some effect from the rumour on the ringgit as the market is jittery with many corporates currently short on the dollar, a dealer said. ``But the real picture is that the ringgit fell in line with the strengthening of the dollar to regional currencies like the yen and the Singapore dollar.'' THE economic meltdown in South Korea has inflicted the most suffering on women of the republic, according to its former Foreign Minister Prof Han Sung-Joo. They are usually the first to get laid-off at a time when Korean companies are going under and because their labour is unappreciated they almost always go without severance benefits. He said in a country where male-chauvinistic trends prevail, the economic meltdown and subsequent emergence of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) era have given South Korean women dual pains. ``One as female workers and the other as housewives in a Confucian society,'' Han said in his paper entitled ``Currency Turmoil in Asia: The Strategic Impact'' presented at the 12th Asia-Pacific Roundtable meeting in Kuala Lumpur yesterday. He said South Korean male-dominated society equates female with lower productivity, so it has taken for granted that female workers must endure disadvantages in recruitment, promotion, wage level and job status. ``Simply put, female workers in South Korea get a so-called `ladies first' consideration when it comes to massive lay offs,'' he added. Han said under the current IMF bailout provisions, the role of women in the labour force is underestimated and relief policies for the current massive unemployment inadvertently exclude female workers. This phenomenon reflects the democratic market system on the one hand and Confucian paternalistic system on the other. ``Women are merely supposed to help and cheer up their depressed husbands. Few people pay attention to women suffering lay-off fears, family fallout, and difficulties at household economy,'' he added.

THE lustre may have paled but there is a lot going still for tin mining in Malaysia and the mining industry as a whole to warrant reviving dormant mines. Now is as good a time as any to get back to basics and look to Mother Earth for sustenance, not to glorify the heyday of tin prior to the 1985 collapse of the industry but for sound economic reasons which reflect the sheen in mining still. To rely mainly on manufacturing to turn the economy around is akin to putting all the eggs in one basket. It is time mining was given its due, considering its immense potential and the technology we have. Datuk Mohd Ajib Anuar, chairman of the Kuala Lumpur Tin Market as well as chief executive officer of Malaysia Smelting Corporation, brought up a case for the selective revival of tin mining recently, citing foreign exchange savings and its contribution to economic recovery if we can reduce our dependence on tin imports. Malaysia's production of 5,000 tonnes of tin annually is not enough to meet its consumption of 7,000 tonnes yearly by the pewter, solder, tin-plating and other tin-based industries. To maintain its smelting capacity, Malaysia Smelting Corporation, our sole tin smelter, will have to import the ores. The volume of refined tin metal exports from Malaysia totals some 30,000 tonnes annually so, if production can be raised to this level, it will reduce the likelihood of imports. The proposal will also ensure Malaysia's expertise in tin mining technology is put to good use locally instead of just being utilised abroad through reverse investments. If the mines are not reopened, there will be no opportunities to train people and ensure transfer of technology. If that is the scenario, our expertise in tin mining technology may well be lost in five years' time. As it is, many old-timers have diversified into related industries since the late eighties when tin prices dipped to as low as about RM11 per kg compared with a high of RM29.15 per kg before the tin crash. The potential for hardrock mining remains to be tapped. In this respect, the Geological Survey will have to work closely with the State Governments and identify areas with economic potential for exploration. For the revival objectives to be met, the States in which the dormant mines are located will have to be more accommodating towards miners. At the onset, the States should perhaps approach the revival of tin mining not on tin per se but view it in a holistic and integrated manner to incorporate the mining industry as a whole. Some by-products of mining have added value in their use as alloys in industries such as aerospace and ceramics. Minerals such as silica sand are exported to countries such as Japan where they are developed into silicon wafers for use in the electronics industry and exported to Malaysia and elsewhere. The renewal of leases and the leasing of land for mining lie in the hands of the State. Instead of according priority to property and industrial development, the State Governments should view mining more positively and make land available for prospecting and mining. For as long as the tin price remains at at least RM20 per kg, royalties will flow into the State coffers. Perak has every reason to cheer as it has been collecting more than RM253,000 in royalties from tin ore in the past eight months. Under the New Mineral Development policy, all tin mining States will get to collect royalty. But understandably, the States are concerned about the rehabilitation of tin mines and the environmental effects after mining has ceased. A solution to this is to include Environmental Impact Assessment reports in project proposals. Mining pools can serve as a source of water supply in times of need upon treatment of the water. They can also be transformed into recreational and tourist attractions. In international tin issues, Malaysia still holds sway and it is worth the while of State Governments to give more than a cursory glance to the revival of tin mining on an integrated basis.

DEPUTY Prime Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim, who is also Finance Minister, yesterday said domestic interest rates must remain firm -especially since offshore ringgit deposit rates now stood at about 20 per cent. He said the business community must understand that interest rates cannot be much lower than the offshore rates as it could otherwise lead to an outflow of funds in ringgit terms. ``It's very important that people who talk about interest rates know the offshore rates for ringgit. If you do not take this into consideration, you are putting the entire financial system at risk, because what is stopping people from bringing out our funds?'' Anwar also denied that a request had been made to the Monetary Authority of Singapore to assist in bringing down the rates for offshore ringgit deposits. ``I think it was simply a matter that was expressed in the Parliament there on all foreign currency deposits in general.'' The offshore ringgit deposits in Singapore attracted attention recently when interest rates breached the 40 per cent mark. They have eased to about 20 per cent. Malaysia's three-month interbank rates are now more than 11 per cent, up from 7.5 per cent in July last year, when Asia's financial problems began. When asked about the statement by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad on interest rates on Saturday, Anwar said Dr Mahathir was merely expressing the general consensus of the business community who felt interest rates were very high. He said the Government did not deny the fact that the business community was facing problems. He explained the policy was to ensure the credit situation eases. ``I personally believe interest rates should be determined by market forces.'' Asked if they could come down in the near future, Anwar said the central bank had that option, but high offshore rates for ringgit deposits must be taken into account. ``The option must be kept open through the central bank. A rate cut will affect adversely the currency and inflation. ``I personally would like the interest rates to come down but what can we do when there are so many other factors to take note of? ``What is more critical now is the easing of credit. This can be partly resolved by the setting up of the proposed asset management companies. ``The AMCs will take over part of the non-performing loans of the country's banks and that should enable commercial banks to disburse loans to the various sectors of the economy. ``We cannot direct the banks as to who or to which selected company they should disburse these loans to. ``Not every captain of industry or prominent businessman can expect that loans must be disbursed to them because of their position or influence. ``I want to say that such a move will be very unwise.''

ASIAN nations have to restructure their economic policies to bring them in line with the international system and global Information Age, Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim said yesterday. He said the Asian crisis came about because of an incompatibility between the Asian national systems and the international system. ``Each new stage in economic development requires a new mental framework,'' he said in his keynote address at the 12th Asia-Pacific Roundtable meeting in Kuala yesterday. Anwar said the present global economy had passed two industrial revolutions and it is now rushing into the third industrial revolution. The first revolution was the age of the steam engine, the second was the age of motor vehicles and aeroplanes and the third is the age of the information revolution. ``The information revolution has already set in, but our minds are trapped in the second industrial revolution. Thus, we have become T-Rex trying to live beyond the Jurassic age,'' he added. Anwar reiterated that Asian countries have to restructure their respective economies to bring them in line with the Information Age. ``A new economic age brings with it new challenges to which Asian countries have to respond. The road to destruction is paved with stubborness in sticking to old modes of thinking. ``We can rival any industrial country in constructing hard and physical infrastructure. But we have not caught up when it comes to the soft, intangible and invisible infrastructure, that is, a regulatory framework to ensure transparency and to manage rapid capital movements,'' he added. While re-inventing these policies to make them in line with international systems as well as Information Age-sensitive, Anwar said Asian countries must re-anchor their policies to address the needs of common people, where wealth-sharing and social justice must be re-emphasised. ``Asia is at a political and economic crossroads. We must exercise courage and wisdom. We must choose between satisfying our jingoism, thereby sliding into the edge of darkness, and taking the path of reform towards a humane free market economy,'' he added. He noted that it is time for Asia to break out from its encrusted mould because a new reality that demands modifications in the conduct of diplomacy is emerging within the region. ``Globalisation, which marches on relentlessly, will re-define both the role and the sphere of the nation-state. We will become irrelevant unless we begin to come to terms with the new reality,'' he added. Anwar said the wave of revolution sweeping the region in the last few years almost paralleled the 1848 revolution that swept away the last remnants of absolutism and tyranny in Europe. ``The demand for reform, good governance and civil society in Asia today is an unstoppable force of history. When the people has truly decided on internal reform, neither the political elite nor their cronies, be they in business or media or anywhere else, will be able to withstand the groundswell.'' Anwar said in this regard, the conduct of diplomacy must go beyond and perhaps deeper than conventional notions such as confidence-building and comprehensive security. ``Confidence-building has not worked precisely because we have not probed into the roots of suspicion and distrust between states. ``We must constantly remind ourselves that in any conflict it is always the people, not the state, who pay the price. We must find ways and means to remove deep-seated suspicions and hostility among states. ``We must arrest this drift to violence and nuclear adventurism. We must oppose opportunistic politicians who fan the flames of jingoism be it in the name of religion or state,'' he added. He noted that Asia remains mired in poverty and destitution despite being a vast continent, populated by one half of humanity, and having at least three nuclear powers.

REEFS are essentially massive deposits of calcium carbonate that have been produced by corals with major additions from calcareous algae and other organisms that secrete calcium carbonate. A coral reef is an assemblage of many types of plants and animals of which corals form one of the dominant components. The basis of the entire coral reef ecosystem revolves around the ability of the coral polyps to remove calcium ions from the seawater and deposit them as a limestone skeleton. These skeletons collectively form massive coral reefs. In addition to coral polyps several coralline algae which also produce limestone skeletons are considered important in the building and consolidation of coral reefs. A reef offers an environment upon which highly specialised creatures have become dependent for their survival. It provides a solid substrate on which many specialised sea bottom-living organisms such as clams, sponges, sea-fans, anemones and algae settle and grow.

HAVE you seen a movie lately? At a cinema, I mean. With so many options available in the market, not many people go to the cinema nowadays. Besides movies on video cassettes, there are laser discs and video CDs which are becoming popular. The more affluent members of our society even have home theatre systems in their living rooms. A friend who had just acquired a big house has installed a theatre system and I've not been able to get him out for our usual teh tarik at night since. The days when going to the cinema was part of the local dating scene are over. I remember when going to the movies was a popular outing, never mind if the cinemas were dirty, toilets stank and patrons smoked. The cheapest ticket then was 80 sen and patrons sat right in front. Those who sat in front usually ended up with stiff necks because they had to keep their heads at about 60 degrees to the screen. Those who had corner seats had to make do with a distorted view of their heroes and heroines. Oh yes, front seats were usually made of wood and they often creaked a lot. In those days, depending on the particular movie's popularity, buying tickets can sometimes end in brawls. There was no queue, and only the strongest and bravest dared to pit their strength. I was told when the movie Sangam opened at the Odeon cinema in Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman, black market operators enjoyed a small boom as touts. Nowadays, the cinema comes into the home and all you need is your favourite drink and kacang. In fact, it's not uncommon to go through two movies at one sitting, especially when there's a long weekend ahead. Shops selling and renting out movies, either on videotapes, LDs or VCDs, are everywhere. If you're a regular, you can even rent them at a discounted rate. Of course, you have to put down a deposit, refundable when you end your membership. It was against this background that I went to a cinema two nights ago. I announced to my family that I was going to belanja (treat) them and this was greeted with much enthusiasm. I've only taken them to a cinema once before, during one of the school holidays ages ago. Armed with two complimentary passes given by Tony, a public relations executive, I bought additional tickets at RM8 each and settled down to enjoy Tommy Lee Jones and Wesley Snipes in US Marshals. The children insisted that popcorn and soft drinks were vital accessories to a good movie, and I duly obliged. The cinema is one of many operated by Tanjung Golden Village, a joint-venture company set up by Tanjung Public Limited Company, Village Roadshow Limited of Australia and Golden Harvest Cinemas Holdings Limited of Hong Kong. In today's language, the movie house is known as a cineplex, meaning that it's a small cinema located within a much bigger complex, usually a shopping complex. The cineplex I went to was at the Mines shopping complex in Sri Kembangan. Today's cineplex are cleaner and look much better. The one I went to was quite pleasing, with polite counter clerks who seemed ready to flash a smile at customers. They were clad in pretty uniforms which gave the cinema operators a somewhat better image. The cineplex foyer was also much better. It was well lit, air-conditioned, of course, and has a feel-good atmosphere. The whole cinema floor was carpeted, with seats which offer lots of leg room for comfort and an unimpeded view. In fact, the floor leading to the toilets too were fully carpeted. Today's cinema operators also appear more customer-friendly. There are disabled-friendly stairways with elevator facility for those in wheelchairs, a plus point any time. The cinema crowd is also less rowdy, the only interference coming from selfish individuals and their handphones. Anyway, apart from slight embarrassment at the ticket counter (I thought the complimentary passes had no expiry date), my family and I enjoyed the movie. Action-packed movies such as US Marshals must be watched on the big screen and with the best digital sound systems. So, wherever you are today, thanks Tony!

JOHOR BARU, Sat. - The State Government will discuss with the privatised Johor Tenggara Regional Development Authority which party should play the local government's role in the Kejora region. Menteri Besar Datuk Abdul Ghani Othman said today that the State Government supported the Cabinet's decision to privatise Kejora, which has areas in both Kota Tinggi and Kluang districts under its jurisdiction. Ghani was commenting on the announcement by Rural Development Minister Datuk Annuar Musa on Thursday that the Cabinet had decided to privatise Kejora, which would become a consortium called Kejora-YPJ Sdn Bhd. Annuar had also said the Government would set aside RM10 million annually to help the consortium take on the role and duties of a local authority, until the State Government had made a decision to hand over the duties to suitable parties. Ghani said the State Government would suggest that the Kota Tinggi and Kluang District Councils act as the local governments of Bandar Penawar (in Kota Tinggi district) and Bandar Tenggara (in Kluang district) respectively. The Menteri Besar was speaking to reporters after witnessing the joint venture signing ceremony between the Johor Farmers Organisation and the Segamat Muslim Orphans Welfare Organisation. Ghani, however, did not rule out allowing Kejora-YPJ Sdn Bhd to act as the local authority of both Bandar Penawar and Bandar Tenggara. He said this would be similar to that of the Pasir Gudang Local Authority, a privatised body carrying out the duties of a local authority in Pasir Gudang.

WHEN we mentioned a price of RM3.7 million for the Rolls-Royce Silver Seraph in this column recently there were a lot of raised eyebrows. But what's interesting is that we subsequently found out that the stablemate Bentley models could cost even more. Rolls-Royce, which has owned the Bentley marque since the 1930s, has kept it as a sportier model. There are two Bentley models which could easily set you back by more than RM5 million, inclusive of Malaysia's 300 per cent import tax and 10 per cent sales tax. Topping the list would be the Bentley Azure, the soft top version of the Continental coupe series. The body is reinforced and the top has been designed and built by Pininfarina, the prestigious Italian coach builder responsible for some Ferrari designs. The stunning lines of the Bentley Azure clothe the sophisticated technology of a 241kph (150mph) sporting supercar. Inside, Bentley keynotes of walnut veneer and sumptuous leather accommodating up to four occupants, while the turbocharged and intercooled 6.7-litre V8 engine combines scorching performance with silken refinement. But it's no lumbering giant. Big though it might be, it behaves very well round corners. Something to do with the Rolls-Royce adaptive damping on the shocks which gives it a very sporting performance around corners. On the straight it is soft and comfortable. Although it weighs around 2,608kg (5,750lbs), the turbocharged V8 moves the Azure to 0-100 kph in 6.7 secs. That's quick for a heavyweight. Also in the RM5 million category is the Bentley Continental T. For the drive, thunderous performance is the single-minded intent, emphatically fulfilled in the latest 420 bhp (312kW) engine. The 6.75-litre V8 propels it to a top speed of 249kph and scoots from 0-100kph in under six seconds. The new Continental T is built to satisfy the most demanding of drivers and bears a black Bentley badge, a mark of distinction that signifies the most daring in Bentley performance. If you are one of those who want to make a public statement about your wealth and status, you couldn't find a better way to do it than in a Bentley or a Rolls-Royce.

Asian currencies sagged in late morning trade, giving up their early strong yen-inspired gains as traders focused on growing evidence of economic strain across the region. Fears of a recession in Hongkong, nationwide strikes in South Korea and expectations of slowing growth in Malaysia all conspired against Asian markets, dulling some of the positive sentiment from the calmer situation in Indonesia. Russia's crumbling financial markets added to the clouds over Asia as traders worried about the contagion effect of problems in emerging markets. ``With the demonstrations and unrest in Indonesia blowing over, Asian currencies had started to settle down. But now we're starting to see more bad news with the real economies,'' a US bank dealer in Singapore said. ``It's not really a trading scenario where you see one bit of bad news and sell the hell out of the currency... People are just not taking aggressive positions anymore,'' she added. The Indonesian rupiah looked set to stay around the 10,500-11,000 region there is some movement on the resumption of lending by the likes of the IMF and World Bank. The IMF has suspended disbursements of its $10 billion balance of payments loan, the central plank of the $41.2 billion rescue package. The IMF's Asia-Pacific director Hubert Neiss said there was no need to revise Indonesia's structural reform program, but macro-economic figures needed adjusting. He told reporters after meeting President Jusuf Habibie that the macro-economic framework had to be adjusted ``to the new situation that unfortunately even weaker than it was before''. The next round of talks on how to reschedule Indonesia's $80 billion private sector debt will take place on June 1. On the political front, economics minister Ginandjar said preparing for national polls could take several months, maybe more than a year. In South Korea, the government said industrial output fell 10.8% in April year-on-year, compared with a 7.1% rise the year before. Industrial output fell 10.1% year-on-year in March. The won firmed back through the 1,400 per dollar level as dollar inflows from exporters outweighed dollar short-covering by players concerned about labor unrest in the country and the yen's recent weakness. The Labor Ministry said over 34,000 workers at 18 sites across the country were on strike as of 0200 GMT. But union officials told Reuters as many as 70,000 workers at 40 organizations were still striking. The militant Korean Confederation of Trade Unions called a two-day national strike to protest layoffs. The ringgit was a little lower amid growing fears about Malaysia's economic outlook and some traders are talking about a revisit of the 3.90 or even 4.0 level. Malaysian Q1 GDP figures are due this week and a Reuters poll of economists produced an average forecast of 1.7 percent GDP growth in Q1. This compared with a 2.8% forecast in a poll conducted at the beginning of May. The Singapore dollar was on the wrong side of 1.66, with players targeting the 1.68 level initially amid concerns about the impact of slowing growth in Malaysia and Indonesia. The Indian rupee opened at 41.30/40 to the dollar and was expected to range between 41.25 and 41.45 after the central bank's rate checking dampened dollar buying interest on Wednesday. Driver implicates Gucci wife in killing, says real killer at large pickup

MILAN, Italy (AP) - A defendant accused in the slaying of fashion scion Maurizio Gucci admitted Tuesday that he drove the getaway car, and implicated Gucci's ex-wife as the mastermind. But Orazio Cicala, a onetime pizzeria operator, threw the case into confusion when he testified the police had arrested the wrong hit man. Gucci was shot dead March 27, 1995, as he walked into his office building in downtown Milan. Nearly two years later, police arrested his ex-wife, Patrizia Reggiani Martinelli; her longtime spiritual adviser Giuseppina Auriemma; Milan hotel doorman Ivano Savioni; alleged trigger man Benedetto Ceraulo; and Cicala. The prosecution says Reggiani Martinelli had Gucci murdered because he'd halved her alimony to dlrs 900,000 a year and she was obsessed with gaining control over his estate. She allegedly paid her co-defendants dlrs 300,000 to carry out the crime. Cicala, a gaunt man in his 60s who used to operate a pizzeria in the northern suburbs of Milan, was brought out of the defendant's cage he shares with Ceraulo to take the stand. He portrayed Reggiani Martinelli as the driving force behind the plan to murder her ex-husband. He said that at the end of February 1995, Savioni and Reggiani Martinelli came to his home to talk about the plan. A second meeting took place some time later at the Bar Jamaica in Milan, a bohemian hang-out in the city's trendy Brera neighborhood. ``We discussed the fact that I was supposed to find the person who would carry out the crime,'' Cicala said. But he said Ceraulo was not the killer. He described the real killer as a ``dolt'' he'd met when he was dealing drugs. ``I can't give you his name because I have children and a family,'' he told the court. He said he decided to confess as ``a matter of conscience,'' saying he was drawn into the scheme because he needed money. It was Reggiani Martinelli's first day in court _ Italian defendants are not required to attend trial. She sat on the last bench in the courtroom surrounded by security guards, with rosary beads wrapped around one wrist and a blue plastic Swatch around the other. Wearing no makeup and dressed in sporty blue cotton slacks and top, Reggiani Martinelli listened impassively to Cicala's statement. At one point she appeared ill, and a nurse came rushing in the courtroom to offer her an injection, which Reggiani Martinelli refused, saying all she needed was a drink of water. (str/djw)

FOR Americans, big and strong still seem to be how they like their vehicles and Ford's future 4x4 is no exception, by the looks of it. The Ford Tremor with its high-performance V8 4.6-litre DOHC five-valve engine, independent rear suspension, all-wheel drive and aggressive looks, will definitely break new grounds in the 4x4 market. This concept sport utility vehicle is said to be at home on just about any terrain. The Tremor is a further evolution of the world's best-selling 4x4, the Ford Explorer which was introduced to the Malaysian market by AMIM Holdings Sdn. Bhd, the local Ford distributor, a little over a year ago. The Explorer was known for its performance, ruggedness and a well-packaged interior. It was making great strides in a rather selective segment of the 4x4 market when the regional economic problems put a damper on sales. It however, is making great strides in other parts of the world. The Tremor is expected to eventually create a new niche for a fun-to-drive vehicle. At the heart of the Tremor is a powerful, all-aluminum 4.6-litre high performance engine capable of delivering an estimated 380 PS and 340 foot-pounds of torque at 5,500 rpm. The engine was built by Ford's Advanced Powertrain group. The Tremor's chassis and suspension are engineered to provide optimised handling characteristics, without compromising the refined ride quality associated with the Explorer. The fully independent rear suspension (IRS) has been adapted from the latest version of the Ford Thunderbird. The nine-inch Thunderbird IRS was chosen because of its excellent durability and reliability, making it an ideal candidate for the Tremor's street and off-road performance needs. According to the manufacturers, even with the significant changes to the suspension to improve its dynamics on the road, Tremor's off-road handling and ground clearance have not been compromised. The front end features a new hood and fenders made from lightweight composite materials. A large grille opening keeps the 4.6-litre V-8 cool even under the most demanding driving conditions. Four large round high-performance headlamps, plus two round fog lamps in the front bumper, emphasise its sporty, purposeful character. Tremor's rich metallic red paint is enhanced by the addition of nickel chrome protection panels on the lower body. The rear end has been extended slightly and the backlight sloped to give the vehicle a sportier profile. The licence plate mount has been moved from the bumper to the tailgate and combined with a new integrated tailgate-opening handle. An innovative roof rack and a rear roof spoiler help to improve stability. The Explorer is known for its interior packaging, and the Tremor concept follows this tradition but with a more performance-oriented theme. Four custom-made leather-covered Lear buckle seats hold the driver and passengers firmly yet comfortably in position during even in the roughest off-road conditions. Grab handles are located near each seat for when the going gets rough. While Tremor is only a concept at this stage, it has been engineered as a fully driveable prototype and will be used to gauge public reaction to the possibility of building a production version. In Malaysia, the Ford Explorer has been on sale since July last year and has made an impact on the local 4x4 market.

MADRID, Spain (AP) _ A 17-year-old girl was killed and 17 other French students when their bus overturned on a highway in northeastern Spain on Tuesday, a spokeswoman from the Spanish emergency services said. BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open-Rios
Rest easy, Pete: Rios is thwarted in quest for top spot
By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Cheered on all tournament long by the vocal Chilean fans, Marcelo Rios was tantalizingly close to regaining the No. 1 spot in tennis. All he had to do was reach the semis. One problem: Carlos Moya. The talented Spaniard used all his weapons Tuesday to defeat Rios, 6-1, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4. He spoiled not only the Chilean's chance for the French Open title _ one he was favored to win _ but also his chance to regain the hallowed spot he'd stolen from Pete Sampras for a month this spring. So what was Rios thinking on court? ``I wasn't thinking about it,'' he said. ``I was thinking about the match.'' Well, maybe. But Rios' fans were certainly thinking about it. With every point he won, they waved a giant Chilean flag. ``Viva Chile!'' they chanted during the changeovers. Rios has been the dominant player on the tour this season, with five titles and a 36-4 record. His baseline game is suited to clay, and he hits his groundstrokes with great power, often jumping up on one foot to whack the ball over the net. He overtook Sampras on March 30, and became the first South American to reach No. 1 since the computerized rankings started in 1973. So even though Sampras recaptured the No. 1 spot a month later, Rios was confident here. And many favored him to win, even before the early exits of Sampras and No. 2 Petr Korda. ``This to me is Rios' tournament to win or lose,'' John McEnroe said before the tournament. But nothing is predictable at the French Open, where being a favorite often is a curse. Last year, Spanish player Alex Corretja refused to name a favorite, explaining that if he did so, that person would lose. Moya, the No. 12 seed here, has been ranked as high as fifth in the world, but is now 12th and has been aiming to crack back into the top 10. He became the talk of the tennis world at last year's Australian Open _ for both his dashing good looks and his talent. He upset defending champion Boris Becker in the first round, then went straight through to the final, where he lost to Sampras. But except for that tournament, the 21-year-old Moya had never gone past the second round of any Grand Slam event. And here at Roland Garros, he hadn't gotten past the second round in two previous visits. Moya was at the top of his all-court game Tuesday, and especially serving well. With Moya leading two sets to one, a crucial moment came in the fourth set at 4-4, 15-15. Rios was serving. Moya hit a shot and Rios let it go, thinking the ball had bounced twice on Moya's side. But the referee said it hadn't. Rios lost the point, the game, and his concentration. ``Maybe if I won that game, the match would have been different,'' he said later. Moya knew that point had an impact. ``It was bad for him,'' he said. Rios went on to delight his fans by saving three match points in the last game, including a lucky net cord. But the Spaniard fired an ace to set up the fourth match point, and Rios netted his final shot. Now Moya finds himself the highest seed left in the tournament, and one of only three seeds left _ all Spaniards, who excel on clay. The others are the No. 14 seed, Alex Corretja, and the No. 15 seed, Felix Mantilla, whom Moya plays in the semis on Friday. Mantilla and Moya are buddies. ``We're going to be friends until Friday,'' he said. ``When we get to the court, I will try to kill him.'' (jn)

INVESTORS should focus on this year's growth forecast of two to three per cent, instead of dwelling too much on the negative growth of 1.8 per cent recorded in the first quarter. Deputy Finance Minister Datuk Affifuddin Omar yesterday said subsequent quarters in the year were expected to show more positive growth. Also, the Government will increase the injection of cash into the banking sector this year to maintain sufficient liquidity. ``We expect investors to structure their investment plans in line with the growth forecast for the whole year.'' Affifuddin said the first quarter's negative growth was expected as the Government had taken steps to restrict the economy's overall growth for the year. He was speaking in Sri Hartamas, Kuala Lumpur, after launching the pilot programme for the ``Smartpay Card for the Government Sector'' for selected Petronas service stations. ``We will wait and see what happens in the second and third quarter growth which is expected to rise to contribute to the targeted growth for the whole year.'' The Government trimmed the country's 1998 gross domestic product growth forecast to two to three per cent, down from four to five per cent announced last December. An initial forecast of seven per cent was made during the 1998 Budget meeting in Parliament in October last year. ``We will meet the two to three per cent growth, and will have to increase the liquidity of the financial sector and attract more investors.'' Bank Negara governor Tan Sri Ahmad Don had said the banking sector would have RM60 billion available for lending for the eight months to December. Meanwhile, the ``Smartpay Card for the Government Sector'' pilot programme is undertaken by the Government to allow its officials to purchase petroleum products at Petronas and Shell stations using a smartcard. It will eventually substitute the current practice by government officials of using indent slips to purchase products. Affifuddin said the project was established as part of the Government's efforts to realise a paperless administration and is a result of an ongoing study on the use of credit cards for government-related expenditure. The pilot programme involves four departments under the Finance Ministry and selected Petronas and Shell service stations. Affifuddin said the project would reduce the time and costs of administering government petroleum purchases from Petronas and Shell which receive an average of 200,000 transactions involving 11 million purchase documents every month.

Close to 30% of the 41,935 barangays in the Philippines had no electricity in 1996, according to the National Statistical Coordination Board (NSCB). NSCB, which released the findings only last April, said only 29,530 of the 41,935 barangays in the Philippines enjoyed electricity service during the period. This finding was based on data gathered by on a study in 1996 which was released last April. By major island group, Luzon was the most energized with 16,709 of 20,473 barangays enjoying electricity service. Visayas followed suit with 65.2% of its 11,441 barangays having electricity. Mindanao came in a poor third with about 53.4% or slightly over half of its 10,021 barangays. On the other hand, electricity reached 96% of cities and municipalities nationwide Electric cooperatives are responsible for energizing 89.8% of the cities/municipalities and 81.4% of the barangays. The Manila Electric Co. (Meralco) distributed power to 7.4% of the cities and municipalities and 13.9% of the barangays. Residential consumers comprised the biggest block of users at 89.7%. The commercial sector accounted for 7.7%, while the industrial sector comprised 0.4%. The remaining 2.2% represented general public uses such as public buildings, street lights, and water irrigation. Electric cooperatives provided 4,131,749 connections or roughly more than half of the total connections in the country. Meralco on the other hand was responsible for 2,869,531 connections or about 36% of the total. Other private utilities handled 839,602 connections.-Chris S. Frondoso

THE malice in Sue Grafton's recent whodunit refers to the bitter sibling rivalry of the Malek brothers who are determined that Guy, their long-lost black-sheep brother, never receives a penny of his inheritance. It is left to Kinsey Millhone, the Californian private eye, to hunt Guy down and bring him home. She quickly succeeds in locating him and brings back a seemingly sweet, guileless and totally reformed man. Nevertheless, the Malek brothers are suspicious of this former junkie, but any chance of getting reacquainted is thwarted when Guy gets murdered. This is Grafton's 14th novel in a series which names each novel after a letter in the alphabet. Readers should be warned that `M' also stands for mundane, monotonous, mediocre! Grafton lacks the skill of Ruth Rendell and the pacing of Mickey Spillane, and her novel is obviously formulaic. Set in the world of middle America, with its trailer parks and middle-aged inhabitants with midriff spreads, it is far too unglamorous to even be considered pulp. Kinsey Millhone is no Charlie's Angel. She owns one dress, is hitting middle age, unmarried, childless, and battling a weight problem and the temptation of sticky buns. Despite owning a gun and having had her nose broken twice, Kinsey has a tender side. She is instantly drawn to Guy and prefers him to his older brothers. He naively mistakes his family's renewed interest in him to be an act of brotherly love. Kinsey breaks the truth to him gently and tries to protect him from the Maleks. She identifies with his isolation: ``I was struck by the fact that Guy's circumstances were oddly reminiscent of mine, both of us trying to assimilate fractured family connections.'' Kinsey becomes emotionally involved in the case and is devastated by Guy's death. Her emotional wall crumbles further when former lover Robert Dietz shows up after a break of ``two years, four months, and 10 days''. Yet even this ex-flame cannot ignite the soggy embers of Kinsey's long burnt-out passionate side. She seems delighted when he injures his knee and the question of whether or not they'll sleep together is hastily swept under the carpet. M is for Malice has little emotional or dramatic punch. Even Guy's murder has no impact. The gambling, alcoholic Malek brothers are too mediocre to be effective villains. The reader is given almost no clue as to who Guy's real murderer might be, so that when Kinsey inevitably tracks this person down, his identity and motivation seem far-fetched and obscure. Thus the avid detective novel reader is stripped of the joy of attempting to solve the case. The whole story is a series of frustrated realisations: Kinsey only solves the crime when it's too late. The murderer is a fictional decoy, clumsily inserted into the plot and Kinsey resumes a lukewarm relationship with Dietz, which has the erotic charge of a night in bed with a husband who still wears his socks after 35 years! The ending is a final insipid splurge. Kinsey has a dream in which she realises her unrequited love for Guy and regrets that she could not save him. Grafton warns us that her story is not over. There is limitless turgid prose yet to come to further disgrace the detective genre. ``What's done is done. What is written is written. Their work is finished, ours is yet to do.''

Q: I AM 40 years old. I used to have spottings two days before my periods but now I am having them for 20 days, i.e., after four days of period, I am clean for three days before the spotting starts again. I used to have a 30-day cycle and then 28 days, and now its 25/26 days. Am I going through menopause? Are there any herbs or vitamins I can take? I go for a pap smear and scan every year but everything is normal. I had tubal ligation done four years ago. A: THERE could be many causes for mid-cycle spotting, menopause being only one possibility. A blood test will tell if this is the cause. In menopause, the pituitary sends out ever increasing levels of FSH (follicle stimulating hormone) and LH (luteinising hormone) to try and ``wake up'' the ovaries which are becoming sluggish, and therefore low in oestrogen. So, in menopause, FSH and LH are elevated while oestrogen is deficient. Another possible cause could be excessive oestrogen (compared to progesterone). This should also show on a blood test and may be caused by the intake of chemical oestrogens through food and water. If you eat only organically-fed meats and animal products, and drink only purified water, this will help to resolve this particular problem. Herbs such as peony and chastetree, and vitamin B6 with a full B-complex are also helpful. Other helpful herbs would be beth root as an astringent and false unicorn root as a uterine tonic and hormone balancer. If the problem does not improve, you should seek medical advice as there may be other causes such as fibroids, polyps or endometriosis.

PLUM Island is a rare thing - a bestseller with a sense of humour. Its humour is even more surprising when you consider that Nelson Demille's American chart-topper is a thriller set in an area that includes an island (the Plum Island of the title) which is a site for research into animal diseases. Actually, it's a little more sinister than that. Nobody is quite sure what does go on at Plum Island but there are rumours abound. The scientists claim they are looking for vaccines against diseases like anthrax and ebola, but more cynical and inquisitive souls suspect that there may be other agendas. How much research is being devoted to cross-over diseases; diseases that affect animals but can also affect humans? And despite denials that the United States is doing research into biological warfare, is that another of the centre's concerns? These local speculations become rather more acute when two top scientists from Plum Island are found dead on their patio. Tom and Judy Gordon were two of the research centre's star scientists. Young, attractive and successful, they had an active involvement in the local community and a lifestyle that looks beyond their means. A nice waterfront house and a fast and powerful boat don't come cheap and a post-mortem check through the couple's computerised financial records reveals that their glamorous lifestyle was too expensive for their modest incomes. So who wanted the Gordons dead? And why? Enter the book's narrator, ``John Corey by name, convalescing cop by profession'', a friend of the Gordons' who is staying nearby, recovering from three bullet wounds acquired in the course of his duties as a New York homicide detective. As Corey puts it: ``So you don't think I'm a paranoid citizen, I should mention that I was convalescing, not from the mumps, but from three bullet wounds, two 9mm and one .44 calibre Magnum, not that the size of the holes matters. As with real estate, what matters with bullet holes is location, location, location. Obviously these holes were in the right locations because I was convalescing, not decomposing.'' Corey agrees to lend his old friend Max, ``who is the law in these here parts'', a helping hand, bringing big-city ways to the backwater of North Fork on Long Island. He accepts a retainer to look at the bodies and advise on the case, which he does for a short while. Then the thinly disguised FBI and CIA presence decides to put out an official explanation of the deaths. Whilst the local township gossips about the Gordons selling a deadly virus to enemy agents, the worried authorities put out a story that the Gordons stole a vaccine which they intended to exploit commercially. Neither story is true. Corey's role in most of this is to ask difficult questions and irritate government officials. He excels at both to such an extent that his retainer is terminated and he is left to pursue the case on his own, unofficially and illegally. Some might also say unwisely. But Corey is not a man easily deterred. One of his most appealing qualities is his scepical attitude to authority, particularly when he believes it to be engaged in an elaborate cover-up. The Gordons were friends of his and his intuition tells him that they were not the sort of people they are made out to be. Too many things about the case do not fit. The official explanations are too neat and too glib. Corey wants the truth. Much of the book's success, and much of the reader's enjoyment, derives from Corey's character. A wise-cracking, street-smart New Yorker with a healthy distrust of appearances, he digs away, both literally and metaphorically, until he unearths the mystery of Plum Island and the real story behind the deaths of the Gordons. His occasional partners in this enquiry are two beautiful women, one a fellow detective and the other president and archivist of the local Peconic Historical Society. They, too, add zest to the book, but it is on Corey's character that much of the book's interest, and almost all of its humour, hinges. The following extract is typical: ``I'm a good interrogator because I can pick out personalities and types, and tailor my approach accordingly. ``This doesn't mean I'm simpatico, sensitive or empathetic. I'm an overbearing, egocentric, and opinionated male chauvinist pig. That's my comfort zone. But I listen and I say what has to be said. It's part of the job.'' I can imagine readers not liking Corey at all. He is definitely chauvinistic and arrogant, definitely not PC. But he is also, of course, all the things that he claims not to be - empathetic, sensitive and thoughtful. It's just that for large parts of the book he keeps some of these qualities fairly well hidden. But just as every prostitute in Hollywood has a heart of gold, so, it seems, does every hard-bitten detective. And very few have been bitten harder than John Corey. Demille is a very professional writer. Plum Island is well controlled and it moves smoothly and effortlessly through to its finale. There are no last-minute surprises, no wholly unbelievable climaxes and no bids to upstage Hollywood disaster movies. The resolution of the plot is not wholly credible but it does at least remain consistent to the characters of the people involved. I was never wholly convinced by the real cause of the Gordons' death but as the book's main appeal is the characters and their relationships, that seemed less important than it does when the only interest is non-stop action. And when I apply the oldest test in the world, I have to admit that Plum Island did well. There are books you read in bed before you go to sleep. There are fewer books that you read when you wake up in the morning. There are still fewer that you sneak-read at odd moments when you really should be doing other things. And Plum Island made me do all of those!

ONE square metre of this grass generates about 10 litres of oxygen per day. Big animals graze on it, little animals live amongst it, and there are millions of hectares of it around the world (Northern Queensland alone has about 5,000 sq km). But you can't use your lawn mower on it - nor would you want to. What is it? The answer is seagrass. Seagrass is a flowering plant, complete with leaves, a rhizome (underground, usually horizontally-oriented stem) and a root system. They are found in marine or estuarine waters. Most seagrass species are located in soft (that is, silty or sandy) sediments. Seagrass tends to develop into extensive underwater meadows that resemble fields of wheat. Eelgrass (or dugong grass), ribbonweed, strapweed and paddle weed are common names for some seagrass species. Seagrass must have four properties to exist, that is, it must be adapted for life in a saline medium, be able to grow when completely submerged and have an anchoring system to withstand wave action and tidal currents. Seagrass also must have a capacity for pollination in water. Seagrass are pastures of the ocean, providing food, shelter as well as breeding and nursery areas for many marine organisms, including fish. They stabilise the sand and mud in which they grow. The sheltering canopy of seagrass leaves rising in the water and the net of roots penetrating into the sediments below, create a calm, stable and protected habitat for a wide assortment of marine life. The grass beds are especially important as nursery areas for young stages of fish, shrimp and crabs. In Australia, studies show that 90 per cent of all economically important fish and prawn species depend, for parts of their life cycle, on seagrass beds. A green leafy feast of rapidly growing seagrass awaits grazers such as manatees, dugongs (sea cows), sea urchins and green turtles. Most of the seagrass, however, becomes part of the food chain as detritus, or decaying matter. Microbes, shrimp, many fish and others feast upon the decaying seagrass. Seagrass help other organisms by recycling nutrients from the sediments into the water and by storing energy from the sunlight into organic matter through photosynthesis, thereby aiding to the growth of other marine life. Although South East Asia is one of the richest seagrass areas in the world, our seagrass meadows are threatened by water pollution, increased siltation and sediment run-off from the rivers and mainland, trawling, dredging and coastal reclamation. Because they are located within the shallow coastal zones, seagrass beds are directly affected by the way we treat the land and what we put into the sea. Ever-growing human population along the coastline increases development. If we don't manage our land more carefully, we will lose another treasure from nature - seagrass.

Standard Poor's recently downgraded the Philippine's credit rating for financial institutions for the first quarter of 1998 to ``negative'' from ``satisfactory''. Greenberg said the effect of Asia's currency crisis on the Philippines ``is moderate compared to other countries. PADESH, Albania (AP) _ Shock etched in their faces, ethnic Albanians fleeing the violence in Kosovo province gave weeping firsthand accounts Tuesday of a major Serb offensive against separatists that is fast turning into another all-out civil war in former Yugoslavia. Trekking over the mountains for up to two days, refugees joining the growing exodus to neighboring Albania described artillery bombardments that forced out entire villages, and house-torchings they said were clearly intended to drive them out. ``It's ethnic cleansing, and it's done the same way as in Bosnia,'' said Ukshin Maliqi, 35, comparing the situation in Kosovo with practices in neighboring Bosnia that appalled the world during that three-year war. ``They shell first so that we abandon our houses, then they burn them so that we cannot return,'' he said. The accounts provided some of the most detailed information yet about the scope of the stepped-up campaign launched in late May by Serb police and army forces, who are trying to crush the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army. The militants have been gaining in popularity and numbers lately after years of heavy-handed rule by Serbian authorities in the secessionist southern province, where ethnic Albanians comprise 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million. There have been no reports as there were in Bosnia of massive civilian roundups or massacres in the Kosovo conflict, which the Serbs insist targets guerrillas. But attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children among the casualties _ more than 200 people have been killed in the last three months _ have prompted increasing comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia and its atrocities. President Clinton told a visiting delegation of ethnic Albanians in Washington last week that, by their account, ``The United States shall not tolerate another Bosnia in Kosovo.'' But the West, which has failed in repeated attempts to get Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to stop the crackdown in Kosovo, has yet to devise a strategy for how to resolve the worsening conflict. A NATO official in Brussels, Belgium, who spoke on condition of anonymity said the alliance was ``preoccupied'' with Kosovo and would debate what to do at a NATO Council meeting Wednesday. ``There is a sense of urgency about this, but it's also important to base what we do on sound military analysis,'' the official said. ``You can't improvise military response, you can't throw troops at problems.'' Based on information from the refugees and ethnic Albanian officials in Kosovo, the latest campaign is focused on the western region of Decani, where the Serbs deployed thousands of additional paramilitary forces and are pulverizing 10 towns and villages with artillery. The town of Decani, with a population of about 20,000, was in ruins with no sign of life, according to the pro-Albanian Kosovo Information Center. Dead cattle littered the streets, it said. While the Kosovo Liberation Army controls as much as a third of the province, several refugees said they saw no sign of it in the sealed-off area under siege from Serb forces. ``When the shelling started we ran to the woods, waiting for it to stop,'' said Nise Mazrekaj, 27, from the targeted village of Slup. ``But then the Serbs set the houses on fire, so we couldn't go back.'' Her young three children were crying and hungry after an overnight mountain journey over goats' paths. Other refugees were stretched out on the grass asleep, exhausted from their trip. ``There's no way back, no,'' said her husband Sulejman, 39, distraught from the shelling a day earlier. The Serb attacks appear to have intensified over the weekend, judging by the stream of refugees that began Sunday morning to Albania.
