THE damning reality is that the high interest rate and tight liquidity are making it impossible for companies and individuals to borrow even for productive purposes. Even those who qualify may still be turned away by banks which have exceeded the loan growth target set by Bank Negara or do not have sufficient funds to lend. It is learnt that some very telling facts surfaced at a special meeting between Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad and senior bankers in Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday. Also present was the Economic Adviser to the Government and executive director of the National Economic Action Council Tun Daim Zainuddin. With the effective lending rate exceeding 15 per cent per annum, it is cheaper to borrow abroad in the US dollar despite the depreciation of the ringgit. One source said even at RM4 to US$1, the dollar lending rate works out to less than nine per cent. As for suppliers' credit, a well-established Malaysian company can still obtain it from foreign banks for as low as four per cent. Yet we hear stories of importers of capital goods being chided for not securing loans from local financial institutions whenever they go to Bank Negara to seek advice and assistance. With the domestic liquidity remaining tight and banks continuing to be cautious in offering new loans, partly in compliance with Bank Negara directives, companies have to look abroad for loans. Some examples have lately emerged to show that foreign banks can be a lot more supportive of appeals by Malaysian borrowers to reschedule their loans in order to avoid defaults and avert bankruptcies. While this may not be the best situation for the country, businesses are not presented with other viable choices. Understandably, they have to abide by the conditions of the foreign lenders. It is no longer uncommon for these lenders to require Malaysian borrowers to subject themselves to examination by foreign auditors before new and existing loans are disbursed. Lenders are also known to dictate terms, such as cost-cutting measures and limiting dividend payments. Even after swallowing their pride and losing their independence, not all Malaysian companies will get access to foreign funds. They may be either too small or too weak to qualify. If the private sector is to remain the engine of growth, its access to cheaper foreign capital has to be widened. One way of doing this is for the Government to borrow abroad and replenish the domestic banking system with reasonably priced funds. This is the most natural thing to do as the country has lost a considerable amount of reserves in defending the ringgit. This was aggravated by the outflow of private funds. Increasing the liquidity of the banking system is an addendum to the removal of the non-performing loans by the Asset Management Company. With the NPLs removed, the banks can start lending again. But some of them do not have sufficient money to do so. They need loans themselves. It is understood that economies such as Japan and Taiwan are keen to offer official loans to us. SAVING the financial system is important. Being praised by International Monetary Fund managing director Michel Camdessus and the foreign media may also be important to some of us. But what good is an inflated ego when the economy is in imminent danger of contracting, confidence diminishing and the survival of businesses getting more precarious by the day? Speaking at the 33rd annual meeting of the Malaysian Malay Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Kuala Lumpur on Wednesday, Daim warned that stagflation, a state of high inflation without a corresponding increase in demand and employment, was imminent if credit growth remained at a standstill. He said a gloomy and uncertain economic climate, fear of bankruptcies and stringent imposition of lending guidelines had caused banks to over-react. Daim said based on feedback from banks, it was unlikely that the 15 per cent credit growth for this year would be attained. If we do not want our economy to stall and tail-spin, we should act quickly to restore the confidence of businessmen, investors and consumers. As Dr Mahathir has often said, we are both producers and consumers. Take, for instance, an office worker. He is a producer who sells his services in exchange for money. But when he spends his money to buy other people's goods and services, he becomes a consumer. But his confidence is eroding. He is worried about being retrenched or having his salary reduced. In reaction, he is not spending as much as he used to. When he does not spend, others who depend on his expenditure will be deprived of their income. Less consumption leads to lower output. Lower output means lower economic growth or even no growth at all. Unemployment and other socio-economic problems will occur. This has happened to us before. In 1985, we suffered negative growth of one per cent. Yesterday, Bank Negara announced that our economy registered negative growth of 1.8 per cent for the first three months of this year. Therefore, maintaining consumers' confidence is important. Scaring consumers into not spending can only be the work of someone who does not know the workings of the economy. If we want to avoid a contraction in the economy, we must encourage consumers to spend, albeit wisely, of course. THE Japanese newspaper, Yomiuri Shimbun, on Wednesday accused Britain of ignoring the dark history of its colonial rule when it demanded that Emperor Akihito apologise for Japan's treatment of prisoners of war. ``There has been almost no mention of an apology by Britain for the darker episodes of its colonial rule,'' the newspaper said. It said Britain was the largest colonial power before World War II and was responsible for many barbarous acts, such as the 1840-42 Opium War. But it had hardly offered any apology to its former colonies. The newspaper noted that when Prince Charles attended the handover of Hong Kong to China on June 30 last year, he gave a self-congratulatory assessment of British rule of the territory. Yomiuri quoted British historian Dennis Judd as saying Britons were good at glorifying their own past, but failed to notice the hypocrisy of their views. It said the British Empire at its peak included colonies that were the sites of massacres and tragedies. When Prime Minister Tony Blair apologised for his predecessors' failure to help Irish victims of a devastating famine 150 years ago, he was criticised by the media and historians. They complained that the Government did not have to apologise for something that took place a long time ago. Coincidentally, just days before Yomiuri published the criticisms of Britain, The Times newspaper in London printed a report on Dutch statesman Hendrikus Colijn whose exploits in colonial Indonesia are being debated in the Netherlands. Headlined ``Hero status of bloody colonialist questioned'', The Times said the debate had been unleashed by the disclosure that Colijn, one of the country's most respected politicians, took part in war crimes in Bali. In a letter to his wife a century ago, Colijn wrote: ``I had to put nine women and three children, who were begging for mercy, on to a pile and have them shot. The soldiers took pleasure in sticking the bayonets into the natives.'' During the massacre in 1894, Colijn, then 25, lit up a cigar. He was leading a punitive expedition against a Bali prince who had objected to the Dutch opium trade. Local women and children defended their homes and were slaughtered. In all, the Dutch killed 2,000 Balinese. In 1904, Colijn was still writing with pride about his adventures. He wrote: ``It made no sense to go to war if one could not shoot women and children.'' After his colonial activities, Colijn, who is regarded as a founding father of modern Dutch politics, became Army Minister in the First World War. In the inter-war years, he was six times Prime Minister. After retiring from politics, he became chairman of Royal Dutch Shell. Now Dutch critics are arguing that his name should be removed from street signs and a full history written. He died on Sept 18, 1944. AT home, another chapter is being written in our history when former Selangor Menteri Besar Tan Sri Muhammad Muhammad Taib was on Friday found not guilty by an Australian court of charges of making a false declaration involving A$1.2 million cash. The verdict aside, there are several things said or which transpired during the trial to which we may want to give some thought as they affect our image in the eyes of the world. Muhammad may find paying cash in transactions running into millions of ringgit speedier than using telegraphic transfer, which he claims took weeks to clear. But for him to say it is normal for Malaysians to carry a lot of money when they travel abroad is not only incorrect but also damaging to our image. To begin with, there are not many Malaysians who can afford to lug around A$1.2 million in hard cash. In any case, hauling a briefcase weighing more than 19 kilogrammes, as Muhammad did when he was carrying his cash in Australia, may be too strenuous for the average person. He told the court he preferred to use cash after his purchase of an 11,000-acre farm in Queensland for A$3 million was delayed because it took several weeks to clear his telegraphic transfer. Perhaps, Muhammad was unlucky when it comes to using telegraphic transfers because I have yet to hear of such a delay unless there are irregularities. As for the testimony of an Australian language expert that Muhammad's command of English is poor, may I urge Education Minister Datuk Seri Najib Tun Razak to improve the teaching of the language in our schools, colleges and universities. The expert who conducted a test on Muhammad told the court that he failed by scoring 53 per cent when the passing mark was 60. He said Muhammad took 20 minutes to understand the currency declaration form. The moral of the story is that one can have a lot of money, but may still not understand national and international rules governing the conveyance of currency. Muhammad told the court he bought properties abroad ``to cushion the effect of recession in Malaysia in the 1970s and mid-1980s which taught Malaysians not to invest everything back home.'' He said the Malaysian Government encouraged the people to invest abroad although it wooed foreign investors. But to be fair to the Government, a qualification has to be made. True, it encourages Malaysians to invest abroad but only in productive projects so that they can bring home profits. I do not think the Government means to encourage Malaysians to buy private properties overseas. At the time of his arrest, Muhammad, who was a Menteri Besar and Umno vice-president, together with his wife, had not one but five properties in Australia. Now that Malaysia is facing economic problems, and the Government is urging the people to bring back their money, Muhammad may want to sell his overseas properties and bring home the much needed foreign exchange. Or isn't Malaysia safe enough?

JAKARTA (JP): Opposition figures held an unprecedented celebration of Pancasila Day here yesterday, a date never formally recognized during the Soeharto era as the birthday of the nation's ideology. Megawati Soekarnoputri, daughter of Indonesia's first president Sukarno, fervorishly challenged anyone who doubted that June 1 not Aug. 18, 1945, was the anniversary of Pancasila. ``There shouldn't be any doubt about Pancasila's birthday, as first president Sukarno said that it was June 1, 1945,'' Megawati said questioning the reasons behind such a deliberate neglect of historical fact. ``Was it because the declaration came from the mouth of Sukarno?'' she asked. There has been much debate about when exactly the state ideology was first coined and the marking of Pancasila's birthday has depended much on historical interpretation. According to history books, during a June 1, 1945, meeting of the committee to prepare Indonesia's independence, Sukarno delivered an hour-long speech containing the five principles of Pancasila. Then the night after the declaration of Indonesia's independence on Aug. 17, 1945, the committee which was preparing the 1945 Constitution adopted the five principles with several modifications to the wording and order. The final version was contained in the 1945 Constitution which was officially issued on Aug. 18, 1945. Judging by the prominent individuals and packed crowd at the Pancasila building on Jl. Pejambon, Central Jakarta, Megawati, the ousted leader of the Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI), was apparently not alone in her historical belief. Also present were former governor Ali Sadikin, former minister of foreign affairs Roeslan Abdulgani and chairman of the Indonesian Democratic Union Party Sri Bintang Pamungkas. Megawati maintained that any claims that the birthday fell on Aug. 18 was a misunderstanding of history. ``If I assume the June 1, 1945, as the birth of a baby, then Aug. 18, 1945, should be considered as the issuance of the baby's birth certificate,'' she said, adding that ``June 1, 1945, was Pancasila's birthday, while Aug. 18, 1945, was the declaration of Pancasila.'' ``But the most important thing now is whether people can implement the principles of Pancasila in their daily lives or not?'' Ali Sadikin said yesterday's celebration was part of the effort to revise history which he claimed had been engineered during Soeharto's rule. Dozens of Megawati supporters were seen outside the building carrying posters and banners expressing the same sentiment. ``Abolish Soeharto's version of history,'' one banner said. Meanwhile, Ruslan called on the people to be united in the reform struggle. ``Reform leaders should be cool-headed and understand the very goal of reform,'' Ruslan said in his written speech. He reminded people that the reform effort was far from finished, adding that resistance to true reform measures may come from elements of the former regime within the new government.

PAYA Jeras State Assemblyman Datuk Saidin Thamby will hold discussions this week with the Shah Alam Municipal Council over poor drainage causing flash floods in Phase 2 of the low cost project at Bandar Baru Sungai Buloh. He said the floods had become a major problem for residents. He said the developer should accept the responsibility for upgrading drains in the housing estate. Saidin added that existing drains could not cope with the volume of water from housing estates in the vicinity. ``After several housing projects were built, the drains cannot cope with the volume of water. Therefore, they overflow,'' he said. ``The developers should have upgraded the drainage system first before undertaking the housing projects. At the moment, all new housing projects are using the same drains to channel water to the river. ``The developer was supposed to submit the upgrading plan to MPSA for approval before starting on other housing projects but the company has not done so.'' He said this after launching the Bandar Baru Sungai Buloh Phase Two Low Cost Residents Association. He said he visited the area several times during the floods and noticed that water rose nearly a metre. He added that the residents had complained several times to MPSA but their effort seemed futile. Phase two has been occupied the past 10 years. Meanwhile, Saidin said, 1,200 residents were squatting on their property as the lease on it had expired. This was because the sale and purchase agreement stated that the lease on the land was for only 10 years while the lease for the house was 99 years. ``I do not know how this could have happened. Normally, the lease for the property is for 60 years or 99 years. I suppose they did not read the agreement before signing it. Anyway, I have forwarded 800 applications for extension of lease to the District Office. ``Some of the residents refused to apply as they are afraid of the premium they will have to pay.'' Saidin said he will negotiate with the District Office for a nominal fee.

Lopez-owned Bayan Telecommunication Inc. (BayanTel) has awarded to Northern Telecom (NorthTel) a $30-million contract covering the installation of a substantial number of telephone lines in several of the former's service areas in Metro Manila. Based on the agreement signed by the two parties, NorthTel will undertake the setting up of 60,000 landlines in Navotas and Manila as part of BayanTel's telephone expansion program. Last November, the National Telecommunications Commission (NTC) gave BayanTel a provisional authority to put up a total of 150,000 in Manila and Navotas as a reward for having completed its 300,000-telephone rollout obligation ahead of the required time period as prescribed under Republic Act (RA) 7925. RA 7925 requires international gateway facility operators and cellular mobile telephone service providers to install at least 300,000 and 400,000 lines, respectively, three years after receiving their local exchange authority. Under the service area scheme, Manila and Navotas belong to Eastern Telecommunications Phils. Inc. (ETPI). Since it still has until November 1999 to complete its own line requirement, ETPI filed a petition with the Court of Appeals (CA) to stop BayanTel's incursion in its service areas. The CA has since dismissed ETPI's petition, paving the way for the expansion of BayanTel's coverage. Under Executive Order 109, the service area scheme assigns each carrier, except Philippine Long Distance Telephone Co., a limited zone for their telephone rollout programs. BayanTel's original service areas were Quezon City in the National Capital Region and cities in the Bicol region. By the time it was granted a franchise to install phones in Manila and Navotas, it had already exceeded its own line obligation by 28,028 lines. --Mark V. Ledesma

Youth transit security teams deployed ahead of World Cup
PARIS (AP) _ Faced with stubborn youth violence as the World Cup approaches, the Paris transit authority has deployed a new and subtle weapon: more youths. Like Guardian Angels in the United States, the first of 350 youths in white and maroon jackets reading ``Mediation'' began patrolling subway trains this week with no other weapon than the power of persuasion. The youths are to advise commuters, report vandalism or other incidents and seek to calm aggressive youths with mediation techniques. The trained ``mediators'' are aimed at reducing urban violence that has triggered protest strikes by transit workers in many cities across France in recent months. Hired on a youth job program launched last year by the leftist government, the 350 ``mediators'' are to be deployed by the end of the year, French media reported. The nationwide program has already begun in other cities like Lille in the north. The program has had generally positive results, though some of the mediators in Lille were attacked by a gang in at least one incident. (cb)

JAKARTA (JP): The government is set to lower prices of various generic drugs by 10 percent this week in consideration of the public's declining purchasing power. H. Sampurno, the director general for the supervision of drugs and food, was quoted by Antara as saying yesterday that Minister of Health F.A. Moeloek had approved the plan. The reduction is the third phase of the government's campaign to make available medicines at affordable prices, he added. Drug prices soared shortly after the economic crisis hit Indonesia last July. The rupiah has plummeted in value against the U.S. dollar. The government initially reduced soaring prices of generic medicines by 34.35 percent in February. The second reduction, by 18 percent, occurred in April. In the same month, Moeloek -- speaking as health minister in the Cabinet of former president Soeharto -- promised to do anything within his means to ensure a steady supply of medicine, particularly generic drugs, for one year. He cited the government's allocation of a US$116 million subsidy to the country's pharmaceutical companies for the import of raw materials for drugs. The Japanese government has also extended a grant for medicines and medical supplies worth Rp 80 billion to ensure their availability in Indonesian hospitals, he added. Antara quoted Omar Hamid of the Front Action for Reform in Health Affairs as saying yesterday that the price reduction often did not apply in the market. ``In the first reduction, in reality the prices of generic drugs in the market only declined by 12 percent. In the second reduction, prices in the market went down by only 5 percent,'' he said. The health ministry has opened a hotline for complaints on food and drugs at (021) 426334 between 8 a.m. and 8 p.m.

JAKARTA (JP): Indonesian trade unions are calling on the International Labor Organization (ILO), which begins a three-week convention in Geneva today, to press the Indonesian government to adopt ILO conventions in order to ensure the protection of workers' rights. The call was made by all 13 trade unions grouped in the government-sanctioned Federation of All Indonesian Workers Union (FSPSI) and the Indonesian Prosperous Labor Union (SBSI). Ali Samioen, chairman of the tourism sector union, said the 13 sectoral trade unions recently sent a letter to ILO headquarters urging the organization to press the Indonesian delegation to commit Jakarta to signing ILO Conventions Nos. 87, 105, 111 and 138. ``We have also lobbied international trade unions to press the ILO meeting to issue a resolution on labor conditions in Indonesia. ``FSPSI will not participate in the Indonesian delegation to the meeting if the government is not committed to ratifying the ILO conventions,'' he said after a meeting of the 13 sectoral trade union leaders here yesterday. The Indonesian delegation, led by Minister of Manpower Fahmi Idris, was scheduled to leave for Geneva last night to attend the three-week ILO meeting. ILO Convention No. 87 covers issues pertaining to the freedom of union, No. 105 is on migrant workers, No. 111 on discrimination in employment and No. 138 on minimum wages. ``In line with globalization and reform, the government has no other choice but to ratify the ILO Conventions to help protect workers' rights and improve their social welfare,'' Samioen said. Recognition SBSI chairman Muchtar Pakpahan said his organization had also sent a petition to the ILO. ``We are optimistic that developed countries and international trade unions participating in the meeting will press the Indonesian delegation about the conventions,'' he said after officially registering SBSI at the Ministry of Manpower yesterday. During the reign of President Soeharto, FSPSI was the only recognized trade union across the country. The secretary-general of the manpower ministry, Suwarto, said yesterday that the government was ready to officially adopt ILO Convention No. 87 and would soon deliver it to the House of Representatives to be ratified. However the other conventions are still being considered. ``If the others are found to be effective in helping to protect workers' rights and improve their social welfare, the government, in the spirit of reform, will certainly consider adopting them,'' he said. Pakpahan expressed some satisfaction yesterday that the government had altered its adverse stance against SBSI. He welcomed the government's positive response to finally recognize SBSI as an independent labor union. He said he would continue his struggle to fight against the abuse of workers and campaign to strengthen workers' bargaining power. ``SBSI will be involved in the National Tripartite Board and the National Wage Committee to evaluate and set regional monthly minimum wages,'' said Pakpahan, who was released from jail only last week. SBSI, established in April 1992, was banned by the government in 1994 when it held its first congress in Cisarua, Bogor, West Java. Many of its activists, including Pakpahan, have been interrogated several times and even jailed for organizing industrial strikes and workers' rallies. Jamsostek About 300 workers from Greater Jakarta and Bandung, West Java, staged a demonstration at the Ministry of Manpower to protest alleged corruption in the state insurance company PT Jamsostek. The workers held a free-speech forum in front of the ministry building in South Jakarta, as they waited for more than three hours for Fahmi to return from a meeting. Setyono, coordinator of the Association for Action of Indonesian Workers (KABI), said that the Attorney-General's Office should conduct a thorough investigation into the alleged rampant corruption in the company, including the use of Rp 7.1 billion (US$620,000) to finance the deliberation of the controversial labor law. In late 1997 then minister of manpower Abdul Latief admitted that Rp 3.1 billion of Jamsostek funds were used to help finance the deliberation of the bill. But he later claimed that he had done it under the orders of then president Soeharto. Setyono led the chorus of dissatisfaction against the controversial bill and the misuse of funds. ``The money embezzled by the company's officials belongs to workers. We gave our money to be collected to improve workers' livelihoods, not to be embezzled,'' he charged. The demonstrators also demanded the government review the controversial law which they said neglected workers' rights. Setyono said that the law should be reviewed because it was the product of former president Soeharto's repressive government. The law is scheduled to come into effect on Oct. 1. After failing to meet the minister, the demonstrators were received by Suwarto who said the government was awaiting inputs from various sides, including law experts, the House and workers, before deciding to amend the law.

Kuerten disqualified in doubles for throwing racket at umpire AP Sports Writer
Eds: COMBINES takes; ADDS quotes, details, background By ROB GLOSTER
PARIS (AP) _ Gustavo Kuerten, who won the French Open singles title last year, was disqualified in doubles Tuesday when he threw his racket at umpire Bruno Rebeuh _ hitting a fan in the stands. Kuerten, who made a storybook run to the men's title last year as an unseeded player and became a fan favorite at Roland Garros, was knocked out in singles last week in the second round. He faces a fine because of Tuesday's outburst. Tournament referee Gilbert Ysern said he was unsure whether Kuerten could be suspended for the incident. ``Hopefully, we can give him (Kuerten) the benefit of the doubt and think that he didn't really aim at killing the chair umpire by throwing the racket at him,'' the referee said. Ysern said the fan hit by the racket apparently was not hurt. Witnesses said the fan was hit in the shoulder. ``He lost his mind a little bit,'' Ysern said. ``The chair umpire could have been hit, maybe hurt by the racket. It's obviously a serious situation. It's a serious case.'' Kuerten and Rebeuh were not available for comment Tuesday. The Philippine Stock Exchange (PSE) holds its general membership meeting today in an effort to finally put to rest the self regulatory organization (SRO) issue which has hounded the local bourse for over a year. PSE President Jose Luis Yulo expressed optimism that a majority ``yes'' vote on the changes in the Exchange by-laws can be reached. ``Majority will attend the meeting and we have the vote... the amendments have already been approved at the board level and this is simply for ratification,'' Yulo explained. He pointed out that with the imminent ``yes'' vote from the brokerages, the Exchange would have complied with all the requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). ``I believe we have complied with the requirements, but the SEC is still the one that will grant the SRO,'' Yulo said. Amendments to the rules will be implemented once the PSE gets a 51% nod of approval from its member-brokers. After which the local bourse takes the amendments to the SEC to meet the June 1 deadline imposed by SEC Chair Perfecto Yasay Jr. The SEC and PSE had reached a compromise wherein the Commission's compliance and surveillance department can operate independently, but with the Exchange's president still having the authority to suspend any investigation at any time as he may deem necessary. Should the PSE still fail to make the deadline on Monday, Yasay had promised to impose stiff sanctions against the PSE, including the threat to suspend the license of the Exchange to operate. An official at the PSE said that 140 brokers, or 75.68% of the total members of the Exchange, signified their intention to attend today's membership meeting. The figures could be deceiving as the official indicated that 46 brokerages, or 33% of those attending, will be represented by proxies. This leaves only 94 brokerages, or 50.81% of the total membership being represented by their nominees. Yulo said most of the nominees have taken a ``sabbatical leave'' and are out of the country. Voting will be done through the count of persons who will raise hands either for a ``yes'' or a ``no'' vote on the amendments. JAKARTA (JP): Emboldened by the success of student demonstrations for reform in major cities, fishermen, farmers and other groups are holding rallies to call attention to their own causes. Some villagers have accused the chief of embezzling the funds for youth activities. Fuad has denied the charge and blamed the demonstration on agitators. In Semarang, the capital of Central Java, about 100 students of the local Teachers Training Institute marched to the provincial legislative council to demand that the body does not renominate Governor Soewardi for the 1998/2003 period. In a meeting with several legislators, the students noisily demanded that the councilors state in writing that they would not renominate Soewardi, whose policies have been criticized as benefiting only a handful of people at the expense of the majority in the province. ``Soewardi does not deserve to lead the province, because all this time he has dismissed the aspirations of the people, especially that of Moslem scholars and intellectuals,'' one student said. In Ujungpandang, the capital of South Sulawesi, more than 800 students demanding the resignation of Governor Z.B. Palaguna faced off yesterday with 200 members of a youth group who support him. Soldiers and police quickly positioned themselves between the opposing groups. The demonstrators lined up about 10 paces apart and traded shouts and epithets on the grounds of the local legislature buildings. Yesterday was the fourth day the students occupied the buildings. They have vowed not to leave until Palaguna, whom they have accused of corruption and nepotism, steps down. The students carried banners calling for reform. Their opponents, members of the youth wing of Indonesia's largest Moslem organization, Nahdlatul Ulama, wore green T-shirts and held posters inscribed ``Reform Is Already Underway,'' according to Reuters. More than 100 students have also entered their fifth day of occupying the local legislature in the city of Jambi in central Sumatra, Antara reported yesterday. The students, from Sultan Thaha Saifuddin Institute for Islamic studies, have accused local officials of allowing gambling to flourish in the district, and claim they will not leave the premises until all slot machines are destroyed. In Medan, the capital of North Sumatra, hundreds of students, fishermen and farmers also used the momentum of the reform campaign to hold their own rallies. They visited the Medan legislative council, the North Sumatra provincial legislature, and the governor's office. Most of the protesters demanded an end to corruption, collusion and nepotism, but also added their own grievances to the list of social ills. For instance, the fishermen demanded that the government stop foreign trawlers operating in their waters as they threatened their livelihood. The same group also demanded that the Provincial Prosecutor's Office investigate alleged irregularities in the selling of land belonging to a state-owned plantation to Siti Hardijanti Rukmana, the eldest daughter of former president Soeharto. Leadership in this country tends to follow public opinion. It should be the other way around. Leadership that follows public opinion is reactive, it cannot set its own agenda. The result is the death of vision and all stagnation. Economists tell us, pre-occupation with demand (the equivalent of public opinion) also causes stultification, lack of excitement and progress in the economy. If Bill Gates was pre-occupied with demand, he would have invented a better typewriter, not the operating system which made possible the desktop, personal computer. Politicians in our country remain powerful because the government is still the biggest source of wealth and power. In mature economies, that source is the individual entrepreneur. As with banks which intermediate wealth, so politicians intermediate power. Both banks and politicians are powerful because they are the keepers of the gates, quite simply. Banks right now don't need entrepreneurs. They survive from consumer finance. Politicians don't need entrepreneurs either. Instead, entrepreneurs need them. This is why our markets are topsy-turvy. Interest rates remain high and the Bangko Sentral can't do anything because here, banks monopolize the sources of capital. In the more advanced countries, the equity and bond markets are excellent and often cheaper capital sources. Not just their corporations, but municipal governments (municipal bonds), the internal revenue (revenue anticipation notes), and even private hospitals (hospitals bonds) issue bonds. As a result, banks are forced to compete for the public's money with them, sweetening their loan deals with reduced interests. Despite the financial squeeze gripping many Asian countries, no serious calls for more State control of the economy are heard. This is a good sign. What we do need is more economic direction, not control. Control is no longer the magic button in the new global order, but strategic market engagement. But for us to have that, we must have a clear map of the future, to be provided only by an industrial policy which will foremost give us development and trade parameters. The new administration must do everything to have at alst a firm, industrial policy we're willing to implement. The new President has a tough mandate. The expectation of the poor for him to deliver will be too much. He must do it step-by-step, starting with peace and order. He must be tough and to some extent, unforgiving and repudiative of friendships which may clash with public interest. Oil refiners will need to raise petroleum product prices by as much as 44 centavos a liter on average to cover increases in the landed cost of crude and a weaker peso, a top oil company official said yesterday. The official, who asked not to be named said that the average cost of Dubai crude in May has gone up to $12.74 a barrel from the previous month's $12.23. The peso, which was an average of 38.40 to a dollar last month, has weakened by about a peso. These additional costs translates to an average 20-centavo per liter increase, the official said. He added that crude cost and the foreign exchange rate in April compared to March resulted in additional costs to the industry amounting to an average 24 centavos per liter price increase. ``All in all, that's 44 centavos a liter of additional cost that we have to recover. We are waiting for Petron to make the move,'' said the official. Petron Corp., which is 40% owned by Saudi Aramco, is the Philippines' largest refiner. Oil company officials said that with increasing competition, they could not readily raise prices for fear of losing market share. The country's two other refiners are Pilipinas Shell Petroleum Corp., a member of the Royal Dutch/Shell group of companies, and Caltex Phils. Inc., the local unit of the joint venture between Texaco Inc. and Chevron Corp. Prices of petroleum products in the Philippines are deregulated except for regular gasoline, kerosene and liquefied petroleum gasoline -- products largely used by the masses. Under an oil deregulation law passed in February, the oil firms will be able to freely set the prices of these three products only after five months from the law's enactment. The state-run Energy Regulatory Board (ERB) last raised prices of these three regulated products on May 18. The oil refiners kept prices of the deregulated products unchanged.

Cocaine found in John Tate's blood
KNOXVILLE, Tennessee (AP) _ Former WBA heavyweight champion John Tate was high on cocaine when he slammed his pickup truck into a utility pole in April and died, the Knox County medical examiner says. Tate, who fought drug problems and resorted to panhandling after his boxing career, ``had been using cocaine regularly in the last 24 hours of his life,'' Dr. Sandra Elkins said Monday. But she said that does not change her initial finding that Tate, 43, died from a stroke caused by a tumor at the base of his skull. She said Tate probably was dying as the truck hit the pole April 9. Two passengers had minor injuries. Elkins described the amount of cocaine in Tate's blood as ``just your average street high.'' However, she said she has seen deaths from less cocaine. Her autopsy report said the loss of blood flow from the stroke could have brought on the seizure that caused Tate to lose control of the truck. The report also said cocaine can trigger seizures. Tate's blood-alcohol level was 0.03 percent, well under the legal limit of 0.10 percent, Elkins said. Tate, a native of West Memphis, Arkansas, won a bronze medal at the 1976 Olympics and made his professional debut a year later. He won the heavyweight title in a 1979 decision over Gerrie Coetzee in Pretoria, South Africa, but lost it less than five months later when Mike Weaver knocked him out in the final minute of the 15th round in Knoxville. Tate returned to the ring three months later and was knocked out by Trevor Berbick in the ninth round in Montreal. A loss to Noel Quarless in London in 1988 sent Tate's career and his life into a tailspin. Tate admitted to a cocaine habit during a five-year period in the 1980s and served time in prison for convictions on petty theft and assault charges. His career record was 34-3 with 23 knockouts.

Sir: In light of all the recriminations and mudslinging that have characterized our recent presidential elections, I would like to point out that the next president of our country, Joseph ``Erap'' Estrada, is neither as dumb nor as unfit to govern as his detractors would like us to believe. On the contrary, the former action star-turned politician has many good, if not exceptional qualities: giving priority to education for the poor by building the first Municipal High School in San Juan; initiating build-operate-transfer schemes in San Juan long before the word became a catch phrase in government, say; or relocating squatters to municipal-sponsored housing, complete with job facilities. But what makes me particularly optimistic about Erap is one physical trait he shares with many great leaders: he's left-handed. That may not look much, but look at how many of America's most recent presidents are lefties: Gerald Ford, Ronald Reagan, George Bush, and now Bill Clinton, are all left-handed. Not only can Clinton steer the American economy while being busy with Monica Lewinsky; I'd bet he can do it even without using his hands. Reagan, of course, is a great influence on Erap. The Great Communicator out-maneuvered the Soviets and ended the Cold War. He ran a superpower with a few meaningful gestures: the right touch, the right words, the right actions. He left details to his more competent aides, a tip President Erap will be pursuing. Not only do lefties become successful presidents, they also tend to be organizational geniuses, like the great military leaders of the past: Alexander the Great, who conquered Persia at 24; Charlemagne, who unified the Franks and Saxons; Julius Caesar, who expanded Rome from a republic to an empire; Napoleon Bonaparte, who overran all of continental Europe; and Norman Schwarzkopf, the architect of Operation Desert Storm. All of these military leaders were lefties. Great monarchs also tend to be left-handed: Louis XIV was one; so was Ramses II, Tiberius, Queen Victoria, George II, and current British Queen Elizabeth II. All over the world, other left-handed leaders rose to prominence because of their willingness to face the odds, their courage to stand up, and their single-mindedness in completing their goals. Cuba's Fidel Castro kicked out a dictator, removed all the Mafia gangs that controlled its economy, and faced down America in an ideological confrontation that lasts until today. Israeli premier Benjamin Netanyahu unflinchingly faces wary supporters like the US, and detractors like the Palestinians, for believing that peace in Israel must not come at a great price to the Israelis. Great men and women rose to face their own destinies, some with great handicaps, helped perhaps by the magic of their handedness. Henry Ford went from part-time mechanic to the world's greatest car manufacturer. Helen Keller, despite being deaf, mute and blind, communicated a depth of feeling for literature, writing (literally in the dark) with her left hand. Joan of Arc, who saved the French monarchy, and was martyred on the stake, was left-handed also. Benjamin Franklin and Nelson Rockfeller are others American statesmen who were left-handed. People of great talent, wit, and irreverence are also lefties. Two of American television's most famous nighttime hosts, David Letterman and Jay Leno, are both lefties. Hollywood is full of great actors and actresses who are lefties: from Dan Akroyd to Carol Brunett, Charlie Chaplin to Robert de Niro; George Burns to Whoopie Goldberg; Rock Hudson to Tom Cruise; Marilyn Monroe to Robert Redford; Julia Roberts to Oprah Winfrey. Great comedians tend to be lefties, from Harpo Marx in the '30s, to Jerry Seinfield in the '90s. The Israeli performer Uri Geller is left-handed; and so is the 700 Club preacher and fundamentalist politician Pat Robertson. Great novelists and imaginative writers tend to be lefties, too. From Alice in Wonderland author Lewis Carroll, to Mark Twain, James Baldwin, Peter Benchley, and science fiction pioneer HG Wells. The world's greatest artists are all lefties: Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael, Albrecht Durer, Paul Klee, and Pablo Picasso. Many of the music world's greatest talents are also lefties: the Everly Brothers, Paul McCartney, Jimi Hendrix, Phil Collins, Chuck Mangione, Cole Porter, Paul Williams, Kurt Cobain, Judy Garland, Paul Simon, and Seal are among but a few. Then there are the great southpaw athletes: Pele; Mark Spitz; Oscar de la Joya; Dorothy Hamill; Marvin Hagler; Jim Connors, John McEnroe; Monica Seles; and Babe Ruth. Those I have named are just a few of the lefties who have excelled or become trail blazers in their respective fields. So you see? Our future President is in very good company. In fact, most of these lefties were at first dismissed as lightheaded and ``not-serious''. But being right-brained thinkers (hence prone to visualize mentally rather than use words), lefties grasp the point faster, and have more creative solutions compared to the textbook-approach of a right-handed person. Who knows? That's probably what this nation really needs right now. (Sgd.) ROMAN LINARO 672 Antipolo Street Sampaloc, Manila

Dr Mahathir said the big (Japanese) companies ``are still interested and still coming in'' to make investments in Malaysia but added that now ``a lot of big investments'' were coming from the United States in the areas of petrochemicals and chemicals. Dr Mahathir cited two American companies, Eastman and Proctor and Gamble, as among those making large-scale investments mainly in the east coast of Peninsular Malaysia. ``The trend now is different. JAKARTA (JP): The government has launched an investigation into corruption under former president Soeharto but has no plans to specifically target the former Indonesian leader, Attorney General Soedjono C. Soedjono said that although the probe did not specifically target the Soeharto family, the investigation would cover its business dealings. ``The former president may be summoned, if necessary, to verify and check evidence in cooperation with other state agencies,'' Deputy Attorney General Ismudjoko added. Ismudjoko said his office would not impose a travel ban on Soeharto or any of his family members, pointing out that his office had received guarantees they would not leave Indonesia. Ismudjoko said that while the investigation was very urgent, it would take some time to complete as the work would involve the checking of many documents related to a large number of business deals. ``What is most important is that we should always maintain national unity,'' Ismudjoko added. ``The investigations are being conducted under the principle of the presumption of innocence,'' Soedjono asserted. Critics and analysts have alleged that nepotism, corruption and crony capitalism lie at the root of the economic crisis the nation has faced for 10 months and have demanded that the businesses of the Soeharto family, cronies and other senior officials be investigated. Soeharto, who abruptly resigned from the presidency on May 21 under strong pressure from the House of Representatives, his cabinet ministers and demonstrating students, has been accused of amassing tens of billions of dollars from corruption, collusion and numerous shady business deals. Leading opposition figure Amien Rais called on Soeharto over the weekend to donate 95 percent of his wealth to the state in return for complete forgiveness from the people so that the government should not have to beg for aid from international agencies and institutions. The secretary-general of the National Commission on Human Rights, Baharuddin Lopa, said yesterday that Soeharto must be prosecuted if there is adequate evidence to prove his wrongdoing. Any corruption case should be handled in accordance with the law, no matter who is involved in the malfeasance, Lopa said. ``If he or she is proven guilty, all of the wealth obtained through corruption must be confiscated for the state,'' he added. Lopa said the ``solution'' offered by Amien was not educative, was against the law and could create the feeling of legal uncertainty. President B.J. Habibie could give Soeharto amnesty, but this could only be granted after Soeharto's accountability is completed, according to Lopa. Lopa is also a member of Gempita, the Movement of Concerned Citizens on State Assets, which was established last week to collect data on ill-gotten wealth and assets. Rp 200 trillion The Indonesian Business Data Center (PDBI) announced yesterday it estimated the wealth of former president Soeharto, his family and its close associates at Rp 200 trillion (US$17.5 billion). Executive director Christianto Wibisono told reporters yesterday the amount included the assets of Soeharto's foundations under the Nusamba group, a diversified group managed by Soeharto's closest crony Mohamad ``Bob'' Hasan. ``What I mean by cronies here are those who are clearly close to him such as Salim (Salim Group's founder and chairman Lim Sioe Liong) and Bob Hasan,'' Christianto said. PDBI's study values several major businesses, in which Soeharto's six children and foundations are involved, at Rp 16.9 trillion, with equity totaling Rp 5.32 trillion. Christianto said most of the wealth had been accumulated through business deals full of collusion, corruption and nepotism such as monopolies, rent-seeking practices and oligopolies. KUALA LUMPUR, Mon. - The Government may have to revise its strategy to stimulate the economy and come up with additional measures if the situation worsens, Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Datuk Seri Anwar Ibrahim said today. As the Gross Domestic Product for the first quarter slipped to minus 1.8 per cent from 6.9 per cent in the previous quarter ended December, Anwar said: ``We are looking closely at the situation and may have to revise some of the strategies.'' ``If it becomes critical, we will have to come up with some new measures,'' he said after opening the two-day 3rd Asia Oil Gas Conference here. However, he stressed that additional economic measures might not be necessary yet and ``... there is no need to revise just yet the projected economic growth of between two and three per cent.'' ``We should also analyse the GDP figures for the first quarter closely and see the trend that is developing. There was a slowdown in the first two months of this year possibly due to shock and over-reaction to the currency situation. ``The worst is over, reflected in January and February. The next month (March) was more positive,'' he said, adding that the trend had to be studied over the next few months. ``I have always said this before: the real solution is to ensure there is easing of credit to ensure liquidity and everything else will follow naturally.'' He also said banks would have to abide by prudent commercial guidelines when lending. Earlier, in his speech, Anwar said: ``The economic, political and social changes seen throughout the region in the last 12 months have made it patently clear that business as usual is impossible. ``The people of the region will no longer tolerate the old ways. They reject corruption, cronyism and nepotism. They demand greater accountability, transparency and a real say in the decision-making process.'' As such, Anwar said the region's people needed to take a close and hard look at themselves and identify their strengths and weaknesses. ``Courage is required, because we may have to inflict further pain on ourselves before we can emerge as new and vibrant economic entities.'' When asked about the statement made by Prime Minister Datuk Seri Dr Mahathir Mohamad on interest rates last Saturday, Anwar said Dr Mahathir was merely expressing the general consensus of the business community which felt that interest rates were very high at present.

JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel's legislature voted Tuesday to dismantle the makeshift shrine that has sprung up at the grave of an Israeli gunman who massacred 29 Muslim worshipers. In the attack four years ago in the West Bank town of Hebron, Brooklyn-born Baruch Goldstein opened fire with an automatic rifle on Muslim worshippers kneeling in prayer in the Tomb of the Patriarchs, a site sacred to Muslims as well as Jews. The makeshift shrine that has sprung up around Goldstein's well-tended grave in the Jewish settlement of Kiryat Arba, just outside Hebron, has become a point of pilgrimage for Jewish extremists. ``What we have today is a memorial and not just a grave,'' said Ran Cohen, the opposition lawmaker who introduced the bill to take down the shrine. Objects to be removed include a cabinet containing a Torah, a case of religious books, and benches and lamps. The grave itself will not be moved. Cohen said that if the grave continues to be a focus of pilgrimage, he will introduce a new bill calling for the removal of the grave itself. dk-hla

Self-described underdog reaches French Open semis
By MARILYN AUGUST Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ She's a self-described underdog, and perhaps the most overlooked semifinalist at the French Open. That's fine with second-seeded Lindsay Davenport, who says she's just an ordinary girl playing tennis. With all eyes trained on Tuesday's much-hyped Venus Williams-Martina Hingis contest, Davenport slipped virtually unnoticed into the semifinals by defeating the defending champion, Iva Majoli of Croatia, 6-1, 5-7, 6-3. ``It's really unbelievable. You know I never would imagine I'd be in the semifinals here,'' she said. ``The focus was really on that (other) match today, and definitely, that helped me playing in my match.'' Davenport, who turns 22 next Monday, said she goes into her semifinal contest against Arantxa Sanchez-Vicario _ Davenport's third consecutive Grand Slam semifinal _ as the underdog. ``If I was a betting person or a journalist, I would overlook myself also. Coming into the French Open, not doing well in Berlin, I didn't have a lot of confidence,'' she said. But Davenport's victories over Majoli, France's Sandrine Testud, Russia's Elena Likhovtseta and South African Liezel Horn were no accident. The 6-ft., 2 1/2 in. Californian arrived in Paris a week before the tournament began to train hard on the soft, slow clay. ``It's probably the first time I've really spent seven days on clay, really trying to get used to it, and that really, really helped me,'' Davenport said. The win also erased the nightmare of last year's quarterfinal debacle: choking after being up a set and leading 4-0 in the second to let Majoli back into the match. ``I felt like I really tensed up so much and probably choked,'' she said. ``That's the worst thing that ever happened to me.'' Davenport, whose best career wins have come on the fast surfaces of the U.S. Open and Sydney, said the French Open was never much a part of her memory bank. She grew up with visions of Chris Evert's last match against Monica Seles at the U.S. Open, and Gabriella Sabatini losing to Steffi Graf 8-6 in the third set of a Wimbledon final. Davenport will test her newfound clay-court expertise against Sanchez Vicario, the two-time French Open champion, who also has escaped the media glare this year. The two haven't met on clay since 1994 when Sanchez Vicario won. ``I'm a little faster since the last time I played her on clay,'' Davenport said. ``Hopefully, I'm a bit more consistent, a little smarter and can wait for the right shot to really go for it.'' Davenport, who's been on the pro tour for six years, said she feels old to be playing women's tennis at almost 22, and said there's nothing specatacular about her personality. ``I don't have a tag,'' she said. ``Maybe that's why I'm overlooked. I'm just an ordinary girl playing tennis and being successful, pretty quiet and modest. That's a boring story.'' (ma/rg)

An employee was suspected of stealing something valuable from my company. He denied stealing it but later sent in his resignation. His manager wants to accept his resignation. His reason is that the matter is solved. So it is useless to take action against the employee. He also thinks that we cannot take any action because the employee has resigned. I do not agree with his manager. I feel we can still discipline him although he has already resigned. Stealing is a serious offence. This is the reason why I think we should not let him resign. I am also worried what effect it will have on the rest of the employees if we let this one escape so easily. What do you think?CKH, Klang. Answer: Your colleague is being practical by taking the obvious way out to solve the problem. The employee has resigned. Just accept it and that's the end of the matter. Very practical, as I said earlier. Very neat. True, the problem is solved at least, where this employee is concerned. But what about the effect on the rest of the employees, as you have rightly asked. In other words, what message is the company sending to its remaining employees? Clearly, the message is that you can commit an offence, including one as serious as theft, and get away with it by just resigning before action is taken against you. Management must be careful of the consequences of its actions. It has to ask itself what standard of integrity does it want to set for its employees. Without doubt, it cannot but be the highest possible. There should be no compromise where integrity is concerned. Failure to act appropriately against a dishonest employee will only encourage others to do so. Years ago, a leading entrepreneur in our country was asked which quality did he value the most in his managers. Without hesitation, he singled out honesty. When asked why, he replied that you can train a manager to help him acquire the skills that he needs to perform well in his job but you cannot teach him to be honest. To be kind we sometimes need to be harsh. We will only encourage a dishonest employee to continue being dishonest by failing to discipline him. The saying ``Spare the rod and spoil the child'' applies in the place of work as well. You are right in pointing out that you can still discipline an employee after he has resigned. In normal circumstances, an employer cannot refuse to accept his employee's resignation. However, if he has a good reason not to do so, as in your colleague's case, he can refuse to allow the employee to resign and take disciplinary action. There is always a tendency to take the easy way out of a difficult situation. Some call this expediency. Why go through the hassle of conducting an inquiry and face the prospect of having to defend your actions in a court of law eventually? We must remember that it may ultimately cost an employer more when he fails to do what he needs to, in the first instance. Dishonesty among employees is likely to increase. In the end, the employer will face more problems. Less haste, as they say, often gathers more speed. Not only is this the best way of protecting the company's interests, it will also send a loud and clear message that the company does not condone dishonesty and will not hesitate to discipline its errant employees. If you cannot convince your colleague on the right course of action to take in this case, let someone in the company who is more senior than both of you decide but stick to your stand. Question 2: What is the role of the human resources department in a company? My boss tells me that the department is like the police. Its responsibility is to ensure a high standard of discipline in the company. In my company, managers refer everything to my department. The managers say it is the job of human resources department to discipline their staff. Their job is to run their departments. The branch managers also have the same opinion. They think their job is to bring in sales only. I have tried to get them to see that staff discipline is part of their responsibilities but to no avail. I am very discouraged because my boss agrees with them. When I discussed this problem with him, he told me that human resources is the `policeman' in the company. He said that if managers have to look after staff discipline, they will have no time to do business. He also said that the company will not need a human resources department if discipline is delegated to managers. I am confused. Please explain. Marcy, Seremban. Answer: Take heart. I am sure that you are not the only human resources manager with this problem. It is a common weakness of managers to leave unpleasant tasks to someone else to handle. However, when there is limelight to be grabbed, you can be sure that they will not want to share it with you. Human resources is a staff function. It exists to support line managers. Line managers are people in the forefront - if you like, the battlefield. Can you imagine how ridiculous it is for field commanders during war to ask staff officers in the headquarters to do the fighting for them? The field commanders are the right persons to carry out this job. The soldiers report to them and they know the situation better than anyone. One of the reasons for the quick and decisive victory of the Allies during the Gulf War in 1991 was said to be the powers delegated to the military commanders in the field to make vital decisions. Previously, these decisions were made in the White House away from the theatre of war. Another good analogy to use is the family. When a child has done something wrong, it is his parents, either the father or the mother, who should discipline him. How effective do you think the discipline is going to be if someone else e.g. an uncle, is asked to take the parent's place? We know that this is only common sense. Unfortunately, common sense often does not appear to be common among people in high positions. It is unfortunate that your boss - I suppose he is someone very senior and influential in the company - does not agree with you. It must be very discouraging to be in your position. Many bosses unfortunately still have very outdated views of the role of human resources. The managing director of one very large company once directed his human resources manager to report half an hour early for work every day so that he can walk around the office to find out who comes late to work and to admonish those who are not at their desks on the dot. It is obvious that he had not the foggiest idea of the correct role of human resources. One could describe him as a ``corporate dinosaur'' who had never awakened from his long, deep stupor. One of the reasons why managers avoid handling difficult staff is because they do not know what to do. So they conveniently push problems to the human resources manager. If this is your case, training is the answer. Managers must be trained to work with their staff - to be effective motivators and leaders. If a manager is successful at doing this, morale will be high. Consequently, he will have little or even no disciplinary problem at all. Management, in the final analysis, is about people - not money, processes or materials. This explains why managers must not only be technically sound, they must also be carefully prepared and trained for the ``people'' aspect of their jobs. They become an ``Instant Manager'' when they are not. Instant managers, in the end, cause immense problems not only for themselves but for their employers too. SEPTEMBER 1958: At noon Inspector Niuh came by with Mohd Alias, one of our Form One boys, saying that he had been picked up along with some Sulaiman School boys for disturbances at the quarters near the hospital where they stay. It seems yesterday Alias approached a Sikh woman in a vulgar way, and she reported it to her husband who, in turn, reported it to the police. Also, the boys had been seen climbing a tree to watch the women take their baths. He denied this, too, but there were strong indications that it might be so. Niuh left Alias with me, and we had a long talk - so long that I was late to my typing class. I asked him if he would like to live here, and he said he would but he couldn't afford the fees. We're going to make room, I informed the boys tonight, and Alias will be moving in on Saturday. Today's paper had a story about a shipload of several hundred people being banished to China. It seems that they were shouting ``Long live the Malayan Communist Party'' as they left. I can't believe that Mr Luke Tan, who was among them, was doing any shouting of that sort. I felt very bad about his banishment, but the Government is stern and doesn't make exceptions. I didn't sign the last petition in his behalf; there was a phrase in it to the effect that he had no relatives, friends, or land in China. I couldn't sign that - because I simply didn't know about his China connections. There was a meeting at the district office this afternoon to plan the collection for the Lady Templer Tuberculosis Fund, and I found myself in charge of the poster competition for school children. Heng Thoong is still a very sick boy. We sent his food to him today, and most of the boys found time to drop by the hospital to visit him. We had a long staff meeting after school to go through the report of last year's school inspection and to discuss the new agreement that all teachers will have to sign next year. Mr Surendranath wanted a clear explanation about each point in the agreement. He was particularly concerned about the one which states that a teacher can be dismissed if his work and conduct are not suitable. When he kept harping on it, I finally told him that if he wanted to resign but couldn't afford the two months' pay that would have to be forfeited, all he had to do was misbehave. ``And for you,'' I told him, ``that shouldn't be too difficult.'' The things I come out with sometimes! At least everyone enjoyed that one. The matter of cleaning the latrines came up again this morning when Razak, who was on that duty, reported that they were absolutely filthy. The buckets are emptied every morning but with some 40 people using them every day, no wonder they overflow. I went around to the back, discovered the mess, and proceeded to help Razak myself, with the aid of Tat Pin and Shek Phooi, who carried water for us. We got them clean, then had a house meeting during which I announced that they were clean and had better stay that way. I think everyone got the message. On my way to school, Ismail bin Jamil stopped me to say that some of his friends might have some trouble with the hostel boys. (By ``friends'' I think he meant gang). I asked him what was wrong, and he said that during the Merdeka celebrations one of the hostel boys threw a rock at Jamaluddin, and it made him angry. During our house meeting tonight, I brought it up, and Razak said that the fact was that someone had thrown a rock at him - probably Jamaluddin trying to start a fight. I warned them about getting involved in gang fights and told them never to carry a knife or anything that might be considered a weapon. Mohd Alias moved in today, and our number now stands at 37. (To think that in the beginning we said 24 would be the absolute limit!) Tonight I treated all the boys to a trip to the Globe to see The Brave One, a delightful story about a little Mexican boy and his pet bull. When we got home, Say Kuang and Murad left us in stitches with their demonstration of a bull fight with Say Kuang as the bull. The students were asked to write down their teachers' pet phrases -to be used in the school magazine. They had several quotes from me: ``Nonsense!'', ``What in the world?'', ``Sometimes I feel like jumping off a high building!'' and of course ``Yakkety yak yak.'' But the funniest, I thought, were from Mr Wong Yoon Chong: ``My my'' and ``Well well.'' Surendranath was on the sick list, so I'm taking over Oliver Twist in Form Four. The students were quite amazed at the speed with which we were covering the book; they were used to more of a snail's pace. I simply didn't feel any need to study Dickens line by line. Mr V. Rasiah from the education department dropped in this morning for a look around the school. He had a reputation for tearing private schools apart, but he was very nice with us. These inspectors have a knack for coming the day before a holiday, and when teachers are sick. Only a dozen boys were left for dinner tonight, the others having gone home for the long weekend to celebrate the prophet's birthday. Alamshah, Tat Pin, and Kamaruzaman (and I) got into some mischief tonight when the other boys were out. We rigged up a `hanged man', using my black Chinese outfit and a deflated football for a head. We strung him up just inside the bedroom, then removed all the light bulbs except one. It was a riot listening to the screams of the boys returning from town when they opened the bedroom door and walked straight into the hanging figure. They were already in a scary mood after seeing Curse of Frankenstein at the Globe, and poor Munzir nearly passed out. Almost all the boys went for hockey practise at 7.30 this morning. I went to school and when I got home at noon, I found that they had doubled up and got the housework done. I was proud of them. The Malay boys all went to the Mosque, and they took with them $25 as the hostel boys' donation for the new Mosque. (They took up a collection among themselves, but it came to only $9.90, so I rounded it out to a slightly better figure). They said that the imam announced the donation during the service, and they were as proud as they could be. A long, interesting letter came from Shamsuddin Salleh. He brought up the matter of the colour problem and pointed out that two British people on his ship when he was returning to Malaya had remarked that Britain had never had and would never have a colour problem - a matter for debate now since the recent riots. Then he went on to declare: ``I had been asked on several occasions whether the Americans treated me as an equal when I was in the United States. Certainly my answer was `Yes'. ``Also they welcomed me everywhere and they took me right into their family circles. The Americans not only have big skyscrapers, big two-toned cars, but also big hearts and are generous, loving and understanding. ``I told them that never had I been treated so nicely - not even by my own people.'' Yeng Kee phoned this morning to say that Foong Chaw's mother had died. I asked him to buy some cloth and send it for me. We were late getting to the house, and the procession had already started. We joined in, walking as far as the hospital. I have always argued that I should not be away from the hostel at night for fear that something might happen to one of the boys. Kjell and Margie invited me to Raub for dinner tonight, and I gave them that excuse, but their ``Just once'' finally won out. I consented to go when they said they'd send Tek down with the van to fetch me and bring me home. Tek got here at seven and we started out - with Chow Yin and Shek Phooi going along for the ride and to see their families in Raub. When I got to Kjell's, Margie told me that the boys wanted me to phone the hostel immediately. It really was no surprise, because just before I left, Munzir asked for Kjell's phone number, and all the way over I felt that something was wrong. Bakar said that Yit Song had taken sick very suddenly and was coughing blood. They had sent for an ambulance and were sending him to the hospital; they had already notified his sister in Raub. I asked him to phone back as soon as they found out how serious it was. I tried to settle down to a pleasant evening and the company was certainly a pleasant lot - Mr and Mrs Lodge from Cheroh Estate, Mr and Mrs Warrington from the Gold Mine, the Thurleys from Mahmud School, and Mr and Mrs Paul Raj. Then the phone rang again, and Munzir, talking from the hospital, said that Yit Song was in quite a serious condition and had lost over a pint of blood. Beserah, the nurse on duty, came on the line and said that a transfusion would probably be necessary. With that, I got ready to come home. Kjell found Tek, we rounded up Chow Yin and Shek Phooi, and we reached the hospital at about 10.30. Munzir was still there, talking with Yit Song's sister and brother-in-law, who had just arrived. Yit Song was resting quietly, so we didn't bother him. Then came a shocking revelation: the sister ``confessed'' that Yit Song had been a TB patient before and had had an examination as recently as the last school holidays. Dr Poopalasingam, who arrived at about 11 said that he'll see how serious the case is before advising me on what to do about the other hostel boys. I'm very provoked with the family for not telling me about his condition when they sent him to live in the hostel. The other boys were all asleep when we finally got home. I'm not sure how much sleep I'll get tonight, though. The phone is by my bed, and Choong Foong has instructions to call immediately if Yit Song should need blood.

Banks were actively selling Treasury bills in the secondary market yesterday due to a supply glut after the Bureau of Treasury sold securities over the counter for two weeks in a row, traders said. ``Most banks are offering bills. We saw some rates went up a bit, about 10 to 15 basis points above the auction rates,'' one commercial bank trader said. One bank was seen offering three-month bills at 13.90%, from 13.885% posted in Monday's auction, while another bank was selling six-month bills at 14.70%, against 14.5%. ``There's so much supply in the system already,'' another trader said. Aside from the weekly auction, the Bureau of Treasury was offering bills through its tap facility. She said the additional liquidity coming from the reserve cut this Friday would not translate into lower interest rates. ``If the Bureau of Treasury will continue to open its tap facility, bankers will not bid too aggressively in the auction. We can have the tap option,'' she added. A Treasury official, however, said the over-the-counter bills, which carry the lowest accepted rate in the auction, were not sold out. The agency decides on whether to open the tap facility after every auction. Yesterday morning, the bureau said it would cut its weekly offering to P6 billion pesos from P6.5 billion. An official said the reduction was part of its borrowing program for the month. The 91-day bill offering would be reduced to P2 billion from P2.5 billion. Other tenors would be kept at P2 billion each. Meanwhile, the overnight call loan rate slipped further to 13.34375% from Wednesday's 13.4375%.

KUALA LUMPUR, Sat. - The Malaysian Medical Association today commended the Health Ministry's move to test Viagra, reputedly the world's first oral drug for impotence, for possible side-effects. In a Press statement, MMA president Dr Lee Yan San said the association agreed with the Ministry's move to test Viagra to ensure it was free from harmful short-term and long-term side-effects before being approved for public use. ``We feel that if this drug becomes available, it should only be available by prescription and should never be sold over the counter to avoid public abuse.'' Some of the side-effects of Viagra, reputed to be the first oral drug to treat erectile dysfunctions include headaches, a flushed face and `blue vision' purportedly caused by overuse. Dr Lee said in prescribing the drug, doctors will take into consideration the medical history and health of the patient. ``The doctor must be satisfied that the patient has erectile dysfunction (impotency) and that Viagra is beneficial. The doctor must be convinced that pharmacological treatment is appropriate and will consider other risks to the patient.'' He added that doctors would also have to monitor the frequency with which Viagra is used to ensure there would not be any abuse.

THEY were young Malaysian women seeking greener pastures in Taiwan. Many of them were tricked by their boyfriends into believing that they could get decent, well-paying jobs. But a day or two after they arrived, their ``boyfriends'' sold them off to syndicates which forced them into prostitution. To make things worse, they were later arrested during police raids for not having valid travel documents (their passports had been taken away by the syndicates). It was during her visit to Taiwan in 1995 to attend an international migrant workers' conference that Aegile Fernandez, coordinator of Tenaganita's migrant workers programme, found these 25 women - at a detention centre. Last year, Tenaganita rescued eight south Indian women in Kuala Lumpur following a tip-off. Aged between 16 and 25, the village women had married elderly Indian men from Malaysia. They were later brought to Kuala Lumpur, sold to syndicates and forced into sex work. These were among 71 trafficked women Tenaganita has helped to return to their home countries since 1994, when this non-governmental organisation started handling such cases. The cases also highlight the fact that not only is Malaysia a sending country, it is also a transit and a receiving country for such operations. ``Trafficking patterns indicate that traffickers and agents are cooperating on an international level, and that established networks have developed. Traffickers, agents and employers in countries of origin, countries of destination, and transit countries are working together to recruit, transport and exploit women seeking to migrate,'' states the Practical Guide to Assisting Trafficked Women, a handbook prepared by the Global Alliance Against Traffic in Women (GAATW). Traffickers recognise conditions which allow them to convince women to migrate. Where economic hardship, political unrest, militarism or high unemployment are present, traffickers and their agents are sure to be found. The guidebook was among the materials used in a recent four-day workshop on trafficking in women and children held in Kuala Lumpur. The event was organised by Tenaganita and GAATW, a Bangkok-based international network of 150 organisations and individuals working against this form of modern slavery. In the process of globalisation, trafficking in women and children has taken new forms to include not only trafficking for the purpose of forced prostitution but also for forced labour in sectors like domestic services and services related to the sex industry. As the workshop was meant for service providers, the 20 participants - many of them lawyers and social workers - used case studies to discuss ways to assist trafficked women and children, while broadening their concept of the issue. Representing the MCA complaints bureau, Datuk Dr Ng Yen Yen said that the bureau has 63 recorded cases of missing girls and women since 1994 when it started proper documentation of each case. However, over the last 10 years, the bureau has handled an estimated 1,000 cases. ``Of the 63 recorded cases, only 25 returned home. While eight girls ran away with their boyfriends, 17 ran away with men whom they had just met. There was this 16-year-old who disappeared, then phoned her grandmother to say she was all right before the line went dead. Her grandmother said the girl was on the verge of tears,'' said Dr Ng. Prevention is what the bureau advocates. ``We conduct many seminars on parenting skills targeted at vulnerable groups in new villages and towns. We hold forums in schools on growing up and making choices and decisions to create awareness among students and teachers as well. The media also plays a big role in raising public awareness of this issue,'' added Dr Ng, who is the chairperson of the MCA committee on missing children. The secretary-general of Wanita MCA champions women's rights and is vice-chairman of the National Council of Women's Organisations. In discussing legal intervention and human rights, M. Puravalen, a well- known criminal and human rights lawyer, said that the hypocritical nature of public morality and patriarchal perceptions continue to perpetuate the bias that cast trafficked women as criminals rather than as victims of crime. He pointed out shortcomings in the enforcement of existing legislation. ``Prosecution is lopsided as it is mainly directed at supply (sex workers) and not at demand (traffickers and customers). In illegal gambling and drugs, both supply and demand are attacked,'' said Puravalen. He claimed that the high profit margins and large number of beneficiaries (including the hotel, transport and tourism sectors, besides individuals in enforcement agencies) are the main reasons why sex workers are harassed and charged for soliciting while customers/procurers are let off lightly. ``The denial of the existence of a sex industry and the lack of political will in prosecuting traffickers, procurers, brothel-owners and pimps will further victimise the woman who has been trafficked. She therefore continues to live in a state of increased violence and work under slavery- like conditions. She seems to continue to bear the brunt of a patriarchal society.'' Puravalen suggested several ways to combat trafficking in women. A minimum of five years jail plus whipping should be imposed on the offender while trafficking, even with the consent of the woman, should be made an offence. Stricter enforcement of the law where brothels are closed, movable property confiscated, high fines imposed and ill-gotten gains forfeited should be implemented. Besides legal reform, there should also be increased public awareness of the issue, said Tenaganita's director Irene Fernandez. Services to help trafficked women and children, such as medical aid, shelter, legal services and counselling, should be improved and increased.
