Healed Del Piero included in Italy's list of 22

GOTEBORG, Sweden (AP) _ Alessandro Del Piero, healed from a potentially season-ending right thigh strain, was included in Italy's final list of 22 players for the World Cup announced Tuesday. Del Piero's inclusion meant the automatic exclusion of Parma's striker Enrico Chiesa, who was a possible substitute for the 23-year-old star of Juventus. Del Piero, who was injured during the Champions Cup final against Real Madrid, will resume full-time training with the teammates later this week. Del Piero is considered a key to Italy's fortunes in the World Cup. ``Indications of the team doctors (about Del Piero's recovery) are positive,'' coach Cesare Maldini told Italian television after a match in Sweden Tuesday night. The list also included Fiorentina's keeper Francesco Toldo, a last-minute substitute for injured No.1 goalie Angelo Peruzzi. Peruzzi, of league champion Juventus, pulled a muscle in training at Coverciano Sunday. Inter Milan keeper GianLuca Pagliuca is expected to be on Italy's starting lineup in France with Parma's Gianluigi Buffon and Toldo as substitutes. Del Piero, who traveled to Goteborg with the Italian team but did not even sat on the substitutues bench for the warmup game against Sweden, was declared fit by team doctors after careful examinations over the weekend. Italy's official World Cup roster (clubs in parentheses): Goalkeepers: Gianluca Pagliuca (Inter Milan); Gianluigi Buffon (Parma); Francesco Toldo (Fiorentina). Defenders: Giuseppe Bergomi (Inter Milan); Fabio Cannavaro (Parma); Alessandro Costacurta and Paolo Maldini (AC Milan); Alessandro Nesta (Lazio); Gianluca Pessotto and Moreno Torricelli (Juventus). Midfielders: Demetrio Albertini (AC Milan); Dino Baggio (Parma); Sandro Cois (Fiorentina); Luigi Di Livio (Roma); Roberto Di Matteo (Chelsea); Angelo Di Livio (Juventus); Francesco Moriero (Inter Milan). Forwards: Roberto Baggio (Bologna); Filippo Inzaghi and Alessandro Del Piero (Juventus); Fabrizio Ravanelli (Olympique Marseille); Christian Vieri (Atletico Madrid). Italy will play its first World Cup match against Chile at Bordeaux on June 11. (pv)

ALOR STAR, Sat. - Menteri Besar Tan Sri Sanusi Junid today took to task those who had criticised the State Government's decision to close entertainment centres on Thursday nights. He was disappointed with the attitude of the operators who appeared more interested in profits than helping to curb social ills. ``It is sad to hear comments about the move encouraging people to visit Haadyai. ``If we are only interested in stopping people from visiting Haadyai, then we might as well turn Alor Star into Haadyai,'' he said when launching an anti-vice campaign. The campaign, to be carried out by Rukun Tetangga, was organised by the National Unity Department and Menteri Besar's media and communication office. Sanusi said the move was to discipline operators who had blatantly disregarded rules prohibiting minors from entering entertainment centres. ``The State Government is not against entertainment. But it is not fair to society to have operators who merely think of profits and not the eradication of social ills,'' he said.

JAKARTA (JP): A forensic doctor said yesterday she was prepared to put her job on the line in differing from official police reports on the death of a Bogor Police officer last month. Police said a student mob stoned Second Lt. Dadang Rusmana, 43, during a break in a demonstration at Juanda University on May 9 and that he subsequently died of a head injury. But Yuli Budiningsih Tjatur of the Indonesian Red Cross (PMI) Bogor Hospital, who conducted an autopsy on Dadang's body on the day of his death, concluded he died of a heart attack. She said yesterday she did not want the public to make hasty judgments on the alleged involvement of students. ``I hope the people do not easily judge the students by calling them evil and that they dared to kill a police officer.'' A ruling could only come through a trial, she told reporters at the Cipto Mangunkusumo General Hospital here. Yuli, also a lecturer at the School of Medicine of the University of Indonesia, announced Saturday her conclusion on the death of Dadang, head of the intelligence unit of Bogor City Police. Police maintained Dadang died from a head injury sustained after a rock was thrown at him by students when he tried to intervene to rescue a military intelligence officer, Capt. Ali, from a student mobbing. Ali remains hospitalized. Students have insisted they attacked Ali because he was disrespectful by entering the university's mosque without removing his shoes outside. Eyewitnesses claim Dadang's body was not at the scene when they were dispersed by hundreds of police and military officers who entered the campus. Yuli said her findings were supported by all of her colleagues, including a forensic expert from the Bogor Regional Police, Abdullah. The latter also took part in the autopsy of the officer together with hospital staff and dozens of police officers. ``He told me 'Don't be afraid. I agree with you. Although I work for the police, I'm also a doctor','' Yuli said. ``I felt relieved.'' Autopsy results have been submitted to the Bogor Police. A police officer, she said, had visited her forensic laboratory recently and questioned an employee why the autopsy finding differed with the police investigator. ``'I'm the investigator, I have obtained confessions from the students that they hit the officer, and a reenactment has been held. This autopsy result has negated our investigation','' she quoted the officer as saying. When asked for comment yesterday, Bogor Regional Police Chief Col. Abubakar Nataprawira said he had yet to study the autopsy report. ``I haven't read it but the confession of the three students and reenactment revealed that the students hit the police officer with a wooden bat, stone and stepped on his stomach,'' he told The Jakarta Post. ``Maybe Dadang had coronary disease and he died of shock after he was beaten. But to be certain of who was responsible for his death, let's wait for a court verdict.'' Three Juanda University students have been named as suspects in Dadang's death. National Police spokesman Brig. Gen. Da'i Bachtiar expressed concern yesterday over Yuli's public announcement. He told the Post that the doctor should have discussed her report with the local police before making a statement. (ivy/edt) Dibyo -- Page 2

After Caledonia, French gov't to consider more autonomy for Polynesia
PARIS (AP) _ The government has agreed to discuss granting French Polynesia more autonomy, the territory's leader said Tuesday, after New Caledonia secured an accord that could lead to independence. Prime Minister Lionel Jospin ``told us he completely agreed on that demand by the territory, for an evolution of autonomy, on an enlargement of authority in Polynesia,'' the territory's president Gaston Flosse said. Flosse commented after a one-hour meeting with the Socialist leader, though there was no immediate comment from the government. Officials close to Flosse said autonomy talks were to begin immediately, though no date was announced. Flosse said Polynesia's demands were ``not as urgent as the New Caledinian case.'' Flosse met Friday with conservative President Jacques Chirac, who on May 27 urged greater autonomy for all French overseas territories in a manner similar to that granted to New Caledonia. Last month, Jospin went to New Caledonia to sign an agreement setting a referendum in December on a transition period of ``shared sovereignty,'' followed in 2018 by a referendum on self-determination. The accord followed a decade of separatist violence in the Pacific island territory. Floss invited Jospin to Polynesia, and the prime minister tentatively accepted though officials had yet to announce a date. The deputy minister for overseas territorial affairs, Jean-Jack Queyranne, was to visit French Polynesia on June 12. (cb-parf)

ORGANISATIONS working on the issue of trafficking in women and providing services and support to affected individuals feel a strong need for a set of standard minimum rules (SMR). Drafted by the Global Alliance Against Traffic in Women (GAATW) and the Foundation for Women, in cooperation with the Foundation Against Trafficking in Women, the SMR aim to protect the human rights of victims of trafficking, and to address the related forced labour and slavery-like practices, in particular the right to control over one's mind, body and life. Said Sherman Manseung Tang, GAATW training coordinator: ``We are now consulting with human rights and legal experts to fine-tune the language used in the SMR. Once we have the revised version, we will promote its use internationally. ``We are also studying relevant laws in various countries to assess the impact of such legislation on victims of trafficking. In Cambodia and Thailand, for example, there are specific laws against trafficking. However, some trafficking laws - in `protecting' women - may actually restrict women's movement by, for instance, requiring them to have their husband's endorsement before they can travel abroad.'' The SMR urge governments to take all necessary steps to reform any law or policy that punishes, criminalises or marginalises victims of trafficking and to ensure they receive humane treatment and protection. The rules list down general obligations expected of all countries, and specific obligations expected of countries of origin, and countries of transit and destination. Generally, all countries are to guarantee that victims of trafficking are not persecuted or harassed by those in authority. They are also to provide adequate, confidential and affordable medical and psychological care besides giving strictly confidential HIV testing. Victims should also be given free legal assistance and a competent translator. To ensure that the victim is able to remain in the country during trial proceedings, destination and transit countries must guarantee resident status (for the duration of her or his stay) in order to take legal action against the offenders and to regain control over her or his life. Adequate and safe housing, access to state-provided health and social services, adequate financial support and opportunities for employment, education and training are also expected of destination and transit countries. The rules discourage governments from placing victims in detention centres. Victims should be given access to the embassy/consulate of their home country and also not be prosecuted for the use of false travel or other documents and/or visas pursuant to their predicament. Countries of origin are to protect victims and their families from reprisals of the perpetrators, including people in positions of authority. They should not imprison or detain victims upon returning home for facts pursuant to their predicament, nor for the use of false travel and other documents.

According to psychologist Carl Rogers, ``Experience is, for men, the highest authority. . . . Neither the Bible nor the prophets, neither Freud nor research, neither the revelation of God nor man can take precedence over my direct experience.'' Truth to these men is subjectively encountered. They contend that nothing really is true unless you have personally experienced it to be true yourself. What bothers me about making experience the real criteria of truth is that, first, it makes finite man, not God, the judge of truth and morals. If, of course, there is no God, it could only follow that there is no revelation of God's will in the pages of Scripture, no direction for man, no real concept of right or wrong. In that case, your personal experience is as good as standard as any to determine what's right or wrong. But, there is a God in heaven who has revealed His will through the pages of Scripture. Whether or not I experience some things personally, I can accept them as true because a higher source of authority or power has revealed them. Iraq finalizes oil prices, signs contracts under U.N. deal
BAGHDAD, Iraq (AP) _ Iraq on Tuesday finalized and submitted to the United Nations the price at which it will sell oil during the fourth phase of the oil-for-food program. Iraq also has started signing contracts with ``a number of international'' oil buyers, the official Iraqi News Agency quoted an unnamed Oil Ministry spokesman as saying. It did not saw what the price was or name the buyers. The submission of the oil price formally clears the way for starting the expanded phase of the oil-for-food program under which Iraq will be able to sell dlrs 5.2 billion worth oil over the next six months. The money can be used only to buy food, medicines and other humanitarian goods. INA quoted the spokesman as saying that the oil ministry also is actively trying to finalize deals to buy spare parts for its battered oil industry. In the previous three six-monthly phases of the deal, Iraq was permitted to sell only dlrs 2 billion worth oil. The third phase ends Wednesday. The oil-for-food deal was started in December 1996 to help alleviate the common Iraqis' hardships caused by the U.N. economic sanctions, which banned the country's export, oil. The sanctions, imposed after Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait, cannot be lifted until it is certain that Iraq has destroyed its weapons of mass destruction. my/vj

JAKARTA (JP): Indonesia's economy contracted by 8.51 percent in the first quarter of 1998, the Central Bureau of Statistics said yesterday. Sugito Suwito, the agency's chairman, also predicted that gross domestic product (GDP) would shrink by 10.1 percent this year, compared to the government's prediction in April that the economy would contract by 5 percent this year. This is the first time that the government's statistics agency has published quarterly figures for GDP growth rates. In the past, the government published the annual GDP figures as part of the president's state of the nation address in August. The GDP figure is calculated based on 1993 constant prices. The agency said the construction sector was the worst hit by the recession, contracting by 27.16 percent. The manufacturing sector followed with 18.58 percent, trade, hotels and restaurants (14.38 percent), financial services (11.1 percent), mining (9.65 percent), other services (3.7 percent) and transportation and communications (2.5 percent). Only agriculture and utilities (electricity, gas and clean water) booked positive growth during the first quarter, respectively by 28.47 and 7.1 percents. The agency said Indonesia's month-on-month inflation rate rose 05.24 percent in May, bringing the total increase in the consumer price index to 40.06 percent in the first five months of 1998. Sugito predicted that inflation would reach 80 percent to 85 percent this year, contingent on an absence of extraordinary happenings such as last month's massive rioting in Jakarta and other cities. ``But if something like rioting happens again, inflation could surpass the 100 percent level,'' he warned. Sugito said the main driver of inflation during the first five months of this year was the prolonged monetary crisis, compounded by bad farm harvests and increasing fuel prices. Interruptions and breakdowns in the distribution network, especially because of the unrest in Jakarta and other cities last month, also contributed to the high inflation rate for May. Food prices rose 3.90 percent, processed food and cigarette prices 4.00 percent, housing prices increased 4.14 percent, clothing 4.53 percent, health 2.4 percent and education and recreation 1.41 percent. Transportation and communication costs shot up 17.25 percent. On international trade, the bureau said Indonesia booked a surplus of US$5.09 billion during the first quarter of this year, with exports reaching $12.29 billion and imports $7.2 billion. Exports declined by 0.9 percent during the first quarter of this year to $12.29 billion, with non-oil exports rising 9.5 percent to $10.02 billion and oil and gas exports falling 30.17 percent to $2.27 billion. Meanwhile, imports reached $7.2 billion, with non-oil imports totaling $6.2 billion, oil and gas $990 million.

Besides Dr. Kaare Rodahl's system, there are other approaches in using the skipping rope in attaining a high fitness level. But one should warm up before skipping, whether he uses Rodahl's or some other trainer's system, or uses his own approach in building the stamina to do 500 skips in five minutes. The warm-up can consist of jumping jacks, squats, forward and side bends, and trunks twisting and turning, each done about 10 times each or until the onset of fatigue. The warm-up should be followed by a rest of about three to four minutes. When one feels quite rested, he can start skipping. Rope skipping can tax the respiratory system severely. Beginners should skip rope slowly and jump only as high as necessary to allow the ropes to pass under the feet. In their first try, beginners should count as they hop, and stop when they're slightly winded or when the legs are tightly fatigued. They can then call it a day. They can begin their program the next day, or two days later by again warming up with the same calisthenics loads, resting, and skipping the same way they did during the test day. The program load should consist of two rounds of skipping each made up of 60% of the load performed on the trial day, and a rest period between the two rounds. The rounds being shorter, they may skip a bit faster, but must rest enough to recover their breath between the rounds. Some may develop muscles pains after the first try. They should relieve the pains with muscle relaxant or with some balm. They can rest for a days or two before starting their program proper. If they wish, they can do less reps in more rounds-say 40% of the first day load in three rounds. They should skip rope daily, or at least five days a week. They will probably improve their endurance by day after the first week or so. They should thus employ a system of progression, which is an important element in exercise. As they do more and more skipping, they should wear well-cushioned rubber shoes. Beginners, especially older people, should progress conservatively, even slowly by adding two to four hops in each round every few days, or every week. Young people, and those who've been quite active, can progress faster by adding 10 skips in each round every few days. They can aim to eventually do as many as four rounds of 150 skips each. When they've reached this goal, they can do a relatively rapid five rounds of 100 skips each. Then, they can shorten the rest periods between the rounds bit by bit. Soon, they'd be doing 500 skips straight. Shortly, they'll do 500 skips in five minutes quite handily. The ``500-in-five'' can lead to higher fitness levels, or the ability to skip 1,000 times in 10 minutes or 1,500 in 15 minutes, or to do fancy skipping techniques. Of course, skipping rope can be combined with strength work for a more rounded and truly athletic physical development.

JAKARTA (JP): President B.J. Habibie claimed yesterday it was the leaders of the House of Representatives (DPR) who proposed the time frame for the extraordinary session of the People's Consultative Assembly (MPR) which will set the date for a general election. Minister/State Secretary Akbar Tandjung said that Habibie, told leaders of the Indonesian Communion of Churches (PGI) and the Bishops' Council of Indonesia (KWI) in a meeting that he merely agreed with the House leaders. ``The president said that the schedule for the session to review laws which would lead up to the election, is based entirely on the proposal of the House leaders. ``Therefore the government took the decision constitutionally and it is in line with the proposals of the House leaders,'' Akbar said. After meeting with Habibie on Thursday, House speaker Harmoko announced that an extraordinary session of the Assembly would be held at the end of this year or early next year. The following day Habibie disclosed that fresh polls would be held sometime next year. Opposition groups and students denounced the decision, saying the government was buying time to consolidate its power. Since Soeharto's resignation on May 21, many have clamored for an election which would eventually lead to the next president being chosen democratically. PGI chairman Sularso Sopater joined the chorus for prompt elections. He urged the president not to lose the momentum of reform and help restore confidence. ``We commented about the schedule, asking whether it was not too long,'' Sularso told journalists, adding that many in his congregation felt the same way. The four-man PGI delegation included Sularso and secretary-general J.M. Pattiasina, while the five-member KWI delegation was led by its chairman Bishop Jos Suwatan and secretary-general Hadiwikarta. Suwatan said the delegation could not fully elaborate on many of their comments to the president since he dominated much of the conversation. Former House speaker Wahono yesterday brushed aside Habibie's legitimacy as president, saying he lacked a mandate from the Assembly. Mandate ``Habibie is a president without an MPR mandate because the mandate is still with Soeharto,'' he told reporters after attending a commemoration of the 53rd anniversary of the state ideology Pancasila at the Pancasila building on Jl. Pejambon in Central Jakarta. ``There should be an extraordinary session of the Assembly to take back the people's mandate,'' he said. After a meeting with Habibie yesterday, the head of the State Intelligence Coordinating Board (Bakin), Moetoyib, reiterated the necessity to reform the Assembly as many of its members had resigned. But the retired three-star general however did not elaborate on ways to reform the assembly. A slew of Assembly members have resigned their seats in a sympathetic gesture to the reform movement and its call to eradicate collusion, corruption and nepotism. During Habibie's meeting with the Christian leaders, he was also urged to conduct a comprehensive and transparent investigation into the shooting dead of four Trisakti University students on May 12. Bishop Suwatan also urged the President to include other fatal incidents which involved security personnel within the investigators' remit. ``The mastermind of the rioting and looting in the last few weeks and the kidnapping of activists should also be probed and dealt with firmly and transparently,'' the bishop said. Then, in an unexpected move, Suwatan forwarded to Habibie a list of the victims of the riots in Jakarta. The list, prepared in a report by the Volunteers for Humanity chaired by Father Sandyawan, put the death toll during the riots at more than twice the 500-odd cited by the government. According to the list, dated May 28, the three days of riots claimed at least 1,215 lives -- 23 shot dead and 1,192 burnt alive in fires. ``Thirty-six people are still missing after the rioting,'' said the report.

PADESH, Albania (AP) _ Ethnic Albanians fleeing the violence in Kosovo province gave weeping firsthand accounts Tuesday of a major Serb offensive against separatists that is fast turning into another all-out civil war in the former Yugoslavia. Trekking over the mountains for up to two days, refugees joining the growing exodus to neighboring Albania described artillery bombardments that forced out entire villages, and house-burnings they said were clearly intended to drive them out. ``It's ethnic cleansing, and it's done the same way as in Bosnia,'' said Ukshin Maliqi, 35, comparing the situation in Kosovo with practices in neighboring Bosnia that appalled the world during that three-year war. ``They shell first so that we abandon our houses, then they burn them so that we cannot return,'' he said. The accounts provided some of the most detailed information yet about the scope of the stepped-up campaign launched in late May by Serb police and army forces, who are trying to crush the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army. The militants have been gaining in popularity and numbers lately after years of heavy-handed rule by Serbian authorities in the secessionist southern province, where ethnic Albanians represent 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million. There have been no reports like those in Bosnia of massive civilian roundups or massacres in the Kosovo campaign, which the Serbs insist targets guerrillas. But attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted increasing comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia and its atrocities. More than 200 people have been killed in the past three months. U.S. President Bill Clinton told a visiting delegation of ethnic Albanians in Washington last week that the United States ``shall not tolerate another Bosnia in Kosovo.'' But the West repeatedly has failed to get Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to halt the Serb crackdown in Kosovo, and has yet to devise a strategy for how to resolve the worsening conflict. A NATO official in Brussels, Belgium, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the alliance was ``preoccupied'' with Kosovo and would debate what to do at a NATO Council meeting Wednesday. Based on information from the refugees and ethnic Albanian officials in Kosovo, the latest campaign is concentrated in the western region of Decani, where the Serbs deployed thousands of additional paramilitary forces and are pulverizing 10 towns and villages with artillery. The town of Decani, with a population of about 20,000, was in ruins with no sign of life, according to the pro-Albanian Kosovo Information Center. Dead cattle littered the streets, the center said. While the Kosovo Liberation Army controls as much as a third of the province, several refugees said they saw no sign of it in the sealed-off area under siege by Serb forces. ``When the shelling started we ran to the woods, waiting for it to stop,'' said Nise Mazrekaj, 27, from the targeted village of Slup. ``But then the Serbs set the houses on fire, so we couldn't go back.'' Her three young children were crying and hungry after an overnight mountain journey over goats' paths. Other refugees were stretched out on the grass asleep, exhausted from their trip. ``There's no way back, no,'' said Mazrekaj's husband, Sulejman, 39, distraught from the shelling a day earlier. The Serb attacks appeared to have intensified over the weekend, judging by the stream of refugees that began Sunday morning to Albania. U.N. officials said 1,600 refugees had registered, but local Albanian officials said about 5,000 refugees had arrived, many refusing to register. ``The people keep coming,'' said Kris Janowski, spokesman for the U.N. refugee agency in Geneva. Communications with western Kosovo remained cut off. A monitor for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe who spoke on condition of anonymity said military action in the area around the border appeared to have declined. Serb authorities said militants fighting for independence had attacked police along a road in western Kosovo, killing one officer. The authorities also said they had broadcast radio appeals for residents of Decani and several villages to return. The residents were told their safety would be guaranteed as long as they didn't participate in ``terrorist activities.'' Ethnic Albanian leaders publicly acknowledged the existence of the Kosovo Liberation Army for the first time Tuesday, noting that the ``massive Serb aggression is meeting heavy resistance'' from the people and the KLA. Adem Demaqi, a prominent ethnic Albanian leader known as Kosovo's ``Mandela'' for the years he spent in Serbian prisons, appealed to the KLA to refrain from targeting innocent Serb civilians in retaliation for police brutality. Nelson Mandela spent 27 years in jail under South Africa's previous white-minority government. He was elected president in 1994.

JAKARTA (JP): Minister of Transportation and Communications Giri Suseno Hadihardjono said yesterday PT Sempati Air, one of the country's six scheduled airlines, would stop operations after being crippled for months by the monetary crisis. ``It is impossible for Sempati to continue operations in the current difficult situation,'' Giri told reporters after a ministerial meeting on economy, finance and industry at the National Development Planning Board headquarters here. ``The government has extended assistance to the company, but its problem is so complicated that there is no other choice for it but to stop operation.'' He did not say when termination of operations would take effect, but company employees said they would likely end this Saturday. ``The management has told us that employees for flight service will be laid off this Saturday, but those handling administration would remain on to collect proceeds from agents,'' a manager said. Sempati spokeswoman Rima Novianti refused to confirm Giri's statement yesterday, but said the company's shareholders would meet Wednesday to discuss whether it should halt operations amid the economic crisis. ``It's difficult to gain a profit today with 80 percent of our cost in dollars, while earnings are in rupiah,'' Rima told The Jakarta Post. Indonesia has been worst hit by the region's monetary crisis, which started in Thailand in July last year. The rupiah sank to its lowest level of Rp 17,000 per U.S. dollar in January, compared with a precrisis level of Rp 2,450 last July. The rupiah was 11,500 against the greenback yesterday. Rima denied speculation Sempati was folding because of the downfall of former president Soeharto. Majority shareholders include Hutomo ``Tommy'' Mandala Putra and close Soeharto associate Mohammad ``Bob'' Hasan. Sempati, founded in 1989, is owned by the Malaysian-Indonesian joint venture Asian Aviation Inc. (40 percent), the Indonesian Army's PT Tri Usaha Bhakti (Truba) (25 percent), Bob Hasan (20 percent) and the Humpuss Group, controlled by Tommy (15 percent). Rima said Sempati operated a fleet of 25 leased aircraft and employed 3,500 workers at its peak in 1996, a time when it was labeled the country's largest private air carrier. Currently, it uses five Boeing 737 aircraft and has about 700 employees. Although Giri said the government would ask other airlines to take on the routes serviced by Sempati, he noted this would be difficult as most carriers were beset by similar economic problems and were reducing their flight rosters. ``Anyway, the government will do its utmost to make sure all provincial towns are served by airflights,'' Giri said. The five other scheduled air carriers are state owned Garuda Airlines, Garuda's subsidiary Merpati Nusantara, Bouraq Airlines, Mandala Airlines and Dirgantara Air Service. Except for Dirgantara, which only operates its own aircraft, the carriers lease many of their aircraft.

The tariff and related matters committee has decided to cut import duties on coffee beans and corn substitutes. Trade Undersecretary Melito Salazar yesterday told reporters the 11-man tariff committee decided to bring down the tariff on coffee beans from 45% to 10% starting next year and corn substitutes like rye, barley and oats from 35% to 20% in 1998, 15% in 1999 and 10% by 2000. The cuts were in line with the Philippines' commitments as a member of the World Trade Organization, said Salazar. These would have a negligible impact on farmers, he said. Salazar said government met with coffee producers and users before it cut the tariff on coffee. These groups confirmed there was a shortage in domestic supply, he said. In a letter to the Board of Investments, the Coffee Association of the Philippines, International Coffee Organization-Certifying Agency, Coffee Industry of the Philippines and the Specialty Coffee Association of the Philippines asked government to raise the volume of coffee that the country could import with preferential tariff from 1,000 metric tons to 5,000 metric tons. These groups said domestic coffee production was hit by the El Nino dry spell. Local corn makers opposed moves to lower the tariff on corn substitutes, saying pork and poultry producers would be encouraged to use rye, barley and oats as feeds instead of corn. The tariff committee has yet to decide on the duties on other sensitive agricultural commodities as sugar, corn, onions and cabbage.

The national government reported to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) that tax remittances from the country's top 10 firms during the first three months suffered a steep drop of 33.5% to P2.113 billion from P2.598 billion recorded during the same period last year. While making allowance for the effects of the marked slowdown in the country's economy, a ranking Finance official in an interview yesterday noted tax evasion was suspected to be the main reason for the slump. ``It was one possible cause, although the BIR (Bureau of Internal Revenue) now focuses on areas where they can get additional collections. Tax evasion is always a problem...the election factor was ruled out,'' he said. He further said government would be concluding its investigation of the drastic decrease by the second quarter. ``It cannot be done in 10 days. The audit requires three months.'' However, the official immediately noted the downtrend was also brought about by the lingering effects of the regionwide economic crunch that ensued in mid-1997. The crisis has led to an average earnings reduction of above 20% for the first quarter for firms listed at the Philippine Stock Exchange. Latest projections have put Gross National Product (GNP) growth somewhere between 1.90% to 3% while allowing for Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth of between 1.24% and 2.40%. Both figures represent a 50% decline from last year. ``The decrease in income taxes from these companies also signified this. The taxes for the period were actually taken from the last quarter of last year,'' the official who requested anonymity said. The documents added that the closure of several corporations in 1997, such as Marcopper Mining Corp. and Marinduque Quick Lime Corp., ``adversely affected collection of corporate tax.'' The official, however, pointed out that collections from corporations were expected to pick up by June. IMF Right About Tax Administration -- BREAKER The report showed government oil firm Petron Corp. remitted P578.88 million; premiere telecommunications firm Philippine Long Distance Co. paid P548.12 million; beverage giant Coca-Cola Bottlers Phils. Government failed to divulge these firms' year-ago individual tax payments which totalled P3.179 billion. Finance authorities had committed to the IMF an amount of P75.588 billion in taxes, higher than last year's actual level of P64.797 billion. The IMF wanted government to further expand its monitoring of corporations' finances to include the 5,000th largest taxpayer nationwide. JAKARTA (JP): West Jakarta District Court sentenced an executive of privately run Bank Central Asia (BCA) yesterday to eight months in jail for swindling Rp 396 million from customers. The scam remained undetected for months because Budiyanto identified rarely used accounts. But it unraveled when several customers reported their money had been withdrawn without their authorization. Parwoto said the defendant was proved guilty of violating Article 374 of the Criminal Code, which carries a maximum punishment of five years in jail. CISARUA, West Java (JP): The prolonged economic crisis and political uncertainty has forced many businesspeople to temporarily close their factories, shops and offices. Some have asked their employees to be understanding and have promised to rehire them as soon as the situation allows. But what can zoo owners do when the price of animal feed and medicine rises sharply? The popular Safari Wildlife Park in Cisarua, West Java, boasts 2,500 animals in its collection made up of 225 species from five continents. Animals in the park, especially the carnivorous species, now have to go without food for up to three days a week. A sharp fall in the value of the rupiah against the U.S. dollar which began last July has caused the price of imported and locally produced animal feed to rise to unaffordable levels. The animals need 16 tons of imported meat, chickens, pigs, and tons of fruit, vegetables and fodder every month. The park's collection of 70 tigers, the largest in the world and including 27 endangered Sumatran tigers, are now left unfed for two to three days each week. The imported meat which formerly made up their diet has become unaffordable to the park's owners and has been replaced with chickens. In rupiah terms, the price of imported meat has soared from Rp 3,500 per kilogram to Rp 11,000 per kg. The price of locally produced feed has also risen sharply and the park's management are at a loss as to what to do. Chicken has risen from Rp 2,000 per kilogram to Rp 7,000 per kg because local farmers have temporarily stopped breeding them, ironically because of the soaring cost of chicken feed. To stave of bankruptcy for as long as possible, the park's owners, Tony Sumampauw and his relatives Frans Manansang and Jansen Manansang, have tried to find cheaper ways to feed the animals in their collection. ``We have no choice,'' Tony told The Jakarta Post, over the weekend. However, the cost cutting measures have not met with success and steps such as feeding the tigers unplucked chickens in the hope that the feathers would satisfy their hunger for a longer period of time appear to have done more harm than good. Animals have shown loss of appetite, fallen ill, and some pregnancies have aborted, Tony said. Consequently the management had to spend extra money on medicines, he added. ``We then decided to starve them for a certain number of days each week, which is a closer replication of the conditions which they would face in the wild,'' Tony explained. Daily running costs, made up mostly of food expenses, have jumped from Rp 7 million to Rp 18 million since the rupiah plunged in value, while ticket sales now average Rp 4 million. ``We are now running the business at a loss,'' he said. A drastic drop in the numbers of visitors to the park has compounded the situation. Tony said the 400-hectare park had received almost no foreign visitors since February. Before the monetary crisis and consequent social turmoil, foreigners made up 12.5 percent of the park's 1.8 million annual visitors. ``Local group visitors, usually 25 percent of our total, have also been almost non-existent since January,'' he added. Furthermore, he said, related park businesses, including a recreational playground, the 400-room Safari Garden hotel, 23 caravan units and 15 bungalows, have been running at a loss, despite the fact that prices have been held at pre-crisis levels. The recently introduced night safari tour has already been closed down. Similar problems are faced by a second Safari park owned by the brothers near Jatiarjo village in Prigen, East Java, where 500 animals from 100 species are held on a 400-hectare site. The animals there need 200 kg of meat, 1 ton of fruit and vegetables, and 6 tons of grass every day. ``If things continue as they are we might only survive for a further six or seven months,'' Tony said. ``We have no idea what will happen to our animals if the situation worsens,'' he added. Tony therefore urged the government to strive to build a business climate that would rebuild confidence and attract visitors back to his park. ``What we are hoping for is economic and political stability,'' he said. Fortunately the animals' plight has been drawn to the attention of a number of animal lovers, including former minister Joop Ave and students from Azabu University in Japan, who have donated funds to the park's management. ``I hope that international animal welfare groups and related organizations can temporarily help us fund our operations,'' Tony said. Despite the gloom, the park's management were pleasantly surprised after 3,462 visitors and 647 cars entered the park on Sunday. ``This is the first crowded Sunday in a long time,'' park spokesman Julius said. Most of the visitors were junior high school students celebrating their graduation, he added.

JERUSALEM (AP) _ Israel's legislature voted Tuesday to dismantle the makeshift shrine that has sprung up at the grave of an Israeli gunman who massacred 29 Muslim worshippers. BC-Sports-Boxing-Holyfield-Akinwande,0679
Neither sandwiches nor questions are up to Holyfield's tastes AP Sports Writer
By TIM DAHLBERG
NEW YORK (AP) _ Evander Holyfield didn't like the sandwiches or the questions about his motivation as he and Henry Akinwande got together Tuesday for the final time before they fight for the heavyweight title. The bread on the turkey sandwiches was too hard for Holyfield's tastes. So he sipped a Coke and scoffed at those who might question how he seriously he can take Akinwande in the wake of two wins over Mike Tyson and a bit of revenge against Michael Moorer. ``People wonder if I can get up for this fight,'' Holyfield said. ``They shouldn't. I'm up for every fight.'' That Holyfield's state of mind is the most important topic leading into Saturday's fight at Madison Square Garden says a lot about the title defense against Akinwande, Holyfield's first fight since he beat Moorer Nov. 8 to add the IBF portion of the heavyweight title to the WBA title he won from Tyson. Simply put, the 6-foot-7 (1.97-meter) Akinwande isn't considered by many to be much of a challenge to Holyfield despite his imposing height and a 33-1-1 record marred only by a loss to WBC champion Lennox Lewis. ``They said the same thing about Holyfield before he fought Tyson,'' Akinwande said at Tuesday's final pre-fight press conference. ``I've made a good living proving people wrong in this sport.'' Akinwande, by virtue of his No. 1 ranking by the WBA, is getting his second heavyweight title shot in less than a year despite an embarrassing performance last July against Lewis in which he was disqualified in the fifth round. He's not the opponent Holyfield wants in the twilight of his career, but with Tyson still sidelined and his camp unable to make a deal with Lewis for a title unification, Akinwande is all he's got. ``I have a job and my job is to win,'' Holyfield said. ``I win and everything takes care of itself. I just go out there and execute and then say, `Next.''' Holyfield will earn some dlrs 10 million for the scheduled 12-round fight, which tops a card that features 46-year-old Roberto Duran seeking a sixth title in his 116th pro fight against WBA middleweight champion William Joppy. Also on the card is junior bantamweight champion Johnny Tapia in a non-title fight and women's fighter Christy Martin. The purse will boost Holyfield's career earnings to some dlrs 185 million but figures to do little to enhance a legend created when he beat Tyson in successive fights. Still, Holyfield and those around him bristle at the suggestion that an Akinwande fight is something less than a top heavyweight title bout. ``People can characterize it as something else but to us it's a big fight,'' said Jim Thomas, Holyfield's lawyer and manager. ``If it doesn't come out the right way, it becomes a huge fight.'' Holyfield was to have fought Lewis to unify the heavyweight championship for the first time since Riddick Bowe threw the WBC belt into a garbage can after his win over Holyfield in their first fight. But with Holyfield wanting dlrs 20 million for the fight and Lewis unwilling to give up his relationship with the HBO network, talks collapsed and Holyfield was left only with the option of taking a mandatory title defense to keep his WBA title. ``There's no other reason to fight him other than he's ranked No. 1 and that's what the rules are,'' Holyfield said. Should Holyfield beat Akinwande _ and he is a 7-1 favorite to do so _ talks could begin in earnest again for a Lewis fight that would probably take place sometime in the spring. If the two fighters still can't get together to unify the title, Holyfield would find himself faced with yet another mandatory challenge, this one against IBF No. 1 contender Vaughn Bean. ``They didn't become No. 1 because they're not good fighters,'' Holyfield said. ``Besides, I tend to bring out the best in other fighters.''

KIGALI, Rwanda (AP) _ A Rwandan court has convicted and sentenced to death six Hutu rebels for the 1997 killing of four U.N. human rights monitors, the Rwanda News Agency reported Tuesday. The monitors, a Briton, a Cambodian and two Rwandans, and their driver were ambushed near Cyangugu, 240 kilometers (150 miles) southwest of the capital, Kigali, and on the border with Congo, where the Hutu rebels cross easily in and out of the country. A court in Cyangugu delivered the verdict on May 26, but it was not reported until Tuesday. The six rebels _ five men and one woman _ were arrested shortly after the Feb. 4, 1997, ambush. They were charged in March with the murder, armed robbery and endangering state security. The incident led rights monitors to restrict their movements, making it tougher to gather reports on human rights violations outside Kigali. Last month, the government decided to suspend the U.N. mission until a new mandate is negotiated. Thousands of people have been killed in rebel attacks and army reprisals since more than 1 million Hutu refugees returned from exile in November 1996. Tutsis control the government in Rwanda after toppling the Hutu-led regime that orchestrated the genocide of 500,000 minority Tutsis in 1994. So far, Rwandan courts have convicted and sentenced to death more than 100 people in connection with the 1994 slaughter. Firing squads publicly executed the first 22 convicts on April 24. In total, 130,000 people are awaiting trial in overcrowded jails throughout Rwanda. On Monday, Geoffrey Gatera, a former surgeon and the dean of the medical faculty at the University of Butare, was convicted on genocide charges and sentenced to death. Gatera was accused of taking part in the massacres of Tutsis at the Butare hospital, 75 kilometers (45 miles) south of Kigali, where he was working at the time. Meanwhile, a British diplomat leading a European team to the Great Lakes region of Central Africa said European Union legislators were preparing a common position on what to do with the Rwandan genocide suspects residing in EU countries. The Rwandan government has criticized European nations for harboring genocide suspects. ``We're engaged in discussions about how to secure the arrest of the genocide culprits in each of the EU countries,'' Tony Lloyd said after talks with the Rwandan leaders in Kigali.

BC-Sports-Boxing-Bowe Indicted,0533
Federal grand jury indicts Bowe for allegedly abducting wife, children AP Sports Writer
By JOE MACENKA
CHARLOTTE, North Carolina (AP) _ Former undisputed heavyweight champion Riddick Bowe was indicted Tuesday for allegedly abducting his estranged wife and their five children from their suburban Charlotte home and driving them to Virginia. A U.S. District Court grand jury named Bowe in a one-count indictment charging him with interstate domestic violence. He faces up to 10 years in prison and a dlrs 250,000 fine if convicted. Judy Bowe and the couple's five children were uninjured in the alleged Feb. 25 abduction, authorities said. U.S. Attorney Mark T. Calloway said he could not comment on the specifics of the incident, but Cornelius, North Carolina, police chief Ron McKinney said it began when Bowe drove to his wife's home in the trendy north Charlotte suburb along Lake Norman. Bowe ordered his wife and children into the car and began driving toward his home in Fort Washington, Maryland, McKinney said. Bowe went some 200 miles before stopping at a fast food restaurant in South Hill, Virginia, where Judy Bowe was able to get to a telephone and call her sister, Lynette Shaw, in Cornelius. Shaw called Cornelius police, who in turn alerted their counterparts in South Hill, and they went to the restaurant and spoke with the couple. Judy Bowe told authorities she and her children did not want to go to Maryland, so South Hill police arranged for them to be transported back to Cornelius. Authorities decided they needed to conduct additional interviews and consult state police in North Carolina and Virginia as well as the FBI before making a decision on whether to arrest Bowe, McKinney said. Later in the day, Bowe entered a medical treatment facility for counseling and therapy, according to Rock Newman, who managed Bowe's boxing career. The boxer has had other troubles since leaving the sport. In May 1997, shortly after Bowe announced his retirement, he and his sister, Velma Melton, were involved in a spat in which both reportedly got split lips. Bowe quickly announced a reconciliation. Bowe joined the Marine Corps Reserve in 1997 and reported to Parris Island, South Carolina for three months of basic training, but he dropped out 11 days later. Bowe was unbeaten in 31 fights and at the top of his game when he outpointed Evander Holyfield for the undisputed heavyweight championship on Nov. 13, 1992. He lost the WBC title outside the ring when he didn't fight Lennox Lewis of Britain. He lost the WBA and IBF titles by majority decision to Holyfield on Nov. 6, 1993. Bowe didn't lose another fight, but he also never again looked like a dominant fighter, with the exception of a sixth-round knockout of Jorge Luis Gonzalez June 17, 1995. On Nov. 4, 1995, he got up from a knockdown to stop Holyfield in the eighth round of a non-title fight. In his last two fights, both in 1996 against Andrew Golota, he won on disqualifications. He was taking a beating in both fights when Golota was disqualified.

BC-Sports-Basketball-NBA Finals,0557
Malone knows it's time for some serious Jazz AP Sports Writer
By BOB BAUM
SALT LAKE CITY (AP) _ Once again, the Utah Jazz have placed their National Basketball Association championship hopes on the chiseled shoulders of Karl Malone. If this is the year the Jazz end the Chicago Bulls' dynasty of the '90s, Utah must have a big series from their superstar power forward who endorses Rogaine, rides a Harley and is the proud new papa of a baby girl. ``The pressure on me personally? I don't think you guys even know,'' Malone said Tuesday after the Jazz's last practice before Wednesday night's series opener. ``I realize I have to bring my `A' game.'' A year ago, in Utah's first trip to the finals, Malone admits the pressure got to him. He was trying to prove he deserved his MVP award and sometimes forced things. ``It was decent,'' he said of his play. ``It wasn't outstanding or great or nothing. It was probably a C-plus or maybe a B as far as my thinking. I think with the MVP stuff, maybe I felt that instead of just playing my game.'' Now, Malone said, he is much more relaxed. ``It's not an excitement attitude. It's not a don't care attitude. It's kind of in between,'' he said. ``Sometimes it seems like I play my best when I have that kind of attitude.'' Malone put a little more pressure on himself and his fellow Utah post players when he said, ``This series is going to be won with our big guys.'' ``I'm going to issue that challenge right now to myself and to the other guys,'' Malone said. ``Our guards have helped us big men a lot. It's our time now to return the favor. We don't disrespect their big guys, but we do feel we can do more to help our guards and small forwards out. ``If we're to win this series, our big guys have to do a great job on the boards, myself included, and we have to play a great defensive help game to help our guards out.'' Chicago has no one to match up well with Malone. Luc Longley, bigger and slower, will start out defending him. Dennis Rodman also will get a turn. Last year, Brian Williams came off the bench, and his ability to run the court with Malone was a big reason the Bulls won the series in six games. But Williams is gone, and no one on the Chicago bench seems able to fill that role. ``It's going to be tough. We're going to have to find some matchups for Malone,'' Scottie Pippen said. ``He's definitely going to be able to get out and run on our big men, especially if Luc is guarding him, or Dennis, who wants to bang the boards and be a rebounder.'' Fouls could be a big problem for the Bulls. ``One of the most important things for me to do is be aggressive out of the gate,'' Malone said. ``Instead of settling for jump shots, maybe take it to them and hopefully get their big guys in foul trouble, get them back on their heels.'' The Bulls know all to well that Malone can create a foul mood. He led the NBA in free throws attempted. ``It's really difficult to guard Karl Malone because the slightest touch and you're going to get a foul,'' Rodman said. ``Here in Utah, you don't get any calls at all. There's nothing I can do except go out and play hard and try to throw him off his game.''

Johnson's loss nothing to worry about, yet AP Track Writer
By BERT ROSENTHAL
BUFFALO, New York (AP) _ Michael Johnson's uncharacteristic defeat in the 200 meters of the Prefontaine Classic wasn't a shocker to him or his coach because of his lack of training and racing. The loss for the 1996 Olympic gold medalist came Sunday, when he finished third at Eugene, Oregon in a wind-aided 20.28 seconds, nearly one second off the world record of 19.32 he set during the Atlanta Games. Johnson was beaten by Maurice Greene, the winner in 19.88, and Obadele Thompson, the runner-up in 20.17. ``We had no illusions coming in since the guys he was running against had run more meets (this year) than Michael,'' coach Clyde Hart said Tuesday. Hart, also the coach at Baylor, said Johnson began training three months late for this season because of injuries from last year, the worst being a right quadriceps strain during a 150-meter match race against Canadian Donovan Bailey at Toronto in June. In addition, there are no Olympic Games or world championships this year, so there was no desperate need to begin training early, Hart said. The coach added that ``Michael's training is going well. He's in good 400 condition now. ``But he's not going to win every time he runs,'' Hart said. ``Michael has to get some good 400s under his belt, then the fast 200s will come. ``He just has to get in more training. He's using this week to train and reload.'' Hart said that the quadriceps injury ``appears totally healed, but whether it's 100 percent, we don't know.'' Johnson also recently missed a week of training because of a ``flareup'' in his leg, Hart said. ``When the nagging injuries go away, he'll be all right,'' Hart said. ``There's no need to panic. Nobody's pushing the panic button. ``Michael's high intensity comes when he's healthy. It's a matter of getting his work in and getting in races.'' Johnson's next scheduled meet is the USA Championships at New Orleans, beginning June 19, but Hart said he might bypass the nationals to concentrate on training. ``He might say I want to train another three weeks,'' Hart said. ``He has to be comfortable that he's ready to run. Michael's speed is always best when he's stronger.''

CARACAS, Venezuela (AP) _ Democracy and free-market economic reforms have helped reduce rural poverty and improve the lives of women in Latin America, but major problems persist, U.S. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said Tuesday. ``Despite the progress, huge challenges of underdevelopment remain,'' Albright told the Organization of American States. The three-day OAS meeting, which ends Wednesday, has addressed subjects including corruption, drug trafficking, poverty and consolidating democracy. Albright also said Tuesday that an undercover money-laundering sting operation in Mexico, dubbed ``Operation Casablanca'', had suffered from a lack of coordination. Mexico's foreign secretary, Rosario Green, earlier criticized the United States for not keeping Mexican authorities informed of the three-year operation. Albright and Green met Monday night to discuss the tensions. ``Obviously there needs to be better coordination in terms of our joint efforts dealing with money laundering and narcotrafficking,'' Albright said at a news conference. Albright also rejected suggestions by some countries that Cuba be readmitted to the OAS. It was thrown out in 1962 after the United States accused Cuba President Fidel Castro of supporting leftist rebels in the region. Addressing foreign ministers from 34 countries, Albright said children are staying in school longer, women are gaining more access to education and health care, and 1 million people are to receive loans for micro-enterprises in the next few years. Still, overall poverty in the region has gone up since 1980, with a record 210 million people now below the poverty line, according to the OAS. Latin America suffers the greatest gap between poor and rich in the world; in some countries, 10 percent of the population controls 50 percent or more of the wealth, the OAS says. Albright's visit to Caracas was to end Tuesday when she departs for Washington, then to Geneva for talks on nuclear testing in India and Pakistan. The leading duo widened the advantage on the last mountain before the finish _ the Giro highest point at the 2,214-meter high Sella Pass - and Guerini won the two-way sprint at ease. Zuelle, an against-the-clock specialist who had beaten Pantani by more than three minutes in Sunday's individual time test at Trieste, finished 4:37 minutes behind on Tuesday and fell to fourth overall, 1:01 minutes behind the new leader. Guerini completed the 217-kilometer (134.5-mile) stage from Asiago to Selva di Val Gardena in six hours, 16 minutes, 58 seconds. Pantani, who trailed Zuelle by 3:48 at the start of the 17th stage, vaulted from fourth to first place in the standings 30 seconds ahead of Russian runnerup Pavel Tonkov, who finished fourth at Selva di Val Gardena. Guerini moved to third overall, only one second behind Tonkov, a Giro winner in 1996. ``When I attacked, along with Guerini, I just wanted to reduce my gap from Zuelle,'' Pantani explained at the finish line, after spraying cheering fans with champagne from the podium. Thousands of enthusiastic people lined along the roads taking to the Dolomite passes and to the finish line of the toughest Giro stage so far. ``I did not believe that Zuelle could lose so much. After the bad beating suffered in the time trial (Sunday) I was dreaming of revenge, of a day like today,'' Pantani said. Pantani, 28, was a champion of bad luck in 1995 when he suffered two consecutive bad spills and a broken leg. He was sidelined for the entire 1996 cycling season. Colombian Chepe Gonzales, who placed third 2:04 minutes behind the winner, was one of the day heroes as he led on the road climbing to the Fedaia pass and surrendered to Pantani and Guerini only on the last tough uphill section of Sella, named Cima Coppi after the late Italian ``Campionissimo'' Fausto Coppi. Zuelle, who already lost and recaptured the pink jersey twice in the current Giro, will have an opportunity to fight back in the next-to-last stage Saturday, an individual time trial of 34 kilometers (21 miles) in the Swiss lake resort of Lugano. Defending Giro champion Ivan Gotti, suffering from back pains and with a gap of 12:42 minutes overall, did not start Tuesday. Those who retired during the stage included Italian top sprinter Mario Cipollini, winner of four stages this year. Wednesday's leg of 115 kilometers (71.3 miles) ends at 1,760 meters of altitude of Alpe di Pampeago.

BC-Britain-People-Jerry Hall
Lucien Freud nude of Jerry Hall unveiled at Tate Gallery
LONDON (AP) _ Art gallery visitors can now see supermodel Jerry Hall from a whole new angle. A nude portrait of a pregnant Hall was unveiled Tuesday at London's Tate Gallery as part of a new collection by British artist Lucien Freud. The postcard-sized painting of the Texan model, measuring just 6 inches (15 centimeters) by 4 inches (10 centimeters), shows the wife of Rolling Stone Mick Jagger lying on one side, pregnant with her son Gabriel, now 6 months old. ``She wondered whether I'd like to paint her in this condition and it was too generous an offer to refuse,'' Freud recently said of his painting. ``I'm especially glad I did it because it led to my now painting her with her baby.'' The painting is on show with 24 of the painter's other works at the Tate until July 26. Freud's painting Large Interior, W11 (After Watteau) recently set an all-time high for a living British artist when it fetched more than 3.5 million pounds (dlrs 5.7 million) at auction. (er)

Iraqis present their case to Security Council, reactions mixed
Eds: LEADS to UPDATE with more quotes from British ambassador By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ Iraqi officials tried Tuesday to convince the Security Council that Baghdad has met the terms for ending economic sanctions by destroying all illegal weapons. U.S. and British diplomats said they remained unconvinced. An Iraqi delegation, headed by Foreign Minister Mohammed Saeed al-Sahhaf, met with council envoys for nearly three hours, one day before the chief U.N. weapons inspector, Richard Butler, is expected to present evidence he says casts doubt on Iraqi claims that it is no longer holding illegal arms. Destroying all long-range missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological weapons is the main condition for the council to end the crippling sanctions slapped on Baghdad in 1990 after President Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait. Al-Sahhaf refused to speak with reporters after the meeting. But British Ambassador John Weston dismissed the Iraqi presentation as ``an exercise in obfuscation.'' ``I just heard four presentations in the course of the last hour and a half which, in effect, were designed to put the (inspectors) in the dock,'' Weston said. ``There is a line in Shakespeare: `Methinks the lady doth protest too much.' That is a little bit what we've got this afternoon.'' ``Iraq once, 5th graf

BC-Sports-Baseball-AL Roundup, 2nd Ld-Writethru,0342
Twins pound Athletics 10-3
Eds: updates with Orioles-Mariners; will be updated
MINNEAPOLIS (AP) _ Dan Serafini won in his first appearance of the season, and Otis Nixon and Brent Gates had four hits each Tuesday to lead the Minnesota Twins over the Oakland Athletics 10-3. Serafini, recalled from the minors on May 27, allowed three runs and five hits in 6 2-3 innings with five strikeouts. It was his second appearance against the A's, the first since a five-hitter last Sept. 8 _ the only complete game of his career and his first win. Nixon went 4-for-4, getting two infield singles. Gates was 4-for-5, matching his career high for hits. Minnesota had 15 hits in all, and every starter scored at once. The Twins led 8-1 after three innings and have outscored opponents 120-61 in the first three innings this year. Tom Candiotti (4-6) was pounded for eight runs and eight hits in 2 2-3 innings. Orioles 9, Mariners 8, 10 innings In Baltimore, Rafael Palmeiro hit his second game-winning homer in as many games, a two-run shot in the 10th inning that carried the Orioles past the Seattle Mariners. Palmeiro connected off Bobby Ayala (0-5) after Harold Baines opened the inning with a single. Ken Griffey had given Seattle the lead in the top of the ninth with his second homer of the game, a solo drive off Norm Charlton (1-1). Palmeiro's 14th homer marked yet another collapse by Seattle's faulty bullpen and ended a second straight slugfest between the teams, who combined for eight homers Monday night in the Orioles' 10-9 victory. Griffey had three hits, including a three-run homer and his 21st of the season in the 10th. Alex Rodriguez hit his 21st home run for the Mariners, who have a team-record 13 homers in their last three games and a major league best 97 for the season. The Orioles got a three-run homer from Brady Anderson, a two-run drive from Cal Ripken and a solo shot from B.J. Surhoff.

EDITORS:
The AP World Service operates on Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) and begins each 24-hour cycle at 0000 GMT. Listed below are key elements of the news service transmitted on all circuits, unless otherwise noted: 0000 GMT Opener, Advisory USING THE AP WIRE, Advisory AP News Digest AP Sports Digest By 0100 GMT AP Top Financial News 0300 GMT AP Asian News Digest, Advisory (Asia only) By 0500 GMT U.S. seasonal sports roundup 0700 GMT AP News Digest (0600 GMT summer time) AP Asian News Digest (Asia only) By 1000 GMT Asia Business Briefs (Asia, Europe, Mideast, southern Africa) 1100 GMT AP News Digest (1000 GMT summer time) 1200 GMT AP News Summary AP Asian News Digest, UPDATE (Asia only) 1300 GMT AP Sports Digest (1200 summer time) AP Top Financial News 1400 GMT AP Europe, Advisory (Europe only) 1430 GMT Africa Briefs (except Asia) 1500 GMT AP World Graphics, Advisory Middle East Business Briefs By 1600 GMT Global Weather 1800 GMT AP News Digest (1700 GMT summer time) AP World Graphics, Advisory 2100 GMT US-Canada-Business Briefs 2200 GMT Pronouncers, Advisory _ pronunciations of names, places in the news 2300 GMT AP World Graphics, Advisory 2330 GMT Latin America Briefs (Europe, Americas) ---- Other fixtures: Feature stories, slugged FEA, are listed at the bottom of each AP News Digest. Three packages on the 0000 GMT digests emphasize specific subjects: _ business on Tuesdays; _ science on Thursdays; _ arts and entertainment on Sundays. ``Editorial Roundup,'' excerpts of editorials from newspapers around the world. Thursdays around 1600 GMT. ``AP Weekly News Calendar,'' a list of significant news events expected in the upcoming week. Sent early in the GMT cycle each Friday and updated late in the cycle with U.S. events and again Mondays. ``AP Weekly Sports Calendar,'' a list of sports events expected in the coming week. Early in the Friday cycle. ``Today in History,'' a list of historic events for each day, transmitted early each weekday about one week in advance. ``US-Top Ten'' in Friday early (GMT) cycle _ the top popular songs in America each week. Theme slugs are used to identify some stories: SCI - science (discoveries, innovations); CYBER - computer technology; MED - medicine/health (discoveries, innovations); ARTS - arts/entertainment; TRAV - travel enterprise; FEA - general features; ANALYSIS - analytical backgrounders. Sports - used on all sports stories. Category codes are used on all stories to enable computerized sorting: ``i'' on general news or feature copy; ``f'' on financial stories or fixtures: and ``s'' on sports stories.

BC-AP Top Financial News,0758
EDITORS:
A summary of financial and business news from The Associated Press at 0000. Stories carry ``f'' or ``i'' category codes and move on this circuit in expanded form: NEW YORK (AP) _ Technology stocks recovered partially from Monday's bruising selloff, but the broad market Tuesday again failed to hold most of their gains as mounting worries about company profits prevailed. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 31.13 points _ or 0.35 percent _ to 8,891.24 after sliding from an early 54-point gain to a 50-point loss. (US-CLOSING STOCKS) WASHINGTON (AP) _ The World Bank's executive board approved a dlrs 225 million rural poverty reduction loan for Indonesia on Tuesday but did not act on a dlrs 1 billion bank credit to help shore up the troubled nation's economy. Both loans had been scheduled for approval by the bank's board on May 19 but were halted as escalating civil unrest that culminated in President Suharto's resignation forced the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund to evacuate staff and suspend operations in Jakarta, the capital. As for the dlrs 1 billion loan, Graham Barrett, a spokesman for the bank's East Asia operations, said, ``We need to take into account the events of the last several weeks before we close off on the loan and submit it to the board.'' (US-WORLD BANK-INDONESIA) ISLAMABAD, Pakistan (AP) _ Pakistan may have to declare a moratorium on repaying its debts as international sanctions bite into its reserves, say financial analysts. The government also may devalue the Pakistani currency by 3-5 percent to discourage imports that are further draining the economy, said a report by the Dutch ABN Amro Bank NV obtained Tuesday. The grim outlook from one of Pakistan's top independent analytical groups was a result of a drop in Pakistan's international credit rating following sanctions imposed after it exploded a series of nuclear tests last month. The governor of the State Bank of Pakistan, Mohammed Yaqub, said the government had no intention of defaulting on its debts. (PAKISTAN-ECONOMY) STOCKHOLM, Sweden (AP) _ Swedish forestry group Stora said Tuesday it plans to merge with Finnish forestry company Enso, creating the world's largest producer of paper and board. ``The merger is based on the excellent strategic fit between these two strong companies, creating a global player in an increasingly competitive industry,'' said Claes Dahlbaeck, chairman of Stora. Dahlbaeck will become chairman of the new company, to be called Stora Enso. Stora and Enso together had about 90 billion kronor (dlrs 11.7 billion) in sales in 1997. Each employs about 20,000 people. The merger will save 1.9 billion kronor (dlrs 2550 million) per year in operating costs, Stora said. (SWEDEN-STORA-ENSO) BRUSSELS, Belgium (AP) _ The European Commission on Tuesday denounced the U.S. decision to limit imports of EU wheat gluten over a three-year period and warned of retaliation. The quota, ``represents a major restriction on European exports,'' the EU executive Commission said in a statement. ``This action is all the more surprising coming from a government that only two weeks ago was calling on WTO members to further liberalize trade in agricultural products.'' The EU head office was considering ``appropriate responses'' but gave no immediate details. EU spokesman Gerard Kiely said the quota suggested Washington will defend free farm trade if that serves American farmers only. The EU has nabbed 30 percent of the American wheat gluten market. (EU-US-WHEAT GLUTEN) LONDON (AP) _ The parent company of Rolls-Royce Motor Cars on Tuesday called a 430 million pound (dlrs 700 million) bid from Volkswagen a good, solid offer _ and said any last-minute approaches would face big obstacles. Plans to sell Rolls-Royce to the Germans were thrown somewhat into question Monday, when a group of Rolls-Royce enthusiasts said they were planning a higher bid with the intent of keeping the company British. Vickers PLC has called a special meeting Friday for shareholders to vote on Volkswagen's offer. The company has not yet received any kind of bid from the British group, which calls itself Crewe Motors and is run by a lawyer, Michael Shrimpton, who previously led a failed effort to bid for Rolls-Royce. Vickers has acknowledged any that last-minute bid, if credible, could force it to delay its plans. (BRITAIN-ROLLS ROYCE)

Eds: Contains items on Maximilian Schell, Kenneth Kaunda, Viagra, a
LOS ANGELES (AP) _ Two years after winning a breach-of-contract lawsuit, Maximilian Schell got a post-appeal boost in his judgment against a German producer Superior Court Judge Joseph R. Kalin increased the award by dlrs 167,000 on Sunday to compensate the actor for delays in payment by Wolfgang Bocksch. Schell already had won nearly dlrs 406,000 on his claim that Wolfgang Bocksch Concerts canceled a European production of ``My Fair Lady'' one month ahead of schedule in 1994. The producer's attorneys said Bocksch was justified in breaking the contract because Schell, 68, didn't fulfill his duty to publicize the play, which was canceled because of dwindling audiences. Kalin ruled that Schell, who won the 1961 best actor Oscar for ``Judgment at Nuremberg,'' made all reasonable requests for publicity. Bocksch appealed but lost. ___ LUSAKA, Zambia (AP) _ Former President Kenneth Kaunda comforted himself during five months of detention with poetry, hymns and thoughts of Princess Diana. Kaunda never met Diana, who died in a car crash in Paris last year, but he ``felt greatly touched by her.'' ``I am very moved when people do good things for fellow man,'' Kaunda said of the late princess's charity work. ``I've been trying to write something on Diana.'' Kaunda, 74, spoke Tuesday with The Associated Press at his home on his first day of freedom. The state dropped charges that he concealed knowledge of plans for a coup attempt last year. After his arrest on Christmas, Kaunda was put in prison and then under strict house arrest. ___ NEW YORK (AP) _ While Viagra may have brought many couples closer together, the impotence drug has ruined at least one relationship. Roberta Burke, 61, appeared in state Supreme Court in Mineola Tuesday to bring a dlrs 2 million lawsuit against her longtime companion 70-year-old Francis Bernardo claiming that Viagra prompted him to leave her. Before Viagra, Ms. Burke said Tuesday, ``I was looking forward to our old age, holding hands and walking on the beach.'' She says her man was impotent until he popped the tiny blue pill on May 1. They had sex for the first time in four years, said her lawyer, Dominic Barbara. Two days later, Ms. Burke says, Bernardo walked out, leaving a note boasting of his prowess. Bernardo didn't appear in court Tuesday. Sex researchers have said the allegations demonstrate the dangers for some relationships when men take Viagra and suddenly have an increased interest in sex. ___ JERUSALEM (AP) _ Is your hotel bill too high? An Israeli hotel will let you work off part of the tab. Starting this week, the dlrs 95-a-night Candle of the Jordan hotel in Tiberias will let guests clean rooms or toil in the kitchen for dlrs 8.50 an hour. The hotel said a visitor suggested the pay arrangement. Guests are allowed to work off half the price of their stay when they make reservations at the hotel from Sunday through Wednesday. The savings is significant: About 5 1/2 hours of grunt work would shrink the nightly cost to dlrs 47. The hotel has branches in Tel Aviv and Netanya, but only the Tiberias branch is offering the discount. The hotel said it did not expect many guests to take advantage of the offer. ___ OSLO, Norway (AP) _ A harpooned whale fighting for its life rammed the Norwegian boat that shot it, breaking the vessel's mast and hurling two crewmen into the icy waters. The whale escaped, but it was unclear if it survived, the Oslo newspaper Verdens Gang reported Tuesday. The two crewmen, one of whom suffered cracked ribs, were rescued. According to the paper, the whaling boat, the Bolga, was off Norway's northern tip on Monday when it harpooned a minke whale, which can grow up to 30 feet (9 meters) in length. The whale then rammed the 53-foot-long (16-meter-long) wooden boat. The two crewmen, who had been spotting whales from the crow's nest near the tip of the mast, were thrown into the ocean, about 425 miles (685 kilometers) north of the Arctic Circle. Norway resumed commercial whaling in 1993, despite a ban imposed by the International Whaling Commission.

BC-Bahamas-Bre-X-Walsh,0474
Chairman of disgraced gold company hospitalized in the Bahamas
TORONTO (AP) _ David Walsh, the disgraced president and chief executive of Bre-X Minerals Ltd., iss hospitalized after he suffered a heart attack during the weekend, the Canadian Press news service reported. Officials with Doctor's Hospital in Nassau confirmed late Tuesday that Walsh was registered as a patient, but refused to give any other details. Earlier, a Reuters report said the former Calgary mining promoter was in critical condition. Walsh, whose now-infamous company rose to fame on the strength of an Indonesian gold find that was exposed last year as a fraud, moved to the Bahamas after the scandal broke in March 1997. The scam cost investors more than dlrs 3 billion. Walsh's Toronto lawyer, Alan Lenczner, was not immediately available to confirm the report. Walsh, a former stock promoter, remains one of the key figures in what began as one of the most sensational rags-to-riches stories in the history of gold mining and ended in scandal. Bre-X was a tiny Calgary, Canada-based company that dazzled investors with its spectacular Busang gold find. It rose from penny-stock obscurity to become a darling of financial markets. It all evaporated in the spring of last year as shareholders realized the Busang deposit, said to contain 200 million ounces of gold, was a scam orchestrated by former Bre-X geologist Michael de Guzman. It was de Guzman's suicidal leap from a helicopter over the Indonesian jungle in March 1997 that first signaled to investors that something was amiss. A private investigator later determined de Guzman and a handful of other Bre-X employees sprinkled gold dust bought from a Borneo tribesman into selected ore samples _ a practice called salting _ before the samples were tested. The salting began in December 1993 and was intended to discourage the company from shutting down the Busang project. Bre-X also earned Canada's financial services industry a global reputation as an unregulated frontier where mining frauds are prevalent and easy to commit. Since May, a barrage of shareholder lawsuits have been launched against Bre-X and its senior officials, securities regulators and several brokerage firms which promoted the stock. The company itself was petitioned into bankruptcy in November after an Alberta court refused to extend its protection deadline. Walsh resigned as chairman shortly afterward. In May, a Bahamian court froze his assets in that country. Former Bre-X executive John Felderhof, de Guzman's boss, retreated to the Cayman Islands shortly after the engineering report on the Busang fraud was released. He has denied any knowledge of the scheme.
