BC-Latin American Briefs,0751
Chile.
Eds: Contains items from Mexico, Argentina, Honduras, Brazil and
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ Cuban leader Fidel Castro met for several hours Tuesday with leaders of the National Council of Churches, whose trip is aimed at showing support for the booming Protestant movement in Cuba. The Cuban government's Prensa Latina news agency gave few details of the meeting. Members of the church delegation left Cuba early Tuesday and could not be reached. But the group earlier said it found that Pope John Paul II's January visit ``has benefited all Christians'' in Cuba. The council noted that Cuban Protestants claim that rapidly growing attendance at their churches equals that at Catholic churches in Cuba _ with roughly 600,000 regular worshipers for all Christian faiths. Catholic church officials insist that their own attendance still out paces that of Protestants on the island, which was historically Catholic prior to the 1959 revolution. The National Council of Churches represents 34 Protestant and Orthodox denominations with 52 million members in the United States. ___ BUENOS AIRES, Argentina (AP) _ An election tribunal has ruled that a third term for Argentine President Carlos Menem would be ``unconstitutional,'' adding fuel to an ongoing political debate over his intentions. A growing number of provincial governors, lawmakers and other members of Menem's Peronist party are presenting court petitions for a third run. In its second ruling since April, the National Electoral Court on Monday declared Menem ``unable able to seek a third mandate'' because of constitutional provisions barring re-election. The decision by Argentina's top election court came in response to a lawsuit by a lawyer pressing for a definitive ruling by the judiciary. With the 1999 ballot still months away, whether or not Menem can seek a third term has been the subject of vocal debate nationwide that could go as far as the Supreme Court before the issue is settled. ___ TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras (AP) _ Roman Catholic bishops from throughout Latin America will meet this month to urge forgiveness of much of the region's immense debt, warning the problem otherwise could cause a ``bloody revolution.'' ``Foreign debt is not only an economic problem, it is also a human problem ... and it is bringing ever-greater poverty to Latin Americans,'' Honduran Archbishop Oscar Andres Rodriguez, president of the Latin American Episcopal Council, said Tuesday. Rodriguez said the bishops would meet here June 29 and 30 to discuss the area's estimated dlrs 600 billion debt. Rodriguez said the bishops also were likely to urge richer countries to aid Latin American development by reducing protectionism and cutting interest rates on their loans ``because economic relations between nations should be expressions of justice,'' he said. ___ BRASILIA, Brazil (AP) _ President Fernando Henrique Cardoso and his wife, Ruth, will visit U.S. President Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary, at the Camp David presidential retreat this weekend, the foreign ministry said Tuesday. The meeting between the two first families will have no specific agenda, said Luiz Neves, a director at Brazil's foreign ministry. But, Neves said, the heads of state could talk about the nuclear tests conducted by Pakistan and Indian, nuclear non-proliferation in general, recent elections in Paraguay and the Southern Cone Common Market, known as Mercosur. The Cardosos were scheduled to arrive Saturday in Washington, where they will attend the signing of an education agreement between Brazil and the World Bank at Brazilian Embassy. On Sunday they will head to Camp David in Maryland. ___ SANTIAGO, Chile (AP) _ Quitting smoking can be profitable in Chile. Under the slogan ``quit and win,'' the Health Ministry organized a contest offering prizes of cash and international trips to smokers who quit during a two-month period. A total of 11,400 contestants participated and dozens succeeded, forcing the ministry to conduct a drawing to determine who would receive three all-paid trips _ to Europe, Rio de Janeiro and Buenos Aires _ as well as cash prizes ranging from dlrs 220 to 1,100. Health Minister Alex Figueroa said the contest was considered such a success that the experience will be repeated in two years. Witnesses and tests were used to proof that the smokers had actually quit.

BC-FEA-Russia-Vladivostok's Dead,0645
In Vladivostok, even death brings no respite from the city's woes
AP Photo NY375 By NICK WADHAMS Associated Press Writer
VLADIVOSTOK, Russia (AP) _ When stray dogs recently gathered around an open manhole, pacing and barking, the commotion led police to another body. A homeless man had climbed down into the tunnel, probably seeking warmth from heating pipes, and died. Solving the case wasn't tough. But removing corpses has become a major problem for Vladivostok's cops these days. A company created to pick up corpses has run out of money, and with considerable reluctance, the beleaguered police force has been handling the job. Lacking proper equipment, officers sometimes transport bodies in an open trailer hitched to the back of a police car. Sometimes they flag down passing trucks to take bodies to the morgue _ although they deny newspaper reports they were even stopping bread trucks. ``Clearly we understand that would cause an epidemic,'' said Deputy Police Chief Anatoly Petrusha. ``We'll usually just stop trucks that have metal in the back, or maybe wood.'' The problem highlights the decline of public services in Vladivostok, Russia's main Pacific port that has been crumbling due to a lack of money, poor management and a relentless feud between Mayor Viktor Cherepkov and regional Gov. Yevgeny Nazdratenko. The mayor hasn't paid the company that collects corpses, SpetsService, since 1996, even though he created it two years earlier. SpetsService wants 300,000 rubles (dlrs 50,000) a year, and until the city pays up, it will pick up bodies only if relatives foot the bill or if it's an emergency. ``If the body is in the street or blocking traffic, then we'll get rid of it,'' the company's boss, Yevgeny Osokin, said. In the manhole death, police approached a number of onlookers, seeking to borrow ropes, overalls and rubber boots _ and a volunteer to go down to get the body. ``We don't like to do it ourselves, and we can usually find someone else who will do it,'' said Sgt.-Maj. Smekhun Starsheserzhan. ``After they got the body out, we figured it had been lying there for a month. By that time we couldn't tell what the guy had died of.'' The police force has gotten no extra funds or equipment to deal with the estimated 3,500 bodies they expect to collect this year in the city of 800,000 people. Last year, a diver drowned in ice-covered water during the winter, but police didn't have the tools to reach him. Instead, they had to wait for the spring thaw. ``Someone finally called when the body floated to the surface later in the spring, and we went out in a boat and picked it up,'' Starsheserzhan said. The mayor and the governor blame each other for the problems plaguing Vladivostok, while services continue to get worse. Their quarrel, which has dragged on for years, is seen mostly as a bitter personality clash. Cherepkov was removed as mayor by presidential decree in 1994 amid corruption allegations. When he was returned in 1996, he said SpetsService was full of criminals and refused to finance the body-removal service. The political feud has prevented any effective solutions to the region's chronic energy problems, and during the past winter, Vladivostok residents had to go without hot water and electricity for stretches of up to 15 hours. There's no escaping the city's problems, even in death. ``In the past, it didn't matter if the corpses had relatives, because the mayor paid for it and SpetsService did the job,'' said police Maj. Alexander Blakzhin. ``Now, if a man dies in his apartment, we'll go in and take a look at him. If his relatives have money, they have to arrange to remove him themselves.''

BC-FEA-Bahrain-Ancient Eden,0687
Archaeologists uncovering ruins of ancient paradise in Bahrain
AP Photo NY307, Graphic ANCIENT EDEN By LOUIS MEIXLER Associated Press Writer
SAAR, Bahrain (AP) _ In ancient times, the land of Dilmun was described as a virtual Garden of Eden, a land where the wolf and the lamb lived in harmony and youth was eternal. Archaeologists today are uncovering more of that once-fabled land, revealing a prosperous trading society that had such abundant supplies of water that palm trees grew heavy with dates almost without effort. ``Fresh water just bubbled up out of the ground,'' said Jane Moon, one of the directors of the archaeological expedition at Saar. ``That must have been miraculous to Gulf people.'' Saar was one of the towns in ancient Dilmun, which at different times encompassed what is now the Persian Gulf island of Bahrain and parts of eastern Saudi Arabia. In about 1900 B.C., Saar was one of several bustling towns in Bahrain apparently ruled from a city whose ruins are beneath a medieval fort six miles (nine kilometers) to the northeast. Merchants in the area grew rich as ships laden with copper from Oman stopped in Dilmun while traveling up the Persian Gulf to Babylon in Mesopotamia, which is in modern-day Iraq. The copper was later mixed with tin or lead to form bronze weapons and tools. ``This very small island ... suddenly got hold of a somewhat monopolizing role,'' said Dan Potts of Australia's University of Sydney. Dilmun was famous for its dates, which were popular in a region where the fruit remains common. Pearls, believed to have been called ``fish eyes'' in Mesopotamia, were also traded. In modern times, Bahrain had a famous pearling industry. Traders' seals found in Saar show motifs such as the double swirl popular in Anatolia, likely evidence that trade routes stretched as far as present-day Turkey. Some 50 seals, most round and each about twice the size of a thumbnail, have been discovered. Dilmun achieved everlasting fame in Mesopotamian religious texts, where it was lauded in mythological terms. One text says: ``In Dilmun, the crow screams not, the dar bird cries not dar-dar, the lion kills not.'' Archaeologists say the same text shows the Mesopotamians viewed Dilmun as a land of eternal youth. ``Its old woman says not `I am an old woman.' Its old man says not `I am an old man,''' the text relates. Some experts say Dilmun's role as a port where ships took on food and water may have led to its glorified image among the Sumerians and later the Babylonians. ``There really was the opportunity to pick up life-saving sustenance there,'' said Gordon Davis of the University of Alabama. Potts notes Dilmun myths predated major Bahrain settlements and may have referred to earlier Dilmun communities in today's Saudi Arabia. The ruins of Saar _ the only complete town found from the Dilmun period _ show some 80 stone houses, almost all with two rooms and a courtyard. It is not clear how many people lived in each room. Next to the town is a graveyard with about 1,000 tombs. Bahrain is famous for having up to 150,000 burial mounds, but it's unclear why so many exist. At Saar's highest point sat a small temple for worship of local gods that probably also was used as an administrative center. ``It is a settlement with a lot of planning, a lot of regularity,'' Potts said. In March, Moon's team unearthed a kitchen, which had a bread oven and a fireplace with supports for a cooking pot. The people most likely ate dates, fish and gazelle meat. About 85 percent of bones found at the site were from fish. The town was abandoned in about the 17th century B.C. for reasons that remain a mystery. Moon theorizes a receding coastline prompted people to abandon the site. Potts says an interruption in the copper trade or changes in the water supply may have caused the town's demise. No written records from the settlement have been found.

BC-ARTS-US-Tony Awards, 2 Takes,0883
The mouse that roared _ changing Broadway and the Tonys AP Drama Writer
AP Photo NY336 By MICHAEL KUCHWARA
NEW YORK (AP) _ The mouse _ Mickey, that is _ roared and Broadway took notice, not only of its stage version of ``The Lion King,'' but of the marketing and advertising techniques Disney and other big-time corporate producers brought to the New York theater this season. No wonder the 1998 Tony Award nominations were dominated by several musicals produced by these companies, which are challenging the old way of producing and selling shows. Look for Disney's ``The Lion King'' and Livent's ``Ragtime'' to divvy up the major musical and production awards Sunday (8 p.m. EDT PBS, then 9 p.m. EDT CBS) when the prizes honoring Broadway's best are handed out. It's the most competitive Tony ceremony in years, not only in the high-profile musical categories but also in drama, where a surprising number of plays _ 19 in all _ competed for nominations. Yet the quest for the best-play trophy is a two-horse race, with either ``The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' or ``Art'' the most likely winner. One area where there is absolutely no contest is the musical revival category _ with ``Cabaret'' an overwhelming favorite. Its two stars, Natasha Richardson, as the extravagant chanteuse Sally Bowles, and Alan Cumming, as the show's decadent master of ceremonies, would appear to have the top musical performance awards locked up, too. Cumming's strongest competition will be Brian Stokes Mitchell, the mesmerizing Coalhouse Walker of ``Ragtime.'' Mitchell was the favorite before ``Cabaret'' opened, but now might divide votes with his ``Ragtime'' co-star, Peter Friedman, who also was nominated. Even Tony's television showcase has undergone considerable change, thanks to the presence last year of Rosie O'Donnell, happy-time talk show host and wide-eyed fan of the Broadway theater. Until O'Donnell emceed last year's bash at Radio City Music Hall, the TV show had been sliding steadily in the ratings. CBS was making noises about not renewing its contract. ``Moving the ratings up was definitely the biggest accomplishment last year,'' O'Donnell says. ``I think it is real important that it stay on network TV because, in the middle of the country, not that many people are as familiar with PBS as they are with CBS. ``Plus I think it is important to stay on so we can encourage the new young playwrights to continue to work.'' For O'Donnell, the 1997 ratings boost was doubly sweet. ``The hardest part last year was just convincing some of the Broadway community that I should do the show,'' she says. ``I think there was a little bit of resistance at first. I had done a revival of `Grease,' but that was all, and the Tony show always had been hosted by very legitimate theater people. ``Then came this girl with a big mouth from TV who wanted to do it at Radio City. Who did she think she was? Now I think the Broadway community knows I just want to help support it and try to make the show the best that it can be in terms of an entertaining two-hour program.'' If plays were much more of a presence on Broadway this season, don't expect many that fail to win awards to be around very long. In fact, one of the best-play nominees, ``Golden Child,'' closed a week ago, unable to hang on to find out that it didn't get the big prize. The other best-play nominee is ``Freak,'' John Leguizamo's autobiographical one-man show about growing up Latin in New York. In ends July 4, not because of lack of business but because its highly popular star has a film commitment. ``Art'' by Yasmina Reza already is a big international hit, scoring in Paris and London. The New York production repeated those successes, pulling grosses each week that rival some musicals. The show's principal competition is ``The Beauty Queen of Leenane,'' introducing a young London-born playwright named Martin McDonagh to New York audiences. Even if he doesn't win, the 27-year-old writer will be heard from again. Yet for glamour and high stakes, nothing tops the battle between ``The Lion King'' and ``Ragtime.'' In theater awards competition so far, the two have divided the major prizes. ``The Lion King'' won the New York Drama Critics' Circle prize, while ``Ragtime'' picked up the Drama Desk nod. Both shows have been masterfully marketed by their producers. Try watching a New York television station without seeing a ``Ragtime'' commercial. It's difficult to do. And Disney earned enormous publicity for committing itself to the rebirth of Times Square and, more specifically, the dlrs 34 million renovation of the New Amsterdam Theater, which houses its musical hit. It was an inspired decision by Disney executives Tom Schumacher and Peter Schneider to hire avant-garde director Julie Taymor to bring ``The Lion King'' to the stage. Taymor was something of a triple threat off-off-Broadway. She did everything there from directing to designing sets and costumes to even writing music. Taymor is a favorite to pick up one Tony _ for direction of a musical _ and she could win two more. MORE

BC-ARTS-US-Tony Awards, 1st Add,0348
NEW YORK: two more.
``Ragtime'' is a musical done the old-fashioned way _ at the instigation of a strong-willed and creative producer, Garth Drabinsky. It was his idea to bring the E.L. Doctorow novel to the stage. Drabinsky hired playwright Terrence McNally to adapt the book and composer Stephen Flaherty and lyricist Lynn Ahrens to write the score. And the competition has even extended off-stage. In April, the financially troubled Livent was taken over by a group of executives led by Michael Ovitz and Roy Furman, a Wall Street entertainment banker. Drabinsky was named the company's chief creator director. Ovitz is a former Walt Disney Co. president who left in 1996 with a generous golden parachute. Now he has considerable say in the running of one of its chief Broadway competitors. Hallmark, the greeting card giant, made a sizable investment in two big musicals this season _ a revival of ``The Sound of Music'' and a pop version of the old romantic potboiler ``The Scarlet Pimpernel.'' The company has aggressively marketed both shows. In the case of ``The Sound of Music,'' it has run television commercials capitalizing on baby boomers' nostalgia for the show and as something they should take their children to see. Its persistence with ``The Scarlet Pimpernel'' _ free mini-CDs in copies of newspapers and other special promotions for example _ has paid off with Tony nominations. The show, panned by most critics, did get a best-musical nomination, along with a nod for its swashbuckling star, newcomer Douglas Sills. And then there is the final best-musical nominee, ``Side Show,'' a sentimental favorite but a decided long shot. The tale of real-life Siamese twins, it didn't catch on with the public despite some good reviews. Many blamed the subject matter; others blamed the musical's lack of marketing, including the absence of a television commercial. Imagine if Disney or Livent had been in charge of the ads. The musical might still be running.

BC-ARTS-Britain-Shakespeare Company,1100
A troubled English theater troupe hits the road
AP Photos AP Photos NY450-1 By MATT WOLF Associated Press Writer
LONDON (AP) _ The Royal Shakespeare Company is taking its show on the road, leaving behind a trail of criticism. The company can be seen in repertory in five productions, first at New York's Brooklyn Academy of Music through June 7 and then at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., June 9-July 5. The dlrs 2.2 million lineup offers an eclectic mix of the company's house playwright, the Bard, who is represented by three plays _ ``Hamlet,'' and the lesser-known ``Cymbeline'' and ``Henry VIII.'' That trio will play in rotation with the allegorical morality play ``Everyman,'' starring expatriate American Joseph Mydell, and Samuel Beckett's solo piece, ``Krapp's Last Tape.'' Among the 50 actors on view will be Tony-winner Jane Lapotaire (``Piaf'') as the ill-fated Queen Katherine in ``Henry VIII'' and two-time Tony nominee Edward Petherbridge in three plays, including ``Krapp's Last Tape,'' which he also co-directed. Likely to be an audience favorite is 40-year-old Alex Jennings, star of a revisionist ``Hamlet'' that has been as popular with London audiences as it was controversial among the critics. It's the sort of array to make American theater companies drool, since they operate in a cultural climate starved of finances and of top-rank actors ready to commit to a season _ or more _ of work. But those are precisely the issues the RSC has had to face of late, while fielding mounting criticisms that a dlrs 50 million-a-year enterprise of some 29 annual productions spread between five theaters has grown too unwieldy. The RSC, playwright David Hare wrote in Britain's Observer newspaper in May, ``is allowed to do dismal work with lavish, unmerited subsidy, while brilliant young theaters ... offer 50 times the RSC's vitality on a fraction of its resources.'' Others merely wonder whether it may be time to give the Bard a break. Perhaps, mused commentator Bryan Appleyard in The Sunday Times of London, ``the greatest plays ever written ... read better than they play.'' The carping falls mostly, and inevitably, at the feet of Adrian Noble, the RSC's artistic director since 1990, who admits to problems within the company but prefers to play up its strengths. ``He's the greatest humanist writer of them all,'' Noble said of the Bard, who gets performed in ``literally all four corners of the known world.'' As for the company itself, Noble said, its very survival pays tribute to a particular British tenacity. ``The National Theater was set up by an act of Parliament,'' said Noble, referring to the RSC's principal rival. By contrast, he said, ``the RSC was set up by an act of will _ no pun intended _ by Peter Hall saying, `I want to create this company, and we will go ahead and do it.' '' Still, when the RSC is in top form, it is a company that is second to none. In its 37 years, the RSC has largely prospered, producing such well-traveled hits as ``Les Liaisons Dangereuses,'' ``The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' and even ``Les Miserables,'' the pop musical that has provided a financial lifeline for well over a decade. Even this season, its productions of Ibsen's ``Little Eyolf'' and Chekhov's ``Uncle Vanya'' _ the latter a co-venture with London's Young Vic Theater _ have been among the year's most revelatory. The problems, as some describe them, lay in a company grown too gargantuan for comfort and in the ethos of today's young actors, who don't want the slow, steady apprenticeship that once turned Ian McKellen, Glenda Jackson and Derek Jacobi, among many others, into internationally known, award-winning stars. The past decade saw the rise of eventual film stars Kenneth Branagh and Ralph Fiennes. Trevor Nunn, a longtime RSC leader who now runs the National Theater, recalls a time when attitudes were different. ``When I ran the RSC for 18 years, there were always actors who most passionately wanted to be part of the company,'' Nunn said. ``They didn't want to be part of anything else. They didn't want to be out in that other life. They wanted continuity.'' Now actors mostly want flexibility. To that extent, long contracts are out and shorter ones are in. ``Leading actors can earn a lot of money in TV,'' Noble acknowledged. ``They leave the RSC worse off. We should be under no illusion about their financial hardship.'' To that end, Noble recently announced a new system of operations to allow for two separate seasons instead of the usual, lengthier one at the RSC's home base in Stratford-upon-Avon, Shakespeare's birthplace. In an effort to revitalize the repertoire, next season will see major productions of Sheridan's 18th-century classic comedy, ``The School for Scandal,'' and a stage version of C.S. Lewis' ``The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,'' joining the Bard's ``Richard III'' and ``The Winter's Tale'' on the Stratford main stage. ``There is a danger of a decreasing pool of plays,'' said Noble, since the 37-strong canon of Shakespeare's work can wear thin with repetition. ``We want to address that.'' Also important is the need to refresh the most frequently seen plays. Director Matthew Warchus' current ``Hamlet'' cut liberally and even did away with several characters without irrevocably distorting the Bard's best-known tragedy. ``I decided to make it a very personal production rather than an exercise in proficiency and expertise,'' said Warchus, a Tony nominee this year for his direction of the Broadway production of Yasmina Reza's hit play ``Art.'' That explains a lively, if sometimes coarsely acted, staging that chops the opening scene, the start of at least one key soliloquy and all mention of the invading Fortinbras in an effort to focus the play as a quintessential family drama. ``It's wonderful to be in something that makes people excited and also very cross,'' said Jennings, the leading player, who was seen last season on Broadway in Noble's production of ``A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' But like many an RSC star past and present, Jennings looks forward to a life beyond the company, where he can earn some decent cash. ``I'd just like to earn a lot of money, really,'' he said with a smile. He quickly acknowledged, however, that the RSC does deliver the goods, adding, ``It's the best.''

BC-Afghanistan-Earthquake,0598
Aid agencies appeal for helicopters to evacuate Afghanistan's wounded
Eds: RECAPS previous. AP Photos ISL103-108, FDB101-104 By JUDITH INGRAM Associated Press Writer
FAISABAD, Afghanistan (AP) _ While hundreds of villagers carried their injured on stretchers made of sticks and old clothes, aid agencies appealed for more aircraft and fuel to rescue the badly wounded in earthquake-stricken northern Afghanistan. Aid workers said they were concentrating on helping the survivors of Saturday's 6.9-magnitude quake and that it would take weeks to get a clear picture of how many people were killed. Estimates ranged from 2,000 to 5,000. The quake struck an area that had been devastated just three months earlier by another massive quake, which claimed about 2,300 victims. Rescuers have reached only 29 villages, or about half of those believed to have been hit hard by the temblor. Of those, 12 were destroyed, or very nearly so, said Rupert Colville, a U.N. spokesman. In the village of Kol, hundreds of people swarmed a U.N. helicopter that touched down on Tuesday. They had carried their injured through the winding hillside streets, past crumbled packed-mud houses, on makeshift stretchers. On Monday and Tuesday, U.N. helicopters evacuated 50 of the most seriously injured to emergency medical centers. They were working from the dirt airstrip of Faisabad, still littered with the rusting junk of old Soviet tanks and artillery from Afghanistan's decades-long civil war. Red Cross helicopters have delivered 2 tons of high-protein biscuits, flour and oil to victims in Shari Basurkh, near the quake's epicenter, about 50 kilometers (30 miles) from Faisabad, the provincial capital of Badakhshan. The villages' remoteness, lack of transportation and landslides that have blocked roads were hampering the aid effort. The United Nations, the Red Cross and other agencies have just three borrowed helicopters delivering medical aid. The helicopters came from neighboring Tajikistan, and Colville said he hoped other neighboring countries would contribute as well. Russia, which has loaned helicopters in previous disasters, said it would consider sending aid. The lack of aircraft ``is undercutting everything we are doing now,'' Colville said. He said the agencies needed at least one more cargo plane to deliver supplies that had already been brought into the region after the February disaster. Throughout the quake zone, most of the injured were women, children and the elderly, who had stayed inside their homes while men worked the fields. Mohammed Karim, who was in Faisabad when the quake hit his village on the outskirts of Shari Basurkh, raced home with four friends, walking the last few hundred meters (yards). They found the village virtually gone. ``We started digging. When we brought the people out they were already dead,'' said Karim. ``We brought the bodies from under the destruction and buried them without an Islamic prayer. We didn't have time.'' The farmer lost all his relatives there _ more than a dozen people among the village's 200 residents. Most of the injuries were broken limbs, internal and head wounds, said Svante Yngrot, a medical coordinator with the Red Cross. Many of the survivors were still in shock, made worse by a series of aftershocks. ``The most traumatized were those who survived the February quake, when they saw friends and relatives killed before their eyes. Now they're going through it again,'' Colville said.

Report: North Korea may have at least one nuclear weapon
TOKYO (AP) _ Japanese defense officials believe North Korea may already have at least one nuclear weapon, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The Nihon Keizai business daily carried excerpts of what it described as a Defense Agency internal report citing fears of regional nuclear proliferation after India and Pakistan conducted tests last month. ``It's possible that North Korea is in possession of at least one nuclear weapon,'' the agency report said, according to the paper. An agency official, speaking on condition of anonymity, would say only that there remains ``doubt'' about the North's development of weapons. According to the newspaper, the agency document also expressed fears that North Korea's rival, South Korea, might eventually move to possess its own nuclear weapons in response. The two countries fought the Korean War from 1950-53 and remain technically at war, though attempts at finally forging a peace treaty are under way. The Nihon Keizai report comes amid heightened concern worldwide over nuclear proliferation since the tests on the Indian subcontinent. North Korea agreed in 1994 to freeze and eventually dismantle its nuclear weapons program in exchange for two light-water nuclear power plants and 500,000-ton annual fuel oil shipments until they are completed. The United States, South Korea, Japan and the European Union are supplying it with the reactors. The Defense Agency report also expressed fear that the chance of a nuclear war occurring in three regions of the world is growing. It identified the regions as the Korean Peninsula, the Middle East and the Indian subcontinent, according to the paper. (kgo-km)

BC-UN-Sierra Leone,0472
Annan envoy urges international community to aid Sierra Leone
Eds: RECAPS previous By ROBERT H. REID Associated Press Writer
UNITED NATIONS (AP) _ A special U.N. envoy is urging the world not to wait for ``perfect peace'' in Sierra Leone and instead mount a major humanitarian operation to rebuild the West African country. ``If the international community adopts the attitude of `wait and see' until there is perfect peace in the country, there's a real democracy that the restored democracy ... will be seriously jeopardized,'' Olara Otunnu told reporters. Fighters loyal to the deposed military junta have been terrorizing rural areas in an apparent campaign of revenge for their ouster in February by Nigerian-led West African troops, who restored a democratically elected government. Otunnu, who returned recently from a four-day visit to the country, said that ``contrary to the impression one may get from outside,'' the government of President Ahmed Tejan Kabbah and the West African peacekeeping force that restored him to power control enough territory ``to allow for very serious programs of rehabilitation and reconstruction.'' ``It is possible with concerted, prompt action, jointly by the national government and the international community, to turn a page,'' Otunnu said. Otunnu said Kabbah's political legitimacy would make it easier for the United Nations to mount an effective humanitarian rehabilitation program in partnership with the local authorities. Last month, the United States and the European Union accused junta forces and its allies in the Revolutionary United Front of engaging in ``horrific'' violence that has killed or maimed several thousand people in recent months. They said hundreds of people are being treated in hospitals after rebels chopped off their arms, legs and ears with machetes. Many women and children have been systematically raped, U.S. and EU officials have alleged. Otunnu said he visited one hospital in the capital Freetown which had received more than 300 people who had lost limbs and hands. ``I will never forget the words of a young boy, must have been about 5 years old, who told me after severing his hands, the RUF soldiers then told him `go tell President Kabbah we are still here,''' Otunnu said. For its part, Otunnu said the government has promised not to recruit youngsters into the ranks of the Kamajors, the paramilitary force allied with Kabbah. Otunnu said the Kamajors had also agreed to begin discharging ``child soldiers'' already in their ranks. In addition, he said the government had agreed to protect ``child soldiers'' of the deposed junta and its still holding out in rural areas.

MUNICH, Germany (AP) _ Whether Austrian, German or English, bookmakers are offering similar odds that Brazil will win its fifth World Cup in France with a probable final against Germany. Almost everything can be bet on at soccer's premier event. Austria's Intertops is offering 30-1 odds against Germany's first score coming through an own goal _ or a modest 1.5-1 payoff if all World Cup goals total between 161 and 170. The English and Austrian bookmakers, as well as Germany's ``Sportwetten Gera,'' all list Brazil as the clear favorite at between 3.5 or 3.75-1 followed by Germany, 5.6-6 to 1, and host France, 5.5-7 to 1. The least likely final? Intertops is offering 750-1 that Denmark will line up against Romania. Ronaldo is the hands-down favorite to be the leading marksman, followed by Argentina's Garbriel Batistuta. The bookmakers split on whether Germany's Oliver Bierhoff or France's Stephane Guivarc'h will finish third. ___ LESIGNY, France _ Romario broke down in tears Tuesday when he was told he'd been dropped from Brazil's World Cup team. Midfielder Emerson of Bundesliga club Bayer Leverkusen was called in to replace the hero of Brazil's 1994 cup-winning team, who misses out with an injury to his right calf muscle. Coach Mario Zagallo made a brief announcement at the team's training headquarters and then turned the press conference over to Romario, who was choked with tears and had trouble speaking. ``Things are happy for some, sadness for others. But now I think you're all sad as I am. I don't want to mean this is a farewell from soccer,'' he said. After breaking down again and covering his face with his hands, Romario said: ``I will now probably learn how to value other things.'' ___ LONDON (AP) _ Paul Gascoigne, the 31-year-old English midfielder, said he was drunk the night before he was cut from the World Cup team by coach Glenn Hoddle gave him the news. Gascoigne spoke about the incident in a story in Tuesday's Sun newspaper. Often criticized for his reported hard-drinking and smoking 20 cigarettes a day, Gascoigne said he left the bar in La Manga, Spain, had sandwiches in his room with teammate David Seaman, and then ``crashed out.'' Gascoigne also said he had been drinking beer during a Sunday golf game just hours before he met with Hoddle. Given the bad news, the star of England's 1990 World Cup team admitted he exploded. ``I completely lost it. I went mad, berserk. I lost my rag big time. I was shouting and swearing. I couldn't believe the injustice of it.'' ___ SOFIA, Bulgaria (AP) _ Coach Hristo Bonev dealt soccer fans a surprise Tuesday when he announced Bulgaria would be going to the World Cup without playmaker Yordan Lechkov. Bonev said that he had also dropped the third goalkeeper, Radostin Stanev, and midfielder Kostadin Vidolov. The goalie was dropped after first choice Borislav Mihailov _ one of the heroes at the 1994 World Cup _ recovered from an injury. Lechkov had contributed greatly to the team's fourth place at World Cup 1994. Bonev did not say why he was dropped. The coach announced the 22-man roster after the team returned from preparations in Germany. They included a 4-0 victory Monday over German champion Kaiserslautern. ___ TEHRAN, Iran (AP) _ Iran dropped two veteran strikers but added two rookies to its 22-man World Cup squad announced Tuesday. Coach Jalal Talebi sacked veteran strikers Alireza Emamifar and Alireza Akbarpour to make way for newcomers, 22-year-old striker Ali Latifi and 24-year-old midfielder Sattar Hamedani. Both rookies play for local club Bahman. Iran's three Bundesliga players, Ali Daei, Karim Bagheri and Khodadad Azizi, were included in the roster as was top goalkeeper Ahmadreza Abedzadeh. The team is in Croatia and will play a warmup against the country's national team Wednesday before leaving for France. ___ PARIS (AP) _ Saudi Arabia's Saeid Al Owairan, who scored the most spectacular goal of the last World Cup, now has the shaven-head look of Brazilian star Ronaldo. Al Owairan drew attention with his weaving run through the Belgian defense in the Saudis recent 1-0 victory in Washington. ``I shaved all my hair off myself a couple of days ago because it kept getting in my eyes,'' said the forward. The Saudis are in action on the third day of the World Cup June 12, when they face Denmark in Lens. MORE

Hwang, 29, South Korea's most famous player, returned to the national team in April after a two-year break due to knee injury. He has since scored three goals in seven World Cup warmup matches. Veteran goalkeeper Jacques Songo'o, who plays for Deportivo La Coruna in Spain, will anchor the team along with striker Francois Omam-Biyick of Sampdoria in Italy. Ever since he was a teenager who went to Brazil to study soccer, Miura had his heart set on taking Japan to the World Cup. He was one of the key members of the Japanese team that failed to qualify for the 1994 World Cup. He scored a spectacular 14 goals in qualifiers for this year's World Cup _ Japan's first.

BC-Air France-Strike,0680
Tough talk ahead of second-round negotiations Wednesday
Eds: RECAPS pvs. Talks resume at 3 p.m. (1300 GMT) AP Photos PAR106,109 of June 2 By CECIL ROUX Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ Threatening a long and devastating strike, Air France's leading pilots' union was talking tough after the first round of negotiations in a walkout already disrupting some World Cup preparations. Talks were resume Wednesday afternoon on the third day of the strike against the World Cup's official carrier, seven days before the championship begins. It appeared virtually no progress was made in the first round Tuesday. After 5 1-2 hours of negotiations inside Air France headquarters at Charles de Gaulle Airport, union leader Jean-Charles Corbet said: ``The conflict continues; it will probably be long, it will probably be tough. ``These effects will probably be devastating on the balance sheet and image of the company,'' said Corbet, head of the SNPL union that represents most of the airline's 3,200 pilots. He accused the airline's president, Jean-Cyril Spinetta, of ``contenting himself with renewing his demands'' during the talks. There was no immediate comment from Air France. In the meantime, Air France said its Wednesday schedule included only 17 percent of its usual long-distance flights, 30 percent of its short and medium-distance routes from Charles de Gaulle Airport and 43 percent from Orly. An Air France source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the airline held firm on 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual salary cuts, but that it could eventually drop its two-tier scale paying a lower salary to new pilots. In an interview published in Le Parisien newspaper Tuesday, Spinetta suggested postponing talks until after the World Cup ends July 12. He said the company was set to lose 100 million francs (dlrs 16.7 million) per day during the strike, which was forcing tens of thousands of people worldwide to look for other ways to travel. Air France's main pilots' union called the 15-day action to protest 500 million francs (dlrs 83 million) in annual pay cuts. The walkout disrupted training for the French national team, said coach Aime Jacquet. The players had been given a three-day weekend to visit their families and were supposed to resume training Tuesday. ``Yes, indeed a lot of players will arrive late because of the strike. It risks turning our whole day upside down,'' Jacquet said. At Charles de Gaulle airport, a shop employee sat alone Tuesday in an empty store stocked with World Cup insignia. Opposite was a newspaper stall where headlines read: ``World Cup held hostage,'' and ``World Cup in peril.'' After walking 70 kilometers (45 miles) from Paris to Chartres over the weekend with 10,000 other youths on a pilgrimage, Ellen Kerry was trying to get to New York on an Air France flight. ``We only found out when we got in the taxi that there was a strike. We could have saved the money and walked,'' said Kerry, whose home is in Virginia. At Marseille's Marignane Airport, passenger Pierre-Antoine Graziani was getting fed up waiting to get on a waiting list to fly to Paris. ``I'm told something different from one hour to another,'' he said. ``I might take my chances with the TGV,'' the high-speed French train. Air France is committed to transporting teams to the 10 competition sites around France and would probably use outside carriers to meet its obligations if necessary. But the U.S. Soccer Federation, heading to France on Thursday, said it is flying its team to Paris on American Airlines, connecting to an Air France flight to Lyon. As a backup, the Americans have rented buses in France. Former French player Michel Platini, co-president of the World Cup organizing committee, accused the pilots Tuesday of ``taking the country hostage. ... This is the image of France at stake, not necessarily that of an airline.''

BC-Argentina-IBM,0362
Argentine judge issues arrest warrants for IBM executives
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina (AP) _ An Argentine federal judge signed international arrest warrants Tuesday for four current or former IBM officials sought for questioning in an alleged kickback scheme, the judge's aide said. IBM Argentina has been accused of paying bribes to win a dlrs 249 million contract in 1994 to computerize state-owned Banco Nacion, the country's largest bank. Federal judge Adolfo Bagnasco signed the warrants Tuesday, nearly one month after two ex-Banco Nacion directors admitted having Swiss bank accounts containing cash they said they received for steering the contract to IBM Argentina. Bagnasco said he issued the arrest warrant after the suspects failed to answer summonses to appear in court. ``There is no other option but to have them sought by the police,'' he said. The judge was expected to ask Interpol, the international police agency, to arrest the IBM officials. Fred McNeese, an IBM spokesman in the United States, said the company has not received official notification that Bagnasco's order had been signed. But he repeated IBM statements that the four current or former company officials are willing to testify before Bagnasco in the United States under the terms of a bilateral U.S.-Argentine treaty. ``They currently have no plans to go to Argentina,'' McNeese said. He described allegations that the U.S.-based IBM officials were aware of any alleged wrongdoing at its Argentine subsidiary as ``unsubstantiated.'' ``The simple fact is that Judge Bagnasco's investigation has produced no evidence that they were aware of any misuse of funds stemming from the Banco Nacion-IBM contract or that they were involved in any wrongdoing,'' McNeese said. The arrest warrants were for Peter Rowley, Robeli de Libero, Steven Lew and Marcio Kaiser, all of whom worked in IBM's U.S. headquarters at the time of the scandal, the aide said. Kaiser and de Libero since have left the company, while IBM has shifted the two other employees to posts unrelated to Latin America, IBM officials have said.

Assault charged against Liam Gallagher dropped
BRISBANE, Australia (AP) _ The victim of an alleged assault by Liam Gallagher, singer with the British rock band Oasis, has dropped criminal charges and will sue in the civil courts instead, lawyers said Wednesday. British backpacker Benjamin Russel Jones, 19, suffered a broken nose, severe swelling and pain after an alleged headbutt from Gallagher during Oasis' tour of Australia earlier this year. In March, Gallagher was released on bail of U.S. dlrs 6,900 (10,000 Australian dollars) after being charged with assault occasioning bodily harm. He did not enter a plea and was due to face pretrial proceedings next week. But Queensland Director of Public Prosecutions Royce Miller said Wednesday that Jones had asked that the charge be dropped. ``The complainant doesn't wish to proceed with the criminal prosecution and will pursue civilly,'' Miller said. ``He has asked through his solicitors in London for the charge to be dropped.'' In a brief hearing in the Queensland Magistrate's Court, case prosecutor Clare Carney said no evidence would be offered. Magistrate Peter Mitchell then formally dismissed the charge. Former Mexico police chief says prosecutor ordered body dumped
MEXICO CITY (AP) _ A state attorney general in Mexico ordered officers to discard the corpse of a prisoner who had been tortured, a former police chief has testified in a corruption case that toppled the governor of central Morelos state. Local newspapers also reported that police in several states protected a Morelos-based kidnapping gang. Several papers published a photo of kidnap suspect Daniel Arizmendi posing with a former Mexico state police commander, both brandishing guns for the camera. In written testimony submitted Monday, former Morelos Judicial Police Chief Jesus Miyazawa admitted knowing about the torture killing of a prisoner by his officers. Miyazawa said he accompanied officers involved in the killing to a January meeting with Carlos Peredo Meredo, then attorney general for Morelos. Miyazawa said the prosecutor not only failed to open a criminal investigation of the case but told police to remove the body from the police station and get rid of it. A scandal erupted when traffic police in neighboring Guerrero state discovered the chief of Morelos' anti-kidnapping unit and other officers dumping the tortured body of Jorge Nava Aviles. Peredo, Miyazawa and other top law enforcement officers were fired and critics charged that state officials may have been connected to some of the kidnapping gangs that have plagued the area just south of Mexico City in recent years. As the scandal over lawlessness grew, Gov. Jorge Carrillo Olea _ a former general who once headed Mexico's anti-drug efforts _ was forced to step down last month. Miyazawa said the fact he notified his superior, the attorney general, proves he was innocent of charges of covering up Nava's killing. Peredo's attorney told the dailies Reforma and El Universal that the testimony did not implicate his client in any crime. Arizmendi's wife and son were arrested in raids on May 21, but the alleged ringleader in scores of kidnappings himself has evaded an extensive manhunt.

BC-Sports-Tennis-French Open,0774
In unpredictable French Open, at least Hingis still on course
Eds: RECAPS previous By JOCELYN NOVECK Associated Press Writer
PARIS (AP) _ The French Open is a tournament where the predictable almost never happens. So perhaps it shouldn't be a surprise that the man many picked to win, Marcelo Rios, has been ousted. But at least one predictable phenomenon remains on course: the onward march of Martina Hingis, the world's undisputed best player. Hingis defeated Venus Williams Tuesday with such ease that it put to rest any talk of a great rivalry _ at least for now. Next, Hingis faces a newly inspired Monica Seles, a three-time champion here, in one of Thursday's semifinals. No. 2 seed Lindsay Davenport plays two-time champion Arantxa Sanchez Vicario in the other. On the men's side, Rios, the No. 3 seed from Chile, blew his chance to overtake Pete Sampras as the world's No. 1 player when he lost 6-1, 2-6, 6-2, 6-4 to Carlos Moya. Rios held that spot for a month earlier this year, and could have reclaimed it with a quarterfinal victory. With Davenport and Seles advancing, there are two American women in the French Open semifinals for the first time since Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert reached the final four in 1987. But there were none of the hoped-for echoes of Evert and Navratilova when Hingis and Williams took the court for their much anticipated match. In a swirling wind that hampered both players, Hingis used her deft touch and uncanny court sense to dictate play throughout. Never in the 6-3, 6-4 victory did the Swiss star appear out of control, off balance or rushed. Williams, for her part, hurt herself with 38 unforced errors. ``I don't think I was as patient as I should have been. I guess everyone knows I like to hit,'' Williams said. ``I suppose I got a little too excited, really wanted to hit a winner.'' Hingis came into the match with a 5-2 career record against the eighth-seeded Williams, but the two 17-year-olds were 2-2 this year. The match promised to be an intriguing battle between power and smarts. Despite her far greater experience, Hingis actually is three and a half months younger than Williams. But, just as in their only previous Grand Slam encounter, a 6-0, 6-4 win by Hingis in the U.S. Open final last summer, the match turned into a one-sided affair. ``It's probably good for me to lose so I can really see what I'm doing wrong and really look at myself and say, `Venus, you're not there,''' she said. Moya, seeded 12th here, is ranked 12th in the world but has been as high as fifth. He's hoping to crack back into the top 10 this week. He became the talk of the tennis world at last year's Australian Open _ for both his dashing good looks and his talent. He upset defending champion Boris Becker in the first round, then went straight through to the final, where he lost to Sampras. But except for that tournament, the 21-year-old Moya had never gone past the second round of any Grand Slam event. And here at Roland Garros, he hadn't gotten past the second round in two previous visits. Moya was at the top of his all-court game Tuesday. A crucial moment came in the fourth set at 4-4, 15-15. Rios was serving. Moya, leading two sets to one, hit a shot and Rios let it go, thinking the ball had bounced twice on Moya's side. But the referee said it hadn't. Rios lost the point, the game, and his concentration. ``Maybe if I won that game, the match would have been different,'' he said later. Now Moya is the highest seed left in the tournament, and one of only three seeds left _ all Spaniards, who excel on clay. The others are the No. 14 seed, Alex Corretja, and the No. 15 seed, Felix Mantilla, whom Moya faces in the semis Friday. Mantilla and Moya are buddies. ``We're going to be friends until Friday,'' he said. ``When we get to the court, I will try to kill him.'' The day's action ended on a sour note when Gustavo Kuerten, the defending champion who lost in the second round, was disqualified in doubles for throwing his racket at the chair umpire _ hitting a fan in the stands, but apparently not causing injury. Kuerten, who won last year as an unseeded player, is well liked by fans, players and the media. In fact, he won this year's Orange Prize, voted by French tennis writers for the player they like best. There's also a Lemon Prize, for the player they like least. The winner, two years running, has been Rios.

BC-Yugoslavia-Kosovo,0897
Fleeing ethnic Albanians describe destruction from Serb offensive
Eds: RECAPS previous AP Photos BEL101-102, AP Graphic YUGO KOSOVO By MERITA DHIMGJOKA Associated Press Writer
PADESH, Albania (AP) _ Shock etched on their faces, ethnic Albanian refugees joining the growing exodus from Kosovo province described destruction and violence from a major Serb offensive against separatists that has sparked concern among Western powers. The accounts of weeping refugees provided some of the most detailed information yet about the stepped-up campaign launched in late May by Serb police and army forces, who are trying to crush the pro-independence Kosovo Liberation Army. The militants have been gaining in popularity and numbers after years of heavy-handed rule by Serbian authorities in the secessionist southern province, where ethnic Albanians represent 90 percent of the population of 2.2 million. Trekking over the mountains for up to two days, refugees fleeing to neighboring Albania described artillery bombardments that forced out entire villages and house-burnings they said were clearly intended to drive them out. There have been no reports like those in Bosnia of massive civilian roundups or massacres in the Kosovo campaign, which the Serbs insist targets guerrillas. But attacks on villages, the exodus of civilians and the deaths of women and children have prompted increasing comparisons to the ethnic war in Bosnia and its atrocities. More than 200 people have been killed in the province in the past three months. The growing violence has sparked alarm among Western powers that the fighting could spill over into neighboring Balkan nations. U.S. President Bill Clinton told a visiting delegation of ethnic Albanians in Washington last week that the United States ``shall not tolerate another Bosnia in Kosovo.'' But the West repeatedly has failed to get Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic to halt the Serb crackdown in Kosovo, and has yet to devise a strategy for how to resolve the worsening conflict. A NATO official in Brussels, Belgium, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the alliance was ``preoccupied'' with Kosovo and would debate what to do at a NATO Council meeting Wednesday. Those concerns prompted NATO last week to consider possible troop deployments in Albania and Macedonia. But Russia said Tuesday that NATO cannot post troops in Albania without the approval of the United Nations. Russia ``opposes any decisions leading to the use of external forces interfering in those problems,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Valery Nesterushkin said. Russia has maintained that Kosovo is an internal matter for Serbia. Based on information from the refugees and ethnic Albanian officials in Kosovo, the latest campaign is concentrated in the western region of Decani, where the Serbs deployed thousands of additional paramilitary forces and are pulverizing 10 towns and villages with artillery. The town of Decani, with a population of about 20,000, was in ruins with no sign of life, according to the pro-Albanian Kosovo Information Center. Dead cattle littered the streets, the center said. While the Kosovo Liberation Army controls as much as a third of the province, several refugees said they saw no sign of it in the sealed-off area under siege by Serb forces. ``When the shelling started we ran to the woods, waiting for it to stop,'' said Nise Mazrekaj, 27, from the targeted village of Slup. ``But then the Serbs set the houses on fire, so we couldn't go back.'' Her three young children were crying and hungry after an overnight mountain journey over goats' paths. Other refugees were stretched out on the grass asleep, exhausted from their trip. ``There's no way back, no,'' said Mazrekaj's husband, Sulejman, 39, distraught from the shelling a day earlier. The Serb attacks appeared to have intensified over the weekend, judging by the stream of refugees that began Sunday morning to Albania. U.N. officials said 1,600 refugees had registered, but local Albanian officials said about 5,000 refugees had arrived, many refusing to register. ``The people keep coming,'' said Kris Janowski, spokesman for the U.N. refugee agency in Geneva. Communications with western Kosovo remained cut off. A monitor for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe who spoke on condition of anonymity said military action in the area around the border appeared to have declined. Serb authorities said militants fighting for independence had attacked police along a road in western Kosovo, killing one officer. The authorities also said they had broadcast radio appeals for residents of Decani and several villages to return. The residents were told their safety would be guaranteed as long as they didn't participate in ``terrorist activities.'' Ethnic Albanian leaders publicly acknowledged the existence of the Kosovo Liberation Army for the first time Tuesday, noting that the ``massive Serb aggression is meeting heavy resistance'' from the people and the KLA. Adem Demaqi, a prominent ethnic Albanian leader known as Kosovo's Nelson Mandela for the years he spent in Serbian prisons, appealed to the KLA to refrain from targeting innocent Serb civilians in retaliation for police brutality.

BC-FEA-Hungary-Dam Dilemma,0800
Danube dam project a monument to mismanagement, indecision
AP Photos NY180-182, Graphic DANUBE DAMS By ROLAND PRINZ Associated Press Writer
DUNAKILITI, Hungary (AP) _ The Dunakiliti dam towers over the Danube River on the Hungarian-Slovak border, but the huge structure sits dormant, and the water flow underneath is down to a trickle. It is a stark monument to political and environmental misjudgments that have produced one of Europe's longest-running environmental disputes. But despite Hungary's agreement to reconsider dropping out of a joint project to build a series of dams, the deal's future is as shaky as its checkered past. Finishing the originally envisioned project would cost the two eastern European countries hundreds of millions of dollars. Critics, including economists and environmental activists who have sponsored several protests against the project, say it makes no sense _ even if it were free. ``Hungary simply does not need the electricity this project would generate,'' said Laszlo Zsolnai, an economics professor at Budapest University. Need for the hydroelectric dams seemed clear when the idea was born more than two decades ago. Czechoslovakia and Hungary, then-communist neighbors, agreed in 1977 to build a system of dams on the Danube to produce more electricity and improve the river's commercial navigation by raising the water level. But with construction well under way, progress on the Dunakiliti dam was slowed when environmentalist opponents successfully tied their fight to the rising opposition to Hungary's communist regime. After communism collapsed throughout the region, Hungary withdrew from the project, citing its potential dangers to the environment. Washed away were dlrs 1 billion spent for planning, construction and subsequent demolition of foundations for a dam at Nagymaros on the scenic Danube bend 30 miles (50 kilometers) north of Budapest. The dormant Dunakiliti dam, 100 miles (160 kilometers) upstream, cost an additional dlrs 700 million in 1997 dollars, said Istvan Majer, head of Hungary's government-run Danube Program Bureau. Hungarian environmentalists celebrated, but it was a hollow victory. After Hungary's pullout, Slovakia built a substitute dam at Cunovo on Slovak territory, six miles 10 kilometers upstream from Dunakiliti. On Oct. 22, 1992, just over two months before its formal break from the Czech Republic, Slovakia shocked Hungarians by diverting the Danube along a 10-mile (15-kilometer) stretch, rerouting most of the river to feed a huge canal. Hungary's pullout and Slovakia's diversion, which has sharply reduced the water flow in the old riverbed, led both sides to turn to the World Court in The Hague, Netherlands. The court ruled against both, saying Hungary broke international law by bowing out of the dam project and Slovakia acted illegally by diverting the river. Last September, the two sides agreed to resolve the dispute within six months. But with that self-imposed deadline well past, no new pact seems imminent. Slovakia may go back to the World Court because Hungary, while initialing a framework agreement in February to restart the dam project, said it needs until year's end to conduct more feasibility studies. If a new contract is signed, one of the huge new expenditures Hungary will face is construction of a new dam at Pilismarot, just north of Nagymaros. One reason Hungary's outgoing government was considering resuming the project is Slovakia's experience with its own Danube dam. The view of the new coalition government taking office is still unclear. The Slovak canal destroyed 40 square kilometers (16 square miles) of wetlands and about 60 square kilometers (23 square miles) of other land were taken for a storage reservoir. Environmentalists had warned of far direr consequences for the environment, such as pollution of water supplies and far-reaching ecological damage. ``The worst didn't happen _ the predicted drying up of the wetland forest and the deterioration of the drinking water,'' said Slovak geologist Lajos Tuba. Tuba acknowledged that because of changed water levels, nature is having to adjust to new conditions and plant life is changing. About 60,000 Hungarians live in 19 villages and small towns in the affected Szigetkoes area along the Danube and many want all of the proposed dam system completed, including a large storage lake at their doorstep. Maria Tamas, who heads the regional government, said completion ``would be the foundation for further development of the region in agriculture, infrastructure and tourism.''

BC-Indonesia-Habibie Interview
Indonesia's new leader unconcerned about past corruption
JAKARTA, Indonesia (AP) _ New President B.J. Habibie has urged Indonesians not to dwell on the country's corrupt past under former leader Suharto, but to look forward to a promising future based on economic recovery and political reform. In a CNN interview broadcast Wednesday, Habibie did not specifically address allegations of corruption leveled against Suharto, concerns about Habibie's own extensive business interests, or accusations of abuses by the military. ``You have unlimited problems in the past. Where are you going to stop? Five years ago, 10 years, 20 years, 30 years, 40 years?'' he asked. ``The future is almost unlimited. ... So I think it is not worthwhile to dip into the past. I have to look to the future and create a better life...for the people.'' During the 30-minute interview, the first broadcast since Habibie was sworn in on May 21, he said his ``main mission'' as president is to fix Indonesia's ailing economy and to improve its democracy in the shortest amount of time possible. He said he wants to restore the self-confidence of Indonesians. Habibie, who took power when Suharto resigned following riots and protests last month, declined to say whether he would run for re-election after parliamentary elections are held next year. He said most of Indonesia's 202 million people are suffering badly from an inflation rate of more than 50 percent and soaring unemployment. He said that many don't care who is the president but instead worry about ``their rice bowls, their homes, to live in peace, the future for their children.'' Habibie, a civilian and Suharto's friend and former deputy, said he was confident the powerful military, which played a key role in Suharto's departure during the unrest, would maintain its support for him as it ``always follows the constitution.'' Critics have accused Suharto of allowing his family to amass fortunes and building massive business empires through nepotism and corruption during his 32 years in power. The government this week launched an broad probe into state corruption, but many want a specific investigation into Suharto's wealth, estimated at between dlrs 20 billion and 40 billion. Some want that money to be taken back by the state so it can use it to help fix the country's worst economic crisis in decades. Habibie, 61, has known Suharto since boyhood and was a Suharto Cabinet minister for 20 years. Despite this close links to the old government, Habibie said he had no problems bringing in reforms. Already he has promised the election and freed some political prisoners. He likened his newfound role as a reformer to that of leaders Boris Yeltsin in Russia and Zhu Rongji of China who brought sweeping reforms to their countries despite being part of old authoritarian regimes. Habibie said he had no option but to reform Indonesia's battered economy while introducing sweeping political change, saying both were interlinked. ``My role here is to bring in the shortest time possible the economy back and to improve the democracy,'' he said, adding that change must be made in accordance with the constitution. He estimated that the current Parliament will have drafted new electoral laws by August and that these would be enacted four months later. He said a new session of the People's Consultative Assembly, made up of lawmakers and government appointees, would then set a date for the election. After the ballot, the assembly could then choose a new president. At least 500 people and thousands of buildings and homes were damaged during riots in May. But despite simmering discontent over the economic crisis, Habibie played down the possibility of further violence on the streets. He said Indonesians wanted reform but not on the basis of ``destroying everything they have built in 30 years.'' He described the International Monetary Fund, which is now revamping a dlrs 43 billion economic bailout package for Indonesia, as playing an important and supportive role. He also praised a team of economic ministers in his Cabinet, saying: ``They are the best sons and daughters of the country.'' One issue that Habibie indicated would change was the fate of East Timor, the former Portuguese territory invaded by Suharto troops in 1975 and annexed a year later. Habibie said East Timor must remain an integral part of Indonesia.

Dodgers no longer pursuing Randy Johnson AP Sports Writer
By JOHN NADEL
LOS ANGELES (AP) _ Randy Johnson is not coming to Los Angeles, at least right now. Dodgers general manager Fred Claire told reporters before Tuesday night's game against the St. Louis Cardinals that the team is no longer talking with the Seattle Mariners about acquiring left-hander Randy Johnson. ``This team is no longer in pursuit of Randy Johnson,'' Claire said firmly. ``It ended at 12 noon today, from our standpoint.'' Shortly after Claire's announcement, Seattle president Chuck Armstrong issued a statement saying the Mariners won't trade Johnson this season. ``Randy Johnson is a valued pitcher for the Mariners who is under contract for the balance of the 1998 season,'' Armstrong said. ``Randy will pitch for the Mariners throughout this season. Accordingly, we have no plans to trade Randy Johnson.'' Claire didn't totally close the door, but said the only trade he would now pursue was one involving right-hander Hideo Nomo, whom the Dodgers designated for assignment on Monday. ``I would hope we should be able to move quickly,'' Claire said. ``Clearly, the sooner the better for Hideo.'' Claire said the Dodgers made a trade proposal to the Mariners ``before noon Monday,'' and gave Seattle general manager Woody Woodward 24 hours to respond. When noon came and went Tuesday, Claire said he faxed Woodward a letter saying the proposal was being taken off the table, but to contact him by 4 p.m. if he had any thoughts. Claire heard nothing, and then held a team meeting around 5:45 p.m. to tell them there would be no deal for Johnson, that he had confidence in them and it was time to move on. In that deal, catcher Mike Piazza and third baseman Todd Zeile went to the Marlins for outfielders Gary Sheffield and Jim Eisenreich, third baseman Bobby Bonilla, catcher Charles Johnson and a minor league pitcher. The Dodgers have until June 11 to trade Nomo, send him to the minor leagues or release him. Nomo, 29, could opt to become a free agent if assigned to the minors as a fourth-year big-leaguer. If he does, he would forfeit the remainder of his 1998 salary from the Dodgers.

BC-Sports-Ice Hockey-NHL Playoff Roundup,0484
Sabres down Capitals to avoid elimination
WASHINGTON (AP) _ Dominik Hasek made 34 saves, survived numerous deflections, a disallowed goal and another that was not allowed after a video review as the the Buffalo Sabres beat the Washington Capitals 2-1 to close the best-of-7 Eastern Conference finals to 3-2 and force a Game 6 Thursday night in Buffalo. Buffalo is attempting to become the first National Hockey League team to overcome a 3-1 series deficit to win a conference finals. The Sabres were outshot 35-16 as the Capitals controlled the game with vicious forechecking, but Buffalo's shot No. 14 _ a superb individual effort by former Caps defenseman Jason Woolley _ found the net with 4:26 remaining. It was only the second third-period goal the Sabres have scored all series. With the Capitals on a line change, Woolley started at his own blue line and skated untouched between the Washington defenseman and put the puck between goaltender Olaf Kolzig's legs. The shot silenced the MCI Center's boisterous sellout crowd, which was hoping to witness the biggest victory in the history of the Capitals franchise. But the game belonged to Hasek, who put the words ``Swiss cheese'' on his shirt after allowing a soft goal in Saturday's 2-0 loss in Game 4. Among his heroic moments Tuesday: He pinned the puck against the right post to stop Adam Oates with 10:49 to play _ a no-goal verified by the replay official _ and snatched Richard Zednik's attempt out of mid-air with 7:55 left. Then there was Bondra, who had a chance to give the Caps the lead with 12:30 to play on his second short-handed breakaway of the night, but he keep the puck low _ where Hasek is at his best _ and the goalie stopped the shot with his right pad. The save came shortly after Hasek was knocked to the ice in a collision with Brian Bellows. Hasek lay on the ice for about a minute before play resumed. The Sabres played 6:30 before taking their first shot of the game, but they scored on their second one just three seconds later on defenseman Darryl Shannon's slapshot from beyond the right circle. Kolzig, screened on the play, barely moved a muscle as the puck went between his legs. It was Shannon's second goal of the playoffs, one less than he had during the regular season. Oates appeared to get the Caps on the board two minutes later when he doggedly stuffed the puck over Hasek's leg on a wraparound, but referee Terry Gregson's whistle had blown the play dead. The tying goal that counted came at the 16:29 mark on Andrei Nikolishin's first career playoff score, a close-range one-timer on a power play. All four Buffalo penalty-killers were caught on the same side of the ice, leaving Nikolishin alone as he received an apparently deflected pass from Zednik.

BC-Australia-Economy
Australian economy growing despite Asian crisis
CANBERRA, Australia (AP) _ Australia's economy surprised analysts by steaming ahead in the first three months of 1998 at an annual growth rate of almost 5 percent despite the crisis in Asia. The latest snapshot of the economy released Wednesday by the Australian Bureau of Statistics revealed gross domestic product rising by a seasonally adjusted 1.3 percent in the quarter ended March, for annual growth of 4.9 percent. Economists had been divided about the effects of Asia's economic meltdown on Australia's growth, with some expecting signs of an economic slowdown to appear in Wednesday's figures while others predicted a final burst of growth ahead of a more dramatic slowing later this year. The average expectation was for a 0.5 percent increase in the quarter, with predictions ranging between 0.2 and 0.6 percent. In the previous quarter, Australia's gross domestic product expanded at a revised rate of 0.7 percent, or an annual growth rate of 3.8 percent.

BC-Sports-Cycling-First Union,0326
Andreu wins Lancaster Invitational road race
LANCASTER, Pennsylvania (AP) _ Veteran U.S. professional cyclist Frankie Andreu sprinted away from two other riders with a little over a mile (two kilometers) to go Tuesday and won the 91-mile (146 kilometers) Lancaster Invitational road race, the first event in the First Union Cycling series. The U.S. Postal Cycling Team rider made his winning move in the last lap of the 13-lap event, getting the edge on breakaway teammate Lance Armstrong and Cezary Zemana of Poland. ``I just had to attack. It was decided earlier in the race that if I had a chance, I would go for the win,'' Andreu said. Andreu, 31, and Zemana, 30, initiated a key breakaway about 63 miles (101 kilometers) into the race, building a gap from six riders who were off the front but were being caught by a chase group of 10 riders. The group of three then built a steady lead of up to one minute and four seconds over the field that was quickly breaking into smaller groups. A field of 143 riders started the race with 43 finishing. The race, part of the Tour of America, had a total purse of dlrs 15,500, with dlrs 2,500 going to first place. The series, which concludes Sunday with the U.S. Pro Championship in Philadelphia, goes to Wilmington, Delaware, on Wednesday, then to Trenton, New Jersey, on Thursday. Armstrong, 26, of the United States, said he was glad to see Andreu win. ``You don't see him win very much. It was gratifying for me,'' said Armstrong, who is continuing his return to competition after being diagnosed with testicular cancer in October 1996. Andreu's victory was his first in the United States since 1995, when he won a stage of the West Virginia Kmart Classic. In Europe, he won a stage of the Mount Bretagne race. ``I'm putting more emphasis on U.S. races this year and want to prove myself in America,'' Andreu said.

BC-China-Railways
Construction on Beijing-Shanghai bullet train to start in 2000
BEIJING (AP) _ Construction of a dlrs 12 billion high-speed railway line between Beijing and Shanghai will begin in 2000, the state-run China Daily reported Wednesday. Trains will be able to travel up to 300 kilometers (180 miles) per hour along the 1,300-kilometer (800-mile) rail line, the newspaper said. Initial designs have been completed although no decision has been made where to start construction, the newspaper quoted Shen Zhijie, the Ministry of Railways official overseeing feasibility studies for the project, as saying. Shen noted that foreign funds would be required to complete the project but the method of foreign participation has not been determined.

BC-Latin America-Violence,0337
International Development Bank promoting fight against violence
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador (AP) _ The International Development Bank is urging Latin American leaders to fervently fight the violence plaguing much of the region in order to strengthen their economies. ``Violence is not a biblical curse,'' bank president Enrique Iglesias said at the start of a meeting on public security. ``Violence is not only repugnant to all civilized society but an excess that cannot be permitted in Latin America.'' Bank experts estimate that violence costs Latin America nations at least dlrs 15 billion annually. In 1996, there were 140,000 homicides in Latin America, a rate of 30 deaths for every 100,000 people which is the highest for any region in the world, Iglesias said. ``We are in the presence of a special theme that has major social, political and economic repercussions,'' he said. A recent study by the University of Central America showed that in 1995, violence cost El Salvador dlrs 777 million _ or 13 percent of the gross national product. El Salvador's President Armando Calderon said Monday that the country's crime problem has been one of the major headaches of his administration. El Salvador suffers a homicide rate of more than 100 killings per 100,000 citizens. Colombia, long considered the most violent nations in Latin America, had a homicide rate of 81 per 100,000 in 1996, the latest figures available. The International Development Bank already has extended credit to Colombia and Uruguay to help fight violence. ``We are proud to serve not only as a credit agency but as a source of social promotion, Iglesias said. ``In the last few years we have dedicated more than half of our resources to fight poverty and the social problems that stem from it.'' More than 500 regional leaders and international experts are attending the session, including representatives from across the Americas and Europe.

BC-Sports-Baseball-NL Roundup,0623
Martinez ties Marichal as winningest Latin pitcher as Braves beat Brewers 9-0
MILWAUKEE (AP) _ Dennis Martinez tied Juan Marichal as the winningest Latin American pitcher in baseball history Tuesday night, scattering 12 hits in a shutout as the Atlanta Braves defeated the Milwaukee Brewers 9-0. Andres Galarraga homered twice and Andruw Jones homered and hit two triples for Atlanta. With both teams wearing baggy replica uniforms from the 1950s, the 43-year-old Martinez (2-2) got his 243rd victory by going the distance for the first time since May 26, 1996. The right-hander walked one and struck out three in his 30th career shutout and 122nd complete game. On two occasions earlier this season, Martinez, who is from Nicaragua, was within a few outs of tying Marichal's mark only to have the Braves' bullpen blow victories. He wasn't going to come out of this one, however, even when the Brewers got a runner to third in the ninth. After getting pinch-hitter Bobby Hughes to ground to short for the final out, Martinez shared hugs and handshakes with teammates. In a 22-year career with Baltimore, Montreal, Cleveland, Seattle and Atlanta, Martinez has a 243-189 record. The four-time All-Star pitched a perfect game for the Expos in 1991 against Los Angeles. Marichal, a native of the Dominican Republic, posted a 243-142 record in 16 seasons from 1960-1975, winning 238 games during 14 years with San Francisco. Paul Wagner (1-4) took the loss. Expos 4, Phillies 3 In Philadelphia, Carl Pavano pitched 7 1-3 strong innings to get his first major-league win as Montreal snapped a three-game losing streak. Pavano (1-0), a highly-touted right-hander obtained by Montreal in the trade that sent Pedro Martinez to Boston in November, allowed three runs and four hits in only his third major-league start. The Phillies stranded the tying run on third in the ninth when Ugueth Urbina got Alex Arias to hit a foul pop to first baseman Brad Fullmer. Urbina pitched the ninth for his 13th save as the Expos won for only the seventh time in 20 road games. Despite pitching his fifth complete game of the season, Curt Schilling (5-6) lost his third straight decision. Pirates 5, Mets 2 In Pittsburgh, Kevin Young hit a tiebreaking three-run triple to finally make Chris Peters a winner over the Mets, and Pittsburgh overcame an evening of violent weather to beat New York. The Pirates have won a season-high four straight. Peters (1-3) allowed two runs on four hits over five innings to end a career-long five-game losing streak against the Mets. Brian Bohanon (2-2) took the loss, surrendering four runs on five hits over three innings after starter Masato Yoshii didn't return following a 58-minute rain delay. The storm was accompanied by brilliant lightning and funnel clouds that approached the stadium, only to veer away. Before the game, another funnel cloud touched down on Mount Washington overlooking the stadium, ripping the roofs off about a dozen houses and dropping hail and rain on the stadium. Cubs 2, Marlins 1 In Chicago, pinch-hitter Jason Hardtke singled home the winning run in the ninth as Florida dropped its seventh straight. Mickey Morandini reached on an infield single off Felix Heredia (0-3) with one out and advanced on a balk. Sammy Sosa then hit a ball between Heredia's legs for an infield hit, and Mark Grace was walked intentionally to load the bases. Jay Powell relieved and Hardtke, batting for Terrell Lowery, hit a soft fly ball into the gap in left center, giving Chicago its fifth consecutive victory. Terry Adams (4-3) pitched one hitless inning. MORE
